reviews.review: Beautiful Views. The climb to the castle is pretty steep, but there are a ton of places to stop along the way! The views and photo ops are perfect! You get a whole different view of the city! Definitely recommend!

A hike, but impressive. The best way to get to the castle would be to hire a buggy. The trams are overcrowded and walking (from experience) although manageable, is fairly steep and difficult. Take your time and set aside a full day for a castle visit, you'll need your walking legs on you. The view and the castle itself once you arrive however are spectacular, a must see if you like your castles

History & Views. We visited the Castelo after walking from the cruise terminal. This is not for the faint hearted. The walk is steep and the cobbled stones are slippery under foot. In hindsight I would suggest taking a tuk tuk right from the harbour side.The entrance fee is €8.50 for adults and the opening times are 9am - 9pm March - October and 9am - 6pm November - February.There are toilets and a restaurant on site as well as a shop. The views are fantastic and there is an archaeological site dating back to the 7th century to view. A quick hint about the loos - ladies take tissues. There wasn't any toilet paper in any of the loos.There are many viewpoints located on the top of the ridge looking over Lisbon. Beware of the paving in the Castelo as we saw many people falling and stumbling. Two of our group came a cropper.
Ok. One of most must see in Lisbon,outstanding view-agree but there's few more points where payment isn't required

Lovely spot on top. We were staying in a quaint apartment right near the castle. It offers some great views, archaeology and a lovely walk. Entrance fee is reasonable and it's open till late at night.

Beautiful Views - Amazing Birds. We walked from the Praca da Comerico to the castle entrance. It is a challenging walk because of the uphill and winding streets. We enjoyed it nonetheless. The views along the top walls are quite wonderful. Some of the upper walkways will be tough for those with height issues - or are uncomfortable with tight walkways. We took several family photos while standing on the walls that overlook the city - these turned out great. The walk around the castle and grounds is relaxed and should be done at a slow pace because of the uneven cobble. There are restaurants in the castle but we did not use them. The bathrooms are a little hidden; they are free and quite nice. The birds look like peacocks but we were not sure. They hide in the tree next to bathrooms. The Tuk-Tuks will take you up and make sure and negotiate the price. We did not do this, but we took a private tour one day and the guide said to negotiate the price.
Lisbon from the Sky. We spent a very pleasant couple of hours here, great views of Lisbon, and other streets to explore. Went up by Yellow tram, very quaint !

Great views, well preserved castle. Walk up from the shore, zig zagging through the lovely cobblestone roads. On arrival the views alone were worth the effort. The lead up to the castle proper exposed 360 degree views across the whole of Lisbon which is a site to behold. The castle itself is well maintained and allowed further views. To walk requires a degree of fitness and good shoes as the cobblestones can be a bit slippy. There is a good selection of food and drink sellers going up the hill and several within the castle area. All round a good visit. It appears to be a good location to site, read or chill.
Tourist. Even though if was a damp day we loved itSo interesting Wonderful views of the Lisbon areaGreat stairs up and down Not so sure about small kids safer on a rein

Great attraction - lots of nooks and walls. Beware the steep climb up (which I rather enjoyed, but took its toll on my quads!). They say it looks closer than it is and they're right. But worth it. Ancient relic - old castle with amazing views inside and out. Not very crowded on a Sunday in October. And not expensive either!
Beautiful and well kept. Our most favorite attraction in Lisbon! Beautiful grounds and amazing views of the city. Highly recommended!

Excellent start to our holiday. Walked up to the castle on the first day of our stay in Lisbon and it was a great way to start our visit. We had planned to catch the tram but the queues were too long, so we took a steady walk up various steps and along narrow streets to the top. It was well worth the effort as the panoramic views helped us to get an overview of the city. We enjoyed a coffee on the terrace outside the cafe, a stroll round the castle and a visit to the camera obscura. Finally we enjoyed a visit to the small but interesting exhibition telling the history of the area, with archaeological artefacts. We then enjoyed a stroll back down through the winding streets of Alfama.

Great views of Lisbon. A lovely way to spend a few hours with incredible views of Lisbon below. We walked up from the centre and although it is a steep walk, it is not that far, and stopping for a drink on the way was perfect. The castle is big enough to accommodate the large numbers of visitors without feeling too busy. We enjoyed our morning there.
Great view!!!. This castle is worth the Visit for the view alone. Great half day spent in the castle.8euros gets you access to the full site and park around the castle.
You can see many parts of Lisbon. Nice view from the top of the Castle towers. You can walk around the castle and see the different parts of Lisbon.

A fabulous visit and a must while in Lisbon. You can easily spend hours visiting this fabulous place. There are amazing views from many vintage points and a lot to cover. The grounds surrounding the castle are also very pretty and a delight to walk around. We truly enjoyed our visit, took our time to savor every nook and crannies and had a wonderful and excellent lunch at Casa de Leao located on the esplanade, with great views of the city. A wonderful visit and a must-see while in Lisbon!

Well Preserved with fabulous views of Lisbon. I visited the castle with my partner. The castle was lovely and well preserved. You can walk along the parapets all the way around which offers fabulous views of Lisbon. There are peacocks in the grounds near the cafe which were a good tourist attraction. Unfortunately their tail feathers have been cropped. The facilities could do with repairing the lock to the toilet was broken. The museum was small but nice to walk around. It was disappointing that we couldn't access the archeological site as there seemed to be a car park in the way. Altogether a nice attraction and a lovely walk up through the old town to get to the castle.
A must in Lisbon. Amazing views over Lisbon. Takes about 3 hrs to take in all the views and history. Get there early to avoid the queue's

Well Preserved Magnificent Fortress with Commanding Views. This fortress is a must when visiting Lisbon. It soars above the city as it has for hundreds of years. The castle grounds are beautiful with many breathtaking vistas of the old city. The original Moorish Castle and moat are within these walls and if you climb to the top of the castle towers the views are tremendous. It's also worth some time to explore the narrow streets outside the fortress walls for this is the oldest part of Lisbon. The walk up to the castle gates is demanding but you can take a tram or tuk tuk for a reasonable price.

The best view over Lisbon, in a wonderful historical landmark. Well preserved castle, highly relevant in Portugal's history! An amazing and unique perspective over the city and the river. Enjoy the visit to the castle and its surrounding neighborhood.

Really expensive. It has a nice view of the town, but it is really expensive for what it is. Basically, you pay to see walls and that's it. Most of the areas are outside, so it is not a good option for a raining day.

Best views of the city of LIsbon. This castle dating from the 12th century was the initial retreat of the first Christians. Today tourists flock to the castle, although obviously not much of the original structure remains. Nevertheless the old walls and fortifications are impressive (and beautifully neat and tidy) and the views of the city and the river fantastic. Added to this it is pure pleasure to stroll through the tiny streets of Alfama to reach the entrance.

Stunning views over Lisbon. The São Jorge castle is definitely worth a visit. Just like any other castle, it is a stronghold situated in a higher position. In a sunny day, one can easily see the Tagus river southbank, the Tagus bridge, the Cristo-Rei statue, the Praça do Comércio. Once up there, try to close your eyes and imagine the cruzaders camps in the opposite hills waiting for their best chance to conquer the castle as they did in 1147. For a good description about what happened in those days, look for the book Charles Wendell David, De Expugnatione Lyxbonensi: The Conquest of Lisbon edited from the unique Manuscript in Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, with a Translation into English, Nova Iorque, Columbia University Press, 1936.
Amazing medieval castle overlooking Lisbon.. If you love history, visit the castle. Wonderful views of the city, and the castle area of the Alfama is fascinating.

Nice view and interesting historie. On top of the hill, a big climb. The ancient castle is impressive. Although it's more or less only the walls, it's view is impressive. The camera obscura is fun to see how you can view the surrounding of the castle projected on a big wooden circle. The camera obscura is a show of 15 minutes and only 20 people are allowed inside at a time.

Actually there are more sources of information than other reviews have complained about. At 1 PM there is a free tour in English by museum staff. Our guide was quite knowledgeable and enthusiastic. She noted that there had been much reconstruction after the 1755 earthquake and also in the 20th century under the dictator Salazar. You can pickup a multi-page booklet in the ticket office. There is a museum of artifacts (neolithic onwards) excavated from the site. You can also visit the excavation.Since I have arthritis, we took the #12 tram up.

A typical castle of the period.. Worth the walk up for the views over Lisbon, beautiful setting with the River and roof tops of Lisbon laid out below. It was a beautiful sunny day when we visited and we just sat by the parapet and watched Lisbon below us.

Best views of Lisbon . The walk up is quite worth the trip. Wandering through the neighborhoods there are a variety of shops and restaurants offering places to take a break. Once up to the top the panoramic views from the castle walls offer great photo ops. A must see if you are planning to visit this city.

Beautiful views. The castle is at the top of a big hill but the walk up is really nice and the views are amazing. We paid 8.50 per person which was not very cheap but still ok. It's a nice activity for an hour or two and you can get a glass of wine or an ice cream up there.A must see if you're doing a weekend in lisbon.
Stunning views! . Beautiful castle with absolutely stunning views over Lisbon. Worth the €8.50 entry fee! Some lovely little shops/cafes on the streets around it too.

You have to see Lisbon from the Castelo !!. You experience the history of Lisbon from this amazing vantage point overlooking the city. Since the early days of Lisbon this easily defended site has dominated the city and been the site of various conquerors over time .Accordingly the structure has ancient, Moorish , Crusader, Spanish and Portugese elements.Getting there is half the fun, either by streetcar up steep and narrow roads or a wild cab ride following a streetcar.Wonderful half day excursion

Great Attraction with a Poor Experience. The castle and the site are pretty nice and impressive. Although, the experience is really poor. All the site has no signage system. No one is available to ask or get information from. This beautiful place with amazing views of the city is not well managed!

Captivating views from an amazing vantage point overlooking Lisbon. From the exquisite entry to the crenelated walkways, the indoor museum to the outdoor breathtaking views, this, the Castelo de Sao Jorge is a must see attraction.Take your time and savour the details, there is much to see and appreciate. For the most part it is easily accessible with some crowding on the stairs to the ramparts being the only congestion points.A detailed history of the castle and Lisbon is clear, relevant, plentiful and available in both Portuguese and English.Remember to take in the views at the entrance before leaving, the impulse is to dive straight into the site itself and miss one of the breathtaking elements.
Spectacular city view . It's a bit of a hike up to castle and can get slippery so would recommend good shoes! Great views of city

Great views of the city.. This is one of the best places from which to view the whole of Lisbon.It was very busy whilst we were there. The camera obscura only takes 20 people at a time and alternates between Spanish, Portuguese and English commentaries. The queues were long.There is a good cafe inside and many peacocks. If you do not want to pay to.enter there are other good viewpoints in the city.
Beautiful castel. Good access to lovely old castle. Great view over Lisbon. Great small museum with lots of information about the castle and Lisbon through the ages.

Yep, its a gorgeous Castle. This was viewable from my hotel room. So off we went to see this piece of Portuguese history. This was my first Castle I was able to see in person and was not disappointed. You have to see the spectacular views of and from this place..
Old fort worth the visit. We spent a whole afternoon at the castle. We chanced on a tour of the archeological site. The tour was interesting.

Well worth the walk up!. I made the long walk up from barrio alto and was glad I did when I was met with the well preserved structure of this Lisbon castle. It's located up high in a nice part of town and offers visitors a great view over the city down below. The site itself is not huge but you can see away 90mins or so here and be able to take it in while learning about its history. I brought my lunch with me and was able to enjoy the scenic view while making use of the shade on offer and the cooling breeze on a hot day. The structure is well preserved and you can make your way around the site while imaging what it would have been like in its heyday. There are small plaques with information as you make your way around but I feel these could have offered up more detailed information for those that would like it such as myself. The grounds around the castle are nice and are likely to take up more of your time as written above.
Nice views of Lisbon. Great views of Lisbon; has a few cafe's to enjoy a drink with a nice view; worthwhile to visit; well maintained

A Castle with a view!. Built on top of one of the cities highest hill, this castle is a "MUST" to visit as the views all round are amazing. Walking round the battlements gives 360 degree views well worth the time and effort in getting to it. Very well preserved, complete with ongoing restoration work, a nice cafe, and even peacocks screeching away.Too hilly to walk from the centre of the city, get a tram or, if you are a daredevil, a tuktuk; walking back down is OK, stop at the Casa Madeira for a drink on the way.

Portuguese inefficiency spoiled it. Commanding views reward the struggle up there - whereupon we were not allowed to enter, having come to the wrong entrance. No signs to direct us correctly and a charming multilingual security chap to redirect us. When the locals catch on to the idea of helping their visitors to get it right first time they will probably be more warmly regarded. As it is, years of living off UK VAT seems to have dulled their sense of public service. Like the public sector in other southern states, they act as if the reason for their employment is to collect nice salaries in complete security with gold-plated pensions to top off a life of ease. (Yes, I am jealous.)
Beautiful place with amazing views!. I love castles & ruins, so this was right up my alley. An added bonus was the views of the city! There were peacocks everywhere, so that was neat to see.

Gorgeous!. My judgment is clouded because I love the Middle Ages and all kind of castles, but I can say, this is really worth a visit! Even just for the stunning 360 ° views you will have of Lisbon and the bridge on April 25th, the Cristo Rei, the Vasco da Gama bridge and the entire city center.Very well preserved, of course you should come in a sunny day. Do not miss it!
Great view over the city. The view is great from all directions. Many stairs inside. Many small and cute stores heading to the castel.

If you love medieval castels, don't miss this one!. San Jorge is a moorish castle, built with solid fortifications on top of one of Lisbon's highest hills. The castle does not hold anything inside, yet the astonishing architecture and amazing view of the city are enough reason to go visit it. If you're traveling with friends, my advice is to take a bottle of wine and enjoy a glass once you get on top. You can still do so, as there is some service there, but it can be pricey. Don't forget your camera but don't plan going there by car unless you have a local friend driving. The streets are very narrow and it's easier to take the tram right next to the underground station. Not advisable for people who can't stand heights or who have to restrict physical effort. It does take some climbing and once you get there, you will need to climb the walls of the castle as well to get the nice view.

Great Views over Lisbon. It's a long walk up to the castle but well worth it. The views out over Lisbon are fantastic. The castle itself is interesting to walk around. There is even a lovely snack bar complete with Peacocks walking around the tables! There are a lot of steps but you don't have to go up them all to see the great views. A visit is very highly recommended.

Well preserved with great view. Castell de San Jorge is on top of one of the mountains surrounding Lisbon. Entrance fee €8.50 . We visited late afternoon.The castle is very well preserved fortress that has a spectacular view of Lisbon It is mostly exterior War good shoes as it has uneven floor of cobblestone and steep steps .

Loved it - fantastic views. A must visit for everyone who visits Lisbon, and great value for money. You will get a fantastic view of the City, a great walk around the castle and after a bite to eat. I would recommend it to anyone.

Great views . Wonderful history here and super cool to walk the high walls of the castelo. The views of Lisbon from up here are gorgeous you can make some nice photos up here We saw some men doing a reenactment they wore vintage uniforms and even shot a cannon. Wish we had know more details of this reenactment, still fun to see.I bet sunsets are beautiful from up there
nothing to see. we had to climb so high. then there was nothing inside. The ticket is costly. except the view of the sea and the city there is really nothing much.

Fantastic views that make it worth the hike . This isn't meant for anyone unwilling to walk and climb. Even if you get to the castle gate you won't see much once you're inside if you aren't up for a climb. The views are astounding the only part I was not okay with was the lack of information - there's not enough. Otherwise it was totally worth it, they have an excellent restaurant that overlooks the city.

the VERY BEST views of Lisbon. By visiting this sight you will get the very best views of the complete city of Lisbon. This is why most people visit. There is an 8 Euro charge per person. Bring your camera!

good views slightly chaotic. You can walk up to the Castle if ready for it or catch any of the trams right up to the top or again use the two elevator buildings to take out some of the strain in the walk, do it as the views are worth it.Inside the Castle once you have amazing views and a lot of great building work to look at, if you have been in some of the 'restored' castles around Europe you will love an authentic historical gem.On a Saturday in the morning there is even a Flea Market behind the castle and at Mosteiro de sao Vicente see images

Super visit. There isn't much more to say about this site other than it was one of our favourite places with a commanding view of Lisboa. The castle with moat is so worth while to wander on the ramparts; the archaeological area a little less so. The gift shop is small but good. One thing that was a treat to see was the large drawing of the old town by the permanent exhibition building.Being here was worth the price of admission. So much history.

Excellent attraction. A really well maintained castle, with real character and good facilities. Worth a trip.The only criticism was the lack of organisation to queue for tickets but that wasn't too much of an issue.

Great Views and Excellent Work out. We caught the 28 tram up to the Castle and walked back in to town. The views from all sides of the castle are spectacular. Many many stairs so sensible shoes are a must.

See the whole of downtown Lisbon and river in the shades of the pine trees on the top of a Hill. Walk all the way up from donwtown lisbon, through narrow alleys and old houses. Enter the castle through the main door and you'll see one of the best views of Lisbon: the downtown, Rossio, Av, Liberdade, Tagus River, The bridge, best for sun set spot.
A must see. Its quite a climb but the view of the city is espectacular The castle in itself is not much... worth the climb
nice castle. nice castle with great views of the citycute streets surrounding with many gift shopscan ride the tram to the castle
Fantastic views. One of the loveliest castles we have visited. Huge piazza shaded by trees, from which you can see most of Lisbon. Not as hard to climb up to as it looks from below.
nice castle. nice castle and grounds. Some great views. Some nice enough artifacts. Large area to wander around in.
Castle ok but view over city great. Castle is mainly ruins but you can walk the ramparts,.the medieval walls were rebuilt in 1938, you do get good views of Lisbon from the walls and gardens.

Must see. Very interesting castle, lots to see good wee museum and the views you get from the 11 (I think) turrets are well worth the steps you have to ascend .not good for wheel chair users or prams also nice restaurantd and café..

Nice place. The place is very nice.
It a shame that there is no public
Transportation to get to Castelo.
For eĺderĺy people it is very hard to get
To the top.

The castle with amazing views. Well where do I start. Probably from the most important part - the view. Yes, you can get some beautiful pictures with the view to the bridge and Baxia neighbourhood (not sure if the name is correct). The castle itself is pretty simple. Don't get me wrong, it has it historical value, what I am trying to say is, there are not exhibitions with any historical items or any inside rooms you can enter to get the touch of history. There are walls and towers, which once again allow you to get another angle for the view on the city, but that's basically it. Yet I still enjoyed the visit. So you can think before spending money. There are plenty of places in Lisboa with free panoramic views, which also have the view on the above mentioned castle. The choice is yours. I have been there and liked it. However not sure if I can recommend it to everyone.

No 1 Lisbon tourist attraction. The Castelo de Sao Jorge is a ‘must’ for any visitor to Lisbon. It is the most impressive of the city’s monuments. I cannot imagine any visitor not going there. It is a thoroughly enjoyable experience. The views from the ramparts are magnificent. The gardens are peaceful. The entrance cost is a mere €8.50 Adults; €5 Seniors; children under 10 go free. Allow yourself at least two hours to go around it. The Castelo comprises both the ancient castle and the later ruins of the former royal palace. The greatest fun is to climb around on the battlements. The Castelo was built by the Moors in the mid-11th century. After the Moors were driven out of Portugal in 1147 it became the residence of the kings of Portugal, who transformed the Castelo into a royal palace in the 13th century. The Castelo continued to play a major part in Portuguese history over the next three or four centuries. However, its purpose became primarily military when it ceased to be a royal residence, and the King moved, in 1511, to a lavish new palace elsewhere in Lisbon. Much of the Castelo was destroyed in the 1755 earthquake. During the 19th century the military constructed various installations within the walls which eventually hid the entire monument area, obliterating the older ruins. The Castelo’s historical importance was only recognised at the beginning of the 20th century when it was declared a national monument. Major restoration work was carried out in the late 1930s -40 when the newer buildings were demolished in order to reveal the old castle. The Castelo then became a national monument open to the general public. In fairness, much of what we see today is not really authentic but this does not distract from the fact that it does feel genuine.There is a permanent exhibition where visitors can learn about the history of the Castelo and past lifestyles. There is also an archaeological site which shows three significant periods in the history of Lisbon: pre-history (BC); the Moorish era; and the ruins of the last palace residence, which was destroyed in the 1755 earthquake. There is also a camera obscura. Entrance is free and at set times – every 20 minutes. A system of lenses projects a 360 degree view of the city. All is explained by a guide. There sessions in a number of languages, including English You may have to wait for the English session. Although the castle is terrific, it would be improved by a visitors’ centre with more information, artefacts and hands-on gadgets for the kids. Warning: There is less attention paid to health and safety in Portugal than in the UK. In the UK there would be rails on the battlements.Tip: This is the most popular attraction in Lisbon. Go early to avoid the queues.

Paying for the views. You are merely paying for the views on top of the castle. The castle itself isn't overly special. It is a big area and you can see every direction around Lisbon. Personally, I think the price is a bit of a rip off. In comparison to all other tourist attractions, this is the most expensive.

Excellent views and reasonable entry fee.. Well worth a visit. The views over the city are worth it. Can walk the majority of the wall around the castle. We also ate at the outdoor restaurant, the food was good (if nothing special) and what better location/view could you have for lunch. Considering the latter points it was not overpriced. Lots of space in the castle grounds and not overcrowded.

Unrealised potential. The castle is now mostly just a ruin. I love visiting ruined buildings but I really feel that this place would benefit from some more work being put into it. More information about the history of the place available in different places around the ruin, more to look at and read and learn.

Beautiful views. Its a fairly strenuous walk (we could have got a tram most of the way) but My gosh it is worth it. The views are absolutely spectacular! There are a plethora of little shops and cafes around here that are pretty awesome as well.

Go for the views. Lots of steps up to the walls (not much left of the castle)where you get a 360 degree view of Lisbon.
Rather steep to walk up the castle and could be a problem if you have mobility issues.
Worth it for the views and to get your bearings of Lisbon.

Castelo Sao Jorge. A hike of 25 minutes uphill through Alfama from Rossio to the castelo, where for 8.5 euros you have a self-guided tour of the restored castle. Spectacular views of the Tagus River and most of Lisbon. Get there early. The crowds are big by 11:30 in the morning. The grounds are pretty, with peacocks wandering around and multiple gardens but the castle itself is so so. The stair climbs could be too much for some people as the steps are narrow, uneven, and slippery in spots. Navigating in both directions ( up and down the ramparts for example ) is almost impossible for all but the most slim! That being said, the walk to the castle through the old neighborhoods with narrow streets and laundry hanging from the windows, is lovely. There are old churches, little cafes, shops and more to experience along the way.

Good view over the city. The castle itself is not unique or the best in the world but it's situated on a hill in the centre of Lisbon. The view over the city makes it worth a visit. There's also a nice terrace to enjoy a glass of wine overlooking the old town and the river.

The best views of Lisbon are right here. Although bit of a steep walk to get to, this is most certainly worth it. You can see the whole city in all it's glory. The views are tremendous and I myself could sit there quite happily all day looking out to them.This is also ideal for history buffs as there is a lot to be seen and read inside the castle itself.

Only walls!! . The area has been used 7,000 BC.Originally Temples of worship , later built into a fortress by the Romans and then the Moores. Nice walking on top of the walls and taking fotos of the different views of Lisbon.Has a restaurant and very small archeology museum.The real fun is walking down through the old 15th century Jewish area called Alfama filled with small cozy restaurant playing Fado music.

Traveling Portugal 2016. PRO'S: This is a high viewing spot above the center of downtown. The fort has lots of battlements to climb around and observe the city below. The camera obscura view of the city inside the castle is fun but entirely in Spanish. CON'S: Entering the castle requires lots of up hill steps to the entrance. The castle map is a poor reference and there are very few signs inside the castle SUMMARY: If you are here for a week this castle is worth seeing but is not a must-see site.

Sao Jorge Castle. If you have the privilege of staying in Lisbon, visiting Sao Jorge Castle is a must. The views are absolutely stunning, as is the opportunity of sharing an ice cold beer if you've been walking up the steep incline through the Alfama region to arrive at the castle. You won't regret it!

The perfect spot from which to understand the geography of Lisbon. A total must when in Lisbon, the history, the views and the atmosphere are wonderful. Step walk up but lots of ways to get there using transport. Great to go there as soon as you arrive in Lisbon as it can help you understand the city better.

Worth a trip, but average as castles go. If you haven't seen castles in Europe before, I highly recommend it. If you have, it's still a nice visit with very nice views from just below the castle, but the castle itself is less impressive than others I've seen, specifically in regards to the interior.

A lot of old stones, stunning views of the city. Well, you must read the many signs available to get a good picture of how the Castle used to be and its purposes. The white limestone is beautiful against the blue of the sky and the green of the trees, olive trees, orange trees, hibiscus trees... but what I found really amazing were the views. Nearly 360° (180+ 180) of the city. Certainly a great place to view the Tejo. Around 8,5€ for an adult, which is just fine.
St George's Castle Oct 2016. Fantastic castle to walk around and soak up the history of the 11 Century Moor Castle. Walked up from the town centre to get there- so burned a few calories doing so !!

Fantastic Views!. The castle is a fantastic site to visit with superb views across the city from anywhere around the top of the walls of the keep. You do have to be extremely careful of trip hazards, low walls, steep steps and no handrails in places, so there is a need to be vigilant. An iconic historical site of Lisbon and a must see attraction.
Must do. Another must do attraction in Lisbon! Castelo de São Jorge is a great place to visit in the morning, preferably in a sunny day!

Must see tourist attraction. Great place with stunning views over Lisbon. Highly recommend Camera Obscura (however there is a queue and not all of the sessions are in English; some of them are in Portuguese or Spanish) Admission ticket for the whole place is only €8 and it is worth the price. Perfect place to take photographs.

Great View Point. This is a must see if you are in Lisbon. There are a number options to get there hire a tuk tuk, get a tram part way, or walk. The walk is not for the faint hearted but the pay off is great with view of the city awaiting you. There is a small fee (8 euros). There is a cafe on site and a number of places of panoramic photos
Okay. The castle has lovely views and amazingly old architecture, but I expected rooms to be set up like they would have been back in the day. It in involved a lot of good walking!

A LANDMARK OF LISBON.. Located in beautiful Alfama, this castle offers some of the better views of Lisbon, especially on sunset. in my opinion, the ticket for the entrance in this Castle is very expensive and i can't explain why this is happening.... this is the only negative thing.

Good views. As originally intended only the walls & towers are present - it was never intended to be lived in so there are no rooms to visit. You can walk all the way around the parapets and climb the towers so there are great views of Lisbon. The small on site museum is not very interesting and has few exhibits. It took much less time than expected to visit (about an hour) but it's a 'must go' place if you're visiting Lisbon, just don't expect much except viewpoints.On the day we were there it was very busy and you needed some patience to get around.
Great way to spend a few hours. Best views in LisbonVery shady comfortable walk around for a few hoursVery scenic with good facilities

Fantastic views. This is an interesting place with history but above all very nice views over city, bay, bridge etc. and easy to reach. No crowded tram 28 pr bus 737. From Baixa-Chiado metro station exit Rua Vitorio gp straight on till the building with latge sign Elevadores/elevators, go up to top floor, exit, cross street, go left pass large building with flags and square, then go right and find second elevator and supermarket. Go up and follow signs to castle.

Interesting but little original left. A central place to visit in Lisbon to consider its origins and get a fabulous view. Crowded with tourists so couldn't use the Camera Obscurer. 1755 earthquake destroyed a lot so mainly rebuilt. Good to see to start your Lisbon trip.

Best view of Lisbon. The castle itself is not worth it but the view of Lisbon is why you go. But if you want, I suggest going there and walking around the castle to places with similar views and not pay a dime.
Very nice. This castle was very interesting to walk through. Nothing much going on but you get amazing or the best views of Lisbon from here.

Second time just as impressive. I visited the castle some years ago with friends and went now with my partner. The castle remains an impressive sight from down below in the city and offers a supreme view from it's walls. You can not have visited Lisbon without having stood on the walls of this fortress! It would be like vositing Paris without stopping at the Eifel tower....

More of a fort than a castle. I have no idea what castelo translates to because I am American, but this is more of what you would expect in fort than a castle. Great views of Lisbon. Fun to walk around. Would spend about 1.5 to 2 hours here. You should visit this.

Camera Obscura. You will go here because everyone does! Some lovely shade and breezes even on a hot sunny day. Lovely views of Lisbon. We lucked into getting the Camera Obscura demonstration in English! (right time and the right place). It's basically a Live periscope that has views all over Lisbon. The gal who did the demonstration acted as a tour guide of the whole city... positively AWESOME! I would try and get to it if possible.
Tourism. Great. We really enjoyed our visit from the historical aspect and the views were amazing it was really informative and being from Australia, heaped in history we dont have.
Amazing views!. A lovely place to visit, only the walls remain but the views are stunning and you can walk around with a glass of wine, whats not to like - careful can be slippy underfoot.

Not overrated. I realize that every travel book will tell you to come here, but it's not without reason; it's seriously cool. It's worth it even just for the incredible views over Lisbon. It's basically just an old castle you walk all over and look out at Lisbon from. I bought the Lisbon pass before (highly recommend) which included this site. The Lisbon pass will get you discounted tickets to the castle, Sintra and other important sites. Bonus: there are peacocks running around here!

Fantastic views. We visited right at the end of September. The weather is still very hot then and it is quite a hike uphill to the castle. However the views from the main viewpoint are stunning. Good place to wander around and plenty of shady places to escape the hot sun. Couldn't find the camera obscura, but then we didn't look to hard. Usual layout of museum at the end that leads you into a gift shop. Worth a visit.

Quite a climb but worth it. We took the lift at the Pingo Doce food store just of Magdelena which shortened the walk somewhat, but it's straight uphill from there (it is Alfama after all). Nice restaurants along the walk and some interesting shops. Great view from the castle.

Wonderful building, incredibly interesting. Set up high on the side of the city of Lisbon, nestled between narrow cobbled alleyways sits the castle. An amazing stone structure of massive preposition, to view Lisbon without seeing this building would be unforgivable. The views from the walls across the city are awesome,

Amazing views. Feeling energetic, we walked from our hotel in Baixa, through the back streets and up many, many steps. There is a lift for the less mobile, which I expect gets pretty packed, or you could catch a tram, but a good walk allowed us to see the beautiful local architecture en route, and there are plenty of restaurants and cafes to stop at on the way up or down.The views across the city skyline are spectacular on a good day and, let's face it, with the Lisbon climate, that is more often than not.The castle itself is interesting, and you do get a small free guide book/map on entry (8.50euros each) to give you a bit of background to the history of the place.Peacocks roam freely around the grounds and there are a few places to sit out of the sun if it gets too hot.The archaeological section of the site was a little disappointing, and tucked away next to a car park. To coin a well used phrase, it was just "a series of small walls", and not very interesting ones at that.

Great views of Lisbon . It is worth wending your way through the maze of narrow streets, inevitably uphill for Lisbon, to visit this castle, as the views of the city are wonderful. The gardens surrounding the walls of the castle are also a pleasant stroll. Even though this is a popular tourist attraction and the queues look long, don't be put off because we found that it was well organised and the queue moved quickly.

Stunning sunset views with Wine. Worth the hike to visit this. The castle itself isn't much but the grounds around it are great and the views are the best in Lisbon. Grab a glass of wine (or three!!) from the "Wine with a view" vendor, pick a spot and watch the sun go down like we did. Fantastic romantic end to a day.

Amazing views and worth the effort to get there . So unless you are a mountain goat and attempting the 10,000 or so steps from Martim Moniz the easiest way to the castle is the yellow mini bus from Praça Figueroa or if you have already bought the ticket the red hills tram pass (19 euro for 24 hrs per adult so expensive to buy just for this and you will wait ages!!) 2016 entrance price to the castle is €8.50 for an adult but it's a good few hours walk around and there's a couple of exhibitions however as with all Castles and most things Lisbon it's really not for the less mobile and it's certainly not wheelchair friendly other than the main grounds and even those are really rough terrain (assuming you can even get there!)Highly recommend

Gorgeous Views of Lisbon. Be prepared to walk uphill! oh my goodness the walk there is literally the worst but once you get there it is amazing. The castle is gorgeous the views are amazing. We spent 2-3 hours there. It really was the best. I think the entrance to the castle was 17 euros for 2 people. There are a lot of steps once you go in the castle so if you have children hopefully they can go up and down themselves or you can pick them up. It is fun though it's like a real live castle!! The best views truly!

Great Views of a Wonderful City. Take the 28 tram to the castle and enjoy some spectacular views of the city. Be warned, this tram is probably the world capital for pick-pockets. Be especially careful of people who are too helpful, or are standing around with some sort of pack in front of them. They use that to hide their hands after they lift your wallet. The tram is usually loaded with tourists, so watch out for people who just do not seem to fit the tourist crowd.

Stunning views, great castle to explore on your own.. Loved this place! We stayed nearby so stopped by a few times. Totally worth the admission price. I also saw a few vendors selling wine and plastic glasses so you can enjoy a beautiful sunset or just the view over a nice glass of wine or bubbly. I think you could bring your own too....but am not sure about that.

Lisbon highlight.. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the castle. Situated high on a hill overlooking the city giving spectacular all round views this is not for the feint hearted if you don't enjoy scrambling up and down lots of open stairs leading up to the top of the walls once inside the castle itself. If that is the case enjoy wandering around at ground level there is still plenty to see. For those who choose to walk up from the city centre the climb is very steep and at times slippy under foot but there are elevators, free of charge, which take you very close to the main entrance. Use the tourist information outlets for guidance to where these elevators are sited. Pensioners get a reduction in admission price to the castle if they can give proof of age. Outlets for food and drink are available in the castle grounds or in the adjacent streets.

Over priced. The castle stands proud above the city, and the 360-degree views from it are worth the effort. But you can get views from lots of vantage points in Lisbon, and to be honest the castle gets really crowded and has an expensive entry tag. You sort of think you have to visit, but it's not the end of the world if you don't.
Lisbon Must DO. We loved this castle especially the grounds. It is worth the climb and has peaceful gardens and fabulous views of Lisbon from every angle. A real historic treasure!
Fab views. Visit early in the morning to avoid crowds. Well worth the climb up. Beautiful views all over Lisbon.
Good. . Worth a visit for spectacular views and an interesting exhibition on the history of the castle. The surrounding area is nice too.

Worth the hike in the price of admission. I'm not a really big fan of castles and churches and other historical buildings. But this one is definitely worth it. The view is incredible and the castle itself is interesting to tour. It's really just a ruin, not a fully functional Castle with rooms all decked out for you to view. Be sure to check out the camera obscura. It alone was worth the price of admission, at least for me. Interesting, informative, and only 20 minutes long. I really enjoyed just sitting here, enjoying an ice cream, people watching and taking in the view.

Alot to look over Lisbon. After climbing up the hill to take a look over Lisbon, they tried to charge €8.50 to enter the grounds and take a look. I think there should be a separate price. This price included everything but I didn't have time for all of that. When explaining what I wanted, I was told that I'd have to spend the full amount. A bit of a joke!

Worth the walk. Airing high up on the hill overlooking Lisbon the views are fantastic of the cityIt has a nice museum that explains the history of Lisbon but it is the views that make the walk worth whileThe road up is steep in places and has a variety of restaurants and cafes to stop have lunch or a snack and the continue exploring

Castle ruins. This place was a nice visit but be prepared to walk up hill to get to it and then up loads of stairs when you are inside. It gets very busy and you do have great views of the whole city. Very windy up there. The peacocks are everywhere look up in the trees for them. It does get very busy up there and getting the trams to it they are packed don't miss the stop it a load of steep hills to get back to it. There are some nice bars and restaurants in the area with lovely views. Lucky lucky men everywhere but they weren't too bothering. Go to the metro station and buy a day ticket that includes team bus tram and tube for 24hrs for just 6 euros bargain. You can visit the furthest points Parks and shopping and then use it on tram to go to the castle. You have to pay to get in the castle I think it was 8 euros each you can stay there all day if you want there is a restaurant there.

Lovely visit . Went to the castle and it was lovely to walk around with great views. Bought 2 glasses of wine from a 'wine with a view ' van and sat in seats made in the stone wall relaxing and looking at the view. A great place with a happy relaxed atmosphere. When I return to Lisbon I will visit here again.

Very nice. We enjoyed our visit to Castelo de Sao Jorge. Not only the castel itself is impresive but there are also nice views of Lisbon such as lovely areas to take a sit. Also make sure to see the small museum and Camera obscura presentation.

Best views. This is really worth it just for the views of Lisbon alone. The castle is well kept and certainly worth the visit. The walk up through the Alfama is part of the experience and is not to be missed, we made an entire day of it just stopping at small cafe's and restaurants when we felt like it ( and we felt like it a lot ). Make no mistake though, it is a steep walk up and could be difficult if you have young kids or are in poor health, if this is the case take a tuk tuk , you likely won't regret it.

A lovely castle with stunning views. A nice castle and not too expensive (it helps I got student discount) however, I thought there might be a bit more information around the place on signs etc. They give you a little piece of paper with information on it, but I'm a fan of information on boards around the place. Beautiful views of the city that you can take a selfie with. There's even vendors selling wine etc. It didn't take as much time as I thought it would, I think I'd done it all within an hou, however I was on my own so I was zooming around a bit. I guess of you're a couple or in a group it might take a bit longer.

amazing views over Lisbon. The Lisbon castle is an amazing fortress located in one of the hills with amazing views over the city and the river. well preserved it is very big, and clearly worth a visit. in a town so beautiful as Lisbon, this is a must go

Wonderful views of Lisbon!. Without any guidance I was a little confused at first in Alfama - lots of winding, steep roads and a lack of certainty about where I was going. All of that changed once we reached the castle. What a view!!!! You can really appreciate the geography of Lisbon from here. It is very steep on the way up to the castle - we took one of the tuktuks! Highly recommend stopping here if you're in the area.
One of the most importants of Portugal. This is one of the best atractions in Lisbon. Be carefull if you want to go by car, its not possible to go exactly near de castelo.
Stunning . The view from the Castle is breathtaking. Worth the hike up the hill. There are busses every 15 mins or so from the square at the bottom of the hill.

Beauty at the end of a long climb. One could spend an entire afternoon here enjoying the shady trees, the expansive city views, and the stone walls. The old city area surrounding the castle is great for wandering on cobble stone streets with many cafes and gift shops.
Quick tour at dusk. Great to see the city lights from up here at dusk. Bring a torch (or phone with torch) if you want to walk around the walls in the evening as lighting poor. Fantastic views
Must visit.. Spectacular views with a castle to boot. Overlooking the city you have an all round view and you can pick out other attractions.
Nothing special. It is definitly not worth the money. You have a great view but that's all. You can also have a great view in the city center on the lift. And that isn't that cheap.
Great views. Fun place to explore and great views of Lisbon. See the old castle/fort and spend part of the day exploring the fort city and the Alfama neighborhood .

Wear comfortable shoes!!!. It is wonderful place to visit. Strategically situated with wonderful views. It is worth going there even just for views on a good day. It is a very steep climb upto the castle so if you are with young children or don't fancy the steep climb, it might be worth to get a taxi. Trams get very busy. Just be warned, surface within the castle is very uneven. So difficult to push pushchairs or even walk sometimes. Restaurant looking over thevApril 23rd bridge is brilliant. Certainly recommend to have a glass of Rose while you are having your lunch and soaking up the views. It is very popular so if you want a table outside, get there early

Great views - little substance. The Castle had its pros and cons. The castle was nice to walk around and see the views from above. There are several different levels of the castle where you do have to walk up and down several stairs to get to. There’s not much to see inside the castle – it’s really more so to see Lisbon from above. There are several ways to get to the top of the Castle. We opted to take the free elevator that is in the grocery store (Pingo Doce – right off R da Madalena). We then had to walk up a few steep hills to get to the top. Since we had reservations at the restaurant inside, we got a 2 Euro discount on both of our tickets into the Castle.

Worth the effort. It's a hard steep walk at times (maybe take a tuk tuk - they are all electric so you won't add to pollution). Once there, the view is a winner. And the air is cool (most welcome in summer) and the walks are really worth it. The day I visited a couple were walking their cat, other walked their dogs and children.

You Don't See This in the United States . Old stone fortress overlooking Lisbon. Incredible views of the city and Tagus River. Be careful walking; all of the walkways are cobblestone that have become polished with weather and wear. The walking surfaces are uneven so wear flat shoes. Be sure to climb the stairs inside to access the towers and parapets.

Wine with a view. Well worth the 8.50 euro entry....spent over 4 hours here.On arrival very large patio area to take in the views which got better and better as you climbed.Plenty of shade to sit and rest.As there are some steep inclines would recommend travellers in wheel chairs make the most of this area.Very easy route to take in all the delights of this place.Plenty of good facilities on route, toilets, cafe areas etc.Watch out for the peacocks who like to join you for lunch.We arrived mid morning so avoiding the bulk of visitors.Whilst walking the walls take in the fantastic views of Lisbon, can get a little conjested at times while doing so but soon rectified.Again plenty of places on the walls where you can sit down to rest or simply dream.Some small craft stalls near entrance but not over commercial which was nice.Took in a glass of very nice rose wine admiring the views....fantastic !

Holiday day trip . We took taxi as there were 3 of us so it was cheaper than a tour bus. Very well restored and has interesting stonework design. Don't bother walking to the waterside, modern cafe, with glass veranda thats through the park as staff only serve young women!

Great view over Lisbon . The castle is a hard climb, so a good tip is to take a taxi up the hill and then walk down. A great view over Lisbon and the Tejo river from the castle, which is the best part of the visit. The castle is beautiful but it would be so more interesting to visit if there were more information about the castle in the map and at points of interests around the castle.There must be so much more information that could be shared with the visitors beside pottery and a few coins!

Nice view over the city. Climbing up the narrow streets you will find the Castelo de São Jorge on the top of the hill. From here you have a nice view all over Lisbon, the harbour and the long bridge. It is nice to walk along the old walls of the Castelo with some shady places and peacocks wandering along. The entry is rather expensive with 8.50€.

Preview of Lisbon from Castle Walls. A Worthy First Stop.. Took the Metro to stop Martim Moniz on the green line then walked up the hill to the entrance. The entrance fee is certainly worth it. The views are fantastic. Plenty of scenic photo opportunities. As you view the city of Lisbon from above, this is a great time to find other landmarks in the city and get a bird's eye overview. Spent about 2 hours wandering around the castle. Many of the photographs taken there still remain among our favourites from trip to Lisbon.

Great castle beautiful views of Lisboa!. Castelo de Sao Jorge is located a short, but steep walk from the Praca do Comercio. Along the walk, you'll pass by lots of cool street art and street musicians before coming on the castle itself! There is a small fee of 8.50 euros, but it's well worth it if you like clambering through the (very well restored!) remains of an old castle! Honestly, the sweeping views of the city from the main castle battlements are worth the admission fee alone! I would give the castle 5 stars, but it does lack a bit in informational plaques around the castle grounds. If you have time for one attraction in downtown Lisbon, I'd definitely recommend hitting up the castle!

A nice place and view. If you are in Lisbon you can't miss those walls with trees on top and tourists taking pictures. The castle is interesting enough especially on a sunny day, but I hoped to get some rooms with weapons, clothes and such of the period.

Worth it. This is a castle and not a palace - there are no fancy rooms with extravagant furniture but there are old castle walls and towers that provide a fantastic view of Lisbon. The archeological tour (every hour until 5pm) is also very interesting and definitely worth it as is the obscura periscope (every 20min in Portuguese, Spanish, then English until 5pm). Both of these are included in the ticket price. I definitely recommend visiting the castle. There are also beautiful gardens if you want to have a picnic.

A castle. You pay 8.50 euro to get in but it's a good 3 hour experience. For your money you also get to see a camera obscura in one if the castle towers. This is a marvel of 19th century engineering though this one was installed in 2006. Don't be put off by queue's as it is every 20 mins and 20 people get in at a time. Go even if it's not in your language as it's a visual experience. The archeological tour was fascinating and only 5 people on the 20 minute tour which took us from the house of prehistoric man iron age to the kitchen and garden of the Moors and then to the palace of the first bishop of Portugal all within a matter of metres of each other on the top of this castle. Best free tour in Portugal.

Great old castle!!. The castle sits atop the Alfama, above a plethora of steep, winding, cobblestone streets, so we took a cab up to the entrance. After entering, you discover a large terrace which overlooks Lisbon with near 180 degree views to the West and South. Gazing down at the city below and the red tile rooftops reminds you this was once a bold fortress for the city.The castle itself is interesting. Most of it has been restored, and you can walk through courtyards, and climb stairs to stroll along the walkways atop the inner walls and imagine fending off would be attackers! There are also several rooms in the castle itself that are interesting. One such is a room (all stone) I imagined was a bath house that had a raised platform and 2 squared pits which i guessed were tubs for water. There was also a drainage system above on the 2nd floor, which may have been a rain water catching system.After you tour the castle, the area directly below (Alfama) is an easy downhill stroll, with many shops, bars, restaurants and cobblestone streets.Castelo de Sao Jorge is definitely a must-see in Lisbon!

Great views of the city . Perfect place to stop off first if you're visiting Lisbon. The castle offers great views of the whole city and can really help you get your bearings of where things are too. Not too bad a price for the views you get

Well preserved castle with amazing views of the city. This castle is located on a hill overlooking all the historic district of Lisbon. It is possibly the best observation point available, providing breathtaking views of all surroundings. The castle is well preserved, and one can walk through all its interior and climb on its walls. It is well worth the effort to get up there. Must see!

Stunning views. Worth a trip. Visited here in April. Weather was fantastic. The Castle is set on top of a steep hill. We took a pretty little tram up to it from the square. Nice trip up through the winding streets. Stunning views inside the grounds. You can see the whole of Lisbon from up there. Some wonderful photo opportunities throughout. Although there were huge crowds, it never felt packed as it is spread over quite a vast area. There is no inside of the castle as such however, it is still a magnificent building. There is an onsite café however, we didn't try it out. It is worth the few euros entrance fee and you can stay as long as you like in it. We enjoyed our visit
Another must see. The views of Lisbon alone are worth the visit,walking and climbing the steps to each "tower" was rewarded with a fantastic view of the city and harbour.
Great castle!. Such a nice place on the top of the hill! Great views and you can walk on all the walls and feel like a knight! Worth a visit!!
Wonderful Castle!. The castle offered great views of the city. The thick walls were great to see. Our visit did include a good amount of walking uphill. Great experience!

Love a good castle. And this certainly lives up to it, explore the grounds and walls, with amazing views and plenty to see.
There is also a few museum areas to look around to get the idea of some of the history

Old and stunning. The castle gives one the best view of the city. It sits atop a hill near the city and near the port. The history goes back to the tenth century and is told well at the site. I recommend this as a must see for any who have an interest in the history of the western world.
A castle. Nothing more nothing less. Not much to see inside, only the ouside and walking on the walls. Very nice view of the city

Good for those who like to explore castles!. We were reluctant to visit here after our tour guide telling us it wasn't worth the €8.50 admission for an empty (not original as it was rebuilt 40s) castle. However, I thoroughly enjoyed the trip. It was brilliant climbing up all the steps to all the different view points in Lisbon!It is open until 9pm during peak season, we went up just before sunset which made the lighting really good for photographs!

worth a visit. It is a steep yet enjoyable walk there and back, requiring a reasonable level of fitness. The castle with it history going back to the moors we found very interesting, with fantastic views. It also has an unusual interesting periscope that rehires patient queuing as only 20 people at a time can be accommodated. unfortunately the commentary is in Portuguese. We found a lovely tapas bar on the return and watched the trams tuk tuks and taxies ferrying the those unable or unwilling to walk.

Best views in town! Breathtaking... to go 1h before sunset. Get the best views of Lisbon from the castle! Depending on the month, check sunset time and go 1h before. Like this you have time to visit and walk around, and you can take pictures of the city from the big terrace with full sun when you arrive and with changing sky colors as the sun falls.Tip: you can buy wine inside and seat at the fort walls and enjoy views, wine and sunset!

Height and Great View!!. I wanted to visit this place when I am in Lisbon and I am glad I made it. The trip was fantastic. The steep climb from the town sqare, follow the tram lines and you arrive at this breathtaking view on the higest hill at Lisbon. The coolness within, vast expanse of space and the great view of Lisbon is a meditative experince. Walk back to Munidal Sqr, through the maze of path and ally ways, polished tiles and steps is a very welcome feel. I strongly recommed this place as a MUST visit.

Beautiful place to spend time. Getting to the castle Sao Jorge can be a bit of a challenge, perched as it is on the top of one of Lisbon's hills, but when you do arrive to it the view of the city and the river from the walls is amazing and a cool walk in the shade of the trees is a very special treat on a warm day, In one corner of the castle grounds there has an archaeological dig, spanning back to the iron age. There are free, regular guided tours of the dig area, which take about 30 - 40 minutes with really knowledgeable guides - if you get a chance to go on one of these tours you really should take it, they are really worthwhile

Spectacular Views. Totally worth the hilly walk through the Alfama on a hot day and the Euros to get in. It was interesting walking the walls, the views of Lisbon are amazing from her and the peacocks entertaining. Must see!

Worth a visit for the super view of Lisboa. Not much to see inside the castle but it has a fantastic good full view of Lisboa. Worth a visit and spend good time for photos. There is a restaurant inside the castle and it got a private function when we there, so better call or email them in advance before any disappointment.

Castello de Sao Jorge. An easy tram ride or short walk from Brown's Boutique Hotel finds one at the Castelo with its wonderful views and ancient history.This site it provides the photographer or romantic with sights and emotions, and climbing the heights shows the city and port below.Ancient Olive trees, Roman steps, bronze canons and large stone pavers great the visitors.You can purchase your tickets at the site, where drinks, food and gift shops are also found.It's a great walk around a lovely landmark

EXCELLENT VİEW THAT İS ALL. Castelo de Sao Jorge or (Saint George Castle) is a Moorish castle occupying a commanding hilltop overlooking the historic centre of Lisbon and Tagus River. The strongly fortified citadel dates from medieval period of Portugal, and is one of the main tourist sites of Lisbon.One of the best place to view the city.

Awesome – Don’t miss this!. Built on a group of hills it was obvious that Lisbon would use the highest to site an impressive fortified Castle. The site is compact and uses the traditional fortification surrounded by grounds and then a ‘town’ making this a self-contained and defendable unit.Admission is 8.5 euros and includes the whole site so very reasonable. The town is alive and people live in the shadow of the castle which adds to the experience of a working site. Through the gates you enjoy the outer grounds before heading in deeper to the inner walled castle itself. In the outer areas are refreshments, the permanent museum and pleasant sitting areas with magnificent views over the City. Inside the walls you can explore through archways, ramparts and climb seemingly endless flights of stairs – but some are uneven and could be slippery when wet so please take care.One thing not to miss is the Camera Obscura. Sited on the tower just inside the walls and using a series of lenses and mirrors you can enjoy a 360 Panorama of Lisbon which is ‘projected’ onto a screen. Numbers are limited to 20 at a session (you stand around the circular screen) and the showing lasts about 15 minutes. They run showings in Portuguese, English and Spanish at 20 minute intervals so plan your trip to include this. Its real time so bad weather could interfere with visibility so be aware.Overall I found the Castle a highlight of my visit to Lisbon. It offers great views, history back to the 11th Century and a feel of connecting with something special. I fear that the number of steps may put some off but there are still many things to do if that is a problem – the choice is yours but do take a chance to see something special.

Must go...gorgeous view. Love walking around that fort for the view. My legs were shaking from the height but I would totally do it again. It was quite windy the day I visited...a bit hard to take photos with hair down... haha girls problem ! Nice sunset view too !

Great views! . From this castle you can see Amazing panoramic views of Lisbon. I would recommend going earlier in the day to avoid larger crowds but either way it is a great way to view the city. They offer a student admission price.
Great views. Toured this castle, has great views of the surrounding city and river. It is hard to imagine the work it took to build this castle.
It had a nice view. There is not much of a castle to see but the view is very nice. If the weather is nice you can see most of the city. There is just not much to do when you get to the top.

What fantastic views!. Visited on our last day in Portugal as we were staying in a hotel in the castle walls. Really well organised, plenty to see and do and nice cafe and restaurant. The views from the castle walls were fantastic and the history of the castle is fascinating. The archeological digs are very interesting.
Superb views of the city. Well worth a visit for around 9 Euros. Don't forget to take your camera as you can get some lovely photographs from the elevated position overlooking the City.

A must see sight. The fortress was built by the Moors in the 10-11th century and reconstructed beautifully. Getting there is an experience and then you understand why the site was chosen.
Don't buy the overpriced cans of sardines and cod.

Beautiful architecture with magnificent views of the city. We visited on a beautiful sunny fall day and it was a wonderful experience. We braved it and walked from our apartment in Chiado. The walk is steep and not for the faint of heart but doable for anyone in reasonable condition with no leg or knee weaknesses. We got some of the most beautiful photos of the city from the castle. You can't visit Lisbon without seeing the historic castle which is visible from almost all over the city.

Fantastic views of the city.. Well worth a visit. we took the lift up the hill and then enjoyed walking through the quaint streets on the castle entrance. We walked around for ages pausing to admire the wonderful views and then stopped for lunch. We highly recommend a visit.

nice views. You will be rewarded with beautiful views over the city, when you visit the castelo. You can also climb to some towers and experience the fortress from a different angel. Definitely worth a visit.

Worth the climb and the crowds. The castle grounds are extensive, the walls surrounding the site and impressive and the views are beautiful. The problem is that it is very crowded and it's hard to feel comfortable.

Stunning views. It is €8.50 for adults so it is not cheap but it is well worth the money. The castle itself is relatively simple but the grounds offer panoramic view right around Lisbon. It is easy to see why many occupiers from the Moors to the Spanish as well as the Portuguese kings chose it as their site to rule the city. I recommend the wine stall for a tasty beverage with a view but pricey by Portuguese standards
See the antique architecture with your own eyes. See the antique architecture with your own eyes! Gorgeous, sitting above the entire city... You must come and visit it!

A highlight of Lisbon. Castelo de Sao Jorge was the standout attraction of our Lisbon trip. The castle is well maintained and meandering around its walls, bastions, courtyards and museum brings the history of this castle to life. Occupying a commanding hilltop overlooking Lisbon and surrounds, the views afforded from the castle are spectacular. Give yourself a good few hours at Castelo de Sao Jorge to explore the fortifications and to relax, simply taking in the panoramic views of the city. There is also a cafe on site. The meandering streets and alleys leading up to Castelo de Sao Jorge are also worth exploring by foot. Cafes and restaurants are dotted around this area (some more expensive than others!), as well as several scenic viewpoints.
Good castle. Well kept castle with good views on Lisbon. Very crowded even in September. You can go on the walls of the castle but they are not very large.
Great views from the castle. Great views for taking pictures, nice to walk around the castle. There is also a cafe so you may take an ice-coffee with pastel de nata withing your day. Enjoy!

Nice views. Castelo de São Jorge is a nice place to spend an hour. The view over the city is cool and the castle itself is nice to walk around. Why not check this place out if you want to see different things in Lisbon. It's also a romantic place to just sit and enjoy life.

Good views... not much else. The castle lies on one of the hills surrounding the centre of Lisbon. The view from up there is great, but apart from that there isn't much to see or do. In fact, apart from a brief walk on the walls, there isn't anything else to do at all as the building itself has been destroyed (little caveat: there is in fact a little museum with some of the artefacts, but it isn't really worth bothering with) so 8.50 Euro for the ticket is - in my opinion - a bit steep.

Well kept castle, good views. We visited the castle and enjoyed the panoramic views it offered of the city, however these views can be had from other locations (the miradouro for example- and from there the view offers the whole castle). Its a well kept castle though, the walls are intact but there is nothing else there, no rooms to visit. I'm not sure it was worth the 8.50€.

Wonderful view of Lisbon. The castle is a very interesting place to visit - a well preserved walled castle. It also contains many artifacts and historical accounts of Lisbon.The castle is set high above Lisbon and the views are stunning.Well worth the climb to the top to visit.

Great view and interesting part of Lisbon history. Although the museum and the history of the castle itself is interesting, the best part of Castelo de Sao Jorge is the incredible views of Lisbon. It is worth paying to get into the castle just to see Lisbon from every angle! It is such a colourful and vibrant city and it is worth seeing from above.The museum is interesting and has some history of the castle and Portugal as a whole. There are also ruins and botanical gardens in the castle grounds. If you are up to the steep walk, is worth going on foot to the castle because you get to experience the less-touristy Lisbon and there are some amazing graffiti murals about.

Good start to explore this old town. What a view from this Great Wall of old Lisbon ancient memories. Absolutely recommended to visit. It's quite a long claiming slope to approach, I'd suggest you to take the bus or tram to get there, but it's easy & also fun to walk down in your way back. I visited there almost the last part of my journey but I wish I would have been there earlier stage, coz it's good to capture the landscape of the old town and make plans to explore the town. You shouldn't miss this place if you want to have this wonderful view!古城へ向かう登り坂は思った以上に大変で、きっとバスかトラムで向かうべきだったと思うでしょう。ただ、期待を裏切らない景色と、街全体の様子をまず目に焼き付けることで、きっとリスボンへの過ごし方が変わるはず。到着したら先ずはここへ向かうのは如何？
Game of Thrones. The Castle is awesome. Even the road to him is nice and interesting =) Big, with the best panorama view on Lisboa, we really enjoyed!
Breath-taking views.. The attraction of the Castelo de Sao Jorge is the views of Lisbon from this high point in the city. The castle itself is rather disappointing; very little to see

Pricey, but a priceless view. In a sense, this is kind of a ripoff. There isn't much to justify the €8.50 entrance fee. But the view is unbelievable. It must be the best in the city. So this remains a must-see Lisbon activity. We went at around 5 o'clock, which was a nice time, but it did mean that the best view was straight towards the sun - not great for photos! Probably best to come earlier or later. Make sure to stop off at the Wine Bar do Castelo on the way back down if you're into wine!
Lisbon's iconic castle. Extensive castle and exhibitions on show. Brave the steps up to the turrets for great city views! Lovely walk up to the castle through alfama too.

Stamena. The castle is impossible to get to unless you walk from the bottom of a very steep cobbled street. It is in an old part of Lisbon which has all narrow cobbled streets. Busses go to the bottom of the road but it is a long hike up if you have any bronchial or walking difficulties. My advice would be to get there about 9 to 10am otherwise there are massive queues to get in. It is well worth the visit for the view alone, which is absolutely spectacular. There is a restaurant and a cafe and very clean toilet facilities and a little shop. Peacocks walk about the grounds and it is quite interesting with original guns and original features. Worth a visit.

Half hour, good views, not much to see internally. €8.50 for entrance to the Castelo and access to the views seemed a little steep after I got in. The views were good but the internal archaeological exhibits were all roped off. The castle is really a walled fortress not a castle. There is nothing to go inside. You can walk around on top of the walls though, and take photos. I was told it would take an hour to see the whole thing, but it only took a 1/2 hour. I did enjoy the bus ride up to the castle though. We started spewing black smoke half way and had to switch to another bus. Exciting, right?! :) all locals on the bus. Was entertaining.

Wait for the periscope tour! . We wandered around all the tours of the castle and took in the views .. It's very relaxed and peaceful despite a lot of people being there. We waited for the "camera obscura" exhibition in English which was about 40 mins of a wait but we wandered around and came back close to the time slot. It was very good .. It's a great idea more places should think of doing it! €8.50 into the castle grounds is dear but I suppose for the conservation of such a magnificent place it's worth it!
Fantastic viewa. Amazing views of Lisbon and the Tagus river from up here! It's a steep walk up to it but well worth the walk!
Stunning views from the top of Lisbon . Go there for the stunning views of the city from a high point. Walk around. Take some pictures and eat at Cantinho do Aziz on your way down.
More than worth the walk. Amazing views from the citadel and the castle. Wonderful grounds around which to walk and rest. Truly spectacular.

Tour of the castle. . My recommendation would be to go first thing in the morning at 9 AM. There are absolutely no lines. You should have a castle to yourself for about an hour before the boats unload. We were told the city receives an average of 7000 tourists per day from the cruise ships. Once tourists depart the cruise ships, the lines are absolutely crazy and long. Great castle and historical monument.
Nice view. İt is difficult to reach Them because of steep but You can use free lift it is very close the Rua Agusta. İt is just a castle no special things but nice view

Impressive, but I was tired so probably didn't do it justice. My headline says it all. I'm not in to history but went because a friend wanted to go. It was a very hot day and I was tired so I kind of reluctantly dragged myself around the place just waiting to leave. That said, I always give accurate and fair reviews and so it's fair to add that I wasn't in the right frame of mind. However now, looking back, I genuinely wish I had of gone first thing in the morning when I had more energy and the temperature was cooler. Because I think it looks a very beautiful and fascinating place to spend 2-3 hours. There's lots to see and do there, lots to explore, great facilities, wonderful views and all for 6.5 euros (with the Lisboa card). All in all I think that the Castle of St George was failed and disappointed by me, as opposed to the other way around. You should go.

Proper Castle!. Long walk up if your not lucky enough to get on the Tram 28. On a hot day a real effort. Well worth the effort though. The castle is very well maintained and allows access to the ramparts. Great views of the City of Lisbon!
It's a castle, get into it.... Well there is a hill with a castle on top. Nice view and most of the walls are intact but most have been rebuilt. Worth a look.
Must visit in Lisboa. Be prepare to walk a lot, but it is all worth it. Beautiful views of the entire city inside a castle full of towers and scenery

Beautiful look point . You need to climb up the city to get to the Castelo Sao Jorge but the view is just gorgeous.. The castle is in ruins but the view OMG it is so beautiful, you can see the whole city!

Just a ruin but fab ciews. 8.5 euro to see this ruin. I didn't do it all as I realised half way round that it wasn't really my thing. The views are amazing and worth the price. There is a public loo, cafe and restaurants. It is steep and cobbled to get there (as is ALL of Lisbon) - wear ridged shoes!
Tough climb but worth the view. There are no easy public transportation routes that don't involve lots of upward climbing or stairs. Can take a taxi or tuk tuk which can get you quite close.
Trip to Lisboa. Nice place in the middle of Lisboa to have a 360° surrounding view. Best to get an overview and plan a visit of the different districts.

Great views of the city . We stayed in the Alfama district and tried to get to this moorish castle a few times. We finally managed to make it on our last day and it was worth the wait. The castle still preserves its medieval structure and is actually quite breathtaking. The views of the city are also breathtaking and to our advantage in having going there on our last day was that we recognised most of the city buildings and how far we had travelled.It is worth a visit to this castle.

Nice simple castle with stellar views of Lisbon. The castle is pretty basic, really just the walls remain. But is does have a great view and you can get a sense of the layout of what it must have looked like when it was totally intact and occupied. As a bonus they seem to have some interesting shows that use the castle as a venue. Unfortunately we weren't going to still be in Lisbon when the next show was to take place.
