We did see the stage being prepared and listed to some of the music that was to be part of the show and watched the crew test the "fog machine". I imagine being there at night to watch a play/performance could be rather magical.

Lovely views. Took the trip up the castle and I must admit it was a lovely spot with some amazing views. The museum inside the castle was very informative. I would recommend to anyone visiting Lisbon that the castle is well worth calling to see.

360 degree views. This old castle sits atop a high knoll. When you walk around the upper areas, you will have views of the entire city. Be prepared to walk and climb a lot. Wear tennis shoes, as the stones are uneven. Bring plenty of water as it can get warm there in the summertime.

Stunning Views!. We thought the price was a bit expensive to enter as we didn't get anything for the 8.50euro but when we walked in and seen the view it was all worth it! Food and drink in the restaurant were really expensive so I would recommend to bring your own as there is loads of space to sit and eat. Really nice walk around the castle. Not difficult. Very relaxed.

Best 360 views of Lisbon and sunset.. Best 360 views of Lisbon and sunset. This is a must do if you're in Lisbon! It's history and beauty are worth the trek up the windy roads. The walk up is interesting with building walls covered with (interesting/beautiful) graffiti. Go for the sunset and have a glass of wine!
Well preserved castle. This is a large and interesting castle/fort complex. Great views of the city and even has a nice affordable little cafeteriaTake your time and wander around all of it

Great views, nice pics. Set high with great views over the river Tagus and the city, this Moorish castle is similar to the Allhambra in Spain but less ornate as it wasn't a palace. You can walk around the walls and up most of the towers and get nice photos with trees, the flags, the town etc. Try not to miss the Camera Obscura tucked away in one of the towers. It does shows every 20 minutes in alternate languages. It is striking how they can use a mirror and a periscope to show you Lisbon in real time. You can see people walking around, cars and trams, etc. Fabulous. There's a cafe there selling hit and cold food and drinks but overpriced because it has the monopoly. Take a hat and water!

Great views, go early!. This is a great attraction really offering really great views over the city.It's quite small and you won't need too long there but def go earl doors first thing to avoid the crowd and it's nice and peaceful.Worth a visit if in Lisbon
Great place to visit. Love the views , realy a must place to visit when you are in lisbon, day or night, the views are beautiful.

Bringing a picnic makes it worth it.. Great views of most of Lisbon but several other places had equivalent views and I didn't think the exhibits were interesting. However we happened to pack a picnic and enjoyed that on the grounds. Lots of room to grab a space and nice cool breezes offering relief from Lisbon heat. I thought the ability to enjoy the picnic made it worth the price.
A good steap walk to a historic place. Very nice to go here. Walk to it is steap but nice. Lots of things to see like a museum. One to two hours is enough. Afterwards go to Almafa for lunch or diner.

Great Castle. I really enjoyed my visit to this Castle. The views over Lisbon are incredible on a clear day. When we visited there was a re-enactment of soldiers and weaponry including a Canon that was incredibly loud - the ground shook! Very well maintained (but not sure how much is recently restored and how much is "original"). Nice gardens and decent coffee shop. A great way to spend a couple of hours.

Great view over Lisbon. This is a moor castle from 11th century. It is built on the highest point of Lisbon with great views. As a museum it is very small and average as only very few items have remained. Still recommended for a nice intro into the city.
Castle . Must see if you're in Lisbon! Evening is best, cooler, with less crowd! Sunsets are beautiful, and a panoramic view of the city!

Beautiful views and gardens. The castle is really worth a visit if you are in Lisbon, even though Rick Steves gives it a pass. Walking or taking a tram up to the castle gives you a great taste of Portuguese culture and the hilltop castle offers beautiful 360 degree views of the city and surroundings. Though not much of the original castle is left, what there is, is beautifully restored. We skipped the museum, which is small and just enjoyed the surroundings.
stunning view. this castle is a great photo op place,views over lisbon and the tram 28 is a fun way of getting there.not much history written about inside but the sheer view is worth the visit

St George,s Castle Lisbon. While in Lisbon we took tram number 28 which goes past St George,s castle. It is well worth a visit as you can spend a couple of hours going round the grounds and get great views all about as it is so high up .We did not actually go inside the castle as we prefer to be outside .

Beautiful Location Overlooking Lisbon!!!. Visited the Castelo de Sao Jorge and it was really nice specially the location as it overlooks Lisbon and the Tejo river. The inside of it is just ok as there aren't a whole lot of renovated areas, however it has a really nice smaller museum that one can visit and see a lot of pottery. Worth visiting!

Great views, nice castle. The views from different parts in the castle area are just stunning. You can oversee the whole city of Lisbon. There are different viewpoints. The castle itself is very nice as well. Different areas to see and get on top of the walls and in the towers. You can easily spend here 1 or 2 hours enjoying the sceneries. It is well worth spending the money (€8.50, adult).The archeological site is not that interesting though. Might be interesting with a guide, because you are not allowed inside without one.
Lovely . It's a lovely place to visitors and me the greatest experience is to see the sunset, there is a place to order a great wine and see the end of the day.
Nice view!. Castelo De Sao Jorge is worth the climb up the hill from the riverfront. The view from the Castelo gives a good impression of the layout of Lisbon's old town.
This is a must. For the history or just for the view, this is a winner. We took a cab to get there and then walked back down through the Alfama. Areal treat.

Better than your usual castle fort. I've toured a fair number of castle/forts. This is the best of them. You have the historical value and the great views, but there's also a nice little garden cafe to stop for refreshment, nice bathrooms, a museum shop with better quality souvenirs and places along the walls to sit and enjoy the view. The ticket office to get in was well-organized and efficient.

Great Views from a Stunning Place. It is a high trek to the top but once you reach the castle and enter the grounds you will get a treat. Stunning views of the city and of course lots of history and things to see in the castle itself. The camera obscura is a great attraction whilst there - make sure you get in the line for either the English, Spanish or Portuguese tours of it which alternate every 20mins!

A wonderful place to spend an afternoon. This is a beautiful castle, well preserved, with magnificent views of the city. There is a coffee shop and restaurant and wandering peacocks to entertain. Take you time and enjoy the ambiance. It is quite a walk to the top, I would recommend taxi up to the castle and walk down to get the flavor of the city without the sweat. Don't miss this attraction if in Lisbon.
Tremendous tour. Took the free tour--- tour guide was exceptional . He was a wealth of knowledge and had a great sense of humor. Would highly recommend that all take the tour...

The views will worth every cent you paid. A very well preserved castle with stunning views from its walls and surrounding grounds. If you already visited any of the Lisbon museums, there's not much really to see inside the castle (unless you are a complete history geek), but the panoramic views over the city and Tejo river are breathtaking! 8,50 € admission fee is somewhat pricey, but once you get inside you understand it was worth every cent. Just relax with a glass of wine and sit on the outer wall among the old cannons looking down the terracotta roofs of this beautiful city. Walking up the hill might be a challenge, but we did enjoy those tiny winding streets with cloths and underwear drying on the sun all over the walls :-) it is so authentic and so vivid!

Must see. Definitely a place to go, the view is great and it is a peaceful spot despite the number of tourists. The walk up to the castle is also nice, but be prepared and bring good shoes and, on hot days, at least a bottle of water. The museum is nice, although a litle uninspired.

Mystery tour of the castle. Wonderful place but information at the place is poor and at times contradictory. There is no signage, because they close off the level access areas especially the Moorish Quarter a lot of wasted step climbing could have been avoided. Just invest in some signs!

Can't miss Attraction in Lisbon. Our hotel was on R. da Vitoria close to the Baixa-Chiado metro (6 blocks away) and the Castle was an easy walk thru the winding streets. Excellent views out over the Tagus river along the way. We were a bit put off by reviews that stated how hard it was to climb up to the Castle but the difficulty is way overblown. My wife and I are over 70 and it was easy for us! However, if you have difficulty walking be sure to take the tram or the bus (cheap) which will bring you most of the way up.This Moorish castle is in an excellent state of preservation and contains a nice museum. There are multiple towers all of which you can enter. Beautiful views of Lisbon everywhere. Don't miss the Camera Obscura which is a reflecting telescope reviewing a panoramic view of Lisbon. Lines can get long as only 20 can enter the room every 15-20 minutes.TIP: Normal admission to the castle is 7.50 euro but if you are 65 or over it is only 5 euro so remember to bring your ID!
Visit to Lisbon. The castle was amazing - you can also see the entire city from the top. There's also restaurants and shopping near the location.
Brilliant castle. A wonderful castle to visit. Lovely narrow lanes surrounding castle. Plenty of places to eat and drink too. Fantastic views. Tram 28 drops you nearby although still a climb. I
beautiful but expensive. Beautiful place but €8,5 for a ticket is a bit to much.. great view and you can see the whole city. Nice little museum to visit as well.
we liked it. We liked it, it was sunny day great for visiting castelo. We liked walking around and exploring the fortress. Great for chilling and loking over Lisbon from fortress. :)

Castelo de São Jorge is an open air park, and with a museum and art gallery within its walls.... Castelo de São Jorge is an open air park, and with a museum and art gallery within it's walls. The park itself is lovely with statues, stone tables & seats, various kiosks serving ice to wine. Worth paying for the panoramic view of the city and to sit watching life below you going on.  The museum is definitely worth visiting, not just to see artefacts and read up on the castle but also on Lisbon too, and it will take several hours if you found it as fascinating as we did.  We gave the religious art a miss, to be honest once you seen 'Jesus' bleeding and looking gloomy by the 5th/6th time on a trip, it's nothing spectacular no matter who painted it.  its not a 5* attraction but its better than a 4*, but if you want amazing views of Lisbon then this is a must visit. Also has a restaurant and wine selling kiosk.
Good view on the city. Visit the castle just for views. Do it better in the first half of the day, when the sun shines from behind.
Must do!!. The castle is mainly about the amazing views of the city you see from it! I would highly recommend visiting when in Lisbon.

Gorgeous grounds, a must see!. We took the old tram up the jail and got off at the castle. Just getting there was a beautiful adventure, winding through the old streets. The castle itself sits on gorgeous grounds with so much to see. We took two small children with us and they loved it.

Amazing views. What a wonderful spot with spectacular views over Lisbon and Estuary. Good cafe at top too. Get there using famous Tram 28 then walk to the top around winding cobbled streets. Just fab.

Best views of Lisbon. Sao Jorge is up on a hill, so the views you get of Lisbon are amazing. But that's about the best part of this fortress. You're tasked with just aimlessly walking around and exploring on your own, which is fine, but there isn't much to see. I've been to fortress elsewhere where information is provided and it's very educational, this is not one of those. Go for the views. But you don't need a lot of time to explore. And if you can find somewhere else to get spectacular views of Lisbon from up high, then skip Sao Jorge.
Lovely Area. We took the no 12 tram up to the top. Didn't pay to go into castle, thought it was a little expensive, but the surrounding village is quaint and the easy walk down was very scenic.

Great views of the City. It is worth the uphill walk to take in the beautiful views of Lisbon, you can also take the tram if walking is not your thing. A great way to get an overview of the city and spend a couple of hours. I would not recommend this trip for families with young children as the best views for the top walls are high and unsafe for children.
thousand years of history. thousand years of history and an impressive lisbon sightseeing. Quite expensive, but nice surrondings. A must go!

Worth the walk!. We walked up to the castle not sure if we would pay the €8.50 admission fee. However when you get there you realise you can't see any of it / any of the views without paying to access and having hiked up we decided to pay.We were happy we did it is a massive area with gardens, the castle itself, great views and places to sit and get a drink.Once you get to the top you will pay to get in but yes it's worth it.

Stunning views of Lisbon. An absolute must if you are in Lisbon. The views are absolutely stunning from the castle. The castle itself is amazing, steeped in history and located at the top of a hill. The entry is 8.50 euros for an adult but worth the fee to see perhaps the most beautiful views of sunset across Lisbon.

Magnificent views. Great old castle with magnificent views over Lisbon. If the '28' tram is to busy, you can get the '12' tram up to St Luzia. There are signs to the castle but it is a little complicated.

Castle with a view. Having walked to the Castle from the city centre and purchased entry tickets, there was an extremely fantastic vista of Lisbon from the Castle Entrance. Spent 2 hours climbing the castle walls, having drinks and making use of the clean toilets. There is a guided tour of the archaeological dig but this at set times, so you might have to wait.

Best Views of Lisbon. I would highly recommend going there due to the area around the castel (which you still need to buy the ticket to enter). They have great views and nice cafes. A must-see when in Lisbon!

An impressive fortress and a great view of the City. At the end of our "free tour" of the City, which was terrific, we found ourselves a few blocks away from the Castelo de Sao Jorge (the Castle of St. George). So, although we had planned to visit the Castle at sunset, because we were told this was a wonderful time of day to see the panoramic views of the City, we altered our plans and proceeded to visit the Castle in the early afternoon. Actually "a few blocks away" turned out to be a rather lengthy trip given the winding, multi-directional roads in the Alfama. Indeed, we wound up taking a tram which let us off a few blocks from the Castle (BTW, the trams are a wonderful way to travel within the City -- however, be careful of pick-pockets.) As we learned, the Castle probably was first built by the Phoenician traders who landed there, later in order by the Romans and Moors, and finally by the Christians -- Afonso Henriques, defeated the Moors taking over the Castle in 1147. There are many exhibits about Afonso and his heroics. The Castle covers a broad area of land on the top of a mountain with steep rugged slopes on all sides. The views in all directions are superb; also as noted, excellent presentations about the history of the Castle, the City and the country. Definitely a worthwhile attraction to visit.

The best view of Lisbon you will ever get!. The castle is at the highest point of the city. You can see it from everywhere with its medieval looking walls. We walked all the way there, be prepare since it´s a long uphill walk, but in the end it was the best way to reach the castle since you get to explore the surroundings.Once you enter the place you are welcomed by a panoramic view of Lisbon and will take your breath away. Take the time to walk around and explore the place, then marvel at the architecture of the towers and walls. It is a really old building with a lot of history and beauty. Definitely a must see.There is also a small archaeological museum but it was closed when I went.
Amazing view. Must see , great view . Admission price is worth the view and the walk around the castles and on the castle walls .
I found this castle to be rather boring and lackluster. I wouldn't wast m time here. Not really interesting or worthwhile. The views are nice though but nothing breathtaking.

Great views . The cost is €8.50 but if you are over 65yrs then there is a concession and the cost is €5. We took an elevator to a point where one then has still quite a climb to get to the castle. Once inside the castle grounds there is a very pleasant walk along the wall with wonderful views of Lisbon. There is the odd shop along the way which includes a restaurant and a few cannons. One can walk around the ramparts and turrets, there are several steps to negotiate and care should be taken because they are slippy. Lovely trees here and there but not much information. Not much more that I can say.
Well worth a visit. Beautiful, spectacular views, you could spend a day here. Admission charge very cheap. Use the elevators to get there but walk down to see the quaint streets and stairways.
Nice view and museum. There is a really beautiful sunset if you come in the evening plus the history of Lisbon is nicely described in short inside the museum.

Not much to observe. It's very cool to be able to navigate an 1100 year old structure. But, there wasn't much else to do. There wasn't many exhibits that talked about the castle or life at that time. Worth seeing but probably not a priority if you have limited time.

Beautiful views. What you're really paying for is the view of the city. Stunning vistas can be seen all around, and the actual castle is worth walking around too, although there was little information about the history available.

Great views of Lisbon. From Lisbon city center, you can find yourself walking up lots of stairs just to get up to the castle. Alternatively, you can take a tram (28) or a new novelty the Lisbon tuk tuks. Once up here, there are great views of Lisbon city center, but I was not overly impressed with the inside of the castle. Although, it is a different era than Pena Palace in Sintra, this is a much better tourist site. Still it's a highlight of Lisbon and needs a visit.

All about the views . Great little visit. Shaded viewing areas give great views of the city. The keep of the castle itself is mostly just the walls and a few artefacts but again offers great views. Was a little disappointed by the archaeological site as could only wander around on one of the tours which had already started when we arrived.

Amazing view over the city. Probably one of the top 3 things to see if you're ever in Lisbon. The Castelo de Sao Jorge was a very cool place. It was old, interesting and the overall atmosphere during my visit was very nice (quite peaceful). It also offers probably one of the best panoramic views of the city.

Great views across the city. Very nice castle though it is mostly bare walls that you can climb up on and walk around. There is a steep walk up to the top via the narrow and beautiful Alfama streets – you can also take a taxi or tram. The paths are often uneven and cobbled, so wear comfy shoes (I wouldn’t recommend for wheelchair users, though I think there is a lift to some of the main parts). The 8 euro entry fee was just about worth it for the views, and the archeological museum had some interesting items. You can also buy wine to walk around with. Good to visit early in your trip to get a feel for the layout of the city.
You cannot miss . Very good visit. Historic place and great view.Quick ticket area. Nice museum and good place all around with a great view of the city.

Great view lot if tourists. On a hot day it's a great visit. There are plenty of places with shade and if you come early, great spots to chill.
Unfortunately as with many hotspots in the area, at certain times of the day it can be crowded with tourists.
If you want to go inside of the castle, it's not free.

Awesome views. Totally worth going. Panoramic views of the city, sipping Port wine, watching the peacocks, it was great. The cafe on site has very reasonably priced food, and it was easy to get to from our hotel. Google maps took us to the wrong entrance so maybe check that before you go.

Don't miss the tour! . Would recommend to visit the castle on your first day in Lisbon and take the tour if the castle. You will get to know more about Portugal and Lisbon, and see all the good parts of the castle.

What a view you have here on Lisbon... Beautifull. The view you have here (when the weather is clear) is magnificent. This is a must !!! And the walk threw the castelo is a great extra.
Don't forget to walk in the small street around the castle . There are some great graffiti's etc

Panoramic views, interesting museum. It's a bit of a climb - on foot - from the centre (Rossio) but well worth the effort. There are buses (the 737 stops just outside) and trams as alternatives to get you a bit closer.There are some splendid views to be had from within the Castello. There isn't a great deal remaining of the original mediaeval castle or of the Moorish citadel that preceded it (check the times of the guided tours if you want see those).I thought that some of the artefacts in the museum were very interesting (and very human).

It was OK. View os great.. Ruins are not very exciting. You can pretty much see only bare walls. The view of the city from the top is great. You have to wait 20 mins to see the camera obscura, but it was actually worth it.
Small castle . The castle itself is small , not much to see, you can claim the walls and towers, but it has a charming garden and great viewsWorth a visit
Great city views. Go tour the grounds late in the day and then watch the sunset over the city. Watch your step as whole Area very uneven terrain.
Views of Lisbon (But that's it). Mmmm save your time and money. Not worth it. In retrospect, the area around the Castelo would have been nicer to explore.

Best sight in the city!. This historic fort lies on one of the many hills that are scattered across lisbon this makes it so that you can get some wonderful views from here. It is also one of the oldest parts of the city, and the little houses and shops that lead up to the fort, in neighborhood of Alfama, make you think that you went back in time. Wonderful area to wander and get a bit lost in.
Fabulous at dusk. We went here at around 7pm and enjoyed walking around the grounds around dusk. The views were fantastic.

Top of the city. Not our usual day out , really enjoyed it, not suitable for infirm , cobbles all the way. Views fantastic. If infirm 2 free lifts to good
viewpoint at cafe enroute.
Views to day for!. Definitely worth a visit , and the whole area is beautiful to explore ! Entrance fee 8.50 pp so not too bad :)

Overlooking the city from millennium-old walls. The castle can be seen from almost everywhere in the city. The oldest part of it it’s from the 6th century.
The castle is open everyday and I recommend you to take tram 28 up there which is more an enjoyable option.

Great views but a bit of a hike to get there. Don't miss the periscope in Ulysses Tower.. Castle was built by the moors during their occupation of Lisbon which ended in the middle of the 12th century.The castle is an imposing structure overlooking Lisbon and there are great views to be had from both the ramparts on the lower section of the castle and from the walls of the keep. Apart from these walls though, there is very little left of the castle to view.I would though highly recommend visiting Ulysses Tower within the keep to see the periscope, which has a camera which gives a real time 360 degree view of the city. Small groups are let in every 30 minutes, with designated times as to when the talks and viewing are in English.Getting to the castle can be a bit of a hike unless one catches a taxi or tuk tuk to the entrance. We caught the 28 Tram to Portas do Sol, which is below the castle, then walked up a stairway and followed the roads climbing up the hill. It was about an 8 to 10 minute walk to the gates of the Castle from the tram stop. We arrived just after 9.00am which was when it opened and there was hardly anybody around. When we departed about 2 hours later it was fairly crowded. There is a small archaeological museum in one of the buildings and an archaeological site, however the latter was closed when we visited. There is also a cafe and some peacocks which roam around and sit up in the trees.Worth a visit.
Unmatched view. A must visit by when in Lisbon. Don't forget a glass or two of wine with a view. The walk is steep but worth with lots of tapas bars to stop off at along the way

Was ok. The castle sounds better than it is. Once you make it up the hill, then you go to the ticket office to purchase your ticket. Once inside, you are free to roam about looking and the grounds. The most impressive sights are the views, the stairs and the peacocks. There is also a great restaurant on site if you want to have a great meal.

A good hike!. My husband and I were on a tour and one of the options was to walk from the Rossio in Lisbon up to the Castelo de Sao Jorge. It was hot and this hike was not easy. Our tour guide showed us spots of interest both on our way up, while we at the castle and on the way down. Very interesting.
Great view of Lisbon. The castle had great views of Lisbon however the castle itself wasn't very memorable. Wear comfortable shoes, the walk has uneven stones and lots of stairs.
Really Nice place. You can really enjoy looking over Lisbon from this place. Really Nice, you can buy wine and drink while seeing the sunset.
Wonderful city view. Walk up along the Alfama streets to the Castelo and enjoy the beautiful sight of the city. Otherwise the castelo is quite common.

Best view of Lisbon. The Castelo de Sao Jorge is an amazing structure offering the grandest views of Lisbon. Touring the castle offers amazing look back at the history of Lisbon. I highly suggest taking two hours to go and visit the castle if you are in Lisbon!

great views.. it's an arduous walk but views over the city are great. you can have a glass of wine or beer looking out from the walls. A wiser idea is to take a picnic and your own drinks...there are lots of benches. you can avoid the walk by taking a tram, tuk tuk or street elevator.

Fantastic Views of the City. The castle is an impressive building sitting on top of the hill overlooking Lisbon and offers great views from different vantage points. The castle interior is not much to look at as it has fallen into disrepair over the centuries. Sunset would be a great time to go as it overlooks the west

Great view, but castle is just ruins. The location is nice, but you have to pay 8 euros just to get in and walk around a bit of ruins. However, the panoramic views of Lisbon are fantastic. You can buy a wine up there and enjoy a romantic sunset.

Wonderful way to spend an afternoon, beautiful views of the city. We took the trolley up and walked the rest of the way. Family rate was very reasonable. Walked through the grounds, saw breathtaking views of the city from up there. There's a restaurant inside the walls with reasonably priced foods and many shops and cafes outside.
Not that impressive. Not easily accessible for handicapped or babies trolley.The exist sign are not well indicated and didn't find staff to ask about how to exit.

The history of Lisbon in a single place. Located in one of the most scenic places in the panoramic Lisbon, the Sao Jorge Castle will allow you to trace the entire history of this city by visiting just one place: from the archaeological site dating back to the Iron Age (visit it with the guide who, at least in our case, it was an exceptional talent in the explanations), to the funny illustration of contemporary Lisbon, made "just in time", in the darkroom placed in one of the towers of the castle, you can understand a lot about this city. For the dark room you must do a little 'in a row, at least this season; but the person who illustrates the pictures is fun!

Great views, average castle. You have to pay 8 Euros to get in and while the panoramic views of Lisbon are fantastic, the castle itself is a little disappointing. I expected a proper castle however it is mostly just ruins that you walk amongst (you can also climb the walls and walk around). However the views are fantastic. Bring comfy shoes as there is a lot of uphill walking to reach it and further walking around the citadel.
Wonderful. Not only a fantastic castle but also the best view of Lisbon. Get there first thing in the morning if you can.

Great for a morning visit. I didn't visit many "sites" in Lisbon - I mostly just soaked up the city-- but I'm glad I took people's suggestions to come here. As suggested, I arrived around 9a, when it opened, via taxi. It wasn't too crowded or hot that early so I enjoyed strolling around outside the castle. It has the most magnificent views. Worth the 5 euro, 10 min taxi from my hotel in Rossi and 8 euro entrance fee. I spent about 1 hour wandering around and then had a pleasant iced macchiato at an outdoor cafe on the grounds.

Premium Attraction. For the first time visitor to Lisbon, the best place to see what the City has to offer is from the walls of the Castelo de Sao Jorge which sits atop the highest of the seven hills.To get there one can either take a taxi or - like us - take one of the communal buses from the main Square which at a Cody of Euros1.8 each represents excellent value. This drops you off a short walking distance from the Castelo's main entrance where there was a short queue (perhaps helped by our visit taking place early afternoon). Within 5 minutes we had paid our entry fees (Euros 8.50 per adult with a Euros 5 concessionary rate available for the over 65s).Access is simple and we were quickly enjoying the panoramic views of the City. To be honest there is not a great deal else to see but we did partake of coffee and snacks in the Cafe where I also fed one of the local peacocks for the first time!All in all, a most enjoyable visit and one all visitors to Lisbon should emulate!

DO NOT BELIEVE THE HYPE!!!. My family and I had great expectations of this place, but to unfortunately, we were dissappointed! The castle is not really a real castle but a replica of a castle that was build during Portugal´s dictatorship. You pay something in the ball park of 9€, just to be fooled. One thing that is somewhat worth it, is the view of the city, but once again, you could have the same view if you drive to Miradouro da Sehnora do Graça. In essence not worth expending your monies here. The sorrounding neighborhood is worth venturing

Beautiful castle in Lisbon. Beautiful castle in Lisbon. Worth a stop on your trip. Be prepared to walk to the entrance from wherever you park/are dropped off. Great views of the city. Even has a restaurant inside with these great views (didn't know beforehand, otherwise would have the rest of our group join us for lunch).
Interesting Castle. Great location above the city where you have spectacular views. The castle is well maintained and well worth a visit. Remember to climb the towers.

Go in the last hour on a Saturday!. After a full day exploring Lisbon, we only made it to Castelo de Sao Jorge during the last hour of operations. It was even more special to be there with very few people; it was quiet and still; the views seemed to be even more compelling. We took pictures in the park with the clearest sunset. The peacocks were incredible too: very unexpected to get so close to them! Very cool that wine is offered from a "food truck" type of kiosk if the restaurant was not a good choice for you.

Not much to see inside it . We didn't do a guided tour so maybe we'd have enjoyed it more if we'd done one. It was very pleasant and apart from the beautiful panoramic view at the entrance we tought there was a lot of walking around and looking at the architecture.It is worth the visit though.

Fantastic views and great terrace for eating or drinking. The views over the city from the top of the castle walls were really magnificent - a great photo opportunity. We had lunch at the restaurant terrace too, which was not too expensive considering the superb location. I thought the ruins of the castle were fun but it would have been nice to have some information about the history of the castle (a common failing of most of the monuments we saw). Still it's well worth the climb to get such a great idea of the city (and you don't have to queue for an elevator!)

Beautiful but not for acrophics. . The castle is quite breathtaking and the grounds are lovely. Plenty of space to sit in calm and beauty, with the most amazing views of the city and the Tejo. If you are afraid of heights, which I just discovered that I am, a climb to the top will be extremely stressful. Otherwise, this is a top visit for travelers and should not be missed.

A must see but not as old as you'd expect.... Definitely a must see for anyone visiting Lisbon, especially for the view from the top and the journey up there. However, due to the earthquake in 1775, a lot of renovation has taken place in the 19th and 20th centuries so it does lose a lot of the wow factor you'd expect. You may be a little disappointed if you're an avid castle fan or expecting something genuinely ancient. If it's a hot day I'd recommend taking a tuk-tuk up there! (€10) Also be prepared to have multiple street sellers pushing selfie sticks, hats and sunglasses on you!

fantastic views but lots of uneven walking and steep steps. Took the 2 free elevators up side of hill , first by giant collage of tiles , then turn left and second road on right ,not marked , then follow signs to castle. Great views , from perimeter and if climb up steep steps on castle wall, be careful lots of areas are uneven very well polished stones so slipery in the dry so if raining must be very difficult. Restaurant cafe and ice cream kiosk at top. Museum with bits of tiles pots coins in. best thing was the views right across Lisbon .

So many steps...great for he fitbit! . The castle is amazing but not for the faint hearted. He walk up isn't too bad, for Lisbon, but the castle has A LOT of steps! For €8.50 you can do so much and he prices are fair within the castle. Go, and enjoy!!!!!

a lovely place to visit. This was a lovely place to visit. We arrived at an entrance that was not for public use but the security guard took time to direct us on our map to main entrance as well as giving us other reccommendations to see in the area!!Leave plenty of time to enjoy your visit and take in all the views. Only complaint is that if you choose to walk up from Alfma district, it is not well signposted.

Beautiful view over the city. The castle is one of the highlights of Lisbon.The castle can be seen from almost any place in the city.Access costs 8.50 per person. For this amount you can take a look at the castle, the gardens around it and some excavations.The excavations were a bit disappointing. There was not much to see and you could not come close to this.The castle itself was big and nice to walk through, you can walk on the walls and take a look at the courtyard. The gardens around it are nice but not very large.You have a great vieuw over the cittyAfter 1.5 hours we had seen everything, and we have taken 28 tram back down.

A castle with an amazing view. My husband is from Portugal and when we were visiting we decided to come here we were not disappointed, the views from the castle are amazing. The grounds are full of peacocks and the tree have a lot of pigeons, how do I know because we sat under one while having a cold glass of cider and one pope right in my glass lol

Worth a visit when in Lisbon. This was a really enjoyable place to visit and explore. A reasonable entry fee (€8.50) and lots to see.The highest points offer the most incredible panoramic views of the city, but be warned - if you're afraid of heights or lack stamina, there are some steep uneven staircases and walkways to tackle to see the best bits.It naturally sits high above the city, but most the journey can be walked easily, or public transport options are available to cover most the distance.

Great start to explore Alfamma . Best way to start exploring Alfamma. The castle is at the top and you will have gorgeous panoramic view of the city. Lovely Moorish architecture. You can easily spend few hours exploring the castle, good exercise as there are many steps. All in all, great half day in one of the oldest and interesting districts of Lisbon.

Nice views. One of the reason why you should go there is the view. Yes you will see the half of the city and there nice spots to take pictures. Plus there is a special owner of this place - peacock :) Ohhhh yes, he is proud of himself always.

It's beautiful but . The local guide and a couple people warmed me that the $8.50 Euro entrance was not worth it. However I'm a kid in a candy story. I wanted entry to this castle. It's stunning particularly the panoramic views of the city, but nothing compares to Sintra.

great views of the city. very steep walk up to the castle but well worth it as the views over the city were brilliant. you can walk around the ramparts but its not for those who don't like heights. cafes around the castle are good to eat in.
Castle. Well worth a visit! Has a fantastic 360 view of the city. If you are walking it is a steep climb So try to go before or after midday!
Do not miss it. Go and visit the Castle from the ground to the towers and do not miss the "camera obscura" anf its mirror on the city

Nice palace and nice view of the city. Nice palace, and has a nice view of all the angles of the city. However, we were more excited about other viewpoints we saw in the city. The palace itself as an attraction is not too interesting. Cost to enter is 8.5 euro.

Typically lisbon. The museums and this fort are exactly the same, this prime example of a tourist fleecing is just a badly restored fort from 1849, nothing really to see, the view isn't even that spectacular, a waste of time energy and money
Nice view, steep price, steep walk. Probably worth popping up for the view over Lisbon but at €8.50 it's a little pricey for a relatively basic castle with relatively basic exhibitions.
Neat. Best views of the city that I've seen thus far. Inexpensive, informative museum, and plenty of shade to enjoy in and around a 10th century castle

Definitely a must see. Beautiful castle with great views of the city and for an adult it's only €8.50 each which is well worth it to see the grounds and the fountains as well as go inside the museum which gives you the history of Portugal and world renowned artifacts

The smell of history. What an amazing place, it has absolutely everything. Incredible history, stunning views, and experience and most importantly ...... Shade!We walked up the hill, which is a bit of a trek, but saw some amazing buildings and got a real Lisbon vibe. There are a couple of great Gelato places on the way and even an excavated Roman Amphitheatre enroute.Reasonably priced admission, and so much to enjoy, could have spent the day there but had so much to do....The views from the main courtyard as you come in across Lisbon were amazing and got better the further round we went. The castle itself has so much history and the guides at the ticket office were really helpful to learn more about the history of this amazing castle. You can walk through the ramparts and also into the main castle itself. Couldn't recommend highly enough

Quite an expensive "nice view". With the exception of an impressive view of the city it is not much to see. The most interesting character was a peacock strolling around with it's tail up in the castle garden.

Fabulous views. Enjoy the walk up to the castle stopping off to admire the view. The views from the castle are amazing especially in the morning when the sun shines over the Baixa an Chiado regions of the city. Enjoy a coffee in the cafe and stroll around the grounds. Stunning.
Travel back in time. Really enjoyed touring this castle. Amazing views of the city of Lisbon. Be prepared for the walk to the castle. Very hilly!

A shady retreat with one of the best views. With a lovely wander up the beautiful streets the starting point, this is a visit well worth the steep incline. Take some water or if you feel the mood sangria for the journey up, it's about 20-30 minutes and up hill all the way. Entry to the castle itself was about €8.50 and you need a ticket even to enter the surrounding grounds. There was a big queue when we arrived but it is very efficient and moves fast. The grounds are glorious in the sunshine and offer some well deserved shade after the climb with a view availible that has few equals. The castle it's self has been restored with interesting fact boards and lots of ability to clamber around.There is an archialogical dig area which offers free tours about 6 times a day, we missed it but it looked good. Nice cafe availible and ice cream. A must do if your in Lisbon even if just for the view.

View from the castle. This is our second visit to Castelo de Sao Jorge in 4 years, but this time with our three and a half year boy.The first time we went up it was July and the weather just perfect, not the same this August and a baby stroller to push around.You better head up early enough before the crowds, there is a long queue for the ticket kiosk. Take enough water and prepare to sit around for some time before you get in, the crew are very helpful and the place is quite romantic.The views are amazing, the watch towers give a 360 if the capital and the experience is totally worth it.
Nice view but not much else. Pretty decent shape but not much to see and do at the castle itself. It is in a cool part of town, Al Fama.Entrance fee was €8.50.

You come here for the view. Didn't have too high expectations coming here, and the actual Castelo isn't that interesting. But just passing the gates you realize that this is a great place to hang out, stroll around, and enjoy the great view of Lisbon.Well worth it!
amazing castle. just loved this amazing old castle in the middle of Lisbon. gorgeous panoramic view over town and wonderful other stuff to explore.
Good viewing point. Good for birds eye view of the city. Open space with shaded benches to sit and relax. BYO sandwich and drink - very expensive cafe there. Apart from this not much more to see.

Make this your first stop. See all of Lisbon in one go- incredible 360 views and a bit of history. Make this your first stop, have a sparkling wine with you through your visit, and then when you have your fill of views, meander down through Almafa. For more views, and old streets, and fado music, and some good food.

A stunning view. This attraction can not be missed, even if it's only for the extraordinary views of Lisbon. Go early in the morning so it's not that hot and take some lunch with you en enjoy your morning. Take a walk around in the castle ground, then go for a tour in and on the castle (don't forget to take a map of the castle, probably available at the ticketshop, so you know what is what in the castle) and then take a love place to sit and enjoy a lunch with a view.

A lovely morning.. This castle is on the top of one of the busiest and turistic áreas in Lisbon.You can have a nice glass of wine or coffe inside the castle appreciating the beautiful views of the city.

Too hot . Lovely views. Lots of climbing up Castle steps, could be dangerous for old or weak people (one person fainted when we visited) expensive water for sale and depressing cafes. Would have liked to see the city mirror but queues too large and in direct sunlight it was just too hot to wait another 20 minutes! Worth a visit but very touristy.

At the top of Lisbon. very nice fortress and it has the 360 of Lisbon. a must go for whole city view and old style buildings.Either you can go walking up the hill or take a taxi for 5 euro from the city center

Best View of Lisbon. The Castelo de São Jorge is a must see while in Lisbon. The views from the top are spectacular. The museum contains many neat artifacts and historical accounts. Walking around the grounds is like taking a step back in time. The entry fee was reasonable and we went late in the day so the line wasn't too long. You will have to walk along uneven, stony streets and pathways to enter and explore the castle, which may not be ideal for some people. There are also many steep stairs in the castle to get to all viewpoints.
Best view of Lisbon. The castle was built by the Moors in th 11th century. I't's a cidel. The are some exhibitions but the castle itself is empy. Worth a visit to take good panoramic views of Lisbon.

Fantastic views of Lisbon. It takes quite an energetic uphill walk to reach the castle around the narrow streets of Lisbon, but it is worth the effort. There are various ticket options, but we just bought entrance to the castle. There is a guide in numerous languages for sale in the ticket office. There is a little mobile café near the entrance, which was OK and there is a larger café in the centre of the castle near the toilets.There are fantastic views of Lisbon from the castle. The castle itself has been partially restored and it is possible to walk along around it, although the stairs are uneven and do not have any bannisters, so be careful. There is a display room showing some of the archaeological artefacts that have been found at the castle and some displays on the castle's history.Allow around 90 minutes for a visit.

Spectacular views of Lisbon!. I wasn't expecting much - ho hum, another castle. But no, I was impressed from the moment I passed through the main gate and viewed the city and bay below. Breathtaking views. This is a great place to begin a visit to Lisbon - here it is, 180 degrees from below the castle and 360 degrees at the highest points. The castle itself impressed me too. I found myself imaging the might of the aristocracies that have occupied it, the ferocity of battles fought there, the generations of diverse peoples who occupied it over the centuries. The castle has been reconstructed in the last century, so it's no exact replica, but it still stirs the imagination. As another reviewer said, the interpretive signage is not very good and doesn't provide much information about history (as does the Jeronimos Monastery exhibit of the history of the monastery, in parallel with that of the world and the country of Portugal). Yet, it's a lovely spot to enjoy. Sunday morning is a great time to visit - less tourists. Go early. Plenty of shade. Lovely gardens in which to wander, and even a cafe where you can rest your feet.

Super view but difficult to get to & walk around. The view really is spectacular from here. The castle itself is quite nice to look around but was tricky to walk up the stairs & around the walls. There isn't a whole lot to see/do really but I am refraining from giving it a lower rating because to view was so good. Would probably be best to go earlier in the day, it was quite crowded when I was there around 4pm.

Great views over the city. Walked up to the castle on the day we arrived to get a perspective of of the old town. Really lovely walk up the hill, not that hard and great views when you walk up the towers and battlements of the castle itself. A must see part of Lisbon.

Great Castle ... Awesome Views. Just a short 15-30 minutes walk from the central city depending on your speed and fitness the castle offers some panoramic views of Lisbon. The grounds are well kept and the ramparts are in good condition. There is a museum for the history buffs and a shop for tourist the surrounding suburbs on the way up the the castle are also a travellers delight for those willing to explore.

Limited reconstruction limits educational value. We visited with a pre-teen,and while he loved the castle, we are less than impressed. The location of the Castillo, and its views, are obviously great. As an educational experience it's lacking. The reconstructed castle itself is unconvincing and lacks interpretive signage. If is not clear what you're looking at. The camera obscura is gimmicky and out of touch with a 12-th century fortress. References to the moorish period are sparse although the city below is full of it.If what you're looking at is climbing stairs and walking the ramparts, go for it. If you're interested in learning about history, this is not he place.

Hard to get to, but worth it. We had a great visit. The views of the city are wonderful. The walking around castle was pretty difficult, stones uneven, steps were well worn and slippery so be careful.

Go there as early as possible. Beautiful place with wonderful views on Lisbon. Main suggestion is going there as early as your can, because it gets crowded on narrow walls of the castle. We came in the morning around 10 and it was fine. When we left at 13 it was already packed.
Beautiful view . Went with family. Alot of tourists and its clearly popular. Our only complain is that it is expensive but it is worth it.

Great for its panorama/otherwise boring. Not really worth the price (17€ for 2 adults) if youre not looking for a panoramic view. Museum could use a huge upgrade. The hike from san domingos church to this place was far more exciting

Great place for a 360° view of the city. Not really a castle in the common way we expect, it's the ruins of a military fortification on the top of the hill. You must climb some dangerous looking steps to reach high places and free guided tours.

Great views.... I'm not so into the history of such attractions but while we were in Lisbon it seemed worth the trip. The views of the city did not disappoint and alone made it worthwhile to visit. The castle itself is also quite impressive to walk around.

Well worth it. Well worth a visit...lots of history, dating back further than I'd realised but even if history and archeaology isn't your thing...worth a visit for the views of the city. Lisboa card gets a 20% discount too.

Amazing Views. Situated on one of the higher points of the city, this site offers amazing views in all directions. Cathedral domes and church steeples jut out at almost all points. Walking the castles walls and towers made me feel as if I were in Winterfell! (Game of Thrones reference).
Awesome city views. Good place to wander around for an hour or so. Get here at 9am to avoid the crowds and enjoy the views from many scenic points along the old castle walls, all to yourself.

A little historical, a little fake, a lot fun ..... ...for my children and the child in me.This castle complex straddling the east hill of Lisbon has Moorish origin and has crenellations built by Salazar in anticipation of the 1940 World Exhibition. Yes it's a bit overwrought and touristy, but it's a lot of fun for the children for half a day, and gave Lisbon a proper castle. In addition, it offers one of the best view of the city.Do go there on Tram 28 and watch the tram barely squeezes through the corners of the antiquated buildings in this old neighborhood. Get off at Portas del Sole, snap a picture of the deal, and then walk up to the castle.

Must visit, but try to buy tickets online. Wow this place is absolutely worth a visit! This place gives you the best views over Lisbon. You see the city, the see.. All from above this old castle. It is recommended to buy tickets in advance or online, otherwise you have to wait for a very long time. We decided to grab some lunch first in one of the restaurants. After lunch the queue was not that long anymore. There is also a restaurant inside. Not sure if many people are aware of this since it was very quiet..

Worth it for the views of Lisbon. The views of Lisbon are superb but the rest is nothing special. The hordes of tourists flock here and the results can be seen in the public toilets (awash and not cleaned). If you have a snack at the cafeteria, watch out for the pigeons who take every chance they can get to steal your food (even from the tables).
Excellent views. Not much to do but admire the excellent views of Lisbon. Careful of the stairs and walkways, no railings.

Awesome fort . This is one of the most amazing forts I have visited so far. Not only the fort but the town itself is just really cool to walk around. 15 min walk down to the shore area is really enjoyable. €8.50 to go into the castle.

Took bus 735 from Rossio and went up there. Took bus 735 from Rossio and went all the way up to Castelo, there was a long queue at the entrance; was a bit sad not to go in because I was unwell that afternoon suffering heat stroke.

Well preserved Castle. Enjoyed the amazing views of Lisbon from the Castle. Fun to walk to the towers. The cafe had lots of choices of snacks and drinks. It was awesome to look up into the trees and see the many different colored peacocks

A very cool castle. We toured the Castelo de Sao Jorge in August 2016. It has wonderful views, a nice cafe, and many interesting and historical things to see. I would recommend it to anyone touring around Lisbon.

Nice ruins with amazing views of the city . There no much left of the castle itself (destroyed by an earthquake some centuries ago) but the walls are well conserved and as you walk over them, you feel how imposing it was during its former days. You basically have access to all the walls, just be aware that it's not exactly adapted to be accessible.Some stairs are very steep and there are places with no handrails. If you have issues with knees or simply are too tired, consider saving the time and money as you get the best of it climbing the walls.There's a museum but it's no big deal. There also a camera obscura that shows 360° of the city real time but it closes by 5pm so I missed it. Lastly, the view of the city is majestic. Basically all Lisbon is at sight leaving no doubt about the strategic value of the castle. It's worth the entrance fee of €8,50.

Spectacular views, fascinating castle. Recommend going late afternoon. We were going to go midday but transport was too crowded. Glad we did something else and then went around 5pm. Brilliant views all around. Museum of artefacts very good. 20% off with Lisboa card. Stayed over two hours - great experience.
Great view of the city. From up there, you have a great view of the whole city. It is a nice place and there are many things to see. My son was specially crazy about the peacocks.
Nice views. It is a must see in Lisbon. The castle offers great views from the city and all in an atmosphere of hundred of years ago. Very nice going for a walk there.
Amazing castle . Amazing place for learning about Portugal and the history of this country. Take the electric for visiting the castle since is on one of the highest level of the city

Vacation. Castelo de Sao Jorge is a well preserved fortress with great views over Lisbon. During our visit a very interesting demonstration of old fighting techniques was held for the visitors. It's well worth the 5 Euro entrance.

Get a free tour to get the best out of your visit. The other reviews are right. There is little to see except what you can see from the outside - and that's fake. Salazar-era walls and battlements not seen in any old paintings form a romantic view from other parts of the city but enclose empty spaces with piles of stones on the inside.But it's worth seeing! - Firstly the archeological museum is great, with exhibits from all eras of the castle mound pulled together and well displayed. - Secondly, the views are terrific and from three sides - you can put yourself in the vantage point of an eighth century Moor. - Thirdly, the actual remains of previous habitation are part of a free guided tour that isn't mentioned in the leaflet and only advertised on a small sign near the ruins themselves, but is really worth doing. The tours are frequent. It took me a while to work out how to get to the ruins as there was a gate preventing access and no obvious route. In fact you have to climb up onto the castle walls to get round. Apparently this is a recent change because the number of visitors was damaging the previously open archeological site so perhaps there's been no time to put signs up yet. Our guide spoke Portuguese, English and Spanish and was extremely knowledgeable. Those big white enclosures that several of us assumed were to block off the site turned out to be outlines of the Moorish houses, complete with courtyard gardens.The cafe was overpriced and the only place I've yet seen in Lisbon with a poor selection of cakes.

Wonderful Views. No visit to Lisbon would be complete without visiting this amazing castle. We would have liked a little bit more about the finds and the history there and in the heat it is rather a trek. Make sure you use the elevators as much as possible. Taking a book to sit and read around the ruins is a great idea as many shady spots available.
Nice sunset view. You can enjoy the sunset in the Castelo, but don't go there too late. It will stop selling tickets at 5 pm.

Admire the Castle and nearly a complete view of Lisbon. We arrived in the morning and from the top we could admire nearly a complete view of Lisbon, sundry rooftops, the Tagus River and the 25th April Bridge which resembles the Golden Gate Bridge of San Francisco. Many parts of the Castle were destroyed over the years but most specially by the 1755 earthquake. It was fortified by the Romans and afterwards by other tribes. It used to serve as a Moorish royal residence and afterwards it became the royal palace. Past the main gate is a statue of King Afonso, cannons and other remains.

Worth the visit. Lisbon is surrounded by Castles, to see how they have all survived the tests of time is amazing and a credit to how they were built and the Castelo de Sao Jorge is no different.It's an expensive attraction but if in the area worth a visit

Worth a look!. A lovely way to spend a few hours with fantastic views over the city of Lisbon and the river Tagus. Certainly gives you a different perspective from up high. Moorish castle which has been relatively recently restored (50 + years) still young.

A castle with not much to see. Your can see the castle from most of Lisbon, unfortunately, once you get there there is really not much to see, the castle is mostly the outside walls that remain and the towers, the rest is in ruins.The best thing about the castle is the great views of the city that you get up there.They should probably recreate some of the rooms in the castle so that at least you get a glimpse of what is was and what importance it had in Portugal's past!
Nice castle. Nice castle with very good views over Lisbon. It is not spectacular in itself, but it is enough to spend some hours in.

Ok... not sure it's worth the entry as lots of building work on. A nice little trip if you are in the area but you can see a lot of the castle, and the little village around the castle, without paying the €8.50 entrance fee. In my opinion it was worth a trip but would be better priced at €4-5 as much of the excavation stuff was sectioned off and we weren't told this before going in. Try to catch one of the tours into the camera viewpoint room as they only let ~20 people in every 30 mins

Favorite place in Lisbon. I have visited most of the attractions in Lisbon, and I would mainly recomend only Castelo de Sao Jorge - the place is lovely, especially if you arrive at the opening, at 9am, when there aren't many tourists. Great Lisbon views, well maintained castle, cute places to sit and take a reading break, great for kids. I liked it:)

Amazing view of Lisbon. It was a bit of a climb since we decided to forgo the tuk tuk and taxi rides and did not know of the elevator but well worth it when we got to the top. We did have to pay to access the grounds but it was magnificent. Quite a few steps to climb to get to the walls but once there, the view of Lisbon is unbeatable. We were also lucky enough to go toward the end of the day so were rewarded with an awesome sunset. The grounds are huge so be sure to wear comfy footwear. We saw a lady in heels and the poor dear is probably still negotiating the cobble stones Portugal is well-known for.
Almost best sunset views of Lisbon. Interesting history and well documented as you walk about. Spread out over fairly large area. limited old artifacts to see, mostly buildings, peacocks and views.

Go early. I'd read about the queues so decided to go early. I was there when it opened at 9am with a dozen or so other people. Had whole areas to myself before it started to get busier an hour or so later. Lovely castle and great views.

Excellent castle with spectacular views. The castle can be reached by 737 bus from Rossio station area or by tram 12 or 28. A day ticket for public transport is very reasonable at under 9 euros. Deposited near the castle gates you have enough energy to explore the spectacular views from lower or higher walls ( the first in shade of trees but the latter in full sun). The crowds are less than most other castles and there is more space. The windy narrow streets with shops, cafes and houses near to the castle are also interesting.

Great views on Lisbon and really interesting Castle history. Great time here. Lots of walking around and taking in the different sites. Beware of eating in the cafe as it is really overpriced and the food is very bad

Beautiful view of Lisbon. The castle itself is not the most beautiful castle of all but the views are spectacular. You can see the whole city from above.Entrance 8,5 euro, a bit pricey.It worth the walk up and entrance.

A bit of history. Did a trip here via tram which stopped at a lookout. It would be hard work getting here on foot, as very steep. Walked around the Castle, lots of great views of the city. Need moderate amount of fitness as lots of stairs, walkways (narrow at time) that needing negotiating. Also need to watch your step as lots of trip hazards everywhere!

Good views. Didn't queue as the queue went on miles but enjoyed sitting on a bench close by and being transported into the past by a 70s dressed piano player at a keyboard in the square in front of Castle. Be aware of overpriced souvenirs shops!
Great evening visit!. Visited the castle in the evening an hour before closing. Turned out to be a great time to visit. Pleasant temps, less crowds, and a great viewpoint to watch the sunset.

Very interesting with great views!. The best part for us of course was the views. An interesting place but please take care to wear comfortable shoes. The whole area is full of steep stairs and walkways and very uneven footing.
Castle with a view. One of the better castles I have visited, fantastic views and we'll kept and run so worth the entrance fee.

Good place to orientate yourself with the city. I would definitely recommend walking up to the castle as its not as far as it looks and you walk past all the traffic and beat any other method of transport up there. The queues for the trams mean that we were at the top of the hill before anyone standing in the queue. We walked on a hot day, 37 degrees, but the walk was shady and not too steep.The castle itself is lovely to wonder around with plenty of shady spots to get away from the sun. It's great to look down over the city and orientate yourself. The camera obscura is also very interesting although the queues can be quote long and each presentation is given in a different language but we went to a Portuguese one, being at the front of the queue at the right time, which was fine as it was still interesting to see the views and didn't really need the narration.
A must-see. If you have limited time in Lisbon, this should be high on your list of places to visit. Interesting history, great views.

Good views over the city. The fist thing we found was a long queue to get in, however the queue moved very quickly and only took about 10 minutes. There isn't a great deal inside the castle, except the camera obscura, however the queues for that were huge, so we didn't bother. The walk around the castle walls gives great views over the city, however we found it more interesting to go to the various viewing points around the city. Over all, if you are short of time, give it a miss.

Well Worth a Visit. We walked to the castle on a very hot Sunday morning working our way up though the steep streets in the general direction of the castle. With help from local people we found the access route to the castle entrance. Around the castle are a number of very good quality craft and gift shops well worth a browse. The castle, itself is an interesting building with great views on the clear sunny day over the city and beyond. It has a very nice café with the entertainment of flying peacocks jumping from branch to branch in the trees in the outside eating area. On our descent from the castle we came across a free car park elevator taking us much more quickly down to the downtown area. I would recommend the castle as a must to visit.

Great views of the city!. Nice way to while away an hour or so, great views of the whole city. Entry was €8.50 when we visited recently, you can walk around the castle up and down stairs to walk around the top of the castle. Worth a visit if in Lisbon!

Great view. It's quite an experience to walk up to the castle through the cobbled streets. The view from here is wonderful but unless you take a guided tour there is no real information to guide you. It would be super to have plaques to provide information. We walked to walls and soaked up the atmosphere.
Wonderful views. We took the elevator which saves you half the walk up the hill. Be prepared to queue for tickets but not too crowded once inside. Worth it for the views.

Beautiful view of the city . On our second day in Lissabon we went to visit the castle. We did not take a tuk tuk, bus or tram but we went by foot all the way up. We would advice everyone to do this as you walk by a lot of great shops and bars. The castle shows you a great view from the city.

Fantastic view. It is not easy to walk to the castle however when you do you'll get a fantastic view of Lisbon.
Because of the crowded season, there was a long line for tickets but it moved fast. I wish that it was possible to buy tickets online.

Excellent. Very spectacular views of the city, river, bridge. You cam spend avort 2-3 hrs teren and stil enjoy it. There is also a restaurant with a terase with a wonderfull view of the city and a museum nearby. It closet at 2100.

Great views. At the top of a steep hill though some public transport does go all the way. If you choose to walk up to the castle there are lots of staircases that open onto small squares with old fashioned bars/cafes. Not a uge amount to see when you get there however.

Breathtaking views. This is a medieval castle that offers breathtaking views of Lisbon in almost all directions. You can see very far on a clear day. It has a cafe and restaurant on site. Bring comfortable shoes for walking on steep, slippery cobblestone streets and sidewalks.

Great Views. We enjoyed the castle, largely for its views. If you are uncomfortable with heights, you will not enjoy climbing the ramparts, which do not include sufficient hand railings on the stairs.We had dinner at the restaurant on the grounds--Casa-do-Leao. We didn't have a reservation and were initially told none were available, but were able to get in following a cancellation. A reservation gives you access to the castle at night (I assume just in close proximity to the restaurant). The food was pretty good, it wasn't too expensive, and wait staff was excellent. I don't think you would eat at the restaurant on its merits alone, but as part of the castle experience, it is a worthwhile dining experience.The museum has a small, but nice museum that I suspect 90% visitors never visit. Provides a nice overview of the castle's history.

Must see place. This place is worth visiting anyway when you are in Lisbon and more or less interested in history and archeology. It has a small archeological museum and an archeological area, where free guided tours are frequently held. It has also great view platform on the whole city and it is just amazing to walk on the old castle walls, even if u are not into such things as history

Nice afternoon . The castle was a nice way to spend our afternoon in Lisbon. There are great views of the city and the castle itself is a neat place to visit. We also grabbed a light lunch at the cafe which was nice. Look for the information booklet to tell you more about the castle. We missed it and it would have been nice to know what we were looking at when we were walking around.

Meh . You can take some nice pics from here, due to the scenery and the location. However, if you are willing to stay in line to buy a ticket, don't get your expectations too high. It's just another touristy place that should not charge for someone to be able to see it. Worth it only if you are in the area.
Learn some history. Aside from the truly beautiful views of Lisbon there is also plenty of history to be learned about the city and the region. The displays are small but worth visiting.

Excellent way to spend a mirning. Having read about horrendous queues for the historic 28 tram, we got up early (not difficult with little ones!) and were on the tram before 9am - only a short wait at this time. It was so lovely being up in the old town early- we were the only people there and walked straight into the castle. Kids were free of charge. Amazing views, children loved exploring and running around. Thoroughly recommend. We left late morning to a huge queue for tickets and the old town unrecognisable due to number of people/cars/trams etc. I would definitely get up early and get there so you can enjoy it un-busy and without queuing!

Twelfth century remnants. The Castle is easy to see. It sits on top of a high prominant overlooking the city. The best view though are fro inside the castle. As I entered the castle the courtyard was full of people but plenty of room to enjoy the view over the city below. walking around the ruined walls gave further spectacular panoramas onto the red rooftops and city below.A must see part of Lisbon.

Authentic Neighbourhood Walk & Splendid Views. Skip the 100m+ queue & lengthy wait for the 'castelo' tram in the city centre and head up to the castle on foot.You will be rewarded with a pleasant, albeit slightly demanding, journey through non-tourist locales. Narrow cobblestone roads wind up the hill, passing locals going about their daily business, interesting tile art, intoxicating aromas of food, old men sitting in the street & many hole-in-the-wall drink stops/cafes. Walk as fast or as slow as you like following the well posted signs (you really can't get lost!). The wait in the ticket line at the main entry may be disheartening after the long walk, but there is much to distract you here, and multiple ticket tellers means the line moves quickly. Our wait was only 10-15 minutes. We paid 20Euro for the family (of 4) ticket.Plan to spend 2+ hours at the Castelo. The information boards are very interesting and the views are fantastic. The exhibit was good, if not only for a break in the air-conditioning! The courtyard on the SE side is very shaded with ample places to sit down for a rest & the small coffee shop & icecream stand was welcomed by all members of the family. For those wanting to buy lunch, there is also restaurant on the SW side. For the romantics, there are also a couple vendors on the SW selling wine & bubbly - a great opportunity to sip away at sunset! The toilets are very clean, modern & have change tables.Kids will love walking on top of the walls and posing in front of the gun placements. A couple of loud peacocks will also get their attention. Overall, a very interesting and well-preserved historical monument.Don't forget your camera!
A 3.5. It was worth the visit in the morning before the crowds, but a little pricey. We also enjoyed walking the colourful area outside the main gate.

Must see. This is a must see when in Lisbon, the views are fantastic, the castle is very big making this great value for money and it is a lovely area. Can not remember the exact price however they do student price tickets and it was around 5€. There is a lovely cafe within the castle and toilets are clean. You can climb steps to the top of the castle which means more fantastic views.

Yes, the views are spectacular - but don't omit the historical significance of this castle. Omitting to do a little historical research before you visit could diminish this experience. Google is your friend :-)
Breathtaking views ... at a price. A bit overpriced as the only thing you really get are splendid city views ... For a price ...The camera obscura is a plus and must-do.

Amazing views. This is a castle with fantastic views over the city center. The dark room with the periscope was fantastic. You can see Lisbon in a 360 view. Take a family ticket. 20 euros for 2 adults and 2 kids
Views outstanding. Worth seeing.. Nice place to view the city and river. The castle "ruins" were too perfect. It felt like Hollywood, rather than history.
Well worth the walk. Fabulous views of Lisbon from the garden. Castle not much to look at, but if you love history plan to spend a couple of hours here.

Nice to walk on the walland the panorama.. There is nothing else in than wall and nice panorama. A bit expensive but worth the view and fresh walk under the three. On the wall, it's differentand pretty hot. Better to visit in the morning.

Definitely Worth It. I was pleasantly surprised by how much my wife and I enjoyed our time at this castle. There are large areas with amazing views of the city. There's even a little wine stand where we enjoyed a great vino verde while sitting in a nice shaded area. Overall, we had fun checking out the castle - it's definitely a worthwhile stop while exploring Lisbon.

Stay to the sunset.. If going with children they may give you some fight. Mine loved to walk in the wall and look at Lisbon from above, the view are great. Staying for the sunset was cool and we took some nice pictures, although the kids have some fight. :-)
Beautiful view over the city. Worth going for the view over the city from almost 360 degree angle. Easily accessible with the bus, tram or taxi as well as a little tiring way up the hill by foot.
Great day out. We took the Lisbon Sightseeing Castle Line tickets about €8 plus entrance €8 well worth it, brilliant city views and history for anyone visiting the city.

perfect medieval castle. this is a castle on a hill above the city but still in the city center so it's easy to visit. There is much more to see compared to many medieval castles which may just be ruins to run around. The camera obscura is worth visiting, and it's worth showing up to take a guided tour. Allow a couple of hours at least. Stunning views from the top.

Stunning. We loved our visit to the Castelo, which is absolutely swimming in history and offers brilliant views out onto the entire city and harbour.It was brilliant to spend a couple of hours just meandering around the Castelo, which has shady areas for those looking to protect their skin from the sweltering temperatures.The cafe was cheap and reasonably stocked, with areas to sit outside with a drink while the tourists walk by and enjoy themselves.Ideal for holiday photos, the Castelo offers a magnificent backdrop and is an unforgettable experience.Simply stunning.

Nice fort with Beautiful Lisbon vires . The Castle is nice but its more of a fort than a castle. Its well kept and you walk up the wall around the fort. Its worth visiting while in Lisbon but since Its at the highest point of the city, make sure you get some type of transportation up there unless you want a great workout. At the exit of the castle there is a store that has some port wine tasting for 1€ The shot and gives you an opportunity to try some white and red port wines. Also try the Natas (traditional Lisbon custard) at the cafe right at the exit of the fort called real Nata or something like that. It's very tasty.

Lots of history . I was staying in the castle walls and it was pretty cool to literally be surrounded by history. We bought a ticket our first day. It's a HUGE place ... More of a fort than a castle. Bring comfortable, non slip shoes. Our luggage got lost so I had on impractical shows so I could not go various places without peril! There is a senior and student discount.

Lots of history . I was staying in the castle walls and it was pretty cool to literally be surrounded by history. We bought a ticket our first day. It's a HUGE place ... More of a fort than a castle. Bring comfortable, non slip shoes. Our luggage got lost so I had on impractical shows so I could not go various places without peril! There is a senior and student discount.
Nice views. There nice views from many places in the castle. You must see the camera obscura. It is something I have seen for a very first time. Great!

Sunset ❣. Visiting during sunset hours was super enjoyable in this hot summer. The cool breeze and the sunset view made the visit very very memorable, not to mention the super short line to get tickets

A must visit - one of the main attractions of Lisbon.. The Castelo is on top of a hill looking down on the city of Lisbon. You can walk up or there are trams that go part of the way too. I would say you need a good 2-3 hours here. Although it is not a very big castle (compared to the castles of Wales!!!) it is well worth visiting and there are some excellent views of the city. We had some excellent photos.
Great view and interesting fortress. Enjoyed the view from the top overlooking Lisbon. Was quite a well maintained fortress and a cafe at the top for people looking for a bite to eat.

what a place and what a view. worth a visit for historical reasons but also a step back in time. Overlooking the entire city and harbour you fall in love with this place but it is much more , plenty to see here and even offers an amazingly placed restaurant however was not open on our visit
Great views of Lisbon. Excellent tour of old castle grounds with views of the whole city of Lisbon from altitude. Lots of stairways/steps with uneven pavers underfoot
