Poppies were in bloom when we went and the castle walls were a beautiful backdrop to them.The ramparts of the castle are impressively high and it's a very sturdy fortress. A nice little visit, but got a bit dull after a while. Don't stay too long and ruin it

Strenuous . We chose to go in evening and we were glad. Amazing views and although plenty of people around, never felt crowded. Climbing the steep stone steps to get to the ramparts was a bit nerve racking, but worth it. It appeared you needed a guide to go into the archaeological site which we hadn't realised. Tram up, walk down,before we knew it we were back in Baxia. Think it could be very hot in the summer or even in the afternoon at this time of year.

Nice walk and lovely view. Liked the castle very much although I would have preferred it if it had actual rooms to explore as well. The views were amazing though and made up for that. The castle is in a very nice area with lots of places to drink,eat after.

Visit to castle. It is a difficult walk all up hill but you can get there by tram. We walked and from city centre took 20 minutes. It was well worth it with some stunning views,although there are also a lot of steps once inside. The cost is minimal and is good value.

Wonderful Views of Lisbon. Castle St. George has fantastic views of Lisbon, the Tagus River and the 25 April Bridge. If you want to check out one historical site in Lisbon - the castle is a good place to go. Wear comfortable shoes with good soles as walking on the uneven cobblestones can be tricky. Also be aware that not all of the stairs have hand rails and some are quite steep. Plan to spend at least 2 hours and a visit to the on site museum, and archaeological site that is part of the castle.
Hmmmmm not dure. Because I have been to many castles in Europe, this didn't stand out for me. Cost a little to much for what you see. Glad I visited it. Great view of the city from up top.

The view is superb. Its worth walking up the hill just to admire the stunning views, the only place in Lisbon i found where you can see both bridges. The castle is great to explore and at euro8.50 worth every euro cent!!

History. You should always take time to see @ least one historical site and this was mine. Perched way way above old Lisbon you got a real sense of what it would have been like to protect the city back in the day!Do the walk up the streets if able as it's the only way to appreciate its location. Since it's up high be prepared for a windy experience though this shouldn't put you off.Superb views and better photo opps!@ Euro 8,50 it's a small price to pay for a piece of Portugal history

Majestic views of Lisbon. We enjoyed our Sunday afternoon visit to the castle. Easy access by foot and amazing 360 views of Lisbon. Be sure to plan ahead if you want to check out the camera obscura they limit the number of people per viewing (20 people every 20 min) and you might have to wait a while to get a tour in your preferred language.

For the view.. Bus 737 drops you right at the entrance. Admission fee was about what you would expect. We went for the view and on a cloudless day like the one we were there, it was perfect. There are various aspects from which you can view the city and beyond, particularly what's happening on the River Tagus.The cafe was reasonably priced for such a tourist trap and being a cake monster I'll happily give a thumbs up to their apple tart.There are plenty of shady nooks to relax after you have re-enacted repelling invaders on the battlements.The voyeurs among you can delight in the fact that the homes of Lisbon locals butt right up to the castle wall in places and so if you have no shame, you can be really nosey before they throw a lemon at you.

Worth the climb. This is a castle built on top of a moorish fortress. It is above the Alfama portion of Lisbon. It requires a climb up a steep hill, but you we rewarded with panoramic views of the city. The structure is impressive and take note of the trees in the courtyard, including a cork oak. There are also some peacocks strutting around as well. Good picture spot.
great place. take a whole day to go walking to the Castelo, starting at Chiado and climbing the interesting streets untill reach the castle. Gourgeus view.

Beautiful City Views. After a somewhat confusing climb through narrow and winding Lisbon streets, we reached the summit - as we walked the castle walls we were delighted with the sweeping views of the city and the waterfront. Definitely on the "must do" list!
Nice and interesting place. Nice place to visit. Don't skip under any circumstances the camera that in top of the tower. Nice on line view on the city!

its a castle. if only it had a dungeon for a dragon I know..... it had wine, wildlife, coffee and...... oh a big castle, my wife and I played hide and seek, kiss chase and had a romantic glass of wine overlooking the city. well worth the walk there

Worth visiting and not that expensive.... Worth walking up the hill to get there through the little streets and alleys.It's something like Euro 8 to get in. You get to walk round the battlements with fabulous views of Lisbon. There's a small museum with the history of the castle and an OK cafe.

Fantastic panorama of Lisbon. Very interesting point to visit in Lisbon. Well preserved. Offers fantastic view of Lisbon.Great old town with narrow streets and small shops. A lot of nice restaurants with great food.

Average castle. The mixture of styles has a first good look, however in the inside looks more like a maze than a castle. There are some sections that are under renovation and might give the castle a better look in the near future. The view of the city is worth the trip.

Great castle . This site high up over Lisbon was first a Moorish Citadel. King Afonso Henriques defeated the moors in 1147 to capture the castle and Lisbon and it was then transformed into a fortress. In 1755 the great earthquake of Lisbon ruined the castle. Sadly it was left until 1938 before being renovated in to the castle we see today. Many towers and fortified walls to walk on and discover and there are large grounds and lots of seating area. Many people bring own food. Gives the best veiws over Lisbon City Centre. Also many peacocks roaming around. Restaurant and shop and public toilets all inside the castle grounds. Entrance in castle grounds and castle is 8.50€. Free colour castle guide in English. Many good souvenir shops outside of castle grounds. Best to walk up from Terreiro do Paco metro station and can be tricky to find. No public parking.

Excellent views and many towers and castle battlements to climb. Once you accept that this was restored in the 1930s with no regard to history - this is lovely place to get good views of the city. Plenty of battlements and towers to clamber - can absorb a lot of people. A long wait for tickets during tourist times.
Stop on Skyline Tour. A strenuous trek, but well worth it. Great views of the city the sidewalk refreshment areas at the bottom of the hill offers great view of the town and river.

Getting there is part of the fun.. Spectacular views of the city from a well maintained castle. Well worth visiting on a nice day despite the €8.50 entrance fee, The new Castle elevator from the Baixa is free and takes most of the hard work out of getting up there.

Fantastic ruin and a terrific elegant restaurant inside. Great old ruin. It's big and fun to walk all the walls and steps. It has wonderful views and there is a very nice restaurant inside that no one seems to know about. We had dinner there and the food and service were terrific. It was very romantic, candlelit, watched the sun set, and there was only one other couple in the place. It was the very end of the day (around 7:30) and we initially thought the restaurant was closed because from the outside it looked dark and the castle itself was closing soon, but we walked in anyway and found it was open and lovely. Definitely recommend it.
Best view over Lisbon! . We payed 5€ because of student discount and it was really worth it. The view is so impressive and u can really spend some quality time up there!
Nice. Beautiful setting, with high sometimes when you go up on the wall. There are eateries there, we did not try them. Peacocks were a little unexpectedly, but charming.

Panoramic Views of the City. Castelo de Sao Jorge is one of those "must visit" places when in Lisbon. Located in the heart of the old town, the castle and its garden boast panoramic views of the city. We were there on a beautiful Sunday morning and could not have asked for a better way to start exploring this beautiful city.
Castle in the middle of Lisbon.. Since i was born 5 minutes for the Castelo de Sao Jorge i can tell you from personal experience that you get the most beautiful view of the city of Lisbon.

Really nice castle. I think it is one of the top attractions in Lisbon. You learn a lot about the history and also it has really nice views of the city.
They have discounts for students.

An interesting place to visit.. It's a climb .... but well worth the views when you get there. The opportunity to catch up on a little bit of Lisbon's history. Not so good if you are unsteady on your feet.

Huge castle. This is a very large castle on a hill overlooking the older part of Lisbon. This is a great location for taking pictures. However, it is just castle walls with a small cafeteria and a small museum within the castle walls.

THE landmark of Lisbon. A MUST to SEE. This magnificent castle above Lisbon is a great location to enjoy views over the city as it is on the highest of the city’s seven hills. From the castle, you can see across the city and pick out all the famous landmarks. Visitors can climb the towers and walk along the crenellated ramparts.
weekend in lisbon. What a fantastic place the views over lisbon and the harbour where fantastic, the castle was great and staff helpful

Essential to visit!. Price: 8.5€/paxGuide: 7€Duration: 2-3hoursLocation: hilly. Expect to walk for at least 20minsNotes: Very hilly and rocky paths, do NOT wear heels/platforms. STEEP stairs. Beautiful view, lots of history, relatively well-preserved. Lots of nice cafes inside which are good for coffee / toilet breaks and people watching. Would be good if they have signages or directions around the castle.

Not too much to see, thoug the view of the city is worth the visti. I recomend the visit, though there is not much to see from the Castel itself. I ticket a bit expensive. Worth for the view one has from Lisbon City. The highlight of the visit were the peacocks.it seems like they are posing for photos with tails wide open for tourists take picutres of them. Don't miss. Fantastic

A place to romp through history. This is a great place to see the city. From the observation terrace you get a great view. We arrived early to miss the crowds. When we arrived there were 4 people in this area. When we came back there were a few tour groups and the area was very busy.You can climb the towers and walk the battlements. This is a great experience but be careful with young children. There is a nice little museum with has a lot of history but may not keep children entertained for long.

Extensive relic.. Interesting relic of the Moorish kingdom , well presented and giving excellent panoramic views or Lisbon and its environs. Bit of a climb to get there, but OK if you take it slowly. Well worth the time and trouble!

Great view of the city. This is a very old place which is held very clean. It has probably the best view of the whole city tho its entrance fee is currently at 8,50€. A few spots to get a cheap drink like the cafeteria or "wine with a view". You have to walk up a few meters and can walk around the old ruins but it's definitely worth a visit!

Good view, but ... if you have time and willing the pay € 8.50 for have a good view of the city in 360 degrees its compensates. Problem is that probably you visit the church and the belvedere of the Grave, also the belvedere of our Madam of the Hill where will have also a beautiful view of the city. Go If you have time and disposal .
Best views of Lisbon. . Great old castle with lots of space to roam the walls and view this amazing city. You have to go simply to see the city views. Breathtaking.
Well worth a visit. Visited with wife and friendsVery steep walk up hill but views worth itGood 3 hours walking around and excellent cafe

Only for the view. View is spectacular but the castle itself is quite ordinary. Be warned that it required efforts to walk uphill to reach it though we realised on our downhill walk that there was an elevator at some point along the way.

A nice view. The castle is a busy attraction reached via tram 15 or 28 routes.Costing 8.5 euros entrance it is possibly over priced as all you get are chances to climb the battlements for photo opportunities .With no historic artifacts we learned the castle was destroyed in the 1795 earthquake rebuilt in 1940. Not for history buffs but is a nice way to spend a hour or so in the sun

If only for the view. Wonderful view spot. Absolutely worth a visit. Fancy restaurant and a less fancy one for a cup of coffee. If it's chilly you blow away this high up the hill, but the castle is beautiful and the view is breath taking.

Worth A visit!. You can not go to Lisbon without going to sao Jorge it is beautiful and the view is great! I really enjoyed it up here! :) there is a good discount if you have a hop on - hop of bus-ticket.

Beautiful!. Although it was rather warm the day went were there, we found some shady scenic places to escape the heat. If you have small children, be prepared to hold onto them as some of the upper passages are narrow, steep and a little dangerous by US standards (no railing).
Lisbon from above. . Great sweeping views of the city from waterfront to the suburbs. Well worth the winding roads to the front entrance. Fees payable by credit card or cash.

Great views over the city and harbour. It's definitely worth a visit and the tram ride from the city centre is an experience in itself! The views over the city and harbour are excellent and there's an enjoyable walk around the turrets, parapets and walls

Great views of the city. We went to the castle on our first day in Lisbon and are so glad we did. The views of the city from here are amazing and you can walk around the whole castle which we really enjoyed. A must see!

Great to see, and view from this place of the city. Good position near the river and over the city, but expensive to into The Castle. Just take in and enjoy the district, and cafes. Avoid the Tuk Tuk trips, and take the tram up and won or local bus, it is a VERY steep climb or hundreds of stairs!

Fantastic.. This is one of the major sites in Lisbon. It is perched on top of one of the seven hills with a commanding view of the harbor and the surrounding city. You can easily climb all over the walls of the castle and through their courtyards. There's a lovely little museum with artifacts from the centuries as well as a description of the history of the castle and those who ruled. Getting there is not difficult and you can either take the trolley or you can hike up the hill. There are a lot of small shops just outside the castle gates as well.

For the view why not but for the old stones no.. You have a nice view on Lisbon but the restoration of the castle seems too modern. I was much more impressed by the Palatin in Roma Is is a bit strange to find a bar and a restaurant inside a historical area.
Castle which overlooks Lisbon. A great place to visit as it overlooks the Lisbon city. Bare in mind there is a long queue for admission into the castle.
Lovely setting . Beautiful views over the city. Lovely restaurant, wine with a view, and peacocks high in the trees.Shortcut elevator can be found on R dos Fanqueiros off Rossio Square.
Bumpy ride up to spectacular views. The castle allowed for spectacular views over Lisbon. Great shops interesting Battlements not for those not keen on heights

Awesome well worth a visit especially seeing the views.. I thought this was very good; I went upto the top and what impressed me more was the views. The castle it self is very good. It cost 8.5 euros worth spending.You walk around; well worth going to the top where the flags fly. I tried to image how this would have been used in its prime. Obviously its high up on top of a hill; so you need to take either a tram or tuk tuk. But good to walk down.

Great workout, great views!. Well worth the 8.50 euro entrance fee. The view of Lisbon is spectacular, and the breeze is nice in the heat of the day. The museum has great explanations of the castle through time, as well as displays of the artifacts that have been discovered there. The restaurant inside the castle is a little pricy, although if you want to eat with a view, this can't be beat.

Great views. We spent about two hours walking through the castle grounds. You get fantastic views and it's big enough to not feel crowded. We took the taxi up to the castle in the morning and after our visit spent the rest of the day making our way back down again, calling at little cafes and shops on the way.

History as far back as 700 BC.. The architecture is amazing to have withstood the test of time! The view over the old city and the Tejo river is breath taking. The artifacts are kept in stone vault, accessible by the public for viewing. Some trees are over one hundred years old. You even have a sit down restaurant on the premises with very nice choice of local delicacies.The Castelo is also surrounded alone it's outside walls by charming cafés and restaurants with terrasses.If you're in Lisboa, it's a must see!

well worth the walk. We decided to walk up the (long) hill to the castle although you can catch a tram or other transportation. The castle whilst perhaps small on the scale of UK castles was really interesting and enjoyable. it is surrounded by pleasant gardens/grounds with great views of the city. You can climb safely up steps to the top of the castle and then walk all the way around.There is a good inexpensive cafe but watch out for peacocks perched in the branches above or you may get something in your coffee that you hadn't bargained for.Definitely worth a visit.

Let's rate the Castle and Alfama. Whilst I agree with some that the castle itself is not the most architecturally complex, impressive or complete as many others in Portugal, I equally agree with other reviewers that the castle as arguably the major building in the Alfama, along with the Alfama district itself makes my "must see" list for Lisbon. The views from the castle are superb, but there are many other great vantage/view points throughout the city. For me, it was the overall ambience of the Alfama quarter with its narrow cobbled streets, trams out of yesteryear crammed to the gunnels, contrasting architectural styles in a couple of splendid churches, etc., which makes me recommend it as a worthwhile half day exercise. But as other reviewers have said, take comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk off the last night's dinner.

Worth a visit. Lovely castle, lacking in any real information though. And archaeology section was closed which was a shame. Arrive early to avoid queues. Great views of the city though so worth a visit just for that!
Beautiful and peaceful . It's a beautiful place, the people inside of the castle are friendly and kind, have an amazing view to the city and some restaurants near the castle.

Wonderful Place to visit. My daughter and I went to this place and it is well worth your time. It has a gorgeous view of the harbor, the bridge and the city. This place gives one a panoramic voew of the city.

Múst see. This castle is situated on one of the hills of Lisbon. It is not a regular castle, more like a small village, protected by walls. Quite a nice surprise. Go see the archeological site, as this place has an impressive history to tell. Many views over Lisbon and the river Taag

Great view!. We rented an apartment near Martim Moniz and saw the castle every day out the window. Finally took the #28 tram to the castle and enjoyed the view from on top of the hill! The remnants of the castle are easy to understand - a good thing as there is no signage to explain. The cafe serves a wide range of refreshments and there are peacocks & peahens strutting around the eating area!
Nice place to get out of the heat. Shaded castle. Ok restaurant. Once you inside there are great views and plenty of breeze and shade. You can walk around the walls with commanding views of the town

Take trainers . This is best accessible through the green line, a car had crashed into a team when we were on the way so we had to walk up through the side streets but in doing so we saw things we usually wouldn't, the place once you get there is full of little shops outside, once you get your ticket you enter into the courtyard with amazing views, you can walk round to the castle and that is a massive old building, there is an archeological site there that you can look around but it's the view from the castle that really shines through.

Well Worth the Effort.. Its a long steep climb up to this National Monument and not for the faint hearted we recommend you take a Tram No 28 up to the castle and walk down, there are some interesting little antique shops on the way down.The castle is a ruin but there is plenty to see and the views across the city from all angles are quite spectacular. Built by the Moors in the mid-11th century the castle occupies the most privileged area of the old medieval citadel. Apart frpm the great viewpoints there is a permanent exhibition, an archaeological site and a camera obscura.
Great views. Want to see Lisbon and how far it extends then the castle is where to go. Perched above the city the views span the river, the bridges and over suburbs as far as the eye can see.

Castle by Bus. The Castle is a ruin - but well worth a visit. Many guide books say get there by Tram 28, but if you use Google Maps you will get an option to use a bus. This gets you closer to the main entry and saves an uphill walk. From there you can lose yourself in the Alfalma district.

Underwhelming. Other than enjoying the views, which you can do from many different points for free in Lisbon, there isn't much to get excited about with Castelo Sao Jorge. There are several much more interesting castles to see around Lisbon (some of which are free of charge). Would skip this and spend your time enjoying Lisbon's other attractions.
Great fun. We loved our visit to the castle. One of the best things we did in Lisbon. Great views and lots of fun exploring the ramparts.

Stunning views over city and sea. It's a bit of a climb to the castle from down town, but definitely worth it. Just the walk up through the tine streets and passages is worth it as you will find many small cafes and bars to sit down for a drink or a bite. The area just in front of the entrance is a tourist trap, but inside it is relatively quiet. Entrance is not cheap (EUR 8.50 pp), but the views are wonderful, across the city and the sea. Overall, a nice outing, go on foot if you can!

Awesome Views. We were set to take the trolley up for the full tourist experience. However the line for the tram was so long, it looked like it would be 3 trams, so we hiked. Nice walk, plus you got to see all the cute shops and cafes and winding streets. We were tempted not to enter the fortress, but the line was short, we paid & went in. We are so glad we went in, the views of the town we just incredible. It was our first morning in town and it helped us get the lay out of the city & see the areas. It was fun to walk along the walls, not much to see other then the view, They do have a small museum. Found it a bit dull, but nicely laid out and clean. They do have these peacocks living there. A small roman ruin area as well. As we left the line for tickets was crazy long (probably all the people who waited for the trolley) so get there early to avoid crowds.

Worth the trip. The walk up to the castle is long and steep. But there is an elevator you can take to avoid most of the walk. It was 7 euros for entry and worth every penny. The views were the best from the terrace as you immediately enter the castle. We also walked along the top to better even better views of the city. There are many shops and restaurants along the street leading to the castle; we stopped by at a cafe and enjoyed the local area. This was the highlight to our visit to Lisbon.

Worthwhile for Outside Views.. This castle/fortress is lovely for its outdoor views; however, the inside, not so much. It is a fortress (not a palace) so is hardly worth the visit to the interior chambers.

Castelo de Sao Jorge. Had only a day trip in Lisbon as we stayed in Algarve originally. This is a must see visit when in the city. Arrived around 12pm and the tram is full packed which we were unable to get earlier so we ended up taking a hike up. Castle entry of €8.50 is paid on arrival no hassle - not possible online as we previously planned to avoid the queues. The view up there is majestic, even on a semi-sunny, cloudy day we were able to take magnificient pictures! The hike down is easier as we stopped by Nata Lisboa for a much neede galao and pastel de nata pick us up. Also bought fridge magnets along the way - win/win! :)

Top visit of Lisbon. If there is one thing that you have to do in Lisbon it is certainly this castle. Not only the castle itself, but also the way up there with is different views and the little charming streets. It is part of Alfama, where you can spent all day if you want.

Day Visit to St. Jorge's Castle. You cannot come to Lisbon without visiting this iconic site. It does get a little crazy with all the tourists now but it is worth seeing. If you should visit in the Summer, the Lisbon Town Hall opens up part of the Castle for concerts and if you are a nature buff, you can visit the Bat Cave to watch the bat colony leave every evening. They also have a beautiful light show and you would be crazy to miss it.

Another MUST SEE. Get a taxi up the hill or take a tram/bus. It's quite a hike, but the view is breath-taking. The Castle itself is a bit of climb as well within its wall. I enjoy the great views from different corners/walls of the castle.

A long walk to some great views. You can take the tram to the castle or walk up the hills and steps (recommended) and enjoy the old town before getting to the castle. Once inside the castle the views of Lisbon are amazing. The castle itself is basic with a nice walk around the top of the wall

Beautifully restored castle ruins. We took the tram up the hill and spent some time wandering around the castle. It is definitely worth a visit. Great views and then a great walk back to the city with grilled sardines along the way in the Alfama district.
Majestic. One of the best places to visit in Portugal. The castle was majestic and offers lots of great photo opportunities. Well-maintained place and definitely worth your while.

A bit underwhelming. It's a castle, and not a particularly cheap one to visit. The walk through Alfama gives you high hopes of something special, but I was disappointed. As you enter the grounds there is a great viewing area, offering a panorama of Lisbon. Beware of the very uneven cobbles and paving - definitely not a place for heels! You can enter the castle and walk around the battlements. The safety fencing is very low. I would be worried if I had taken children, although they would probably have loved the risky nature. There is no signage or explanation as to the different parts of the castle. There is an archeological site behind the castle but, again, no signs telling you how to reach it. You cannot explore the excavations, unless you get on a tour. Our guide was excellent and made the wait worthwhile.

Great views!. While there is a lot of walking and stairs, this is a great view of the city and surrounding area - definitely a must-see if you're up for the climb! Great place for families (loads of kids with places to roam). Note: a small shop around the corner sells the cutest fabric bags sewn together right in house (which is convenient, if, say - your purse straps rips...). We had a fantastic time exploring this place! P.s. Peacocks hang out in these nearby trees!

What's not to love?. You HAVE to come here!!! What s great place!!! Love it so very much! Tip: take ur lunch and eat it in the grounds. You won't be disappointed here. Not just the castle itself but also the sweeping views of Lisbon! If it didn't cost to get in, I'd go everyday!

Not a must . Ok first let me tell you this visit was my older parents and myself far from being a teenager but under ' type a visit' there was not a proper option for our situation. Next, tons of climbing even from our near by residence of 800 meters which nearly killed them so I would suggest a tuk tuk ride, tram 28 or bus 736 to avoid the huge steep hills and/ or 1001 steps. Regardless we survived on foot going up. Very congested for weekday including local group of school kids. I think it was nice for the city scenery but otherwise you do nothing but climb extremely steep steps nonstop higher and higher for the same city sites. There are cafes and restaurants on site as well. A pair of beautiful peacocks that walk around among people like pigeons without concern especially if you are at the cafe as they are looking for food scraps and call each other back and forth. Be prepared for high pitched shrills that sound like they are being tortured. A quick 2 hours and we were done. Took bus to Rossio plaza as we were done with the hiking. I think I would pass on this unless you have nothing else to do. I would not take small kids or older people as your entire trip is climbing.

Sao Jorge Castle visit. Very impressive and definitely worth a visit for both for its well preserved features and for its panoramic views which are great and on a really fine quite spectacular as you pan round and look at Lisbon, the Tagus river and the Bairro Alto to name a few. If you get the Lisboa Travel Card, you can get free access to this site and others, discounts to other very attractive sites and free travel on the public transportation system. Otherwise entry to castle is not prohibitively expensive and is well worth the visit.

Kids Loved Running Around...Great Views!. The views from Castelo de Sao Jorge are awesome - great scenes of Lisbon. There are some open areas where our kids enjoyed running around and the place has SEVERAL "house peacocks." So you hear them running around all over the place - pretty entertaining.There are plenty of rooms to check out with old artifacts, there's a cafe, and to climb around the castle walls gives you many scenic panoramas of Lisbon. On the grounds there is also a wide open area which also provides great views of the water. This is definitely something to do on a nice, sunny day. We had some rain, so some of the many steps were slick, and there was some puddles and mud - just FYI. All-in-all, a good visit and worth the price of admission (€12 for 2 adults & two free kids).

Great views & sense of historical importance. Walked to the Castle from the Tuesday Market, fantastic views from the top, as it was a hot and sunny day. Interesting to walk around and up onto the fortifications. Had a quick look in the museum then stopped for ice cream.

Great scenery and well preserved castle. This is definitely a trip for a fine day. The views are stunning across to Bairro Alto and the Tagus and the remains of the castle are evocative and well presented. Well worth a long visit on a nice day.

Pretty incredible. . For 8€ it really is a bargain. The grounds are huge, the trip up the hill is an adventure in itself, whether you walk up or take one of the trams.The views are incredible from the towers as well. I really got a sense of how Lisbon fits together. There's huge gardens, peacocks, an archaeological museum, and outside the Castelo there's lots of gift shops and restaurants. All in all it's a wonderful waste of a day.

Windy but Excellent Views. Only the castle walls, but no halls, remain which was a bit disappointing. Lots of steep steps to climb so do not visit if you have "bad" knees. Despite the very strong winds, and occasional rain shower, worth a visit simply for the panoramic views over Lisbon.

Great views, walk not that bad. We visited the castle on a Monday when many of the other attractions are closed in Lisbon. Therefore we decided to walk to the castle rather than get the tram as we weren't in any rush to see other sights. We visited the Sé on the way and from there it was a well signposted 10 minute walk which while on an incline was not as bad as we expected based on previous reviews on here. A tram passed us the way and it was absolutely jammed so we skipped that experience!As it was a rainy day there was no queue for tickets and the rain stopped when we entered so the views were spectacular. Others have said the €8.50 entrance fee is steep as you are essentially paying for the view and I love a freebie, but I thought it was worth it considering how long we spent up there wandering around the walls. A great place to get your bearings of the city on our first day in the city. We grabbed some lunch in the 28th Bus cafe in the little street to the left as you leave the castle which was reasonably priced and fitted out like a Lisbon tram inside.
Lots to see. Lots of walking. Views amazing. Spent 3 hours walking around looking at the view. A must even though the taxi driver told us not to go. Worth it for an afternoon. Views are spectacular.

the highlight of our visit to lisbon. an old gentlemen, local portuguese, told us the view was not that great, not worth paying 8 euros, well, he was wrong. awesome views from up there, highly recommend it
Great view. Its a beautiful place to spend a couple of hours in Lisbon. In addition to the castle itself, offers a great view of both the city and the ocean.
The best view in Lisbon. Entrance fee is 8,50 euro, but it is worth to this price, view is fantastic on sunset, archeological site interesting with free tour, that is held every hour. Recommended!:)

Yes and No. well... the castle is not really a castle per se, it's just its walls and the inside ruins. Nothing really exciting about it (hence the No) if you like old castle interiors and gardens then his is a no. There is no pretty garden or rooms to admire, just a hollow shell. Yes, because of the views. the view to the river and the city are impressive (hence the yes)it's not expensive €8.60 it's up to you if you want a good view and no castle ;) also, there is nowhere to shelter from the rain so bring your brolly in rainy seasonHappy travelling.

Magnificent views. We decided to walk up to,the castle. The walks demanding but provides many highlights along the way. Once at the castle the views are amazing from all angles. A highlight is the resident Peacocks, and hens.

Average . Ticket cost €8.50 - was alright for a wander round .. Lovely views but probably not worth the money. Was wet when we went and steps are steep small and slippery, not suitable for the elderly or people with mobility problems.

Good views, not a lot else to see.. We went to the Castle primarily to see the archaeological site, but they are only seen from above and at least half of them (the Moorish part) are covered. There is little to no explanatory text to help interpret what you are viewing. As other have noted, the castle is way up in the hilliest part of Lisbon and it's a hike to get there. Once inside the castle, there really isn't a lot to see but empty spaces and then lots and lots and lots of stairs leading up and down hither and yon. The hilly neighborhood around the castle is as interesting as anything you see inside. Overall, it's worth a trip, but not a lot of time.

Impressive castle with a magnificent city view. The 1500's castle is well worth a visit if you have a couple hours free time in Lisbon and like history or art or just want to take a long walk in a scenic place. Although it is centrally located, you should get a good city map before attempting to visit since the entrance can be very hard to locate among the various narrow and winding streets, many without street signs.

Nice located place with desent food.. We got a table very fast, due to the crowds in line, we decided this is the place. The food was OK, I had a Sea bass, the taste was good, a little bit over cooked. The local white wine was a perfect match. My wife had a octopus sallad, which was somewhat boring, not salty or tasty, but with some sal and pepper it was OK.

Incredible city views . This is a must do. You can meander up the narrow street, enjoying views, shopping and dining along the way or opt for a taxi or the ever present tut tut. The last option is fun but be prepared for a teeth jarring ride over the Coble stones. The old castle provides breath taking views from numerous vantage points around the castle interpretive signs give the history and importance of this landmark. You can enjoy a glass of wine, an ice cream cone or take a picnic. A Stroll down at the end of your visit is more relaxing.

Worth the climb. Sited on top of a steep hill, a visit to the castle requires a moderately strenuous climb up pretty rough roads and paths, or a bumpy taxi ride. At the top tickets are not overly expensive and concessions are available. Once the climb has been made it's definitelly worth going in and exploring, and although the interior of the main castle is somewhat bare, the discovered artifacts are all there in the museum to see without extra charge. The archaeological part is interesting as well, but because of the earthquake damage 250 years ago the reconstructions look a bit of guesswork - probably not the case, but that's what they look like. Parts of that section are covered up for protection and access is only on the regular free short guided tours, which usefully helps to explain some of the features. I was impressed that the conservators seem to be taking considerably more care of the wall decorations and exposed pieces of floor than is the case at, say, Pompeii. Seeing the whole site requires good stout shoes, trainers or boots as the paths are very rough, and wheelchair users or others with impaired mobility are in for a disappointment. Finally the views across the city and river are exceptional.

A must in Lisbon. This is a must-see attraction, as it can be seen from all over Lisbon. The inside of the castle is much like any other, but you can get wonderful views of Lisbon from the top. the archaeological part is very interesting and I loved the peacocks. There is a long queue to get inside, but it moves quickly. We enjoyed spending a long morning here. On the way back down, see if you can find the man painting with coffee--his work is marvellous.

Nice view over the city . Take an ure or two and take a stroll around the casle and on the walls.
Both Café and restaurant inside.
Great wiew over the city.
Peacocks in the trees and on the ground.
Take the 28 tram up and walk the rest. It's not far to go but it's uphill.

Beautiful . This fort is a must do in Lisbon. The fort is rich in history and has awesome views of the city. Make sure you are wearing sneaks when coming to this area. A lot of walking around the facility.
Fantastic . Perfect place, amazing view, brilliant. We will definitely return and will highly recommend! Great time Wioleta & Marek
Best view yet in Lisboa. A tough climb but so worth it. Explore the whole area. Climb up to the battlements. Take pictures of the peacocks and talk with the security guards.
A good half day out. A great place for a long ramble up from the city centre. Interesting museum but real treat is exploring the old fortifications and checking out the fabulous views of Lisbon.

Some say a must see ... I disagree , if you only have limited time don't go. Its a castle and that is interesting , but if you only have a limited time, why bother? Its not cheap and its almost to busy with tourists. walk around town more, go to the castle if you really are into them , otherwise give it a miss..
Dismissed. Decided not to pay entrance fee, since we could see park area from entrance gate. Views were great..museum area near entrance was small.

A Big Sprawling Fort to Climb All Over. This is located in a great neighbourhood, and up some steep roads to the top. The fort is in very good shape and you can climb the stairs to the top of the walls to walk all around for the wonderful views (and wind!). Great for a sunny day, and not on a rainy windy day.
Gorgeous views. It's worth the uphill trek to catch the castle ruins and the awesome views around the city. Don't go in the rain, it's mostly outdoors.

Amazing castle, but poorly shown.. Place itself was very impressive, and scenery was worth of trip. But there was no infotables nowhere, about castleparts. Museum was very poorly lighted, infos were written so small fonts, that me, healthy man, could not see properly what was written to them. So place was worth of seen, but overpriced.And if you are poor at your feet, dont bother to climb to towers.

Disappointment. I expected much more for the ticket price (in comparison with the Tomar Castle) - it is only crowded and there is nothing special to see. You can have this view from other places.
Very boring, you would rather have a nice dinner instead of this visit.

The best place for a sunset in Lisbon. Go here as the sun sets over Lisbon and treat yourself to some fantastic views of the city.The castle itself is the bare bones - simply just walls, stairs, open courtyards and turrets - but it's all the better for it. You can a chance to walk around freely and imagine how it must have been all those centuries ago.It's a hell of a climb up the hill to get there though.

Long walk but worth it. Good historic castle, with some amazing views from the top of the towers. I was a bit disappointed that you had to wait for a tour of the archaeological site (however they are quite frequent) but still a great place to visit in Lisbon
Worth it for the view. A bit of a climb up to the castle butbis worth it for the view. The castle itself is interesting but a little bit touristy.
Quite a climb. Interesting historic building.The view over the rooftops is worth the strenuous climb. Great photograph opportunity.

Lovely walk around ancient castle with magnificent views. I've been here several times, but this time I brought the kids. They loved it. Lots of walls to walk along, between the turrets. And there's an archaeological dig which you can walk through.

Outside is great. Inside not so much. It was fun to walk the top of the walls to see great views in every direction, but the grounds outside were much prettier than being inside the walls. It was worth the money since I got half price as a senior.
excellent location in Lisbon..... accommodations are clean, newly renovated and very quiet. The landlord was wonderful. We totally would recommend this apartment.
Valuable surprise . From outside one can never image the view and the spirit of it. You will travel back in centuries and will feel nice. A must monument to visit in Lisbon.
Very interesting. Not crowded, great views, good lavs, very interesting and well worth a visit.Easy toi walk to from the centre and definitely no need to hire a guide.

Definitely something you need to go 2. Beautiful castle with beautiful views. You can walk around it and you can go to the top and have the best view over the city. They keep it clean and tidy and that's something that you don't see everywhere you go.

A Must see for the View!. Be warned it is a steep climb up to the castle... As should be expected since it was built on top of a hill and designed but be difficult to siege! There is a small museum, cafe, and restaurant. There is not much to the castle itself but the view is stunning and it is fun to walk around the battlements. Be careful if it's wet, the rocks are slippery and space is limited on the castle walls.
One of the best castles. We loved the castle very much. It is an ancient castle with history, actually 2 in 1. And also necessary to mention remarkable views of Lisboa from the territory.

If you've seen one castle you've seen them all.... This is likely a review based solely on personal experience and travels but we've seen a bunch of castles at the top of hills in Spain, Italy, France and this one didn't strike me as anything special. Pretty cool there's an active archaeological dig ongoing but not much to see within the castle. The views however are beautiful so definitely recommended for avid photo enthusiasts.

Worth an evening visit. The castle is open until 9pm so we decided to leave it for an evening activity. This turned out to be a brilliant choice as it provides amazing views over Lisbon and the water. The castle itself is interesting with an archaeological site where you can get free guided tours. However, the trip is worth it just for the views which I'm sure are equally as stunning during the day.
Cool place with great views. Wonderful place to wander around and take in amazing views. Reasonable entry fee. A must see for those who want beautiful pictures and/or love history.
Great views. Lots of great views and an interesting walk round. Little to see in the archaeological area. Very interesting museum, well displayed.
Small but interesting. This is not a huge castle but has loads of bits and pieces which makes it a good trip out. Somewhere to eat and drink, plenty of shade and peacocks!

A required trip. When you are in Lisbon you have to see the castello, it hovers above the town. Unfortunately, they now require an admission of 8.50 euros, and it is within walking distance of the big cruise ships. You have to see it, so go early when it's quiet and enjoy the views.

We stayed within the castle walls for five days!. What fun to rent an apartment within the castle walls and to visit the castle and then return for dinner when no one was there. There are beautiful views and you can climb around on the walls. And there are peacocks calling and displaying.
I'm dissappointed. There is nothing there. Just walls from the inside and all of this for €8,5. I was hoping i will see some chambers and what was inside, but there was just nothing.

Good Quiet Afternoon. Neat castle atop a strategic hill. Take your time and pad thru the castle and its grounds. I especially found the location and it's views very nice, I cannot say it is not to be missed, however if you have the time and entry fee, do it.

Amazing view over the city. After walking steeply uphill for quite a while, my friend and I finally arrived at the Castelo de Sao Jorge. The Castelo itself was interesting but I felt like there wasn't that much to see. It looks impressive from the outside but once you enter it, it seems empty. You can walk around on top of its walls but that is all there is to it. It is still definitely worth a visit; the scenery around the castelo is beautiful and the view over the city is absolutely breath taking.

A must see!. We went to the castle when wandering around the city and were very pleased that we did! Lots to see and some of the best views in Lisbon. It only cost us €5 for a student ticket, but would have still been worth the €8.50 for the standard adult! Beautiful castle!

Great views of the city. The price is reasonable and the grounds are sprawling! It's the highest point in Lisbon and offers fantastic views of the city. There's a really cool museum that has good information about Lisbon's long, long history. You can climb along the walls to see even better views of the city. There is a cool archaeological site with a free guided tour. There wasn't much else in the castle, but maybe in the high season there may be more to do.

This castle is several centuries old. This castle sits on a hilltop overlooking the city of Lisbon. It is several centuries old and has seen Moors, Visigoths, and others. It is huge and there is a lot to see. There are cannon throughout the place. Take a couple of hours and enjoy the place.
Great views. Very enjoyable time wandering around the grounds of the castle and taking in the views of Lisbon. The exhibition is a bit limited.

Great views and good information. Loved this castle. Great views of Lisbon and very well organised information throughout the visit. Grumpy staff unable to get up and get change. It would have been good to do a guided tour or try out the restaurant.

Life at teh top. The Castle of St. George sits atop a hill overlooking Lisbon. It can be a rewarding uphill hike passed churches, shops and residences, or you can get to within a couple of blocks via streetcar. There is a small entrance fee. The castle has many parts to explore and the views from the walls are worth the trip. There is a gift shop (surprise) and a nice looking restaurant.
Beautiful View. Lovely view of Lisboa. Go there in time for sunset, pack a picnic supper (pao, cheeses, olives, deli meats) and a nice Portuguese red, explore the castle and enjoy the sunset.

Best castle out of all I visited in Europe. Loved it! Parts are in ruins, parts amazingly intact and you can wander the large grounds at your leisure. The towers are in fabulous shape and the views of Lisbon from them are truly breathtaking.

Storm the Castle. If you are a photographer and you want to capture some of the best views of Lisbon than head to the castle before sunset. Aside from the views of Lisbon Castelo San Jorge is a fun and interactive experience. Climb any of the narrow and dangerous staircases to the top of the castle and look over the short walls as you take in the amazing views. Just be careful not to catch vertigo from the height and low walls.

A stunning start. Plain and simpel (and besides the historic part): the walls and overlooks of the castle offer amazing views of the entirity of the city of Lisbon. And that at very agreeable prices. This would make for a fantastic starting point before diving in and discovering the old town.
Ok castle . We got the lift up to the castle which is still a reasonable walk. Thought the price was a little expensive for the castle. It is cooler up there. Peacocks are noisy and beautiful.
Nice but...... It is a beautiful view pointThe garden is pleasantBut don't expect any historic pointThere is not !It s more a place for a " Balade " and picnic spot

Great views of Lisbon . The castle is authentically preserved. There are free guided tours of the ruins at certain hours - look them up ahead of time. You must get in line for the telescope before 1730. You will get amazing pictures of Lisbon and the ocean from all around.

Not worth €8.50. Waste of time unless you want to just go up there to take some panaromic pictures of Lisbon. There is absolutely nothing there but the castle walls. It cost €8.50 to enter. They could have done a bit more to improve the site and added a bit more creative ideas to make it more interesting.
Interesting . We spent a few hours wondering around this Castelo. It was very lovely and interesting. The views were stunning I would recommend a visit

Highlight of Lisbon tourism . This castle is so historic and offers sweeping views of the city. I felt swept away in a different time while walking through the stone courtyard. There's even a little wine shop so you can relax and enjoy the sunset over the city. This is great for history buffs and tourists looking for a neat experience alike.

Great viewpoint. We visited the site of the Castelo de Sao Jorge and found that although the original castle is only visible from one side (strictly speaking), there was a great archaeological exhibition and the place offered fantastic views of the city too. Definitely recommend visiting after 5pm to appreciate the majesty of the place and to see the sun setting over Lisbon

Castle visit. Worth a visit as has good views but the castle itself is disappointing. Did not take a tour but might be worth it if really interested in the history as not much information available otherwise.

Great touch to Portuguese history. Preparing for the trip to Portugal I have mentioned the key items and places of interest that in my opinion could help me and my friend to know the western European country. This castle was included into this list. First impression was it's size and the whole construction. It is really in a good condition, especially when knowing about the awful earthquakes that took place in the city. Frankly speaking it is a great real fortress on the rather high hills, you can easily see the picturesque overviews of the Lissabon from the top of the fortress. I think not only the kids will be admired by this place of interest. Must visit in Lissabon.

Its worth a visit. Well presented with great views looking out over the walls.Its also reasonable priced both the entry price and the various concessions including the cafe inside, and the guide map/book is free (take not English heritage/National Trust).

No dragons here ... . After the tram ride up (and a market on some days) you can enjoy some of the finest views over Lisbon and then grab a lunch or coffee in the restaurants to steel yourself for the walk down. Warning though ... wear sensible shoes!

The staunch survivor of Lisbons tumultuous past. Sitting above the beautiful city of Lisbon, like a damaged, yet grand old stone guard, watching over its intense yet innovative people.A steep walk leads you through zig zagging cobbled streets of the oldest part of Lisbon. On arrival at the castle grounds, take a view of the city from its original ramparts, or relax in the gardens whilst peacocks surround you at ground level and above.
Fabublous!. What a view from Lisbon and the river! Besides being a huge castle, you can see almost all over Lisbon. Inside, has many tower the allow you to see Lisbon right from the top. Excellent!

Go early, take the bus. Go to Placa Figueria and take bus 737 to within a few steps of the castle. We took the 10 a.m. bus, walked right in to get tickets, had a leisurely walk all around the castle, parapets, museum. When we left, there were many, many more people (mostly tour groups) waiting for the tour guides to get tickets. We had a 24-hr. transportation pass which is good on the metro, buses, and trams. It started to rain heavily just as we left the castle. We had planned to walk throughout the Alfama but the rain foiled that plan. Fortunately, the 737 bus had just arrived and we were able to get on it and ride it down to Se Cathedral.

Take a tour of the archeological exhibition. The castle itself is fairly uninteresting; lots of 1930s-1940s reconstruction so it's unclear which bits are original, it's very crowded and peacocks are screaming incessantly. The views are nice, though. There is a free castle tour (some tours are in English, some Spanish, some Portuguese, so check before you go when your preferred language is offered) but this is not very good: our guide did not speak English well and did not manage to paint a clear picture of the castle's history - she talked mainly about how hard it was to attack. Might be interesting for kids, though.What's really interesting about this place is the archeological site at the far end. Again, there's a guided tour, and this is the only way to see it. It's amazing - you can see remains of Moorish houses with the original floor and wall decoration still intact, parts of the later palace, and well-preserved remains of Iron-age houses. The site has been developed well - it gives a very clear impression of what life was like in these periods, and our guide was very good. This alone is worth the entrance fee! Once you've seen this, go to the museum to look at the objects recovered from the archeological site.
Must be point in Lisbon. Have a walk , it's worth it! If you can't walk you can use tuktuk. You have to buy a ticket but it's worth it. The amazing view will pay off the effort!
Quaint Castle. The wife and I enjoyed a morning exploring the castle and grounds.The viewing points are great and you can walk the castle walls.An enjoyable couple of hours to see the sights.

Well worth a visit for the views.. The Castle overlooks the City. So take the tram up the steep hill to it. Only €5 if you are a pensioner. Not sure sure how much for youngsters, but well worth it. Take your camera for the great views. Afterwards stroll down the hill to the town.

Old castle superiour view.. The casle de Sao Jorge is on top of a hill and you have a splendid view over the city Lisbon, the river and the Atlantic Ocean. Its like all castles in Europe. Old, stones, but nice to see when you visit the city.
Nice to see some history. Nice place to walk and see some history of Lisbon. There is a good museum and cafe with Terras. Marvelous views over the city.

Fantastic view in a peaceful place. This old castle, to be visited in the morning before 10 am, is a fantastic place to discover the city. You can enjoy a 360° view with the city noises reduced to nearly nothing. The stones, the pavement and the trees form a fantastic combination of colours.Highly recommended. Right after, take the train to Sintra (1 hour) to discover a completely different ambiance with the Castle of the Moors and the Palace of Pena.

Adventurous, mostly nice for the various views. You can walk on basically all the walls, so very different viewpoints of the city. Very adventurous, but not for those who have difficulty climbing (steep) stairs.

Fantastic view from the Castle!!. We walked up to this castle although many suggested the 28 tram. It was the right decision. The castle grounds was nothing to shout about...it was like any castles you have seen in the past. However the view you would get from the Castle is a sight to behold if you want to know how Lisbon looks like now...and in the past when ships from all over the world sailed to this port which was known as the "centre" of the world. I was actually imagining myself as a guard in one of the watch towers looking for enemy from the Castle or the artillery guard ready to light up one of the cannons facing the enemy ship!

Castle of St George.. To visit this castle by foot takes you through winding streets and often many steps but the effort is worth it. The views across the city and the harbour are wonderful. On foot you can go where the trams and Tut Tuts do not go. A historic monument well worth the effort.

A great view, but pricey.. Not quite worth the 8.50 euros, but the view over Lisbon is beautiful. The walls of the castle are well preserved, and there is an archeological site. I just would haved liked more information to bring the history to life a bit.

Excellent views. This is probably the best spot to take pictures as it is on the top of Lisbon, try to visit on a clear day. You can walk there or you can ask a taxi to get you to the entrance and avoid the walk, preferably walk downwards and visit the shops and restaurants, all that area is really nice.

Nice views of the city. Close to downtown and nice views of the city. It is a must to understand Lisbon. You can walk by yourself and have the opportunity to use the cable car which is another must in Lisbon.

A wonderful place to visit. You will not regret a climb up the hill to the castle; the walk itself offers plenty of panoramic views over the city. (So if you don’t feel like paying to enter, you can just enjoy the walk up to the castle.)The entrance to the caste itself is a little pricy, but I considered it well wort it. The view from the castle a really beautiful and you can spend time exploring the castle grounds and the castle itself, climb atop the walls, visit the exhibitions – or sit at the nice restaurant at the castle relaxing and enjoying the atmosphere. The place is also pretty big so even in tourist season you should be able to move about in comfort. If you don’t like high places (or have small kids with you), please mind your step: mostly it is perfectly safe to climb atop the walls and towers, but there are a few places where you could fall down if not careful.

Where it all started!. Don't think being in Lisbon and skip the castle! Nobody would understand and you'd loose one of the best view over the city and the river. You may stoll inside. There is a small archeological museum. But you should also walk on the narrow sreets around the castle. Better take a bus (36?) or the elevator in rua Fanqueiros if you fell tired because the streets are very hard to climb up!
too little value for the buck. nice view over the city. But too little to be worth 8,50 euro I feel. Too crowdy for my taste. Too little to see. I would not go again.

You would regret not going. You would wonder at the views from the peak of Lisbon, so go. The entrance fee was 8.50 euros in April 2016 and there is not doubt it is steeped in a lot of unknown history. The information provided was good and the views are outstanding. It would not be good on a wet day but on a hot day there is plenty of shade provided by the Cyprus and olive trees. Watch out for the peacocks and peahens in the trees! Drinks and refreshments are available. This is not a wheelchair friendly site but I did see one family struggling over the steep and cobbled flooring. There are lots of steps to challenge your fitness. I took a leisurely walk down hill through the colourful alleys and absorbed the surroundings but my knees complained at the end of the day!

Crown Jewel of the City Center. Not to be missed, not just for the spectacular views, but the sense of space and history. From here, it is an easy walk down to Alfama, to complete a day of steeping in the historic and the colorful.

Fantastic view. The views from Castelo de Sao Jorge are worth the admission price alone. We arrived by 9:30am and avoided the queues for admission. It is a very steep climb to get here. We caught a taxi for about 6 euro from downtown Lisbon which was well worth it, as the taxi dropped us at the entrance. I think this is a must do thing on a visit to Lisbon.
Castelo de Sao Jorge . Definitely worth a visit. Amazing. Even offered 'wine with a view'!Archeological site very interesting. Good views over Lisbon

Great for a Monday or anyday. The castle was very easy to get to by bus which stopped right outside the gate.The day I went was a lovely sunny one which made the experience even better.The views of Lisbon from the castle gardens were fantastic.There is so much to see there both inside and out.Lots of steps to climb and ramparts to walk.Many quiet places as well to just sit for a break.

Wonderful Castle and Grounds. One of the best castles I have been to. The history is fascinating - be sure to pop into the museum. The grounds and views are breathtaking. A must see if you are in Lison!

Excellent views across the city. This was the only building to survive the earthquake, sunami and subsequent fires that occurred in the 16th century so that tells you it is pretty high up. You can walk along the battlements and visit the archeological site. There is also a visitors section which gives background and also has pottery and other items on display. There are also some beautiful peacocks wandering around which attracted a lot of attention. We took some great photographs here including the 25th April bridge. This was one of the stops on our hop on hop off bus but there are also trams and tuk tuks which will take you there or if you are feeling energetic you can make the climb yourself.

One of the best views in Lisbon. View from São Jorge is really nice during sunset.
It will compensate your hard work to get there.
The castle itself has few things to see.
If you come or leave to the left route, you can use elevator for some time. It will make you easier.
And there's a discount with Lisboa Card.
Extremely interesting. The views from the castelo are amazing. The facilities within the castelo are very good. There is a cafe, restaurant and gift shop.

Very nice castle with a great view over Lisbon. A very well maintained castle with a great view over Lisbon. Very relaxing atmosphere. You can walk on top of the castle walls, great for (not to small) children.

A reminder of past times. I was only able to see a small museum inside, so for me it was an adventure climbing stairs and looking at the amazing view from the old platforms. It has once been a huge castle and you can walk around for quite a while, experiencing the different platforms and lookout places. There is also a part where you can have a guided tour on a excavation site, but unfortunately no one showed up when the sign said time for a tour.

Wonderful views. The best parts of the visit to the castle were firstly the walk up from Rossio and secondly the view from the castle when we got there. Although the walk uphill is steep and tiring it's worth it for the 'graffiti' (street art) on the way (I'm glad we didn't miss it by taking a taxi or tram). Once in the castle the view over Lisbon is gorgeous and we must have spent a good half hour or so taking photos. The castle itself is quite impressive - I believe the inner battlements were reconstructed in the 1930s but it's fun to walk around them and the towers and also the outer fortifications to enjoy the view. There's a small museum in the grounds which contains artefacts although we did not spend much time there. There is also a small cafe and garden (although not much is growing) with the odd peacock or two. All in all a delightful morning out and well worth the visit..
Great view. The view was nice. I could see all parts of lisbon. But it made me get frightened to walk on the high part of the castle.

Castle visit . Would recommend anyone visiting Lisbon to visit the castle it is enjoyable and relaxing the peacocks are fabulous have your cameras at the ready the Area around the castle is lovely and the views of Lisbon are fabulous

Historical, A must see. Castelo de Sao Jorge is a must visit attraction/site in Lisbon. Sits atop the hill in the Alfama neighborhood. The wait to get in is very long, but the lines moves very fast. Once inside you will be rewarded with a view view of the city down below. Lots to see and to do. Its a huge place, make sure to climb the towers and walk along the ramparys for the most breathtaking views of Lisbon. Make sure not to miss the Tower of Ulysses and visit the Camara Escura.
Stunning view!!. The castle of St. Jorge is located on the best spot in Lisbon, and the view is fantastic! You have to visit this place even if the entrance fee is €8,5/person.

Must see historical site in Lisbon. I visited the Castelo on a nice Sunday in April. It is very popular with tourists and there is a small 8.5 euro entrance fee. Its a long walk to get to the Castelo, but views from the different sides of the Castelo are absolutely spectacular. It is a little tricky to walk on some of the old stone step, but take your time and enjoy the experience.

Castelo de Sao Jorge is an excellent family destination . The castle is a must! It's a hike up the hill or stairs to get there but it's worth every moment of it. We took a Tuk Tuk ride after the visit to the castle and it was a nice way to end the trip. My son loved the towers and canons that were located there. Plenty to do there, such as cafes, museums and sight viewing. Make sure you take a camera because the views are stunning!!!

Amazing views and lots to do. The views are incredible and the grounds are extensive and very old. There is an archeological dig on site whereby free tours are provided. There is also a museum, gift shop and resturaunt in the castle. Oh, and there are also peacocks! For €8.50, I don't think this is at all bad (€5.00 for students under 25 years with valid ID.. Note: 16-25 young persons UK railcard worked).

Don'tmiss the Camara Oscura. The Castel is a very nice site to visit for the History lovers. Although most of the palace has dispaperead, the walls and the site are gorgeous. If you never experienced a "dark room" Camera Oscura, thre's one in the one of the fort tower and it is a unique experience to take.

An amazing visit, loads to see.. Wonderful attraction, though difficult to get to, best to use tram, then walk. We walked from Santa Apollina station which is too far. Fascinating ruins with wonderful city and river views. Very good leaflet guide and cafe facilities, plus great walks. New excavations especially interesting, excellent guide explained history which brought it alive.

Fantastic views of Lisbon city. Castelo de Sao Jorge is a must visit when visiting Lisbon, amazing views of teh city, you can take a yellow tram from lisbon central up to the Castelo and it is a free to get in and you can buy food and beer up there, it fantastic to see the great Portuguese architecture. Great views and you can spend a 4hours exploring and it is very peacful at the same time.

Really lovely. It was a very windy day and none too warm but it was a great afternoons activity. The gardens are atmospheric as are the wall walks. The tea room is good value and the peacocks funny to watch as you sit in the shade outside. I was not keen on visiting an over restored Disneyesque castle but I'm pleased I had my arm twisted!

Great experience, superb views. Visiting the Sao Jorge Castle is just one of many great experiences one can enjoy in Lisbon. The walk up there, the castle and - best of all - the views don't disappoint. But like I said, make sure you walk up for a better experience.

Must see!. This castle is beautiful and a must see when in Lisbon. The views from the top are amazing! You can walk on the walls and towers as well as the grounds. Several peacocks and cats live there as well. This is in a very charming area of Lisbon.
Historical sight . It is a nice historical sight but don't go there when it is raining as I did. It is impossible to understand anything under the water.

Very castly . Had a great walk around this lovely old castle. Some spectacular views from that high up too. Even lucked out and got on the ruins guided tour too. But felt a bit thin on exhibits for what is meant to be a prime attraction in lisbon for tourists. Still very glad we went and in a nice day too.

Wonderful!. Castle overlooks all of Lisbon - fantastic views, especially from the ramparts. if the weather is good, walking the entire site is well worthwhile. If a break is needed, there is a lovely restaurant or if too grand, very nice outdoor cafe.

Breath taking view. It's absolutly a must Wen you visit Lisbon. Find the lifts that will take you almost to the Castle. I recomend to visit after lunch. There is a Museum and an archeologic site which recreate an ancient arab house. Enjoy the Nice view and take a lot of photos.
Best view of the city. If you want to see the city from the best view,go here! The only downsize is that there are some health and safety things they should invest in.

Fab views. Took the yellow bus tour that also has a tram to a stop just below the castle & offers a discount for an adult or family ticket. Only a short uphill climb from tram stop. Not arduous but be aware of tight cobbled streets & taxis!The castle is wonderful with lots to look at it includes a restaurant & terrace bar. Closes late so you can visit later in the afternoon. The view in my opinion is worthy of the entry fee €7.50. Also saw at least 6 peacocks strolling the grounds. Fab neighbourhood & wonderful history. It has 11 towers so plenty to explore.

Nice Castle. I guess that If you are in Portugal you should go. That's what I did and the view was outstanding, but as a castle im not that sure. Also, it helped understand the Portuguese constructions in certain colonies where I've been before such as Colonia del Sacramento (Uruguay)

Not really interesting, great views. The castello was demolished during an earth quake and is only partial rebuild. From the outside it looks impressive but that are only the walls. The views over the city are great because of its location
Fantastic views of Lisbon!. Fantastic views of the city and 25 April Bridge -- especially on a sunny day! Nicely preserved castle and well presented museum!

Very old castle with great views of Lisbon. Lots of walking and clambering up stairs to the battlements. Not a place to take young kids that are hyperactive as there are plenty of unsafe areas to have an accident. Not for the infirm due to all the slopes and steps. Sorry about the negatives as it is a lovely place to visit.

Wonderful views. The Castle is very large and there are many stairs to go up to and enjoy an even better view. From the garden you can see the 25th April bridge in the background and the old part of Lisbon.

Beautiful old Royal Castle. It was a nice walk from the city center to Castelo de Sao Jorge, yes upwards but really good to see the differences in buildings and standards as we got nearer the castle.The Moorish neighborhood all back from the 11th century was really nice. As we "climbed" upwards, it was easy to understand that why the castle was build in the 11th century on this difficult to access place. Some nice cafees, bars and restaurants gave us some good pit stops on our journey among all the nice, old buildings. The view from the castle was just great, overviewing the city of Lisbon.Really majestic sights.The castle has got 11 towers remaining, and some original cannons was in place. The castle is the former Royal Palace of Alcacova. The area is held in good shape, including the areas of the Romantic Garden. Even though the palace was heavily suffering after the earthquake in 1755, we could see the drawings of the city and the castle prior to the earthquake in the permanent exhibition. And not to forget, it is a nice walk down to the city center again after this great experience, or you can take one of the old yellow trams.

Beware of timing!. We took our time walking up to the Castelo not realizing that parts of the castle close at certain hours yet the price of entry is the same... The view is amazing and I would recommend bringing a snack and finding a quiet spot to sit and enjoy the views (get your 8.50EUR worth). It was nearly empty when we went which was great! Average castle, would recommend the trip to Sintra Castle instead of you have the time.

Worth the trip. Anyone who says that the Castelo de São Jorge isn't worth the trip must not like amazing views, 11th Century forts, or history. The castle provides amazing views of Lisbon, an overview of the history of the city from the founding by the Moors till the Middle Ages and some pretty cool peacocks. Honestly, my friend and I wandered around and climbed (scary!) stairs, and snapped pics for over an hour in awe that this place existed. Sure, it's 8.5€ but it's worth it.

Must see this if in Lisboa. Wow, this is spectacular. Be sure to see this if you can. A bit hard to get to, as it is up a steep hill, but you can take the tram there (can be crowded). Not recommended if you have trouble walking. The museum was a bit disappointing, however, the rebuilt ramparts have a wonderful view of all the city and the neighborhood within the walls is charming. So glad I took the extra effort to see this.

Worth the admission price for the panoramic views alone!. As stated in the title, the castle really does offer stunning views of the historic city of Lisbon. It really is an impressive sight and very reasonably sighted. You also get chance to walk around the historic walls, which aren't for the faint hearted or those who find it difficult to walk around as the steps are steep. There is lots of information about the history of the castle and the roles it had in it's past. Overall, i would recommend this for anyone with a keen interest in history, or those who just happen to love a impressive view!

Nice view and walk. To be done ! Beautiful view on the city, nice walk in pine trees, olive trees. Soldiers walk on crenels nice to do. Worth it !Just avoid touristic restaurants around and walk down in Alfama.

Worth the Walk. Not exceptional as a castle as really just a hollow shell but the views are excellent. It is a steep walk but a lot quicker than trying to get on the tram which always seems to be full (we gave up waiting).

Great place to start a visit to Lisbon. The views are amazing and our kids had fun exploring the castle. A thunderstorm added a little drama when we wondered if we had become inadvertant lightning rods. We were traveling wtih folks who had lived in Lisbon a long time so we benefited from some good advice . . . like getting a taxi up the hill to the castle in the morning and then walking down through Alfama in the afternoon for lunch and then a walking up to the Miradouro Sao Pedro de Alcantara for early evening. Shopping and a coffee along the way were welcome breaks.

Excellent place to spend a day going back in time.. We went by taxi to the Castle because it is quite a climb up to it. This only cist a few Euros. The admission charge was 8 Euros 60 which we thought was really good value. The views from the castle walls are amazing. You can see all over Lisbon. We went on a day when the weather wasnt too good so we didnt see things as clearly as we might of done. Although we were still impressed. The is a lot of information on the way around and a very good museum. We would love to see the castle in brighter weather.
Wonderful views. The walk up the hill through the streets of Alfama is just as much of an experience as arriving at the Castelo itself.Once there the views of the city were stunning.

Go early to avoid the queues. You cannot visit Lisbon without visiting the castle. Spectacular views. Definitely recommend getting your ticket early in the morning (open from 9am) as later in the day the queues were dreadfully long.

Stroll around the grounds. Had a lovely time strolling around the grounds with a great view over the city skyline. The castle itself is just a shell but nice to walk around the walls in the sunshine (and wind). It is 8.50 per adult to get it. As long as you dont expect to much and take it for what it is, it is a nice couple of hours.

Breathtaking views!. Castelo de São Jorge is considered one of Lisbon's most spectacular sights.You have a nice view from up there and some parts of it are more interesting than others. This is mostly true for the actual fortified part of Castelo de São Jorge. Towers in all directions provide great panoramas and the long and steep passageway leading down to St. Lawrence Tower is spectacular. It served as a means to leave the castle.In one of the other towers is the famous Camera Obscura which provides visitors with a new view of Lisbon. The view were 360° degrees which is amazing.

Great guew. I loved the walk to the castle from Chaido. Discovered many interesting shops. The castle sports a beautiful view of Lisbon. The lower walls I found to afford better views than the towers. There's little to see of the tower itself. It's s fairly barren structure and the museum is extremely modest.

Great castle with great virws. This building has amazing architecture. It has great views over the city.The price is fairly reasonable. It would have been great to learn more about the castle though. The book that you are issued is interesting, but there is no actual information as you go around the castle.
Wonderful place!!!. It's amazing and it has a wonderful view. You can see almost all city and take beautiful pictures. I strongly recommend this castle.
Best view of Lisbon. Quite pricy for Lisbon but the view of the City is splendid! Some of the towers allow you to be pretty alone despite the crowd.
