The queues were even longer when we were leaving, but although we didn't make it in we had a lovely afternoon in the area! The elevators are a great way to avoid the hills.

It had to be done. . Unfortunately we were only able to get up there at twilight, and arrived nearby on the team which was an adventure in itself. The hazy mist which had shrouded the view all morning cleared in the afternoon, but was coming in again from the Tejo as it cooled. Nevertheless, we concluded that on a clear sunny day this would be a magnificent view and walk. We walked down to the busy centre of town.

Perched high above Lisbon. The castle has impressive (and in places, well restored) stonework. The views of Lisbon from the ramparts are the best you can get. We took the tour of the archeological area, and were interested to learn of the varied history of the site. This would be one of your must hit spots.

What a great piece of history. The back supply gate was just up the street from our apartment. It was just a series of right turns to get to the entrance. That was a super advantage with all the climbing throughout Lisbon. As you walk around the fortification you can see all the levels of security. The outer wall, the dry moat, the chinks in the walls for shooting. The multiple levels of towers with that fantastic view was the crown on the security of the castle. It was quite a hike up and down stairs to get around the entire expanse. In a quiet section there is an archeological site that contains remains from three periods of history of the site. Most of it is covered for protection of the remaining artifacts but there is a schedule for free tours which is really worth the time. The 1st era represented was the Iron Age (7th-3rd c BC), there is a Moorish Quarter next 11th-12th c and finally the Palace 15-18th c. The artifacts, seeing the layout of the housing and administrative areas are subtle and very low key. Bits of special tiles etc. are highlighted by the tour guide who really puts the life back into this significant area giving it a fullness that enhanced our visit. We almost missed the lower level museum, well worth seeing.

Beautiful views of the city!. Go late in the evening for nice views of the city and no crowd. We were able to walk around and take a lot of photos with hardly anyone else there! A welcome change after a day in touristy Sintra.It's a bit of hike uphill to get there. There's an elevator on Rua da Fanquieros near the wine shop which will take you up a few streets. Then walk across the street and you will see another elevator to the castle (it's near a grocery store). These will save your life!

Arrive at opening time for the best view and short lines. Castelo de São Jorge provides an amazing view over Lisbon. The view is especially bright in the morning, when the sun is at one's back. There's much to see here and the map provided at the ticket office was quite useful.

Great views. The castle itself is nice if you haven't been to many before. But for me what made the place was the charming streets on the way up and the outstanding views of Lisbon. Had a nice time visiting. Recommend.

Lisbon's Castle. You get tram 28 to this castle on the hill good view of the boats in the harbour steep walk to the castle good views from the castle top of the town around. Walk around the castle walls, so some steep steps. Places to eat just outside the castle walls.

A castle is different from a palace.... I never thought about these things before I visited this castle of Saint Jorge. With a nephew-in-law and my husband, we rounded up every corner of this old ruins and wow...it didn't only give you a glimpse of the monarchy in olden times but also a magnificent view of Lisbon, the cidade. It's truly fascinating!

Definitely worth seeing. It was a hike to get up to this castle, but the views of the city are definitely worth the trouble. When we arrived there was a pretty long line, but it moved relatively fast, so in about 20 minutes we were in. On a gorgeous day like ours it was perfect for taking pictures, 360 degrees! It is also situated in a good neighborhood, with good restaurants, just make sure you get in one before lunch closing time (which is around 2:00-2:30 PM).

Nice castle on hills to give you a good view of the city and the mountains across the river, but nothing too special. We missed the stop when we took the bus up. You need to get off when you see the plaza with the open view of the river/sea. Then walk back to find a small alley that leads to the castle. We bumped into a few lost tourists when we left, the signs are not clear.The castle was nice, sitting on the top of the hill giving you a really good view. But nothing too special, I would prefer spending more time on the castles in Sintra.although we did get a picture that we really liked from an artist selling her work inside the castle area (outside the old castle gate) . she even draw a cartoon rooster on the package of the painting.All in all, good place to see some old architecture, but you won't feel you missed a lot of things if you skip this one.
Very enjoyable visit. Well worth making the effort to visit Castelo de Sao Jorge. I spent about three unhurried hours having a look around the place and admiring the views of the city.

Pretty views of city. This is an interesting castle where you really get to walk around on the edges of the castle walls and pop into each one of the towers. We arrived just about an hour before the sun was setting for some gorgeous views. Beware all the tourist trap shops on the walk up to the castle!

Unremarkable castle but with great views. The Castle is quite interesting and worthy of a visit but the real delight is the great views of Lisbon from the walls. There is also a very good restaurant within the walls!

Take a Tuk-Tuk Up!. So, you know that you'll end up at the castle at some point on your trip, so you may as well save yourself the uphill walk and hop on a Tuk-Tuk from the Praca do Comercio! The castle is really a cool place to walk around and it's big enough that the crowds aren't a factor. We followed the guide map and did okay, but I suspect that the history would better come alive if you could get some kind of a tour.
Fortified castle beautifully preserved. At the top of a hill overlooking the city, a wonderfully preserved fairytale castle. Get a cab or tram up there and walk back through Alfama.

A walk with a view. We loved getting to the top to see the castle. A lovely park to stroll around. You can even get a glass of wine! We heard it gets crowded on the weekends. it was delightful late afternoon.

Not worth the price! . Went to the castle today and were a little stunned that we paid 8.50 euro for a fairly average attraction. The views were lovely, but the castle itself was underwhelming and most things were blocked off. Compared to other similar sights in Spain and even the tower in Porto I don't think the price was reasonable. I would find out if there was a free time to access the castle and go then, wasn't worth it for the price!
Amazing, Amazing, amazing . An absolute must do. Beautiful views. Had a wine from wine with a view - and that is an understatement.

A must see in Lisboa. One of the best views of Lisbon. The journey there is amazing on the tram and the views are breath taking. I recomend to arive there 30 min before sunset for a great spectacle of lights.

Stunning views of Lisbon. It's worth coming up here just for the views of Lisbon as it really does give you a good perspective of the whole city. The castle itself is pretty interesting and has some good history to tell, but the views are what made it for me.
Sensible admission price and reasonable selection of food/drink outlets too.
amazing view from the top of the castle. The castle itself it not amazing from the insight. But if you buy a ticket to the castle you can enjoy looking down on the city. The view is incredible!
a must see in lisbon. We went as a couple and enjoyed the castle immensely - great views inside and fantastic views of the city from the castle's walls.

Not sure if it is worth paying for it. The area of the castle is beautiful definitely go and explore on your own. We were advised by our host and another local not to pay to enter the castle as you only get a great view - for alot of money. It has been reconstructed apparently and it is not very accurate from the historic point of view - that is what we have been told. There are plenty of nice free view points! Go and explore Alfama - the old neighbourhood of Lisbon!
The place to be on a clear, sunny day. The views were amazing. Lots of places to sit and enjoy the views. Don't expect a palace or much of a museum.
Beautiful castle. Beautiful castle. Wonderful views from the top. Very nice for the kids. Not a bad entrance fee either.
A must see. We loved this castle. It is really old and feels like a no nonsense military castle. It is in ruins and that made it more attractive to me. View of Lisbon from the top is beautiful.

Magnificent views.. Take a taxi to the top of the hill, enjoy the view and then walk down through the streets outside of the castle. We got there around sunset and the view was exceptional. The walkways along the top of the walls are not really handicap accessible and some of the stairs are steep with no railings. But there is also a great view from the plaza which has no stairs.
Cool views and history. This should really be done the first day of your visit. It lays the whole city out before you and also presents a historical perspective.

Nice place. The castle is very impressive and it's fun to walk around. When you look at this amazing structure you get a sense of how it was back then, and that this castle was probably able to provide excellent defense against invaders. It is definitely worth a visit.

Excelent Super viewas of Lisbon. The castle is on top of a mountain that can be seen from the city of Lisbon. It is an extraordinary visit by bus, electrical trolley, taxi. Pictures taken from the castle are exceptional beautifull. One of the best cyneris in Lisbon.
Lovely for a wander. We went on a gorgeous day in October and the view was great. Take a book and enjoy a litte wander around.

Fabulous views from this hilltop castle.. The castle offers fantastic views over the city and the river so worth it for those alone. You don't get the best insight into life at the castle, there is a small museum but there are hardly any signs when you're walking the castle ruins so it's quite hard to know what was used for what. If you really want to go to the camera obscura, make that your first stop to find out when the next tour is. And queue early, we queued but then were told they were full and the next tour was not for another hour. Not a deal-breaker for us but it might be for others. There is a restaurant, a shop - and peacocks! We enjoyed it and wouldn't have missed it but couldn't help feeling they could do more to make this interesting and informative for the visitor.
Great top of a wonderful city!. THe icing in the cake of the most inviting and cozy city! So much beauty and history! Don't miss it!
Wonderful view! . I wonderful area if you want to spend few minutes In a quiet place and to see the city! Here was my first place where I went in my holiday to Lisbon and I wasn't disappointed !

Great views . We decided to walk up from the plaza do comercio instead of taking the tram up. The walk-up is through some steep and windy streets but it is well worth it. The castle has an 8€ entry fee which is well worth it given the sweeping views of the city.

Amazing views.. We walked up to the Castle from the city. It was steep but gradual and a straight forward route. As pensioners the cost of entry was acceptable. There are plenty of ramparts to walk around and the structure is impressive and the views over all aspects of the city and river are wonderful. We enjoyed the visit and were glad we had made the effort as from the city centre it looks a long way.

Amazing views. It was well worth taking the tram up to this castle as the views across Lisbon are fabulous. When we were there it was warm and sunny and there was a mist settled under the bridge. Walk around the walls and then enjoy the walk down. There is a man who cuts out patterns on coins and makes them into pendants on leather so take him any interesting coins.

Beautiful views but limited access to archeological site . Stunning views - probably the best in the city - and we went on a truly beautiful day. However there isn't much to actually see or do at the castle - even the archeological site was mainly covered up and there wasn't much to learn there so that could be hugely improved

Very costly view.. Entrance fee was eight euro fifty cents. Obviously that 99% reviews on this site was about the panoramic view, and so, how about the castle? The ticket fare increased, while no other functions were improved. I totally understand it costs to maintain a historical site. But, why people pay such money on natural scene? It wasn't a private owned hotel roof, on the contrary, it was a government state. They charge so much for such beautiful view of the city itself. Blocked the whole open field, and gaining money from tourists. It is not appreciated at all.

Beautiful view but too expensive. What remains of this castle is nice but not outstanding. View is great although not unique in Lisbon. A little bit too pricy and certainly oversold to my point of view. If you have limited time in Lisbon you can miss it.

Beautiful views. Amazing views from the castle but not the greatest castle Ive ever been to. Its preserved very well & is a little over-priced. One thing for certain you'll get a work out from your visit. Lots of steps............lots & lots of steps.
Worth The Visit. Excellent views of Lisbon and interesting History, use the tram if you do not like walking up hills.

Beautiful castle but.... It may be a beautiful castle but I personally think that the entrance ticket is quite expensive, 8,5 euros I remember. If you go in just to see the view of Lisboa then you should consider other "mirador" which offers you more fantastic view. , Mirador do Graça, Mirador do Santa Luzia, Portas do Sol to name a few.

A 360º panoramic view on Lisbon. Castelo de Sao Jorge can be reached using the tramway No. 28 then a bus (or a walk).The visit enabled us to have a global view on the city on our first day in Lisboa.Archeological remains are shown on the North-Eastern side of the castle.The terrace with a view on Praca do Comercio and the river is certainly perfect to watch the sunset (but we preferred to do it from the hill where Chapel Santo do Monte is located).A 15-min. show on the top of walls (yes you gotta climb) presents a live panoramic view of the city thanks to optical lenses. It is quite interesting.We spent 2 hours in the castle to take the time to relax.
spend a whole day here. We spend almost a whole day in here. Massive grounds and a lot to see (if you consider it only costs 8e). It was a rainy day but we didnt mind!

A Must Do In Lisbon. The iconic castle sits high above the old town (Alfama) and provides superb views of Lisbon. The ramparts have been well maintained and you can walk all around. There is plenty of associated history of which the guide booklet gives a brief outline. For the fine detail you might want to get a local guide or a specialist book. We waited patiently for the Camera Obscura but the technology is dated, not that impressive and made even less appealing by being conducted in Portuguese (there are some presentations in other languages too). Entry to castle esplanade and ramparts (including Camera Obscura was 8.50 Euros. Best are the views.

A Lisbon heritage. This is a historical place to visit, especially because Portugal was one of the most active country in the world in terms of navigation and colonization to other countries during the 15th to 17th centuries. And Castelo de Sáo Jorge is the most important heritage and symbol of that rich Portugal period of history. You can get there by tram 28, which is one of the famous line in Lisbon. From the tram stop to walk over the hill is needed.

Good but baron. Don't get me wrong, as a castle it's good. There are walls and turrets and walkways but it is baron. There is no history or story or things to look at. Climbing up the walls you can see a bit of the city but there is no one good vantage point to view the castles (disclaimer: did not go into the photo obscure). Looking up at the castle is actually the same, because of all the buildings it is very hard to get much more than a bit here and there. Did not know that the archeological site was by schedule so missed that which was a pain.Seriously recommended the political prison! Overview of the city from the café are the best and looking down on the cathedral.

A MUST. As first time visitors we visited the castle. The views over the city are great. We also had lunch in a modern cafe situated in the castle with the option of eating outside. In the garden next to the cafe were about 7 Peacocks who wandered about the tables but did not bother the people but would eat scraps if offered.Over 65's pay 5 Euro entrance instead of full price which is 8.50 Euro so make sure to carry age I.D. It is advisable to wear walking shoes as the road up the the castle is hilly and rough.

Long climb and entrance not obvious. Maybe better to go on the tram, but we walked up from Alfama. We found a back entrance then walked right round the walls outside the castle to the ticket entrance. The castle is huge, I wouldn't bother to go round the oldest sections as they are just some walls, but the museum behind the restaurant is worthwhile. Even on a quiet day there were 15 people for the Camera Obscura , so we just walked the battlements. Impressive city views and suggest timing a visit for sunset. There is a wine waggon in the grounds so you can buy a regional wine at sunset (5pm opening ?)

Nice but very crowded. The views are among the best in the city, but unless you get there early in the morning, it takes a lot of time to get tickets because it is a very very crowded place. Also beware for pickpocketing!
Well worth a visit on a clear day. Lovely castle with great views of the city. Well worth the €8 entrance fee. Was one of the highlights of a fantastic city.

A Great Experience. This is a tremendous old castle, and a must visit when in Lisbon. Situated high on a hill in the 'old town', there are great views over Lisbon. There is tremendous historical significance associated with this castle, and the stroll through the 'old town' reinforces the historical significance.

The best view in Lisbon. At the top of the Alfama is the Castle of St. George. Begin your visit here with its panoramic view of the city. You can see everything from this vantage. This is a great place for kids who want to climb the walls and pretend to spy invaders. There is a restaurant and bar if you need a rest.

Castelo de são jorge. Very beautiful place to see and visit in Lisbon! If the weather is good you must go there. You will see great views of Lisbon's rooftops. The castle it self is very impressive and interesting. And you may taste Port while you are there...

Worth visiting for the view. The castle can only partly be reached by public transport and would be very difficult for anyone with a mobility problrm because the final part is very steep, so consider using a taxi or tuktuk. The castle is not intact apart from the towers one of which houses a camera obscura. There is a marvellous view across the city from all angles.
Stunning views!. Worthwhile the walk up the hills and the entrance ticket to see the stunning views over Lisbon city.

Worth to see and nice view of Lisbon. Castle is nicely located on top of a hill and offers nice views on Tagus river and city.
Entrance fee is around 8€.
There is a periscope on top of a tower allowing to have a panoramic view with all explanations given by a guide.
There are some peacocks moving close to the restaurant/coffee area.

Interesting structure with amazing views of the city. The castle had very cheap entrance, especially for students. There was also a café there which offered drinks and food if you fancied it. The castle had simply breathtaking views of the city and you could get a panoramic view across the coast and the city.

Great views. Plenty of castle walls to walk on with great views. It was 8.50 entrance, not bad value. There is a restaurant, a museum, a gift shop & an exhibit on the camera obscure, which is only for a max of 20 unfortunately we missed it. Good signage in English.

Truly a "TOP" site to see in Lisbon!. What can we add that others (and guide books) haven't? Our party of 4 took a taxi UP the steep hill to the entrance of Castelo de Sao Jorge ... then spent a leisurely 3+ hrs touring the grounds on a gorgeous September day. After a glass of wine on the terrace near the overlook, we then leisurely strolled DOWN the hilly streets taking in the local atmosphere along the way. A 'bonus' at the site was that we were lucky to catch up to and join a guided tour of the ongoing archaeological 'dig' that's on site.~ Wear comfortable shoes~ Take your camera & binoculars ~ Don't rush yourselves! Allow for at least 3-4 hrs!~ Choose to go on a sunny day if you can.
What a view!. The castle is beautiful! You can take lots of nice pictures from up there. The view is amazing from there.

If you have a fear of heights, beware. The views are stunning from the castle. However, quite often you are walking along a very narrow, very high path with only a small bar for safety. At one point, I was hugging the wall while another visitor was trying to squeeze past me, and there was the flimsiest of barrier keeping us from going straight down into the courtyard.
The view!. The best thing about this castle is the view you get to see for the city of Lisbon and the photos you'll take .. we got a little bit lost going up to the castle but it's worth it!
November in Lisboa 2015. Great views and a lovely visit. It is perfectly placed where you can see the city, bridge, incredible sunsets and many nice places to sit. Peacocks and cats are unexpected.
Lisbon. Well worth the walk up some very steep steps if you are interested in history.The views from the castle over the city are marvelous.

A top attraction. The castle is large, with many interesting features apart from the obvious attraction of walking the walls and enjoying the great views to the city below. A visit will occupy half a day, particularly if you choose (as I did) to walk up. Be warned, it's a steep climb!

Excellent view and camera obscura. Castelo de Sao Jorge offers you a wonderful view over Lisbon. It is an area of the old medieval citadel, consisting of castle and ruins of the former royal palace. This is a must see place for a tourist but don't miss camera obscura! I can highly recommend that for you. It is impressive, if the weather is fine, this optical system of lenses and mirrors provides view of the city in real time. It is also very funny to stay in a room and see cars, boats and people moving all around the city.

Superb views, great space. Well worth the climb to come here. Amazing views of the city. There are plenty of quiet, shady areas here, plus restaurant available. Would suggest bringing a book and spending a few quiet hours enjoying this magnificent space.

LARGE INTERESTING CASTLE WITH GREAT VIEWS OF THE CITY. As the castle is on the top of a hill (hence everyone talking about the views) I recommend using the tram (12 or 28 will get you there for 1.25 euro when using viva viagem card) or the 737 bus. The grounds are extensive and the castle itself full of history. The café was very good there and we stopped for a quick drink. The cathedral is very close by as well and it takes about 10-15 minutes to walk back down into the city centre. 8.50 euro in for a good couple of hours of sightseeing.

Excellent view; neat opportunity to climb the walls.. Impressive view over Lisbon; the Castelo de Sao Jorge is particularly memorable for offering the opportunity to walk all along the walls (seeing both remnants of a Moorish fort and an older, Bronze Age settlement). The small museum that features artifacts from both Christian, Moorish, and older settlement is a quick walk and not worth too much time. The things not to miss here is the general view over the city and the opportunity to walk the battlements.Worth the trip and ticket if you're into castles, though there isn't a ton here (the castle itself is essentially barren, the peacocks on the grounds were an unanticipated surprise).
Beautiful view. Went by taxi, great views. There is a restaurant there and some peacocks walking around. It was a good starting point in the alfama area, as you then can walk down

Stunning Views. This is an old castle originally built by the moors in the 11th century. It is on top of one of the highest hills in Lisbon overlooking the center of the city. It is well preserved and such a historical place. I really enjoyed my visit. Be warned its a lot of walking and climbing stairs.

Great views of Lisbon!. To be honest, we had a great time here - (with reduced entrance fee with a Lisbon card) but the main thing is the view of the city from the castle walls. We enjoyed walking up and down the steps of the various towers but the spaces within the ruins are empty. There is a museum with artifacts but we did not go in to this section. We had a fun ride up to the castle in a tram and enjoyed a long walk down through the windy cobbled streets of Alfama which reminded us of Monmartre in Paris.
A High Point In Every Sense. The view across the city is, in itself, worth the visit. Other portions of the castle and the rich history it encompasses makes this a must item for a visit to Lisbon.
Interesting . One of the better sights in Lisbon. The peacocks roaming around are an added attraction. Definitely worth a morning or afternoon. Much Portuguese history is invested here.

Great views but expected it to be bigger. They say the views from this castle are mesmerizing.. and mesmerizing they were. Getting to the castle is certainly not easy other than via tram or the tours but when we got inside it only took about an hour to explore. Whatever the case this place is a must for those visiting lisbon.

Great Views but Little More!!. If you're into a pile of old and broken stones (with little form or function) then a visit to this former castle is for you - otherwise don't waste your money as all you'll see is a view across the city (which isn't particularly inspiring).Wear comfortable footwear as any visit is an assault course (many totally inaccessible areas to anyone without full mobility) containing lots of high steps and stairs - leading to nothing!Very disappointing!!

Best view of Lisbon. The castle was built in the eleventh century by the moorish people that lived here and was conquered by the first king of Portugal and his people, coming from the north. Today it is the best place to look over Lisbon, though the entrance price should be less expensive.

Amazing castle. Do yourself a favor and make the trip to the Castelo, worth every step.....even in the rain! Panoramic views of Lisbon are incredible. A highlight of your Lisbon visit, and you can burn off some of those lovely pastries that you enjoyed earlier!

Ancient, historic but not that fantastic . This place is of course very historic and tourists flock this place as expected. Honestly though, other historic places around the world, e.g. turkey have much better places.

Castle on the hill. We thought about getting a bus up to this castle but in the end decided to walk. Be prepared for many steps up to this huge building. Better signposting would help you find the entrance when you arrive on foot as the local streets nearby gave no clues to the entrance so we just kept going higher and higher. There is a lot of graffiti in the area, some of it is very artistic but some is just scruffy and doesn't enhance the experience or architecture. Once inside though the castle is well preserved and you can explore to your hearts content. The views are outstanding and there are lots of viewpoints. The whole site is refreshingly uncommercial so if you expect snack bars and trinkets then look elsewhere. There is lots of archeological information for the site and the views are amazing. Did I already say that?

Best views of Lisbon from here. We took the Grey Line minibus as it is a very steep walk to the top, NB not many seats so best to get on at stop 1, an alternative is a taxi, putput trike or tram.Castle is a ruin, mainly flat inside, with well-preserved walls that you can walk around although some steep steps to access the higher levels so not for those who have poor mobility. However, great views from the ground level walls as well as the top of the castle. There is a small exhibition of artefacts plus a restaurant, coffee bar and gift shop. Outside plenty of small shops and cafes/restaurants. entrance cost c 10 euros., less if you show your Greyline ticket.
Views. The castle itself isn't that impressive however the views from the walls and towers are amazing. We watched the sunset on a warm evening in November !!!!

Could be more.. A beautiful place, no doubt about it. A fantastic view over Lisbon, and that is it. For 8,5 Euros I expected more. The relics inside the castle has only a vague explanation of the supposed date it was manufactured but no indication as to where it was found, when it was found etc... And there is also the picturesque trolley trip to the castle wich provides a historic view of what a maze the city is.

Wonderfull view when going by sunset. The castelo is wonderfull to visit on it's own but if you can, try going by sunset. The view over the city is amazing and the orange light makes it even more fairytale like. When you leave you can walk down trough Alfama with his beautiful illuminated small streets. The castelo itself is not really big and contains mostly ruins without explanation of what the used to be. But it's definatly worth a visit.

A Great Outing. The Castelo de Sao Jorge, situated on a hill overlooking Lisbon, is an excellent outing for the family. The structure, built over centuries, traces much of the history of the area. The kids will love climbing the walls and battlements and the adults will enjoy the splendid views of the city and countryside. There is light food available on the grounds and there are a myriad of cafes in the area immediately below the fortress. A great venue for a morning or afternoon trip.

Nice to see. This a nice walk to the castle.
The building itself is very impressive. Few explanations, take an audio guide at the reception.
Allow 1 to 1,5 h to visit.
Interesting for children but loads of stairs.

Good views of City, little or no interior. The ramparts give a good view over the City and the river: the walkways around the keep are largely complete. However, if visitors are hoping for an exhibition of medieval armour, furniture, or tableware, they will be disappointed.
On the Sunday we visited, there was a display of medieval fighting.

Nice views. I didn't find the castle itself particularly interesting - I've certainly seen more impressive Moorish ruins. It is, however, worth visiting because of the panoramic views of the city which can be enjoyed from this vantage point.

Amazing views. I toured the castle while in Lisbon, it was an incredible experience. Through the self guided tour I felt transported through time imagining cooks, vendors and villagers walking through main squares and common areas of the castle. It freedom to explore was so refreshing compared to most European castles.

Historic value!. The place is beautiful, interesting and gives you amazing views over the city!
It's worth the 5€ I paid as a student, recommend it for an hour maximum.
Awesome !!. I really liked this place ... What a beautiful surprise the periscope that has inside to see 360• of Lisbon LIVE. Must!!!

Loved it! . Great castle to see with young kids. There's much that's intact or rebuilt, and it's pretty stroller friendly. After seeing many that are not, this was a welcome relief- more fun for my toddler and definitely for us as well. Incredible history and views of the city.

Great castle and view. Well worth a visit to this castle as it is impressive piece of history and the view of Lisbon is amazing. Catch Tram28 to get to the castle while enjoying the sights of Lisbon along the way. Tram 28 is one of the best tram rides in the world. After visiting the castle walk down the hill stopping at the cafes and really interesting shops along the way. Work your way down to Pracado Commercio to enjoy one of the most beautiful squares in the world.

Be there at sunset. Great for a view of Lisbon, and the castle itself is of course also a must-see for any visitor. We thoroughly enjoyed the castle, especially watching the sun set from the romantic open courtyard.

Old castle & great views on the city. The best about the castle is that it has Mirador to look at the city centre from above and the views are just amaizing! Fhe castle itself is nothing special and looks the same as many others in Europe. The part of exposition was closed, the staff in a cafe with great view was inpolite and didn't want to show hospitality to their guests so it was only Mirador that worth visiting there

Impressive castle and tour.. I have been to castles before. The castle is at the top of a hill in Lisbon. tremendous views and fresh atmosphere. I was impressed by the place frem the moment we walk in. The guide was very well informed of the details of the place and and gave us all the information regarding the history, defence of the castle, the way they lived.
Offers a great view of the city. The castle offers a great view over the whole of lisbon, the is lots of information about the history of the castle and of Lisbon

Perfect city views. Perfect view over the city and its neighbourhoods, very nice areas with lots of trees that give you shade on a warm and sunny day. Definately worth the visit, it took us 15 minutes to get to the castle (from baixa).

Mainly for the view. The views from the castle walls are stunning but there is not a great deal to see inside. The walk around the walls of the keep/inner castle is interesting but precipitous, so if you are not good at heights don't do it. Disappointingly the camera obscura is only open for guided tours in alternating languages, so you may have to wait a couple of hours to have a meaningful visit. Good concession for oldies so was worth it for us.

Lots of very steep steps!. After a long walk up to the castle it was a relief to be on level ground. The views from here are great on a clear day. There are lots of places on the narrow streets outside to stop for a coffee or bite to eat.

Go for the views and the walk if nothing else. While it's powerful position and (over-restored) walls promise a great castle experience the truth is there's not that much here. There's a small museum which tries to make the most of the scattered, broken material retrieved from the site and there's a camera obscura which you check out if you haven't seen one before. But the best thing, obviously, is the stroll around the walls and the excellent views of Lisbon. Worth climbing up the hill just for this - and don't be put off by the climb. It's only 10 minutes from the flat and presents no real obstacle. But if you really, really hate climbing hills check out the Baixa elevator (which actually consists of two elevators) which takes most of the effort out of what is little more than a gentle up-hill stroll.

Castle on top of Lisbon. the Castelo rises up above Lisbon and reflects the historic need for protecting the city. It offers great views and can easily be combined with a stroll down through the Alfama
Beautifullll viewwww. Must do part of your lisbon trip. It wouldn't be complete without it.Anazing view points. Great to explore from inside and see different angles

Great view, interesting history. It's a little hard to get to but we found it was only a short and cheap taxi ride from the Baixa or Alfama areas. Excellent views of the city and river, nice little collection of centuries-old artifacts and explanation of the castle's construction and role in Lisbon's history.

Lovely location with great views. Lovely shady promenades with the best views of all of Lisbon, great ruins with all the walls and towers intact and accessible. Good archeological site that has free tours. Good museum and really nice garden areas. Very enjoyable and relaxing way to spend the afternoon.

Great View Fires the Imagination. Almost obligatory because of its commanding 360* view of the city and suburbs (on a clear day) and bristling with history. I particularly enjoyed the Arabic steps leading down into Mouraria. If you're interested guides make the experience much more interesting. There appears to be little material to self direct yourself. A fancy restaurant is available. As noted, you can breeze through in under an hour appreciating the view and the sense of antiquity or spend hours if so inclined.
Spectacular. Great way to spend 2/3 hours. We wandered in amazement of the grandeur of this palace with its amazing views of the city.

Spend a few hours or a complete day here. Decision is yours!. Even though the Castelo looks nothing special, it is very entertaining to stumble around and discover all the ancient places inside the walls. You should definitley visit the Camera Obscura, which gives you a very nice live view around Lissbon! For that, make sure it is a sunny day.

Great Views of the City. It was fun to walk along the castle walls and to think about the history but the selling point is the view of the city. The castle is built on a hill so you are able to overlook the beautiful city of Lisbon. However, since it is built on a hill, you may have a hike to get there depending on your mode of transportation. We took a stroll of the city with the castle being the culmination of our walk.
A must see. You cannot go to Lisbon without going up to the Castle. Take the stairs and walk around the top of the walls. Beautiful views.
Nice castle. Excellent view over Lisboa.Good renovated and conserved castle wall - you can walk on the wall the whole length.

Just A Typical Castle . Go if you've never seen a castle or perhaps for the view, otherwise a very ordinary castle of little significance. Best enjoyed from below as it towers over the city. Not worth the money.

Impressive castelo. Pleasantly surprised by this enormous castle. So nice to wonder around with great view of the city. You will need at least 1.5 to 2 hours to complete the entire place. Walking from Baixa to the castle was about 1.5 hours. Slow walk and nice. Closed at 6 pm. If you want to take nice picture of the city, please do so from 9am to11 am when the sun is shining at the town.

Beautiful views and a tour through history -- a marvelous day out!. I only had one day to enjoy in Lisbon, and I'm soooo pleased that I decided to make this part of the adventure! You can take buses up to the top of the hill, though if you are game, the walk through the winding streets is its own adventure. Lisbon is a truly beautiful city and walking from the main port plaza to the Castelo was fantastic (and burned a lot of calories!), but the views from the Castelo made my jaw drop in awe. I probably spent 90 minutes there, but next time I would plan to lunch at the restaurant and spend much more time soaking in the atmosphere.

A Great View of the City and some history as well. We took a tuk tuk up to the castle. Interesting, but a very rough ride. Recommend a taxi. A public tram can get you close but you have to walk uphill for several blocks. We spent about two hours looking around and taking pictures. We walked down and enjoyed this walk as well through the Alfama.

Peak of the city - in more ways than one!. It's quite a hike to the castle, but you can get a small shuttle bus from the Praca de Figueira (737 if I remember correctly!) for 1.80 euros. Once there you are literally on top of the city with spectacular 360 degree views. There is lots of history up here too, with centuries of architecture and culture there to see. You can then climb up the towers and see the city through a camera obscura, refresh yourselves in the café and then either walk back down or get the shuttle bus back to Praca de Figueira. I would count no visit to Lisbon as complete without getting up to the castle!

Nice spot and better outlook . Really good spot to go to. Nice overlook of the city. Very nicely preserved though a little steep not just because of the emplacement but also for the price, almost 9€ cover.
Brilliant way to spend a few hours.. Definitely worth climbing the hills and paying to visit this monument. Interesting with amazing views and photo opportunities.

Grand views. After a long uphill walk as every tram was full we paid about five pounds each for entry.once inside there was not a great deal to see other than to walk round the perimeter walls. Nice cafe however with hot and cold dishes but I guess the best thing about being here were the views.
Gorgeous views of the city!. Perfect spot for a romantic walk with breathtaking views. A must do in Lisbon. The alfama Neighborhood is definitely worth a few hours.

Worth the visit! . The view from the Castelo de Sao Jorge Walls and gardens is worth the ticket. You can see the whole Lisbon! It was lovely day and we had a great time. The walls itself were nothing spectacular, and we didn't go inside the museum. There is an artist at the gardens from which we bought adorable paintings, from her and her partner called Haucke.

Well preserved piece of history. The access to it is very interesting as it is on a steep inclination in the middle of Old LisbonYou can also experience a glass of wine (red, white or even Port) while walking (overpriced, but worth the experience)Once there theres is an amazing view of the old part of the citysome parts of it the floor (big square blocks) can be very slippery the climb up to the castel's watch towers is very narrow and hard to walk down from, using the steps, specially if you have small kids
Be a King and Queen for the day. Easy to get to fanastic views 360. all over the city you get a free guided tour which itself is very informitif
very good views of Lisbon. Very good views of Lisbon, the bay, nice neighbourhoods, lots of restos and shops within walking distance. Visited in September, 2014.

Stunning Views Above Lisbon. We wandered into Lisbon from our cruise ship without any idea of where we were going or would end up. We wandered around little streets, alleys and paths all very steep as we climbed our way uphill. Eventually we stumbled across Castello de Sao Jorge, paid our €8 or €9 each for entry and what a treat to see the views we got from this castle, towering above the city! It took us 2-3 hours to wander round the castle and the grounds, climbing some steep (and some arguably not very safe) staircases but the view and the pictures we got of the city made it all worthwhile. Just one word of warning if walking through Lisbon up to this attraction, watch out for thieves, pickpockets and drug dealers, Lisbon is notorious for crime and we had 2 occasions of locals wanting to 'high five' us (a very clever hand flick will remove a watch from your wrist without you even realising) and one even went in for a hug (while his hand would have been in my pocket if I'd allowed). We were also offered Hash twice and cocaine from three separate locals and I can assure you we, although young, do not look likel 'druggies' by any standards haha! As with any city, be alert, keep valuables out of sight and keep your wits about you at all times. Castello de Sao Jorge was great though!
Nice castle!!. Climbed up to the top and the view from there is amazing. My friends and I went there and took a time lapse video during sunset. Note that things is a bit expensive in the cafe.

Lots to see and do an excellent value. Views, museums, walls, periscope. Take tram 38 upto the restaurants that look out over the river. Walk up to the castle or take a Turk tuk. Have lunch outside the castle as it's cheaper would recommend m castello up the street to the right of the entrance. Spend as long as you can in there as its a large compound with several distinct areas.
Castle. Another nice castle. Great bastards got in here and set up the mills and laidview of the city. Steep uphill climb to get there. Some scarey stairways.

Really good escape overlooking Lisbon. This is a nice escape from the city, but it is no Alhambra, quite plain but to while away a few hours it is fine. The cafe is good, the staff with the usual level of curtness, but the food is good

History and views.. Visited the Castelo de Sao Jorge in the early evening and watched the sunset. Very beautiful. Also was lucky to time my visit to join the free tour of the recent archeological findings and diggings. Very interesting.

Definitely worth a visit. Long climb to this attraction, but options to get there are by tram, taxi and tuk tuk. We chose tuk tuk, about €15 euro for 4 from outside Hotel Mundial. Great views of river and city and good historical information and displays. Busy place so plan about 3-4 hours to get there, tour and get back.

Need the strength of Hercules if walking up to the castle summit. I walked up to the castle and it then took a full day to recover since I thought my knee was going to give way. Getting to the castle on foot was like a Sherlock Holmes mystery. Misleading signs. Eventually got to the top and took some pictures and then started the trek down again.

What a view. The view from the castello is beautiful. Allready the ride with the tram nr. 12 or the bus though the narrow streets make the excursion to rhis place special. Go there early to avoid long waiting times at the cashier.
Magnificent Views. This old castle sits high on a hill in the heart of the city. It is well worth a visit for the views alone.

Go for the sunset!. It is a steep hill to walk to get there but totally worth it. I woudl recommend going after lunch for sunset - we really enjoyed it and the views are amazing. Approx €13 each in for adults. There was a mini wine van where you can buy a glass of wine to enjoy while you explore the caste grounds, lots of little places if you'd like to bring a picnic as well.

Another ruined castle. There are good views of Lisbon from the castle, but that is it. Where as the walls are standing, that's about all. There are 2 exhibitions located within the castle but not much to see. It is what it is, a castle of ruins with good views, sorry I couldn't be more positive.
Not much to see. We walked to the Castelo but we were disappointed as there really wasn't much to see. It has a great view of the city from here.

Good views, pleasant walk through and around the old buildings. Be sure to visit the camera obscura.. This cost me somewhere beween 6 and 8 euros to get in; I can't remember. Before you line up to buy tickets, look behind you; there's a quaint "Urinol" in the corner, about 100 metres down the street. It's a place for boys (and girls with a little less privacy) to pee if you're not shy. A bit smelly as you pass by!Anyway, the castle grounds are very pleasant to stroll through, and the buildings offer plenty of opportunity for exercise. There are loads of steps going up to lots of points where there are great views. Speaking of views, don't miss the room that has a camera obscura in it. You may need to queue for it; I was lucky - I walked in just as a demo was about to start. I'd guess they only let in about 20 people at a time. It's worth seeing though; mirrors and lenses (manually operated by the staff member) give a really cool panoramic view of the city on a parabolic dish in the centre of the room, all in total darkness. Nice.

Visit the camera obscura. The castle has lovely views across lisbon and the alfama and some lovely ruined 'romantic gardens' and the shell of the castle. There wasn't much going on at the archaeological dig site, and very few signs to explain what you were looking at. However the best part is the camera obscura which is included in the ticket (there's a queue for it on top of the walls over the entrance to the castle but not much signage again). They take you on a 360 degree tour of the city and you can see people and boats moving and the ships on the river. It's in English and the tour guide spoke English very well. An image is projected onto a white table thing which you all stand around in pitch black. There are only 20 people allowed in at a time though so the queues can get quite long and sunny days are better than cloudy ones.

Best photo location in Lisbon. The views from up here are hard to beat especially on a fine sunny evening. I doubt if any one comes here for the castle itself which is a ruin and no very attractive. The walk along the battlements and ramparts are for the 360 degree views of Lisbon and are not to be missed. The streets leading up to the castle are also worth exploring as they are full of atmosphere and character. The no. 28 tram takes you up most of the way but the final stretch must still be walked, but easily done. From up here you get to see the sun set in the west over Bairro Alto.

Lovely sunset from the castle walls. The castle itself is quite nice - lots of walls to explore and great views from the top. But if you time it right, you can see the sunset from the castle - and that certainly deserves some planning ahead!

The Castle. The view from the castle is breathtaking. There is a tile panel which works like a map identifying the important buildings in the landscape.The grounds of the castle are very interesting to explore and you often come across somebody singing the national song (Fado - meaning Fate).

Historic landscape over Lisbon. The castle is one of the historic landscape over Lisbon and in october the thousand olive trees leave olives fall down.It's a little bit slippery but, as tourist squeeze this olives, its smell is in the air

Great views of the city. A short and very enjoyable tram ride took us up to the castle which has spectacular views over the city and beyond. Large numbers of visitors and some queueing unavoidable but still worthwhile.

Quite difficult to enter and need time to venture. The Castello is located at the top of hill. Getting there on foot is an adventure in itself. We choose the city elevator , which is free, and then walking the street up to the main ticket office and gate. The line ups were huge and we were short of time, so we opted not to go in considering the cost as well.Just looking over from the entrance, the views were awesome of the city below, of the river and the two bridges.Wish we could have gone in- perhaps next time.
Great views of Lisbon. Lovely peaceful oasis from the bustle of Lisbon. The restaurant is excellent and if you can get a table on the terrace it would be difficult to beat the views whilst you eat.

A must visit location. We took a tuctuc ride to the Castle from Rossio at sunset, we walked up to the castle which opens until 9pm. The entrance fee is well worth it as the views of Lisbon were stunning as dusk draws in, enjoying a peaceful glass of portregeuse red wine whilst sitting on the castle walls and watching the city liven up below.

Try to get there for Sunset. Very cool castle and worth the risk of twisted ankle on the old old cobblestones. Definitely flat shoes for the ladies and robust shoes for the guys. Spectacular views especially at sunset as the photos show. And walking down is also worth it as there are some great restaurants and bars on the way but away from the immediate vicinity of the castle.

Enjoyed visiting. Castelo de São Jorge is an area of Lisbon i did not expect to find; in fact, i was ashamed to discover I didn't know anything about this important part of the city's history. Besides the great views of the city, the inside really feels like being inside a very old town. i don't think there is anything particularly remarkable about it, but enjoyed the visit.

Well worth a visit - and the climb!. Group of friends ( all middle aged ladies) enjoyed a very pleasant sunny afternoon in the Castle of Lisbon recently. Note - it is a stiff climb up from the old town area and also plenty of stairs once inside the castle grounds itself, but well worth the effort. This is a self guided tour and we would have enjoyed it more if actual guides were available for tours or at least some questions, you miss a lot due to lack of information. We did happen along to a short tour of some archaeological excavations which was really interesting, given by a local student of history - would be great to extend guided tours to the main castle itself. Good entrance price with reductions for seniors & students. Also, we were warned by several local shop-owners to beware of pick-pockets in the streets adjacent to the castle, so be careful!

Great View Over the City of Lisbon. Climbing up through the steep streets of Alfama brings you to the Castelo Sao Jorge. A Moorish castle built in the medieval times which soars above the city and provides an excellent post to guard the traffic up and down the Tejo stream and the entire city of Lisbon. The castle yard and surroundings is a wonderful place to take an afternoon walk and learn about the interesting history of this old citadel. After the visit it recommended to walk down through the narrow streets of Alfama with all its shops and crafts.
yet another castle. typical castle, towers, ramparts, walks along the top etc. Well preserved, good tea room, taxi not expensive if the hill walk puts you off.

Fun and interesting. We loved wandering around this moorish castle, most of it in ruins. The views are amazing and the grounds are really lovely. Wild peacocks stroll about and here and there a cat perches watching the people go by. Lovely.

A castle for those who love castles!. The view from Castelo de Sao Jorge is phenomenal, just as you would expect. But the history behind it is also quite interesting. There is no interior left but the network if walls and towers are reminiscent of what you thought a castle should look like when you were a kid. Personally I loved it. Be prepared for lots of climbing - in fact, I recommend taking a cab or tuk tuk to the castle so that you aren't worn out when you get there. Climbing all of the walls and checking out all of the varied views is the best part.

Best sunset view in Lisboa. Amazing views of the city and sunset. Open till 9 pm in October and well worth the trek up. We saw the lights of the city come on in front of us - got a glass of LBV Porto from a vendor next to the sunset - it was gorgeous and highly recommended.
Very interesting. This is very interesting with great views of the city. We had a reduced rate because we had a Lisboa Travelcard.
Incredible view over the city. Visit this Castel to have a drink on the terrace! You will surely enjoy the view on the terrace! Especially during sunset this is wonderful and very romantic!

Great views of the city . A very nice place to visit especially if you are around the Alfama area. Ticket costs around €8.50 , cheaper if you have the Lisboa card! The views are amazing. Be prepared to do a lot of walking while inside and climbing up the stairs / steps. It worth a visit .
Best Views on Lisbon. This Castle on top of Lisbon has marvelous views in all directons. There is a large terrace where you can look on central Lisbon. You can climb the walls and towers.

Great views over Lisbon; great place to amble around; surrounding area good to walk round too.. We visited and spent about 90 minutes here. Walking along the many walls and climbing into turrets was all worthwhile. Good value at €8 each. Worth visiting; good photo opportunities.

Outstanding views of the city. We took tram 28 to the base of castle and walked up to the entrance. What we saw took our breath away! The views are out standing. You get a panoramic view of the city and the water. There is nothing to see in the castle itself but the walls. But they are doing an archaeological dig that dates back to 7 BC.We stopped in the garden terrace for coffee and walked back to our lodging in the Chiado following the tram tracks. (45 minutes)

Amazing views. Well worth the €8.50 (€5.00 for seniors) to get some amazing views of Lisbon. Don't expect to see a castle as such - it is the walls that remain but one can imagine the impressive structure it once was. Lots of climbing stairs involved but well worth it.

Great view but overpriced. Originally a Moorish castle later taken over by St George. Average as castles go, with a decent small museum mainly dedicated to broken crockery from various eras. However, the view of Lisbon from the battlements is spectacular. Admission is €8.50, which in my opinion is a bit of gouging. You can get an excellent view from Porto do Sol just down the street and only slightly lower in altitude for free.

Castelo de Sao Jorge. Sits on the top of the hill, you can take tram 28 or tram 12 to the top, make sure you get off when you see the nice view of the cliff from the tram, you don't always hear the driver, worst case it takes back around to Plaza Figuroa. We went during sunset it was quiet and had some nice pictures of the city, the castle is kind of empty with not a lot to see unless you understand what you are looking at.
Nice view. From this place you can see all the city and walk around wall.If you like you can enjoy the view with glass of wines.

don't miss the archeological ruins beyond the main castle. This castle is imposing and gives wonderful views from the top of the walls over the city. The archaeological ruins just beyond the main castle are best viewed by joining the free timed tour so that you can go into the ruins and see inside otherwise covered areas. The museum on site is worth a visit but the camera looking down on the city was a great disappointment. Because of the orientation is was always upside down and I was unable to determine the points of interest.
Good Place to See Sunset. The Castelo de Sao Jorge is high up overlooking the whole city, gives you 360 degree view of the city. A good place to see sunset.

Castle ..battlements...yawn..... i was dragged over the Three Billy Goats Gruff bridge entrance reluctantly and desperate to find it boring and get it over with quickly so we could have lunch. Despite the noise of the trolls i felt no fear, and made my way to the battlements and discovered the secret of this ridiculous protection goodness knows whom.... the view.... to die for.

Incredible views over Lisbon and a really beautiful castle to explore.. Worth the walk up the hill and the entry fees for the breathtaking views of Lisbon & across the river and the opportunity to explore the grounds of this fabulous castle.

Fascinating and charming!. Do not miss visiting this Castel. Nothing special but the view and the area in and around are so intresting. Many shops and restaurants. Don't forget to have a tuk tuk tour around Alfama and they also can take you to another great view point. You can end up your tuk tuk tour in the castel cause it is hard to reach the castel.

Very nice place. You can see Lisbon from the high streets, the castle is a history's part, it's beatiful and has many privat places where relax. For me it was a very pleasnat kit kat where I stayed in Lisbon by work.

You need to have a head for hights. If you want to go to the castle, prepare your legs for some steep stairs, because you'll always be climbing. When you get there, you'll have an amazing viewpoint of all Lisbon.Don't forget to bring your camera and take amazing pictures all over Lisbon.

As Castles Go this is top 10. Great Views for the those of you with the selfie stick!! It is a superb castle but no inside areas. At 8.50 to get in it is great value and well worth a trip if you find yourself in Lisbon. I was in Lisbon for the marathon and went to the castle the following day.

Worth the trek up the hill!. It was quite the walk up all the hills and steps but worth it in the end. The views are amazing. We missed the one area as it closes at 5pm. They have a few vendors inside and one selling wine which was a nice touch. We shared a bottle and took in the views. Be careful if it has been raining or raining at the time as it gets quite slippery- especially the stairs. Much bigger than we thought so took more time than we anticipated. Well worth it.
Must see!. The admittance fee is 8,5 for an adult, but the view is worth it, the castle is from 11th century so lot of history there, it is high so if you suffer from vertigo it is little bit scarry.

Great views. After walking around the Alfama in circles trying to find the entrance, we finally made it in! The views were incredible, and some of the castle was interesting, but as castles go, the view beats the actual contents.
Castle on the hill. Great castle high on the hill overlooking Lisbon. Interesting displays inside and wonderful open areas to view the city.

Amazing view. If you want to go to the castle, prepare your legs, because it's always climbing.When you get there, you'll have an amazing viewpoint of all Lisbon, I advise you to go in the afternoon, because for me is the best time!In my opinion it can be less expensive, don't forget to bring your camera and take amazing pictures all over Lisbon.

Great viewpoint. As an individual more interested in looking around than history, this was a fine point in the city. Of course, plenty historical aspects here as parts date back to the 2nd century BC, with many additions along the way, so for those who want historical Lisbon in a package available for a morning or afternoon visit, Castelo de Sao Jorge is perfect.For me, the best aspects were the views (see photo), and the fine level of preservation of these old structures, all for 8.5 Euros. This price includes a Camera Obscura, but the queues on my visit, a particularly sunny day, put me off this attraction. Also here is a large ostentation of peacocks, adding to the photography opportunities.In terms of accessing the castle, much of the travel up the hills can be cut out by using the free elevators starting at the east end of Rua da Vitoria.

Reconstruction area. It is a very nice area but we were very disappointed, the castle is under reconstruction, not possible to go in. If you don`t mind to walk through 3 streets with ice bar and coffee it is nice to go up. Right now you miss the castle and the view.

Must see in Lisbon. I don't need to tell you that the complex is one of the must-sees in Lisbon. Besides having a stunning vantage point that offers gorgeous views over Lisbon and the Tagus River, this is one of the most comprehensive castle complexes in Portugal, if not the world. Although much of it has been restored, the Moorish apartment remains have been left as is, and offer a glimpse into what life was like before the Christian invasion.

St George in Portugal.............. a fairly well preserved facility with great views of Lisbon, has two cafes and provides an opportunity to visit the walls and other araes of interest within the fortress

Fabulous Views of Lisbon!. We took a taxi up to the castle and were glad we did (the walk up would have been way too long, steep and strenuous for the average person). Walking back down to the City from the castle was fairly reasonable. The views of the city from the castle are beautiful. The castle is well preserved and is very interesting to walk around. Very clean WCs available inside. If you only have one day to see Lisbon, this should be on your list.

Old castle in the center of Lisbon. Worth walking around this historic site. Easy to buy an entry ticket when you first arrive. The gallery exhibit is a good place to start and then walk around the grounds and check out the view. See the peacocks! No need to climb the castle walls to see a nice view.The castle walls have steep, tall staircases to climb to get to the top-most levels. The stairs have poor, shaky railings. Wear sneakers and keep your hands free. Too bad there was no elevator!

History right in the Capitol of Lisbon. Sitting on top of the Lisbon 7 hills, this castelo protected this capitol city for many many years. The views from the top down to the river are breath taking. A must see if you are visiting Lisbon. We walked down to the bottom to experience the true Portugal. Well worth the trip.
Good views. It's fun if you don't mind heights, yeah have a look about. Views are great, what more do you want me to say, it's a massive castle with good views.

The Long walk. So apparently more people break their legs or feet on the way up the hill than ever see the castle itself. What can we do about it? The elevator present certainly does not take away the effort, for it only goes half the way. Pretty nasty if you ask me. Certainly the castle itself is beautiful, though kinda empty on the inside. Too bad. The views are magnificent and the towers are too high, no matter what anyone says.
Stunning views of Lisbon.. Even if you don't like the history and architecture, you still MUST visit this castle for stunning views of Lisbon.

Wonderful Castle. This is a impressive Castle with great views over Lisbon, we also took in the unique 360 degree camera view of the City that is included in price of ticket(8.50e) getting here is a bit of a trek and if you struggle on your feet get a taxi. well worth a visit.
Amazing old castle. It's an amazing old castle on the top of the hill, so you will have a breathtaking view of the city. don't miss if you are in lisbon!
impressive site of history. getting there if half the battle. forget trying to walk there,...a cab ride is more than half the fun.

Stunning views across city. Visited just as rains came down and winds picked up but even so still enjoyed walk around castle walls and views over city. Museum and camera with a look especially if weather good.

A beautifully well-preserved castle. I've seen a lot of medieval castles throughout Europe and the Levant, and this one definitely impresses. Kudos to the Portuguese government for maintaining it so well. It's worth the visit just for the views even if you aren't interested in the history.
Great experience. Impressive location, reliving the past ! Nothing to add besides you need to see this. Great views take a tram to the top (12 and 28)

It's got a great view. . The place is a nice visit as a quick thing to do but honestly when we went there wasn't a lot to look at apart from ruins. Despite that it is an expressive visit and the view is outstanding

Fantastic place to see the sunset. The castle is perched high on the hill to the west of Lisbon and provides wonderful views over the whole city and the 25th April bridge and is brillant to watch the sunset. The castle itself is Moorish in origin and has many towers to climb. There is a reasonable archaelogical museum in the grounds Unfortunatly the camera obscura was closed when we were there. Reach the castle by tram or bus

A Great Aspect. I thought it was going to be a fairly brief visit - how wrong I was. The Castelo dominates the Old City with fine panoramic views of the River Tagus, the Alfama and the Commercial District. As well as walking along the walls, there is an informative museum as well. As is general in Lisbon, exhibits are dual signed in Portuguese and English. This is a must-do experience.

View from this vantage point -- breathtaking. Best for photographs! take the bus 737 from Rossio town square, as best way to get to the top. Interesting fortress castle, breathtaking views from the battlements, a cafe or two inside, for refreshments. Worth the trek.
Wonderful place but beware of pickpocketing!. This castle is a must if you visit Lisbon! It is absolutely beautyful and the location is stunning! Beware of pickpocketing in this area though!

Beautiful Views of the city. Super touristy up at this part of the city, but its worth it. Beautiful views and a nice way to have a lazy afternoon. Watch out for pick pockets though - as its so crowded its easy for them - we saw two guys trying to take a wallet out of an older mans back pocket.
excellent city views. I liked the city views and see such an old castle. You will not see nothing much more, it is just the shell of the castle with no interiour.

The iconic structure atop Alfama hill. No trip to Lisbon is complete without visiting Castelo de Sao Jorge. The buildings and courtyards are beautiful and the history is fascinating and engaging. Best yet is the view of the city from this landmark atop the bulging hill of the Alfama district. Be prepared to climb and wear comfortable shoes. Not for those with knee, hip, or foot problems.
Nice view... but not much else. It's a seriously stunning view. But apart from the peacocks they've not really made much of an effort
Castle with a view. Great views from the terraces and castle walls out over Lisbon. Entrance fee 8.5 Euros. Long queue for the camera obscura.

Worth the Entrance Fee for the View. Best view in Lisbon from all sides of the Castle. Its a nice to spend a morning. There is not much cover so not great when it is raining and the cafe has the slowest service in Lisbon.

Another "must see" in Lisbon. Lisbon is a small town (compared to other european cities like Paris, London, Madrid) but with lot of history to tell and see. This old castle lets you see Lisbon with other eyes

Beautiful castle, amazing views. I'd definitely recommend visiting the castle, it is beautiful and old and gives you breathtaking views of the city. There are also plenty of interactive learning opportunities.
a wonderful historic experience. a good walk up to the castelo for a wonderful castelo, stunning views and a better understanding of Liasbon's history. Onsite café very good too.

Must. Just go. Walk up the steps. Walk all around the castle wall. Soak up the magnificent views.
Once you've left the castle, as you begin descending try and find the hidden little cliff garden with the most breathtaking views over the gulf. You'll be rewarded.

A Must Do. Overlooking the Alfama and Lisbon, this former Moorish stronghold has been restored and provides a good sense of what a medieval stronghold was like. While there are taxis to take ne here, the real experience is climbing the narrow street, and steps, that lead you to the entrance and a nice historical stop. Wear comfortable shoes!
Nice old castle. The way up to the castle is really nice, it's not expensive I think 8 Euros per person and they have group discount as well.
Love it!. Nice castle, very nice view. Perfect place for dating. One of the most beautiful place in Lisboa. Tickets are about 8 EUR per person. Very nice place for chill out.
Castle in old town of Lisbon.. This castle is worth a visit. Ot is at the top of a hill in the old town of Lisbon. A maze of narrow streets wind upwards towards this ancient structure.

Worth the climb!. The fee is a bit steep at €8.50 as is the climb! But the views are impressive and there is a small museum explaining the Castle's history and there are some great photo ops up there. Watch out for peacocks...and mosquitos!
well well well.... Not worth as I though. Vievs from the highest point od tower was similar to the last station of tram number 28. I don't want to reccomend.
lovely views at Lisboa. the whole castle complex is huge and is very interesting to see, the location also offers lovely views at Lisboa, kids loved walking around the castle walls

Early morning visit.. We went just after opening time. The castle is extensive with good access to the walls and brilliant views over the city. An interesting museum and a good cafe too! Days when cruise ships are in port tend to be busier. Access is steep, but there is a bus service almost to the gate and trams run close. Plenty of cafes, bars and restaurants nearby. Not to be missed!

Bombastic 360° view of Lisbon. Easy to reach by foot or tram 28 the main attraction of the castle area certainly is the fantastic view from the terrace or from one of the many towers. And the view always changes so it is worthwhile getting up (or down) to each of the towers. The castle is well maintained but basically is a large ruin consisting of walls and towers, so it is an outdoor experience, nothing for rainy days. There is a small museum displaying coins and pieces of broken pottery found on the premises, not very exciting, but providing some shelter in cases like an unexpected thunderstorm (which we had).

Must see for fantastic views over Lisbon. While the Castelo is lovely on own its own, the views over Lisbon from the Castelo are awesome. If you can visit on a sunny day for a more enjoyable visit. The Castelo is a lovely calm place to escape the noise of Lisbon and unwind for a while, lovely restaurant also in the Castelo and Peacocks roaming free. Around the outside of the Castelo there is also some nice souvenir shops of a higher quality than most.

Take a look at the olive trees. Amazed that this incredible structure survived the 1755 earthquake, and lucky for us! I enjoyed exploring every nook and gazing out from every window. I did not, however, wear appropriate shoes — make sure you have enough traction, because the stone steps are slippery! Also, take time to admire the ancient-looking olive trees on the terrace.
Worth visiting. This is really simply a must in Lisbon. Nice place, nice views and good memories. :) We were visiting on a clear, sunny, warm day and the stroll around was very very nice.

Most spectacular views. You have to come here, the castle is on top a very high hill, we took a taxi up lol I wasn't going to get caught walking up those hills it was about 12Euros not too expensive. When we entered the views were amazing! we enjoyed some wine as well as we walked around the castle and continue seeing amazing views. A lot of history there is also a restaurant and peacocks inside the castle.

I can see my hotel from here..... Although a bit of a trek, the views from here are absolutely phenomenal. It's very crowded from what I can gather all the time, so expect a few people around! Looking out over the city and the river is amazing, and after a few days allows you to easily pick out a few of the attractions you may have already seen.The castle itself is fairly unimpressive. Don't expect the Tower of London or Canaervon!Note on access: Streets are extremely steep, but we were told of a new escalator at the end of Rua da Vittoria in the Baixa, going straight to Rua do Milagre de S Antonio - meaning there's only a 10 minute walk.

A perfect place to see Lisbon from above. This place is magical,speacially when you go at sunset when Lisbon get its best colors. I nice place for relaxing and enjoy Lisbon from above. The view is breathtaking.

Interesting piece of history. The castle is situated on a hill so comfortable shoes are a must. There are many areas of the castle that have stairs which are at times steep and narrow. The views are spectacular when you climb up to the few towers that exist. There is a cafe on site that offers a variety of delicious pasteries. There are several peaceful cod on the property which are very people friendly they will eat from your hand.

Wonderful--even on an overcast day with showers. I had read remarks about getting to the castle on foot. I would have been crazy to try that. If you're near Figueira Square, just take the yellow bus 737. It costs less than 2 euros each way. It will have Castelo on the front & the castle is its only stop. Then take it back down. It will then say Figueira, and that is the end of its route. You'll still have a short, steep walk to the castle. I didn't have advance tickets but probably waited no more than 10 minutes. You can get a nice brochure in English that shows the layout and gives an overview. The views are great, even if I was left wondering just how incredible they would be on a sunny day. I didn't try the cafe, but I thought the artifacts were quite interesting in the museum. The exit from the museum takes you past a WC and on through a small, cramped gift shop. On a wet day like today, every pace, wether climbing stairs or walking on a "flat" surface, is dangerous. I always wear shoes with soles that have good traction, but here I had to be extra careful of my footing because I was terrified I would fall and break my camera.
Historical. Great place to see the city&aruins are ruins for me but a nice walk and views to die for. Don't go on a hot day- very little shad
Don't miss it!. Another 'must see' for visitors to Lisbon. Good value and great views. Busy but the queue for tickets was handled speedily.

City views. Another defensive fort overlooking the city centre and includes a camera obscura ,be aware the commentary in there is all in Portuguese,however it is free and an interesting feature within the castle

To the citadel.. The castle dominates the skyline in the city centre and is well worth the visit. especially if you walk up to it through the winding old streets. The history lesson is very worthwhile and the views over the city stunning.

Possibility to dine/lunch with superb views over Lisbon. Interesting atmosphere in walled citadel-like hilltop with remains of castle, set in neighbourhood with private houses, restaurants/bars and shops.

Stunning views. Great for an evening walk; the building itself gives you some absolutely gorgeous vistas over the city, and there's a decent little cafe when you've run out of space for photos. Our visit was marked by some rowdy peacocks, which was slightly bizarre but not off putting.

Have to do it. You really haven't been to Lisbon without visiting this place. You will be on the top of the hill with the perfect view of the city. I recommend that you take a taxi to get up and walk down through the wonderful streets after you are done. Walking up is work. And I had the perfect lunch with a view in the castle.

A wonderful afternoon in a medieval walled city. The Castelo is the original medieval walled city of Lisbon. We spent an entire afternoon there just wandering around through the various buildings to see how people lived a thousand years ago. There's a nice, small museum in the Castelo with interesting artifacts and a wonderful outdoor café that has great city views and excellent food.

Spectacular view. Fabulous view to all points of the city from the castle. When you return to the center you can see the old quarter Alfama, the Cathedral and the Pantheon. I would recommend to go there by hiring tuk-tuk car. It is an unforgettable experience.

A Glimpse into the Past. A steep climb to experience the past. Fabulous views of the valleys below. The climb is steep with minimal support as you climb. But this is a site that should not be missed. The architecture is a wonder. Plan to spend some time and not rush through this site. The walks are beautiful.

Expensive, with a nice view.. The price you pay for the view is too big, there are some bricks, but nothing to see in the castle.
Mass tourist place.

well worth a vist. On our first day in Lisbon we meandered the narrow hilly streets up to the Castelo de Sao Jorge. At 5 euro per person its not too expensive and we really enjoyed our walk around in the sunshine.
The castle walls are amazing and so are the views.
Well worth the visit
Great views. Need a while to look around to see it all, i unfortunately cut it abit short, nice gardens to relax in, take a picnic
