A beautiful entrance and a big castle to visit. A castle in Lisbon, the capital of Portugal. I prefered the Belém Tower, but Saint Jorge Castle have your charm and you need to visit if you can.

Great, Awesom!. When I was in Lisbon in March 2015, I supposed to visit the Castelo de Jorge but we've met an accident in front of the entrance gate. So, we've moved to hospital and spent a lot of time there so couldn't visit the castle.On this trip, I've visited the castle and it was a lot better than my expectation. It has awesome and panoramic view over the River Tagus and the city of Lisbon. It's impressive place to visit. Personally speaking, I would like to recommend folks to visit Castelo de Jorge if in case of choosing one either Torre de Belem and Castelo de Jorge.

Old World Splendor. Charming Castle on a hill with a cobblestone walkway. Set in a charming area this castle has a magnificent view of Lisbon! Be sure to go late afternoon and watch the sun set over the city.
Remade Castle. Although the castle affords beautiful views of the city, that is about all it has to offer.there really isn't alot inside. The basilica nearby has much more interesting artifacts.

A great view over Lisbon. ok, so it must be said that the actual castelo de sao jorge is nothing to write home about - it's average. it has some tricky stairs to navigate if you want to climb up into the turrets and you need to be careful walking back down them.but there's a much bigger picture going on here and it forms the whole experience. the main story is the journey up to the castelo. it sits on top of a hill overlooking the whole city so you have to get up there first and foremost. walking up is a great way to see this part of the city, and it's a walk well worth doing. yes you have to pay - it always amazes me how people get cranky and disillusioned because they have to pay.once inside the gate, the grounds are quite sprawling. there are many different angles and vantage points to look out over lisbon and for this alone, the castelo is worth it.
Great views!. The castle itself isn't particularly stand out. However, it has a great view of Lisbon. Make sure you bring your camera along!

Worth the admission fee for the views. We almost didn't pay the admission fee as it's fairly expensive. However I'm so glad we did! The views are out of this world. Take a picnic as they have little stone tables. You can eat lunch and admire the city.

Grand old castle with views of Lisbon. Much bigger than it looks! You are able to walk the walls of the entire castle and explore the inside and a small museum. There is a nice cafe as well for a well deserved cold drink after scaling all the turrets. We sat cooling off whilst peacocks and their chicks walked around us. Fantastic views of the city, down to the water. Make sure you wear your walking shoes to make the most of your visit :-)

Great views from Castelo. Wonderful place. although not historically correct restaured, it still has a wonderful feel to it. Take a taxi early in the morning (you definately do NOT want to walk up there) and you'll have the place virtually to yourself. We were there on a very hot August Sunday and was nice and quiet. Upon descending from one of the towers we encountered a group of actors playacting a knights (in shining armour?) fight. Complete with swords and heavy armouring....not sure if this is a regular thing but it was fun. Worth a. Visit is the archeological museum there if you're interested in such things.

Relaxing and great views. The castle itself is not up there with some of the best castles, but the overall location and area are great. Don't get me wrong, the castle is well worth visiting, it's just not Windsor Castle or similar.The gardens are really refreshing with all the Peacocks - including up trees! The views are superb and we really enjoyed our time there.The only negative was the archaeological site, to be honest that was a waste of time if you have been anywhere like Rome or have been to Roman or British ruins elsewhere. .

Stunning castle and views. Hard to imagine any invading army stood a chance trying to attack this fortress from either land or sea.
Be prepared for plenty of steep climbing and sore legs. Or just sit in the cafe eating ice cream and enjoying the views.
Muito lindo Castelo. This is a beautiful castelo and quite vast! The views from atop are spectacular and breathtaking. The grounds around the castelo are kept in order and the area is very clean.

Right out of a fairy tale.. This castle is amazing. As an American, I'm not used to visiting castles. This one is 1000 years old and feels like it is straight out of a fairy tale. The grounds are beautiful. It just transports you! I you are in Lisbon, don't miss this.

Exceeded all expectations. The views are some of the best in Lisbon if not the best and the castle itself is fantastic to explore. A photographer's dream. The museum is also interesting. Be sure to allow time to explore the areas around the castle too!

Not to be Missed. The Castelo de Sao Jorge fortification was built by the Moors in the mid 11th century and was the last defensive stronghold for the elite who resided on the Citadel. A maze of staircases and cobbled pathways takes you to the castle. There were many parts of castle one can explore. The castle also has a unique camera system, invented by Leonardo da Vinci, called the Camera Obscura. This is an optical system of lenses and mirrors which provides 360° detailed views of the city in real time. The views of Lisbon are stunning, one can also see the Praca do Comercio and the ruins of the cathedral & apse of the Carmo Convent, the 25th of April Bridge with Christ Redeemer on the hill and various other city highlights.

A must do. Of course we didn't miss the Castle! Missing it is like going to Vatican and miss the Pope! So yes we climb the old city narrow streets up to the top and yes we love it. The spirit of traveling is thus: go to places from were you can have a great view . Lisbon is one of the most city's I have ever been.. The way it is laying down to the river is so elegant and the river is really spectacular. I think that no one that visit Lisbon may understand the vibe of this city without climbing up to the Saint Jorge ' s Castle that, by the way, is am interesting picture of medieval age.
Only go for the view. The castle is in ruins so only go for the views of the city, which are fabulous. The stairs in the castle have no railing so it's a bit scary going up and down them.

AMAZING, BEAUTIFUL SUN SET WITH A GLASS OF DRINK. Recommend to go around sun set time, 2000-2100 to see the beautiful view. There is a restaurant to have a drink at terrace outside seeing a beautiful sun set. i think, this place is one of the best place to see the sun set of Lisbon.
Fantastic view . Fantastic view over most parts of Lisbon. Worth a visit. Discount on tickets for students . Take a walk on the top of the castle walls

A hell of a hike up but well worth it. Getting up there via a maze of staircases and paths is a challenge but you get to see Lisbon from a different view. Once up it was terrific walking around and exploring the different parts of the structure. You could see how strong the defenses were and imagine the cannons with an open view of everything for miles around. The only thing missing was a full moat filled with crocodiles

Great view of the city. Even if it look close on the map, take the bus to arrive to the castle because it's not easy to arrive by foot.A great view of the city is available there. Show your student card to get a discount. The restaurants within the castle area are expensive (approx. 3 euros for a bottle of water). But it is a must once you're near the center.

Extensive castle set in interesting neighbourhood. Castelo was a highlight of our trip to Lisbon and occupied a long half day. It is easily accessed by tram 28 (pretty special itself) and then a winding walk through little streets and houses. The signage to the Castelo is a little erratic meaning good signs in places, and other areas it is follow one's nose (and the crowd). Once inside Castelo there are excellent views over Lisbon, and many parts of the old castle to walk through which includes much climbing and descending narrow stairs. Camera Obscura provides a good coverage and understanding of the city. Take some form of bus or mini-bus or eco-car if you don't like walking over rough pavement with regular hills.

What a view !!!. This is a must, when you are in Lisbon. A magnificent view where you can see most of the city, the whole down-town and west south/north part. Most of the walls are still in place, watch the peacocks climbing up the trees is funny to look at, just close to the restaurant.

No value for money. An expensive (8,50€ per person) visit without a real reason. Great views... but Lisbon is plenty of "miradouros", where you can have similar views for free.The castle is just a few ruins, not worthing the visit.It's a nice walk, the one you would expect in a public area. I would rate it 4 stars, if it were for free!

Amazing view. Eat your Wheaties before heading up there. It is quite an uphill walk. Or maybe there is a tram that goes there and being a New Yorker, my default is to walk. At any rate, my wife and I walked all the way up about 20 minutes before closing. The view was very nice and it was very peaceful up there.

You can not miss this site. One of the most famous touristic site, you will have an amazing Panoramic view of all Lisboa. Inside the castel, you can find à place to eat and drink even if it's a little expensive. (Pasteis are tasty). You can have a walk in the castel neighborhood and find gifts shop.

So good!. Our first day in Lisbon and we decided to visit this castle after a nice walk through the centre of the city. We spent a very nice couple of hours walking and discovering all the little parts of these walls. The views of the city were so wonderful and the price of the ticket was not expensive.

Stand at the Top in Lisbon. Easily accessible by tram/bus/cab, the castle is nestled up the hill and a walk through the winding streets is more interesting. Founded in the 11th century as a Moorish castle, transited to Christian world in 12th century after The Christian Conquest. Remained a royal palace from 13th to 16th century. Was converted to Military Barracks in 17th century. The earthquake in 1755 destroyed many parts and subsequent work made it into more of a military installation. The Castle and ruins of former palace were discovered during restoration work in 1938.

Well worth a visit.. It's a fairly steep but scenic climb to Castelo de Sao Jorge along narrow, cobbled, twisting streets. It is in my view, in the best region of Lisbon - the Alfama. The castle is steeped in history, is well preserved with lovely grounds and fantastic views over Lisbon. There is also a museum. Tickets were EUR 8.50 when we went in April 2015 and it was well worth the visit.

Expensive views, disappointing shell. The castelo provides great views over the city, which is simply hard to beat. I do however feel like 8euros is expensive to enjoy this as inside there is little else worth seeing. This could be an amazing place to visit if there was an effort to inform you more of its history, uses of parts of the buildings, or recreated sections of how it should look. It's such a shame!! I honestly think it's not worth the visit. Enjoy the views from many of the city's free view points and enjoy a cocktail instead. Disappointing to say the least!

Views of Lisbon are stunning! . We used the hop on/off tram tour to get to the castle, we went early in the morning so we avoided the queues. It was 8.50e to get in but it wasn't worth it. The views of Lisbon are gorgeous but that's really it. Not much to see in the castle.

A castle visit that you have to do when you visit Lisbon.. We took the trip to the castle on the last day of our four day trip at Lisbon. It is absolutely worth to do as the view over the city is great. You will recognize most of the places you saw in the town.

Just another castle. The castle has been rebuilt, so there's really not much of genuine cadtle left. Good view of city, but one can get for free in many parts of Lisbon. Very crowded, long wait, better to skip and just soak in the atmosphere of the city on your own!

Go back in time in Alfama and Castelo de São Jorge. Loved this Castle in Alfama, loved this whole area, it was like going back in time, then walking the Hill and into the ruins of this castle really added to the experience. The view from the top was breath taking, so many photo opportunities. We were lucky to also see a family of Peacocks, 2 female and 1 baby together and the male in the gardens relaxing and looking beautiful. I would so recommend this Castle, walk the walls and feel like you are back in time..

Good view, not worth getting inside. It is worth it going for a walk around for the view and the streets around. In my opinion it is not worth getting inside as the castle is relatively new and there is no much to see inside, except for mass tourism, to justify the 10 euros entry.

Fabulous Views. We went early so there was not a queue. Great views in all directions over Lisbon but not much else to do once inside. When we left there were long queues and hoards more people heading towards it.

Stunning Views, Gorgeous Castle. We took the trolley up to the castle - the trolley is crowded and there is a long line since it is a very popular tourist attraction (like the cable cars in SF), but the walk up to the castle would be tough. Where the trolley drops you off there is a little café and breathtaking views of Lisbon. How could it get better? But it does! Walking up to the castle, grab a shot of the local cherry liquor, gingham, and head in through the gates. The grounds are vast and provide lots of opportunities for walking and picture taking. The breeze is fantastic up there and there is a woman with a cart who sells glasses of wine (and you can keep the glass!). My kids happily climbed the battlements while I sipped my wine and took a lot of pictures. It's so worth it for the view of Lisbon, and I can't imagine visiting the city without making this stop. There is also a restaurant on the grounds with tables overlooking the city, but we did not eat there. It really is a very beautiful place.

Breathtaking panorama of Lisbon. The Castelo de Sao Jorge was the best visit we did while staying in Lisbon. Making the most of the very pleasant weather, we spent a couple hours walking around the gardens and various terraces. The different views are simply beautiful and you'll be able to see the city from different angles. I would recommend to go at downtimes in order to avoid the crowds of tourists at rush hours (especially on week-ends). We also enjoyed some nice fresh strawberries and cherries sold on the street close to the castle after our long afternoon of visits.

Brilliant views over the city. It's a great trip by tram and then a short walk up a steep hill but well worth the effort! The entrance fee is not too high and you can easily spend a couple of hours walking around the ramparts and sitting admiring the views of the old city. Plenty of places to get a drink or ice cream if it's very hot!Does get very busy though.
Go for the view. Quite a ride to the top. The view of Lisbon is great. There is not a lot of interesting things within the castle itself.
Tourist trap. 10 euro entrance and long lines. Didn't even make it in. Stunning views from the surrounding free terraces though!

Beautiful views. We walked up the hill up lots of steps and side streets to get to the castle and spent the majority of the day there. Cheap entry fee, beautiful view and great photo taking opportunities and then the castle itself is wonderful. No wheelchair or pushchair access from what I could see. Some steep steps with not much safety hand railing wise so probably not good for young kids but you can still enjoy the castle whilst avoiding the awkward stair climbs. They have a nice gift shop and museum / exhibition part and cafes to chill in and around the castle grounds too. Good family or couples attraction for a morning or afternoon.

A castle like many others . It was a little workout to go up to the castle by foot, which isn't negative in any way. Still it should be considered if you're planning to go there. We payed 5,00 € for entering. Personally I think it's a bit pricey. It is an old castle like many others. There isn't really something special about this place, however you have a great view over Lisbon. If you don't have a limited budget and/or you're in to castles you'll probably enjoy it.

Don't miss it. The walk up to the castle entrance is delightful. It's a bit of a climb but worth it. You'll pay a few Euros to enter the castle walls but it's well worth it. The vista views of the city are awesome. While the buildings inside the walls are in ruin there are clean washrooms, a restaurant and wonderful areas to sit and relax. We probably spent about an hour walking around the walls of the castle.

a must see. The castle with its amazing views of lisboa is quite a long steep climb up or you could take the lift halfway there and then enjoy a quiet drink just outside it. before you enter turn right and then left go to the top of the road to Rua das flores de santa cruz and enjoy the wonderful little local hostelry. Hugho is the affable and friendly owner he is the one who brings olives to his neighbours and speaks to the man across the road with the amazing cat who behaves very territorialy towards his owner crying for him when he goes out. This is the real life of the castle a small community living together in harmony, helping each other out. the castle is what the past was and yet it is also the present reminding the visitor of the conquerors who claimed the area in the artefacts held therein from ancient times and that there are inhabitants of the human kind as well as the wonderful peacocks. There is a small gift shop in the grounds and a cafe and restaurant but the views and the artefacts are wonderful.

Great place to visit. We were really pleasantly surprised with this castle. It stared off nicely, as we were guided in front off the ticket line, as we are travelling with our little son - really cool in the warm weather. The castle is surrounded by a nice garden and it offers great views and plenty of space for children to run around - not worrying about the traffic in town. Just a nice place to chill in town.

Not Much Inside the Walls. Maybe it was because we came straight from Rome, where the castles and ruins are hard to beat. Or because so much of the architecture in Lisbon is beautiful and FREE to look at. Other then the incredible views, the castle offers little to look at. There are a lot of big castle walls, with not much inside. A disappointment.
the view!. the castle itself is mostly what's left of the walls but the views are to die for (and well worth the climb).
Awesome view. I went here on my last day of visiting Lisbon and I wish that I would go earlier because that day was cloudy, but even though the view is amazing and everyone should go there.
good. it wasn't that exciting in design but this castle does have some important historical history because it was a property of portugal's first king Anfoso I wich makes this place important.

Great views of the city and river. I can't think of any other place in Lisbon that will provide such great views of the city, and obviously great photo opportunities also, especially if it's a sunny day. At €8 though, it is a little pricey considering you are essentially just walking around an open area which is little more than a shell of what it must have been in the past.

By Jorge, that's a view. We had been warned about the crowds at the castle, so we set out early and (so beat the heat, too). That was good advice. And a brisk walk up the hill was not a problem in the morning cool. Entrance is 8.50 Euros per person, which is expensive for not much more than getting access to a fab viewing point. And, yes, the site does afford 360 degrees of spectacular views of Lisbon. Try and catch the Camera Obscura if you can ... though it's limited to 15 visitors per showing and may entail a wait in the full sun. And if you do find the need to escape the sun, there are plenty of shady spots. And bring a hat and sunnies.The museum is also worth a look.
A worthy walk up. A great way to start your trip in Lisbon. Walk there unless you are unable. Breathtaking views and it will be come your focal point for the rest off your trip.

Great spot to look over Lisbon. Old casles were always build on a good spot, and it's not different concerning Castelo de Sao Jorge. A well preserved castle which houses a wild bird show, a nice restaurant and a gift shop.But it's the view over the city which has the biggest impact.

Breathtaking views of the city from different angles . Fantastic city views. That's about it. Expensive entrance tickets and steep and slippery stairs to get to the castle towers. We saw quite a few people falling down up or down the stairs. Careful!

Beautiful castle overlooking Lisboa. Great views and beautiful castle right in Lisboa. Fine hike up the hill to the castle, including two long flights of stone steps and some long switchback style streets up to the top - a bit steep but just slow down if you are not in shape. Go early in the day if it is summer as the heat is intense by the middle of the day. Castle inside is grand but not that unusual if you are already blase after seeing so many spectacular castles on the Iberian Peninsula. If this is your first it will be a wow. Walking or hiking shoes best.

OK, but not that great.... The castle is mainly some walls which where not preserved too well. There is a nice little museum with histotic artifacts. It's nice, but if you have only a couple of days to spend in Lisbon I wouldn't reccomend to go here.
Best views. Must be said best views of Lisbon from inside, but other than that not much to see or do, enjoyed the walk up and down

City's History Landmark. São Jorge Castle is just fundamental for you to dive into Lisbon's history. Besides being a great place to be, full of trees, peacocks, fresh air... The castle has a great top view of the city, which helps to understand how the city works zonewise. I'd highlight 2 attractions inside city's castle: 1 - the archaeological site, which has the great intervention of the architect João Luís Carrilho da Graça and was also the arabic neighborhood during their occupation. 2 - The Periscope, with time-set sessions - maybe from 1 to 1 hour, but gets you to see the city in 360º real time.The entrance is average price, but Lisbon citizens don't pay it. And you can also picnic in there! :)
Nice castle!. A nice view of the city from up above! And the castle is really nice and big, with lot of things to see. I loved the walk on the walls.

Great castle ruins. Many vis-a-vis seats built into the actually wall, perfect for couples <3. Perfect views all round. Pay 50 cents for a 2 minute view through a binocular. Be careful when climbing the stairs to go up on the ramparts, unsafe for little kids, safely rails lacking...
A must see attraction. Beautiful grounds and a great view of the city. Make sure you see the Camera Obscura presentation, very impressive.

Amazing old Castle + 360 degree views of Lisboa. Want to pretend you're defending the city from invading marauders? This is a great one for practice! Ha! A very well preserved castle with placards and ramparts and arrow slits, oh my! There's also a gaggle of peacocks living on site. For a 360 view of Lisbon, this is the place to go.

Close 10 EUR for the view?. I thought that the view is for free and wanted to pass the gates but the staff just jumped over me, as if I would be a criminal, and was almost arrested for my try… had to stay in the queue for 20 minutes and buy the ticket for 8.50. As I got inside, there already were a lot of tourists everywhere, a lot of people pushing each other around even on the high walls. It wasn’t possible to get a small place, from where to enjoy the view, so I felt very disappointed about. I couldn’t feel the smell of the great history, but the smell of money and sweaty tourists. Everything here was too commercial and touristic for me. Worst experience I had along my way. There are a lot of more to see in Lisbon…If you are looking for a perfect place to stay, look after “BookMe Lisboa”, an exceptional apartment in Alfama! I really can recommend it!

Nice views. Great castle from 12 century. You can spend hours there viewing gardens, statues, cable, museum. View from there are magnificent. Take few photos of Lisbon from there. Fee is 8.50 Euros per person for entry.

Not the best site to visit but worth it.. Dear readers...Not the best site to visit due to how crowded it gets. I would recommend that you visit this site and plan on doing so followed by another since there are a variety of places to see in close proximity.

It's a good climb up there but so worth it. Prepare to spend the entire day at this one, so much to see, from the gardens, spectacular views across the river estuary, statues, the various museums and exhibitions, there are the most ancient ruins, loads of information boards in various languages, you can climb to the roof terrace, relax in the massive garden areas of stop for refreshments in or outside the cafe......Oh beware the peacocks, they may well be perched on a branch above your head!

Great Castle. The queue for the castle was non-existent during the week, at least in the morning. We didn't get there super early, but we got right in. Even when we left several hours later, the queue wasn't very long.We spent hours here! There is a museum which exhibits artifacts found on site from the Iron Age right up to 18th century, and gives a great timeline of the castle's use through that time. Connects the history of Lisbon and Portugal, too.The castle itself, a separate part of the whole, was amazing. You get some great views of the city from atop the walls and within the towers. The stairway down from the castle to the Tower of St. Lawrence is long, which means you have to come back UP to continue your tour, so be prepared. The queue to get into the camera obscura part was a little too long for us, so we skipped it. Before you exit the castle part and cross over the small bridge, turn left and follow the signs to the archeological area. There are some ancient Iron Age areas, some Roman areas, and some Moorish/Muslim areas, and there are guided tours of this small archeological "dig" throughout the day, which I recommend.There are many things to see outside the castle proper (the museum I mentioned above, being one). We saw some resident peacocks, a peahen and a chick near the cafe! The entrance fee is 8.5 Euros for adults; you get a lot of bang for your buck, here, depending on how much you want to see.
Back to the past. A nice castle in an hill over Lisbon city. Amasing bellevue over the most part of the city and also over the Tejo river and the Independent bridge.

Only for the view - but for that it's a must.. The castle itself is not a big thing - specially if you have seen castles before. But the view... it's amazing. You can see the whole city, the bridges, the ocean... If you visit it in the main season, prepare for the crowd on the walls.

Best Mira Douro. This is the best place to have a great view on the city! You could have a walk on the medieval wall and take a breathtaking view on different part of the city ! You have also use all the attraction inside the castle as the permanent exposition and the black room just to have a demonstration of the physic phenomenon !! Totally suggested
Beautiful. If you want the most magnificent views of Lisbon, be sure to go to the castle. Walking around the top, from tower to tower, takes you back in time and gives you a magnificent view.

Loved the castle. 1. Ignore the TukTuk drivers who tell you 'it's a waste of time, it's 10€ to get in and it's just a bunch of walls when you get there' and then try to persuade you to take you on a tour of the outside 2. Get the No 28tram up to the Castillo stop (it's not the last stop so look out). You can't catch the No 28 from the main square by the sea, it's about 3roads back from the sea front. 3. Signs to the actual gate aren't clear, so just ask someone, don't wander around like we did. 4. The castle isn't 'just a bunch of walls', it's amazing. A beautiful ruined moorish castle, with stunning views from the hilltop, you can safely walk round the battlements, there's an archaeological site, the grounds are lovely, there are peacocks everywhere. We loved it. Just 8.50€ each.

Don't bother. We took tram #28 to the top of the city after an hour wait. Then still had to walk up a few hills to get tho the castle. about $10 to get in and not much to see. Went to other castles and much better. there was no info on what each area represented. Not good for those that are afraid of heights
Great place to sit and relax. €8.50 or €6.30 with (LC)lisboa card,LC also gets you their free on Tram 28,Great views with lots of shade and a cool breeze to offset the blazing Sun,
Loved the castle. This was on the top of our list in Lisbon. The views from the castle were spectacular, the castle was in amazing shape and lots of history. We really enjoyed it.

Quick tour. This is really just ruins from an medieval royal palace but offers a wonderful viewpoint to take photos. The castle is accessible up a steep staircase and is not for the weary. The walls are knee high so I was not comfortable walking around the narrow walkway let alone my kids.
great view!!. great view!!it´s an important arqueological place were you have an amazing view from the city.it will give you great pics.for free for Lisbon citizens.

Great view but that's it. Great view point of Lisbon by not worth the admission fee. Was hoping there would be done part of the restored castle for visiting. Didn't learn anything! What a shame. They were hosting a large group for cocktails. Hope we didn't miss stuff!
Great views. This is a place that's worth its entry ticket. Great views over the Lisbon city. The castle not so interesting but the views make up everything. Must visit!

Interesting . A great castle. Very nice views of the city but not so impressive. Design is cool and it's good for professional photographer. If you have the Lisbon card you will get 20% discount on the ticket. It's recommended as it's close to the center center.

Step back in time!. St.George castle or Castelo de Sao Jorge is great fun to see. It allows you to step back into the golden age of Portugal. While there isn't much difference from the outside to the in, it is fun to fantasize about the past and what must have taken place within its walls.

The heart of Lisbon. A very pretty castle affording excellent views over Lisbon. Some good scrambling around the walls and a decent museum on site which helps. At the heart of Lisbon's history and probably a 'must' for the city.

It's a Castle!!. It's a castle inasmuch as it's very like castles anywhere but it's very well preserved and the views are pretty awesome. We walked up from Rossio square and the views made it all worthwhile. We didn't take a tour, though I'm sure they are worth it for the experience, We just wanted to stroll around enjoying the sun and the scenery, very nice it was too.
Lisabon Awesome. it was very nice to traveling in Lisbon,was awesome to ride on ship and to see the scenery view of Lisbon

Castelo Sao Jorge visit. The Castle is a must do when in Lisbon. Take the Number 28 tram or one of the tours from the seafront square and walk up the narrow streets to the entrance. The views of the City itself are worth the trip and admission price, but climbing the various castle towers and exploring the grounds are great fun with kids. Grab an ice cream on the way out and stroll back down to the city. Great way to spend a few hours and work up and appetite.
Castel de Sao Jorge - worth the walk, worth the view. Interesting, with fabulous views of the city. A walk back in time...albeit after a walk up a hill only to be done in the cool of morning.
For hot days . Not bad. Especially for the hot days. You can sit and relax and admire the castle. There is amazing view, museum and restaurant.

A visit worth!. We actually walked here from the martim moniz stop. It was a quite steep walk through the narrow roads, ut it was nice and autentic. The castle had a great view and cool details. I would say it's one of the better view of the city. There was an archeologic site all back from the 700's BC and some of the old house walls around 900-1100's AD was rebuilt extending into new walls so you could see how it actually was back then. There was a short walk from here to the monastery nearby.

A must visit. We decided to walk up the the castle on our first day in Lisbon. We were really tired after the flight so we debated not going in but I am so glad that we did! The view from the castle is amazing, you can see the whole of Lisbon whilst sitting and enjoying a glass of wine at the restaurant there. Bliss! (Make sure you wear comfortable shoes though as the terrain can be a bit difficult!)

Take the stairs..... Take the stairs, climb the hill, work your butt off to get to this one. Don´t just shag a tuk'tuk, or grad a bus or cab. This one was meant to be reached the hard way. It´s a great, but short visit--not much to see, but you´ll never forget it, ever.
Beautiful view. Very beautiful place and with a gorgeous view of the City. Also very crowded so be there when they open and enjoy the place all by yourself :-)

Not impressed. I was expecting a bit more than I received. Entrance fee seemed a bit too much for what we received in the end. Nice view but you can get a better ne just a few minutes away, for free.As for the obscure room - only visited with Guide and next one available was in 1.5 h. So we decided to skip the attraction. Overall, my impression was that we could have used the moneys for other things.

Fascinating Castle. Castelo de Sao Jorge was one of the more enjoyable attactions in Lisbon. It provides an excellent insight into what Portugese castles look like and their construction. One of the coollest portions of this castles was being surprised to see the beautiful Peacocks strut their stuff. It really made the visit even better, with a neat aspect to the Castle. If you're in Lisbon, this is perhaps the best attaction in my opinion. Take the time to visit, and I don't think you'll be disappointed"! It's relatively easy to access with a hike that isn't too long from the main center of Lisbon. Safe travels.

Go see it and take your kids!!. The Castelo de Sao Jorge was not really high on our list of things to see and do in Lisbon, but we soon were convinced that it was one of the highlights. The ancient structures (some dating back to the Bronze Age) were much more interesting than we had anticipated and just climbing all those ancient stairs and feeling like we were in medieval times was amazing. It is a bit of a climb to get there if you do not choose to take the tram 28 which is apparently only used by tourists and pickpockets (or so every sign we saw warned us), but it is well worth it. Take your kids - they'll just love the fact that they can climb all over the place! The view is breathtaking but we didn't stay until sunset and did the free walking tour instead.

Must see!. Rick steves didn't recommend it so we were a bit hesitant but it ended up being the highlight of our stay in Lisbon! The view alone was worth the 20 euros we spent. This covered 2 adults and 2 teenagers (15 and 17). You could climb up and walk along some ramps along the side of the castle and climb some guard towers to get an even better view. Probably the best part was the real time 360 "camera" which showed all of Lisbon. A tour guide explained it for free and it was worth the 20 min. It gave a great introduction to the city! Overall, no complaints!

Castelo de Sao Jorge. My second day in Lisbon, we visited the Castelo do Sao Jorge, also in the area was an unguided walking tour of the ancient Alfama neighborhoods. This was fascinating to me. Tight windy streets, people hanging out their windows talking to neighbors all day long. I learned the streets were built this was originally to give the residents more time to escape in case of invaders. Everywhere we went the people were friendly. It helps to know the language though. My sister in law spoke portuguese and we had no troubles anywhere we went.

Go for the View. Nothing much to the actual castle. The only reason to go is to take in the view of the city. It is the best view o the city in town! Be sure an take the trolley or a cab up the hill it is quite a climb to the top from the city.

Got the wow factor. Best views in Lisbon. You get to see the whole city and appreciate the River Tagus in its full glory and the bridges that cross it. It's a well kept castle and the walk around the top is amazing, but with no hand rails you need to be careful - take really good, grippy walking shoes.

Great historic site. It is a great place to spend an hour or two. Entrance was 8,50 but it was worth it.You have fantastic views over big parts of the city. You can also explore the walls and towers of it, and sit there to relax a bit. Another part is the ruins of really old days, like the iron age. Maybe not that exiting at least for me.

The finest view in Lisbon. This hilltop citadel was the residence of the Portuguese king,a theater, prison and arms depot. After the 1755 earthquake the place remained in ruins until 1938 began a complete renovation, rebuilding walls and adding garden. From top of the castle you will have a great view of Lisbon.

Not much to see . A disappointment for us. There aren't much to see other than walls and ruins. Views are nice but you can get the same view from many other look out points. You can pass this attraction if run out of time.

Great Views. This is a very old castle that has been remodeled many times. The views from the city walls of the city is amazing. Worth every penny. The castle is cool. The architecture is magnificient from the outside. We are not allowed to enter any rooms. Overall it is a great experience and if you are in Lisbon a must.

Amazing castle and day out. Brilliant place to go and explore for the day. Surprised by the size of the place and can easily spend a whole day here.Some spectacular views from castle over the whole city and the Camera Obscura is worth seeing too whilst there.Admission price initially seemed high, but after spending the whole day there was very reasonable. The only thing that let it down the day we went was that there was no water so the toilets were closed.

Great view!. We walked there so it was the worst part of the trip because it was faraway and was to hot outside. But i'll recomend you this great viem from the castle. You can see there all the downtown and piece of the see. The castle is nothing special but the view is just amazing.

No indications at all. The only thing worth in this castle are the views. Everything else is not indicated so you have no idea where you actually are. The only map was unreadable as it was full of rust.

Tremendous perspective of Lisbon. The castle and grounds are a must do in Lisbon. The Castle itself is nice...not tremendously intricate but nice with large grounds, amazing views, plenty of places to explore and climb to get unique views of Lisbon. The scenery and view of the city is tremendous
Amazing view!. You well get an amazing view of Lisbon while being at Castelo de São Jorge. Sweet combination between nature, city and beatiful architecture.

Great Visit!. I had a great time at the Castle. There were tons of opportunities to take great pictures. Plus there were peacocks that roam around and come right up to you to beg for food (watch out they bite). You also get to climb up onto the walls and walk around. It;s probably not a great idea if you are scared of heights. The stairs are steep and the walk way are narrow, so wear good shoes and be careful.

Wonderful views from the castle and well conserved!. I was in Lisbon with a friend that I made that day after missing a flight to New York. Since we had to wait for a whole day in Lisbon, we decided to explore the city and take advantage of the situation!We took a taxi from hour hotel to downtown and made our way up to the castle. We had to walk for a little bit to get there, and although we were not planning on going to the castle, we ended up there.The castle is not the most impressive one I've ever seen. It was just regular, however the views of the city from up there were just amazing!It is worth it when you have some sort of discount, student in my case. Otherwise, 7 euros is a little too much for what it has to offer.

Great (and uncrowded) view of Lisbon. There's not a whole lot of castle to see; fortunately the castle has a super panoramic view and lots of space in which to view it (unlike some of the Miradouros) We were there mid evening and thoroughly enjoyed watching the sun setting; the whole experience made even better by the "Relax take your glass with you" truck; nice local wines to buy by the bottle or the glass.
Great place to relax. Amazing place with beautyful viewpoints. Around Castel there is a lot of nice stores and restaurants. Tickets are not so expensive.

Not so easy. If you have mobility problems, think about going to this attraction. It´s up in a hill with very bad indications to go up. No heels recommended.The view is beautiful, but we had leg cramps the other day!!!

Great historical viewpoint over the city. We spent 1,5h in the castle. In a hot day there's a nice cool breeze in garden providing amazing panorama over the city center. The castle allows you to enter every wall and tower (lots of climbing though...)

Excellent viewpoint for Lisbon, and a great historicalmexperience. Felt like a walk up to the castle, but the lift at Pingu Doche (free!) would have saved some time and effort. Once there, the view over Lisbon was fantastic, and a walk around the walls gave us a 360 degree view. The museum supplied the history in an interesting way, and I would recommend a visit if you are in Lisbon.

Nice view otherwise boring . We as many others took the tram line 28 to the castle - that is a nice experience. there is a short but steep walk from the tram stop to the castle 200-300 meters away. The admission fee is around 8-10 euro pr. person and there isn't really anything in the castle worth seeing except the view, which you can get for free numerous places in Lisbon

Moorish castle overlooking Lisbon. Old Moorish castle on hill overlooking the city of Lisbon. Take Tram 28 to the castle. great views, especially at sunset. All that is left are the walls and doorways of the castle - but the experience was memorable. Lots of peacocks running around.

A highlight of Lisbon. Lisbon is a fantastic city, one of my favorite in Europe and reminds me very much of San Francisco. The Castelo de Sao Jorge is quite amazing to see, and the fun part is that you can run around, climbing up into the castle and through many nooks, to feel as if you are truly exploring. Kids would absolutely love this place. The gardens around it are very nice, and you could easily picnic and relax to watch a sunset there. The views are beautiful and there are many great photo opportunities from inside and on top of the castle. You cannot miss this if you go to Lisbon.

Worth it for the views over Lisbon. The views over Lisbon are everything, so good chance for sweeping panoramas. Also, good opportunity to watch air traffic coming in low over the city and disappearing to land at the airport. Otherwise a bit underwhelming. Not a great deal to see and no great effort made to provide information in English. They could make so much more of this attraction with just a bit more effort. However, when you come out of the castle and return to the main road take the opportunity to hop on to Tram 28 for the trip downhill, through the narrow roads of Lisbon and on to the end of the line. Get off then catch the same tram back and do it all over again. Great fun!
Nice Castle. First saw this castle from Santa Just a Elevator, amazing pictures of sunsets. also a good experience if you have the Lisbon pass.

Nice castle, but most spectacular is the view over Lisbon. A lot of sights derive their beauty from their location. Castelo de Sao Jorge does that too. Sure, it is a nice big castle, there is a restaurant and small museum, but most of all it has a beautiful view over the city and river Tejo. You recieve a small book with some basic information. The castle itself is big but not very spectacular, although you have the possibility to walk on the big walls and towers. Watch out with little children though, since not everywhere are good fences to prevent you from falling down. In the museum we ran into a little costume play, which we could not really follow, but looked really nice with traditional dances.

Interesting castle with outstanding views of the city. This was one of my favorite things during our week-long stay in Lisbon. We did this on our first day in Lisbon and took our time walking up the hill to the castle, which was a nice way to explore a little bit. For those who are unable (or unwilling) to walk up the hill, you could take a tuk-tuk or trolley up and then walk down after visiting the castle to do this as well.Upon entering the site, you have the opportunity to gaze out over the castle walls to the city below. The views are outstanding and going to the castle for this alone was worth it. But stay for the castle! It was great to have the opportunity to walk through such history. You could imagine guards manning the castle walls. There is also an archaeological site and small museums on the site of the castle. We spent time just wandering around through these exhibits and enjoyed them, although more description could have been provided for some.
You have to visit if you're in Lisbon. Lovely view. Nice to walk but a little dificult specialy with the hot wheather. You have to visit if you're in Lisbon

Affordable price for entertainment . We spent about an hour and a half here without stopping for snacks or drinks. The views are unbeatable and there's a lot to see. There are places to eat or even get wine to go.Entrance fee was 6.50€. Worth it in my opinion!

Could be better. Place is a charm with stories waiting to be unravelled behind each stone but... fact is very little is available/narrated for the visitor to discover the spot. Worst of all, markings tablets are nearly worn out so as to prevent legibility when available. I regret what that visit could have been, templar, mauresque era...Worth the spot over Lisboa and the Taje

Nice enough, nothing special. I enjoyed walking around the castle ground. As expected it was quite busy, but as the grounds are fairly large, this was not a problem.Main attraction for me were the amazing views of Lisbon that can be had from there. Climbing the stairs to the castle towers was also fun, but in all it wasn't anything so special to be sorry to miss. Worth seeing, but pricey really for what it is.

Among Lisbon's Best. The castle is in the Alfama District, which happens to be an amazing part of Lisbon. The castle is well-preserved. I walked up to the site, which was quite a hike for me but the effort was well worth it...spectacular views throughout. There was also a quartet performing which made my visit all the more exciting. Visiting Lisbon, I suggest getting the Lisboa card. I didn't but had I bought one, it would have meant a lot of savings.

An Embarrassment of Beautiful Views. This national monument was the first stop on our Alfama tour and it set the stage for the rest of the day. Ridiculously beautiful views wherever you turn and a sense of Lisbon you just don't get on the street. Though hot, there are plenty of pleasant, shady spots throughout the park. There was even a peacock pecking about the day we were there. The archaeological part of the site is the most strenuous and least shady.
Good views. Nice views over Lisbon and its surroundings from the old castle and its walls. Entrance fee is 8,50€/adult.

A Castle with character. We spent several hours walking through this wonderful ancient castle/fort. The informative modern museum is well worth a visit, and a walk around the ramparts is a must. The views of Lisbon from the top are simply spectacular.The trip up to the Fort is almost as interesting - a passenger lift takes you from the street up several floors to another street. Then you walk through a supermarket to another passenger lift which takes you up several more floors. Then you walk about a kilometre to the gates of the fort. Fascinating.Be sure to walk down some of the intriguing narrow cobblestoned laneways on your way back, and stop in at one of the many bars or cafés.

My favorite attraction in Lisbon. I was planning on staying at this beautiful castle for an hour or two. I ended up staying for close to 4 hours. I walked the castle grounds 3 or 4 times and took a nap in the shade overlooking beautiful Lisbon skyline. The castle itself is not the most amazing in the world, but the view of Lisbon on a nice breezy day is worth the trip itself. I very much enjoyed watching the sunset from the castle. It's also quite fun to get a frozen treat hot day, find a spot, and people watch. I will definitely be back.

Interesting Castle good views over Lisbon. We travelled up on the Tourist Tram from Lisbon Centre. Steep walk up to Castle from tram stop. You can walk around the battlements but be careful. We saw a lady fall over on the uneven surface as its uneven stones on the walls and ground. Lovely views all over Lisbon. Steep walk back down to tram - tourist tram did not arrive so we got the Tram 28 which is often very crowded. That took us back to our hotel The Mundial as it starts and stops there. Which was great as we were tired after walking around up by the castle and all around the castle. Well worth visiting though.

Beautiful Sunset. It was worth a visit for us, because we like old castles and got to enjoy the sunset from up there. Otherwise there isn't all that much to see inside. There would have been some exhibition, but it closed half an hour before closing time. So we didn't get to see it.
intersting. beautifull site, intersting ploace where you walk in the past.it preserved in a very good condition and give you the feeling of walking in the past

Must see in Lisbon. This is a castle/fortress on a hill in the middle of Lisbon. It is in fairly good shape - there isn't much to see but the walls and a small museum. The best part about this site is the views - they are really spectacular. You can get a really good idea of the city from the vistas.

Not worth your money. You only get €2 discount with the Lisbon card. You really are just paying for the view. Yes, the view was fantastic but the maintenance of the castle has plenty of room for improvement. It rained just before we visited and most of the railings were cover with rust as a result, because the paint has long peeled off. We had to be careful not to stain our clothes while taking pictures.

Amazing views of Lisbon. We visited here on our last day in Portugal. I think if we had visited this site before Sintra, we would have been more impressed. Sintra is so amazing that this castle, unfortunately, paled in comparison. However, we took a tuk tuk to the castle which was very fun and then we listened to some street performers. We also bought cherries on our way into the castle and then spent some time savoring the views of Lisbon! Overall we had a very nice time. I would go back as we did not spend a great deal of time here.

Great place and views. Although it was Sunday, this place was not overcrowded. Excellent views of the Lisbon town and the long red bridge. Tour through the all places here takes cca 2 hours. Many possibilities for refreshment, clean place. Recommended.

One of the best views of the city. The castle of st. Jorge has one of the best panoramic views of Lisbon. It costs 8.5€ but is well worth it I enjoyed exploring and there are quite a few peacocks that have taken residents inside the fort.

A must visit when in Lisbon.. This old castle on the hills overlooking Lisbon is well worth a visit. You can either walk up the hill (takes about 20 mins) or catch a tram up and then it is only a short walk. The castle gives amazing views over the city of Lisbon.

Worth the Climb. Amazing castle, gardens and awesome views. One of the best places to visit in Portugal. Wonderfully historic Moorish castle with the best views of historic Lisbon. Walk along the walls, sit on the terrace and reflect on the beautiful city below. Walk down through the Alfama, so interesting and picturesque. Fantastic!

Great view. As we only had a couple of hours before our flight to the Azores we took a cab to the castle and spent there about 1 hour which wasn't enough. The ticket isn't cheap, 8.5€ but if one has time it is certainly worth it, the views of Lisbon are breathtaking, the site is clean and well kept, and even the peacocks that walk around seem to be really well kept....I am sure that on our next visit to Lisbon we will spend a morning in this castle
Great castle, wonderful view. This is, by far, one of the best spots in Lisbon.Take a walk to Castelo de São Jorge and enjoy the magical view from the top of the city. Breathtaking!

Soaked on the battlements. The castle dominates the city of Lisbon and it is worth the climb for the views alone. Despite a prolonged downpour we still stayed for two hours or so before diving into a nearby restaurant for shelter. The lower walk is very pleasant with old olive trees. Much of the structure remains and there are even better views from the battlements. However explanations of the structures are sparse, leaving you to guess the various functions. There is a restaurant (closed when we visited) and a small cafeteria.
Great view. One of the best views that you will find in Lisbon, and great walk alongside the walls. Not for people afraid of heights :)

Amazing views. Worth it for the views from the castle. Not a lot to see in the castle itself but the views alone are worth the 8 euro entry fee. You can get there by the famous number 28 tram (which goes through the old alfama area up to the castle) from martim moniz but be prepared to queue. We waited over an hour with only 1 or 2 trams then all of a sudden 5 came at once! alternatively we also walked there one day, 20 minutes uphill walk. There is a great wine bar - wine bar de castelo for after the walk, which is close to the castle

Extensive ruins with excellent views of the city. We walked around the battlements on a beautiful sunny day. You can see for miles from the walls and the surrounding streams has lots of good restaurants and bars

Incredible views over Lisbon. I didn't manage to squeeze a trip to the Castelo during my first trip to Lisbon, but now I am back here, I managed to visit it the other day and I am so glad I did!On a beautiful sunny day, the miradouro (panoramic view) from the Castelo extends out over Lisbon and the River Tejo and it really is magnificent. There are beautiful gardens to walk around and many opportunities to get different viewpoints over the city. The castle itself is interesting to walk around and there is a café a restaurant etc. if you want to extend your stay and enjoy the views.It is up steep, cobbled streets (like much of Lisbon), so be prepared!

Battlements from the Middle ages. This was the ancient seat of Portugal for over 400 years with strong battlements showing a view of the Baixa and Rio Tejo. You can take the tram up to the top and then walk a short while however if there is limited mobility, this castle is not suitable. Try to visit the wonderful periscope projector invented by Leonardo da Vinci and installed at the vantage point in teh castle to look out across the surrounding countryside for attacks

Overpriced-Great Views. Lucky to have visited on a cloudy (quiet) afternoon. The route around the attraction contain little in the way of signs/information. (Its unfair to charge full price admission when the Moorish area is partially closed off and there are a few dead end walking routes.
Must see. Great views over the city with interesting things to do within the walls. There is a camera obscura (one of few in the world) and an archaeological site dating back to the 7th century
Spectacular.. It is a must! Enjoy the history, Enjoy the view of Lisbon. Enjoy the castle. Walk all over the limits on those old walls. Take a look into the museum. It is incredible.

wonderful. Eventhough the castle is not in its original state,it was recently rebuilt,it haw wonderfull viewpoint of the city and I would recomend visiting it using thw old tram, or a tuk tuk! When you are on the towers mind the strong wind, Also, every staircase is not really safe so mind your children and confortable shoes!!!!!
The views are amazing ,. You should get a taxi to take you all the way up once you are there you will not regret it great pictures.

Must see in Lisbon . However long your stay is in Lisbon, this is one of the spots you must see. Views of Lisbon from this castle are phenomenal and the walk to and around the castle is both pleasant and fascinating.

Well worth a visit. Having walked up through the Alfama district from the river, I almost chose to take a couple pictures and head back down, rather than tour the castle. That would have been a huge mistake. Regular tickets are 8.50 and student tickets are 5 euros, but you have to be 25 or under (hint: they don't ask for proof of age). As others have mentioned, the views over the city are stunning. The castle itself is in great condition. It would have been nice to have a bit more interpretation around, to explain the buildings and their history, but it was still beautiful as it was. If you're not a fan of heights or have knee problems, the walls will be an issue -- very steep stairs and not always that much in the way of hand railings. There's still plenty to see just wandering on the ground, though. It was really great to see the foundations of buildings that have been dug up and some good explanations of how the castle would have looked if they were still standing.

Best views and fantastic ruins. Well worth a visit. We took a taxi which got us almost to the door. It is a steep hill so the up journey is best not attempted if your fitness is in question. Likewise it is easy to slip on the way down on the cobblestone streets so be sure to wear your sturdiest runners. The walk around Alfama and down from the castle was just as interesting. June is festival time in Lisbon so the decorations were up for the festivsl of St Anthony and the festival of the sardines. Lots of little genuine 'made in Portugal' souvenir shops and great good value cafes nearby too.

A must visit when in Lisbon. Great views over the City and river, the castle ruins make for an enjoyable walk and exploration. Take a picnic as there are plenty of places to sit and eat in the grounds. A good value visit

A must see castle in the middle of the city. A beautiful moorish castle in the middle of the city, the views from the walls are great, and you can even have your picture taken with exotic hunting birds! While many cities have the typical tourist attractions, this is one that is definitely with the visit.
magical experience. We were almost alone in the whole park. it was magical. the views were lovely. I would recommend the walk up and the coolness of the gardens.

Nice relax sightseeing. Great views from the top of the castle. Also a great place to take beatiful pictures. We went thereas a couple late on the day. Alsmost at closing tile. Not that many people around. You could realy feel the atmosphere of days long gone by.

Historic place with romantic atmosphere and scenic view.. You should'nt miss the castle, not only for the interesting exhibition and the historic dimension but also because of the incredible view over the entire city center. The Castle is truely a must for Lissabon-visitors.
Maravilhoso!. Just loved it, there aren't enough words! Great views, amazing history, lots of ups and downs, perfect for walking around and admiring :)
Priceless. Really good place to see Lisbon from above. Tourists have to pay to get in, but the view is priceless. Best time to go: late afternoon and see the sunset

Quite a hike, but worth it for the views of the city!. It is definitely quite a walk up hill to this place - its doable if you are young/fit, but may want to consider a taxi if not. It's worth a visit just for the beautiful views of the city, and the castle is very nice as well. Although be warned, it is all old ruins.

Well worth the money. When we bought our ticket (approx 9 euro), we thought it would just be the castle but it's much more than that. There's ALSO a beautiful observation point of the city, the ruins, a museum, and some sort of telescope of the city (didn't get to see that). Great package deal! This entire thing could take you a couple hours. The castle is enormous... Be warned, there are a lot of steep stairs to go up on the walls. It can get tiring after a while!

Stunning views but be prepared for somem excercise.. The walk up to this castle is a tough one (there is always the tram) but the effort is well worth it. Having paid your 8.5 euros, there are some parts of the castle which give you spectacular views over the city. The castle itself still has fair length of its walls you can walk along but again this involves some steep steps to get onto the walls. There is a small archeological site with some Moorish and Iron Age ruins left. There is a small café on site, complete with peacocks! It's a nice way to spend a couple of hours.

Worth the views alone, but history great, too. We visited the castelo on a Monday morning, arriving around 11:30 by taking the 737 minibus from Praca da Figuera - we don't recommend walking up that very steep hill. Entry fee is 8,50 Euro for adults, free for kids, and 5 for seniors. We spent about 2 hours strolling the grounds, walking the ramparts, and enjoying the great views of the entire city. We also took a short stroll through the castle town to glimpse the narrow, curving streets. Lots of souvenir and craft stores in the castle town as well as the streets outside of the main gate.
Beautiful views of the city . Use a tram to get as high up to the castle as possible as even then it's a steep walk to the entrance. Loved it there for the history and views. Take a camera.
Magnificent . Very beautiful historical clean and Awesome! Nice walk to make you stop and Think Bout life in their times. And if you could have lived than! lol

Amazing Place. Get to this place early as it is warm up there in summer and the number of tourists increase during the day. I was there as the gates were opened and it was fantastic walking around before other tourists. The views are spectacular across the roofs and the river. Great restoration work on this old castle

One of the must-sees in Lisbon. One o the oldest attractions in Lisbon. If you're any serious tourist you'd probably must see this place. Getting there can be a little PIA. The way goes quite high up - so if you're lucky you can catch one of the old street cars or you have to just climb. There are tuc-tucs as well. The view from the castle is really magnificent. And the ruins themselves really give you a sense of times past.

Castle was great, views were amazing!. Bring your hiking shoes to get to the entrance but a great walk through the Alfama district. We were there during the Santo Antonia festival and the streets were abuzz with celebration. Had a great time touring the castle, but the views were spectacular. Well worth it!

Great view. Some pretty impressive castle walls left. There is an archeological museum on site of relics found there dating back to B.C era. Cafe for drinks and food available. An amazing view of Lisbon is worth the visit alone. Its a faie hike up some hills to reach worth a visit. Kids under 10 are free and 9 euro for adults.
Great castle with great views. Great castle with walks around the walls with brilliant views of Lisbon. Good student pricing and facilities in the castle.

Great view. Awesome place if you are interested in the historical fortification. You can see how it was protected in several layers/zones. A lot of old cannons on display, you can walk on the old defence walls etc.If you are not at all interested in the history part, it is still worth a visit, just for the view.

Make sure you are in shape!. An absolute must while visiting Lisbon! Be aware however it is quite a hike to get up to the Castle as well as a lot of climbing stairs while at the Castle. It is well worth it once you get there. The view of Lisbon is breathtaking. There is also a lovely outdoor restaurant to have a great lunch and lovely glass of Portuguese Vinho Verde, very refreshing on a hot summer day. If I remember correctly the admission is 8.50 Euro per adult. Make sure to stop there! and enjoy!

Wonderful castle!. The best way to get to the castle is to catch the 28 Tram at Martim Moniz. You will wait in line for the tram, but it's worth it. The hike to castle is a pretty intense climb. The tram takes you through beautiful Alfama, and drops you close to the castle entrance. The line for tickets wasn't bad, but you could probably purchase in advance to avoid waiting. We went in the morning, and waiting maybe 20 minutes. The castle grounds themselves are huge and stunning with great views. You can also climb up and down around the castle and it's fun - but don't wear a dress (like me...)! :)

Nice view of the city. The Castle sits on top of a rocky elevation overseeing the city and the River. You can walk up and back dawn through a maze of small streets and stairs (without any signaling) or take the tram using the same metro ticket. You can also use a taxi or a motorcycle taxi (fun). You have to pay an entrance fee or a reduced fee for families or students (as in nearly all monuments in Portugal). The castle itself is only the fortified walls, but it is fun to walk the top of the wall. A nice park surrounds the castle and you can buy wine and snacks and look at the sunset (the best time to be there)

Worth it for the views of the city. The Castle isn't worth it as much as the views of the city and the river from the grounds. The peacocks might be a quaint sight if you haven't seen them before. The cafe on the grounds is worth it and not very expensive.

Fabulous archaeological site. The views from the castle courtyard are amazing and the Castelo is also incredible. I particularly enjoyed the archaeological site. There was a sign saying there was a free tour at 3.30pm but we were there at that time and we waited for a while but no one came to take the tour. The age of this place is mind blowing. It's great walking around the ramparts and seeing the views from each different side of the castle. Definitely worth a visit. There are refreshments available which is great if you've walked up the hill on a hot day.

A Symbol of the Past Might of the Kingdom. The Castelo is another UNESCO World Heritage site. It is built on a hilltop that has been a fortification since the time of the Roman Empire, and has been used subsequently by Celts, Phoenicians, Greeks, Carthaginians, and Visigoths. The Moors built much of the current huge (almost 18,000 feet in circumference) walls. After the Reconquest of Iberia in 1148, it has been further developed with ramparts, and towers and has served as a royal residence and the national archive of the Portuguese nation. It has also housed the one of the first telescope observatory, a military hospital, and a school for the poor.Its dominant position, high above Lisbon's harbor is accessible primarily by foot or taxi. There is an elevator from the foot of the hill.
Worth the climb. Fantastic views walking up to it over Alfama, and great views over the city. Cheap entry for students, easy way to spend a few hours.

PERFECTION. Drinking wine over looking the water, historic Portugal in the sunshine with my man! Couldn't think of a better day/date. Also that 360 view thing (can't remember its name) was so cool! My favourite thing in Portugal.

Pretty views and not much elee. There is no audio/guided tour offered with your entrance fee, no is there a lot of information provided around the castle. The views are beautiful and offer a lot of good photo opportunities but you will basically just walk around the outside buildings of the castle. Worth a look if you have the time

nice but high. On the hill above the city.Surroundings are sort of dirty, but the castle is nice.Unfortunately to come up there are plenty of stairs (lots of them), or the streets that rising ...so take a taxi

amazing view. I was not sure whether it is worth to go inside, but luckily we did it. Castle inside is not special, but for those who loves castles there is always something interesting. my 7 years old daughter had fun there. This castle is worth visiting especially because of the Lisbon view. This experience is really worth time and money. I can fully recommend this attraction. For me it was more interesting than Belem. Nice surprise is possibility to meet number of peacocks, just walking around or sitting on a tree what was surprising view and great attraction.
great panorama view. Great panorama view. Amazing spot for pictures ...red roofs of the Portuguese capital. Highly recommeded.
Rather disappointed. Views are magnificent. But I hoped to see something more than just landscapes. It's rather walls than castle.

Great views of the city. If you want to get some great pictures of the city and surrounding area then this is the place to go. The history of the fort is fairly interesting. However, I did find it a bit overpriced. I do suppose, though, that it costs a lot of money to keep up and it's still an ongoing archeological excavation site.
the views are fabulous. the castle per se is not a major attraction but the various views on the city amazing , really not to be missed

Great way to start your visit to Lisbon. I can't imagine going to Lisbon and not visiting the Castelo de Sao Jorge. It is located on top of the highest (or one of the highest) points in Lisbon in the heart of the Alfama neighborhood. The Alfama is an historic neighborhood (touristy), but well worth the walk through.The admission to the Castelo is not expensive and it provides incredible views of the city. If you spend a little time, it is fascinating to get an understanding of the Moorish history and how the Moors were conquered by the Portuguese. You can see this in the different architecture (and the signs, which provide information). It is also interesting to see how the lines of defense were created through the structure. There is an archaeolgoical exhibit within the Castelo, but down from the top, which is fascinating. There are also beautiful peacocks walking around within the Castelo walls.If it is hot, there is a nice cafateria to get a drink, snack and go to the bathroom.

Great views but little else. There are amazing views of Lisbon from the Castle but at €8.50 to get in its a expensive view. The castle itself is rather disappointing when up close. If visiting be prepared for long lines for tickets (which do move pretty fast) and wear comfy shoes as the cobbled ground around the castle is very uneven!

worth it if your looking for something to do.. if you have extra time, then definitely worth having a visit, nice view points and scenic spots over looking the city. we joined the english tour by the front gates, which took about an hour or so, good info to understand the history and design behind the castle.
Good afternoon.. Really lovely views across the city. Peacocks were a pleasant surprise. Would recommend going here and being wowed before visiting the Castelo dos Muoros which is in Sintra.

Worth the effort. Very reasonable entry €8.50 I think.. Well looked after with killer views, easy to spend a few hours here, liked the mobile wine merchant too - genius. If you can't face the climb use the elevators to get most of the way

Fine views. We visited this after finishing the free "Chill Out" walking tour. Tickets are excellent value, especially for the over-65s. Magnificent views over the river and city centre and many photo opportunities around the walls.

History and beautiful views over the city. The castle situated on the top of the hill, is one of the best places to visit in the portuguese capital.Take a metro to the Baixa and climb the hill, 10 minutes easy climb, not very steep.You have also tram 28 (not recommended), always crowded and has not so many departures. Or tuktuks.The castle has museums, walls to walk on, you feel inside the history.
Great place. Good day out would recommend getting transport to castle and walking back as it is in a very ellevated location

castle review. It was a nice climb up to the castle. You can take a cab or ride up in the fun tram. The view from this vantage point is amazing. Great picture place and i do recommend it. The signage and history is good and the red roof and view of the bridge is fantastic! Also good to walk 360 around the area and see more of Lisbon.

Views of Lisbon I was not expecting !. The Castelo de S. Jorge is a castle built in the mid 11th century during the time the Moorish period. This fortification is in a very out of the way and difficult place to get to. The views are pretty cool when you finally reach to the top. We visited the castle inside, not your typical castle. Worth the trip up there. Impressive views of the city from up there.

Wonderful views. We walked up to the castle, we could see it from our hotel room window and it did not disappoint.The views over Lisbon are amazing from the battlements, good vantage points for photographs, not to be missed. The narrow streets leading up to the castle have some interesting shops.
Can't beat the views. Best views of Lisbon. Wish i knew that before going on the elevator and visiting other view points. Castle is very nice too and worth the visit

Beautiful views!. I loved the many great viewpoints from the castle... whether you're on the open patios or climb up to the stone walls... views won't disappoint.It was a bit much for my parents as we had done a lot of walking uphill just to get there, so they opted to just relax on the castle grounds while my husband and I explored the castle walls. I'd recommend taking one of the tuk tuks to get there... we did the opposite, and took a tuk tuk back down to Rossio. The kids loved it and so did we!There's a lovely garden with peacocks as well, to entertain the kids.Overall, glad we took the time to go there.

A castle in the sky. The castle is one of the main attractions of Lisbon. Set quite high you can view most of Lisbon which looks nicer than at street level. Allow yourself at least one hour to see everything and also take photographs. The gardens are also quite nice and when you walk out of the castle there are many places to have a snack and a drink but also a few places selling cheap souvenirs. Overall, worth a visit whilst in Lisbon.

Enchanting place!. A walk up the hill through tiny, streets filled with old houses and Fado filled patios leads to the castle. Once inside, you walk through a maze of walls, doorways, and plazas with ancient olive trees and guitar players serenading you. If you're lucky, there'll be a concert in the big courtyard. You also have the most amazing views of the city and ocean/Rio Tejo.

Great views and shady spots on a hot day.... We visited the castle on a hot Lisbon day and were delighted to find lots of trees and delightful spots to sit and enjoy the beautiful views, both over the city and amongst the remains of this impressive castle. If I could offer one piece of advice, bring your own lunch or sample a nearby cafe or restaurant in Alfama. We didn't find the cafe offerings particularly appealing. Otherwise, be sure to come for spectacular views of the city below.

Great view. From the castle you have wonderful view on the city. You have great photo opportunities. You can walk around, not to much left from the ancient Castel. It is still something worth to visit it.

Amazing views from historic site. This can be reached by tourist team 28 and a shortish uphill walk or a taxi or tuktuk will take you even nearer. On a commanding site overlooking all historic Lisbon and the Tagus /Tejo River with incredible views. It is well shaded by trees, has a tuktuk selling wine by the glass (!), a cafe, and a posh restaurant (where we have happily eaten in the past). It was the site of the early fortified city, but was largely rebuilt after the catastrophic 1755 earthquake.It isn't expensive to go in; there are the usual concessions, and it is on the Lisbon Card but that wouldn't be worth buying unless you plan on visiting many of the attractions.We also found a treecreeper (bird), doing its thing upside down in a tree, unconcerned by the vast crowds. It was the only place where we saw notices warning of thieves, and Police were watching the entertainment crowds for trouble. Don't let that put you off from a lovely experience, just be aware and careful.

Walk back in time. We loved walking the old walls of this mediaeval castle imagining the days gone by when from such a vantage point overlooking the river and town all could be seen.The gardens are lovely too with roaming peacocks and a museum of excavated objects. Guided tours operatedaily and have coffee with a view to die for in their cafe. The walk back through Alfama is just a great experience of the maze of Moorish streetscape, cafes and shops.

Castelo de São Jorge. Nice place to see the city of Lisbon.
From up there its possible to take wonderful pictures.
The Castle is very interesting and always full of tourists.
Go there!

A fantastic overlook in Lisbon .... Castelo de Sao Jorge offers fantastic panoramic views of Lisbon's historic neighborhoods and waterfront. And, the structure allows visitors to learn vicariously what life was like during ancient times in Portugal. The shops that surround the castle are also worth visiting.

Lovely afternoon. Lovely place to spend a few hours wandering castle walls, archeology site and museum - great views too.
Don't both with Lisbon card - cheap to get in anyway and only save a couple of euros - not worth the 39 euros on card.

Cool castle with amazing views!. I really liked the castle. Everywhere you walk, you get an amazing view of Lisbon. STUDENTS: Make sure you ask for the discount - it'll only be 5 euros. I highly recommend!

Great Place to Visit, Awesome Views of Lisbon. Well worth the wait to visit; a historic structure providing excellent views of Lisbon. The museum they have was nice, and walking the grounds and up on the walls with the turrets was cool. Although we didn’t take advantage of it, they do have eateries located on site along with a place to purchase souvenirs. The walk up to Sao Jorge is pretty cool too, you’ll pass an area where there’s a wading pool of sorts, not too far from the church, which provides a great view of the ocean. Definitely worth a visit.
