One of the best castles in Southern Europe. We hiked from our hotel to the Castelo de Sao Jorge and it was a long walk uphill, but well worth the trip. Spectacular views of Lisbon from the top with plenty of trees to provide shade. The castle was largely rebuilt after the earthquake of 1755 and is in great condition (move-in). They have a small museum, an upscale restaurant, and a cafe for more modest dining and refreshments. A must see in Lisbon...and great exercise. We took a taxi back to our hotel and it was worth it.

Worth the hike. Beautiful castle on nice grounds with beautiful views. It is a little tough to walk to, but worth it. Very busy place, but plenty of little spots to get away from the crowds. There's a restaurant on site

Great walk to a very good site!. We actually enjoyed the walk up to the castle as much- if not more- than the castle itself! Walking thru the old neighborhood, churches and look-outs a long the way. The castle itself is interesting and the views from the walls and garden pretty special.It's a lot larger than it looks from the outside, once you get inside and start exploring!

Nice but not sure it's worth it. Perhaps I'm being stingy, it's €8.50 to get in (and I was expecting it to be free which didn't help), you get some lovely views and the grounds are generally quite nice. You can wander around the old castle walls and see some archaeological stone work, which is nice if you like that sort of things. It wasn't very expensive but if what you're after is a view you can do it for less. What I didn't do, which might have been nice, was sneak in some bread and cheese and wine and sit in the grounds and have a snack.
Views are amazing. Interesting historic castle from 11th century, must visit if you are in Lisbon !! The views are amazing !

Magnificent remains to visit. This is a castle very well preserved for the enjoyment of those who like this kind of tourism. Worth visiting. You also have plaza Rossio in the nearby, to enjoy the day with a cup opf coffe portuguese style.

Outstanding. This is a spectacular place to visit in this amazing city. The views are amazing and it's great to be able to pick out other places in the city. A definite must. We walked up but if it's too hot take the 28 tram. You could spend hours wandering through this castle

Wear good walking shoes!. Situated on top of the highest point this 11th century Moorish castle is close to the Baixa section of Lisbon. Best to avoid weekends if you can. There were very long lines to buy tickets on our 1st attempt to see the castle and was closed the 2nd time we tried to visit due to a Bank Holiday. Third time (on a Tuesday) we actually toured, saw incredible panoramic views of Lisbon. Be forwarned that you mainly tour the outside perimeter and courtyards. Be careful of the many steep narrow steps to climb, some without guard rails. Cobblestone walkways everwhere makes it difficult for the elderly and couples with baby strollers. Enjoyed the wine cart with a nice variety of wines. There is one castle building open that is set up as a small museum consisting mostly of photographs and some artifacts. Look for the elevator on Largo Chao do Loureiro, it will save you some of the long climb to the castle.
Gorgeous. because it was a holiday we walked to the castle, which maybe made it that much more interesting. Great preservation and insight into the history of lisbon

Excellent Landmark. If you want the best view over Lisbon, this must be the best place you can get it.Lots of things to check out in the castle, and you can even go and check the inside of it.It is a really great experience and I would totally recomend it!
Good Views. Spent 90 minutes here last week.. Wasn't crowded as I went before lunchtime.. The cafe was good value..

Nice views of Lisbon. only the walls remained from the castel itself, so if your're intersted in that, I've seen better.The nice thing about it is that it provieds a great panoramic view point of Lisbon.

Great viewpoint. Impresive.. Went early in the morning to beat the queque. The views of the city are great from every point in the castle. Went in all the towers. It is history at its greatest. If you are in Lisbon go and visit it you will not regret

Best view of Lisbon. The place to go if you want to see Lisbon from the top! Lots of places to sit down and admire the view, maybe have a break and something to eat. There will be stairs and cobbles, so comfortable footwear is advised. Easy to get there by tram or bus, and then walk down and admire Lisbon's old neighborhoods, the Cathedral and view points.

Lovely for a late afternoon stroll. We went in the late afternoon when the lighting at the viewpoint was perfect. We could buy glasses of wine to enjoy as we walked around or sat enjoying the view which was nice. The castle itself was fun to explore although there wasn't much information around the castle to explain the history, and we couldn't figure out where the gift shop was from the map. Overall well worth d visit for a fantastic view of the city.

Back in history at the castle!. We spent about 2 hours exploring the castle and its surroundings. We explored all the towers and went up and down many staircases. It is a must to wear good and conformable shoes. Go as early as possible in the morning. It is less hot and there are not as many tourists as if you go later on the day. It is also better to take pictures in the morning as there is less sun. There are a few small Restaurants near the castle. However there is no food available in the castle. You will love this historic place with its great view over the city and the ocean.

Excellent views. Yes, it is a climb but there is an elevator you can take part of the way. Take your time up the hill and take in the view of the city and the river, well the sea. The castle is well worth the effort. The hike down is through a rabbit warren of narrow streets and also a delightful experience of exploration.
Take the bus up and walk back down. If you want to photograph peacocks this is a good place. You get some great views over Lisbon . Could easily spend a day up there if the weather is good.

Amazing view over the city. My favorite place in Lisbon. Well, amongst them. Loved the view over the city! Go early morning or mate evening when it is calmer and cooler, and the light over the city is magnificent.

Great views. It's a must see if you're in Lisbon! I enjoyed the spectacular views and the overall atmosphere. Look also for the peacocks while you're there, and make sure you are in shape or at least well rested in order to able to climb all those towers.

Amazing Castelo de Sao Jorge. The castle stands proudly over the whole of Lisbon and is a major landmark.There is an elevator on Rue San Mameda which makes it easier to get to it and it is free. Would be difficult for those who find walking on steep cobbled surfaces. We went up from Largo Maritim Moniz and is where Tram 28 departs. Wrong move as it is 250 steps or so before you even get onto normal roads. Once there however it is a pleasant vista all over Lisbon right out to the bridge and the River Tagus. No real rooms to see as there are just walls remaining. However a good historical experience and worth the effort. Peacocks roam throughout the castle grounds. BEWARE of PICKPOCKETS in this area.

It's #1 for a reason-but not for the faint of heart. You can't say that you've seen Lisbon unless you've SEEN Lisbon from the Castelo. I am a fit middle aged person and recommend taking a cab to the site, walking ALL over the grounds, climbing every tower and soaking up every vantage point. All views are gorgeous and you really get a feel for the area and history from this visit. THEN, have a beverage to rehydrate and begin the long and entertaining walk down to town. We did not use a map-just followed the winding streets and stairs. We visited the the Cathedral on the way down and ended up at the water. All told, about 2 1/2 to 3 hour visit. It's the perfect thing to do in the morning, before it gets too crowded.
Great views of Lisboa. You get some of the best views of lisboa from the castle. Entrance into the area was only a few Euros. Definitely recommend just for the views!

Hard climb but worth the effort. This Moorish Castle and palace ruins sits atop a hill above the Biaxa area in the centre of the city. Taxis or tuktuks are available for the trip but we climbed the (very) many steps to the castle under our own steam. Very reasonable entry price at 8.50 euros per adult. Spectacular views over the city towards the April 25 bridge. Castle is a ruin but still evokes times past for the visitor and our teenagers loved the peacocks wandering freely.

Amazing Castelo. We visited the fort during a re-positioning cruise on the Celebrity Equinox with transposition from the hop/on/off bus. Wild peacocks are roaming the grounds. Many photos to take within the walls and the views from the fort. Allow a couple of hours and there is a lot of walking and climbing of step but is well worth the visit.

Picturesque, romantic views. That was a nice visit to ancient fortress, there you can get the most fascinating view of the city, the bridge and the river, there is a romantic garden with peacocks freely walking around. Enjoyed it!

Great views. We more or less just enjoyed an icecream and the views. The views of the city is spectacular and after climping the steep and narrow streets leading there, so the rest was needed.
The castle itself was fine enough.
Great Veiws. Get the bus up then enjoy the views around the castle wall, there's not much going on as the castle has fallen but it's a nice few hours passed

great and well worth the effort to get there!. We actually took the time tuk to the castle. The castle has a 360 degree view of Lisbon. It really is well worth a visit. I cannot understand people saying "not worth the money... Go stand on a hill". They obviously have no soul for the historical value of the castle or the pure joy of walking atop its walls etc. We walked down through Alfama where we are staying. A walk through a bustling, vibrant part of Lisbon.

great views, huge crowds. the views are fantastic but you have to battle massive crowds in and near the castle. having said that it is certainly worth the effort to have a look. the entrance fee was about 8-10 euros each to get in which was not too bad for such a popular tourist spot. plenty of seating available for a rest and drinks are sold near the entrance. The only hassle is the hundreds of sellers of sunnies, selfie sticks and any other crap you can think off. Good day out.

Watch out for pickpockets. This was the first place we visited in Lisbon. Let me warn everyone that the pickpockets in Lisbon are quite professional. I had my wallet lifted when buying tickets for St Georges. I am almost certain that it happened as we were walking out the door after purchasing our tickets. The pickpocket would have been able to see me put my wallet back in my pocket, and I remember being slightly "bumped" on the way out the door.Don't expect much help from the police. Picking pockets appears to be an accepted profession. We went to the police station to file a report and it was like being at the DMV. People (i.e., tourists) were lined up to file reports.

wonderful views of the city.. This is well worth a visit when in Lisbon. It gives wonderful overview of Portuguese history and puts the city into perspective . It is advisable to take the tram up as far as possible as it a very steep climb. If you do not take the tram and want to walk up I would suggest going up through the railway station as the escalators will take you some of the way.

The views are fantastic. I am a history addict so this was a must see for me. The views and walking along the ramparts are worth the price of admission as far as I am concerned. They have some peacocks walking around the grounds which was pretty cool. I recommend it.
Great view. A must do. Great views of Lisbon, also some shade to hide from the heat in nice surroundings. First time seeing peacocks on the trees!

Not worth the money . The view is amazing indeed. That being said - there are so many viewpoints in the city, that paying 8 euros for this one is just a rip off, especially in Portugal prices. Just take a look at the map and find the nearest viewpoint - it's a woody hill few minutes away..

Worthwhile. There will be positive and negative reviews no doubt, there is lots to see and plenty of opportunity to make this a great visit. But there is the crux you have to make it a great visit and in my opinion it is

High on the hill. Take a taxi to the gate, which saves you the trek up the hill. Once inside, it's a level walking area, with quite a bit to see. the old fortress is interesting and well preserved, and there are a collection of pea-cocks and -hens in the gardens, displaying their iridescent plumage. They fly! even with that tail!Once you are done, exit to the right and there is a fantastic restaurant tucked into the corner below the wall and a great shop two down from the restaurant which sells beautiful original ceramic art pieces.

Worth the climb!. Definitely worth the climb. Go later in the day and avoid the crowds. Take the #12 regular trolley and walk up the rest of the way through the Alfama district.. Don't take the over crowded tourist trolley. As you walk in after buying your ticket look to your left and but a glass of wine from the cart. You can drink it as you tour---very civilized-- (and you get to keep the souvenir glass).
Amazing. A must see in Belem. No camera can do justice to this huge church. To think of how old and all that it endured, is awesome.
Great views!!. The castle itself is nothing too fantastic, but the views from its walls are pretty incredible!! Well worth a visit

A Nice Place to Stroll. The Castelo and grounds are a nice place to stroll. The upper parts of the walls are accessed by steep stairs.Note, there is no interior to it, just the walls. That being said, if you don't have time to actually visit, seeing the castelo from afar is fine.

Fascinating!. It's worth going to the top of Lisbon to get an understanding of it's early day, see a mideaval castle and take in beautiful views of the city. The surrounding Alfama community also has great choices for restaurants and quaint shops.

Stunning views. We walked up to the castle and were rewarded by stunning views of the city. Small museum and archeological site within tour. Need sensible shoes as when walking round walls etc. it is tricky. Take your camera!

High as a kite. We took a trip up to the castle on our last full day in Lisbon. While we were very impressed with the views and the area around the castle including the street traders selling lemonade and fresh berries. My only complaint is the difficulty I had getting to/from the place. We ended up having to take a tuk tuk up and down which cost more than I would have liked but overall it was probably worth it. The castle looks a lot closer on the tourist maps then it actual is. Our Lisboa Card allowed for a discounted entrance fee.
Impressive castle . Unbelievable well kept castle from the 11th century!!! 8.50€ per ticket. View is worth it the price. Got some restaurant and small place with ice creams and drinks

Great views but watch your step. Worth the walk up through interesting little squares, winding steps and narrow streets. Would be a nightmare if it was wet as the cobbles would be lethal. Great views in most directions from the ramparts but hard to get a good feel for the place. There is so much area under exploration - it will be much more interesting when these are complete. And some of the cobbles are very uneven so watch your step.
Great city views. Well worth the hike up to the castle, great city views. Be sure to get the audio tour headphones as it contains many interesting facts that make the tour so much more enjoyable.
See Lisbon from on high. This is a ruined castle on a hill, visible from most places in Lisbon. It is interesting as castles go but the views are the best thing.
Imposing presence on top of the Alfama. Heavily fortified castle overlooks the city and the Tagus river. You can climb the tower and walk the ramparts for great views.
Lisboa looks attractive from above.. Enjoy a glass of wine while wondering around the castle grounds and absorbing the relaxing views. You do get to keep the glass as a souvenir.
Nice view but not much else. Over priced for what is basically an open park with a nice view. The exterior is the best part of the sight.

I went In 2004. I was impressed by the feeling of history but I was expecting different.There is nothing in the castle... just ruins. It is beautiful but I am not sure if I would suggest it. I did not see any tour guides while I was there.We were there for the fifa cup... there was a lot of people from everywhere in Lisbon that weekend.

History and great views!. This castle is at the top of the hill and provides great views! The castle is still in great condition and is an awesome piece of history. There is a fee to get in, there are restrooms as well as a cafe to get something to eat. Wear good walking shoes as it is all cobblestone. If you enjoy watching peacocks, you will see plenty of them. Would certainly recommending you make the walk up the hill to visit this castle!

Great Castle, Great Views. Very nice castle, great for walking around, taking a stroll around the castle, also have great views of the city and the beach and Lisbon's bridge, I think it was 8.50 euros to get in.

Go for the view & picnic spots.. As castles go, this one's a bit of a let down - lots of concrete reconstruction, walls and not much else. It's worth going though for the unbeatable views of Lisbon. Take a picnic & enjoy it on one of the many stone picnic tables available, most with fabulous views.

Worth a visit. This was definitely worth the time and effort to find (if taking the tram, should ask someone exactly what stop to get off), as the views from the castle are amazing. If you happen to have any mobility issues, you might want to consider taking a tuk-tuk or taxi up, as the hill to reach is quite steep. It was nice to just wander around, sit in the shade, and watch the many peacocks on the grounds (many were up in trees, and several were just walking around).

Panorama & Views!. It's a nice medieval castle on the hill, with beautiful terraces looking on the old town and walking on steps along the walls you reach the tower with a 360° panorama. Beautiful peacocks all aorund the garden and on the trees!

great view of Lisboa!. Lovely place to wander around, with looking exhibitions showcasing local archaeological finds. A great place to immerse yourself in real history with the romantic gardens being a delight; the shade of the trees and breeze from the river really calming. I think it is in the process of having exhibitions added with some of the newer cases looking very much like the exhibitions in Pompeii. The views from the castle walls are very impressive but walking around the castle should be the main reason for visiting.

We just loved this castle. What a delightful place, nice little village around it, reasonable price to get in, spotlessly clean inside. Many terraces with incredible views where you can see for miles and miles. The ramparts walk all around the castle was well worth the entrance fee alone, lots of picture spots. Very pretty moat with a photogenic bridge.The cafeteria in the castle is self service but very reasonably priced, cheaper than outside the gates. Good choice of hot or cold food and drinks. Sat under the shade of lovely trees having lunch with peacocks strutting around you. Brilliant.

Wonderful views. This castle must be visited when in Lisbon. It can be reached by walking, tram, tuk tuk or taxi. We walked up to it and although a bit steep, it was really nice to wander along the old winding streets to get there. Once inside we were amazed by the view across Lisbon. Great photo opportunities! The castle itself was great to explore and we spent quite a few hours looking around it. Care needs to be taken as some of the paths are uneven and the steps pretty steep too. Well worth the money.

Lovely cool afternoon in the shade. I don't understand the negative reviews! We almost did not enter after reading them, but decided to take a chance anyway. I'm so glad that we did to this because it would have been a terrible shame to have missed such an enjoyable historic site! There are restaurants and a museum on the grounds to enjoy. Peacocks strut around among the people, with fantastic photo opportunities. I felt like a kid again, exploring the ancient walls and walkways. It was absolutely great! Not sure what people are expecting but we thoroughly enjoyed several hours here!

Great views. Half the fun is walking to the castle. You'll go through parts of town with lots of great shops to browse. As big as it is, it's a bit difficult to find. It's off an alley you need to walk up. So just ask someone. Everyone is sooooo nice !

Interesting history and great views. Towering over the city this old castle of moorish origins offers splendid views of the old town and river Tajo as well as some of the newer parts of the city. The castle and the small museum also offers some interesting history on Lisbon. Walk the battlements and enjoy a 360 panorama view of the above mentioned - just recall that most of the walls and buildings date from the 1920's when major reconstruction works took place. Note: There's a fee for entering the castle. If you want to avoid this and still get some pretty excellent views of the city, you may rather want to visit Miradouro da Senhora do Monte.

Good views but expensive for what for it is. We wanted to like this more than we did. It's one of the big things to do in Lisbon and we always enjoy visiting places like this. However, it did seem slightly too expensive for what is essentially a fortress with nice views. You can walk around some of the ramparts, but the museums there aren't up to much. The archeological remains aren't that in interesting and there is little information provided. You have to pay extra for the camera obscura, which seems a bit mean after paying so much for the entry fee - and you get to see the views anyway. So, not quite sure why so many people were queuing to visit it. There are a couple of restaurants/cafes inside, which makes me think that that's the main attraction, rather than the actual fort itself. Some of the surfaces are uneven and there are some steep stairs up to the ramparts in places. The easiest way up to it is to catch the lift that takes you up several floors from the ground level to near the fort level. It saves on the feet and is worth it to avoid endless uphill walks. So, worth it for the views, but the price is still a bit much for what you get.

Nice view - overpriced & overcrowded. Lisbon is a charming place and great for tourism. But the authorities have let themselves down here. €8.50 for a castle and museum is not TOO bad - but at that price the castle and the theMuseum ought to be a tad more interesting! Charging for a view is mean spirited if not downright rapacious. My tips? Get your view elsewhere and go to a better castle. If you like crowds and tourist tat you will love this place though. And to be fair, the toilets are useful. (At €8.50 they should be!! ).

Great views and interesting site.. We started to queue for the tram, gave up and walked to the top. It's not that far - probably 10 minutes, but we did stop for coffee near the castle.
Structure is well maintained and relaxing with shady mature trees and places to sit.
Need to be aware and careful when walking near unguarded edges and open steps.

Best view ever!. The castle is a must visit place - with lots of ways to get up and down, winding through the old town streets in foot, on the tram part way, by taxi or tuktuk. On foot is best, getting a bit lost on the way. The castle has been renovated with more to visit since we were last here 7 yrs ago - the views are still spectacular of course. But you also have to queue for tickets to get in now, and we were disappointed that gates close at 9pm. We used to love coming up here after dinner and sitting looking at the view until late at night. Having said that it's a wonderful place to spend a few hours wandering, climbing the castle walls and sitting in a shady spot looking out over the river. Not to be missed.
Great view. I found the castle itself slightly underwhelming, however, the castle has views of the city that are unparalleled to any other vantage point in Lisbon.

Very nice. The buildings are impressive and well maintained. The museum has nice artifacts but we would have liked more historical information. We took a taxi there and we're glad we did. We usually walk but the hill to the castle is long and steep.

Real History. Lovely place to wander around, with new looking exhibitions showcasing local archaeological finds. A great place to immerse yourself in real history with the romantic gardens being a delight; the shade of the trees and breeze from the river really calming. I think it is in the process of having exhibitions added with some of the newer cases looking very much like the exhibitions in Pompeii. The views from the castle walls are very impressive but walking around the castle should be the main reason for visiting.

Must see when in Lisbon. Beautiful views of the city! Lot's of walking and lot's of steps, not recommended for those with mobility issues. Really enjoyed this castle and it's history. Also enjoyed the beautiful peacocks and their babies!

Excellent view of the city in peace . It's a real good place to be for the best view of the city. Also a place to rest after a walk. For young people; you can walk to this place and you will see very interesting places. For young people wit bad hard or legs; take a taxi or something els because it's to high.

Beautiful 360 views of the city. The fort has a small museum of no great interest but something to justify the entry fee. The walk around the the top fortifications affords beautiful views of the city from all angles.There is a nice outdoor restaurant for a lunch stop plus other food around the compound.The neighborhood where the Fort is situated is fun to walk around.

Impressive and Enlightening. The view was great and the history behind the castle is amazing. Climbing up on the top of the fort was breathtaking for me but scary for my wife. Safety features are minimal up there. Make sure you are physically and psychologically prepared. Did I mention the view is breathtaking? Well it is! Well worth the cost of the entry fees.

History with scenic views. A climb up the steep streets of Lisbon lead to this charming castle set high above the city with panoramic views. Wandering round the walls and climbing steps to walk round part of the ramparts was so interesting. A cooling ice cream watching children enjoy themselves in the shade of the trees and people of all nationalities taking in the the history. There's a restaurant, cafe and amenities for everyone - just the usual queue for the ladies toilets as the only disappointment - though they were very clean.A visit to the castle is a must for visitors to Lisbon

The very best of Lisbon attractions downtown !. I walked up the streets a few blocks from the main plaza to the free 7 story elevator which helped me upwards towards the Castle, towering over downtown Lisbon. It was just an easy grade on up to the castle entrance from there. You can take a tram or bus up also. The castle is huge, with endless views over Lisbon. There were modern , clean rest rooms and a nice little cafe also. It was park like in several lovely areas. There were even spectacular peacocks wandering around. This is a # 1 "must see" if visiting Lisbon.

Fun if combined with a walk through historic district. The Castle overlooks Lisbon and hence will give you a good view of the city. That said, the place itself is only mildly interesting-- a collection of rambling old ruins. It would be purgatorial on a hot day, because you have to squeeze your way through crowds of people all trying to make their way up and down narrow walkways. I visited it as part of a walk through the historic district, going up the stone steps from Praca da Figuera (the nearest square) and then wandering back down through the Alfama (picturesque neighborhood preserving many features from before the 1755 earthquake), and this made the whole experience much of a real adventure. But there are many, many, many steps, and the signage is poor (I got lost a couple of times and had to reorient), so doing it this way is not for the faint of heart (or lung).

A nice half day. My wife and myself visited here last month and had an enjoyable and interesting half day looking around.greatview from the top across the river in lisbon.Nice walk above on the walled castle and look in the turrets.

Great view!. The view of the city from the top of the castle is fab! It was cloudy when we went but I would presume that seeing the colours of the buildings on a summer's day is magnificent. Highly recommended!

Worth the hike. We hiked over here from the vicinity of the Santa Apolonia train station. It did require a couple of inquiries to find out where the entrance to the castle might be, and for the small entrance fee the trek was well worth it. The complex is huge, with all kinds of catwalks and views of the Lisbon surroundings. You can even eat here or pick up a glass of wine to complement your tour of the grounds. If you like visiting this kind of edifice as much as I do, it is well worth the effort to get there.

Not much to see, but the views from up there are really good. Most guides and the official web site tells you to take a bus 37, tram 12 or 28. Don't! They don't take you all the way up. Instead, take a bus number 737 from Placa dom Pedro (same stop for no 12E tram!) closest tube is Rossio. This bus stops straight in from of the Castle's gates. Its a very small bus, looks like a transit van! The entrance fee is 8.50 Euros for an adult. Views are really good, you can see all Lisbon from here. But there is nothing else to see there. For what it is, its totally overpriced. So if you are on a small budget, don't waste your money. There are other places in Lisbon where you get a good view.
Take the bus!. Great views but if it's warm take bus up the hill. The Lisbon tour buses go almost to the top and allow you to get off and board a later bus down.

Worth it. Enjoyed seeing the castle. Wish their was more information to read about it throughout. Museum exhibit cool. Don't miss seeing the gate that someone gave their life to ensure that it didn't close.

History with a view. Was there just before sunset, so the views were amazing. The castle was very impressive, but I was truly in awe of the very, very old historical site from many centuries before. Well worth the ticket price. Be careful scaling some of the walls!

great walk through the Castelo with beautiful view over Lisbon. There is a great walk over the stairs directly to the Castelo des Sao Jorge where you have a beautiful view over Lisbon. The Castelo for itself is a visit worth and you'll find a nice area with a lot of beautiful views in all directions. Independent in which direction you will always find something nice to see. you can easily stay some hours there and I recommend using the "long way" through the old streets, when you go done to the city as you'll get really nice impressions of the old alleyways.

Either you like it, or you do not. Let me preface by saying: we had already been to several overlooks, taken the train to Cascais, and walked the skin off our feet by the time we entered the majestic,clean ruins. We stopped at the cafe for a bite. Totally food for the captive audience. You did not get value for money. Later we checked the menu at the restaurant; again for the captive audience. We ate well for far less at other venues in Lisbon. I was not going to climb all those stairs just to get another viewpoint of something I had already seen. Hubby the scientist went off to find the camera obscura. He liked it.  I think charging 8.50 euros is sort of scandalous,since you can see great views for free other places without hundreds of tourists about.on the other hand, it is clean, it is historic, there are the views. If you can't get anywhere else, I suppose it is worth the money.

Breathtaking views of Lisbon. Nice walk up to the castle and breathtaking views from the castle. We walked on the castle walls and around the grounds, and you can feel the history of the castle.Definitely worth visiting, even if you go just for the views it's worthwhile.

wonderful views of Lisbon. at the top of a hill, accessed by very steep cobbled roads, easiest way to get to & from is by taxiwonderful panoramic views across Lisbonbasically ruins, but a pleasant cool walk away from the noise & heat of the city belowsome very raucous peacocks

Super views over Lisbon and the Tagus. Admittedly, we have no "real" castles in Canada, so my post will be jaded. We loved the Castelo de Sao Jorge, as we love ruins, archaeological finds, exploring cities and finding unparalleled views. If you like the same things, read on. We spent the morning fairly sedentary as we explored Belem via a hop on/hop off bus, so we were more than willing to explore our way up to the castle on foot and were pleased to have done it that way. We stopped midway up the hill at a church for a shot of Ginjinha/lemonade, stopped a bit further up to look at the view where weary travellers soaked their feet in a public wading pool, and then meandered slowly toward the hilltop for the castle.As others have noted, there were peacocks on the grounds, including a blue and white one that I'd never seen before. We were most inspired by the views and our ability to walk around the ruins of the castle. It wasn't as impressive as the Castelo dos Mouros in Sintra, but we hadn't been there yet, so we enjoyed our first Portuguese castle experience including our trip up the hillside and walkabout. We have since heard that they had a great selection of wines at the cafe, but didn't stop for such items inside the site. At 8 euros, this was a fee well worth paying from our perspective.

Sympathetic restoration, wonderful views. It seemed strange to me, walking around this castle, that it was restored (beautifully) in 1938, the eve of WW2, how amazing that life felt normal enough then to restore a castle. It is very lovely, honey coloured stone, fabulous umbrella pines shade the esplanade and the views over Lisbon are gorgeous. There are plenty of steps , walking around the battlements , some of them plenty steep, and virtually no feeling of battle/ defence/ attack, perhaps just like the summer before the war...

Based on reviews, didn't go in. I am writing just to inform travelers that there is an elevator up, and of course down....which means a much shorter walk uphill. About halfway up Rua da Magdalena, there is a small square (no trees, no benches, just an open square with a restaurant at one end) and there are signs indicating the way to the castela, and one sign indicates an elevator right next to the Pinto Doce grocery store ...where the food is cheap. If your feet are tired or your bones are aching, this is a good way up. At the top outside the castle, there is a bus stop.

Great city views. We took tram 28(caught it 2 roads back through the arch from commercio square)up near the castle,a stop that has a nice viewing area.walked up the picturesque roads to the castle. It was well worth the visit as the 360* views over Lisbon from the ramparts were quite something. If you are thinking of visiting This wonderful place buy a Lisboa card it covers all transport and discount on lots of sites.

It's not a castle - has great views. It is open 365 days a year - almost - see website for specific closures. It is 8.50 Euros per adult. Lines to get in and you do have to walk up hill to get there but there several ways to avoid a lengthy walk and steep inclines, including a free elevator ride. People think it is a castle but it doesn't look close to what most people envision when they hear the word castle. You have to remember Lisbon was almost demolished in the earthquake of 1755 so they don't have many original structures still around. There are 3 main attractions inside. 1. The periscope which takes 20 people every 30 minutes. They alternate languages so the first one is in Portuguese, the second in English, and third in Spanish (maybe not that order but if you miss your language you have to wait through two other 30 minute cycles to get it again). 2. The ruins - they have Iron Age, Moors, and Medieval periods. Note these ruins are outlines of buildings but they are decent outlines and the Moors area has some mosaic tiles still visible. 3. The museum which houses all the artifacts they found in the castle area. The cafe is nice and not overpriced and you can have a light snack and watch lots of peacocks. They have a wine cart so you can sip on wine and enjoy the sight.
Beautiful vista but not much to see inside. Beautiful vista but not much to see inside. Camera obscura very interesting. Archeological site static and boring.

Go early to avoid crowds . We abandoned our first attempted visit when we saw huge crowds (it was about 11AM on Wednesday 20 May). Luckily we were able to return at 9am the next day, and were rewarded with lots of space, no crowds and stunning uninterrupted views of the city and river.

Amazing views. We went here beginning of March and really enjoyed it. The walk up to the castle was really nice and the views from the castle grounds were breathtaking. We walked on the castle walls and around the grounds, and you can feel the age and history of the place.
Definitely worth visiting, the views alone made it worthwhile.

Panoramic views of Lisbon,. The USP of this castle is definately the views! You can do a full circuit of the upper battlements, and the views are superb throughout.If you have the energy walk up one the various routes which incorporate picturesque sets of steps from the town, some of the which are adorned with murals. The best Metro stations to do this are Rossio or Baixa-Chaido on the Green line.The cost per adult is €8.50.

Great views of the city in all directions. A "must see" destination for superb views of the city. My only complaint is that I would have enjoyed it a bit more with more historical information about the castle and the remaining artifacts. Beautiful grounds and a great place to go on a clear day! And a beautiful flock of peacocks running around, too.
The views!!!. OK, it's a truly great castle, with different parts from history, but the views of Lisbon are one in a million.

A must visit . In the heart of Lisbon... Surrounded by small shops and busy streets... It's a magical place with great views of the city... Was busy and crowded when we visited... But it went smoothly afterwards

Have a glass of wine!. The remains of the castle offer a spectacular view of Lisbon and the area. It's easy to see why it was built atop this high hill overlooking the water and the surrounding countryside. Take the time to climb to the top of the castle walls, where you can walk around the perimeter of the former castle. The walls have been restored and there is a perfect parklike area on the South side to sit and watch the sun set over Lisbon. When we were there, there was even a wine cart where you could purchase a glass of wine to enjoy. It is the perfect place to wind down after a day of sightseeing.WARNING: We took the Grey Line Hop-on Hop-off bus to the top of the hill. Although the literature listed the time the last bus down would run, it never came. We got to the bus stop early and waited for more than an hour. We ended up having to find a taxi to take us down.
A real castle. Top of the town. Really windy. A great castle, great views from the walls. Interesting and peaceful.

No inside to visit. The children were expecting to visit a castle...but there was no inside to see...just walls...The view of the city was stunning and the peacocks were a nice entertainment for the children.Walking up the stairs to the top of the ruins was very scary and having 3 children to watch felt quite unsafe.
Nice. Getting there is a nice trip and the view is simply amazing.Being a student under 26 will net you a discount so don't forget your student cards!

Great views of Lisbon. Nice old castelo high up giving commanding views of Lisbon. Old ramparts to walk on, but no rooms any more, some archaeological remains, but not so well preserved. We had a good time wandering around.

Great view on the city. Try to get to the castle early because it is very crowd. The view over the city is amazing. It is extremely nice to walk in the shade of the trees when the heat of the city is too heavy.
Best view over Lisbon. The castelo de Sao Jorge can be difficult to find but once you found it it has the best view over Lisbon.

Great Castle. Being a bit of a history buff I love visiting all of the old castles whilst abroad and this did not disappoint. Great views of Lisbon and well maintained. The stairs leading up to the upper levels are very steep and those of more limited mobility will struggle!Also there was a a stand just outside selling fresh strawberries at very good prices. They were delicious!

Spectacular views of the city. You can survey the city in all directions with unrestricted views. There are plenty of shady corners where you can quietly relax and enjoy picturesque interior. A must for any visitor.

Not super exciting, but worth seeing. We had an okay time at the castle, and the overlook of the city was very pretty. However, other than the overlook there wasn't too much to do that was all that exciting.

Overwhelming view over lisbon. This National Monument includes the prime area of medieval citadel (fortress), composed of the castle, the remains of the old royal palace and part of a residential area for elites.The fort, built by the Muslims in the mid-eleventh century, was the last defensive stronghold for the elites living in the citadel: the Moorish mayor, whose palace was nearby, and the elite of the city administration, whose homes are still visible today the archaeological site.Open to the public 7 days a week, Castelo de São Jorge is now a place where you can enjoy the heritage, get to know some of the history of Lisbon at the Museum, explore the remains of the Islamic quarter of the century XI in Archaeological Site, discover city unpublished views on Periscope - Tower of Ulysses, stroll through the gardens and viewpoints, take a break at Café Castle, participate in guided tours or other recreational and educational activities, or simply let yourself be swept away by the music, theater , dance and gatherings on assets ranging animating the days in this remarkable Lisbon Monument.

Beautiful site. This was the best spot in Lisbon for us. High above the city this castle delivers breathtaking views of the city below. Take a cab up there and then walk downhill into the Alfalma district of the city.

Gorgeous!. I'm a big history buff, active, and love fantasy war literature. If you fall into those categories, you'll want to visit this! This Moorish Castle has centuries upon centuries (literally) of history. It's on top of a hill as a strategic military position, which offers stunning views of the city of Lisbon. The actual citadel itself is just amazing, I can't rave about it enough. I've visited the Tower of London, walked around the medieval city of Carcassonne, but it was here that I made the comment "This castle just makes sense!" There are a lot of signs around the place in English which give you the history of the ruins you're seeing. Plus I grabbed the brochure when we bought tickets, which helped. Not to mention it was a beautiful day and the flowers and trees were in bloom and peacocks and peahens roamed freely around the place. At this risk of sounding like a Disney Princess, it was all so magical! Just go. No regrets.

Lisbon view. It is a must to visit the castle in good weather, best up by taking the yellow tram from the center of the town. The downwalk to the center after the visit was also interesting. The towers gives a fantasic view over Lisbon. The castle itself is a rough stone construcion, and an interesing old construction with many towers.
Classic attraction. You get a very attractive church and monastery, but if a number of cruise ships are in port the lines are huge. It took me 45 minutes to get in and the place was packed.

Walk to the castle. The tram being overcrowded we walked to the castle. Signposting is very poor from the Graca side, but we eventually found the entry. The castle is essentially a ruin with only the battlements and walls still standing. The museum is interesting, showing the pieces that have been recovered with archaeological digs. The archaeological site itself I thought was poor. Since it is now 14 years since they finished digging, I thought there could have been a lot more effort put into interpretation. It has a remarkable history that needs more interpretative material

In Awe.... It's so amazing to see a structure that has withstood the test of time. The fortress is well build and sustained, The views from the castle of the city are stunning. Be prepared to climb lots of steps!It's a great value to see such a piece of history.

Must visit in Lisbon. Beautiful views! The castle is also wonderful. Is mostly old walls no roof but well taken care of. More like a park inside a Roman castle. They have beautiful Peacocks strolling around the grounds. It's a nice part of town to strole around after you see the castle.

Perhaps Overrated?. Long lines and €10 entrance fee.Great view of Lisbon but there are plenty of alternatives.Just masonry looking suspiciously reconstructed.Its Disneyesque feel enhanced by hordes of tourists (like me)Lisbon has so many attractions many much more interesting than this.Bus 737 (not 37 as per official web site) runs from Praça da Figueira directly to the Castle, providing the drivers are not on strike

Not the best castle we have been to. As we could not get the tram as advertised (we later discovered that the tram drivers were on strike that day) we went up on foot. A continuing theme in Lisbon is that signage is very poor. This resulted in us climbing and walking more than we needed to to reach the castle. Again, we used our Lisboa Cards and got discount on entry, paying 13 euro for the two of us.The views over the city were very good, but there is little else of interest in the castle. You can get views as good from other places for free. There is small museum, but it has nothing 'wow' in it.There is a camera obscure in one of the towers, but with absolutely no signage telling you how to get to it. We assumed in the end that you had to climb up the battlements and walk round. Not good if one of your party is unsteady and suffers from vertigo, especially as it was very windy. So, we gave that a miss. The highlight for me was the very good coffee and excellent custard tarts sold in the cafe.

Frankly...overrated. This castle is reálky overrated. For 8,5 euro tou get a nice view on a city, but thats basically that. Garden is nice, but nothing that cant ve seen elsewhere in the city and archeologická site do not provide aby memorable experience.

Should be rated higher. Lisbon is built on a hill and this old fortification is on top of a hill overlooking all of the City. If you good by foot it is a good work out. The views that you get of the city alone are worth it , but you can also walk around the walls of the fort and visit a small museum among other things. This place is popular with the locals and also for families. There was a beautiful peacock that was strutting around also.
Nice view and few rocks. Very nice place if you want to see whole Lisbon. Also hrať great gardens. Much things to see and also some archeology stuff too

Great view of Lisbon. Although you can use the tram, it is possible to walk up to the castle, but be aware it can be steep in parts. The castle grounds provide an excellent view of Lisbon and the surrounding area, great for getting great photographs of the area.

Beatiful...green. The castle, the view, the peacocks,the shadow of the great trees in a very sunny Lisbon. It's the end of a beautiful journey through the best part of Lisbon.Try to catch the sunset there... with an ice cream.

We loved the views. Although the castle itself was just a bunch of ruins with too little information, the money paid for us to at least enjoy the beautiful views of Lisbon. We wouldn't go back there but we would recommend because of the fun you will have going up to the castle, as the little streets are really cute and you will see a lot of local merchants too.

So peaceful. Amazing to find an attraction where you are free to wander at your own speed and make your own discoveries, instead of being herded round a planned route.Second set of toilets just above / behind the entrance aren't as well signed, so no queues!Stunning views and rather dodgy walks around the tops of the old walls. Flat shoes and good legs required to fully appreciate it, but worth the entry fee for the initial terrace views alone.

Great Views. For sure the walk and the tram ride up to the castle are fantastic, walking up the narrow winding street or taking the special trams are a great treat. The visit to the Castle was interesting with the view from the terrace being by far the best part. Whether or not it was worth the queuing and the entry fee I am not really sure.Go if you have plenty of time and really want to see the view.

A castle with great views. We enjoyed the castle very much. We walked to the castle and it's not as difficult as imagined. Definitely it's a must see in Lisbon. You can see the main land marks of Lisbon from there.

Gloveless, peaceful castle with great views. We had a nice uphill walk to the castle where it is really calm and peaceful. There are great views from the castle. It's nice to wander around the castle walls and the palace ruins.Also nice cafes and shops in the castle area.

A Calm Place in the middle of Lisbon. While it is a hike to get there, it is so worth the effort. My initial observation is that the environment invites calmness. There are many places to simply sit in peace and enjoy the beauty of the grounds. I saw several areas where one can meditate, it is that calm.Of course the structure and history of the building is educational as well. Kodak moments are endless with the port of Lisbon in the background. Brochures are available in a variety of languages and the low cost makes this well worth while.As in the rest of Lisbon, good walking shoes are mandatory!

Relax and visit on sunny day. We visited the castle on fine sunny day and enjoyed. There is not much to see inside apart from the walls but the view from the wall walk is terrific. Ah, and spledid peacocks!
Lots of fun for the entire family - those of all ages. This is a beautiful castle to tour with your family. The views are beautiful and climbing around the castle feels like quite the adventure!
wear good walking shoes !. I enjoyed the visit to this castle & the views of Lisbon are amazing. There are many steps so good shoes are essential

Lovely views of Lisbon. Good value ... Approx £7 each, like all Lisbon attractions though no reading/ info to speak of However if you just want a stroll it's beautiful.BEWARE on tram 28 (78?) up to castle as pickpockets operate on that tram as its so packed. My friends purse was stolen

Closed on May 1st !. I would loved to have reviewed the Castelo de Sao Jorge but did not get opportunity as it was closed ! There are very few attractions in Europe that would be closed when there are so many tourists visiting Lisbon.

Lovely Walk Around, Great Views of Lisboa. As I seem to find in alot of Lisbon attractions, the information and history of these places are steeped with many twists and turns but unless you hire a tour guide, you don't really learn much onsite. I would recommend looking up the history of this lovely old castle before you visit if you're not going to shell out for a guide. We walked up through the Alfama neighbourhood which is no mean feat I can tell you! By the time we got to the Castle (the 2nd time around - please note, its closed on Mondays!), we were pretty tired already but we didnt have to queue for long. The grounds are well kept and beautifully laid out, don't forget your camera as there are some amazing views of Lisbon and the 25 de Abril Bridge to be had.You can climb up the battlements and wander around amongst the snapping Portuguese flags in the wind and look down on all of Lisboa - please note, if you don't have a good head for heights then you may not like the upper levels where the Camera Obscura is. The cafe onsite is a bit costly for lunch but the staff were very friendly. Do sit outside and enjoy the calls of the many peacocks that like to roam and show off their feathers! You can also get a nice glass of vino for a decent price and sit in one of the many alcoves and benches that nestle along the lower levels of the castle view. Do go and enjoy :)

from here we can see a beautiful view of the city. if you are lover of castle this one,i love castle plenty to see around,i loved everything,has plenty steps to go up and down, if you have problems with walk of back i wont recommended it

Stunning Views. What can I say about this that hasn't already been said? This is well worth the uphill walk but you can take the tram or a tuk tuk if you're not feeling energetic. This historical jewel is very well preserved and commands stunning views of the city. This is a must see while in Lisbon.

An absolute highlight. I'd heard a few people dismiss the castle as 'just old walls' or a 'bunch of ruins', but I feel this is totally missing the point. The beauty of Sao Jorge castle is that it is in its authentic rustic state. Once entering the castle grounds, you are free to wander as you like, and when I went (about 6pm in the evening) there were hardly any crowds, so you get a personal experience. As someone who loves history, I really enjoyed walking along the walls and fortifications, trying to imagine their stories.A bonus - the peacocks! When I first arrived there was a peacock on full display who seemed to be used to guests, as he twirled around and around showing us his plumage for about ten minutes!There are also stray cats, which is a plus or minus depending on what sort of person you are. I love cats, so I found it a charming touch. Even if you don't like them though, they keep to themselves.The views of the city are also sensational.In a city like Lisbon that's often teeming with tourists, I found the castle to be my most private & memorable experience. An absolute must-visit, I'd say.

On the top!. If you're first time in Lisbon, all you need to know - it's all about hills, sometimes not easy ones, but it is always worth to take them. The castle of St. George is one if those amazing buildings on the highest hill is old city. We've visited it in the late afternoon, not crowded period at all. You can walk in a calm atmosphere, watch the old city, the bridge 25April and the sunset from the top of the top! The pictures are breathtaking !!! Must do!

Real, Big High Perched Castle-Village. A very scenic great first place to visit in Lisboa...the walk up was fun and full of fun shopping, eating and drinking spots not to mention cable car, tuck-tuk and people watching. The nearby ancient shopping district is highly recommended too, especially The Cork Shop where we found the best selection of top quality fair-priced great cork products...tell Sonya Bon Dia from me. Oh, and the castle itself is both fun, educational and a great place to scope the hills and dales of Lisbon before you explore more. Be sure to bring your camera.

A Nice Historic Castle with A View. This castle is not quite up to the the Moorish Castle in Sintra, but it has more history associated with it. Read the history before you see it. Wikipedia has a nice summary. The views from it are beautiful.

Overpriced . 8.5 euro is a lot to go round some ruins. The views are good but apart from that it's boring. Saw a peacock which was nice, can see that in my local park for free and go round the museum there for free. Not worth the walk up the hill

Castelo. We had heard that there wasn't much to see however the views and history surpass the lack of detailed historical evidence on offer. If you have visited castles and like the genre this will not disappoint. 12th century and full of heroic deeds this place is awesome.

The Castle. The historical significance is great. The view of the river and bridges make it a must to see. The peacocks are amazing. There is also a statue of the first King (united Portugal) that I had never heard of but is similar to our George Washington.

Worth the Admission. This castle and it's grounds are very nice. Excellent views down upon
The city below! There is a cafe here and also bathrooms. Beautiful
Peacocks walk the grounds.

Picnic time take time out. We gathered our supplies caught the tram up then spent time walking though the castle and catching the beautiful views of Lisbon. Spend time sitting and relaxing taking in Lisbon. Then we wandered down the hill. Great afternoon.

Great views. Difficult to write that much as my visit co-incided with strong winds and quite a bit of fine rain. The forecast was even more daunting for the afternoon! However managed to venture round this quite large site. If you think it's going to be wet then choose footwear with care as wet stones are quite a hazard underfoot. Nonetheless worth a visit - bus 737 is usually easier to get on than tram 28.

Great Views. Nice interesting walk up the cobbled streets leads to the castle. Excellent views (on clear days of course) and well worth the visit. Number 28 tram gets you there but v busy most of the day. Watch your possessions outside the entrance/way up as prime pickpocket area.
Well worth a visit. Get a taxi or tram to the castle, well worth a visit for excellent views around Lisbon. Lot of hills and steps so need to be reasonably fit.
Great views. having seen many castles over the world, this would not be in my top 10. However, it was a pleasant walk along the parapets and good to see Lisbon stretched out below.

Overpriced. We stayed extremely close to Sao Jorge Castle, so we walked the few winded streets to come upon a smattering of street salesmen and people looking for change. Upon getting there we were told that we needed to pay nine Euro for entrance to the castle grounds. Having accessed many site seeing destinations previously for no cost I was skeptical of the cost. We paid, we were there for an hour we left. Very pretty, not a whole lot of stuff to see, pretty brief. Not a lot of value for the admission price at most the entrance should be 3€.

excellent tourist attraction. Ive been to Lisbon maybe 30 times over the last 10 years, The perks of being married to a pilot ;)So much to see in this beautiful city.The castle is magnificent. From the outside its sheer size is breathtaking, Photographs really well and if you can go their at dawn or dusk you will take amazing photos, (My Nikon was worn out after the last visit)The insides are a little sparse. Lots of wonderful wildlife around which makes it a nice place to stroll around.You won't see a better view of Lisbon than you see from here.

A nice view of Lisbon. This castle is worth a visit if you want a view of Lisbon. Very little is left inside the castle itself except the walls and towers. The peacocks in the garden add a little charm to the place which is usually packed with tourists.

Beautiful View of Beautiful Lisboa. Must see place! The view of Lisboa is amazing you can see te most of touristic places in this view the 23 de abril bridge, the christo statue, rossio square and all other squares its amazing! The inside of castle is also beautiful & historic also you should go down to city centre by walking then you could see beautiful historic neigbourhoods next to the castleEnjoy!

Amazing to see the castle and view. An unexpected view and a well organized place where you can reach history and eventhough so many groups are around, you do not feel in a crowd. It is possible to find a quiet spot and read the tables that are placed around. Some things are under construction, but this does not bother your visit. Standing at the wall shows you how huge the inner part of the city really is.

Breathtaking view, a must. Hands down, THE place to visit in Lisboa, if you go nowhere else in this city. Very well cared-for grounds. Preserved, without much commercialism. Lisbon should be proud of this outstanding historical place.

Peacock running around!. As everyone is writing, you can see a spectacular view over Lisbon old city from the castle. What suprised me was a peacock. I do not think it's a wild but it was first time for me to see a peacock outside of the zoo...Sorry it's a digression. Again, it has a great view. If you are visiting in winter, be careful...the temprature suddenly drops after dark.

Castle with lovely view. Enjoyed the visit but disappointed that the camera escura closes at 4:30 even though the castle is open till 9. A bit more info to put things in context would have been useful. Incredible views and well worth a visit.

A Steep Climb. We found a flight of near vertical stairs – 150 of them - leading partway to the castle which towers over Lisbon – needless to say we walked back to town down a cobblestone road which was so narrow we flattened ourselves against the wall if a tram came down. The castle was interesting but not for anyone who has a disability or anyone wearing high heel shoes – and we did see one woman wearing them! Peacocks were strutting their stuff and castle staff were everywhere happy to give assistance or information. Toilets were very clean. We spent an interesting time admiring the views and looking around the castle although the archaeological dig was a disappointment. Discount on the entry ticket was available if proof of age was provided – e.g. copy of passport

Beautiful view over Lisbon. We visited the Castelo de Sao Jorge and it was really beautiful.The view over Lisbon is amazing and if you are in Lisbon you should definitely visit this location.There is an admission fee though. It costs 8,50 Euros to get in.There is a small museum with ancient artifacts and a digging site dating back 1000 years where you can explore ancient roman housing.

Spectacular views . Definitely recommend visiting this Castle which overlooks the city of Lisbon. Inexpensive entry fee. The amazing views of Lisbon are breathtaking. situated in the beautiful cobbled streets this place should not be missed.

Beautiful and restful. I've seen many ruins and this is in my top 5. The views are outstanding and the garden peaceful. Of note look for the peacocks there are several and they entertain! Be warned if you don't want to walk up you will need a tuc tuc or taxi to reach the entrance

Interesting piece of history. Perhaps it was my mood or that I was tired but other than the incredible views and the "castle" look to this place, frankly, I found it a bit boring. I was not in the "use my imagination" mode to picture the past from the remaining rocks and walls. Yes, the intact parts are fascinating and it's great to be able to walk around up top like a soldier of the past, preparing to fire my weapon from atop the castle walls. After a while it was all rocks and rubble! I suppose it is an important part of Lisbon history so you MUST visit for that reason. If I only had one day in Lisbon I would not spend too much time here.

Excellent views of the city. Must see when visiting Lisbon.. Even if you are not into history, the castle is worth the visit for the views of Lisbon (lots of photo opps). You should spend at least 1 hour to walk around and see all the vistas of Lisbon. The stairs steps to take you to the upper walkway to see the castle turrets and are much steeper than standard steps. They can be difficult to navigate for those less physically inclined. There are handrails though that help a lot. The entrance fee in April 2015 was only 8.50 Euros.
Great views. Moorish castle overlooking Lisbon and the sea, small museum, cafe and shop. Worth the 8 euro entry. Minibus no.737 goes from Praca Figuera. The medieval alleys around there are nice too.
Interesting ruined castle and great views. We had an interesting stroll around the castle grounds and admired the views over the harbour and rooftops of Lisbon.

Not to be missed.. This was one of the highlights of my trip. We were fortunate to have a beautiful day. We took tram 28 which was absolutely packed. We were let out at Santa Luzia viewpoint and then a short walk to the castle. We had wonderful views of Lisbon from every angle. But one of the highlights were the cheeky peacocks that took turns in the square being photographed. They would each in turn strut and display their feathers and slowly circle while all the cameras clicked. They were very entertaining. Also there is a lovely cafe and wine kiosk. Very relaxing. If you don't want to climb the ramparts it is still and enjoyable and scenic visit. Not to be missed.

a long climb upstaircases behind houses, stop for a Mojito and then. Following our Easter Sunday mega meal of boiled offal, we made our way up what seemed like innumerable stone stairs that ran behind many a home and finally to the castle, after a very necessary short stop for a super mojito.The castle is one of a few places open on a Easter Sunday.Yes, worth the effort, splendid views, reminded me of some of the castles in Andalusia, Spain, well it would be as all built by the Moors centuries ago.We did discover that you could take a bus from the cathedral to the base of the castle, we did use the bus on the way back and that's another story. Man its a bone shaker due to the cobbled streets. I think taking the hard route is far more interesting, plenty of "is this the way to the castle". Amazing that this was built so high up so long ago.Well the castle is largely a ruin, with some walls intact, later additions such as cannon in place. Sound of peacocks but none seen, wonder if it was a tape being played over some loudspeakers?There is restaurant and another for snacks and drinks, toilet not an issue. Go see it.

Need to see in Lisbon. It's quite beautiful. Walk the whole exterior wall- above- and the views are amazing. It's not for the handicapped or very old. Difficult stairs in a lot of places. But interesting and very large area. Take tram # 12 or # 28. And it's still a hike from the drop off. I think it was $17 E for the 2 of us.

Our first attraction in Lisbon. We visited the Castle on our first day in Lisbon as we were staying just around the corner, it is well worth seeing if only for the views, they were fantastic, the castle can be walked round at either ground level or from the wall, be careful as can be quite narrow and the steps are very steep, they is a restaurant inside the grounds which did look lovely but quite expensive 33 euros for two courses, there was a gift shop and café, also a little cart selling wine by the glass. My best memory was of the amazing peacocks which roamed around, they were huge and so colourful, it does get very busy with tourist parties. Would recommend it though, sorry there is an entrance fee 8.50 euros per person.

Very enjoyable- worth the admission cost. The Castelo sits on top of a hill overlooking the city. A nice way to while away a few hours and would suit differing interests. I would suggest that you visit on a nice day to gain full benefit and enjoyment of the grounds. Those with an interest in archeology can see some ruins of different ages and there is also a small museum, again with items of interest excavated over the years. We enjoyed our visit and felt the admission price was fair.
Amazing visit!. The Castelo offers a lot for different types of people, photographers, historians, religious people - it is worth the price of admission.

Rather underwhelming castle. I made the trek up to the castle from close to Figueroa square. You can take the elevator near by for most of the up hill section or just walk up. The best part about the castle is that it occupies the highest point of the Lisbon city area, so you can have really good views of the different structures in the city and Tagus river. Outside of that, I really don't see much else to see in this castle considering that the royal palace is supposed to be here. There is supposed a royal palace in the form of archaeology ruins there, but it's very small and not much to see. The permanent exhibition does not really show that much and the castle itself just has some walls. If I had seen this without reading their guide, I would've thought it was just the castle of a Portuguese knight that fell into ruins over time.

Great. Very enjoyable. We walked up the hill from Rossio square pushing a jogging stroller. Lots of nice shops along the way. The castle is fun to climb around. Ok with a jogging stroller but would be very difficult with any other kind. Awesome views. Cafe in the middle for a beer or coffee.

Beautiful view. Situated on the top of one of the highest hills in Lisbon & there are hundreds of hills, the view over the city and surrounding areas is spectacular. There was a wine vendor in the grounds. Treat yourself to a cheeky glass & drink in the view. Walk the ramparts after you have got your breath back.

great views of Lisbon. a very interesting historic spot, not easy to access if you have mobility limitations or if you go with elderly people. However the views are stunning, and you can enjoy a glass of great portuguese wine at the same time. You gotta go.

History with a View. I have toured many castles and this is one I would recommend. However, don't just walk through it and enjoy the views. Learn the history, know which parts of the castle are original and what has been replicated. The grounds are massive and castle walls have been rebuilt so you can walk along the top of the castle. Kids will love all the opportunities to explore - just note they need to cautious - steep steps and long falls possible! You do not need to take tour - just talk to the staff or volunteers who are in red shirts. They are very knowlegeable and spoke very good English.

Views and Rampart walks. Clearly this is the place to see Lisbon from as there are many viewpoints. The castle itself is just a backdrop. Don't waste your time on the 'new archaeology' area unless you love archaeology - its really quite unexciting and just means you walk further for not much.

i give it a 4 for the peacocks and the view. the castle itself is not as impressive as i was expecting. the price of 8.5 euros is too much for what it offers. however, inside, the view from the romantic garden is amazing. they have also live peacocks and if you are lucky enough, you will get a tail display from one of them.the climb to the castle is just horrible tiring, however, they have elevators! there is the elevator Baixa on Rua dos Fanquiros, around no 170. make sure to look up for it, and have the address as it is not signaled in any way, and from outside it might look like a regular bank or office building. this takes you up one level. second elevator is...as you exit this one, cross the street, and slightly to your left go up to the Pingo Doce supermarket. inside the supermarket is the second elevator. go up to 7th floor. from there on it's a max 15 mins walk on the steep streets to the castle. the effort the elevators save is immense.
Great. Great castle, beautiful views, lots of history. Best to go earlier or later in the day - VERY popular tourist destination.

Mostly for the view. The castle looks very nice from outside, when you're walking in the Baixa. But once you climb the hill and get inside (for 8.50 euros), it is a bit disappointing. There isn't much to do besides walking on the castle's walls and enjoying the (nice) view. Would still recommand because it is an emblematic site of Lisbon but don't expect too much from the visit. Enjoy the small streets on your way there.

Views and History and Castle oh my. Only €8.50 for adults...bargain! The castle has great views, an archaeological area that shows what theyre unearthing, walls to walk on, and plenty of places to sit and picnic. It looked like there were a lot of activities for kids (a trail to follow or something). Plus there are some resident peacocks! On a beautiful day in Lisbon, this cannot be missed. Just be wary of pickpockets, especially near the entrance/ticket queue.

Must see fort overlooking Lisbon. Don't miss the opportunity to visit this castle, if only for the views of the city! The strongly fortified citadel dates from medieval period of Portuguese history. While various cultures occupied this site, it is my understanding that the fortifications were rebuilt by the Berbers in the 10th century. Then between 1373 and 1375, the a walled compound enclosing the castle was built by João Fernandes and Vasco Brás, thus replacing the Moorish walls. The castle and the city resisted the forces of Castile several times during the 14th century. Later, it was a royal palace. It was the site of a reception by King Manuel I for Vasco da Gama when he returned from discovering the maritime route to India in 1498. The 1755 Lisbon earthquake severely damaged the castle, but many of the walls are still standing.You can walk around the top of the fortified walls, and the views of the city and water are fabulous; best view of Lisbon! The museum is also worth spending some time in; there is a sizeable collection of Moorish pottery sherds, coins and other items.

Definitely Visit. Gorgeous views, a thousand years of history, and ongoing excavation projects? Yes!!This is a top experience while in Lisbon for a reason. I visited while 6 mos. pregnant, so I recommend taking Tram 28 (but don't catch it in front of the Hotel - find another stop) up and wearing good shoes to prevent falling on the very old stones and stairs.Views are worth it, and so is learning the history. I truly enjoyed visiting this place.
Stunning views. Nice spot to admire the sunset. If you're on the hunt for this perfect instagram/facebook photo from your holiday you need to visit the castle. Oh the castle is pretty neat as well.

What a view!. For the price of entry a visit to Castelo de Sao Jorge is well worth the money. Set in a lovely location within a historical part of Lisbon, with quaint winding roads, the historical sight offers plenty of marvellous views of Lisbon. An ideal place to wander around the ruins and take in the historical factors of its purpose. Also included were one or two surprise finds of an even older age. The site is well kept and the staff are very polite and helpful, showing their knowledge of the castle itself. The castle also offers a cafe and restaurant for lunch or simply a rest over a cup of coffee. Well worth half a day's visit.

Walking through history. The castle and the attached museum and the archeological site are all attached and accessed via one entrance, and for one admission price of 8.50 Euro. There is also a great view of the city of Lisbon at the courtyard entrance to the castle, and a yard full of peacocks. The museum entrance is very informative and discusses a history of the city of Lisbon and the founding of Portugal, and then the castle is a fun place to roam around. The castle walls are accessible via some very narrow, slippery, uneven staircases, so be very careful! There are also some excellent views from the various corners of the walls. The tour ends with an archeological dig site that is accessible in a roundabout climb up and down another wall. There is a restaurant attached, but very pricey. There are plenty of cafes surrounding the area. It was a great way to spend 2 hours.

Beautiful views from the castle. I am not sure if this is a good idea or not, but you can buy wine in plastic cups to have while walking around the castle. So, of course, we did! But, then you think maybe wine is better after climbing the narrow staircases and walkways - some without handrails. A great visit in Lisbon - amazing views of the entire city and the waterways. Also, castle grounds are nicely restored.

Stunning views. My husband and I took a taxi to the top of the castle as I am pregnant and the walk is very steep. The castle is vast and you can explore most of the outer walls giving you the most breathtaking views of Lisbon. The price is good and once inside the facilities are all beautifully clean and adequate. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit.

Plenty to see.. Excellent attraction, well maintained with fantastic views over city and sea. There is a museum as well as the main castle building to view. A restaurant on site is expensive, but also cafe available. Took tram 28 up, but opted for tuk tuk down. Enhanced trip.

A must see. No visit to Lisbon would be complete without seeing the castle on top of the hill. It's a bit hard to get up there (there are no tram or metro stops nearby), so if you don't want to walk, consider hiring a tuk-tuk (motorized cart) to take you. The views from the castle are lovely, and the castle itself is interesting. It's fun to imagine what it looked like when it was actually in use. Be sure to keep an eye out for the resident peacocks. There are about 10 or so, and one of them is white!

Great views overlooking Lisbon. There is a charge to go in but once in you can walk all the way around. Amazing views from the lower level. If you climb up to the turrets the view is obscured by the tall trees. The stairs are very steep and there is no safety rail so would not recommend young children go up as they could easily fall over the wall. There were a couple of peacocks when we were there that added to it.

View over Lisbon. We went by elevator near the supermarket under the hill.Saved climbing more stairs!The information booklet written in English was good to tell us about the castle.The peacocks are amusing and everywhere ,must have been 25 or more?They made noises and put on a display of feathers for photos.Lovely way to see the views and roofs of Lisbon.

Spectacular views and also fun. At the top of Alfama, visiting this castle is best incorporated with a visit to the winding streets of the district. The Lisbon city card which I'd recommend, brings down the price to only 6 Euros, (if I remember correctly). Stunning views all around. Stroll through at a leisurely pace while also exploring the walls of the castle. Note that paths are narrow and steep in parts.Typical with trying to find things or navigate in Lisbon the musesum which was supposed to be part of the package was nowhere to be found.

Amazing views. €8.50 (adult). We took the green tourist tram up the hill. Yes it's more expensive, but we used the hop on hop off AND it was empty compared to the public tram. The castle was great. Amazing views, lots of places to sit for a picnic. Had a good coffee and pastel de nata.

A must see in Lisbon. superb castle situated near Alfama with great views and history. You are able to walk round the whole castle. The area has some lovely local cafes so you can spend most of your day in the area

Great views and history. This was my second visit to the castle - this time with friends, on a sunny April day.
