Views are great across Lisbon because of the high vantage point on the hill and the ramparts and towers are well-maintained and inner courtyards are very atmospheric. There was a modern dance rehearsal taking place in the inner courtyard which was entertaining! You may also see one of the many peacocks displaying their tail feathers in or near the cafe or sitting in the trees above the seating area. The walk up to the castle from the old town is full of narrow cobblestone alleyways with some lovely cafés as well as the usual tourist shops and little boutiques. The views from the old town near the castle are also good over the river and rooftops.

Fantastic castle with access to almost all of the walls and turrets. This castle is certainly worth a trip if you are in Lisbon, it begins with the spectacular views over the city but for me the real treasure was being able to climb all the old steps to the ramparts. I can imagine some of the steps may be difficult for some as they can be quite steep. The fee of 8.50 euros seems reasonable for such an attraction. There is a camera obscura but I did not have time to visit on my quick trip

A very impressive castle.. A stunning castle which is very well maintained. Fantastic views of Lisbon. You do though need to be pretty fit to navigate all the stairs, and you'll need to keep a good eye on any kids as there are no safety rails.

One of the must see locations in Lisbon. Castelo Sao Jorge is situated on the tallest of the seven hills of Lisbon and gives you great views of the Tagus River, Alfama, and other sections of Lisbon. It's a must see. For those of you expecting a completely medieval experience understand that this is a partially restored castle. Most of it was level in the massive earthquake of 1755 which destroyed large portions of the city. So you are visiting a ruin rather than a fully functioning medieval castle. That said, it's still worth visiting for the views and for what's still there. You can walk along the castle walls and ramparts. There is a small museum to visit that shows some of it's history.  If you like history then you will especially like the excavations. Those excavations show remains of iron age, moorish, early Portugal, and later Portugal. It gives you a great understanding of how long Portugal has been around and it's continual habitation. Getting there you can take a trolley or bus. The trolley will still leave you with a walk though. We took the trolley up but then took a taxi to our next destination. Taxis do make sense if you have 3-4 people.
Super cool. I visited the castle first thing in the morning and it was great. Amazing views of the city and river, and plenty of places to simply stop and soak up the atmosphere. A beautiful site.
Great Medieval castle. It is just in the center of Lisbon and such an amazing view from there. City walls are well preserved and you can feel how it was like to be there 500 years ago.
Fantastic views. One of the more intact castles I've visited, walk the walls and get some amazing views of Lisbon. The peacocks roaming freely around the cafe area were a bit of a shock!

Good views but expensive.. The castle is in a lovely spot. It is a calming place to walk and the views are the best in Lisbon.
Take a bottle of water in with you as there is not much in the way of refreshment and what is there is very e expensive.
How it is possible to charge to see this monument?. The castle it is beautiful and the view it is great but paying almost 10 eur for this... no words. Choose other places for free to enjoy Lisbon
Good spot for the sunset. Get the bus to the top of the hill. Great place to watch the sunset. Great views of lisbon and good to explore the building and castle while the sun goes down.

Lots of stairs to climb! . To get to the towers, be prepared to climb a ton of stairs. Your workout is rewarded with some great views of the surrounding city. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes. Go early or later in the day to avoid the tour group crowds. There's a camera obscura in one of the towers with demos for groups of 20 at a time every 30 minutes. The language used for each session alternates (English, Spanish, Portuguese), so pick the right one, and line up 20-30 mins beforehand to grab a spot. Interesting way to see the city and hear about the sights. Only lasts for 15 minutes though, so may not be worth it if your time is limited. You might spend more time waiting if there's a crowd!

Tranquil viewpoint, interesting ruin, great peacocks. Thought this was good value for a major tourist attraction. I felt the views were possibly the best bit, but when we visited it was quiet and the site felt peaceful and picturesque. There were several male peacocks ambling around and displaying.The ladies toilets seemed higher than normal!

Worth the walk. We saw from the distance and decided to go and see it.It was bit of a walk but they views were beautiful. We saw beautiful peacocks .After we explored the castle we sat outside and at a snack and a drink from lovely cafe.Very good location
Perfect place for an evening jaunt. Castelo de São Jorge is open from 9am-9pm, making it a great place to visit in the evening when many other places have closed. The views are fantastic.

Highlight and light of the Castelo quarter. Serving in the past as a fort, theatre, prison and arms deposit, Castelo de Sao Jorge is the bulwark protecting the city from whatever angle it is observed. Nearly destroyed in the ravishing 1755 earthquake in 1938 it has been restored with a landscape patio providing its current charm. The walk to the castle is a beauty in itself, taking into account you actually get to see the beautiful streets curving upwards towards the castle providing a really portuguese feel with its traditional housing.Inside the castle you can climb onto the upper floors and see what proves to be another amazing view providing a small glimpse into the houses packed with flowers down below.The photos speak for themselves. Enjoy!!

Well restored fortress. This fortress / castle on the hill above Lisbon has been tastefully restored (not too much). It reveals what life would have been like for the forces defending Lisbon and the elitist that lived within its walls.

A "must-see" in Lisbon. Nice castle to walk around. The walk to the castle is actually fun too. We visited during a time that appeared to have a long wait but it actually did not take long to get through the line and to the castle. Enjoyed just walking around and taking photos but favorie part was definitely the view. We sat and enjoyed a beverage and olives at the restaurant outside of the castle just to enjoy the view a bit longer!

Excellent views from a wonderful castle. The castle was very interesting and provided wonderful views of Lisbon. It is a winding,narrow walk on cobblestones through Alfama. I thought the fee was a bit pricey but I am glad I went. We had a beautiful sunny day for the visit but on the next day on a bus tour, it was cold and rainy. Would have been a different experience. If I go back, I would inquire about the Kisbon card.

Scenic and serene views. When you are in Lisbon, the most epic of things to see and do is to get a panoramic view of the city, especially the old town of the city. And since most of the beauty of Lisbon is to visualize it from a high vantage point, Castle de Sao Jorge is the ideal place to go to get one of those spectacular views. Do keep in mind that walking around Lisbon can get a bit tiering since the are lots of hills and steep climbs, but if you are truly an adventurist, it is a must go to place to check out.
Interesting Castle. The Castle has a very nice view of the city. Very nice place to visit, and also can give you a romantic atmosphere, at least I guess if you find a nice weather there.

Fantastic Views of Lisbon. Having seen the castle from the town we thought we would take a visit. Used the little red hop on, hop off but however there are other ways. Cost about £3.00 return for the short journey so not to bad.At the top outside the entrance is a fantastic café bar with amazing views of all round the city. Once in the castle the view are fantastic.Well worth a visit.

Lovely castle. Visiting the castle was a part of our walk through the old city and that was great! I was amazed how well it is preserved. Everything is in fantastic conditions: It still looks like a 'fortress in use' Loved it!

Fantastic views. A very tiring walk up steep steps streets, but well worth it.On the way down however we discovered the elevator that takes you into the Pingo Doce supermarket!Some lovely little gift shops one even gave our girls a free gift as we walked in.The views were incredible and it was lovely just to sit in the sun and spot the different sights. I have never seen so many peacocks some odd looking! The kids loved walking around the walls a very enjoyable few hours.

Gorgeous views of the city. Quite a hike if you choose to embark upon it. We walked from Rossio metro station up the hill, stopping along the way at Lisbon Cathedral. The view is well worth the price, plus exploring the ruins, walking along the top of the walls, and enjoying the parks was all very nice. There are tuk tuks and other vehicles that will drive you to the summit, but I really enjoyed the walk as you get the feel for the neighborhood.

Beautiful Views!!!!. Came here with my boyfriend and it was absolutely stunning! The views are the highest in the city and you can get some great photos. We had perfect weather which was an added bonus. Our taxi took us literally to the entrance, which we appreciated because the it's ALL uphill steep walking. It was cool to walk through and we stayed for about an hour. What's really nice is that after your visit, you can walk down through the little streets to the squares and enjoy Lisbon. Really fun!!!

An absolute must!. Great views, wonderful seating areas, lots of shade, a restaurant and a cafeteria to cater for all tastes and budgets - and a good castle. This is an absolute must and you could easily spend a few hours on a picnic here

Beautiful views. It was very busy when we visited the castle so had to queue to get a ticket.€8.50 per person is a bit steep as apart from the views and castle walls, there is not much else to see. On a beautiful day it's a nice location to visit though and you can wander through the many streets of Alfama on your way down.

Panaromic views!. Stunning views from at the top level. Unfortunately we went when the weather wasn't great, resulting in the roads/surfaces being very slippy. The entrance fee is possibly a little steep...€8.5 each adult. There are few signs once you are actually inside. The walk from the metro is ridiculously long & steep. The old fashioned tram only takes you part of the way so be careful. There is a lift you can take which takes you most of the way though...we found this out after we were up at the top! Can't remember what it's called! Tour guide given out are a bit poor and lack detail. Worth going for a view or two at the top. Not as good as expected!

Lovely views from the hill top.. After a very steep climb the castle was a welcome sight. The visit is very good. You get the chance to walk around the walls so you can see Lisbon from many angles. There is a café serving food and drink that was reasonable. Don't miss the peacocks - when we visited there were 14 high up in one tree by the café. The walk down is easier!

Castles, views and archaeology!. On the day we arrived we had our two year old daughter in her pushchair. One of the guards ushered us straight through so that we didn't have the stand in the queue. To be honest the Portuguese as a whole were friendly towards children and made our stay very pleasant. There was space in the security gate to leave our pushchair and I don't recommend taking it around the castle; the cobbled floors would be difficult for even the largest of pushchair wheels. Straight through the main entrance you're welcomed with beautiful views across Lisbon. The castle grounds are completely open and you can walk right around the castle walls and towers; we all really enjoyed it. At the back of the grounds there is a small archaeology site showing you the foundations from the 7th-3rd century AD; something we again enjoyed. There are many peacocks near the cafe and museum, all of which seamed eager to show off their tail feathers and kept our daughter smiling. Once we'd finished we took a walk through the old streets of Alfama back to the city. We'd definitely recommend this attraction when visiting Lisbon.

Amazing views. Well worth the 8€ entry fee just for the view over the city. Lots to see inside including an architectural exhibition and a tree full of peacocks, and lots of historical info provided in the leaflet. Well worth a visit!

Great Castle but where's there's blame there's no claim. We went to Castle de Sao Jorge over Easter and it's worth a visit but families beware! To get there we used the old trolly busses, which are a great way to travel and a thrill ride to boot. 6 euro will get you a pass for Metro, buses and trams (purchase at Metro stations). The tram was number 28 and we squeezed on like compressed sardines; there seems to be no rules as to how many people can be crammed in to a very small space. Word of warning, the tram windows are open in warm weather and if you stick your head out you might get it chopped off as the trolly busses go very close to walls and we passed scaffolding which was literally inches away; scary thought. Take a best guess which stop to get off at as no one tells you and it's not obvious. The first day we went we never even found the Castle and ended up on the opposite valley. When the trolley bus arrives at an open area overlooking the bay, you have arrived; intact you have gone one stop too far. Walk back around the corner and start your accent to the Castle. It cost about 16 euro to get in and the kids were free. The first thing to note is you are walking on very uneven ground and very slippy if it's wet so be careful. Secondly, beware when you go to look at the magnificent views over Lisbon, the wall is very easy for kids to climb up on and there is a sheer drop of 30 ft + on the other side. There is a restaurant in the grounds or a cafe for lighter bites. The facilities are pretty good. When you enter the castle and climb up on to the ramparts there are no safety rails and again the danger to children is sever, make sure you supervise them at all times. The views are again worth the climb although the steps are overcrowded and there is no system for going up or coming down so people squeeze past each other. There is a museum inside the grounds and all in all it is a great castle to explore. One thing though the Portuguese are not very good at exploiting this asset and there are few explanations of various parts of the castle as you travel round.

great view, but nothing impressive. Very awesome views of the city, but the 8.50€ per ticket is all you really get out of it. You can walk around the castle walls, but that got boring fairly quickly. I don't recommend it. Go to Chapita and sit in the outside area and you get almost the same view. All in all, nothing fun/exciting outside of the view, but not worth 17€ for two.

Beautiful views. The views over the city are wonderful. It's a lovely castle to wander around, it is massive, so give yourselves a couple of hours, there is lots of climbing to be done and lots of lovely views to be seen. Make sure you see the peacocks wandering around. When you've finished take a slow walk back down to the city.

History and Beauty . It was a sunny and beautiful day when I came to visit the castle. Great views of Lisbon and nice place for photos. It was so nice to experience part of Portugal history. Get there early to avoid long lines at the entrance.

Stone fortress with amazing views over Lisbon (and some peacocks). The climb up to the castle is gruelling but worthwhile for the far-reaching views across Lisbon, the Tagus river and the hills beyond. There are plenty of places to sit and soak in the views or soak up the sunshine. The fortress itself is a set of massive walls, with battlements you can walk around, but little else to see inside. There is an archaelogical museum and an archaeological site (which can be reached by precipitous stone steps). The restaurant is set in well-tended formal gardens where large numbers of peacocks and peahens mingle among the cafe users outside. They perch high up in trees above the tables - so watch out! There is an elevator from Baixa which goes up to the lower streets below the castle, which will save some of the climb, with a restaurant with views across the city. Entrance fee (April 2015) is €8.50 for adults.
Panoramic View over Lisbon. Great views over Lisbon from the top. Hight walk up to get there though. Not much more I can say about it really - castle worth visiting.

Look at Lisbon from up there. The Castelo overlooks the city and the harbour. Once the castle you get a feeling of history through its battlements, which overlook a specious keep. The cafe inside the castle is a pleasant relief after walking up from the city and the peafowl keep you in your toes.
Lovely view!. A great place to spend some time while in Lisbon! Amazing view from the top, and nice and quiet parks to sit in the shadow. Met some peacocs walking around too ;)
Crazy view, incredible place. Absolutely drop dead gorgeous view! Amazing piece of history, very well maintained and clean. Perfect for a sunny afternoon.
Fabulous views. I enjoy castles and this one did not disappoint. The views across the city are worth the visit alone.

Amazing views... TIP! Buy your tickets online and save a long wait at the ticket office!. Not many people know this, but if you book online, you can save yourself a possible 10-20 minute wait. We didn't know this either, so I thought it would be good information to share. Check out the official website, where you can buy your tickets. Inside the castle, there is plenty of space to walk, climb, roam around and enjoy the spectacular views (so bring your camera!) The cafe was reasonably priced, and there doesn't seem to be a problem bringing your own drinks either, as we saw people who had brought their own water, juice, etc. You can save yourself quite a walk up to the castle by using the free elevator at the nearby pingo doce supermarket, and getting off at the 7th floor. The castle does offer discounts for students, the disabled and families, so don't miss the experience...
Great Views. Lisbon offers plenty of places with great views over the city, but the view from Castello Sao Jorge stands out. Entrance fee was a bit pricy, though.

I'll never forget this; but get here at 10am. We took the shortest route to the Castelo from the Santa Justa Elevador, straight down the Rua de Santa Justa, straight across the Rua da Madalena, up some steps passing some incredibly good street art (graffiti), passed a little un-named cafe (really good coffee at half the price of anywhere else), round a church and up a winding street (follow the sign). By the time we arrived there was a 30 minute queue(it can be much longer apparently) but we were entertained by a living statue near the entrance. Admission is around 7 Euros but you do get a free guide book to help you plan your route around the castle and grounds. The surfaces are, as to be expected, a little uneven so watch your footing, but there are some delightful vistas, spectacular viewpoints and shady calm areas. If you have children, keep an eye on them as the walls are not high and you could lose them over the edge. I wouldn't advise you taking them up on the parapets either as the steps up are very steep, narrow and have only a single rail to hang on to. I don't want to put anyone off visiting here though as the whole place has a magical calmness and there are plenty of areas that are safe for children. The peacocks hang around the cafe at the centre of the castle and are always good for a show, either on the ground or up in the trees. The loos are down a flight of steps which might prove difficult for some and the shop is very small and has a very limited stock. Attached to the castle is an archeological dig, which you can access via another parapet and steep stairs (gulp) and right on the top is a camera obscura (again they might be queues to get in this bit). Find the right spot, out of the breeze and you could spend a good few hours here.

Probably the best view of the city. A rather peaceful and tree-lined place once you manage to get up the winding road. The views are stupendous and the castle and ramparts are interesting. The signage could be better since we had difficulties finding our way around the grounds. The café is OK and the peacocks that stroll around are a lovely photo op. A nice diversion from the hustle and bustle of the city. Getting down the hill could be a challenge with all the forks and intersections in the road. Well worth the admission fee

FAB VIEWS. pleasant but steep trek up to the castle, trams are around to take you if preferred. quite reasonably price entry 7euros, i think. Lots of steps up and around the castle, really good views of Lisbon. Nice cafe with a good choice of hot and cold food

Get an idea of the past. Of what it was like in 1147. Great architecture and views.it is an €8.50 entry or free as a Lisbon resident. Restaurant and wine is available inside the site. Portuguese and Spanish tours. Catch to 24 tram, or take a leisurely walk up the hill. There is plenty of shade and seating.

The most amazing panoramas of Lisboa. With your Lisboa card the entrance is free and you will enjoy the most beautiful views of the city.Set high above the city, the historical experience is great : a castle partly in ruins, partly restored. Take a brochure at the entrance explaining the castles importance and function as this information will not appear on the grounds during your visit.That aspect of the visit could be improved upon.Nonetheless a great experience.

Great historical experience. At a cost of 8 euros each this was a great experience with lovely grounds, ruins, roaming peacocks and all the castle battlements you could ask for. Only set back for some would be that everything is accessible by lots of high, smooth and tottering steps. We seemed to go up and down continuously to get to various parts. Also we were disappointed that the descriptions and signage to explain how parts contributed to Portuguese history where scant or weathered. It was still a lovely experience to wander about and the peacocks perched high up in trees were fascinating

Offers some great views but needs some finishing touches. It is an interesting walk up to the castle through the old town although a bus takes you there as well. There are some lovely views to be had of the city but the museum didn't have much in it and there were no signs or information telling you what parts of the castle you were in. They have some nice peacocks though but there is rom for improvement.
Incredible views of the city. Well worth a visit for the views of the city. Go by taxi or Tuk Tuk as the walk to it is very steep. A breathtaking panorama will then unfold.

Great place to visit in the open air. Worth the slow climb up through winding streets to see the preserved ruins plus the most spectacular views of the whole of Lisbon. You can wander at leisure and clamber up the ramparts to see even further. It would be tricky for anyone with mobility problems.
Wonderful views!. Great for a walk around. It was very peaceful when we went, which was a great stop for a sit down and just enjoy the city!
Nice view. Nice view over the city. Nice park. They have speciel service for families waiting in line for the tricket Office. Be prepared to walk up hill, we took a taxi. Can be recomended

SPECTACULAR!! Must see / do when in Lisbon. Once you walk through the main entrance gate, you are greeted into a large courtyard area that branches out to provide spectacular views (on your left and straight ahead). Be cautious of the walkway as it is uneven cobble stones that I saw several people trip on. The roots from the trees have also called uneven surfaces to walk on. The courtyard as you enter is shaded under sprawling trees and is a nice place to relax before and or after you enter the castle walls. The views of the city of Lisbon as it is nestled against the Tajo (ocean straight) are sights you won’t soon forget. As you stroll further into the heart of this walled city / castle, you’ll be in awe of the city that spans over the rolling hills all around you. Panoramic views of the city are best from here – a top some of the castle walls. Once you enter into the courtyard within the castle itself, go ahead and climb the narrow, steep, worn steps to the top of the walls. You can make a full circle around the castle by walking atop the walls – you will also gain some of the most spectacular views surrounding Lisbon. There are many unique architectural features built into the castle as well – so explore the upper walls. Once you return down the steps from atop of the walls, stroll over to the courtyard that is lavish and has the restaurant tucked away within it. Look in the trees – there are Peacocks all around and you will be able to hear them. On the right, just passed the cafeteria, is an entrance to the museum – worth the walk through as they provide timelines, artifacts and additional information about the castle, city of Lisbon and its history. A few suggestions and or helpful hints:* Tickets are 8.50 euro* Tram #28 will get you to the drop off point to take a short walk up to the castle. This rickety, old romantic type trolley car will whisk you by various sites of Lisbon and the bustling beat and vibe of the city. * Get the daily pass card (6 euro at any M or metro station), this allows you 24 hour unlimited access to all the trams. * Pack a lunch – there are a few restaurants prior to going in you can get a snack at and or bring your own. * They do have a mini wine truck on premise – but it is not always open* Don’t let kids wonder free a top the castle walls. The stairs will provide you with a warning. The top of the castle walls have open railing and not the best for kids “running” around. * You can get a “tuk” and or a cab directly to the ticket office if you’re not wanting to subject yourself to the semi steep, short walk. A “tuk” is basically a 3 wheeled motor cycled that is enclosed and or a convertible in some cases. They are quite common all around Lisbon.
Great Castle and Views of Lisbon. A "must see" on your Lisbon tour. €8.50 each and the views from the castle park and of the castle itself are stunning. Some great cafe's closeby for a bite to eat.

VIews of the city and river to the ocean. I walked up and really enjoyed the ascent and descent. There is food and bathrooms at the castle. Some areas up on the walls do not have railings so watch your step. Peacocks roam up there. You can see in many directions and get your bearings.

Great view over the Lisbon. If you like narrow cobble stone street going up to Castelo de Sa Jorde and great view over the Lisbon, this place is great to visit! Go early and void the long que. There are a lot uneven stone surfaces just be carefull.

Beautiful views of the city. We spent around 2 hours wandering the grounds and looking at the views of the city from many different directions. The tram ride up the hill was fun and then it was a short, but steep walk to the castles entrance. Other than the view there isn't a whole lot to do here. The kids enjoyed running about the walls and having an ice cream at the cafe on site. Be warned it can be quite windy as it sit on the very top of the hill.

Historic castle with great views of Lisbon and enjoyable walk back downhill!. Interesting historic castle with fantastic views over the city of Lisbon. Located in a walled area, entrance is via barcoded ticket purchased at the ticket office nearby. Look out for the Moorish ‘living statue’ who can certainly help the time pass whilst queuing.The views from the very top of the castle battlements are well worth the effort climbing the steps, but the walkways are narrow and in some places the railings are quite low – probably wouldn’t pass the UK Health & Safety police!Although sunny on the day we visited, there was quite a breeze, so be prepared for a chill if you spend a long time walking around the upper paths. There is a self-service café located in the grounds which has a range of snacks and sandwiches – nothing fancy but you can at least sit outside among the many peacocks whilst taking a quick break.We felt both the castle and the archaeological dig area could benefit from much more information – there were few plaques and only minimal information in the printed guide. Perhaps a guided audio tour would be something the tourist office could consider.After a couple of hours walking around the castle, wander back down the winding hilly streets, taking in the sights and sounds of historic Lisbon and Alfama.

Took in the castle during a walk around Lisbon.. Magnificent castle well maintained. Signage is mostly in English and Portoguese. Brilliant views from the battlements. Reasonably priced cafe. Entry prices very reasonable for seniors.
Awesome!. Great spot to tour. Amazing vistas! Loved the history. Could be slightly better marked so your map makes sense easily!
heights of lisbon. gr8 views ,plenty sights to see good walkaround area ,restaurents cafes had plenty to keep most people amused

Great views but disappointing visit. The views from the castle are great as you can see the whole city, but the castle itself was not very interesting and I think the fee is quite high (8,5 EUR per adult). There aren't explanations of the parts of the castle, so we just wandered and didn't learn anything new. I have been in other medieval castles where -even if you don't pay extras- you can find little posters with info about its past, but nothing in this one. Plus, there was a lot of wind and some of the balustrades were broken, so it was quite frightening.

Lisbon at your feet. Lisbon is one of the most beautuful cities in the world. Though destroyed by a dramatic earthquake in 1755, the São Jorge Castle still remains as a memory of medieval part of this wonderful city. Just climb the "colina" by tram or walking and you will have Lisbon at your feet. And don´t forget to look at the sky, an unforgetable blue that will not forget.

St George and the Peacocks!. our first visit was made in true conqueror style by walking the steep hill to the castle. a stop at the viewpoint gave us the impetus to carry on, but the long queues for the castle made us detour to the fantastic ice-cream shop nearby. our second assault was by vintage tram and we entered the castle unhindered. peacocks displayed to the peahens near the romantic gardens and the battlement walks give 360 views of the city below. a guided visit to the camera obscura, a well-presented archaeological site (with guides on hand to answer questions) and notes on the history of the castle left us feeling: we came, we saw and we were conquered.
Lots to do. The Castelo is absolutely massive and you get a good view of it on the way up the hill on the Tram, allow a few hours to explore it all.

Day out. the castle is a lovely place to visit. It is hard work climbing up but then most of Lisbon is hard work because everywhere is very hilly.
The grounds are beautiful and the ruins are nice to see. The views from all around the site over the city are fabulous
Overall, it was a lovely 1/2 day out.

At the top of the hill.. We spent an afternoon at Sao Jorge Castelo after our hotel manager told us it was not that great, and recommended doing other things in the down town area. We hiked up the cobble stone street maze to get to the gates and decided we would try it any way. Glad we did. There is a beautiful 'park' area just inside the gates that afforded a great view of Lisbon and the river. The castle was fun to navigate and we saw ruins/footings that dated back to 300-700BCE. For Canadians, this is very old and I'm glad I didn't miss that. Thoroughly enjoyed walking around climbing walls, taking pictures and eating ice cream on the premises.
Great castle. Don't eat around the castle as reception was not friendly. Only time we found this in Potugal. Enjoy the castle and the views.

Historical site with a good view on Lisboa. Take time (2h) for visiting the Castle and have a great view on the city. If you are lucky, you will meet peacocks at the bar ;) After what, i advise you the go down to the city center by feet, and appreciate Lisboa, the little shops, the little streets .. a typical walk in the city.
Weather Dependent. Weather dependent but a great place to visit with wonderful views. Take the tram up but walk back as it is a quick nip downhill back into the shopping area.

Fantastic views. Lovely way to sirens some time. It was unusually windy when we went so didn't venture onto the upper parts but the views were still awe inspiring. Lovely clear day and it really helped to get our bearings. Worth the money as you could see it being well spent for the upkeep and restoration work. Lots to see, beautiful garden areas with trees giving shade in warmer times. Look out for the peacocks too. Lovely place to visit.
brilliant. Visit there in the end of the day and could appreciate the sunset. It is just awesome to be there and see all the city over the castle towers. Totally recommend the visit.

put yoursef back in time. a wonderful location to get a good panaramic view of LisboaTake your time wandering around grounds. There were alot of places that people just walked pasted. If they had looked, they would have seen the communal ovens and all the water spouts, where people could collect water. Also lot of gather areas, where you could imagine sitting and talking.Alot of maintance work is being done, and the gardens were jusst starting to bloom when we were there.There is an eating area where you can enjoy the sun, but watch out for the numerous Peacocks:)..if you aren't careful they will steal your french fries right out of your hand:)For History buffs, this is a good place to spend the afternoon.

Great city views... A must see. My friends and I just went here and we took lots of pictures. The view of the city is just amazing. I would definitely recommend you to go at sunset since the combination of colors is just beautiful to watch.

Fantasctic views. Arrived and queued for tickets like any tourist attraction, the cost of entrance at 8 euros seemed a little expensive at first but was well worth the price as you walked around the historic ground and came across spectacular views. You need to be reasonable fit to walk around the cobbled pavements so wear comfortable shoes. As you walk around the grounds you come across peacocks; archaeological sites; magnificent viewpoints and the camera obscura.Defiantly recommend a visit.

Interesting and Great Views. Very interesting castle overlooking the city pf Lisbon,and the views are very good indeedOn the upper levels of the castle,i.e. the battlements,the walkways are quite narrow,and the railings are fairly low,and the steps to and from the battlements are steep and narrow.Caution is advised,but the views from the upper parts of the castle are worth the effort.More information plaques around the castle would be a plus to explain specific areas and their use in previous ages.The archaelogical dig area is also very interesting,and highlights the areas of earliest occupation of the castle site.Overall a very enjoyable visit.

its exactly what a castle should be. The views from the fortress of Lisbon are unsurpassed. Be careful of the cobblestone surface it can be slick. Careful climbing the stair to the upper levels, stair are narrow and worn which makes them slick. Take tram 28 which is a great experience. Even so lots of steep climbing to get to the entrance. Locals with golf carts will take you for a few euro. Locals are the nicest people.

Nice view of Lisbon. The castel is offers great view of Lisbon.Also has peacocks...they are amazing...it is nice to have coffee time in the garden, and to go there with the tourism tram...you can take also tram 28, but it is very crowded.

Breathtaking views at sunset. Go to this place at sunset and it will take your breath away. People were enjoying a drink at the top, which looked really nice. You can spend a while just exploring all the different vantage points here and getting different views of the city
Best place in Lisbon for a view. My wife and I as a history lovers had visited this castle. Nice place for pictures or videos and views over Lisbon. Loved it

Historical place but little bit boring. Very nice place because there is so cool view. You have to climb/walk very much, so take some water with you. Water, beer etc is little bit expensive at cafe, so maybe you should take your own with you.Better to get there at morning or late afternoon (at summer).

amazing view. One of the Lisbon´s main attractions, with foundations dating to before Christ times. Although quite a walk-up, you get rewarded with probably the most amazing view of Lisbon (though the miradouros are awesome of course, especially Santa Catarina is my favourite).

Nice place to oversee the town. If you want a great view high above the town this is the place to go. For the rest it is a castel as many others. Nothing interesting to see within the walls for wich you have to pay!

Go for the views, not the castle. The ruins of the castle are not the greatest I've seen and there are a lot more beautiful ruins to see in Europe and even in Portugal. But the views are amazing. There's a stand there called 'wine with a view' where you can buy different Portuguese wines and portos. They come in hard plastic wine glasses, which you can take with you while you walk around and enjoy the views. A refill is a euro off and you can keep the glasses. In the middle of the domain there's a square with a restaurant/bar. The tree in the middle of the terrace is filled with peacocks! Quite a view, but I would be careful picking a table as you don't want to spend the rest of the day covered in peacock poo :-)

Wonderfully maintained castle and worth a visit. An old castle dating from the Moors. Perched high on a hill, it is a long uphill walk - I did it and would not advise others to do so. Do not pay the €10 for an organised tour, get the local tram as it is much cheaper. Great views from the top and lovely photos of Lisbon and the Tagus River. Definitely worth the visit and cheap to enter.

A step back in time....... What a view of Lisbon from this must-see attraction! Undoubtedly one of the highlights of this fabulous city.
Well worth a visit.

If you only do one thing in Lisbon, make sure it is this Castle!. Located on one of the 7 hills that the city of Lisbon is built around the Castle has the most panoramic views of the whole city and the bay area. The castle is easy to see from pretty much anywhere in the city centre but a little tricky to get to due to the narrow winding streets that lead up to it. However the effort is well worth while as you can easily spend half a day up here, longer if your pace is very relaxed. Within the walls there is plenty of shade from the summer sun under a canopy of trees but all the viewing points are magnificent, looking out across the city in every direction. You can walk on virtually all the rampart walls and climb most of the towers, including one which has a camera obscura exhibit - well worth a look. There is a restaurant and a less formal café in the main courtyard all of which were reasonably priced. We spent an easy 2-3 hours up here in warm 18c spring sunshine, loved it.

Beautiful well preserved and great views from Castle. A lovely way to spend a couple of hours is wandering around the battlements and areas within the castle. Best views over lisbon are from the cannon containing battlements. Loved the peaceful time spent here though I guess it gets very busy in season. Que was about 5 minutes but could I predict get significant. Worth the climb up and a must not miss in Lisbon.

Amazing views of the city and beyond. A slice of history with amazing views, I felt fortunate to visit on a warm February day as could imagine it being overtaken with bus loads of tourists - instead full of Lisbon school children enjoying a day out. Don't just go to the Castle - spend time exploring the surrounding district of Alfama with its labyrinth of tiny passageways - you'll find many gems hidden away. We spent a lush afternoon just wandering.....
Highlight. Wonderfully simplistic. Don't miss archeological site. Imagination required. See during the late afternoon then stay for a wine overlooking the city and water.
A great medieval castle with panoramic views. An awesome medieval castle in quite nice condition. You can climb up the ramparts and towers for a nice panoramic view of Lisbon.
Wow!. One of my favorite views of Lisbon, right close to the old alfama area, where you can look into all that lisbon has to offer while learning about its amazing history

Must see! Amazing views of the bridge with a glass of wine!. Although there is not much information around to learn about the castle and it's history, the place is amazing for its unparalleled views of the city of Lisbon. Panoramic views with a glass of wine from atop the castle add to the breathtaking views and experience of being in the castle. It's a must visit.

Beautiful view of the city. The view of the city in all directions made the visit perfect for my first day in Lisbon. I was a little disappointed by the archaeological presentations, especially on the current digs. I usually enjoy history and felt this feature could be ramped up substantially, especially since the castle is a main attraction in the city.

Awesome sights of Lisbon and Tejo river!. Very nice castle, well preserved.One can overlook most of Lisbon and the beautiful Tejo river. This alone is worth the visit. As I like history a lot, I was expecting to see much more details around the history behind the castle and its interior spaces.

You must visit castle, even just for a views. It was great visit for us so I highly recommend. If you have a spare 2 hours go for it,it was worth way more than price of 8,5 euro we paid. I highly recommend if you enjoy nature, great views and walk around trees, also of course if you enjoy castles. I choose to go there around 5 o'clock as I knew sunset will be about 6:40 and I advice you do the same. Beautiful view and colours, something that is truly magnificent :). When we get out all taxis were gone, but fortunately that was some bus and for 2.3 euro we get to square next to Rossio in 8 minutes, great value.
A castle. The castle has good views over the city but it is of scarce archaelogical interest. It is worth a shot visit and the buildings around it are of socio-historical interest.
Superb Views. The castle offers superb views over the whole city. Well worth the €7 entrance fee for the views alone

Relaxing experience. After purchasing a 3 in 1 yellow bus pass for 48 hours (€25 each) We used our pass on the tram that took us up to the top of the hill - a further steep walk took us to the Castelo - price €8 per person.This is a relaxing quiet place where you can walk the castle walls, visit some archeological findings and even have your own picnic in the many pretty picnic locations. There is even a little st all selling wine for you to enjoy whilst breathing in the wonderful viewsThere are toilet facilities and a cafe if you fancy a drink or snack - but watch our for thee many Peacocks who rest in the trees overlooking the Cafe!Enjoy - no hawkers, buskers or sunglasses sellers here!

A must see attraction in Lisbon!. We loved both the castle and it's lovely views over the city. It was a fairly steep climb up to see it but well worth the effort. We were also lucky enough to see the images afforded by the Camera Obscura which was invented by Leonardo da Vinci. Unfortunately the weather was overcast at the time which meant that the images were not as clear as they might have been but it was still very interesting. It was just a shame that the commentary was in Portuguese only but to be fair the tour guide could hardly be expected to translate everything into different languages.

Amazing Views. An entry fee of €5 is well worth it. Great views over the city from the Castle walls, and from the tables of the Restaurant. A great way to spend a few hours. It's a little climb from the lowered city, but do it and enjoy.

The View - Well Worth the Climb. If you have arrived in Lisbon and the weather is clear, here is where you should head. Yes, it can be a bit of a climb, especially after lunch. Yes, the Castle itself is not the most interesting that I have visited - although there are interesting archaeological excavations to one side, and arches which formed part of a past royal palace to another - but the view of the City and the Rio Tejo estuary and bridge are why to go. We went during a late afternoon and watched the sun descend towards the horizon, fuelled by a glass of wine that an enterprising trader sold from a well-equipped tuk-tuk, parked within the Castle.I believe that this is the best view of Lisbon from the land. Pick a good day and just soak up being there.

A pleasant afternoon. My wife and I spent a very pleasant afternoon at the castle. The walk up the hill seemed a bit strenuous, so we walked down towards Commercio and caught a tuk-tuk to the entrance. Our driver provided some security advice (put your head as well as your arm through shoulder bag straps, and carry the bag at the front not the back), and we were off. The ticket office is a ways down the road from the entrance, but the guards at the gate lose no opportunity to tell you where to go.The entrance area inside the castle is nicely shaded, with a small drinks kiosk if you need it, and a loo up some steps. The castle itself is easy to walk around being all pretty much on one level, and there is a nice shady museum and a cafeteria where you can get baguettes and soft drinks and sit outside. The central keep doesn't have much going on inside, but for completeness you should explore every yard in there. There was an archaeological dig going on next door, which could be reached by a rather precarious set of steps that my wife baulked at. There is also no way out other than to come back the way you went in, so if you don't have a desire to walk down, and then back up, 30 feet of stone steps with no guard rail, give that bit a miss.Other than that, its a very pleasant way to spend an afternoon. The main battlements have been largely levelled, so the main walkway looks directly out over the Alfama, Baixa and Bairro Alto, with terrific views. Seats and tables for you to enjoy a refreshing drink make it very restful.The walk back was downhill, so we used shanks pony. About half-way down we found a large restaurant with an elevadore on Costa do Castelo, which eliminated a lot of walking and brought us back to ground level about 10 minutes after leaving the castle.

Time lapse. Walked up there and enjoyed the sunset over Lisbon. The old castle is lovely and exciting. Make sure to bring picnic stuff with you and enjoy the scenery when most tourists are gone (after 4.30pm). You won't regret it.There are only a few railings etc. and when it became really windy, you really had to take care of every single step. But I found it refreshing and in contrast to the overprotected sites in most European countries.

History with a stunning view !. We took the tram 28 to see the castle, be aware that you have still quite a climb from the tram stop and there are very few signs to tell you where to go... a map in lisbon is essential...... great views and was really worth the effort....

Nice view of Lisbon from the top. You will need to pay the entrance fee to enter the castle ground. The view of Lisbon from here is stunning but other than that, nothing much to see. There was also some souvenir shops located at the entrance of the castle.
Quality. This castle was top, we all said it was best part of our trip, well worth the walk! And Ben had a analice cream, pav was gutted he didn't get on it

best view over lisbon. If you're here for views, head here to overlook the city and climb the ancient ruins. Tickets are sold before the entrance gates, discount for students, children and lisbon cardholders. Street stalls inside and quiet place for picnic or drink whilst watching world go by.

Gorgeous views but otherwise monument is not exciting. You are really paying to see the view. Otherwise,it's unclear what grounds you are standing on or what you are looking at. Beautiful being up there though.

Awesome panoramic view of Lisbon. A great site to explore, climb around and check out the numerous photo ops or just relax and enjoy the stunning panoramic view. Lots of benches and seating scattered about plus a wine cart, snack bar, ice cream kiosk, fine dining (no one seems to ever want to be very far from the next meal, drink or snack in this city).Easy hike in the right shoes or you can grab transportation to the gate. Check out the ruins too.
Beautiful view. Best thing in the castle is the view you get of almost 360 degrees of Lisbon, as you go around the castle.Parking is really had in this region, as the streets are really narrow.

not worth a visit. Other than the view- there is little to see and this is not worth the entry fee... the archaeological museum in there is not good and requires more than a vivid imagination and there is not much left of the castle. Other than a basic museum and a restaurant- I would not recommend the hike up the hill and the entry fee to see so little..

A great viewpoint. The easy way of getting to the Castelo is by bus or nowadays tuk tuk, but the best way is to walk slowly up and feel the castle's dominant position. The range of views is spectacular and covers all of central Lisbon.The high walls are brilliant for those without vertigo - for those with a fear of heights, stay down.There is not much inside the castle but the small archaeological museum is special since all the artefacts are from the site.And the peacocks are there for photographs.

Best views of Lisbon. The castle, like all other attractions in Lisbon, is just great. The views across the city is just fantastic. Off course you need a dry or sunny day. You can spend a couple hours here, just staring out over the city.

Worth a visit. Great views from the castle wall, but don't lean out too far,as the walls are pretty low!! No health and safety here! Also,if you are a bit unsteady on your feet cobbles are very uneven.

History alive.... A fantastic castle with amazing views over Lisbon in all directions. Lots of stairs and some ramparts with no fences or rails but if can overcome your fear of heights it's well worth walking up to the top and imagine the sentries walking along here at night with just a torch to guide them. Must visit the back of the castle where archaeologists are in the process of unearthing the original Moorish foundations. This is truly living history. If you're lucky one of the 'live in' peacocks will give you a show of tail feathers.

Woe nice castle.... The castle simply worth the visit and if you want you can arrive here by feet waling around the Alfama district... The Castle is visible at night by different spots of the city of Lisbon but if you arrive at Praca Dom Pedro (Rossio tube station) you will have a beautiful view of the castle itself...

Very impressive views. The ascent to the castle, in my opinion, is its own touristic delight - weaving through the tiny cobbled streets, there are so many beautiful sights of the old town. The city is a sight to behold from atop the ramparts.We went in the off season when there were few others in the castle, and I found the experience of wandering within the sheer blank walls very peaceful indeed - the birdsong and tree rustling contributed for sure.We didn't get to experience the camera obscura because the English language tour was not timed well for our visit, so please be aware to plan ahead of you decide to make a trip.

Breathtaking view. A must-see to feel the city and experience the history of the country.... there's a tram that take you there from Praca da Figueira but I encourage you to walk/climb your way up there if you are able- it's a lot more fun, more to see on the way....

Remaining of castle and have good views of Lisbon. From the building itself, this attraction is not that exciting.It has many ruins but I think it is worth to explore, including the wall's of castle itself.The view of Lisbon from this place is really amazing.I believe this is the main reason why people went here.You can see the town, the sea and the other land across the sea from here.There is a cafetaria and toilet inside so it should be helpful.My kid however likes the presence of many peacock birds here.

Fantastic views over the city.. Worth pre booking tickets otherwise you join a long queue that snakes up the road. Once inside there was lots of space to roam and plenty of places to take great photographs. The cafe was sufficient and not overly expensive as one might expect. Well worth taking your time and walking up from the Placa De Commercio, with lots of interesting sights to see on the way.

Good Views - bit overpriced for what it is maybe.. A good attraction for views, there isn't really much to see in there apart from climb and walk along the walkways on the top of the castle. This gives you excellent views but you can also get them from other places in the city for free. Glad we went in but you don't need all day to visit, an hour/1 1/2 hours is probably needed at most.

Must do attraction.. We visited in February 2015 around midday and the weather was spectacular. Very clear views of the city. Is a very nice café that serves authentic Portuguese food at very reasonable prices.The cost of this attraction is also very modest I believe it was somewhere around eight to €11 per person. If you have the time it's definitely a must do you will definitely enjoy it.
Beautiful views. The views of the city and the river from the castle are amazing. The story of the how the castle was build and what happened to it years after are also very interesting.

The most highest place in Lisbon. You will enjoy with the beautiful scenery and a panoramic view of the whole old city with its special red roofs .. the castle has 4 towers every tower has a special view of a space of the old city ... the ticket is little expensive .. 8.5 euros .. but it deserves .. the only bad thing that the very few marks to guide us to climbe streets to the castle .. I lost my way to above several times until I arrived

great view!. The view is fantastic from the castle. I took the bus up from Rossio Square, but the you can also walk up to the castle.
Take your time and climb up on the walls and enjoy seeing Lisbon from so many different angles.

Nice views but why pay?. The castle is mainly ruins, with some nice viewpoints and a ramparts walk. It has a shop and toilets. However why pay for this, when there are so many other viewpoints that are free? Hence I would not see this as a "must do" item if you only have a short time in Lisbon

Well worth a visit. Getting to the castle is worth the steep walk to it. There is an elevator for part of the journey. Be sure to find it on a map before you go, we didn't! The views are magnificent. The castle too is a site worth looking at, together with a walk round the walls. There are the usual tourist tat shops but get a free guide from the ticket office. A good hours visit. Don't bother with the wine that is for sale and don't bother with the cafes and restaurants close by. All seemed poor value.
St George's castle. Great views from the castle, but there is little to look at inside just a few old walls and some peacocks. The exhibition was okay

Stunning views of Lisboa. We walked up to the Castle and whilst a steep climb, it was well worth the visit. The castle has fantastic views especially from the ramparts where you can walk on them virtually the whole castle. Suggest you get there early, we arrived a little before ten, and was able to buy tickets for entry immediately, however when we left (a little after 12) the queue was lengthy. Whilst there, have a walk around the local streets, some great little back street cafes to enjoy coffee and pastry.

Enjoy the view!. We visited in September 2014. Late morning / early afternoon. The queue manageable and moving quite fast, we probably waited around 20 minutes.The castle is on the very top of the city. Its vantage point is perfect, the views brilliant! You can realise very fast why the castle was built here - strategically excellent!Take your time and stroll around at your own pace. Mostly enjoy the view. Lisbon looks lovely from here!

View was well worth the entrance fee.. We visited the castle on a Thursday in February. It was late afternoon and the queue was minimal. The main selling point of the castle is the view. From its high vantage point it offers uninterrupted views of everywhere in Lisbon. I would recommend this on your first day of your visit as it will later serve as a good reference point. Discounts available for students and Yellow Bus customers.

Travel to the Castle. Well worth a visit to the castle,fantastic views over the city.The trams were very busy so we caught the bus from Praca de Figueira.The bus was empty both ways and followed full trams.If your are going to tour around the city get a day pass for 6 Euros, includes buses ,trams and metro,great value at 6 Euros.The metro closes at 1:00 am.

Worth the entrance fee and and the time.. The accepted advice seems to be to take almost legendary tram 28, from the square of Martim Moniz. However, by 11:15 am (on a Tuesday in February!) the queue for tram 28 was huge. Just behind the stop for 28 is another tram stop, for number 12, which takes the same route up to the Castelo! Curiously there was no queue for number 12. We watched three number12s come and go before we realised. Hopefully this tip will help other TA readers avoid a long wait.......until the tip becomes more widely known anyway! Alfama is an amazing warren. Having left the tram we wandered about in the maze until we paused for coffee and Pasteis at Palazo de Belmonte, in lovely sun trap courtyard. 2 coffees 2 Pasteis €8, a bit steep, but a nice location. We thought the Castle was well worth it. Fantastic views over Lisbon and the river and the views really are better from inside the castle than outside. There are lots of ramparts to explore. Also, you get a reduced entry fee if you have a Lisboa Card (which in turn gives you FREE entry to the Monestary Jeronimos, so it seems that in Lisbon you really can have your cake and eat it). Well worth the time and entrance fee.

It is OK. We had been to lisbon and visiting Sao Jorge. I found it is just OK to be there. Nice view of city and that is it. I will not recommend this. But if you have time and want to just sit and relax with top view of city and willing to spend 8-9 Euros for single ticket then choice remains yours.Out of way Tip - Better visit Cabo Da Roca, quinta de regaleira and Sintra - Day trip from lisbon.

Childhood fantasies in Lisbon. Hovering above the city, Lisbon's St. George's Castle has long been a mark for all Lisboners. The grounds have been cared for, filled with tranquil pine trees and gardens, and the views all simply spectacular as Lisbon is truly at yor feet. Located in one of the seven hills of the city, in one of the oldest neighbourhood of the city, which merits some walking around time on its own, it all seems to send one back in time. For me its the views and being within old castle walls, but there is a restaurant and small shops about. Ocasionally there are also cultural activities taking place.Definitely a place to see when in Lisbon. Beware of the numbers of steps to climb, although the is a small shuttle to take you through the most part of them. Please, pretend you are a princess!
Not to miss, a great placue full of History. Very nice place to walk around. From here we get a wonderful view of the city, the river and the other side.It's full of history.

I nice castle with nice view. That's all.. The best thing about the castle is the view. However, you can save the 8 euro fee and sit outside one the many lovely outdoor cafes and see the same view. Save your euros for Monestary Jeronimos.
Great view over the city. Spend a couple of hours at the castle, most for the view over Lisbon! It is also a great place to take pictures of the colourful city!

No1 attraction. This is a place I wish I spent a lot more time. You could easily spend a day here. Every evening with your lover watching the sun go down. It's views over Lisbon are amazing. Get the Lisbon card for reduction
not worth going there. it's like they want you to get up there dead tired. But the view is quite nice. You will enjoy the whole city. Chose sunrise or sunset.
Good spot. Good place to enjoy the view of the Tejo river.Not overcrowded with people;Good spot for photography, including 360 degrees.one against, price ticket inflated.

Beautiful birds eye view of lovely Lisbon. We went to the Moorish Castle In Sentra outside Lusbon and thought the Sao George Castle might be a let down but the view of Lisbon and the water at Sao George was worth the 14 Euro entrance fee. We thought we'd take tram 28 up the hill but it was so crowded we paid a few Euro and zipped up to the castle in a taxi. There was a guitar guy singing near the entrance and a beautiful arch and orange trees and the wait at the ticket office zipped by. The most mesmerizing view of church domes and red roofs greets you at the entrance. There are old Portuguese cannons and ruins and it's s joy to wander up and down stairs, over motes, seeing castle remains. We spent two hours at Sao George, including eating lunch and watching the peacocks. Just a lovely way to spend our last day in Portugal. We walked into town and admired the tiled apartment fronts and poked into stores and caught tram 28 down which was a lot less crowded. Great way to spend a quiet a relaxing afternoon.
Worth it for the views!. Great views of the city. Space to wander... Lots of stairs ! If you are interested in archaeology there is an interesting site.

Great place, but relatively empty. This place was a really nice place to get a 360 degree view of the entire city of lisbon. There is also a wellkept castle, but for those traveling all around europe. There are plenty more that offer much more history and elegance. For 10 euro it's a bit steep for just a castle and not much going on inside. Definitely worth doing once, but only 1-2 hours worth of time spent there.
Definitely take a taxi. It's on a very high hill so you can see the whole city's skyline from here and can be windy. Taxi is definitely recommended as it is not very expensive.

The best view, but not such a great place. Visited here and its view is amazing, very beautiful view from Lisbon, they have a restaurant overthere and sell some snacks around, Its not that exciting, but is worthed only because of the view. Theres a dark room with a panoramic view of the city, spend one hour and a half in line and couldnt waste my time anymore overthere, so just left. Its every 30 hours groups and it was during the rainy season so during summertime you might spend more than 5 hours in line for that specific atraction. Took nice pictures and get ready to go up thru the hills, there are a few elevators that if you are able to locate you can save some big uphill walk.

Great Views Of Lisbon. We walked up and it was a struggle (age 65 and 58). Views from anywhere around the castle are excellent. Well worth the effort. You can take tram 28 but found the line up too long so decided to do the walk. Cafe and restaurant but we did not use.

Lots of stairs, great views. Our family enjoyed an afternoon at the castle, with its interesting views and steep staircases. The archeological site is fascinating, and the little museum has some very interesting pieces. There is a cafe and restrooms available, which is important when traveling with children.

Lovely view. This castle is just a husk inside, but the view is lovely and the garden is nice. There is a unimpressive but inexpensive cafe on the premises.Insider tip: If you are a couple: bring picnic food with you and enjoy it sitting at the small seats for two that are built into the outer ramparts (just at the steep drop down to Lisbon). Perfect view.

Beautiful old castle, great views. It's a steep walk up to the castle but the view when you get there is great. I particularly liked that there are stairs so you can actually walk along the top of the battlements, although the stairs are steep. Definitely a must see if you are in Lisbon
Great views of the city. A must when visiting Lisbon, even if only for the views. The castle is grand with views of all of the city.

A walk in the past with some extraordinary sites. The Alfama. If you are on foot, first you have to find your way "in" to the Castle. This may seem like a no-brainer and we walked virtually all the way around it to find the entrance. You can follow the crowds, but the crowds aren't always going to the entrance. Just saying. Still, once you are there, buy a ticket and enter. The grounds, towers, walkways and views are well worth the walk up and the admission. The Camera Obscura is a wait, if you want to see it functioning, but the rest of the area is open and easily accessible. The views to the city below are magnificent.

Walk to the Castelo de Sao Jorge. We dare you.. Yes, there are easier ways to get there, but we chose instead to wander up from our hotel, which was near Rossio Square. Our route meandered through town, past theaters, shops, houses, and graffiti murals. The way can be quite steep at times, and we got lost once or twice. No matter if you do--just look up and head towards the fortress on the hill. Sooner or later, you'll get there and be rewarded by the commanding view from the small park surrounding the Castelo. We treated ourselves to a good, but pricy, lunch at the rather formal restaurant in the Castelo. It had been a long walk, after all, and we'd worked up good appetites.

Beautiful view over city. Took some great shots along our trip but the views here, out to the city were beautiful. You get to see portuguese architecture below and get to imagine how it looked 100yrs ago. Really beautiful spot and some interesting stall sellers too.

Castelo de Sao Jorge. Worth the climb, but it could do with a little more interpretation. It has lots of history, but this should be shown. Still the views are stunning, and maybe you could stay there for half a day.

Lovely view of Lisbon. The view from the Castelo de Sao Jorge was quite stunning on the chilly but beautifully clear day we visited it on. The price of entrance is very modest. The castle is very well kept and tastefully restored such that the walls are accessible and safe. There are gardens to enjoy and a pleasant cafe for a coffee and pastry. The walk up to the castle is through charming streets lined with shops and several examples of beautifully tiled buildings. Well worth a visit.

Best views. Well worth going up to just for the views.We spent some time talking to one of the guides who gave us a lot of history of Lisbon. She made the visit very interesting. Great on a sunny day.

Stunning views & wine :-). We visited the castle on Saturday 7th February, my 40th birthday, and we were spending the weekend in Lisbon to celebrate. I'll be honest, I'm not a fan of history, however the castle is at the top of a hill and we imagined the views would be fantastic. We weren't wrong! Abeit a little chilly, the sun was shining and you could sit on the castle wall and look across the city. Much to our surprise, there was also wine for sale from a small Tuk Tuk van within the grounds. What more could we ask for, sitting in the sun for 3 hours, overlooking the city, putting the world to rights after 3 bottles of wine then a short trip back to the bottom on a bright pink Tuk Tuk!! Oh and the small part of the castle that we did actually see was stunning. Would recommend this on a nice day, wouldn't recommend if it was cold and raining, wouldn't have the same atmosphere and the views just wouldn't be the same.

NIce view and not much to see!. The place is really beautiful. It’s a nice castle in the middle of Lisbon old historical area. A break in time and space.This is the best place to have a nice360 ° view around the city. After that do not seek for a treasure or more than the walls and the view.

Lofty Charm. We visited Castelo de Sao Jorge on a Saturday afternoon and loved it. Views of the city are spectacular and the walk up to the castle is a pretty avenue-type affair. It has a really chilled out feel and whilst there are guards dotted about, it feels like you're wandering about your own castle at leisure. Loved the peacocks milling around in the cafe (!). My one criticism would be the ticket office - there was a long queue because two out of three of the ticket sellers had randomly decided to count tickets/money, leaving the queue to get ever longer. Very much worth a visit though.

Amazing view, ok castle. If you're going having in mind to visit the castle you will be disappointed. However the view was worth walking there. Breathtaking views specially at sunset. Make sure to look what time they close we almost missed going in

A breath taking view over Lisbon. This is the best place to enjoy the famous light of Lisbon. You can have there a breath taking view over Lisbon and the Tagus river. Choose a sunny day (more than 200 days a year in Lisbon) to go there.

Worth the climb!. Great views on the city of Lisbon. Had a pleasant time wandering around in the castle, on the top walls, admiring the views. Historical site very well kept. Must do when visiting Lisbon.
Wonderful views. Beautiful area with very nice views. Easy to explore the castle and get around. Great place to catch the sunset

Well worth a visit. Take the time to walk up to the Castle from Lisbon. Hills are quite steep & watch out for the shuttle busses speeding around corners. Well worth the walk though. The castle itself is lovely. Old, peaceful & lots of time for wandering & taking it all in.

Great views and experience. Loved the views from here. Morning or Afternoon would be best on a sunny day for the best light over the city. Didn't realize there was a restaurant here. Would have been nice to dine here for a unique experience. Took about an hour to go through the grounds. Unfortunately, we didn't know about the tours of Camera Obscura that have set times. So when you arrive, check on those and then wander around the Castle.
An optimal view of the city. You can see the whole city from the top of the castle and climb the towers. Fantastic place! After the visit take a walk in the neighborhood.
bar with view. Can you help me with the name of the bar near castle of San Jorge, from which is very nice view og cristo rei, there is an outside terrace

Worth the climb up to the castle. We stayed in a hotel in the old town and it was a short walk up the hill from there - but it was a little steep so be warned. The castle was well restored and easy to walk around with incredible views and vistas of the city - it is worth it just for that! You can walk up and around the walls - that can be a little steep as well going up the stairs. There is a small museum in the castle that is free and very interesting. On one side of the castle they are still doing archeological work - and also a couple smaller areas in the grounds area. There is a café there and a nice restaurant that appears to be open in the evening and would have wonderful views of the city. It is not a large area and probably about an hour you can see most of it. There are some interesting streets surrounding the castle that have a nice flavor of the city and some interesting photo ops.

Amazing views and a peaceful feel. We spent a good two hours here enjoying the views and the peaceful atmosphere (we were there in January somI am sure it is very busy in the height of the season)The views over Lisbon are amazing and the old olive trees make it very beautiful. We used the small cafe and sat outside with the Peacocks wandering around. Watche where you sit as the roost in the trees above the tables! Coffee was average bug the apple tart was delicious.The ramparts are interesting to walk around. Not the best if you have young children as the steps are very steep and at times there are some dangerous drops with no guard rails! We asked at the ticket office if the ticket was valid for the day if we wanted to return later in the afternoon to watch the sun set. The young man said yes, no problem, if we ask the guard at the entrance gate to sign the ticket, we could come back in.On leaving we asked the guard this and he said no, he couldn't do that. We questioned the ticket office again and he said he could not understand why he had said that and that, if we returned, he would reissue us with a new ticket. Unfortunately, we never got back to that area that day.Well worth a visit for a couple of hours.

Excellent views. We went there on the sightseeing bus and walked back down into the square..It was a clear day and the views were excellent from every part of the castle. Nothing in the castle, apart from steps, a few statues it's really just a shell. Still glad I went to see it..

Beautiful place with fabulous views. Beautiful place. Fantastic views of the city. Recommend tram to stop after the castle and walk back down along the tram lines which goes past many beautiful vantage points. Bring your camera and walking shoes!

Impressive views, but.... If you go there after seeing the views from one of the free viewing points in Lisbon, you will be dissapointed. Of course, the views are impressive, but the rest - you will see mostly the walls - is just not what you would expect for a quite expensive fee.

Magnificent views of Lisbom, from Castelo San Jorge. Whitin walking distance, or by TRANVIA, an amazing medieval castle, full of history form ancient arabs livng in this area.You can experience what it meant to live and possibly fight from inside the castle; overlooking the River Tajo. Worth taking a good camera.
Don't Miss the Views. Go for the views...and oh yeah, check out the castle while you're there. Definitely worth a trek up the hill while you're in Lisbon.
Wow. Despite the rain, the views were wonderful and we enjoyed a very nice stroll all around the vast grounds. Highly recommend.
meh. Amazing view of the city but I found the fee very expensive. The guide was really nice and knew how to explain the historical details in a funny, interesting way.

Incredible Views and Amazing History. This site is a must see for anyone visiting Lisbon. My favorite part was walking the dizzying walls and experiencing a castle with no guard rails. You really get a feeling for what it was like living in an ancient castle and a true feel for the dangers.Certainly the views of Lisbon are outstanding. I particularly enjoyed viewing the ancient ruins dating to Roman times in the adjacent archaeological site. If you visit the castle, make sure you take some time to wander around the adjacent Alfama district. There are lots of shops and restaurants in the entire region.
Great views. The visit was interesting and informative. It is quite an effort to walk up to the castle, but the views from the top of the battlements across Lisbon are worth it.

Loved it twice!. I have been twice in Lisbon and I love this Castle! Amazing views and amazing in the inside. Totally worth it to pay as many times as you can. Fantastic if you are planning to see the sunset is the best place in the whole Lisbon, very romantic!

A wonderful piece of history. Great walk up the hills to get to the castle, but not for the faint of heart-it's a good climb. A wonderful piece of Portuguese history that gives a glimpse into the great power that was ancient Portugal. There is a fabulous restaurant outside the castle that is worth a look. Wander around the great cobblestone streets and get one of the best views of the city. Watch out for the cars and tuk tuks, there's not much room and they push right on through!! Went twice during my recent visit and was it great both times.

There's a hill and a half to get here!. The castle is a good way to get a good view of the city. Getting up there however is quite a little trek. I suggest taking a tram that can get you a bit closer to the castle. Once there, it's really nice to be able to see a castle that has lasted centuries in almost perfect condition. Also,there's peacocks up there walking around so that was slightly random but cool. Overall it is a nice place to start a Lisbon trip as it allows you to kind of see where you are in relation to everything else.

View of Lisbon from the castle. according to our tour guide, The St. George's Castle (Castelo de São Jorge in Portuguese) is in the parish (parish) Castelo Lisbon Portugal.Known in its early days simply as the Moorish Castle, it is situated in a dominant position on the highest hill of the historic center, giving visitors the most beautiful views of the city and the Tagus estuary.Human presence in this place dates back to the Iron Age: archaeological excavations have proved a primitive occupation of the Lisbon site dating from at least the sixth century BC. BC, made successively by the Phoenicians, Greeks and Carthaginians. Historical information, however, only date back to the conquest of Hispania by the Roman legions, when Lisbon was still named Olisipo.
Great view. A great view over the entire city and the surroundings.It's not an easy walk but it's totally worth it, the castle is an authentic ancient castle!

It is a long hard walk up to magnificent views. The castle beckons you from all over Lisbon. It is on the skyline and you just know you have to visit it before you leave. The castle is impressive but the best reason for making the effort is the superb views across the river and over the rooftops.Try and make sure you access one of the many discounts available from various sources ie yellow bus tours as the entrance price is pretty expensive.

Worderful view. If your unsure wether to go or not, I would say: go for it! It is not amazing, but if you go to Lisbon you should go to this castle at least to have an wonderful view of the city. It is really beautiful to see Lisbon 360º. You have to pay to go in, but it is not a ruge amount of money anyways. We didnt get any tour guide, so if you wanna learn more about the place, you should ask more about guidance. We just wanted to go, take a look and go back. You can get a map there explaining everything which makes things easier. We ended up being surprised by the view from there and by the story about the castle. I would recommend for sure!(but research more about other view points in Lisbon aswell!)We carried our baby in a baby carrier, so It was possible to go anywhere with her. But be advised that Lisbon is very hilly and a buggy it is not the best option there.

Great for a panoramic stroll. I agree with the other posts about the cost for entrance to the castle being on the pricy side. On the other side entrance allows for stunning photos in side the castle.
