We didn't go inside, Instead the Neighbourhood around it was good for a stroll and photos of typical old Lisbon homes along panoramic views. We found an overlook (mirador) with beverages and pastries available, we had coffee before sun down their, quite nice.

Not impressed. Nice view over the city, BUT that you can get from so many other places in the city. (From the elevator, the arc the rua agusta, if you are ok with paying a small sum (2.5€/with metrocard) or from Bairro Alto, wich is for free. Apart from the view, its a ruin, with not much to see. There is a museum with old artifacts, so if you like that, go. There is a studentfee, 5€, that is not on the list at the entrance. If you walk up the hill, witch is not that challenging, there are many cozy cafés and restaurants. One in a small square, as you walk straight down from the entrance. SO, as you see, many more interessting things to do than the castle, I would say.

Overrated. It costs 8.50 euros to visit this castle. This price is really to pay for the scenic views that you can see from this point of area. There's really not much to see in the 'castle' itself its basically a fort you take a walk around that has some trees, nice shrubbery and peacocks. If you want to see some great views and take some pictures - visiting here is one area to get them! Personally I felt it was over priced and overrated.

Fantastic history and views of Lisbon. The castle is always a favorite 0lane to spend the day wandering the grounds, eating at Casa de Leo on the grounds and savoring the gorgeous panoramic views of Lisbon. In the summer, find a nice shady spot and take in the city from all angles. The grounds are interesting with peacocks, tons of history and different paths. Finished? Head to the Alfama neighborhood and make your way back down to the city center. A wonderful day trip that can't be missed!

Very interesting. Lots of steps!. Spent several hours here. Archeology from Iron Age. Lots of steps to climb to walk along the castle walls but great views all the way round. Very nice cafe with reasonable prices. The toilets were very clean and free. There is a charge to go into the castle with concessions available. It's a long uphill walk to the castle so we took the 25e there and back.

worth a visit.. Cost 8.5 Euro but it really is worth it. The views are spectacular, walking around little streets to get there you just absorb the atmosphere. Informative museums in the castle. If you have a walking disability I wouldn't advise visiting as lots of steps, along side VERY uneven floors.

The best panoramic view in Lisbon!. The castle's gardens definitely offer the best possible view over the city centre! It's extremely beautiful and romantic at sunset. The castle itself is nothing special in my opinion. There is a small museum with artifacts fount on the place. It's worth to visit mainly because of the garden and the terrasse. Still, I think the entrance fee of 7,5 euros is a little pricey. (it's more bearable for students: 5 euros)

Great views of Lisbon. A small museum explains the past of the historical site very well. You may climb up and down the towers of the medieval castle and enjoy the greatest views of the town. The camera obscura is an interesting thing to visit too. The explanations in English and Spanish are very good and easier to understand for most of the tourists than Portuguese. There is a fine wine stand near the biggest terrace, not cheap, but good choice and a nice way to sip a Portuguese speciality with a view as an aperitif for a restaurant nearby

Amazing view to the city. You see the castle from downtown of the city and you have the feeling that it is worth going up! You are right! To enter the castle I paid €5, student price, and it was worth every penny. View is breathtaking the castle itself very cozy and big! There is a museum inside and a cafe and a guy who sells very unique coins . Very nice coins, from all over the world. He saw around the figures in the coin and wow, it looks very nice and special. Prices from 12-25 euros. Not cheap..I did not buy any but the temptation was really high! Do not miss seeing the castle.

Beautiful views of the city. I'm sure in the summer it gets more crowded but in December, the castle was practically empty. There were moments when my friend and I were the only ones in the open square or on that particular section of the castle wall. For 8,50 Euro, it was a great place to visit - the views are amazing. You can see out to the river and into the city. You sit and people watch, sketch, or watch people sketching. Kids can run around playing "owner of the keep" (and there was some kindof medieval experience for kids program-type thing going on when we were there). If you're planning on walking on the top of the wall, make sure to wear rubber-soled shoes because it is a bit slippery. To get to the castle, you can follow the tram line up and wander up from the main square. Or you can hop on the tram 28 which will drop you off nearby.

Can´t miss Castelo São Jorge. Worth the visit for the view, the new museum and the suroundings. The castelo área has many nice streets to visit. From the center you should take the free elevators to this área or any kind of public transport such as tram 28.
Great quiet place and amazing views. Great place over the hill with amazing views of the downtown and riverside of Lisbon.Loved the palce and I go there everytime i visit Lisbon!

my hometown castle. i'm suspicious cause this is my home town castle but nevertheless, is has one of the best views overcasting Lisbon surroundings, and further more.historically it was a moorish citadel, lately conquered by our first king.really worth a slow visit to enjoy all the spectacular views over s Lisbon
Good views. Great views from the castle. Difficult hike up to the castle! A little overpriced I think, but cool to visit.

Go for the view, but don't forget to visit the neigbourhoods as well. The castle is worth a visit for the nice view of Lisbon. Go there, and just look out from walls and towers, there is not much else to see. But one you have visited the castle, take some time to walk in the streets around it, it will give you an idea of the first settlements in lisbon. It's a good tour for kids as well.
January visit. A great place to visit, offering fantastic views of Lisbon . Reasonably priced entry and reduction if you show your hop on hop off bus ticket

A real castle!. Panoramic views of the city from the old fortificationsInclined to be windy, unsurprisingly Take care on some seriously unprotected stairsUnless you're an enthusiast, don't bother with the 'archeological site' which is of limited value and not well laid out

The views and the thing. This is simply a great place to wander, eat your picnic and enjoy stunning views of Lisbon. This was my fourth time here.Our two children ran about pretending to be medieval knights and we loved walking around the walls.I would love to see a bit more interpretation dotted around the place of the history of the castle and the various spaces. There is some, I'd like just a bit more.Inside the archaeological centre there was some pretty 'edgy' contemporary dance going on, to the degree that we ended up having to move our children away when the mock intercourse became too obvious! No idea why it was there...
Great views of the city. Nicely restored castle. Finishes the walk up to the hill and you can appreciate the views over the city. Plenty of walls and towers to walk on

Oh! What a view!!!. Can be quite a walk inside - It's soo huge! In fact, one doesn't realize it when one enters it. Charming castle - but great directions inside makes it quite an easy places to explore by oneself. The city looks beautiful lighted up towards the evening - must visit!

A Must Do If You Have Limited Time in Lisbon. Sitting high above Lisbon, this citadel allows visitors a view of the city from different vantages. We chose to walk from Marques de Pombal station where our hotel was, and hiked around hilly Alfama to give us an opportunity to see old Lisbon as our time was limited. We were glad to to have sturdy walking shoes for the steep cobbled streets in the light rain on the way up to the castle. Once in the castle, we felt transported back in time while exploring the castle walls and battlements. The bonus was the view of Lisbon in the fog, especially as the city started to light up in the evening - just beautiful. This attraction was well worth it, and we wish we had more time to go through the displays thoroughly to learn more about the history behind the artifacts found in the castle and surrounding areas.FYI: There are very clean bathroom facilities by the display area.

History - Lovely view. Visited it and made it in time this time and it was worth it. Lovely view and surely the best viewing point in Lisbon. Wish I had more time as it was getting dark. Would love to come back again.

Great views of the entire city. Excellent hike up the hill to the castle, and rewarding views of the entire city when one gets there. It is helpful to take the map of the grounds available at the ticket desk; following the map ensures that all of the nooks and crannies have been visited.

Moorish fortress. Amazing hilltop vista of the city. Lisbon being built on 7 hills seems to be an on-going uphill climb, except for the tram ride :) Like the Moorish Castle in Sintra, (built to protect against invasion from the sea) both are older than & bear resemblance to the Great Wall of China. . .

Lovely, if a bit tiring. I can only echo the 1,700 other reviewers who felt that this is an excellent and inexpensive attraction, it was a defensive position, so yes, it is on top of a hill, just pace yourself and you'll be fine. refreshments available just inside the gate (beer, soft drinks, ice-cream). the castle is very well preserved and home to many cats, peacocks and, in the uppermost tower, a falconry ( or is it a hawkery?). handrails are only occasionally where they need to be and wheelchair access is severely restricted.

gorgeous. an amazing gem on a hilltop close to the historic centre. beautiful walk up to it although the stairs and hills get a little exhausting after a while. lots of gorgeous murals and photo ops in the side streets and alley ways on route.
Nice views, worth visiting. It's worth the 8,50€ for the views and of course it's a nice castle all in all. We spent about an hour here.

Watch out for the peacocks. The castle gives you excellent views across the city. Some of the stairs are a little steep (and without handrails) so not somewhere for anyone with mobility restrictions. There is a camera obscurer in one of the towers but it is limited to 20 people per show so allow time to get there and be prepared to wait for the next show. There are several peacocks who live in the castle grounds.

have to go. Excellent view!!!!!!!!!
fantastic place!!!!!!!!!
You have to go!!!!!!!!!
it's a place that you must visit!!!!!!!!!

Picturesque, but not impressive and dangerous climbs!. The views are very beautiful, the site is very well preserved and pleasant to visit, but walking on the walls is incredibly dangerous, due to the lack of railings or any sort of safety measures on most of them. Scary. And expensive.

A "Must" if visiting Lisbon. Sitting on top of the hill between Alfama and Mouraria the Castela de S. Jorge is a main visitor attraction in Lisbon and is certainly worth visiting. From the moment you enter the grounds there is lots to see - the views across the city are amazing and many of the internal structures within the castle grounds are fascinating.

Just what a castle should be. Magnificent position with wonderful views. Good range of buildings. There is a café which looked reasonable. Many other local cafes quite expensive as once you have climbed up to castle location you have to take what is on offer

A perfect way to enjoy Lisbon. Take a leisurely walk up to the castle. NYU will need comfortable shoes and a camera. There is an elevator that will take you part of the way but it is a lovely walk with charming side streets and alleys to explore.Walk all around and see the views. You can also find the peacocks that hang around and provide interesting photos.

Great views. worth the trip just to see the views of the city. Not a lot of information around so you needed to read the guide. Museum had some interesting pieces. Take the bus up, it goes all the way, where the trolley does not.

Spectacular Views. Only Outer Walls of the castle exist in some places, but apart from that only ruins not much in terms of castle remains . The scenic views of the city from here are breathtaking . We felt Entrance fee a little expensive but the views and the general feel of the whole castle is worth the climb to this castle . Hop off and Hop on tour does not include this point . We took a cable car to get to this location from Rua Augusta street.

Very atmospheric. It's well worth the climb just for the views especially as the sun sets over the city. As well as the remaining castle walls there is a museum and an archeological dig site which brings history to life. There us also a cafe so you can build up strength for the journey down!!

dominant position with wonderful views over Lisbon. The fortress of São Jorge has a dominant position with wonderful views over Lisbon. It can be combined with a super ride by tram 28 through the oldest part of the city Alfama, and not far from the fortress there are numerous vantage points from which one can enjoy spectacular views of the entire city.

Lots of steep steps to climb. The peacocks around the castle is nice, some stairs to be climbed, but the view is worth the effort. Around the castle is a bit bare, but the view along the battlements makes you feel like you are on top of the world, or Lisbon at least.
Great view. I didn't know I liked visiting castles until we saw Castelo de Sao Jorge. The views from the top of the castle are amazing. It was one of our favorite sites in Portugal.

Great for photos,360 views of Lisbon but grounds are bare. Pros - DRAMATIC VIEWS OF bridge, Targus River (in distance) and most of city (Baixa especially closeup) from massive and extensive stone extension walls, ramparts and turrets. Its huge so u can spend a lot of time (2-3 hours) walking round.CONS - pretty bare as most of it destroyed in 1755 quake, never fully restored.Where: Rua de Santa Cruz do Castelo, Lisbon 1100-129, at top of a hill above Alfama and Baixa - Walk up from Baixa or Alfma, or bus 37 from Rossio.When: Daily 9AM-9PM (March-Oct.), 9AM-6PM (Nov.-Feb.) Please check opening times! Okay I went cos the thing was visible and calling to me from almost everywhere in the city. My busy cooking school schedule left little time or money but had to do this along with Belem. No regrets as an avid photographer (bring a wide angle lens for the most views of a pretty city compared to even the many hillside terraces ("miradouros")).You'll get a distant look at the Targus River, the graceful 25 de Abril Bridge and closeups of red roofs (and washing lines with clothes blowing in the wind) of Baixa. (checkout fotos) BTW - I walked rapidly up from Figueira Square in Baixa as it looked close, but it was still a steep hike of 25 minutes so be warned if u have a heavy backpack! You could take Santa Justa elevator in Baixa to cut down walk. But it left a lot to be desired in terms of feeling the history and how it functioned as a place to live in - not much besides the stony walls. Wouldn't recommend for very young kids. (Comparatively, Castel de Moros in Sintra is even more of a ruin but SOOO dramatic on hillside that recommend that 100percent) There's small museum that gives the bare bones (pun intended) as there are bones of pigs, sheep, horse and cows reared and obviously eaten by inhabitants thru the ages, relics (good collection of ancient kitchen equipment), tiles and assortment of weaponry but all too briefly explained. Pity, as the Celtic and Iberian tribes as well as the Romans, the Visigoths and the Moors populated the hill it sits on. The oldest parts of the Castle proper dates back to 6th century, built as a residence then fortress by the Moors who lived there til booted out by Portugal’s first king, Afonso Henriques aided by crusaders as part of the Seige of Lisbon in 1147.Maybe it would've been more fun in the summer where there are supposed to be festivals in the massive courtyards. Still, tons of ramparts to climb up for varying views of the city - Just be very careful as many are not railing-ed, keep your eye on the kids! Tip1 - After visit, if you walk SouthEast (turn left at gates toward Alfama instead of right to get back down Baixa/elevator) there's an EXCELLENT, cool self guided, but a bit grungy, historical walk you can find on http://www.lisbonlux.com/lisbon/alfama-walking-tour.htmlTip2- Oops, nearly forgot the gorgeous peacocks which let u get close if u move slooooowly. Check out the photos.Tip 3-Theres also a small restaurant in the middle that looked open but empty of customers during lunch in the winter. Lots of little cool cafes just outside walls as alternatives that are a bit tourist-trappy, the better ones are nearer to downtown Baixa.

The place to see in Lisbon.. I love castles and was delighted with Sao Jorge when I saw it more than than thirty years, ago and I was not disappointed to see it again. Entrance fee is 8.50 euros, 5.00 euros for seniors You have to be fairly fit to climb all the stone steps to walk along the battlements and investigate the numerous watch towers and other defences. If anything, it has been improved by further renovation.You can catch a small bus No 737 from Praca da Figuera and use your Viva Viagem card which you should get for the Metro. One journey costs 1.40 euros,  When you come back, either walking or, by bus you can go to the very nice Christmas Market in Praca da Figuera.

Breathtaking Views of Lisbon. Castelo de Sao Jorge overlooks the port city of Lisbon. The castle is a great place to relax and enjoy the wonderful scenery below. There are numerous opportunities to climb the walled complex. The nearby area houses quaint shops and outdoor cafes. Throughout your visit to the area musicians share their talents and help to make your visit truly enjoyable.
Great view. Lovely location with a perfect view of Lisbon and ocean. The archeological remains are not really worth visiting, the cafe is pretty with a good cup of tea.

Worth a look. This castle is great. There is an elavator near the castle where you could get good view of the city for free. Takes about 2 hours to stroll the castle. Great view form walking at a height on the castle walls.
A magical must see. This was the best part of our trip to Lisbon!It had an incredible view of the city and the castle was gorgeous.Don't know why it's so low on the list of things to do.

History and a fine view. The restoration of the site is fine. Moorish and Portuguese history. Elevators from the Baixa neighborhood. Fantastic views over the city and the Tagus estuary. Off-season was not crowded.

A castle with a view (river, monuments, boats and hills). First you have to walk a little. But, mind you have a free elevator from downtown Lisbon, till the middle of the road. After that, surely you have to climb. A little more effort and you will be in touch with nice ways all around the castle and the most beautifull landscapes. Stop and take thousands of pictures to the various Lisbon hills, to the river, to the Cathedral (Sé) to dowtown, and again to the river. See the reflections of the sun on the houses and on the river. Take proffit of one of the most beautiful sunsets you ever see. On coming down. stop at Miradouro of Santa Luzia, and see the views over Alfama. Then go down the stairs and walk around in the narrow streets of Alfama, having some wine, sardine (when it´s the time) and listen to Fado. What more shall you need?

Another viewpoint on Lisbon. Interesting: the old Muslim fortress still shows impressive remnants, whereas the royal palace that nearly replaced it was destroyed by the earthquake of the 18th century and later transformed into barracks. After having visited the place, walk down across the Alfama district to the river: you'll enjoy to discover other aspects of Lisbon!

Great place!. Highest point of Lisbon. You have a 360° view of the city. Absolutely stunning landscapes. The first time I tried to visit the queue was really big. But this time I arrived early in the morning and I could explore all the walls, the museum and the garden. Plan yourself and do not miss this visit.

really worth visiting. If you never visit a real castle before then this one will gives you an idea how a castle is. You have a great view of Lisbon so just for the view, it is worth visiting. There is always a big line up to buy a ticket, any day, any hour (unless you go there within the first opening hour). I rent an appartment just near the castle and I checked every day and there is always a line up. But it goes quick, and if you are with young children, they can put you in special line. There is a tour in different language also. i did not take it though.

Beautiful views. Castelo de Sao Jorge is well worth a visit. The views over the city of Lisbon are really stunning. Entry is a little pricey. Would recommend taking tram 12 rather than the very popular tram 28.

Great place for views of Lisbon. There isn't a lot see inside the castle but the walls are a great place to get great views of Lisbon even on the wet day we visited the city. The walk through the steep narrow streets to the castle is also enjoyable, though tough on the legs! You can also take the tram if you're feeling a bit tired!

so-so. The castle was just okay. If you are into history or archaeology, then go. It has an archaeological site that shows medieval walls. The view from the castle, you can get it somewhere else in Alfama.

Castle with a view. Sadly there really isn't much castle left more like a few walls.... You'll really only need about 30 mins to see it. But the view of Lisbon is unreal!!! Btw not one person warned me but be careful cuz the entire city is up and down lots of hills!!! The castle is on the highest of them all!! I wore running shoes but after 3 days of walking my legs killedEnjoy great city!!

Impressive castle but little detail or things to see. Tip - if you go here you can get the #15 tram from Rossio Square which circuits the castle area and saves quite a climb! A full day ticket on trams and Metro costs 6.50 euro so you can then use this to go to Belum or the aquarium which are the further away tourist spots. The castle entrance fee was 7.50 Euro, short queue for us but if it were longer we saw a machine for tickets by the entrance turnstiles, could try there. It's an impressive castle with nice views of the city and the river, you can walk around the battlements in places, some of these have low guard rails so watch out if you have small children. There is an archaeological site with parts dated back to the roman era and a museum area with (some) artefacts that have been extracted from the site. It didn't have any reconstruction of castle life or armour etc that you might see in some castles so it was more of a nice interesting walk on a sunny day.

Breathtaking view. The site is fabulous. The view are great. There is a small museum that is worth to have a look and then.... Just relax, take a cafe , or just let yourself go with the atmosphere .actualy there used to be a castle in this area but the existent one is so reconstructed that at the end is a bit of disney butnevertheless its a must

A must see! Unforgetable view over Lisbon and Tagus river. This is one spot that woths a visit when you are visiting Lisbon. The castle, the restaurant and the breathtaking view over Lisboa and Tagus river from this hill. Visit it at the sunset!
Excellent. Great place to see all Lisbon, nice place to check if you visit Portugal.Its free only for localsHave nice restaurants near to the Castle.

Great views from St. George Castle!. We enjoyed our visit to St. George's Castle and it is a must see in Lisbon. To arrive there are several methods- drive and park in a car lot, take a minibus, take a tram, a taxi, a tuk-tuk, or just walk. Whichever method you take, you will end up walking the last part. There is a lot of walking to see the Castle and some stair climbing involved to get the best views. It can be nerve-racking, but also exhilarating! You can spend hours inside exploring everywhere. Don't forget to take lots of photos and enjoy the peacocks!The cost to enter was 8.50 Euro for adults and 5 Euro for ages 11-25. Children under 10 years are free! We got a family pass that includes 2 adults and 2 children for 20 Euro.

Great Views. The Castle commands a view of Lisbon that is unsurpassed. The castle does have a fee to enter and it is worth it if you also take a guided tour and then explore on your own. You need to remember that the Castle has served various purposes over the years so sometimes you are seeing a version of the castle that has been restored. The archeological sites that from the Roman and Moslem periods are very interesting. The museum is one that you can explore on your own and is sufficient for some one who enjoys the many items to spend more time than a quick run through to get a quick overview. All in all it is worth the time and climb if you walk up the hill to it. I recommend the walk up for the views and feel for Lisbon and the neighborhood around the Castle.

Worth the Walk. We loved this castle. We took the mini-bus to the castle gate and walked uphill just a bit of the way. It was a wonderful visit. We paid to enter and spent quite a bit of time inside. The view of the city is spectacular but we loved all the arches and pathways to explore. Nice attraction! And you must go down the old steps to the most modern WC!
A "must go" in Lisbon.. Simply grateful. Go and enjoy an unique view over Lisbon and the Tagus river. Dream about older times and old worriors fighting to win entrance to the castle.
on top of the mountain. Great view of the entire city. If you gonna visit it late evening, make sure to wear warm clothes as the temporature drops quite a bit after sunset.

amazing view..put on ur most comfort shoes!!. To get there, take metro to station (Baixa-Chiado), After exiting, walk about 2 minitue... you will see a sign "elevator" on top of a building. YES this is literally an elevator.....take it to the top floor...exit...and walk across the street, look for another elevator (there's a faily large supermarket). take it to the top floor again....Now you start walking towards the entrance:) steep hills.. .when you leave, you have the option to take the bus (2 euro) to save ur feet/shoes

Great spot with magnificent views of Lisbon. I'd definitely recommend a visit to the Castelo de Sao Jorge--the first of a number of castle stops for me during my three week vacation in Portugal. Take a couple of hours to explore the grounds and poke around. There are lovely peacocks to admire as well. The camera obscura was an interesting diversion. The man demonstrating did a good job, but the room can be a bit cramped and the camera obscura images hard to see through the crowd. Worth checking out, though.

Good views but not worth entry fee. Visited at end of Nov when half the restaurants and bars were shut so really we paid entry fee for the view point. Although views were good there are many view points over Lisbon that do not charge. Buy a day pass on the trams €6 (available from post office, covers trams metro, bus, funicular and other attractions in Lisbon) and you can see them all. Might be worth a visit in summer months but do not pay in winter. Tram ride up to Castle is good though, taking you through small streets that you would take bets on were not large enough for a tram.

Not To Be Missed. This Castle is a must for all, yes, it is a bit of a trek on foot but you can take the local transport. The cost for seniors is only 5 euros, great value. You are welcomed by the roaming peacocks inside the castle. It is in reasonable condition and you can walk along the lower walls and the upper parapets, some of which need an extra high railing. The views are spectacular from which you can see all over the city.Do not miss this great landmark,

Amazing view. Great history of the city. We loved our trek up here, beautiful views and neat parks. Our three year old got to run around and chase peacocks (which are scary!). Lots of great photo shots on a clear day. Wish there was more of a story of the castle itself (maybe I missed it).

Fantastic view over Lisbon. If you are in Lisbon you must go to Castelo de S. Jorge. You can have a great view over Lisbon and be inspired. From there you can see the famous "Seven Hills" and rio Tejo (Tagus river).
Lisbon.
The Castle could be better maintained, but despite this and the ticket cost is an opportunity not to be missed.

Well worth the entry fee. We eventually found the Castle after lots of detours through winding steep streets and enjoyed an hour wondering around it. The views are spectacular. The guide provided was a bit short and i didnt find the map that easy to follow. There wasn't much on site to tell you what you were looking at, in the form of information boards etc, so I would recommend some research before you go, especially if its history interests you. Also, once you climb the steep steps onto some of the high walls, the railings are not high, and the drops are vertiginous, young children need to be carefully supervised. That said, I totally recommend a visit!
To see everything. From the top of this castle you can see the entire city and some surroundings! The castle is very well preserved and the only bad part is the entrance fee.
Best. This picturesque and historic old fortress offers the best views of Lisbon as it sits atop Lisbon's highest hill. Walking here was a killer. Don't be a hero; take a taxiup.

Amazing views. You MUST go in and pay the entrance fee to the castle - otherwise you will miss out on fabulous, unparalleled views of Lisbon. It's a large site too, lots to explore, you'd better have a head for heights too - you can walk the castle walls with only a low (50 cm) wall on the inside to protect you from a 10 metre fall! Interesting archaeological excavation area too with remains dating back to the 10th century.

A day trip in Lisbon. Awoke early to a sunny Lisbon which lies on the Iberian peninsular at the mouth of the river Tagus. We were sailing past the 25th April bridge (which looks like San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge) it's called this after the 1974 Revolution and is the second largest suspension bridge in Europe. We pass the towering Christ the Redeemer statue ( a mini Rio de Janeiro statue) this statue was funded by the women of Portugul in thanksgiving their men were not actively involved in WWII.What an absolute magnificent view to open your curtains in the morning. We disembarked Santa Apolonia port in the Alfama region, the ancient Moorish area and walked along the sea front and entered the rather Grand 18th century Praco do Comercio ( commercial square), three of its sides are enclosed by noble buildings, classical in style with tall arcades supporting two upper storeys. King Carlos and his eldest son were assassinated here in 1908. This square overlooks the river Tagus, it's very picturesque. We walked up to the Main Street in the Baixa (pronounced Biatha) region to Rossio square which is the main plaza. We spotted the elevator Santa Justa ( mini Eiffel Tower) but walked up the steep labyrinth of streets to the ten towered Castelo de São Jorge. Built in 10th century then expanded into a Royal Palace 13th - 16th century. It has commanding panoramic views over Lisbon. We spent several hours here and were worn out. It has a romantic garden, museum which displays artefacts collected on site from Romans to the Moors. Well worth the €8.50 entrance fee. The camera obscura was fabulous giving a 360 view around Lisbon. This uses mirrors and convex lenses to bring Lisbon up close and personal. Rain and cloud spoil the images.Peacocks roam freely around the castle gardens with the odd feral cat and is surrounded by native trees. A splendid time spent here. On exit we wandered and discovered a sun filled terraced bar which has magnificent views over river Tagus and enjoyed a cooling beer and free wifi to catch up. We walked back down the winding cobbled streets passing Lisbon Cathedral and popping into the odd shop. The Azulejos or coloured painted tiles are a master craft here and very expensive. The tiles fit together to display great scenes, geometric or abstract patterns. Buildings, churches, town halls and railways are lovingly adorned with Azulejos. A lot of shops were closed as it's Sunday but all the restaurants are open and full of families enjoying time together.
City Break. It is a very nice castle. There were some great views of the city from the top especially if you get the weather.

Great view. The castle itself is not actually a castle but a fortification. Sometimes scary to walk on the walls as the fence is not too high and if the wind is strong it is a bit terrifying. Missed Camera Obscura, they say it's good. The garden is very nice though and ducks and peacocks are all over the place walking among people. Incredible views of the river and overall of the city.

Safety lssue. A few high walls where we walked had not guard rails. Make sure to wear good shoes because there are some slippery steps if there was rain the night before or even on the day.Otherwise, enjoy it.

Good views - In my opinion not safe for children. The Castle has some awesome views of Lisbon and is a decent enough attraction to spend an hour at. But beware, the uneven paving of the castle and access to the highest parts without adequate railings etc is dangerous. If you are hungover, drunk, plain clumsy or a child stay away. All humour aside you are one stumble away from death so be careful and if you take young children up there don't let go of their hand. And at the end of the day all it takes is some other numpty to try and squeeze past you at a dangerous point (and keep in mind tourists tend to behave both dumb and ignorant).

good castle. Very hard to get there take the tram from Praca De Comercio , ask for directions , there is a nice church and a Mirador on the tram way down you can make a quick stop and get on the tram again Lisboa card is great itgives you also free transportation ( I took the 3 day options and saved lots of money ) Take care on the narrow and steep steps at the castle , the day I came it was raining and very slippery
Boooooring!. Old stone and nothing else.... Great view over the city! We were here in november and I can imagine a long wait in que in the summer. Not worth it.
Views!. Worth the climb up to see the views from here. Go at sunset.Uneven paving and could be dangerous for young children .

Great view, nice walk up to the castle. While the castle itself is nothing stands out amongst many castles in Portugal and in Europe. We did enjoy the walk up the castle starting from Chiado. We decided against taking the tram and have enjoyed the scenic route up to the castle. The journey is more fun than the destination. However, the castle offers a great view of the city. Some of the nearby boutiques and cafes are great so, it makes the visit very pleasurable.

One of the best places to visit in Lisbon.. We caught the tram to the castle and once off the tram and after a shirt walk arrived at the castle. There was virtually no queue waiting for entrance tickets and once having paid we walked up to the castle entrance. The views from the castle over Lisbon were fantastic and offered some fantastic photo opportunities. The castle remains were pretty typical but you could climb on the walls for some more photos opportunities and inside the castle was an interesting museum, cafeteria and toilets, plus some gardes with peacocks wandering around. I think this was possibly one of the best places to visit in Lisbon and would recommend it.
Nice views, but nothing else. Apart from the views, I was quite disappointed. For €8.50 you get to see some underwhelming castle walls. That's it.
Stunning views of the city. Take the bus upto the castle to save your legs for walking around the castle. Beautiful views from the walls and the shops are worth a visit.

really shows the lisbon spirit. I went up fairly early one morning and took the winding streets up through the local neighbourhoods. A really amazing sense of the city with pictures of residents outside their homes - super charming. The castle itself has a beautiful view and you can walk around almost all of the grounds. It definitely feels more social and communal than many other castle designs, perhaps reflecting the culture? Well, well worth a visit, but get there early so it's not too crowded, and you can soak in the view of the entire city and sea.

A must see. The castle is large & rambling with plenty if staircases and towers to climb. Lots of beautiful, breathtaking views from the top. Could be tough for those in poor physical condition or even for people who are scared of heights since the stairs have little or no guard rails.

Step back into Portuguese History. This is a very romantic little part of the original Lisbon with tiny cottages and winding lanes - it is like a village at the top of the hill overlooking the city. Musicians were performing - it was really hot (in October!) and there is a free lift up to the base of the Castle environs. Fabulous view from platform near the cafe out towards the River Tegus. Very panoramic and peaceful looking over the rooftops and church spires (if you ignore the scaffolding and cranes!).Note: Flat comfortable shoes are a must for this City as the pavements are all cobbled - save your heels for Paris!

Great castle.. This castle is probably one of the highlights of Lisboa. Great views and interesting castle structures are definitely worth a visit and the ticket fee. Certain times might be better then when we went (approaching noon) as the que to get tickets was rather long and the castle was busy. It was hard to take any photos with out other tourists in them. The wine booth is a nice touch and a glass of wine while enjoying the view is a good way to rest the legs. I would recommend friends definitely check it out and I might even go again.

View is good.... Decided to take the tuk tuk up the winding streets…worth the $E10 to ride one and save my legs for when at the castle.View is quite spectacular whilst the castle itself is okay.The town is abuzz with tourists.Some nice shops especially the cork shop!But ticket online to save a long queue…also visit first thing in the morning to avoid the congestion of all the buses.
Worth a visit.. Worth a visit, although if you have an issue with steps and heights the areas you can go are a bit restricted. Great views in all directions.

Great Views. We took a taxi from the Praca do Comercio up the hill to the Castle and that was 5€ well spent! It would have been a long and tiring climb uphill had we walked. Once at the castle we were treated to wonderful views of the river and Lisbon. Wandering the castle walls was fun. The surroundings are delightful, there are even peacocks strolling the gardens. We walked back down the hill through the Alfama neighborhood, also very interesting.

One of the must do sights in Lisbon. It's uphill all the way but once you get there, the views are well worth it. I recommend getting there early to avoid the tourist coaches and inevitable queue for entry tickets. Taking the 28 tram is a good way to see some sights, but beware the pickpockets. Gents, if you think the young lady on the packed tram is getting very up close and personal with you, put your hand on your wallet.

Great views but with safety concerns!. We arrived at the Restauradores Metro Station and head south to the Praca Dom Pedro IV and took the 737 minibus to the castle. This took around 10-15 minutes going uphill and passes the Se Cathedral on the way. The alternative is to walk, take the number 28 tram or take one of the many Tuk-Tuks.At the ticket office, we used our LisbaoCard to get a discount of 20% on the 8.50€ adult ticket.Once in the castle grounds after showing our tickets we were in the Observation Terrace and from here we could look down at the city.Inside the perimeter of the castle walls, it’s an open area. There is access to the top of the walls (around 10 metres high) via stairs but I’m not very fond of heights so we stays on the ground level. There are stair barriers but it looks like there is no protection once at the top walking level and this seems to be very dangerous. Unfortunately, the Archaeological Site could only be accessed by walking along the wall as the road was closed and we felt we missed out on our visit.There is a Permanent Exhibition showing objects found in the Archaeological Site.The castle cafe sells cakes and drinks. We sat inside for lunch but there are outside tables and people were watching the peacocks come and go.We spent around half-a-day there and rather than taking the bus, we walked down and stopped at the Se Cathedral before ending up at the Praca do Comercio looking up at the castle.

wonderful views of the city. There are many ways to make the journey up to the castle. Trams are interesting, taxis OK, but by far the TUCK TUCK must be the best. The roads to and around the castle are very interesting. Some days the queues to the castle are hug. If its quiet well worth the visit but if overcrowded give entry a miss.

Castle plus and minus. The castle is on top of a hill which provides a nice view of the city. Recommend shortcuts mentioned in travel books unless you are looking forward to a lot of elevation walking.The grounds around the castle are worth a stroll. Charming and nice views. The castle itself is basically the castle walls which you can reach via steps in many areas. Provides nice views of the open areas below as well as the area outside of the castle. There also are some ruins and foundations but not much else. Overall it was interesting enough to keep us exploring for a couple of hours. Do recommend the visit but do not expect to see rooms in the castle. If you have difficulty with stairs or feel uncomfortable with heights then it might not be something you would enjoy.Otherwise enjoy your visit.
Lovely views. Wasn't top on my list but extremely happy I went! The grounds and castle were very clean and inviting. The history was fascinating and the views of the city below were breathtaking.

Worthwhile visit. We visited the castle today. The best way to the castle is to get the 737 bus from praca da faguira. This bus takes you all the way to the top and stops at the Se cathedral also. The views from the castle are breathtaking. Well worth a visit.

For nice view ( only ). A bit overpriced entrance, as basically you are coming here only for nice views. Not much to see inside the castle - ruins only. I was a bit confused, as some dangerous ( I am not a oversecure person, indeed ) on my opinion areas on the walls doesn't have enough protection - so be carefull, especially with childrens. Also a stand with falcons, you can take photo with them at price of 8-12 eur ( depends on bird size ).

Superb views of the city. This really is a must-see in Lisbon. It is a long walk up the hill - though there is an elevator for free from near Praça da Figueira or several trams and buses from Baixa and Graça. The walk up the hill through Alfama is fantastic in its own right as you walk through literally 3,000 years of urban history going back to the Moors, Romans and even Phoenicians. The castle itself offers mostly stupendous views over the city as little remains of the fortress apart from Medieval ramparts dating from the 1940s 'restorations.'

Worth the Effort. Visit this site but be prepared for some fairly intense walking up hill. I suggest taking a cab there and if you feel up to it walk down. We "cabbed" it both ways since some of our friends had issues with walking. Taxis are very reasonable in Lisbon by the way. There is an entrance fee but the views over looking the city are magnificent and work the time. There are food options inside as well as rest rooms.

Interesting castle with great views of the city. There are minibuses to the foot of the castle (737) or take tram 28 and walk up a couple of lanes. The ticket office is on the right as soon as you pass through the gate (also quite a bit of begging). There is a discount with a Lisbon Card. Once through the inner gate there are great views over the city with an explanatory map pointing out some of the main sights. Venture into the inner area to access the castle proper and climb up on the ramparts. Reasonable coffee shop and gift shop. Quite a few peacocks too!

Great Views of Lisbon. This castle ruins are well preserved and offer great views of Lisbon. You come in from the busy streets to a nice quiet relaxed area. The history of the site is quite amazing.Remember to use the Lisbon card on entry to get a reduction on the price.A nice placed to watch sunset from, especially if the 'Wine with a View' cart is there. Buy your glass of wine and then sit and watch Lisbon carry on beneath you.

Should have been on day 1.... The castle itself is nice but there isn't much to see besides the walls and the view from the top of the walls. The little museum contains mostly broken potteries, the few exhibits spread around the castle have no explanations, and the queue to the camera obscura is often quite long. Had I visited this castle on day 1 of my trip in Lisbon, I think I would have enjoyed it, but after a full week, including a day-trip to Sintra, visiting the castle felt more like ticking a box rather than a nice attraction...
Great view and history. Located in the high region if Lisbon the Castle is a great place to check out the city from above. The building is from the 1100's year. A great place to visit wile in Lisbon.

Centuries of history. Well preserved/restored in spite of earthquakes and sieges. Towers to climb, live birds of prey collection. Cafe and evening restaurant. Lots of peacocks patrolling. Camera obscura for excellent all round views. Don't miss and go early to avoid ticket queue. New Elevadors cut climb down considerably.
Great views. We thoroughly enjoyed climbing in the Castle.You need to be able to step up some big steps but its worth the effort.

The best view over the city. A lot can be said of the history of this castle, but its best feature is probably not its many tales of kings, knights and other legends - it is, instead, the panoramic view it offers of the majestic city of Lisbon! Try it late in the afternoon and there's no way you won't be amazed by that beautiful light going down on the river, while you enjoy the cool breeze under the trees near the walls. The castle is well preserved, people in the neighbourhood are incredibly nice and that view is simply unforgettable!

On the pricey side but worth a look. The trip up to the castle is half the fun especially on the 15 tram or the little minibus - very steep. Pricey attraction at 8.50 euros each, the view over Lisbon is great but we were unable to access the archeological bits and I didn't like the birds of prey set up as a tourist attraction for people who have the photos taken with for money. As a peregrine falcon lover I was really tempted to set her free! Do make time to visit the camera obscura - good 15 minute session with a guy who spoke English really well. When you exit turn left up the hill and have a drink/snack at the café/bar which is decorated like a tram inside. Really good cold beer on a hot day and has a Trip Advisor sticker on the door.

Excellent attraction, not to be missed.. The Castelo de Sao Jorge dominates the higher area to the East of downtown Lisbon. A great sight to behold from afar, it is equally impressive close up. The winding roads snaking uphill to the entrance have a multitude of shops, cafes and bars ripe for trying - with the cute pissoir outside the walls a relief to some no doubt. Inside you do get a problem with queues for tickets (if you just want a guidebook don't be afraid to go through the line and get one). Costs €8.50 per person to get entry to the castle grounds, thought this a bit expensive at first but then remembered how much it is to get in some castles in the UK! There is quite a lot to see within, a wonderful miradoura (viewing balcony), canons to climb over (if so inclined), walls to walk, cubby holes to squeeze into, peacocks strolling around, birds of prey, with cafes and shops within the walls too. There's also an archaeological dig area to the rear worth a visit whilst there are fabulous views from pretty much every part of the place. And it's all downhill when you've finished!
Beautiful castle. You can get there on the trolley (28) or through an arduous walk up the stairs. Worth the trip. Well preserved and a great view

great castle, fantastic view. one of the highlights of this great city. good there on foot or with tram 28. little expensive admissionfee, but certainly worthwhile. the catle is lovely the view are great. must see.

Castelo de Sao Jorge, Lisbon, Portugal. Perched high above the city of Lisbon, Portugal, stands the monumental Castelo de Sao Jorge, an enormous castle/fortress built originally by the Moors in the eleventh century This enormous structure with its well preserved turrets. and courtyards looms so high above Lisbon that the city seems dwarfed. The Castelo later taken from the Moors by the Christian conquerors also served as a royal palace for over two centuries. There is an admission price and one must climb along narrow stairs if one wants to walk among the high towers. A fancy restaurant and a great cafeteria plus gift shop are located below the high turrets. There is a falconaria, a stop within the castle walls if one wants to see a number of falcons or even pay six to twelve euros for a photo with one of these magnificent birds standing on tour heavy leather glove over your right and hand. The Castelo is reached by cab or tourist bus. Only the brave and strong would walk the steep hills to visit.

Great camera obscura. Fantastic views from the castle. The camera obscura is well worth a visit (included in admission price and in English, Spanish or Portuguese) to see a live view of Lisbon and hear the history of some of the places you can see.

Start your Lisbon vacations here!. Beautiful views of Lisbon downtown and historical center. You can program your visit from the top of the castle. Nearby you have a lot of interesting stuff to explore, both old and new. The place is getting very trendy

Become Yourself a Knight. Hello Travellers, this is another must see in this town, if you visit in the summer go there a little bit before the sun goes down.......enjoy it you have the most magnificient view over the city and the river, sometimes at night you have some events like concerts, games, shopping.its a good place for couples, family , solo etcHope you like it

Back to the Moorish times. It is with no doubt one of the oldest places in Lisbon after the Roman era this a good place to start to discover Lisbon with a great panorama of the city there is a lot to see around the castle and the views were absolutely Fantastic!The streets nearby are great places to explore.There is an elevator that gets you out in one of the multi storey car parks/shopping centres in the city.To finish I would definitely with no doubts visit the castle again,

This is a nice castle with very good views over Lisbon.. This is a nice castle with very good views over Lisbon. The entrance is 8€ for an adult. Don't forget to bring enough water when it's hot, the walk to it is exhausting, if you cannot afford a taxi like me ;)

don't look down!. on a day stop over on my most recent holiday, we decided to visit the Castle as I've been many times to Lisbon and never been up there. the trek to the top is not for the faint hearted, its a bit of a walk up cobbled and step path but once up there the view is pretty good. Sadly some of the views are obscured by the buildings surrounding the castle (although you do get an excellent view of the bridge and the statue of Christ on the other side of the river), but the castle itself is lovely. we walked around the ramparts and I can tell you some of the drops (and steps down) made me feel a bit dizzy, and I never though I suffered from vertigo. the entrance fee was very reasonable and i would think there is plenty to keep you occupied for a couple of hours whilst up there. All in all a nice place to look around

Queen of the Castle. This was one of the highlights of my trip to Lisbon......plenty to see around the castle and the views were absolutely breathtaking! It costs to get in but may have gone up now although it is well worth the price for the views all across the city. The castle is open till 10pm daily and although it is a bit of a hike up there, it is worth it. The day we visited it was relatively busy and we enjoyed the amazing views from the top. A solitary guitarist played in one of the quieter parts of the castle which was nice. I would definitely visit the castle again, well worth a visit!

great place to start your visit. We visited the castle on our last day. But wished we'd started here. You get a great panorama of the city and the camera obscura show was an overview not just of the sights but the history of the city. The streets nearby are great places to potter around too (with an excellent ice-cream shop a few minutes away). And walk there - it's not that bad!

Beautiful place. Walked here from city centre, didn't take long but beware, the signposting is sparce and its a hilly walk with lots of steps. On our walk back, we discovered an elevator that brings you out in one of the multi storey car parks/shopping centres in the city, saving our legs! It costs to enter the castle grounds which at €8.50 I felt a little pricey but admittedly, we were inside for a few hours. Notable things to see include the museum, the archaeological site and fantastic views over the whole city. Option to climb even further to get higher views but steps are narrow so beware if you're unsteady on your feet and wear good shoes. But a beautiful place, go!

Great views and don't miss the camera obscura. We walked up to the castle (daft thing to so!!) And there are great views. Need a head for heights whilst wandering around the castle walls and the camera obscura was great. Runs in English Spanish and Portuguese every half hour and lasts 20 minutes. Saw all over Lisbon including people on streets etc. Lunch at cafe in the castle was good too.

great to explore with stunning views. I took the grayline castle tour, and got off near the Castle. This tour operator ticket provides a 10% discount on castle admittance prices, which was helpful. It was a lovely & warm afternoon, but slightly hazy however the views across Lisbon were still wonderful. It wasn't very busy, and we were able to leisurely amble around. In the main courtyard, were some birds of prey that you can pay to have photos taken with, and this seemed quite popular with families. There is a cafe, which is reasonably priced, and a restaurant which I didn't go into. There was some tree cutting going on, so an area near the excavation part was closed off. There is even a lovely lime tree in the grounds. Well worth a trip, the castle is in ruins, but the views of Lisbon and beyond make it worthwhile.
Fabulous. A lovely castle to explore - shady courtyards and amazing views from the walls. Lots of steep steps though so maybe not the best place for small children or the infirm.

A great end-of-day attraction, especially for sunsets. At the end of a long day, we took the #12 Tram to the top of the Alfama District (the stop that overlooks the Lisbon Port and lower half of the city) and walked up a side street to this castle/fort, just as the sun was setting. It was wonderful. The grounds are lush and spectacular, and there are even wine and cheese vendors up there that help you enjoy a glass of wine as you sit by the rock walls overlooking the city, river and the Lisbon "Golden Gate" Bridge. We also climbed up the castle for more views of the city...In the evening, the castle is beautifully lit up. Right outside the entrance gates we picked up one of the local neighborhood minibuses that took us back to the main plaza where we got the tram downtown. Just ask the bus driver if he's going where you need to go. Everyone in Lisbon speaks English so no worries there!

Superb castle and amazing views. The castle is in a great condition, great to walk around. Good excavations of some of the older areas of the castle. The views over the city and river are amazing and you can see almost all of it from one watch tower or another - it's all open until late so maybe try and be there or finish at night/sunset.

Wonderful place for an afternoon Visit. This is just a great place to get a great view of Lisbon. There is also a lovely restaurant at the castle. Some individuals felt that this wasn't as exciting as Sintra since there was no furniture in the castle. This is a great example of a Moorish fortress in Portugal. The site itself has been used as a fortification since 2nd century BC so this is a fabulous place for history buffs to wander.As an "extra added attraction" there is a raptor rescue group doing photos of you with some of their birds. All costs and donations are for the birds of prey and it is just a really fun experience.

Great place to while away a few hours. We visited the castle on our first day, after doing a circuit of the area on foot. We didn't have to queue for long for our ticket and we really enjoyed meandering around the castle gardens and walls. I particularly liked the 'wine with a view' - after looking out across Lisbon from the walls in the sun, I was just thinking the thing that would make this perfect would be a nice chilled wine....and loh and behold I see wine with a view, grab a chilled white white to take around the castle grounds. Just perfect! Definitely worth a visit as is the surrounding area.
Beautiful views over the city. I would suggest to get there a couple of hours before sunset. Visit the ruins and then seat by the fortification and enjoy the sunset.

Great views, grab a glass. Peaceful and relaxing area. Super 360 degrees views of Lisbon. Recommend the 'wine with a view' guy, nice alternative to the endless espresso carts!Try and get the 28 tram there, but the 737 bus goes much closer and is easier to get.

The best view of a city which has so many great vantage points. Visited on our last day in Lisbon, almost didn't visit it once we got there and saw the queue for tickets, but so glad we joined the line and went in. The views of the city, river and surrounding countryside are amazing, the exhibits are well presented, their explanations are informative & the castle has been restored to it's original dimensions after the damage of the earthquake and the subsequent years of neglect and repurposing. All good reasons to visit this attraction. However the best reason to visit is for the guided tour given by Bruno. He really did manage to tell the story of the castle in a way which gave you a real understanding of it's history and uses down the years. Only downside are the uneven pathways, watch where you are walking at all times.

See the City from on High. This is a must for every visitor and you must make the effort to get on a tram and ascend to this castle. Virtually destroyed in the earthquake of 1755 it has been wonderfully restored and you cannot believe what a large area it covers until you get there. Great panoramic views over Lisbon - most impressive.
Worth the entry fee. We almost didn't go in and I'm so glad we did. There is a great view of the city from the Castle and you can walk around the walls. Well worth it.

Wine With a View. The Castle of St. George in Lisbon was a lovely place to spend a an hour or two. It is on the Tram 28 route (if you can get on it), has a commanding view over Lisbon and is very well preserved and/or restored. In the castle keep is an exhibit of live birds of prey (eagles, falcons, owls, etc.) which is interesting. On the battlements is a small wagon serving Portuguese wines by the bottle or the glass which you can wander the grounds with, though it is not such a good idea to be navigating the steep stairs up to the towers after a few glasses.

A Real Live Castle. When I was told Lisbon had a castle, I thought it would be along the lines of some Disney-esque monstrosity. However this is a real live castle (except no moat and no dashing knights). At some points, I expected a dragon to pop out of no where. You get to climb the inside and outside walls. They have a small museum and an ongoing dig site. It was so much fun to climb all over and see this awesome place. It is a must in Lisbon.

Best views in town. This castle is a beautiful place to visit with its high walls dominating the city below and offers the best views of this great city, they also have a great collection of prey birds from falcons to owls and eagles, also lots of peacocks around the gardens(very well kept). A must see in Lisbon

Not to be missed. Despite the first afternoon "climb" up the streets to the castle, we were pleasantly surprised by the views and the castle itself. Spend a good 2.5 hours in the area climbing towers or observing historical items or sites. Cracking views of Lisbon as well as.

Great views of the city. Castle itself is disappointing as it's mostly just walls. Archaeological site is also poor. Outstanding views over the bay/river and city from the gardens and the castle walls though. Plenty of photo opportunities. A little expensive for what's there.

Whole family enjoyed the castle. Surprised how many negative reviews there are - we just went with our two kids (6 and 10) and we all enjoyed it and think it was one of the highlights of our trip. Yes, it's 8.50 entrance for adults but the kids were free. Everything in Europe costs this much (or more) so surprised by the grumbling.We took the bus up and it was brilliant - got on at the terminus and we all had a seat; it let's off right outside the castle. I had heard the tram 28 was a bit circuitous, crowded, and full of pickpockets so we avoided it. We got there on Sunday morning around 10:30 and there was a short line for tickets. The views and scenery were amazing; we spent a long time walking along the edges and taking photos. When we finally got up to the castle and the ruins we again spent a long time - everywhere you look is a beautiful view and picture!One thing for parents of young kids - we found it very difficult walking on the ground because of uneven tiles and walkways and were quite nervous walking up on the castle walls/staircases with the kids. We held their hands and went slowly and were glad it wasn't crowded.The inside museum part was small but worth a peek; we saw dancers in period costumes at the entrance, which the kids enjoyed. We also thought the shop at the exit was quite nice and had some unique things unlike what we've seen in other tourist shops.We also walked down rough the Alfama and took in more spectacular views. Can't imagine walking up but the walk down was really nice - we went via the cathedral (Se) which I think is more impressive from the outside and age at a really cute restaurant that I would write up for TA except they didn't have business cards and there was no name on the street! LOL

Must see!. A huge castle located on a hill, dating back to Moorish times. Several buildings from various periods of history, cannons, sculptures, towers to climb - that in itself is interesting enough, but then there are the views over all of Lisbon, simply breathtaking. Whatever else you do in Lisbon, do not miss this!

The Castle Treck. I'm not a history buff but we went to the castle twice. The first time we reached an hour before it closed, and were told it would be a waste of our ticket. The second time, we spent almost half a day there. Go there for a long long walk, to build your muscles, to see Lisbon from its tip, to feel the extent to which the esteemed were protected. Go there in the morning, (take the bus if you're not up to a heavy walk before the actual walk) spend a few elevated hours, and then walk back down into the city, through the characteristic Alfama. Oh yeah, take company, or then be prepared to meet people along the way, catch some street music, step into an impromptu dance to one of the the street bands' music.

Nice place to visit. Castelo de Sao Jorge can be reached by tram 28E departing from Martim Moniz station (green line). We asked for the stop location and a local pointed the direction and said for us to look for a large crowd gathering. We joined the queue and managed to get on the second tram that passed. Ask the driver to tell you which stop to alight off the tram to reach the castle. Its entrance is not visible although it is a short distance from the stop. Buy a day ticket before using the public transport system. It costs 6 Euros, but each metro trip is 1.40 and the tram costs 2.85 when boarded (and they only take coins).Entrance to the Castle is 8,50 Euros. The castle grounds are quite ample, and almost all parts are accessible, including the walls. A good view of the city bellow and also of the surrounding neighbourhood. The castle includes a birds of prey exhibition, a museum with artifacts excavated and an excavation site remnants from the iron-age, Muslim and Christian occupations.Catch the same tram on the opposite side of the road to return to the metro station.

Good views. The gardens and views from the castle walls were spectacular but after a long queue to get tickets we were disappointed that there was no audio commentary and there are not many guided tours, the day we went was only Spanish and English was the next day. They could have made more of what was there.

Well worth a visit. Visited here on a sunny afternoon and thought the €8.50 entrance was well worth it for the view alone,never mind anything else. The whole of Lisbon is below you and you can really spot the different areas/squares etc. Lovely to just sit there ,people watch,take in the view and can even have a glass of wine from a little cart selling it ! Probably not the same in the rain or on a cloudy day though!Outside there are lovely little windy narrow streets where locals live and hang out their washing from the windows,little wine bars/cafes and shops. Its a steep climb up so maybe take transport up and meander back down.

Beautiful views. We took a cab up from rossio square. The castle was stunning. 1000 years old. The views of the city were breathtaking. This is one thing we totally disagreed with Rick Steves on- he said it wasn't worth the 8 euro (?) entrance fee but we felt it was one of the most fantastic castle ruins we've seen. We walked back to rossio thru the alfama. Fun, easy stroll down.
Amazing view!. Such a cute place with an amazing veiw of the city! Very worth the visit to see all of Lisbon below.

Lovely view at sunset!. I went to Castelo de Sao Jorge with my boyfriend and I definitely loved going in. There's a museum inside, and you can see peacocks walking around and on the branches of the trees. Nice place with lots of history, the perfect spot to see the view of the whole city from above. Beautiful at sunset!

Beautiful castle and amazing view. You can take one of the sightseeing busses to get up to the mountain, which is about a 10-15 minute trip. There are trams as well, but I didn't take it so i can't comment on that. I'd specifically advise to go on good weather days. I can imagine the stones there are not easy to walk on when wet (especially risky for the steep stairs). Furthermore the view over Lisbon city is amazing. Obviously best viewed in clear weather.Price for tickets was 8 euro, but we've received a discount through our bus tickets. Really worth the trip.

Great views, but too much to get in. First the good: The views are terrific, assuming the weather is nice enough. It's a pretty cool castle to look around at.The negative: it costs 8.50 euros, around $11 US. I expected a bit more for that price. $11 to see a nice view is overpriced. People talk negatively about the walk up to the castle, but it's about what I expected really. When I got off the subway I could look up at the castle. It's up on the hill. So you have to walk up to it. Coming out I did notice an elevator that got people pretty high up, but I didn't follow it to see where you get on at the bottom.

a great view. It is hard to get to without a taxi since it is on a high point of the city. The view of the city is spectacular but be aware that the many steps in the castle are not kind to those with walking problems. A senior discount is available.

a pleasant surprise. We did not expect the castle to be as big or as interesting as it was. As many said, there is an abundance of amazing views throughout the property. For the short amount of time it takes to get to the castle, the views are much higher up than one would expect. Be sure to have a few hours set aside to walk around and explore. Even the excavated archaeological site was pretty interesting. We did not take a tour but wished we had. I was surprised that the castle had a decent setup with facilities and food. By the cafe area there were a group of peacocks walking around and they will come right up to you looking for food like they were pigeons. The line to purchase admission tickets will appear long but don't get discouraged as it moves fairly quickly.We enjoyed the walk up to the castle from the center of the city then walked down through the narrow streets of Alfama. Although all uphill, the walk to the castle is not bad at all. Some were even pushing strollers. We noticed after the fact that there was an elevator by a hotel towards the bottom that can save you a few steps.

An overview of Lisbon. This was possibly my favourite attraction in Lisbon. I left my visit until after 5pm to take in the sunset as well as a meal in the cafe. The views are stunning - and keep on getting better as you climb up the castle ramparts. The centre of Lisbon is on show, as is the Tagus with the ferries crossing backwards and forwards.The cafe was sensibly priced for a cake and coffee, with the outside tables attracting the attentions of the castle peacocks.The sunset highlighted the suspension bridge across the Tagus, and after it got dark the the city squares and the Christ's statue across the river were nicely lit.

Great view. We didn't fancy the walk up to this hilltop castle so opted for a 10 euro tuk tuk ride from one of the squares (well worth it, even if it was a pink one). Castle commands a great great view of the city, we went late afternoon so the light was great, lots to walk around and climb up and over. Not much info provided on the history but this didn't take anything away from the experience.

Worth a visit. The castle is certainly a site to see, it has some of the greatest views of the city. Be sure you are in shape though, to visit all of the castle and the archeological site you need to go up an down some sleep and long stairs.
Worth it for the views alone.. High above Lisbon it's a rebuilt castle but with great views around the city and a peaceful and good place to relax and walk. Worth the queue for the tickets.

dont walk lol. really worth it but what a climb. We probably approached this from the wrong direction from the cruise ships so approach from the centre or better still get a taxi or tram. But once there really good and worth the visit. Also the local cafes outside castle are good value for money.
Views of Lisbon were Spectacular. Castelo de Sao Jorge.... do not miss this if, for nothing else.... the views of Lisbon from the castle are amazing. Lovely!

Enjoy the landscape. If you are planning to visit Lisbon on summer or spring wait the sunset in this place with a cup of wine will be priceless.Isn't only a romantic place, but where you can think how gorgeous is the World. Since the San George castle you can see the " Praça do Comercio" and other tourist place.Enjoy the poems and the wind.

Fantastic views. The views over Lisbon alone make this a must visit. You can climb, walk along the ramparts, some are a bit precarious need to take care. We spent several hours wandering around, there is a restaurant and snack bar if you need refreshments. Also if you come on a clear day visit the Camera Obscura in the Torre de Ulisses to see projected life time views of Lisbon. They do as shows every half hour alternating in English/Portuguese/Spanish for 20 people at a time. This was one of our favourite places in Lisbon.
Beautiful view. Go there before sunset and you will see all wonderful views of Lisbon and will take tons of great photos. Walk along the walls or just seat and enjoy the beauty.

Worth a look. Whilst the name "Castle" is slightly misleading, a trip to one of the best viewing areas of Lisbon is certainly worth the effort. It is basically a fortification with no inhabitable living quarters or rooms. I felt a bit sorry for the birds or prey who were tied to their stands and provided a but of novelty viewing but if they were not there (ie free in the wild somewhere) it would not have detracted from the experience.The cost was reasonable and there is plenty of viewing areas that allows for vistas in all directions. It is worth spending a couple of hours wandering around, checking out the museum and just sitting watching the world go by and checking out Lisbon from "up high"We walked up and back with out any issues so unless immobile don't worry about taxis etc.This is a must do for any tourist visiting Lisbon

A castle is a castle, but this one has wine on the ramparts at sunset!. The castle is impressive on its own, having dated from a bygone era. There are lots of towers to explore and wander through, plus, birds of prey as others have noted. However, for us, the best part was watching the sun set over Lisbon rooftops with a glass of wine in hand. There is a little wine cart called "Wine with a View" in the garden terraces, and for 4 Euro you can get a decent plastic glass of wine, and you get to keep the glass (so discounts if you return for a refill). We've been using our glasses elsewhere on this trip to make our own 'wine with a view' spots!

The most beautiful views of Lisbon and the Tejo River. I've been to the "Castelo de São Jorge" many, many times. Its is indeed one of my favorites spots in LIsbon and I keep going and going. The views from its ramparts and belvederes are amazing: the city and its river - Lisbon and the Tejo, inseparable. The castle has ever been there, being built by the moors (around the 11th century) and later on converted in the royal palace of the new Portuguese Kingdom. D. Afonso Henriques renovated the moorish castle and the Portuguese court got its new royal palace. "Castelo de São Jorge" is named after St. George, patron of knights and crusaders and a martyr much praised and worshiped in the Medieval Ages (and up to our days, of course). The castle had its golden years between the 12th and 16th centuries. Later on, it was converted into military quarters. In the years 1940, its ruins were totally renovated, acquiring the actual looks. Since 1910, the "Castelo de São Jorge" is a Portuguese National Monument and visiting it is a total must. I enjoy seating on a quite corner watching the beautiful views, relaxing and looking for some inner reflection moments in such peaceful environment. Two last remarks: 1) the castle is on the top of a hill, if you have any kind of locomotion problems, take a taxi up to the castle's gates at Rua de Santa Cruz do Castelo; 2) entrance fee is around E$ 8,50 per person - check if you are entitled for any kind of reduction, as senior citizens (over 65) pay only E$ 5,00. Enjoy!

To fully appreciate Lisbon's beauty, come here. Although expensive - €8.50 for an adult entry. It's still worth visiting this very old castle.The views of Lisbon from here are impressive. Only from here can you really appreciate how beautiful this city is.Come before 5pm to see the live panoramic view of the city.

Take a taxi & work down!. Start at the highest point & walk down to the cathedral & other attractions. Visit the birds of prey in the grounds - we had a great photo taken there & the staff speak English.Fantastic Views.
Great Views of Lisbon. The Castelo is worth a visit. Lots of towers to climb and ramparts to walk along. Falcons to hold for a fee. Great views over all of Lisbon and a cafe for lunch.

Camera Obscura is totally worth seeing. Castelo de Sao Jorge is a moorish castle and once you see one, you see them all. BUT there's a beautiful garden and a camera obscura on the top with 360 real time view of the Lisabon. Tours are just for 20 people max held in EN/PT/ES language taking about 30 minutes. The guide was really funny and professional.

Its a castle with good views of Lisbon. Worth the walk up the hill for the views of Lisbon, but I think I would recommend the tram. We arrived early and there was no queue for tickets, but there was a big queue when we left. Some steep steps up to the higher parts of the castle. The observatory was worth 20 mins live trip around the city and provided good information on the history of Lisbon. Not a huge amount to see. Cafe was a bit on the pricey side even for a small bottle of water.

You can't not miss this Castle if you are in Lisbon. A history must.. In top of Alfama there is this castle of St.George, and this is a must visit you, can miss all other Castles in Portugal, but this one you can't . If you go around the Castle you can see the city of Lisbon from many angles, and you can enjoy peace and serenity at times, althougt if can be crowed at moments, specially when paying for the fee to enter the Castle , but is is a price you have to bear with delight, the castle itself is not so fantastic, but the view makes it so special

A nice view but not worth the entrance money. The queues were minimal when we went in and had grown massively by the time we left. The walk up is lengthy and gives glimpses of the view over Lisbon. Outside there are numerous tourist shops of varying interest. Views from the ramparts are magnificent - but no better than those to be had elsewhere free! Little else to see. The permanaent exhibition is uninspired. Very expensive restaurant. Lots of better things to see and do in Lisbon!!!

Great view. it's better to come there by opening bcs when we went back we saw long line to enter. Castle has really great view, breathtaking in good weather, and it worth to see and spend some time there. It's nice to walk around, even better if you don't need to be in hurry. Lust enjoy as we did.

Great. To start with we took a tram 28 up the hill and got off when we saw a magnificent view,then climbed the hill and found that castle,the panorama from it is amazing,8.50 for entrance and you get the whole adventure to middle ages,you can take a picture wit owls inside the castle which is from 5 euros per photo,I wouldn't recommend to line for obscure tower as there is nothing special there

Must do in Lisbon.
