We took a taxi to get there early ( 10 am ) very few people but by noon the queues were very long .Wonderful layers of history and a fairytale castle in the centre .Hard to describe , within the walls there is a small town , then you pay to access the inner walls and then the actual castle is within that again .breathtaking views and its great to walk down the hills through the cobblestone streets .Would like to go back to see the dawn or ( more likely ) sunset .

Very good experience. We went there at 9am. We missed all the tourist lines and had a good hour with barely anyone there. First off the views are breathtaking. The castle was good for us. We liked walking around and exploring it was our second castle and we very much enjoyed it. There was also an archeological dig as part of the tour. By going early we did miss out on other activities they have later in the day.

Nice views, lovely neighborhood but average castle. Go for the views and the walk/tram ride to the castle hill through the lovely neighborhood; The castle itself is a bit average. Still for the views and the museum/castle there is an entrance fee, worth it.

Great castle with great views. We walked up to this castle on a day trip to Lisbon. Sadly the day we did this we had torrential rain most of the day. At the point where we were already soaked to the skin that it didn't matter, we continued with our tour of this castle. I would love to go back here on a dry day because this was a lovely castle with great grounds to visit. We ended up on a rushed tour as the castle is on a hill that slopes towards Lisbon, and most of the castle grounds were almost a river as we walked through, those areas that were flat were fast becoming a swimming pool. This is an old castle and the rain we had was incredibly heavy that made the old stairs difficult to climb up as there was water pouring down from the top. We still walked to the top to see what views we could see, and had it been cleared, it would have been worth the trip for a photo stop alone. If I'm in Lisbon again, then I will definitely go and do this on a dry day so that I can appreciate it more.

Great view! Great castle!. Charming tram-ride to the Castle. Really long line to get tickets, but it went amazingly fast. Had a lovely walk arrounf th Castle, super impressive, and as a Scandinavian it it always fun to see the old remains of the Normanic culture. Fun to see the Falcons and Owls on display, we didn't take our pictures holding one of these amazing birds, but it sure seemed popular:)Stunning view over Lisbon, and the really nice restaurant with outdoors serving, made our day. A nice cold beer overlooking Lisbon on a beatuiful day was heaven after hours exploring the castle. Despite hordes of tourists, the castle somhow seemd untouched by it, and the whole experience was very pleasant.

Nice for the view, not essential Lisbon. A trip up to this castle teaches you how hilly Lisbon is - and then you get the wide open view over the estuary and the city itself. That is probably the most attractive part of this visit - the castle itself has an interesting history, but the remain are what they are : remains.I would put this on my list if I had a week in Lisbon, but if your are short of time, then there are better places to visit.

I love castles but this is a bit rubbish!. We got tram from centre of Lisbon to Alfama and the had a lesuirly Stroll up to the castle. We arrived early queue to buy tickets wasn't too bad. The views from the Castle grounds are stunning and I suppose for a photo addict like me the entrance fee is worth it just to take a few pics and roam the grounds.Saying this the castle itself if really disappointing, I mean really!!

Great castle with great views of Lisbon. We really enjoyed walking around this castle and enjoying the views over Lisbon.We recommend that you come early though, as it can be quite crowded during the day
Magnificent views. The many vistas from this castle are spectacular. The walk up the hill is worth it! Drop in on the Lisbon Cathedral on your way up the hill and ride the #28 tram after.

Worth a visit. Its a castle. I'm biased as I love castles but its a pleasant way to spend a couple of hours. Was part of our Lisbon Card deal but would have paid the fee anyway. Views of the city are very good.

Abuse of birds inside the castle !. We visited the castle (8,5 euro) in september 2014. You have a nice (but not spectacular) view of Lisbon. Inside is really not that much to see. The walk to the castle (Alfama) is more interesting than the visit of S. Jorge itself. We would not do the visit again. Inside there is a place with wild birds, ... If you pay, you can make a picture with them :-( if you like wildlife, don't visit the castle inside. It's really sad to see this birds, sitting there, very unhappy ...

Worth while walk for great views. Visited the castle on a recent cruise. A fair walk up to it although you take a taxi or the nearby elevator. The history of this building is great as are the views from the ramparts. Well worth the walk and would recommend when in Lisbon.
Castle at the top of the Hill. Its a bit of a steep climb and this is a designed for defending and not living in. There is a good view and the gardens are very pretty

A must see in Lisboa. Start the trip by taking a tram no. 12 or 28 - but in high season the trams are crowded, so be patient :-) The castle has an entrance fee. I paid €20 for a family ticket (2 adults and 2 children). We stayed for 2-3 hours, because we walked on the old walls and saw the exhibition and took a tour on the outside garden and ruins. And at the end we sat and enjoyed the amazing views from the canons placed around the castle.

Who doesn't like a castle?. We beat the tour bases by getting there before 10:30. The ticket line was short when we arrived, but was huge when we left. You get awesome views of the city, and at the same time you get to check out a castle too! They had a birds of prey show as well, which for a few extra bucks you could "donate" to their foundation and get your picture taken holding an owl, hawk, or other bird of prey. But the birds were on display for free, and fun to watch. You could walk all over the castle, along the battlements, really all over. They also had an archeological dig site that you could check out which was cool to see almost 2700 years of history. There were also several peacocks roaming the grounds! Well worth it, especially if you beat the tour bus rush.

A must see while visiting Lisbon. It's that castle I imagined of when I heard medieval stories as a kid. Walking along the exterior walls and looking out to see the incredible views of Lisbon was amazing.

Stunning views, wonderful adventure. This castle is a fantastic way to explore the views of the city and to give your legs a good workout. The panoramic views are worth the many steps to climb to the top of the walls and many towers of the castle. If you have a Lisboa card you can claim 20% off the entrance fee. There are also guides at various intervals in the day and in many different languages, just check with the castle ticket office for the timings. Once piece of valuable advice: Take plenty of water and sunscreen with you. The castle is exposed to the sun and water in the shops inside is not cheap.
amazing view. I loved the view from the castle, i took amazing pictures from there, you must be able to walk and climb stairs, the path are very thin and danger fro kids or old people

medieval wonder. We took a tram number 12 from Praca da Figueira and then you have a short walk upwards to the ticket office/castle. We had a discount with our Lisboa card. First , you get to his big open space like a park with the most amazing views of the city. Then, you can visit a small archaeological museum and then proceed to the castle itself. You can read about it in your guidebooks, I'll just say it's really beautiful, with well preserved walls and towers, which you can walk on all around. I suggest a visit to Camera Obscura, it's on one of the towers, and there's a show every half an hour. Luckily, we stumbled upon the one in English. Basically, you get in this dark room and the guide uses this very simple and archaic system to project real time images of the city to a canvas, a screen. And you see whole of the city. There are only a few of these around the world, the oldest one is in Edinburgh (unfortunately I have visited Edinburgh but missed on this). After the castle you can also visit a small archaeological site. And that's it.

Worth seeing. The views from this castle are certainly worth the trip. The bus gets you up the steep windy streets so far, leaving just a short walk up to the entrance. I note the comments previously about queues, we arrived at the ticket office on a Monday at about 10am and there was no queuing. Note the Lisbon Card gibes you a 20% discount in the entry charge.

castle. Nice cable car ride to the top where the castle resides. Take the E15. Do yourself a favor and get the metro day pass. It will save you $$. The metro system is very easy to use. Plenty of street sid3e cafes for lunch. Castle was amazing
Unforgettable!.... There are no words to describe what you are going to see, as soon as you arrive at this castle. Enjoy this marvelous city, full of history...

Best views of a city I have seen. This place allows you to walk up all the back streets of lisbon which it's self it's lovely, the castle is only 8.50 euro to get in and you can spend a good couple of hours around the grounds. The views are amazing the best I have seen of a city and it even houses peacocks which can walk around freely. There are toilets and a cafe and it holds role plays of medieval times. A most if your in lisbon

Fantastic views. We got the little chug chug up to the top and walked back down. Very interesting inside, lots of view points and batlements to walk . There were birds of prey where you can handle the birds and have your picture taken. Also a cafe where you can rest and have a coffee.

A good day out with great views. A long line to buy tickets was served quite quickly, and fees were not unreasonable. My children (under 10 years) were free. Despite the queues, it never seemed crowded inside.For us it was worth the visit, for the great views of the city, picking out some of the sites we'd seen already in the landscape below, and an afternoon of exploring the castle. The kids were excited about the peacocks/ peahens around the grounds and in the trees, and a falconry show available at the time. Almost as interesting as the castle itself are the parts of the old town inside and just outside the wall. Well worth a stroll, and the climb to get there.

A Must See in Lisbon. The nice thing about Portugal is their castles are all tourist friendly. This one in Lisbon is another example where you can go anywhere on the grounds (and have a glass of wine at the top). Take the public transit as this is a very steep and long walk from downtown.

Nice views, little dissapointing inside. The entrance for the castle is nice. There is a large terrasse with a panoramic view of lisbon.you can go around in the castle and check out the different views. This is good for pics. The castle inside is a little dissapinting as a it is very flat nth really there to see in the inside all abt he vieq and outside design ans stairs

One of the great views of Lisbon and Tagus river!. Although the first fortification on this hilltop date to the 2nd century BC, archaeological excavations have identified a human presence in the Tagus valley as far back as the 6th century BC. Castelo de São Jorge is a Moorish castle occupying a commanding hilltop overlooking the historic centre of the Portuguese city of Lisbon and Tagus River. The strongly fortified citadel dates from medieval period of Portuguese history, and is one of the main tourist sites of Lisbon.Here you have one of the great views of Lisbon. The only negative thing is the ticket price: 8,50€

Wonderful views over Lisbon. The castle is on a high hill in the middle of the old town. If you can find it, there is a lift next to a Pingo supermarket which will get you half way up there. There were 7 cruise ships in port on the day that we went, which meant that the queue to get in was long. It costs 8.50 euros for adults, but only 5 euros for pensioners. It is worth paying this for the view alone and the walk along the battlements is the main thing you'll do in this attraction, but beware the steps are steep and uneven so you need to be fairly mobile to attempt it.

Beautiful view!. This Castle offers a beautiful view of the city, it's a must see for every fan of Lisboa! You can get there by a bus of public transportation, or one of the famous trams that goes up the hill. Or ride in a tuk tuk! :D The tickets are cheap so don't lose your breath walking there :P The castle is large and there are not many exhibits to see but the history, the size and the view make up for it. You can take pictures with owls there also.

Great view over the city. You can see the castle from pretty much anywhere in the city, because it's placed on the top of a hill. It drew our interest right away. Navigating towards the castle is quite easy, signs are placed throughout the city. Some of the roadds leading to the castle are pretty steep, walking your way up in 32 degrees celcius really isn't that much fun. About the castle itself; There was a long que for the tickets, which cost €8,50. Once inside you're immediately drawn to the edge of the castle. There is an amazing view over Lisbon. This view is the most attractive part of the castle. You're able to walk the castle wall (eccessible via a small stairway) to enjoy some other views. There are no real chambers to visit and the castle is pretty barren. If you like an amazing view visit the castle, although the tickets are somewhat costly. I'd say €5,- would have been a better price.

Quit a climb but worth it. We went up by foot, only to realise there's also an elevator which will get you more than half way there :)View is great, castle is really beautiful. Price was a little bit expensive for Lisbon standards.But def a must-see when in Lisbon.

A bit pricey for what it offers, but great views. 8.50 euros was what it cost me to get into the castle, and I admit I expected more. The castle is deceptively large, so you will spend well over an hour just walking around it, as it was built over several centuries, and the history is fascinating. There is a small museum inside, with mostly archeological artifacts recovered from the dig site (so expect lots of broken pottery), and a few restaurants. There is a small side show of birds, that look miserable as they are chained to the ground - this seems cruel and unecessary and I'm not sure why the construction of an aviary wasn't considered?Aside from this, there isn't much to see, except the views. There are plenty of views, from all sides, and of course the castle is very well preserved, so if you are interested in fortresses or medieval castles, you will like this one.I gave it an average score because of the value - for that price I at least expect functioning facilities - All 3 of the toilets on the site were out of order during my visit. Then there were various push buttong exhibitions out of order also. If you make visitors pay such a high price it's probablya good idea to at least make them comfortable.I'd say if you can afford it or if you like history or castles, then you should probably visit it - getting to the castle is half the fun as you have to navigate lisbon's windy cobblestone streets which are always very scenic.

We loved it. We took the guides tour offered by the castle which is free of charge. Our guide was Bruno and he was excellent. He kept taking us back in time and lot of information was shared which made the visit more interesting. We really had a great time. Don't miss it.

Route. Take the metro to Rossiotake the exit to Praça da Figueiratake the public transport bus number 737 this will take you to castle and back to Rossio.No need to pay the bus if you have the daily travel card

Amazing views over Lisbon, bizarre pricing for tickets.. Quite a climb to get here, the tram does go part of the way but in August is packed with tourists. Certainly not a place for anybody who isn't mobile and like a lot of European castles outside of the UK it has the potential to be a death trap with some very low railings next to some considerable heights; that is one of the joys of visiting though. Previous reviewers have got it spot on that there isn't too much to the actual castle but the spectacular views more than make up for it.I would have given this 4 stars if it wasn't for the strange and discriminatory ticketing policy; they have a family ticket (2 adults and 2 children) that works out cheaper than paying separately for 2 adults and 1 child. I have no problem with that but on the day we visited the ticket office don't seem to have the discretion to sell the family ticket to a family, like mine, that is 2 adults but only has 1 child. In their twisted logic they have made it cheaper for 4 people to visit than 3. I did query this but was firmly told that the rules could not be broken. My advice to anyone in a similar position would be to leave your husband/wife and 1 child at the gate and go and buy the family ticket on your own, our mistake was to all go to the ticket office together.

A place to relax in Lisbon. You can spend here as much time as you want. Yes, it's one of Lisbon's ex-libris - but it's really worth visiting it. You can take your book and spend an afternoon there, under the shade of one of the many trees. You can see Lisbon and the river and not getting tired of it. You can just sit and enjoy, as time goes by. Really worth visiting.

Castle, tick.. Nice castle where for 8.5 euro you can walk around with a lot of other tourists and explore the outside of the old town walls and *cough* castle. There is a very small museum inside the castle grounds itself but this is the only "inside" area except for the usual restaurants and souvenier shops so there is nothing to really give an understanding of what things might have been like at the time the castle was fully operational. Similarly nothing in the outside area was signed with any kind of description about what it actually was or was used for, with the exception of the oldest parts of the castle where archaeological digs appeared to be taking place. I would say the most interesting part of this visit was watching a cat killing a pigeon together with picking what I was a lime but was in fact an unripe orange.

Not really worth the visit. The location of the castle is great as it gives a lovely view over Lisbon.. However the castle itself was not very impressive.. I guess it's really just about the view. I wouldn't recommend it though.. There's a very sorry collection of birds ( falcons and owls) specially for tourists.. The birds are tiedto masts and are not able to fly, I dunno why this is necessary, none of the tourists seemed really attracted by it anyway.

Castle. Great veiws of the city from the castle Court yard. Beautiful at sun set as i discovered, decent price to get it. I woukd warn there is little in safety hete and once you've climbed to the top of the castle falling over the knee high rails. Other than that a must see.

A singular setting. This is a very distinctive place. Being a Brazilian, we do not get to see a real medieval castle every day. In that sense, I was really impressed by this building and its stone walls, alleys and impressiveness. Once you get to the top of it you can appreciate a nice view of Lisbon but not the best view in Lisbon, which was, in my opinion, from Santa Justa's Elevator. but I must say that the cannons in the walls and all the stones make this place very unusual. Worth visiting.

Worth the walk up the hill!. This review is mainly for parents with small kids. We took our double pram to Europe and was so glad we did as a stroller would not have coped with Lisbon's cobblestone streets. We used google maps a lot to find places so with a pram make sure you use the car option for directions so google doesn't give you walking options with stairs! Most of the roads are one way and up a hill. We managed but it was certainly a challenge. Make sure you wear good walking shoes and bring water as the hike pushing two kids uphill is very tiring. The Castle was great and the view fantastic! Definitely worth the hike up the hill. Since we had a pram we were able to skip the line and get tickets which was great. Not a lot of food choices once inside but we weren't after anything fancy. We found a lovely man outside the cafe doing €10 Shiatsu massages. He was very good and worth it after all the walking around. Definitely not to place to be missed if you visit Lisbon.
great views over the city. Amazed at the unprotected walls and high walks that children were allowed onto. Was very well looked after and clean.

Not worth the line-up. St George's Castle is a pivotal landmark in Lisbon sitting high up on a hill overlooking the city. As a site to visit it is only moderately interesting. Inside is mainly courtyards and there is a small museum and quite a good cafeteria where you can get fresh fruit quite cheaply. Otherwise it is mainly walking along the walls and enjoying the views of the city. What really makes this a questionable visit is the staggering line-up. I have seldom seen so many people lined up for so long and the Castle itself does not provide enough interest to make this worthwhile.

Visit here for the views. This was on the list of must sees in Lisbon and although there is very little of the actual castle except walls, there are some magnificant views of the city to be had. The area is huge so you don't feel as though you are fighting with other tourists for a look around. Be careful clambering over the castle walls as there are few handrails and some areas were just too high for me - and I like heights!

Castle with a spectacular view. This castle overlooks Lisbon and when the weather is sunny the view is amazing.You could take the tram 28 or 12 up to the hill-but go there early otherwise you will have to wait ages to get on the trams specially during busy time.Worth getting the lisbon card so you will not have to pay for the tram neither for the entrance fee.During the journey its really good to see the city itself and those tiny streets as well.The castle itself is on a big land and also worth looking around the little park.The view from the walls is amazing,there is also falconry for kids.The gift shops are pricey and but the little coffee bars are ok. Don't be scared if you have peacocks begging for food around the castle restaurant.

Unrivalled view over Lisbon. We were advised to take a walk through old Lisbon, up to the St George's Castle. We were not disappointed. Great battlements to walk along - ideal for children's imaginations (from Knights to Game of Thrones). Ideal position for a coffee under the shade of an umbrella pine, with the beautiful vista of Lisbon below. Get there early to avoid queuing.
A castle with a view!. History and a superb view over Lisbon, surely one of the most beautiful cities in the world. Unexpected and unforgetable.

Amazing castle and views. If you love castles, great views or taking photos, or all 3 like me, you will love it. On the highest point in the city, it offers simply amazing, 360 views of Lisbon. The castle itself is very neat, very much like what you imagine a medieval castle should look like. Make sure to walk around the little streets nearby. Highly recommended. Take 737 bus from figueroa plaza right up to the entrance or the trolley up to the castle area, though you will still need to walk up a bit.
Best view of Lisbon. An elevator was recently inaugurated to access the Castle. Best view of Lisbon. An elevator was recently inaugurated to access the Castle. Don't miss this fabulous spot!

It's a dominant landmark (literary it's on the highest point), but not that interesting. The Castle is visible from far away since it's located on the top of the highest hill in town, so it's really tempting to go and check it out. When you get inside, most of the Castle is fenced off and required purchasing a ticket to get in. Frankly, this is not the most interesting castle to see. It's basically just bare walls. They have museum inside, but it doesn't tell you much about who and how lived in that Castle (well, they mostly focused on some archeological artifacts, than on a comprehensive story about the castle). Also, it's not really kids friendly because some of the steps and walls have no rail guards, so it's really scary to walk there even for the grown ups.So if you have no better ideas - yes, it offers some nice views and will keep you busy and offers some picture opportunities.

Not much to see. The walk to this site is already an effort. Not too hard but it should take about half and hour climbing stairs and uphill. Perhaps the view of the city as you go up can be a reward. Be prepared for the way there beforehand (e.g. mark the way on your smart phone), as the signs are quite few and confusing. Lisbon is a very hilly city so the perception from looking at the map can be deceptive.The castle itself does not have much to offer besides the view of the city (well, it's actually a fort, not a castle), in my experience 8.5 EUR is not worth it. 20 minutes insides and that's all. Rather dark and old. If you are fan of old forts like this one, try Moorish castle at Sintra instead.

Great spot!. I was sceptical first, especially when I heard that I had to line up for getting a ticket. But the view of the city from the castel is absolutely worth it. You can easily wander around for an hour or even two.Don't miss this spot if you are visiting the city. I recommend going there in the morning or then late afternoon/early in the evening, when it is not too hot.

Great views of Lisbon. As others have mentioned, there aren't really any information signs, but the views of the city are amazing. We went there late afternoon - although there was quite a long queue, we didn't have to wait long to get our tickets and the castle area didn't feel crowded. 8.50€ isn't exactly cheap, but I would say it was definitely worth it. It's a great spot for pictures.

Underwhelming. Firstly the walk to the castle should be enough to put you off (steep hills in 30• heat). Secondly it completely lacks information signs, meaning you are wandering aimlessly looking at the same view, amazing as it is, over and over. It is redeemed slightly with its museum (which handily has signage), although it is very small.

Fun for ruins & views. My husband was dying to see this castle in the late afternoon/early evening to take in the sunset, so we trekked our way up (by trolley and foot). It shows my dedication to him (and sightseeing), because we did this at the end of a LONG sightseeing day when it was at least 90 F outside and I was almost 7 months pregnant (and whining). Even I had to admit it was worth it. We were able to get the student rate (thank you, grad student ID from 5 years ago!!) so I was less whiny. The actual castle complex is a lot bigger than I was expecting and we walked most of it. I got a little annoyed when we walked to the section where Moorish ruins are being excavated and discovered that there was no direct way to get back - we HAD to walk up a big flight of stairs and back down again. But the views were great. The castle itself has little description, but I enjoyed it more for the atmosphere of walking around the ruins and seeing the different layers of history represented in this one spot.The complex isn't far from the trolley stop, but it seems quite daunting when looking up because you can't see it. It really only took about 5 mins to walk there. And it was nice to have a few restaurants in the surrounding neighborhood to choose from on our way back down.* If you like my review, I appreciate you clicking the 'helpful' button; those of us who take the time to write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more :) *

Great castle!. Visited the castle in August 2014 together with my girl friend. The walk towards to the castle is quite steep, you might wanna take the tram.The castle itself is a little dissapointment. Of course there are the great views of the city and the pie cocks are impressive but the castle it self lacks information signs.

Surprising that this isn't number 1. Of all things I've seen in Lisbon, this was the one that stood out the most. Stunning views of the old city and rooftops and a really great walk around the walls (slightly reminiscent of the Dubrovnik castle in this way) - really enjoyed the visit! Suppose the only downside is the queue but even at peak time it's not too horrific.

High point of Lisbon. If you want to get an overview of Lisbon and see a beautifully restored castle, the St. George's Castle is the right place to go to. It is busy (30 min + waiting in the ticket queue) but once inside the crowds disperse and you can explore around the area and the castle itself in peace and quiet. The gardens are lovely - providing just enough shade in the August sun to make the heat enjoyable. The castle itself is worth a visit just for the view. Make sure to walk around the walls and explore all the towers.Definitely recommended.

Incredible view over the city.. Don't do this in the beginning of your city-trip.Do this at the end. When you see this, you can really imagine the greatness this country has been in the 15th-16th century. Stunning 360° view over this metropole of discoveries.Here at this Miradouro, you can fall in love with this city of light, joy, sadness and grandeur.

Good and really good the view... I will suggest to arrive early in the morning so you can travel alone on the tram 28 and not being in the line for ages in order to buy the tickets.Lisbona is really beautiful but full of tourist, the good thing is that everybody wake up late.I have been visiting on saturday at 9am, it was quite, perfect temperature. and the view amazing!

Great views - steep prices. I would probably call it a must see but be warned for the 8.50 Euro you only get nice views. Nothing else to see really. Even if the queue looks long - one get served quickly. Nuff said.

Amazing Views of the Sea and the City. As soon as I entered the site, it started raining. Luckily for me, Lisbon is absolutely beautiful in the rain and the view from Castelo de São Jorge is stunning. I found a semi-dry nook under an arch for refuge from the rain and watched the flags of Portugal and Lisbon blustered defiantly, as if battling the wind for control of the castle.After the rain subsided, I ventured from the ramparts down some stone steps to an old watch tower where only one or two other people were milling about taking advantage of the different viewpoint of the city and the River Tagus stretching out past Belém to join the Atlantic.After climbing back up to the main fortress, I walked around the ramparts while listening to the closest thing I had to fado on my iPod (George Dalaras, who is Greek, but good enough). The city seems to ooze melancholy in the rain. Walking past the Câmara Escura, I realized they had closed the periscope due to the rain, which was disappointing, but I don't know what I would have seen that I couldn't already.The way up the hill from the central neighborhood of Baixa is quite easy, as there are several free elevators to give you a lift up the otherwise steep hill. One even has a grocery store and a decent restroom inside! From Baixa, head over to where the hill begins and look for a modern glass building among its historic neighbors or just ask somebody for the elevator. It's the same word in Portuguese.

Amazing views. This castle - or military fort in my opinion has some very interesting history and some fantastic views of the architecture and surrounding landscape. We took the train from Cascais (40 min) and walked to the castle - it was easy to find. You can get some really good pictures overlooking lisbon and the river. We then did a tram tour around Lisbon however we were not too familiar with the system resulting in us getting off the tram a few stops early for the train station. If you are to use the trams, I would recommend familiarizing yourself with where you need to be and what number tram you need to go on. Overall it was a fantastic day and well worth going to!

good place to get rid of inlaws or kids. Maybe the best attraction of Lisbon.when you visit a Castle, you will for sure imagine being at war like you did when you were a kidfirst, walk on the outside part of the fortification and enjoy the view on the harbor and Targus river next to the old canons and imagine how you would destroy any enemy boat attacking you.once it's done, walk further to the inner part of the castle and climb on the top of the towers and guards paths but be careful not to fall. there is no fence nor bar to indicate you where you should walk as a tourist and where you are not supposed to climb and some place have a nice drop if you fall. (nice idea if you have to visit on a windy day with your inlaws... Darwin award guaranteed )superb view in all direction, one side on the modern side of the city and the other on the residential area.because the visit can take a while, enjoy a drink/ice cream in the restaurant of the Castle. it's expensive but you will not find much cheaper around anyway because of tourists prices everywhere.if you are lucky, you will see some peacocks. if you are not lucky but still want to see some peacocks, walk a bit in the small paths around the restaurant and you will end arrive in a strange place, not knowing if it's still part of the castle or already the houses of neighbors... filled with 6-8-10 peacocks^^

Really cool Castle to visit. If you have seen one castle, you have seen them all. But this place is also with spectaculair views, its nice in the shadow with a little wind to chill in your Lisboa trip. Dont bother about the line at the ticketoffice, this one goes fast, it wont take long!

Nice view of Lisbon. We took the old Tram no. 12 from Praca da Figueira, a nice way to get to the castle through the Mouraria and Alfama neighborhoods. After that we had to climb quite a steep street to the entrance. The main atraction at the castle (most of it parts of buildings and ruins, and also some archeological excavations) is the beautiful views of the city and the Tejo river, in all directions. Make sure you come in a day with good visibility. Also the climbing and walking on top of some walls is interesting, but in some parts quite scary, because of the hight.Besides that, there is nothing special to see in the castle.The main problem is the many steps and the uneven surface, which makes it very difficult or impossible for disabled people to visit most of the castle, and even for people with smaller walking difficulties. We returned to the city using the Elevador do Castelo from 2013.

a fort.. Nice walk up to the top to see the St.George's castle, lets get this correct, seen a few castle's and this is a FORT, great views from the top, but for 8,5Euro, not worth it, You take a walk around the walls, and after that, its over, little view in the dungeon ! :-) and move on.

Not to be missed.. This is a wonderful place to go and watch the sun go down over Lisbon, the views of the city are something not to be missed. The castle itself has lots of steps and low walls so care is needed when walking around but still it has so many places to stop and admire the views. There is a tram that you can catch halfway up which is a great experience and saves you the long walk. The ticket price is about 8.5 euros which I thought was reasonable.

Lovely placed above Lisbon. The Castelo de Sao Jorge is placed on top of the tallest of many hills in Lisbon, so it offers a splendid view of the city. It is a nice place to go for a stroll, and you are also allowed to climb onto the walls of the castle itself. You don`t get to see much of what is inside the castle, but the views make ut for that. I would definetly recommend a visit here. If you walk up from the city centre, you also get a bit of exercise for free. The walk is steep, but manageable for most, I would say.

A must do but nothing spectacular. You probably have to go here if youre in Lisbon but there are better ruins in Sintra. The view over the city is nice. The walk up wasnt as bad as it looks. The "archeological site" is a waste of time but the artifacts aren't bad.

Nice views of the city. If you want a cool place to view the city and see what a castle fortress looks like, I recommend visiting. If you are wanting to see really cool stuff inside the castle though, reset your expectations. In agreement with another reviewer, "The walk up is steep but not too hard and the view over Lisbon is well worth it. Apart from the stunning view, there is not a lot to see in the castle grounds." I don't regret going, but I want others to understand what to expect.

Historic site with a fantastic view. Castelo de Sao Jorge is well worth visiting. Not a lot survived the big earhquake in 1755 but the outside walls are renovated. The biggest reason to buy a ticket is the wonderful view of Lissabon and its surroundings.
A fort, not unlike others. This fort is similar to others but has the distinction it overlooks the city of Lisbon hence the beautiful sight around. Not a |stunning" place yet a pleasurable visit.

Was a little bit of a let down after visiting Sintra. We visited here the day after visiting the Moorish castle in Sintra. We took Tram 28 and then a taxi up to the castle (4 Euros). We got there very early so did not have to wait in line. When we left a couple hours later, the line to buy tickets was extremely long. So my advice is to get there early.There were peacocks and cats roaming the grounds which were adorable. The gardens have beautiful flowers and everything is just beautiful.It is very interesting to walk around and up all the stairs to the towers. The view is also amazing. Unfortunately, after visiting Sintra this was a little less impressive. If you plan to visit both, visit here first.

A fairytale, medieval castle/fortress. Lisbon's iconic picture postcard castle is a must do--definitely worth the price of admission. The fortress and grounds are so well preserved and maintained, the complex almost looks like a movie set. Amazing 360 degree views. Go an hour or two before sunset to watch the city transform from day to night (bring a sweater--it is cooler and windier up here.) I was there at the height of tourist season and was surprised at how few people were there for the sunset. Wear sturdy shoes and keep your kids close--there are steep stairs, hundred foot drops and no guard railings.

Stunning Views. Visited the castelo in July in the morning which made the walk up the hill to it easier though this isnt too bad and can be taken leisurely. Its worth a visit for the views over the city in particular which are spectacular and you can see all over Lisbon. It took us about two hours to have a wander about the castle without rushing as there is plenty of walkways and things to look at. And if you feel like taking a break there is a cafe to rest and catch your breath . The only fault i had with the castle was that i wished there was mor info provided in the guides on the history of the castelo

St george's castle fab family outing. we took note of the reviews - caught a cab up (which was only 7€ for family of four) and got there just after 10 am on a Tuesday morning in August. only had to queue for about 5 mins - noted the big queues on the way out. This is a great location for an easy explore with the kids. They loved the birds of prey and the camera obscura. The staff were great - even letting us have a private view of the camera obscura as we'd have to wait an hour for the English visit. This only allows 20 people in every half an hour on the hour and half hour and they rotate between languages so check at the ticket desk when the next one is in your language. Its well worth seeing. Only point for small kids is that the walls on the parapets were quite low - and there was no barricade so do take care! There is a lot of room for picnicking and the views are sensational. walking back down the hill was easy and we made great use of the barrio elevador (lift).
Beautiful View of Lisbon. My husband and I visited back in July of 2013. This is a must see place to get the best views of Lisbon. Enjoy the spectacular views and take a walk around.
Archer's slits. It's hard to imagine how violent the times were or what defeat meant. According to The Siege of Lisbon, when the Crusaders took the city, they killed every mam, woman, and child

you HAVE to go.. This is a MUST while in Lisbon. It is on the peak of the highest mountain around, so the views are spectacular. Also on the way to and from, you will be able to see nice little stores and roads around.THE place to visit in Lisbon.

Great view but didn't like birds of prey exploitation. The walk up is steep but not too hard and the view over Lisbon is well worth it. Apart from the stunning view, there is not a lot to see in the castle grounds. I seriously disliked the birds of prey put out on display and being exploited for stupid tourist pictures.
Must see!. This is a great place and a must see! You can see Lisboa from different angles and the view is exceptional. Dont miss it

Amazing Views. Beautiful Views of the city--it is easy to see why anyone controlling the city would use the hilltop. I think it would be nice to have more historical background on the castle. The signs do not do it justice, nor do they adequately explain what part if any of the castle that remains is Arab (Moor) and if any stones for foundation date back to the fortress of the Visigoths that stood in same place. Something like a headset tour would be appropriate here.

Great Views. We walked up here from our hotel. Its quite a track up in the heat of the midday sun!!!!! The views are just amazing. Lots of walking inside - around the towers - but I would go just for the panoramic views. The little restaurant inside is quite nice too. Entrance fee was about €15 for the 2 of us.

The whole city is your oyster. Either climb up or take a taxi to the top, and then enjoy the views from the magnificent castle, You can see the entire city from a variety of towers. The pictures you can take and the memories you make are well worth it!

best in lisbon. By far the best view of the city, much better than the elevator. Its a really well maintained fort and easily worth the ticket price of €7.50.Go early to beat the crowds and get a look at the camera obscura (which i missed). I'd also recommend leaving the flipflops behind for this one, especially if you plan walking all the way up from the city.

a great view of the city. Standing on a hill overlooking the city centre, you can also see the Tejo bay, the 25th of April bridge and the statue of Christo Rei. The castelo is located in Alfama, one of the old neighbourhoods in town. You can take a taxi or the bus, but we walked up to the entrance. So we had the possibility to see more of the area surrounding the castelo, which is tipical for Lisbon. The entrancefee is 7,50 euros, which is okay. You can walk around on groundlevel and get on several walls through steep stone stairs. Unfortunately the castelo isn't as beautiful as the one in Sintra, but the view is worth a visit. There are some musicians playing old instruments, a restaurant/café and some people doing and selling their handicraft.I have been here a couple of times before, but not in recent years, but I was still impressed with the great view of the city.

Go and visit. Ticket is 7,5 € (for adults)My recommendation is dark room or black chamber. There is a camera obscura, an optical system of mirrors and lenses, which provides 360º detailed views of the whole city (in real time), so one can see all monuments, the river and people walking on the street, cars, even birds and planes in the sky. The man who controls the periscope will tell you the most important things (he speaks English, Franch, Spanish and of course Portuguese) and you can also ask him anything you want to know. There is a schedule at the entrance, and if I remember correctly: at 11am is in English, at noon is in Franch. Only 20 people can enter the room, so you may have to wait a little bit (but it is worth). Black room don t work if it is raining or foggy, so pick up a sunny day and enjoy!11 in english 12in franch

Old castle on top on of Lisbon's 7 hills. Would definitely recommend taking a taxi from lisbon as its the cheapest compared to the tram or the tuktuk.There is an entrance fee for the Castle which I think its worth it, it would take you a couple of hours there.Great scenery of lisbon from the hill top, good for pictures as well.People who are afraid of the heights watch as you will have to go up some stairs to reach the castle's fence where you can go around the castle there.

Average. Nothing fancy about this fortress , the only advantage is its location which let you take great photos of lisbon. If your looking for better forts and castles you can skip it and go to Sintra .
The best place to visit in Lisbon. I'm from Lisbon and I go to the castle at least one time every year.It's really the best place to visit in Lisbon. Don't miss it in a sunny day.

Worth the hike. Phew what a hike but well worth it, not only are the views amazing but its so much fun to walk all around the castle and on the walls, there are lots of shady places and a cafe when it gets a bit to hot.

St. George's Castle. The walk is not challenging, and the view is by far the best in Lisbon, easily beating that of the Elevator. Besides the initial area, equally beautiful views are gained from climbing each of the castle's many towers.The castle itself is wonderful to explore and climb all over, but a little more insight into the history associated with it is more desirable. Nevertheless, a beautiful piece of architecture with scintillating views of the surrounding area.

Walk & go early. So everyone told us the walk was hard. It is NOT hard if you walk a lot. The stones do get worn with walking so don't wear flip flops. It was a short walk to the castle from the main square. It is a little confusing on how to get to the entrance, use a good map. Alternatively you can take the tram up or elevators which are now available just outside a grocery store Pingo Doce. Go earlier. We went for 10. There was NO line. When we left at 11:45, there was a HUGE line. Go check out the dark chamber show times for your language first then walk around. There are shows in English, Portuguese and Spanish. They happen in intervals of 30 min. I gets crowded later on, so try to do it early. Give yourself 2 hours here.

Worth the effort when you arrive!!. If you decide to walk from the centre be warned it is quite a hike with some steep hills and steps, also make sure you know the way it is easy to go the wrong way....we did!Take the tram or bus or taxi (they are as cheap). Once there you need to get a ticket...arrive late and it's very busy!Inside it's lovely...great walks and fantastic views...walk along the walls, if you dare!Places for coffee and snacks.

Wonderful place. This is really worth the hike up the streets for this castle and park. There is a lovely park area and the view of the city is the best. You can sit peacefully by the cafe and watch the peacocks walk around and take a break from the walk. It is in Alfama the oldest and most lovely part of Lisbon. It really is a must see in Lisbon. The Se Cathedral is also nearby so there is much to see. On the way down, stop in a Fado restaurant if it is at night or just a cafe to relax. It's wonderful.

Came to the castle for dinner. I cannot comment on the castle itself and its grounds beyond the restaurant area, but like reviewers before us we tried to take Tram #28 to the castle and it was packed. Soooooooooooooooo, the six of us ( yes 6 : 4 adults, a 7yr old and 8 mnth old baby and a full sized stroller) took the ride of our lives in a TUK TUK. What a blast...I highly recommend this mode of transportation up the hill as they drop you off right at the entrance to the caslte. The cost : $10.00 Euros for all of us..not per person and we took our Tuk Tuk ride from the pedestrian concourse at the bottom of the hill. Our driver spoke clear and fluent english which was a great suprize. As earlier stated, we were coming here for dinner and being all dressed up it was quite nice not having sweaty people sticking to you on the ride up. Think sardine can for a depiction of what Tram #28 looked like. I can comment on the night views of the skyline and they were beautiful. The one downside with us going to the castle for dinner at night is that the Tuk Tuks do not come to the castle at night. Therefore, we (the group) all like to explore so we ended up walking down all the way. During our walk, we came across several neat restaurants where the locals were all watching the world cup and it was quite an experience. We ended up going into a few and had a blast.

Great view over the city. From the castle, you'll have a great view over the city. It's also nice you can walk around on top of the castle walls and even get into the towers. You have to pay an admission fee to get in, but it's well worth it in my opinion.

Nice Castle in Lissabon. The kids really liked to run around on the narrow walkways on top of the castle walls. It has a nice wview over central Lissabon but can be a hardwalk up the hills. We tried to get the tram but it was really packed, you need to get on the tram at the starting point!
A park on top of a hill. Nice views and a great place to just chill out in the shade on a hot day in Lisbon. Not very big, but worth a visit for sure. Just remember there's an uphill walk.

experience worth trying. The castle is beautifully restored. If you are not afraid of heights you can walk on the ramparts and have beautiful view over Lisbon. The walk from the centre to the castle is very steep and it is better to take the bus 737 from Rossio (it stops right in front of the gate to the castle) or the picturesque tram No 28. There is a camera obscura in one of the towers and it is worth trying - the guide shows you the city, explains where is what and tells a lot about the history (it takes about 20 minutes) - it is certainly very interesting. The presentations are held every half and hour and in different languages. Take good shoes, as the old stones are quite slippery and stairs steep.

Lovely Views, But Just a Castle. The view is incredible, no doubt about it. That said, there are other locations in Lisbon you can find a majestic view of the city (a few lookout points). It is neat to walk around the Castle and climb through the walls, but if you've been doing Europe for a while (or in my case, just spent a day in Sintra), it can fall a little short--it's just a basic castle. If you do decide to go, the line is long but moves quickly, but watch out for the guys trying to gift you "gifts" like jewelry... as with most things near tourist spots in Europe, it's one of those "Now was gift do you have for me..." scams.

Essential part of Lisbon visit. Well worth making your way up through the old streets to this moorish castle, if only for the views of the April 25 Bridge, Christ The Redeemer statue, rio tejo and Lisbon city centre from the ramparts. Reasonable admission and we didn't feel as if we were in a tourist trap.

First real castle ever!. Get your hiking shoes on because from where the bus drops you off, you do need to walk up hill to this site. Once you get there, you are going to be amazed! Walking on the castle walls is awesome. On the day that we went, there was music down in the town that wafted up the the parapets and it just made the visit seem so realistic. We went to the archaeological site and viewed the ancient part of the castle. Coming from the USA it is really cool to be able to see and touch history.

Good but not great . While this castle had some neat aspects, I didn't have as great a time here as I had hoped. We were here with our two kids (ages 3 and 6) and I think walking up here from downtown was probably our first mistake as it was a hot day and we arrived rather sweaty and bedraggled. As a result, more walking around in the heat seemed more like punishment than privilege. Taking the tram would have been a much smarter option.There was lots to do and see including climbing up the castle walls for some great views. Just remember to wear good walking shoes because the steps are steep and narrow and flip-flops just ain't gonna cut it!There is also an interesting experience where you can get your picture taken with a bird of prey (ie: falcon).A must see but take the tram if you really want to enjoy it in a non-sweaty way.

Spectacular View!. High on a hill, getting there requires a taking a good hike or riding one of the city's quaint trams. A helpful pamphlet comes with the entrance fee.The castle offers wonderful views of the city and an opportunity to learn about the city's history. There is a small museum and restaurant on site. Good walking shoes and about two hours are recommended.

Amazing place, very beautiful and romantic view of the city. This place is amazing. I fell in love with the view of the city. Very very romantic. The visit can be also educational if u visit some of the exhibitions inside the castelo. I literally spent there maybe more than 2hours as I couldn't get enough of the view from different angles. The neighborhood is beautiful as well, so reserve at least half of the day to discover this part of the city.

Worth it for some. It took me a month of living in Lisbon before I actually went into the castle, and when I finally did go it's because I was with a boy (ooh la la) and it was his idea. And it was lovely -- because of who I was with. Great view, cool spot to hang out, but I would have been bored on my own. With a wealth of castles in nearby Sintra, solo travellers should get their fix there instead.

Fab views & history. Make sure you take Tram 28 early morning for the experience of its journey winding up to the castle, the hill's a bit of a climb. Ensure you know which stop to get off or you'll be coming back down the hill?We took the tram Martim Moniz and got into the castle midweek at 10am with 2 people in front buying tickets. Coming out at about 1pm queue must have been 70-80 at least. We were able to get excellent photos around the site unhindered by jostling visitors.One word of caution, some of the steps & railings up & down from the ramparts are a bit precarious, views are worth it though.

Nice and relaxed. Worth the money. We spent over 2 hours in there just walking around, reading the little booklet you get at the entrance and admiring the amazing view. Nice light weight history. It's not the best place for strollers or people in high heels.. The steps up to the view points are high and steep but not a problem unless you are really afraid of heights. They also offer that you can hold an owl or an eagle (mainly aimed for the younger ones).
Neat castle, great views. This is a really neat old castle built on even older ruins as it was the strategic high point from the beginning of civilization. Amazing views from up here.
Great view of Lisbon. This is a very interesting historical site with an explanatory museum, but it is worth the visit for the spectacular overview of Lisbon!

history..... walked all the way up to the top of the castle. the view when you get upp is all worth it, u can see the city of Lisbon, the color(houses) and the water(river) just amazing. a lot of history. old stores and old restaurant, people are so friendly. so relaxing.

Must see in Lisbon. It's a hike to get up the hill but worth the walk. Good presentation of the history of the castle and the different groups that settled the area. Definitely a place to bring a camera with a good telephoto lens. The castle is well maintained and has a cafe on site.

no no no and no again. Urghhhhhhh....do not attempt to walk up the hill of torture unless you are fit. I'm not unhealthy but I was nearly sick by the time I reached the top. The reward for my effofrt was a swarm of tourists, workmen renovating stuff, tacky souvenir shops and traffic every where. I didnt go in so I suppose I shouldn't really be commenting...there were a couple of viewing areas around but be prepared to be hassled by bead and water sellers. Stayed for about 15 minutes and then got an old tram down to the terminus at estrala..go and see the basilica there and have a wander around the park. Basilica shuts at 1pm.

Stunning Views. If visiting Lisbon, this is a must! From the road at the bottom, we walked up the winding streets and when we got to the castle, the views over Lisbon were absolutely stunning!!! I took sooooo many photos!!!! You can walk right up the towers if you can manage it, the whole experience was amazing!

Well maintained Castle with great views. After reading all of the reviews that called this castle a waste of money, just an empty old castle etc, my family spent the rest of the trip saying "ahhhh, just a bunch of old rocks. Just an old church. Just some boring old monastery" for the next ten days. People are so weird.This is a great castle, with wonderful views of the city and we thoroughly enjoyed it. Until we went to Sintra near the end of our trip, it was my 15 year old son's favourite spot as it was his first trip to Europe and his very first castle.Yes, you have to pay to get in. This is how these places are maintained and, as a tourist, I came a long way to see Portugal so I will happily pay an entrance fee to see well kept castle perched high above the city.

Cool on a hot sunny day. Couple of great cafes for a spectaculsr view whilst enjoying a glass of white port on ice. Its a lovely walk around, about an hour, more if you stop and sit, its that kind of place.

great historical landmark. we spent around 3 hours in the castle. very attractive place- walking up on the fortress wall, relaxing with coffee and local desserts in various cafes, exploring archeological sights, amazing viewpoint on the river and whole city! very good photos of Lisbon from there!

Great view and fun for the kids. An elevator, hilly walk and entrance fee takes you to castelo de sao jorge. It's a great view and you can climb further up the towers, if you don't have mobility issues. My 8 and 10 year old climbed up without issue but I was a bit freaked out watching them because the old stairs are uneven heights, slippery and some without rails. But, we survived and got some great photos. The kids loved running around playing knights and regretted that we didn't pack their armor and swords. (If you take the elevator up, take note of the great grocery store pingo doce, for all sorts of snacks and ready made food.)
Lisbon's must see. In my opinion this is the most beatiful place in Lisbon. A lot of things to do. Beautiful view, museum, castle, archeological site for one price.

One Of My Favorite Sights in Lisbon. St. George's Castle is definitely one of my favorites sights in the city. The views overlooking the city are pretty cool and the castle itself is fun to explore. We hiked up to the castle from the main pedestrian street which was somewhat of haul, but it was definitely worth it. Overall the castle should only take a couple hours of your time, but it is time well spent.

Nice attraction but a bit pricey.. Nice attraction with stunning views of Lisbon, but to be honest for the price it was not worth the entrance fee. There is a museum at the castle but the site itself lacked any great detail on what each of castle ruins were so most of the time we had no idea what was what. It was very difficult to visualize it in a time when people lived and worked there. I also thought the 'take a picture with a bird of prey' attraction was a bit gimmicky'for such a historical site.
Great View. The view of lisbon was incredible and it was fun to see the castle and learn a little about the history of lisbon
Castelo de Sao Jorge. Brilliant views overlooking lisbon. When you arrive at the base of the castle, please note that there is a short, steep hike to get in! But totally worth it!

Expensive option for city views with many free options nearby. It was once free to visit the castle but nowadays there is a charge of €7.50 for the dubious privelidge of viewing the city. There are spectacular viewing points at Graca and Largo do Portas do Sol which cost nothing, have cheaper cafés and are less crowded. It's notable that Lisbon residents have free access to the Castle, as they would laugh at the idea of paying into a ruin. If pushedf I'd say that visitors can walk along the castle walls, although there are similar experiences to be had in Sintra and Sesimbra which cost nothing. All in all this falls well into the category of rip-off tourist-trap.

Just the Walls and a Phenomenal View. It IS indeed worth the visit. Pick a day with clear skies and wear your tennis shoes. While the castle is not there, the walls are there. It is fun to walk around. We had a port wine tasting event there. The view of the city is stunning. Afterwards you are close to other sites and the neighborhood is worth walking around.

Fabulous view. Some people told us that there was nothing to see at the castle, but I disagree. There are lovely views over Lisbon & it's a tranquil place to have a coffee in the shade. Walk around the site & visit the archaeology. Take the bus from Rossio square.....or brave the uphill hike.

Fantastic view over Lisbon. It is worth visiting the castle simply for the fantastic views it offers over Lisbon. We spent a long time walking around the outside of the castle enjoying the views. The castle itself is pretty and you can climb up it and walk around the top. The castle is also located in a pretty area of Lisbon, high up at the top of some small winding streets - it's worth getting the bus up and then walking back down.

Worths a visit. Very well preserved, there are a lot of things to see around. The view is astonishing, and very well organised (view plans etc.). You have to que in order to see the 3d plan (only 20 places starting every half an hour in english afterwards spanish and finally portuguese). There is a self service cafe inside the castle. The ticket is reasonable compared to what you see.

Best views of Lisbon from this spot!. Simply put this was excellent. Great that you could walk the length of the castle walls. There was lots of exploration. There are restaurants there too. We went close to closing time so it was practically empty but we also got to see the sun setting. Of all the viewing points in Lisbon this is definitely the best one!

Go in the early evening to watch the sunset!. It's hard to find the right path to get here and the walk uphill will leave you winded, but this is a must-see. I recommend going later in the day - the weather is cooler, there are fewer people, and the sunset over Lisbon is spectacular. There's a restaurant inside that serves sangria by the jug - cheap (7 Euro) and delicious. Don't limit yourself to just the main viewpoint - go inside the castle itself and climb the castle walls (we were the last ones there!). I wasn't expecting much, but the views absolutely blew me away.

Stunning Views. We hiked up to the castle (and it is a bit of hike up steep, winding streets) but have to say it was worth the effort. The views of the city were beautiful and the castle offers plenty to occupy a couple of hours be that sitting and taking in the views, looking at the archeological excavations or climbing that bit high atop the castle walls. Worth a visit!

Must-do in Lisbon. This castle has a lot of values: Lots of splendid views over the city and the Tejo River, and a history that goes back to the 11th century. If you want to learn about the very special history of this corner of Europe - with influence from both the North and the South, this is the place to go, but go early in the day. The area around the castle is very touristic and in my opinion not very interesting. It's the castle that counts! :-)

Awesome views. If you visit Lisbon, this is one of the required places stop by. The castle is part of the important portuguese history and you have the best views over Lisbon and Tagus river from this place. The gardens are also very nice. Its a bit like Italy w/ too much tourists, but its quite normal for one top touristic attraction!

Visit the castle area via the local No 12 or No 28 tram. I didn't want to see inside the castle - so saved my money - and enjoyed the local Alfama area instead. You can catch the charming, canary yellow, "mini-me" No. 28 or 12 trams from a stop in the inner-circuit. You pay only 2.85 Euros to drivers good at liaising with worldwide tourists. Same price no matter where you get on or get off. Remember you must pay again if you exit and wish to ride again. [Don't spend your money on the expensive tourist trams doing the same route!] Excellent panoramic views, a visit to the Decorative Arts Museum (4 Euros - allow under one hour), lovely handmade craft shops near the castle entry, friendly open air restaurant for a delicious lunch, checkout the art installation at the back of a nearby cafe featuring thousands of silk flowers arranged on the derelict brick remnant walls, visit the beautiful church five minutes down the hill from the castle. Talented saxophonist & guitar vocalist played several tunes during lunch "busker" style. The tourists cheered as a dark haired bride with theatrical glamour makeup exited her limo and joined her young, stylishly groomed and "model" handsome blond partner for a society wedding at the richly decorated church. A special day on many levels

Living history. Lisbon's castle is a monument with a millennium of history imbued into its stones. You'll find a mixture of islamic and christian influences there, at the same time being shown one of Lisbon's most amazing views.

View from the top. I cannot believe those reviewers who say it's not worth it - after all, how often do you get a slice of history which such panoramic views over such a beautiful city? If it's humdrum to you, I'd love to live in your world! Apart from anything else, it's quite relaxing to be up there and take in the views and atmosphere, you can have a glass of wine or something to eat, after having climbed up the stairs to the top, and enjoy being in another world. Perhaps combine your trip with a visit to the cathedral as well and if you choose to do this late enough in the day, you can maybe hear some Fado on the way down. Tickets are 7.50 euro each and there is a free map available in different languages. If the weather is hot, do go early as the queues can be very long, and definitely take a bottle of water too. Definitely wear the right footwear and be advised the castle isn't suitable for wheelchairs or those who have trouble walking. There are also some nice (but expensive) gift shops on the way down, which sell some slightly unusual things.

I don't even have words it's not worth!!. We went to alfama flea market found so many good stuff & we were so dumb to go by trip advisor reviews cut our trip short! & went to see this dumb place which is nothing but views from top? People really need to know how to rate places since genuine travelers do depend on this review on short trips!!!

Enjoy it. Been inside the castle, makes you feel on those ancient times, great view, of surroundings , city and from there you can chose where to go, just point the place and go.. Nice place, it's quite expensive fee to get thee but have to doit, don't know what they do with the money because don't looks like they take care of the castle... Have fun!!!

Best views of Lisbon and Alfama district. The Castle per se was quite ok - it was quite large and well maintained. The Miradouro at the castle has great views across the city and Alfama district. The place is worth a visit if you have a Lisboa card - you get a 30% discount on the entry fee.
Spectacular View...worth the effort . Hills are quite steep but worth it for the fabulous view! Was quite peaceful when we were there. Not very well sign posted though.
Interesting history. We enjoyed the views from the castle. The castle have us a glimpse of history. You can walk the walls and climb all the towers.
Great old Castle to explore. Up on one of the hills, great views from the high walls. This old castle is made for exploring. Really good value, low entrance fee. Well worth a visit to look around.

Great views. It's worth the trip. Walking is uphill and can be steep in places. Alternatively take the tram to the Miradour and walk the 10 minutes uphill. Views are of all Lisbon and onto the estuary and bridges. Walls are good but not much left of actual buildings inside. Wear comfy shoes as much of the outside floor is cobbles and/or uneven.

A great castle with lots of history. A Moorish built castle, later a royal place, this castle has a wealth of history and an array of ancient buildings to explore and visit.It is very well preserved in parts, with archaeological excavations in others, and it is easy to spend a good few hours exploring all that it has to offer. A walk around the fortified walls offers impressive views over the castle grounds.As the castle is also on top of the highest hill overlooking Lisbon, the views from the promenade around the castle allow you to see right over Lisbon and out towards the Tagus river and down towards Belem. It was a sunny day with clear blue sky when we visited and the views were amazing.Entry was 7.50 euros each, but there is a lot to see once inside so it was well worth the entrance fee. The cafe was also not very expensive, which was a bit surprising given that it is a major tourist destination.

Incredible view. It doesn't cost much to get in and is totally worth it. The view is stunning and it's so peaceful up there when the sun is out. The ruins are fun to walk along, but be careful you don't fall when you're going up the stairs to walk along the walls.

Great views of the city. This castle is worth a visit if you are a history buff and to see the views of the city. It is a steep climb but you can get close to it by taking the historic tram #28 and get off at the bottom of the last part of the climb. Lots of courtyards and open spaces and rampart walls at the top. Great views of the city. Most interesting was a fat cat sunbathing while seated almost upright and peacocks that roamed the castle.

Climb is worth it for the View. A trek to the top but there are a few cafes on the way up if you cant do it in a one .Beware the Looky Looky men as you make your way up as they are very persistent and dont give in easily .Once there you can run about the ruins to your Hearts content and it is a must for photos of the whole of Lisbon city and the Tagus and you will want to take lots and lots of photographs .You cant go to Lisbon without seeing it but as a native of Edinburgh nothing on this Earth compares to it but in saying that Lisbon's is great for the view

Amazing views and cosy courtyards. This is the main castle in Lisbon, and is on top of a central hill (you can see it from many of the central areas). As you might expect, you get stunning views over all of central Lisbon and the river, and it is worth walking up here just for that.We walked through the winding roads to get up to the castle, but if you are very unfit or overweight, you might want to catch the bus instead as the roads are very steep. That said, the street life is great, and there are plenty of cafés or restaurants where you could have a stop-off on the way.You could also grab the #28 tram to relatively near the castle, and walk the last 10min or so.The entrance fee of €7.50 (€5 for under 25) was reasonable, and although there was a big queue to the ticket office (which is across the road from the actual entrance) it moved swiftly along.Once inside, the castle mostly consists of a couple of courtyards (shaded by trees), and the fortified walls - which you can mostly climb up and walk on top of. There is no real indoor area or elaborate castle interior - you simply come here for the view and the walls!In terms of amenities there are several free toilet blocks, and a cheap(er) café and a more expensive restaurant - though I wouldn't bother with either.

Well worth a visit. One of the best points of interest in Lisbon.You can climb up or you take a mini bus in a very narrow route,very enjoble the park full of lovely peacocks colorful some of them on the ground or on the big trees.The views of Lisbon and River Tagus amazing.

Castle grounds were wonderful. We had a lovely time exploring the castle area. The walk up the hill is not near as bad as you might think from reading some of the information. Great location for pictures

A long walk for a fort. There is a very long, steep, cobbled and uphill climb to get to this site. There are very nice views of the city and the river with great pictures to be taken.The castle itself is not very impressive compared to other sites in the Lisbon area that are spectacular. It has a simple open courtyard and several stairs to get to an upper level walk-around. It's more of a fort than a castle. The walk to get to it is not any easy one and it doesn't boast amazing architecture but it is an inexpensive fee for Lisbon views with great pictures.

I enjoyed the castle very much.. It was a very winding road that led up and down. I was with a local during my trip to Lisbon. So I don't really know the ease of traveling here without access to a car. It was interesting. But not necessarily a must do.

The climb up the hill.... St. George's Castle was a pleasant climb up the hill although you can take a tram. The view is fantastic and worth the time and energy. Some interesting history of Lisbon, Portugal.
Amazing views. Well worth a visit for the stunning views across to the bridge and the christ statue and all of Lisbon

Didn't really care for.. We made the long journey up to the castle and found that it wasn't as impressive as I thought it would be. It was difficult to walk up and there were a lot of stores and shops there. I also felt the admission price was a little much for what it was.

Not enough information in English. We had a hard job finding the large castle on the hill as there are no signs until you get to the very top !! When we did find the ticket office the staff were helpful . The grounds are lovely with the peacocks roaming around , the cafe is quite basic , though all we wanted was a cold drink so this was ok , the restaurant looked very good though we did not check out the prices . I was looking forward to the archaeological ruins, quite impressive but not enough info when we we in the actual areas . But all in all a great 3/4 hours roaming around

A medieval place with a lot to see.. One of the bests points of interest in Lisbon. It as a beautiful view of the city and there was a lot of animal inside that gives a strange and nice sensation of come back in time. A medieval place very important in the story of portugal with a lot to see.
What wonderful views of Lisbon and River Tagus. Well worth a visit. Lots of peacocks and peahens - and even baby ones to be seen. The climb up is well worth it

Mostly Just Walls and Views of Downtown. We took tuk tuk to top of hill since we didn't want to wait for bus. It was nice because he dropped us off at ticket booth. 7.5 euro to get in. Mostly consist of just walls at this point. It is large and high at points with great views of downtown. We walked to archaeological site area and honestly I think that could be skipped. I think taking your time you could see everything in an hour depending on tourist traffic.(To Travel Is Too Live)

Interesting fort with magnificent view. The ancestry of this old historic fortified citadel can be traced back to around the 11th century. The structure is a lovely way to spend a few hours walking around. The view over Lisbon is one of the best in town and should aptly be described as magnificent.

Great Views, Not Exactly a Castle.... I wouldn't call it a castle since all is left from the castle is the layout of it. The walk up is a bit tricky because the building "disappears" from your view depending on the street you're in but getting lost and finding little stores selling souvenirs is part of the charm I guess. Once you get there, there's a small museum with pretty much nothing in it and some walls still standing up but you're gonna need a lot of imagination to get an idea of how the castle must have looked like. At least you know it was big since it occupies a really big area. You can go up some stairs and walk around to one of the towers but it's a bit dangerous and the steps are very steep. You can also see what's left of some houses built just outside of the walls of the castle (cross the bridge to the main entrance and go to your right, follow the signs)Look around for what seems to be the official pet of the castle, a peacock walking around freely with its babies :)

Picturesque. This is a worth while attraction to visit. The cost was €7.50 each for an adult. The walk to it is very enjoyable all in the old part of Lisbon, many shops on the way, most with a lot of the same souvenirs. Many little restaurants to stop for a drink or a bite. The view from the top is amazing, you can see all of Lisbons roof tops and water, beautiful! We spent about an hour and half here. There is also a small cafe inside the castle walls with limited items and drinks.

Terrific in the late afternoon!. This is a great place to visit in the late afternoon when the water of the Tagus sparkles in the sunlight and you can enjoy panoramic views of the city. Enjoy a hike up through the narrow cobbled streets of take the 737 bus from the central square at Rossio. There is so much to see as you wander along the walls, visit the archaeological site or museum. If you have a Lisbon card, you get discounted entry. When you have finished your exploration of the Castle, find the artisan Icecream store around the corner and enjoy! Best Gelato in Lisbon!

Nice day out but lacking in some areas. We spent half a day walking around and looking at the castle. The walk to it was very nice and the area surrounding it is lovely. It's €7.50 each for entry which isn't too bad. The views of the city from the top are worth it on its own. The castle and ruins are good and nice to walk around. There is a museum and a cafe. We found a lack of information about the place. At castles around England there's always plaques and information on the walls as you are walking around telling you about the place and it's history. There were none here. In the museum were some information boards but they didn't really go into any detail apart from saying what each item was. That is a disappointment but I certainly wouldn't say don't visit as it is a nice place and worth half a day.

Great views & worth a stroll around the castle and surrounding area. The entry fee proves great value. From the castle you'll have impressive views over the city and access to the castle itself. There's a nice little cafe inside too. As others have said, the surrounding streets are well worth a stroll too.One thing to note is that the walls of the castle are quite low and some don't have handrails so I would be cautious with small children.
