Nice views, Castle and Museum miss-able. The Views are good from up on Soa George, but really not worth the taxi and entry fee. It does have a nice relaxed feel about the place if you are seeking a relaxing place to sit under the shade of trees. For families it is probably a good spot. The cafe and Museum are seriously lacking.

Great views of the city. There is a stunning panorama of the city bellow, but other than that, there's not much to see inside. The walls can be climbed and walked on, but the we've expected much more from it. There are also a couple of beautiful peacocks, graciously 'posing' for the tourists. The full ticket price is 7,50 EUR/pers.

Nice view of the city.. Its worth a visit for the nice panaromic view of the city. We took the tram up the hill through some old neighbourhoods and walked to the castle. This way its only some minutes of uphill walk, however it will be through the old living places of elites. Try to be at the castle before 16:00 to have a chance to visit the camera obscura with English guide at 16:00. They will serve the first 20 visitors per session and the guide gives a brief desctiption of different places, sites and neighbourhoods via the panaromic camera obsecura.

Well worth a visit. Well worth the 7.50 Euro entry fee, fantastic views and photo opportunities, a cafe, museum and very interesting ruins to explore. You can climb up onto the battlements and towers, a great attraction with lots of history, fun for all the family. The streets surrounding the Castle are also well worth exploring, lots of little shops and cafes

Great views, castle not much. Well, when you're on the highest point of the city you certainly expect to have great views! The castle itself was not so great, but it was still fun to climb around the walls and to see the panoramas of Lisbon.

Outside peak. *We did not pay to go inside the castle*That being said, we did make the climb up to see Sao Jorge Castle. The climb up allow really nice views, passed by shops and takes you up to a small area of restaurants and music. That alone is a great reason to check out the castle.

Fab castle, brill views, good price. The first thing when you arrive at the castle is that the ticketing system is a little confusing. You buy a ticket (around 7 Euros each) from a kiosk on your right hand side and it looks like the entrance is by that - its not. You have to continue to walk up the hill and the entrance is on your left hand side. Once inside, its got lovely garden area, a small but interesting archaeological museum, small archaeological site and the castle. The castle is great as you can walk on the tops of walls giving you brilliant views of Lisbon. Def worth the fee to get in. We didnt try the cafe/restaurant but there is one if you want it.

Wonder point to have great view. It's in a hill of the Lisbon city and easily to be access by city bus 737. Inside the castle the ground was not so flat so you have to be careful not to tripped by the rock or gravels. THe view from the castle is wonderful, you can see the squares in the city, the ferry to Cristo Rei, the bridge of Apr 25th and Cristo Rei so it is wnoderful to go up there and enjoy an afternoon time.

Beautiful view. I was staying nearby and could see this beautiful old castle from the window of my room. After an inclined walk through the narrow streets of old Lisbon we reached the main entrance. Beautiful views from this castle. Nice (pricey) restaurant in the castle. There is also a kiosk at the entrance to buy some pastries (including a nice pastel de nata) and soft drinks. Nice grounds.

Simply Gorgeous, wonderful scenery and memorable landmark!. Easy accessible by using the city elevators and short walking distance to Castle. Antique and beautiful sights all around the Castle. The wine that is typical to their region called Ginja (sweet red wine) poured in a chocolate cup is also simply a delight at the Castle's café. Can easily visit lower and higher levels of the Castle and an unforgettable view of the city and its surroundings.

Superb view of Lisbon. Don't get fooled by the many lifts in the city that claim to offer good views, just walk to the castle and visit it. The view is simply stunning and the castle itself is a great way to spend a few hours in this wonderful city. Also, don't forget to check out some of the many bars on the way down!

Best views. The views are amazing, almost a 360o of the city, with emphasis on the historic center. Definitely a "must see" when in town.Be careful in the surrounding areas because this is especially known for "pick-pockets" since it is highly touristy.

Every town should have a castle. The castle is probably one of the best maintained examples of Roman History we have seen in terms of buildings. Everyone talks about the views which are amazing and provide opportunity for great photos. It was fun to walk/climb around the walls. It gives you a good understanding of life in ancient times.

Great Views and good fun. Definately worth it.We took the 28 tram up which was cramped and bumpy and stopped a fair walk away from the castle. Walking back down the hill to the tram stop we found an escalator attached to a terrace bar. We werent sure if it was for a car park but actually if you go to the lowest level it drops you right down into the town centre and its FREE!!

Great Views of Lisbon. With a long walk straight up the hill, we decided to use the two elevators to save the legs. We lucked in that our hotel was around the corner from the first elevator. The second elevator is in a grocery store. A small walk uphill at the end was not too taxing given that one of our party had a bad knee. Long lineups to purchase tickets, however once in the area is large enough that you do not really notice the crowds. The castle itself is OK...nothing spectacular. Having said that, there are very scenic views of Lisbon and if worth the visit.
Great views, nice castle. That pretty much sums it up... A very nice place to hang out and enjoy the views, a shame there's an entrance fee, otherwise I'd probably go back a few times.

Great Views, Well Preserved.. The castle sits atop a hill overlooking the bay. From the scenic overlook you have a great view of the square, one of them, the bay, the main bridges in town. You can also enter and climb the walls of the castle and enter several of the towers. If you have any fear of heights or impaired mobility you will not want to try either. The walls are narrow and feature no railing of any meaningful kind. There is no lift to the top. This is not a palace. This is a fortress so there is no residence to tour or interior of any serious sort. It is walls, towers and that is it. There is a small museum that is about 90% broken bits of pottery recovered from the hillside that will hold only passing interest to any non-specialist.

Fabulous view of the city. After the 7 story elevator ride, and then the very steep walk to the top of the hill after that, you are rewarded with spectacular views of the city. Although, as far as castles go, it is just average. There is nothing particularity special which makes it stand out over all of the other castles which we've seen. But again, the views are great. So for that reason alone, it's worth the trip up the hill.

Fantastic viewpoint, and well preserved stone fortress. This 11th century stone fortress is a must visit location in Lisbon. The first thing that hits you when you pass through the walled gateway is the amazing panorama across Lisbon. It is a great place to start your visit to Lisbon, to get your bearings for the city.The fortress is very well preserved, and again offers countless viewpoints, and great locations for taking souvenir photos.The museum is a little stuffy, but does have some interesting artefacts. The Islamic ruins are brought back to life with a contemporary, but tasteful twist.The castle is a little pricey to visit, but given the amount of time we spent there, it felt good value for money.I would suggest you arrive early to beat the queues. Also the city is beautifully lit first thing in the morning. Though I suspect watching the sunset from the castle is also a pleasure.

Great views of the city!. Went here with some friends during a 7 hour layover in Lisbon. It was about $10 to get in but well worth it. The grounds are huge and they are 360 views on the whole city. We climbed up the ramparts which were a bit steep and narrow but well worth the effort. Loved the silence and the views of the city.

Brilliant Views. The castle is in brilliant condition and offers excellent panoramic views of Lisbon. Although situated at the top of the hill I would recommend either walking down (or up!) as there are some lovely restaurants along the way.

a must starting point of the trip. or a nice way of ending an afternoon. know some history and how at one time this grand city protected themselves from invaders. enjoy the views and walk your way down Alfama. Entrance fee is quite high but it's worth it if you like history.

Beautiful sight with Peacocks too!. This castles was such a beautiful sight. On the top of the hill overlooking Lisbon. Bring student card to receive a better rate upon entrance.The castle contained a number of beautiful peacocks.A man and his cats played music that fit the ambience of the castle ages.A must see in a Lisbon,

Getting there was part of the adventure!. Just get off the On and off bus and you're here? Not nearly...We're glad we asked a local police woman in the square and she asked how are you getting to the castle. We looked confused but she said we needed to jump on an antique, wooden tram (#12) after buying our tix from a gambling place. The trip up to and away from the castle on the (#28) was a wild mouse ride thru narrow streets that just skimming by a number of homes. That being said, we safely arrived and walked from one end of San Gorges Castle to the other to the accompany of a flock of Peacocks and a talented Fado guitarist in a courtyard. Our visit was topped off at the beautiful outdoor cafe' overlooking the city of Lisbon. This was another "high spot" in our Portugese adventure! The Brady's USA

Well worth the climb. Either walk across from Alfama, catch the fuinicular or a bus. Anyway, make the effort, the views from the top are amazing. The castle itself is a bit bare. But there's plenty of room for everyone to spread out and the views are really what you are after!

Good fun, great views. Either walk up and enjoy the windy uphill and sights, tram with the ever crowded E28 or bus, or (as we discovered only about 3 days later), along Rua Dos Fanqueiros and Vitoria there is a huge sign “Elevador Castillo”. Take this free lift up to “B” – upon reaching this level on Rua Dos Madelena, go left about less than 10 steps across the road, you will see a supermarket in a building – walk towards this free lift and go up the top of this lift. Once up there, go right and keep left uphill towards castle – less than 8 minutes and you are at the castle at the top! We did it the hard and tough way walking all the way as the tram and bus were full. Great views from the top to the castle from Convento da Graca but even better (almost 360 degrees) views from the park of Largo Monte (from Rua Damasceno Monteiro). This has views to the airport, new town, old town, bridge, statue of christ, Convento da Graca and St George’s castle – all in one! Toilets below are also very clean.The castle itself is interesting. Of course there is a fee - can't remember but something like euro 8.

Dont miss! Really cool place!. As a travelled, I have seen castles and palaces and this one is really cool. It doesnt have any palace rooms or anything. We were outside climbing up and down the walls getting amazing of the city. I dont know why its so low on trip advisor. I would put this in my top 5 things to do in lisbon!

castle st. George well worth a visit. After reading several negative reviews, we weren't sure if we would go to this castle. But after reading a better way to get there, we figured we would give it a try. First of all, don't take Tram 28..The tram is too small, too crowded, therefore most people are standing up, and there is not much to see on the trip. Yes some of the streets are very narrow, but...... and then you must walk up to the castle. Better to take bus 737 from Placa da Figueira, it takes you right to the door! The castle and grounds are beautiful, well kept, with facilities, cafes etc,and incredible views of the city, and just delightful to leisurely walk about. Beautiful peacocks to see as well.

SAINT GEORGE'S CASTLE (CASTELO SAO JORGE). During our ride on Tram 28 (Graca), we realized we were passing near the Castelo Sao Jorge (Saint George's Castle), a very neat looking castle we'd seen at night up on the hill. We got off at the end of the line and started walking, looking for the castle. After wandering around in the general direction, we almost accidentally found it and paid our 7.50 Euro entry fee. Although not as neat as the Castelo do Mouros in Sintra, it was still pretty cool. We stopped at the castle's cafeteria for a couple of pastries and coffees. Here is where I met my 'friend', the female peacock. She was one of 3 or 4 peacocks wandering around loose, and I think the only female. She apparently noticed that I had food that she wanted, and proceeded to beg by snaking her neck up near the table where I was eating. I think I made a mistake either by giving her a couple of small pieces of my pastry, or by not continuing to do so. When I didn't offer any more pieces, she decided she'd jump up almost into my lap and snatch a mouthful on her own, almost taking my hand with it! Oh well, it was an interesting experience.
The views are World Class. All of Lisbon can be seen from the Castle. You will not be disappointed. If you have limited time in Lisbon, then make this a priority.

From begining to end is stunning.. From the walk to it, the arrival, the site, the view, the archaeological sites, etc, this site is worth a visit. Ideally would be by taking the tram (No. 28) to the area and then walking to then walking up, stopping by a restaurant and having good food while listening to a fado singer. What an unforgettable experience.

Worth the Views. It's sometimes hard to muster up the excitement to see yet another European castle, but this one is worth it. Situated with beautiful panoramic views of Lisbon, it's within most travelers ability to reach by foot but I'd recommend either the trolley or a taxi ride up and a leisurely stroll back down the hill when you're done. Plenty of little cafés and restaurants along the way and be sure to check out the residential area just outside the castle walls. Looks like some lovely accommodations are available there too. Also be sure to pick up some souvenir stuffed animal sardines, a Lisbon tradition, on your way back down to the city.
A great historical site and view of Lisbon.. Excellent view of the waterfront and Lisbon from an 11th century castle originally built by Moors. Beautiful grounds - great for taking pictures.
Great view. Highly recommended simply for a view of the city you get. Bit of a hike to get up to it but isn't overwhelming at all. You can also take a cab or streetcar as well.

History & fantastic views. The castle is situated above the town but the walk up the hill is well worthwhile. The castle itself is very historic and interesting but the views over the city and the Tagus river are just amazing. There is also an excellent restaurant there too. Definitely a must do if you visit Lisbon.
Only the view. The whole place is just walls, walks on the walls, a small archeological site and 2 coffees. But the view of the city is worth for the ?7,50! You can see everything everywhere.

Nice Ruins!. Nice ruins in the city of Lisbon if you have good knees for climbing stairs. Views are spectacular from the top of the Castle but otherwise there is nothing to see. Walk up the hill can be brutal and beware of pick pockets on the free Tram 28. I found it better pay for the yellow or red line which went by all the sights so I could have a seat on the bus. You can also take a taxi.

Amazing piece of history. Easily catch from public transportation this castle offers you a wonderful piece of history with an amazing views of the city, river and close surroundings. Just pass through or sit and relax in the shadows of old trees and "catch" the historical atmosphere...

THE place to go in Lisbon. A beautiful old castle on a large hill, overlooking the rest of Lisbon. You get great views form all along the battlements. I do wish there were more historical exhibits referencing the castle's past, but that's just me. I did the brave thing and walked up to the castle from the city below - it's a hike! Best to take a taxi or a tram and then walk down. Just make sure you go down through Alfama; what a beautiful district!

Great views of the city. This was a great castle to just wander the grounds. There are great views of Lisbon from various points. Our boys loved wandering along the various walls and getting lost exploring. You'll want to get there by car, but afterwards it's a fascinating walk back down through the Alfama.

Great Views. The castle was quite interesting and was in a real pretty setting. Not too much in the castle museum but the grounds and walls were great to walk. The views of Lisbon from the castle were super. You buy the castle tickets at the ticket office but the entrance is about 100 feet up the hill and on the other side of the road. Didn’t see any entrance signs but just followed the crowds. Do not walk up to the castle – take a taxi up & walk down.

I bet it was better in 1755 - a bit disappointed. Apart from good views we were disappointed. They need to spend more time and money on the experience. You can't keep blaming the earthquake of 1755 for an average location. We needed a better experience than just wandering around battlements looking down on the city. Compared to other castles around Europe this lacks a lot of history and stories. An audio tour should be provided. We have been spoilt in Rome and Athens.

Fantastic views of City. Castelo S.Jorge is a fort over-looking the City. Before reaching it you have to go up then down then up again on very steep roads but well worth the effort. The Castle has many interesting things to see, cannons, statues and an archaeological dig site and is well worth a visit. The views are wonderful. Entrance fee was cheap - 4 euros for Senior Citizens.

If you have time, then OK, but don't prioritize. There are so many things to see and do that this didn't really rank very high on my list. It's on most top ten lists to do in Lisbon, but having seen other castles, especially in Sintra - skip this, focus on the other sites in Lisbon, and do a day trip to Sintra instead.The highlight I think is not the actually castle but the views from the observatory area, but you can get similar views for free from a lot of different areas including the hill top near Barrio Alto. That's free and has the same type of views for the most part.The castle grounds is basically a cafe and a restaurant... with the castle. There are the ruins you can go see in the back but if you are into that, then go to Italy where there's more to see.Walking around the castle, be forewarned that if you can't climb stairs then I would not suggest bothering paying the entrance fee. There are steps to get to the top of the guard towers. It really is "a shell". I expected what other castles I have been to where they had replica things on the walls and historical items - nope. Just the castle walls.So, if you have time, then add it to your list, otherwise Sintra!

Fantastic views. Worth a trip for the views alone. We walked as it isn't,t that far but the hill is steep in parts therefore if you have mobility issues get a cab as this will be the easiest all round. En-route we passed Lisbon Cathedral which is a wonderful old building. Nice coffee shop at the top of the hill to rest after the steep hill.

Best views in Lisbon! . It is quite a hike to get to the castle, but it is the worth the effort. The site itself is well maintained and you can explore almost everywhere, but it is really worth it for the views over the rest of Lisbon. You can take in the Baixa, Barrio Alto, and Rossio districts while also getting a good long distance view of the 25 April Bridge and the statue of Jesus. Take the time to explore all the castle's nooks and crannies for a variety of view points.

Tranquil and evocative of times past. The castle is prominent over Lisbon but getting there is a challenge. Forget the tram and bus as queues and traffic are impossible. A taxi is easy and cheap and takes you very close. I imagine the queues must be terrific at times as it was a most inefficient process both to buy tickets and then enter through the turnstiles. The site is remarkably under-signed but with terrific views over Lisbon and the harbour. The restoration of the fortifications emphasises the stronghold that Lisbon was. It was a pleasure walking around and enjoying the views. The site seems to be well tended with no litter, peace and quiet and very good toilet facilities. But you may have to avoid weekends and holidays! Beware that the peacocks don't try to share your lunch at the cafe.
Amazing!. What a wonderful castle! We would definately recommend visiting while you are in Lisbon - the views are amazing!

Beautiful views of the city not to be missed!. We took a bus to this gorgeous castle above the city of Lisbon and paid the 7 Euros to get in. Was it worth it? YES! I feel it was a great way to see the city from above and it was also unique to be able to climb around on a real castle. Views, views, views. I sound like a realtor, but this place should be your starting point if you plan to visit Lisbon! We walked around for over an hour taking photos and just enjoying the vistas of the downtown and the harbor, as well as the bridge and surrounding hills. Then we joined the Sandeman's New Lisbon free walking tour and saw the important sites around the city itself. For having one day in Lisbon, we really feel we maximized our time and will absolutely be back to see this gorgeous city!

THE city view and feel ancient times. There is no better 360 city and bridge view of Lisbon. It cost 7 euros but its worth it. The challenge is to find the ticket office 30 meters down the hill in an alley!

Nice views. This is exceptional for views over the city and deserves the trip (walk up the hill). We were charged €7.50 each and was reasonable Note if you get the Yellow Bus pass ticket 4 in 1 you can get 20% discount by asking and showing your ticket.....
Fantastic view!. It brings you back toward very historical moments of Lisbon.The restaurant in its walls is beautiful and impressive for its décor.

Stunning views. A must do in lisbon. Stunning views and worth ever 7 euros. Loved the man on the whistle and bells - really set the tone. stunning atmosphere near the castle with fab buskers and small market on a sat.

Wonderful view over the city, nice surroundings. You have to find where to pay the entrance fee, From the entrance It´s down the road to the right at some brown banners on poles , leftside of this road. De lux restaurant in castle building.
Wow, great views!. Enjoyed most of an afternoon walking around the castle grounds and taking in the fabulous views. I would definitely recommend comfortable shoes as there are a lot of stairs!

Wonderful views but now you have to pay for them. We hiked up to the Castle for the view but got there to find a long queue and an admission fee. I lived in the area some years ago and we would go up to watch the sunset and watch the old men playing backgammon in the park for free. We decided not to queue and went for a coffee. In a week in Portugal the cafe outside the entrance was the only time we felt we had been ripped off - 6 Euros for two average coffees.If you are willing to queue and pay the admission then it's well worth going for the view but don't be caught out by thinking the park is free.
Must-see!. The perfect place to sit and enjoy the view of Lisbon, being able to walk the old castle walls gives a 360 degree view of the city. A must see in Lisbon!

Well-worth the views from the top. No matter where you stand along the walls and ramparts of the castle, you're guaranteed to have a breath-taking view of Lisbon. You're allowed to wander around most of the castle, but it's not much more than a vacant stone structure. The cafe's outdoor seating is nice and keep an eye out for the very friendly peacocks. Overall, it's a must-see in Lisbon just because it's so prominent and immense, but don't expect to spend too much time here.
Best of Lisbon. In my opinion the most interesting site in Lisbon, very nice monument, ancient walls, good views from the city center

Magnificent view of the city. There are a few great view points dotted around Lisbon, but this was one of the best. The castle is not THAT impressive, but certainly worthwhile taking a walk around. Loads of great photo opps.

Worthwhile view or the city. While theres not much to see on the inside, the outer fortifications are certainly impressive. The walls are high and completely accessible, they made for a good walk around the perimeter. There are several watch towers open to the public as well which make for a good chill session. Best to go when sunny to best enjoy the gardens.

Wonderful castle with magnificent views of the city. This is a "must see" if you're visiting Lisbon. You can see the entire city from here, and the castle itself is well-preserved (much is reconstructed, I grant you), with lovely grounds and a small cafe that serves light meals and a really great apple cake. Get your tickets early in the day-- the lines stack up quickly (we got there about 9 and had no wait at all)

great views.... The Castelo is a 'must see' place when visiting Lisbon according to all the guide books. The walk to get there is great, the peacocks are beautiful and the views are fantastic! The actual Castelo...well, I must admit I was not overly impressed by it. It seemed that a lot of it had been reconstructed and I almost felt like the Castelo was not historical but instead built for tourism. There is an entrance fee and some people would say it's worth it just for the view but you can get great views from other parts of Lisbon for less or free!

Wonderful castle with great views of the city!. My daughter and I really enjoyed the castle. The views after you enter the castle area are spectacular. The castle itself is unusual. Be sure to visit the archaeological site which as the original foundations of the castle. The castle was destroyed in the 1755 earthquake and later restored. It's still a great site and the views from the different sides of the castle are simply stunning. There are peacocks on the grounds which make for fun picture taking. Some guidebooks are less than enthusiastic about the castle but if you like castles, you'll definitely like this one. This castle has no furniture (although it has a museum with archaeological findings); if you want a more Versailles experience visit the castle in Queluz.

Very nice place. We visited the castle (entrance fee 7.5 euro) and we liked it very much. From there, there is a very nice view of Tejo river and of the city. There are stone arches and stone benches, and stone bridges etc., and nice little gardens, where peacocks stroll about. I recommend it.

Nothing special. The view is great and you can walk all around the walls which is quite nice but doesn't really justify the entrance ticket (I suspect I might have enjoyed it more in nice weather, but I'm trying to be objective in my review!). There is a small museum and some sort of older ruins, but there are no explanations (I think you can probably buy a guide book for it but I usually prefer not to). I kind of feel like I "had to" go as it's one of the main attractions, but at the same time I wonder if I could have done without......
Best views in Lisbon. This had great views of Lisbon. The castle is very old dating back to the 11th century but is in great shape. This is a must see on any trip to Lisbon.

Amazing Views. We visited in April, if you have a Lisboa Tourist card, remember to show it at the Ticket Office as you get a Discount. The views are fantastic from the Top. Be aware the paths are rough and if you are unsteady on your feet, you may want to consider your footwear. There is shade in the trees & a small cafe bar inside the castle grounds. The streets outside the cafe are narrow and steep as you would expect. So use the local bus service to get to the top. A nice relaxing visit, but we were out of the main tourist season, I can imagine in the summer months it can get extremely busy.

Castle with a view. We walked and took a rather unconventional/unintended route to the castle, and found some fascinating wall art of photographs of the local older generation. Once at the castle the view is fantastic and the walk around the castle walls well worth a visit

Not happy. Very disappointed with our trip to the Castelo. With no prior warning and a long walk up the hill we were met at the gate with a sign saying the workers were on strike for the rest of the day. Lots of angry and upset tourists and rightfully so.

A must in Lisbon. This is one of the sites of Lisbon that are definitely worth seeing. Most of people take the tram 28 because it is one of the oldest and because the road goes up to the hill. However, if you can, I highly recommend doing it on foot. It is about 20 minutes from Rossio square and you walk through nice little streets with cobble stones; you’ll have plenty of opportunities to take nice pictures, including of the trams going up and down the hill… The castle is rather large and you have an opportunity to walk on the ramparts all around it (plenty of pictures to be taken there…..) I also enjoyed the 30 minutes visit of the ‘camera oscura’ (at 10:30am for English); they bring you to a dark room and use a telescope to show you live images from Lisbon surrounding the castle. It is interesting and informative as the guide explains a lot about Lisbon’s history. Little advice: when you get to the mirror position yourself on the side closest to the entrance to have the best and most complete view of the city. While walking around the castle, make sure you spot the peacocks for a nice picture. On the way back down you’ll have the opportunity to buy local artisanal products that are unique; just passed the Cathedral there is a very nice shop selling all wool products (clothes but also fridge magnets and other things. It’s definitely worth a visit!!)

In a sunny day!.... This castle is probably the one with the best scenic view!....An amazing place to visit when you are in Lisbon, use that time to walk across the surroundings and the old part of Lisbon.....
To the Lou . I was impressed by the place and especially the urinal outside was spectacular! No que and fresh and clean! Verry expensive on the - side

Great views, incredible history. First off.. Walk up to the castle.. Experience the neighborhood.. Take time to see the Alfalma and take some incredible pics. Great pics to be had from the entrance to the fort overlooking the city. Walking through the castle, along the walls, up and down the stairs... Great first hand historical experience. Ancient ruins can be visited too. Can't stress enough all the great views from all sides of the castle... Decent cafe to eat at also... With peacocks all around.. Great way to spend a nice, sunny day

Best view of Lisbon.. After a two hour hike through Alfama we finally got to the Castle, and we were not disappointed. It has the best views of Lisbon and beyond. The old stone walls are still in very good shape. You can climb all over the walkways around the walls and get a good feel for what it was like to defend the Castle. There is a small food court and rest rooms, and if you are lucky, a peacock will perform for you.

Castle splendor!. We heard from our hotel that this place was expensive but thought we would try it since it was close and because if you had a dinner reservation you could get into the castle after it closed. Boy did we hit a home run! Our meal was delicious from start to finish! the wine sommelier, Stephan was knowledgeable and very nice. He did NOT try to steer us to an expensive bottle of wine but one that would fit our taste and it was delicious for 30 E. Hard to find that at home for that price point. My husband did the tasting meal and was very happy with the choices guided by the waiter as we wanted to try local Lisbon or Portugese fare. After having dinner, we walked outside for a nice, leisurely walk around the castle and took pictures of the city from the high view of the castle. It truly felt like we had our own castle! the meal was not rushed and like most places in Europe, you have to ask for the check to get them to bring it. Our hotel concierge tried to discourage us from going saying it was expensive but we thoroughly enjoyed the food, quality, atmosphere and felt our meal was much better than at Zambeze which is where they steered us the first night which had the worst service i ever encountered. If you visit during the day, you won't believe it at night!!!!

Great views over city. Worth a visit for the views. Camera obscura only takes 20 people at a time for a 30 min show - time of next show displayed on door of the room. Stay off the ramparts if you haven't a head for heights. A slightly albino peacock gathered the biggest crowds. 30% off the €7.50 entry fee if you've a ticket from a bus tour (we took a red bus tour from Marquis Pombal).

Not to be missed if visiting Lisbon. We took the tram up to the stop nearest to the castle. Very pleased we did as the roads leading up are very steep. The view from the area around the tram stop was worth the trip in itself. Entrance to the castle was a very reasonable 7 euros 50 (with discount if you have a Carris -open top bus ticket). The castle is basically a ruin but with extensive grounds and fantastic views over the city from almost 360 degrees. Wouldn't be easy for anyone with limited mobility, as to get the full impact of the views it necessitated climbing up steep steps onto the ramparts.I would imagine that it would get busy in the summer season but there appeared to be plenty of places to stop and enjoy the views, may positions under the shade of trees. Well worth taking a picnic and just taking time to soak up the views. Everywhere was spotlessly clean, including the public toilets.

Must do site. We had a great scenic trip on the tram up to the castle vicinity. Kids loved the cannons spread all along the castle walls with great views over the different regions of Lisbon and across the Tejo. Very scenic and enjoyable walking up towers and along walls. Archaeology exhibit (Nucleo) interesting artefacts. Archaeological dig not as interesting - not much info/no "life" in the exhibit.Not much information on the site other than in pamphlet guide from entrance, but still well worth the visit. Our kids loved the moat where they could lie down - lots of kids/teens rolling down the grassy hill of the moat.Cafe and terrace bar were cash only. Cafe food overpriced. Sundowner drinks on terrace were well worthwhile. Awesome views over Lisbon. Restaurant didn't open until 7:30pm which was too late unfortunately for our family when you added in the time back on the tram to home.

Panorama you cannot beat. For us the view of the city was worth the admission. Not much more to the castle other than well preserved walls. Reccommend getting there early, around 10 to beat the rush. Taxi is a great way to get there is you cannot get tram 28.

Great panorama and funny show by peacocks. t is very nice to walk on the walls of the castle and admire from all over Lisbon. Breathing history through the trenches , slits and guard towers . Around the area of the restaurant and bar there is a community of peacocks which safely pass under the tables and, how sparrows or pigeons do, they feed on the crumbs and leftovers from lunch . The male peacocks make a lot of noise from the more points you high and proudly show the wheels of their feathers without any fear of the proximity of humans. Inside the Castle and ' possible to book to get into a "Dark Room" which is projected the vision of Lisbon at 360 degrees in real time through the use of a periscope installed on top of a tower above the projection room . The show lasts over 20 minutes, but take heed to the behaviour of the speaker because as we could only attend to the demonstration in Spanish, at the last minute, and although there was a majority of French people and others willing to listen in English, she has decided to speak in Portuguese, disappointing!

Great view of the city and way to relax. Took the Street Tram up to the Alfama and wondered upon the castle. It is was early morning so no crowds and felt the place was only for me. Upon reaching the castle entrance, there is a nice terrace which have great views overlooking Lisbon. The interior contains the old Walls of the Palace which have stairs to the top for additional great views. Not sure if it would be better to visit at sunset for sunset view over Lisbon, but morning view is great as well. Would recommend walking down from Castle back to the old town and stopping at the Cathedral.

Pretty views, walking on walls, not much else. This castle was the one thing in Lisbon that I really wanted to do. And it was good, but not as good as it could/should be. It's in such good repair, if it had a proper guidebook, audio tour or signs depicting castle life, it would be 100% better. It has none of those.n You're just left to the walls and your imagination. Worth a trip, but don't get your hopes up. 7.50euros for adults, children under 10 free.

Worth the extra time. On the moment, seven of us from our group of 27 decided to leave our group behind and take the E1.80 bus from Figueiro Square to Castelo de Sao Jorge. I'm glad we did! In addition to the often mentioned great city views, visiting the castle and vicinity takes you into neighborhoods and mixes you with locals and tourists. After taking our city photos, we walked to the other end of the castle and climbed the ramparts for even better views. When we were hungry, we found the little café and enjoyed sandwiches, chips/crisps, and ginginja in chocolate cups. As we ate on the tables outside the cafe, peacocks and peahens wandered around us. At one point, one of the peacocks decided to show off his plumage right in front of the café door. Just to make sure we noticed, he shook his feathers and tail periodically. A peahen made friends with one of my travel mates - I hadn't been so close to a peahen before I so was able to admire her beautiful feathers and eyes up close. All in all, a wonderful way to spend a sunny afternoon for E7.50 plus the cost of the food.

Great views of the city. Not much to see on the inside of the castle walls, but you are free to walk on the walls themselves, as well as around the perimeter. A few cafe's on site, nice to relax on a sunny day with a beverage. Amazing views of the city no matter where you are on the castle grounds. Peacocks roam the castle area, very beautiful to see. Original canons are seen throughout the Castle, also original arches, doors, and ground stones. 7.50 Euro admission and there is a free Portuguese speaking tour at 1600. Many shops/restaurants/ice cream outside of the Castle's entrance/
Another nice view. Definitely worth the hike up (there's also the tram, but they were way too full). Nice place to walk around and enjoy the view. The museum is small, and not that interesting.
I love this Castle. In 1347 our King Afonso Henriques took this castle from arabes, is the Lisboa fundation. It´s very interesting and have a 360º view on Lisbon

Fantastic view !. Good value for money. Lovely panoramic view of Lisbon ! Great for ambling around the ruins.
Would def recommend.

Cheap to get in and good views. Spent a lazy 4 hours there, it has a reasonably priced cafe inside and lots walls to walk around, Ignore the reviews about taking the no28 tram, its not that high and also Lisbon has a great system of elevators built into the hill to save your legs, these are free!

The most popular place for visitors in Lisbon!. This is "must see" place for visitors in Lisbon. You'll have the most beautiful panoramic view all over the city and bridges connecting Lisbon with its neighbors. You can also walk on the walls to get the best feeling of historical castle. While walking there, please do not miss an observatory of Leonardo da Vinci.

Beautiful view of Lisbon. It was sunny when we visited the castle at early March. It was very windy, but the view of Lisbon is breathtaking. Given it's located probably at the highest point of Lisbon, it has 360 degree view of the city. It was fun to walk on the castle walls. The archeology site was interesting. I like the way they built a simple walls that represented the building structure of the time. It gave me a good idea how they looked like hundreds years ago/ Unfortunately, there isn't too much else to see inside castle.

Pricey enough but you get the best views in Lisbon. The point of visiting here is basically for the views but they are quite staggering and the castle grounds themselves are pretty extensive and it's pretty fun to explore the whole place. it might be a little bit pricey for what you get but when you compare it to skyscraper viewing decks in other cities where the views are indoors or behind a grating and cost at least double the price, it's more then worth it.

It's all about the view!. Having heard so much about the castle, naturally, we had to go there. I was a little unsure at first having herd there's nothing really at the castle and yet you pay 7 euros 50. Anyway, we made our way on the tram and followed the steep hills. We arrived around half five in the evening and the sun was at its peak. There is a teeny tiny ticket office..be sure not to miss it! The huge bonus here was, although there were a fair few people there were no que!Up more steep hills, round the corner, through the ticket barrier and...Ta-dah! There is lovely Lisbon laid out in all it's glory. The first view you get is of the bridge and the Christ the King statue which is just spectacular! Have a good look around all of the castle although be warned....there are some VERY steep steps and rocky paving at some points...walls are also very low! I suppose essentially they have just used the castle as a way of climbing various levels to get good panoramic shots, however if you like architecture it's probably a very good building to explore. The castle grounds are very nice to walk around. Is it worth 7 euros 50? Probably not in reality but....the views make you forget all about that. The price does slash by about half if you are a student, child, older person etc so don't forget to mention these things/bring your ID cards with you!!

Fantastic views. This wonderful old castle is worth the trip to see the view over Lisbon as well as the remains of the castle and subsequent archaeological digs. There is also a museum and cafe with peacocks and peahens. take the time to climb the walls and walk around for even more stunning views. Could get very busy so we went early in the day, walking to the Cathedral first and then continuing up the hill to the castle, getting there just after 10am. The walk only took about 15 mins from the cathedral and we found it easily. There is a small entrance fee but it is well worth it. We spent about an hour and a half there. Afterwards we walked back down and found a lovely bar , Zanzibar, where we had a drink on the terrace admiring the view.
The best views in Lisbon. Fantastic views from the castle & student price, about €4 to get in. Picnic seats available if you want to keep costs down.l

Lisbon's dominant landmark. All the time you spend in Lisbon, your eye will keep being drawn to the Castelo de Sao Jorge, perching on top of one of Lisbon's highest hills, so when it came to a sunny Sunday morning, it was time to satisfy the urge to climb the hill, past the Se, to see it for myself.The route isn't particularly clearly marked, so watch out for taking the wrong road - in short, once you have passed the Se, you'll pass alongside the tram tracks for another quarter mile or so, then you'll need to head straight up hill once you reach Santa Luzia. It's a bit steep, but there's a handy outdoor urinal if you need a toilet break en route!If you're not up for walking, the tram will take you most of the way and there is a bus as well.The ticket office is just across from the main entrance - all very straightforward and you're given a helpful map of the site as well.The views across Lisbon from the ramparts are typically excellent for a castle in this sort of position - accompanied by the remains of the cannons that once protected the city.There is a permanent exhibition inside the main castle building itself, which is a bit limited, as well as a decent cafe, which is patrolled by several peacocks and peahens, some of which will almost certainly decide to make a bit of a show of themselves.The castle keep is also accessible, with some pretty steep ascents to higher levels, some of which are fairly narrow, so watch your step!A definite on your Lisbon itinerary.

Take the tram! Walking recommended for the very fit only!. The castle is in fact a ruin and the entrance fee is worth the price if you enjoy spectacular views and old walls and stairs. A "mature" man, dressed in era-appropriate clothing, plays a flute while dirty cats lie on his coat eating something strange. If you try to take a photo of him, he turns his back unless you place money in his coat. Other than that, there are a few beautiful peacocks and a shop to buy souvenirs (the same items are cheaper in downtown Lisbon). If you would like to see Leonardo da Vinci's telescope you need to buy another ticket and the tour is only available at certain times. We did not want to wait 45mins to enter the museum nor pay more money so we wandered around some more and left the castle to get some hot chocolate in the cafe downstairs. In the streets below, we found many stores selling lace items and the like. I'd suggest the walk back down to Lisbon but not the walk uphill to the castle. We missed the tram stop for the castle and hiked our way up; an awful experience for the unfit but great exercise!

View from top. Don't miss this one for many reasons
Small museum with well displayed exhibits and history of Lisbon
Nice castle grounds
Fabulous views of whole town under tree shade
You can get there by tram 28 or 12 - short walk up
Or take bus 737 right to castle gates from Praca Figuera
Well worth it

Go for the surroundings instead. The castle looks impressive from a distance, but the place is very busy. I would suggest to take a stroll in the surroundings instead and sample some food and drinks in authentic neighborhoods. The great views are available at many other places in the city.

Really enjoyable. Beautiful views and a beautiful castle. Well worth the €4 entry fee for students. Would benefit from a view signs to illustrate the history of the site for those who are unfamiliar with it

Interesting archaeological remains and beautiful views!. While the castle itself was surprisingly small and empty, its main attractions were the views, and the remains from archaeological digs on the site. I would recommend climbing the walls first because from that height the city is genuinely absolutely stunning. You can walk the whole way round the castle as well, then afterwards at the foot of the castle you can see old Roman walls, a small buildings from when the Moors invaded and medieval floors - all outside but very pretty place! Entry was quite cheap - only 3 or 4 euro I think, worth it.

Worth it for the views. The castle itself I think was quite a let down and we wandered through it very quickly. The views over the city however are breathtaking and well worth the hike up from the city for the view.

Awesome place. This is a pretty awesome castle with amazing views of Lisbon. The walk up is pretty steep; however, the reward in the long run is worth it. The museum is pretty cool and has several artifacts. Definitely take the time to explore this place, it's worth the trip.

Nice castle. The best thing about this castle are the panoramic views of the harbour & city of Lisbon - they are spectacular. The castle itself is interesting and it is an easy walk through it. It is not very stroller/wheel chair accessible, especially if you want to walk along the top of the castle or go to the washroom.We tried walking from Baixa to the castle & it is not a well labelled walk! We took a few detours to get there! Take bus 737 from a Baixa and it quickly takes you to the castle entrance.

Wonderful views. This wonderful old castle is worth the trip to see the view over Lisbon as well as the remains of the castle and subsequent archaeological digs. Thee is also a museum and tearooms. There are regular trams (12A and 28) up to the castle as it is quite a steep walk up. There is an entrance fee but it is well worth it and then after your visit wandering through the old streets of Lisbon back down to the city centre.

One Man's Castle.... People get confused by the name "castle". They are thinking of Palace. A Castle was build to fend off overtakers and rivals so it's just stone walls and a big fortress. Things inside the walls that went on where cooking and blacksmithing, selling of livestock etc. And due to the age of such things are really going to be ruins. It's history is interesting, the views are fabulous and it really gives you an idea of how people back then lived inside the Castle walls. A fun trolley ride up and down on the 728E.

Brilliant! visit at sunset. We mainly bought the ticket for the view of the city. We were up the Alfama and the sun was setting so we caught great views over Lisbon. The romantic garden is very pretty and the castle walls are impressive. We must have spent over an hour climbing the walls and looking at the peacocks. It was quite magical. There weren't many tourists at this time either so we were by ourselves on some of the walls. There is a small museum which consists mostly of broken pots. if you are a student there is a discount and it only cost 4 Euros for us to get it. a must if you visit Lisbon!

What more could you want?. Not sure what people are expecting from this beautiful old ruin.. of course there's nothing inside its a ruin. The views are spectacular and the opportunity to walk along the rampart even for a hater of heights like me was well worth it. It only costs 7.50 with my lisboa card only 6.00. There are some beautiful garden areas with sculptures, mature trees, cats and yes peacocks who do indeed steal food from those eating at a very good and inexpensive café within the grounds.I should add it is hard going if you are not so good on your feet and is not really wheelchair friendly. The small museum was fantastic really well exhibited with some great information and the chap in there was very knowledgeable and helpful.There are several ways to get there... by foot (hard work), tram (28E) which doesn't drop you off at the entrance or you hop on a 737 mini bus which runs from Praca da Figueira and which is free if you have a travel pass or lisboa card - it drops you right outside the main entrance and this is the only public transport which does. Then when your done with visiting the castle walk back down the hill and enjoy the craft shops and little bars/restaurants you could fill a whole day just doing this - enjoy..

Good sunset view. St George Castle is easily accessible. u dont have to climb up the hill but using the escalator. this castle was student friendly, as the student entrance fee was relatively cheaper than other attractions. it is really worth a visit.
Worth a visit. Well worth spending an hour or two here especially on a nice day as the views are great, castle itself is ok. Costs 7.5 Euro's for adults

Good views of the city. You can see the castle from all across the city, but be ready to climb in order to get here. We enjoyed the views, but there isn't anything to see within the walls other than the various steps and turrets to climb for a panorama of the city.

Best place to visit in Lisbon (especially on sunsets). The first fortifications on this hilltop are dated up to the 2nd centyru BC, but what you'll see are the fortifications built by the Moors which were taken by the Portuguese in the 12th century and then expanded.  It is truly a walk into history as you'll be able to have breathtaking views of Lisbon while walking through the walls, and it is extremely recommended to visit near sunset, so you will see one of the most awesome sunsets in your whole life.

Wonderful - Make sure you get there!. Lots to see and do. Walk along the ramparts, down to the west tower, look into the archeological digs! Very impressive, with the most amazing views across Lisbon. Don't forget to look up in the trees - peacocks everywhere! Well worth the walk/elevator/tram to get there!

Best part of your travel. Amazing viewBreathtaken sightAnd ... U must visit beautiful beautiful lisbon from this old castle till your trip complete . Dont forget u must walk to a hill and if you have problem for climb those amazing narrow street rent or book vehicle to arrive that beautiful castel but if your joint work correctly go there by walk ...

Fascinating. The main thing on your way there is to be very careful, it is really easy to get lost. In walking distance from the centre of the city and so worth it once you get there! The price is very, very good. The remaining part of the castle is in excellent condition and the best part of it all is that you can go up the stairs in the towers at the corners, walk between them and enjoy an amazing view of the city and a unique feeling of a different era.The cafe next to the museum is great and it has its own special performers, the lovely peacocks! Mind you though, while one of them is showing off its impressive tail, another might try to steal your food!

not that special a place. The views over Lisabona are beautiful, especially when the weather is good. That is only positive point. The visit is expensive for what it is, the museum or the exposition is of no interest. My advice for other visitors is to better visit the museo de coches (museum of carriages) or the pharmacy museum.

Not worth the price. The castle in itself is good and worth having a look at, but the price to go inside was really not worth it, even for the view. There are other places to go to for free with excellent views, and there was nothing else inside. A few peacocks roamed the grounds which was really nice but otherwise just an empty castle.Although the best part was the architectural grounds which date quite far back in time so this was really cool but again they were just walls.

The View. Went there towards the end of the day and with the sun coming down I found that there was something surreal to the place and its 1000 year of history.The cost of the entry is £7 per person and its definitely worth it as you will spend at least 2 hours walking around. Also the view of Lisbon is stunning
Worth a trip for the views across Lisbo. It's worth making this trip for the wonderful views across Lisbon. There isn't a lot to see inside the castle, but it's lovely to wander around.

Nice castle, view the alfama from here!. Definitely worth to visit when you're in Lisbon. Take Tram 28 to reach here and other attractions. The place is quite large, enjoy walking through the castle and you will feel the old charm of the castle.

Great castle. This castle was one of our joint must sees when we got to Lisbon, unfortunately, by the time we got here at 18:00 the views had diminished. We spoke to a very honest ticket Lady and she advised us not to pay and go in as large parts of the castle are poorly lit and there would be no audio tour at that hour.Still, we walked around the outside of parts of the castle and the surrounding neighbourhood and were able to get a great feel for the place.If we come back to Lisbon we will make this one of our first stops.

A beautiful old castle with stunning city views.. Panoramic views of the city in an idyllic setting. A perfect place for a walk or a picnic. The castle is pretty big and there are different beautiful views from every side and level. Also lots of lovely peacocks roaming around.

Castle with good views and ramparts you can walk on. Not normally a fan of castles but this one was great. Good to walk around the edge to view Lisbon below and then climb the ramparts and have another good look round. Lots of people had gone to watch the sunset.Wished we had brought a bottle of wine and picnic to enjoy - the restaurant bar was closed by the time we got off the ramparts.

Long uphill climb but very rewarding. After wandering through the pedestrian streets and squares of Lisbon we made the long climb up to the castle and were rewarded by a spectacular view of the city and of the river. The bright blue sky and warm temperatures made it a very pleasant experience to walk and climb the steps of the castle. I would caution that those with mobility issues would be hard pressed to access any part of the site and I suspect that if wet it would have been a very different visit as the stones would have been very slippery. ur only concern was the location of the water closets as they are located down a very steep narrow set of steps and would be inaccessible to anyone with mobility issues.

Fantastic views. This is well worth the pretty challenging climb up from the centre of Lisbon just for the views alone but in fact it's an attractive location for much more than the views. The history is fascinating and well presented in a permanent exhibition. There are café restaurants and gift shops as well as picnic areas. Really a must do on any trip to Lisbon.

Worth the climb. The castle itself is well preserved considering its age, and the view is great, but walking up the e streets of Alfama to get there is an equally rewarding experience. We payed about 7 euro per person to enter the castle.

Great view!. What a fantastic view. Nice place for a stroll and to drink a glass of wine. We bought a bottle at the on-site shop and got some plastic cups. Then sat & sipped taking in the sun and sweeping vista. It's a bit of a hike up a hill on cobble stone roads to get there but worth it!

Poor pricing policy. Castle is nice, but ones in Sinatra are far better and well worth the trip. Castle has a Greatview of the surrounding area and is an impressively fortified castle. No audio tour available and very little in the way of history on the castle available, which would have made it more interesting San Jorge castle probably got me started off wrong with one of the dumbest pricing policies I have ever seen. They have a family rate for 2 adults and 2 children under 18 for 16 euro. However, we only had one child so we had to pay 19 euro for the three of us. We asked several times to make sure it was correct Also, had nicely written displays in the museum, which were somewhat interesting, but the English was grey lettering on grey background and in some areas they had almost no lighting. We had to use our cell phones as flashlights to read them

Great views of the top. The castle itself is not very impressive but the views over the city are the big reason to come. The Tagus river estuary and the hills of Lisbon make for excellent pictures. The walk up is really nice, either on the Mouraria side or Alfama, as you picture a little of eras gone by.

Highlight of our visit. We were planning on visiting some castles outside the city but because the weather forecast was for rain, we went to this one in the city. Wow. The entry price was high (7.5 Euros) but it was worth it. The view is spectacular and the museum is great. We took the red trolley run by the Yellow On/Off bus company but once we were there, we realized it is close to the city center by foot, but the streets are steep. That added charm to the visit if you have the time to poke around the neighborhoods.

great old castle and fortess. The castle is situated on top of the steep hill has excellent views of the city below. there is some information in the grounds and castle as well as a museum (you are given a free map and guide) You also get a discount on the Lisbon card. The castle itself is a ruin but the area around it is excellent. there is a cafe and souvenir shop. Number one Must visit in city you could spend 3 hours or more here.

well worth a visit. We decided to go there from our hotel by taxi as the walk up the hill was very steep. Once there though it well well worth it. Some relly stunning views. One thing to beware of is the stairs in the castle are quite steep and uneven so be sure to wear sensible shoes!!

Must see in Lisbon. I only had about 3 hours and was able to physically see all of the sites in this castle, but I wanted more time. I would make a day of it and do the full experience (all the shops around it, eat in a little cafe nearby, do the cable car experience, etc). It does cost 7 Euros, but I though it worth it. Definitely save this for a good weather day. If you are able, pack a picnic lunch and eat on the castle wall (there are seats in the wall).

Great place to see Lisbon from.. Fabulous views of Lisbon are to be found from the castle. I also loved how you could walk alongside the turrets of the castle. Make sure to wear good shoes as the stairs are quite steep and uneven and there aren't great safety hand rails for people to use.
Great views and fun for the kids. Great views across the city. The kids could walk along the top of the wall, which they enjoyed. A good attraction and not over priced.

Worth a visit. If you're in Lisbon this is one the places you should visit. Great views and some nice grounds, that's about it. It's a small place with battlements you can walk around, safety is not the name of the game here. Wear sensible shoes and be aware that there's some uneven and lengthy steps to negotiate to the upper battlements.If you're not so young you should be relatively fit to be able to enjoy the views from the upper levels.

Great first stop in visit to Lisbon. It's well worth getting up to the castle nice and early like we did - there was no queue for tickets and we were able to watch the fog lift over the river as the morning went on. Amazing views over the city and a great spot for pictures with castle walls or panoramic backdrops.
Best sight to do in Lisbon. Loved the castle and the views it offers of the whole city. Only EUR 7.50 and was probably our highlight for sights in Lisbon alongside the Torre de Belem.

Worth the walk for the views alone. The last time we visited Lisbon a few years ago entrance to the castle was free however there is now a 7.50euro entrance charge although there is now more to see than before. An excellent vantage point over looking the city (which I guess why it was built there) but do bear in mind, the lanes and footpaths leading up to the castle are on a steep hill, and you have to walk uphill a lot, but it is rewarding when you reach it and stopping off at the various gift shops and galleries makes for a nice break during the walk You can if you wish take the bus or hire a TukTuk. The views from the castle are stunning, however some of the walks along the castles walls and stairs up to, along and down from the towers can be some what difficult for those less agile. A excellent place to view most parts of the city.After the walking and picture taking why not relax outside the small cafe and watch the peacocks parade around and the castle cats chasing (and sometime catching) pigeions..

Put this on your list of must see's in Lisbon.. Its very easy to get to Castelo de Sao Jorge, I used the on/off bus green line. The castle is in excellent condition especially considering it is from medieval times and it has an amazing documented history. There are a series of stairways that allow you to climb up and walk the perimeter walls. The climb is minimal, and if you're not afraid of heights the stair climbing effort will reward you with a panoramic view of the city and River Tagus.

above all the views. The castle itself is of course imposing also with its history and the foundation of portugal. But above all a good reason to climb up here are the views over Alfama, Barrio alto and Tejo with the bridge

a nice walk. these is a nice walk! visiting this castle is enjoyable but also getting to this place is as well, you pass trough many streets full of culture, stores and fado playing all over the place. You can also see that this castle was definitely a great piece of an architecture.

More of a fortress. This castle is more about walking around the exterior walls and gardens with no access to the interior. The archeological museum was interesting giving a history of the site from before the Romans, then the Moors, and finally Portuguese kings. The view is much better from the other side of the old the city because you can see the castle! Take the elevator Justa and see the city view from the top.

Beautiful even on a cold December day. I would love to see this place in the summer. Even on a cold and grey day in December this castle didn't disappoint. The views are wonderful, the gardens with their strutting peacocks are lovely and being able to walk around the castle walls themselves was great fun, again with great views over Lisboa. Together with a small museum and archaeological area there is enough to have a look around to justify the entrance fee (I paid student, so wasn't too bad).

It's a Castle on a Hill. Quite expensive for what's on offer. The main castle is open to walk the ramparts and towers etc plus the grounds are quite nice with peacocks wandering around. There's a small museum with a few artifacts and history and the usual cafe and gift shop. The covered archaeological area was a bit pointless as it's not really protecting much. Nice views over Lisbon but probably not the best parts.

Beautiful city view. Castelo de São Jorge offers one of the best city views, an excellent place to make great pictures and to see Lisboa and Almada (on the other side of Tejo River). The museus has a small but significant collection of objects that help to explain the islamic influence in Portugal and the transition to Christianism circa 1.200 a.C.

Nice view. Really nice pictures you can obtain fm the different walls of the castle.Green territory and funny birds in the local garden.Few caffe are available inside.museum,situated inside was full of foto's and explanations,which was not interesting for us and we by-passed it.reccomended in the good sunny day.You can easy reach it by foot for 15min fm the city centre.tickets price is not match with attraction.
Panoramic views. You get some great views form here and really nice to visit the castle on top of the hill. Lots of nice cafes and shops around the walls.

Great Views. I am partial to old castles. We started out taking a tram up the hill that was recommended by the staff at our hotel. The tram was a horrible experience with thugs kicking and pushing their way on to the tram and picking on my partner and I because we are gay. (They made gay slurs) We got off the tram and walked up the hill. The walk was great! I would avoid the tram, no matter how charming it looks. You really can't get lost, just head up the hill. We shopped, ate ice cream, and took pictures along the way, which reduced to effort to climb the hill.

Stunning view!. We went there on sunset, lovely and big castle. The ticket office works until 17:00, so be aware. There was an obscura camera - nice entertainment (working only for certain hours when the image is more or less clear, we were lucky) - if you dont know: its a system of big lenses pointed over the city, so you can see in details what is happening around the whole city in real time in great details ))

Nice views over the city. Castle is atop a hill so if walking be warned it is a bit of a climb. Buses and trams do go here so if you don't fancy a walk grab one. The transport system is great but a 24hour metro pass for €6 and use buses, trams and funiculars for free too. The castle was well preserved, fab views from the top, peacocks wandering around the grounds, gardens are shady so I guess would be lovely for a picnic in the summer. A few cannons around and also a museum. There is a restaurant here too a bit pricey but I guess you are paying for the view. If you get vertigo or have small children be warned there are some very low walls with big drops around the castle ramparts. The streets around the castle are also nice, lots of narrow winding streets and local shops and bars. Worth a downhill stroll after the castle!

Top of Alfama. Despite the relatively cloudy weather, the top of the tours of St George's Castle were impressive. We had a panoramic view of Alfama, the Targus and even the Christo Déi. Its a really good cultural and historical attraction.

A piece of history in a great city. As a Lisbon resident I'm allowed to visit this castle as much as I can, no fee charged. That is why I came here often and play tourist on my own city.I love taking my kids to walk and learn about this castle and all it represents for the city, as my parents once did with me when I was a little kid.The view is priceless and I recommend the guided visit to the camera obscura on top of the highest tower to have a unique full circle view of the city.

Great Views of the City. This place offers great views of the city and is worth the effort to climb up the hill. a must see for me, there is a lift up this area and worth hunting down even if you don't use the lift the stairs beside it will reduce the climb up the hill considerably

Great view!!. Very nice castle and I would recommend it for someone visiting Lisbon. The view from the castle is great. The thing that bothered us, the castle has really lot of dead ends so we spent most of our time walking, then hitting some wall and then returning. Should be a mark somewhere.

A View to Die (or kill ?) For!. We walked up here through the Alfama and were not sure if there was enough left of the old castle to pay 7 euros each especially as it was only about 45 minutes until dusk. As it turns out, the view at sunset was well worth the price of admission. The Moors knew what they were doing when they chose this commanding location, not only for defence. What a charming spot! Other members of the family explored the castle while I stayed with a tired one, happily sitting on a bench overlooking the city below. The ancient stone walls, the cannons, the olive tress and the sunset over the city were well worth the walk up and the price. Not to be missed!

There is a reason this is considered a "Must See" whenever you read about Lisbon.. I only had a short time in Lisbon, not usually my style to limit myself to the most well known tourists sites but read that San Jorge had amazing views so decided to meander my way up there. Sooooo glad I did!!! Not only was it fun going thru the lovely neighborhoods to get up there but the castle itself was facinating and well worth a visit. As promised, the views are lovely but it offered so much more that I didn't expect. To see the genious behind it's midevil plummbing and structual design, the insight it gives you to the Moor culture with their attention to meditative gardens and private nooks mixed in with a strategicly designed fortresse,well, the whole place was just facinating, And then there's the views. Don't miss it. Also, found the "souvenir" shops in the area to be of a higher quality than most.

FOCAL POINT FOR THE CITY. Excellent views and a great place to get your bearings in Lisbon. We walked uphill which is very demanding and I would recommend a tram or taxi to most visitors. The exhibits in the museum and castle are 'ok' but not greatly inspiring and there could be more modern interactive screens to help capture the interest of younger visitors.

Very nice panoramic view. The castle is easy to reach by tram 28, and once you get there the view over the city is splendid. The entrance fee is 7,5 euros for adults. There isn't much to do or see inside the castle, but it's worth visiting for the view.
Good place to see. Historical place to know the country from inside. Old castle makes you wonder. Great sightseeing over Losbon

Walls and views. This is the mother of all sand castles and snow castles, it is easy to imagine knights and fools and fair maidens. Museum is reasonably sized and timeline helps if you didn't have all the moors and crusaders and attacking Spaniards in the right order in your head. There is a camera obscura but the visits are scheduled and we just missed the opportunity. Views are superb, trees give a nice shadow and sound of fountain adds secluded atmosphere. Peacocks and cats roam freely and add excitement for kids.The archeological digs are probably interesting for experts, for others it is some pits with stones and a signs telling that the lower stones are from older ages. To get to the toilets, walk through museum, turn right just before the shop.

Great visit!!. Loved loved this castle!! Cobble stones, uneven pathways but worth every bit of seeing it. Price very reasonable, even had student discount. It was an amazing place to wonder into another century. To think back on how they protected the castle when you are standing in certain areas was mind boggling. The view was spectacular even though it was raining and very windy. This is definitely worth seeing. You can spend about 1-3 hours wondering and taking in the view.

Beautiful veiw from the park. You cannot miss this castle on the top a a hill in the middle of town. The walk up to the castle was steep and worth the effort. The castle park was the highlight of the visit. Worth the entrance fee.

Great views, lots of steps. As some have written, there isn't much about the castle itself, unless you're a big fan of this kind or achitecture. But the views are fantastic and make for great photos!This is however not suited for people with heart conditions or moving disabilities, since you have to go upwards to reach it and then climb a whole lot of stairs throughout the area. If you're up for it though, you will enjoy the scenery. The only issue as I see it is the group of men who will try to sell you things as you enter, necklaces and bracelets, I am always bothered by that, but you can just ignore them.There is an entrance fee of 7,50 eur and there are signs around Alfama that help you find the castle. Inside the gates you can find some cafés and around the castle there are plenty of souvenir shops and restaurants.

Worth a visit. Located at the top of the old city, the Castelo de São Jorge is a must see in Lisbon. This is really a medieval castle, whose the main attration is the walls and the view. Not much else is displayed in it. Be aware of the climbing. The stairs are very slipery during raining days. Better visited during sunny days.

Great views. This is a castle situated on a high hill in the Alfama district. It is fantastic for people who want to take breathtaking pictures of the surrounding area, plus there is a fairly interesting Iron Age style excavation area, and a small gallery. Unfortunately there isn't a lot else. No matter, as we sat wondering how to make the most out of our visit there, a small cat came and serenaded us with its mewing. I called it Dashiell. My wife called it Bathsheba. We couldn't agree and I fear it may have been a source of conflict between us. Say hello to the cat if you do visit. I'm sure you can think of a name yourself.

Amazing place and view must do while in Lisboa. Best site in Lisboa had a wonderful day exploring this place. From the walk up and down through the winding streets. You can take the tram though we wanted to take it all in and in my view this is the best way. Just do this if nothing else simple as that fantastic.

Beautiful view, exhausting climb. Take a cab! Even the tram lets you out a few hundred exhausting meters from the castle. Also keep your eyes pealed for the ticket office (7 euros). It is hidden away to the right of the street somewhat short of where the entrance is. The view is incredible, but in my opinion, it's not really improved by climbing the walls (I did). The restroom is a bit hard to find but clean and modern.

Great view to the old city. The castle has a great view the old part of Lisbon, however, the entrance is 7€!It's on top of the hill so you have to go all the way up from the downtown area to get the, but once you do, you can relax and enjoy an ancient castle but very weel kept right in the midle of a city!

Beautiful views and interesting museum. We visited the castle on a rainy day but still enjoyed our time. The views are wonderful, some of the best over Lisbon and the museum is filled with intriguing artifacts. You can walk along many high walls of the old castle also. We took the yellow 28 tram up (a tip for people with metro tickets - you can use these on the yellow tram but not the red one which is more expensive) It is well worth the walk down the hill through the houses and washing hanging out everywhere, such a colourful and fantastic atmosphere.

Spectacular hilltop view!. Hilltop citadel / castle overlooking the river Tagus and central Lisbon. Armored knights recreate the feeling of being there more viscerally if you have children. Lots of ramparts to climb. Nice coffeehouse and a group of peacocks and peahens inhabit the gardens along with lots of sun basking cats. It's a bit of a hike, but no trouble if you're in shape. Try to beat the crowds and tour buses for the best experience.

Great views. I used a Lisboa Card for discount. The way up by foot isn't that well marked, pay attention. Tram 28 goes nearby to lessen the walk. The castle has been partially restored and the views over the city. & river are great

Enjoy the view. Take the tram from the center of town, which is in itself a pleasant experience. However, transport will only take you so far, and from there its quite a walk up steep cobbled streets. Still, it gives you the opportunity to take in the local atmosphere, and there are plenty of small shops and cafes where you can stop for a rest. Remember to pay at the small kiosk opposite the entrance before entering the castle grounds. The views are stunning - from the river all across Lisbon. Walk the ramparts, visit the museum to see the ancient artifacts found on the site, and be sure to spend time at the Ulysses Tower. In here there is a camera obscura that reflects - in fine detail - Lisbon onto a large table. Enjoy the peacocks, which are the denizens of the castle. If you intend to climb the ramparts take a sweater, as even on a warm day the wind can be chilling.

Beautiful views for a reasonable price. The atmosphere inside the castle is very nice, you can walk around wandering as much as you like, exploring walls and ruins. A must see are the "miradouros" from which you can see practically the whole city from a privileged corner. Be sure you bring your camera because a lot of things are worth a shoot. A pleasing surprise were the bathrooms, extremely clean and nicely scented.
