Having a coffee inside is a bit expensive for the portuguese standards (1,50€).If you are a student be sure you bring your student ID otherwise they won't give you a discount.

Outstanding city views - A must see. Get out the camera - Beautiful views both within the castle and overlooking the city. Numerous vantage points. There is a cafe and indoor exhibit. Take your time and see all there is to see, wander the castle ruins and stop for a few minutes to let the views sink in.

no doubt - a must. This year it costs 7 Euro to enter the castle. There is not much inside but the views are to a kill. And you can also observe some peacocks pass you by. Enjoy during the day and in the evening.
Historic ruins. This is quite a pleasant ruined castle which you can walk round and also go round the upper ramparts. This is easy to get too just get the 12 or 28 tram

Great Views. We caught the number 28 tram most of the way up, getting off at the Cathedral and walking the remainder. We had purchased a Lisboa card which entitled you to discount on the entry price, I think with the discount the ticket was about 6 euros. The views were great and castle sprawling however although we enjoyed wandering around and looking out of the city it would have benefitted from information boards etc.
Awesome Place to visit!. Typical Lisbon/Portuguese place. Great view from Lisbon, the Tejo river and Portuguese Architecture. Nice mood.

Beautiful view. The view from the lookout point is breathtaking I felt like I was inside of a postcard. This does require quite a bit of walking up steep hills and climbing of narrow steps. You walk walk up to the tower points and look out across people below. This was easily one of the highlights of my trip to Lisboa simply for the views alone.
Great view!. If you want to see an amazing Lisbon panorama, this castle is the place to go! The ruins inside the walls are not so interesting, but the view is great!
Greatest views ever!. The castle itself is nice but the views it offers are mind-blowing. On a spright sunny day the overwhelming light itself is very special.

Great City views. Well worth a trip to this castle. lovely views over the city and further afield. The castle itself is a little bare of features bar a camera obscura. In many ways being there early in your trip to Lisbon allows you to understand the areas from above which isn't too easy from the ground level.

Impressive design. This site is not for anyone who has walking or stair climbing challenges. This castle optimizes a strategic property/location position with amazing architectural design, intended to keep invaders out. It's quite fascinating. The location features the best view of the city.

Great Walk Up Through Narrow Streets. If you are able bodied then do walk up to The Castle through the winding streets rather than by taxi or tram. You get a great sense of the locality that way and feel you have earnt that beer for later! castle is fabulous and great views and pictures can be had. Spend at least a couple of hours up there and then walk down to one of many bars/restaurants available. We went to Restaurant A Mourisca (reviewed elsewhere) and were not disappointed.

Tremendous views. After catching the elevador it was quite a walk uphill to the castle but well worth the effort. The views over the city were amazing. It was a clear day when we went and had some wonderful views. Do make the effort to go.
Brilliant views. Enjoyed a couple of hours wandering around the castle and enjoying spectacular views over Lisbon. Highly recommended.

Perfect attraction- almost whole city on your hand. Above the town, the St. George´s castle is a fantastic place to visit when you are in Lisbon.It is easy to reach by the old and very attractive tram or using your own feet (I recommend you the latter) You can enjoy a breathtaking views from the castle´s fortification, which you will surely keep in your memory for the rest.

Stupendous views. The castle overlooks the city of Lisbon and has marvellous views, ancient trees, an archaeological site inside the walls and a museum that is fascinating. WE walked the walls and visited all the attractions we could. Definitely worth the money.

More to do here than you think. As I have written in another review St George's castle is difficult to find by foot. There are very few signposts to it as you make your way up the cobbled streets towards it. When we did find it we were pleasantly surprised by what was there. There is of course the magnificent view over Lisbon but there are lots of ramparts and towers to walk round, although some of them are uneven and you do need to be careful. You can also see some old Moorish house remains and other archaeological sites. These are a bit away from the main part of the castle but were very interesting. We had a drink at the cafe in the grounds and watched the peacocks roaming around. We spent over 2 hours there and felt it was worth the entry fee.

Cool but could be dangerous.... A trip to Lisbon is not complete without a visit to this castle. It is a little tricky to get to it on foot, but we had decided against taking the streetcar as the queue was quite long. As we were heading up the streets toward the castle, we stumbled upon a sign for an elevator. The elevator is part of a grocery store and car park, but takes you right up the hill. There is a small discount on the entrance fee to the castle with the Lisboa Card. The views of the city are pretty. Watch out for the cobblestones as they are uneven and slippery. There are areas of the castle where you can walk up to the towers and along the walls. The steps are uneven and in some areas there are no railings, as well as very low walls. This is not the place for anyone with mobility issues. Be very careful, especially with small children.

They don't build them like this any more !. A trip back in time wandering round the castle and defensive towers.Worth an afternoon wandering around after negotiating the steep climb up the cobbled street but the lifesaver is the life which makes the last bit so easy. Walking down isn't much easier either!

High on the Hill. Best view of Lisbon and quaint old streets. Good facilities in Castle and a lovely calm atmosphere even though full of tourists. Trams run up the hill but a taxi is cheap and easy too. Our favourite attraction in Lisbon. If you have the energy walk down the hill back into Lisbon and go through some of the lovely old quarter. Plenty of little restaurants to stop for lunch.

Nice view but not much else. We took a taxi up here and avoided the walk up the hill but walked back down after our visit and had a nice time walking through the streets . I do recommend going for a walk in the area because not only is it close to a couple of other sites but also you get the chance to see some local businesses and stop by a local restaurant to eat. The castle itself is alright... it has a nice view from all around. I liked walking up to the higher points and thankfully it wasn't too crowded. I was actually expecting to see more so I was a bit disappointed with how little there was to see. For those who are on a budget, I'm not sure if it's worth the entrance fee but we enjoyed our experience and I do recommend visiting the castle if you get the chance.

By George this is worth a visit. The 773 bus stops right outside the Castle and saves that walk up the hill. Catch it at the SE’ (Cathedral) or get the 28 tram. At 7.50 e each and students upto 25 only 4e a bargain for what you get. Great views over the city, a castle that continues to be restored and a museum which plots the history of it. See the settlements that date back to the Iron Age and other excavations. Walk on the walls and view the different aspects of the area. Allow 2 hours to get a good appreciation of the place. Bars, the ever present souvenir shop, and a restaurant. The little village just outside the grounds has shops, bars and restaurants. An afternoon can be taken up quite nicely with all on offer.

decent view, but that's it. We happened upon the castle by accident after walking through some very non-tourist areas of Lisbon as we got lost heading for the centre,As we were there, we thought we'd stop in, it seemed fairly busy so figured it was worth a look.It's really just the walls left, not a lot to see inside, just fun to walk along the wall-tops, taking in the views. The views are nice, but not worth the entrance fee.

Magical. Castelo de Sao Jorge is beautiful ! The perfect place to visit in Lisbon with a sweeping view of the whole city. There was a lovely courtyard with Portuguese music and a magical atmosphere.Will be back !

A peaceful place with great views. Considering its warlike heritage this is a very peaceful spot with a tranquil garden, interesting archeology, proper battlements and high walks round the walls offering stunning views over the city.
Tale the No 12 tram up from the town to get a first hand encounter with the narrow streets leading up to it.

Perfect Place to Start Your Visit To Lisbon. The castle is beautiful and interesting in itself but the real attraction here are the amazing views over the city in every direction. We came here on our first morning in Lisbon and thoroughly enjoyed it. Looking out over the various areas of the city whetted our appetite for more exploring. It was a very pleasant walk up to the castle , although it is quite steep and the views on the way up are spectacular. I'm not sure that anything would have gotten us as excited to be in Lisbon as spending our first morning here.

The views are good!. This place is a bit of a tourist trap with some very insistent pedlars hovering. I had visited the Moorish castle in Sintra the previous day and this paled in comparison. The labyrinth of streets surrounding the castle are nice. The views from the castle walls are cool. The interior is a little uninspiring and uninformative. The ticket collector was not very friendly. Worth a visit if only for the views.

Incredible views with a great. A good walk that takes you up a steep hill - wear walking shoes and enjoy the sights and sounds of the community as you go up. There are a variety of small plazas, viewpoints to enjoy as you go up. The signage is not great to find the castle - but ask the locals - they are friendly. Once inside, check out the tile maps at the major viewpoint/plaza that label what you are looking at in Lisbon. The castle is amazing - with lots of stairs to climb to check out the site. There is an archeological site with good descriptions of the various time periods uncovered. A must in Lisbon.

Fantastic views. The journey to the top of this castle is a fair way but it's actually enjoyable, once there the castle is really lovely and the views are spectacular.I was so impressed I proposed to my now fiancé at the top of the castle over looking the town, thank you

Definitely worth the visit. Beautiful views. Doesn't need all day. If you arrive around 3pm you can walk around the castle, watch the sun set and walk back to town through some nice little streets with restaurants and souvenir shops. Has archaeological ruins, a nice walk on the wall and a little museum with archaeological artefacts and instruments from the time of the Moors.
Very good view!. Enjoy the views of the city of Lisbon.You pay 7,50 euro fee.It's a open castle, then dont forget to bring your umbrella.There is so craft to buing in the streets of the castle.

Like stepping back in time!!!!!. As many others had said the views over Lisbon are amazing!!!! We visited while the street market was on, they call it the "robbers market" and its full of interesting finds...Back in the days robbers used to come here to sell the items they got, nowadays they still call it the same name. You can hear and smell the local restaurants with the Fado music at night.....Please be aware that the alleys/streets are very steep, so you will have to manage to do some walking in that condition. We really enjoyed visiting this Castelo.

Excellent attraction. On a sunny day, why not wait until 2 hours before sunset and get some great shots as the light changes. As it's open until 2130 then you can see the city light up. Sounds of Fado may waft up from one of the squares, so just enjoy it. There are peacocks to see too.A great place for adults and children alike.

I expected more. Hands down, the view over Lisbon is amazing! The castle and the surroundings are beautiful and clean, yet I couldn't find information about any of the things I was looking at. There was a map at the castle entrance, but once you get inside there's nothing else. Maybe there are guided tours that help you understand a little bit better, but I went on my own. The ticket is expensive for what you get (7 euros if I'm not mistaken). There are tons of stairs, and I didn't see access for disabled people or people with limited mobility. Stay away from this place if that is your case.

Must visit. If you spend any time in Lisbon you should go to the castle if only for the panoramic views. Very steep roads. We were lucky enough to find a parking space not too far away but it's probably best to use public transport.

Very nice, yet dangerous after dark.. This reconstructed castle (from the late 1930's) is one of Lisbon's symbols.You can see it from practically anywhere in the city.Getting to the castle by foot is NOT recommended, as it's a very steep climb. Take a taxi instead.The price is 7.50 Euros per adult (free with the LisboaCard).The views from the castle are stunning, especially if you arrive near dusk or sunset. The entire city is colored with beautiful reds.The castle itself is less impressive once you walk its battlements. Pay special attention to the steep stairs, as the place is VERY poorly lit and the fall from such a height can be fatal.

A perfect setting to play knights and dragons ant to survey the citadel of Lisbon. We spent an idyllic afternoon up here enjoying the views and playing knights and dragons with our five year old. Everything about the Castillo feeds the imagination, from the castle turrets, the view, the cannon, the tunnels, the roman ruins........ the journey up and down on tram 28 was a perfect start and end to the castle adventure. The cafe is also good and reasonably priced. Our one regret was probably not hiring a tuk tuk which looked great fun and we didn't really see again in other areas.

St George's Castle. Good views over Lisbon and well worth a visit. A pity that the tram driver did not announce the destination and we had to rely on a local passenger for the stop, nor was it clearly sign posted when we were off the tram.

best views to Lisbon. There are too much reasons to visit Castelo: the best views of Lisbon, countless passages on the walls and below, great siiting/picnic areas under olive trees, a lot of things to discover. Day or night it is a place to enjoy for adults and children. Notice the peacocks walking next to the walls and sitting on the trees at the end of the days. Listen for a fado music while enjoying the best views. Discover a great exhibition at Nucleo Archeologico. you can easily spend several hours there, you will be surprised by calm and refreshing feeling.

Don't miss the archaelogy dig site.. Plan to spend lots of time here. There is a museum and an archaelogical dig site as well as the castle. The views of the city are impressive. It is blended right in with the hill and the scenery. Really enjoyed this even though the weather wasn't perfect. Hightly recommend.

This will bring out the boy/girl in you. We visited this old castle and I really enjoyed it. (We caught bus 737 from Praca da Figueria right to the castle through the steep narrow streets.) Portugal seems to have a very relaxed attitude to health & safety so when you walk around this castle you will find no safety fences at the edges of big drops or at the side of narrow, steep stairs and this can be daunting to some but to the adventurous among you this is fun. There are some great views out over Lisbon from the ramparts and with a bit of imagination you realise how little there was for people to do back when this castle was built. As a child I would have loved to run around here pretending to be a soldier of old :-) but at my age my wife would not let me :-(

Enjoy the Castle and see Lisbon in 6-8 hours. Buy a 24 hour Yellow double decker tourist bus ticket that also allows free travel on ALL yellow buses or trams. The bus pass can be bought near the Augusta Arch in The Praca do Comercio Square that is not far from the Cruise Terminal. For the Castle take a No. 28 yellow tram and ask the driver for the Castle! Use the bus pass to make two tours. The Tagus tour and Olispo tour, both about 1 hour 40 minutes. Enjoy especially Belem. Happy Touring
Disappointing. Not as interesting as so much else in Lisbon. It's worth it for the view, but expect nothing more!We walked and wandered and saw the peacocks, but didn't find the castle area notable.

Beautiful ruins and amazing views of the city. We walked up to the castle and it was totally worth the energy. The price was quite reasonable (I had a student card so 4 euros, 7.50 for general admission) and the castle was really beautiful. The views over the city were incredible and there were plenty of photo opportunities on some old cannons! The ruins of the castle itself were fun to explore & you could climb up high on the battlements. There was a great archeological area, pretty little gardens, a cafe & some roaming peacocks! Would be a fab place to bring a picnic- really wish we had thought of that. Would definitely recommend as a good place to visit while you are here.

Great Views. Our out of date guide book also said it was free entrance, but it's EUR 7.50.We had a bit of trouble finding it on our first visit and it was also closing as the staff were on strike.However, we returned the next day and I'm glad we did. The castle was built on the highest hill in Lisbon and there are Great view of the city from the towers and ramparts. There's also a small museum within the castle as well as a restaurant and cafe and gift shop. Clean public toilets too. Well worth a visit.

Best sightseeing place in Lisbon and awesome castle. I consider Castelo de Sao Jorge the best miradouro (sightseeing place) as it is placed in a position where you can embrace with your eyes all the sides of the city.The castle in itself is full of history with a fortress where you can walk up to its walls, and archeological excavations, as well as a small museum. Entrance price is not expensive at all (7.5 euro) and you get to see a lot of things, Suggested for a visit to Lisbon

A genuine fortress worth the entrance fee.. Our out of date guide book had this down as free to enter but it is actually 7.50 Euros. There is no point in walking up to the castle and not paying the entrance fee as you need to go past the turnstile to walk round the battlements for the view. Clambering up and down the towers is a pleasant enough way to spend a sunny afternoon for the able bodied. Make the effort to walk to the edge of the site to see the archaeological remains dating from the iron age and Moorish era.

Views. A must visit during your stay in Lisbon. The views of the city truly are breathtaking. Beware of climbing the castle towers. There are some very steep stairs and some unsecured parts. There is also a restaurant inside and a small exhibition of excavated things.

A Definite on the 'To Do' List!. We walked up to the castle, as we love to walk and were fit enough for the task. The view is excellent and there were interesting gift shops and a few artisans, as well as a flute player who added to the atmosphere and made it feel as if you had gone back in time. A great experience and well worth the effort. There are cafes and restaurants in the area.Tips: For all attractions check opening & closing times to avoid disappointment. The Lisbon Card is very useful especially if you are in Lisbon for a few days. We purchased the 72 hour card and it was so convenient for all forms of transports as well as providing free or discounted entry into attractions. It paid for itself and we ended up marking significant savings overall.

A must see. If you cant climb stairs you wont see much.. We spent a better part of the day here. As someone growing up in north america we just dont have authentic castles and this one is magnificient. It has not been modified in any way for safety. stairs are very steep, narrow and low (knee) high walls on the top. If you are scared of heights or cant climb stairs you may want to pass or just enjoy the main grounds on the entrance way. What you see on the outside does not prepare you for the inside which is a museum, a courtyard and then an entranceway into the castle grounds. The views from here are of course only seen from the top of the walls. The courtyard on the ground level does have spectacular views of Lisbon. We walked down to the city square from here, a mile or two and there were lots and lots of little shops and restaurants along the way. Just keep walking downhill and you will find the square and the river. Be warned that the gift shop inside the castle has the same souvineers as outside but at a huge increase in price.

Best view of Lisbon. The view from the castle is definitely worth the trek up the hill. We were warned about pickpockets on the tram to get here, but we took the bus from the main square and had no issues. I was surprised at how much of the old castle is open to those adventurous enough to climb the stairs. Handrails are often in short supply so take care when climbing up and down steep stairs. If you are into history, it's a must. Even if you aren't, it's a lovely place to spend an afternoon and relax.Not recommended if you have any kind of mobility issues.

take a cab to the castle. nice view of the city but not much else. steep stairs with few handrails to climb to the top of the walls. the peacocks in the snack bar area are charming but fierce. beware.

Castle with a View. Stunning view of this most romantic city. Steeped in history, we learned about Lisbon's very early years. We were lucky enough to hook up with a young docent who had the knowledge and enthusiasm to share his passion of the castle. A must see!
Must visit this castle. Beautiful castle with great history of Martin Moniz. Words could not explain, beautiful view of the city at the top.
Must visit this castle. Beautiful castle with great history of Martin Moniz. Words could not explain, beautiful view of the city at the top.
Great Views. I'm not sure that touring the castle is worth as much as the views of the city from the castle walls. It is quite spectacular and great photo opportunities from up there.
History, Animation and Great Lisbon View. A place full of history and a great view of Lisbon. During summer have a lot of events from music, handcrafts etc.

Worth a visit. Last time I had been there the access was free of charge but now costs 7.50 euros, which I think it is expensive. The castle has been renovated but there should be more information for visitors while they stroll along the battlement . You can walk up the hill, but the best way to get there is bus 737 that starts in Praca da Figueira that leaves you by the castle entrance

Great Views. A fantastic vantage point with stunning views across Lisbon and the Tagus river. The site is well-maintained and has good facilities (toilets, cafe, restaurant). Lots of shady spots where you can recharge your batteries after exploring the city. If you don't want to walk up the hill, you can take elevators from the Baixa area instead. The main one can be found on the Rua da Madalena next to the Pingo Doce supermarket.

Beautiful views from the top. The historic castle overlooking one of the many hills of Lisbon, this enormous castle has long lines to enter so be sure to arrive early. Part of the splendor is the view from the top, with some friendly peacocks nearby to strut their stuff.

Great views from the castle. Mostly well kept remains. Not much there but there is a museum with it too. Good place to see the city from and also to befriend the local stray cats :)Not too expensive . . .

St. George's Castle. This is MUST see, what a beautiful place to spend an afternoon, overllooking Lisbon- Many vendors to look at their wares, beautifully restored, walking up to the Castle can be a chore, but walking down and exploring the architechure etc. is wonderful- The people of Lisbon are so kind and helpful- they can spot a tourist a mile off, and are there to make your visit superb.

A beautiful place to visit. This castle is well worth a visit. The views are fantastic and there is a lovely cafe where you can sit out under the trees and look at the peacocks which live there. Delightful.

Fantastic view!. Full of history and fantastic view all round. A must visit when in Lisbon! Along windy alley ways and trams. You will reach this castle. Pine and olive trees complete the picturesque surroundings. Really beautiful location and perfect for photogs ;)

360 degree view of Lisbon. You can follow the wall of the castle for an amazing 360 degree view of Lisbon. The railing is either very low or non-existing to the inner of the castle so you need to be careful. You can buy a family ticket for 16 euro for two adults and two children under 18.

Amazing view. A amazing view over Lisbon and Tagus River. A main attraction and a must see for all travelers !.
We have been in Lisbon several times and always visiting the castle.

Stunning view. This Moorish castle is on the hilltop overlooking the historic center of the Portuguese city of Lisbon and Tagus River. This is one of the main attractions of Lisbon and a must for all travelers!

very steep climb. fabulous castle,great if your on a diet,cobbletones and rocly climb but stunning views over lisbon especially the 35th april which is an exact copy of the golden gate in san francisco
The real deal. This castle is so amazing and authentic, it's not adorned with any glitz or glitter just the way it probably was when it was being used years ago. A must see

Beautiful view of the city. This place is definitely worth the trip. There is a nominal entrance fee, but the grounds and the views overlooking the city and the Tejo river are amazing. Take time to relax in the gardens and have a coffee, enjoy the walk around the walls and don´t miss the camara oscura on top of the wall. They have presentations from opening to a bit before sundown and rotate between English and Portugues presentations.

A must visit to get the best views of Lisbon. Its a treat to walk up to this castle from the main square below. You will see trams going up and down and you can ride one to the castle as well. The views from top on a clear sunny day are the best views you will get of this amazing city.
Nice views. It is worth visiting. Very nice views of Lisbon. Be sure to be protected against the wind that blows hard in some parts of the castle.

A must see place to go in Lisbon!. The castle is located right in the city of Lisbon, apart from all the amazing history it is a scenic site and have 360degree views of the city! We spent a couple of hours there but you could easily take a picnic lunch and soak up the atmosphere and history!

The Guided Tour is a must. We luckily arrived just as the English tour was starting (1pm on a Monday). The tour was educational and thorough and all areas of the site have been opened to visitors. It would be worth timing your visit with a tour if at all possible.

Warning - Pickpockets (St. George's Castle) - please see the photos. The Castle is well worth your visit. My topic is a specific warning that it's important that you protect yourself from pickpockets at all times. They pose as tourists and work in groups. One person spots potential marks by observing what you have (cell phones in particular) and where you keep it. The spotter then gives this the information by phone to two others who will follow you until you reach a vulnerable spot. Zip up any bag, pocket, etc. Always. My wife was robbed in September 2013 after visiting the Castle. We went back a few days later to spot the criminals, observe what they do, and photograph them so that we could warn others. The attached photos are of pickpockets that work in Alfama, near Castelo de Sao Jorge and the Miradoro de Santa Luzia. The one on the phone is the spotter. The three men walking are the pickpockets who follow you and strike when your attention is diverted. They dressed exactly the same way both the day that they robbed us and a few days later. After they steal your phone, they hide it in their back pockets -- you can even see bulges in one of the photos. I've already given these photos to the Lisbon police, but only you can protect yourself from being robbed in the first place. Please share these photos with whomever is going to this area.
Expensive views. Very good views but little else to justify the entrance fee (7.5 euros) Area around the castle very interesting.

nice view and a must see. walking on the big stones and climbing up steep stairs took my imagination to a place in the past that we have only seen in movies... overlooking the river and whole city it is certainly a fantastic location for a castle and even with the vast empty hallways and rigid walls you can feel that someday long before us here lived great people... the hike up might be exhausting especially in the summer so you can take the tram or a tuktuk to the entrance... a young female artist sells her paintings of the city inside worth taking as a souvenir :)

NICE!. When in Europe you've got to visit castles, and this one is a great one to visit. Excellent view, well manicured grounds, and great ambiance. My only complaint is the hills, but for a castle that's the ideal backdrop.The views of Lisbon from the Castle are incredible.

Beautiful Views and Nice Visit. Quite the hike to get up there, even got lost a little bit, but who cares you're on vacation. I believe you can take a tram or bus up there but I was already walking around so I just continued on my walk. I didn't take a guided tour, but had a map and just enjoyed walking around the castle. The views of the city on one side and views of the water on the other are amazing. Such beautiful pictures and I just stood up there in awe. It was raining and pretty windy but I didn't let that effect my time there. Not much to see on the inside as far as decorations so please don't compare it to the Palaces around, its a fortress and a castle not a Palace with furniture. That being said I think its worth the visit.
Nice. Very beautiful, it's worth climbing all the hills to get there! The view is great and the castle is very beautiful as well. It gives you the feeling like you went back in time.
Beautiful views. The views of Lisbon from the Castle are incredible. Just make sure you're wearing your walking shoes!

Nice view but far too expensive. Two years ago it was 5.00 Euros, now it's 7.50. Free for local residents only, still paying for non-Lisbon residents, which is ridiculous. Far too expensive for essentially a good view and fairly uninteresting ruins inside the castle. The view is good, but there are miradouros in the same hill that have the same view, for free.It is quite a steep climb, so if you don't feel like walking up, take the 737 bus from Praça da Figueira and then walk down. Should you not mind walking, I suggest you walk to Rua da Madalena and take the Escadinhas de São Cristóvão (a long flight of stairs that brings you to a churchyard and then walk right along the hill on Rua Costa do Castelo and past Chapitô.

Nice view and fantastic geodesic observatory. The castle is nice but not spectacular, anyway you can appreciate a really beautiful landscape of Lisbon. The geodesic observatory or "Torre do Observatório" is really fantastic, you have to wait for guided visits of 20 people but it's really worthy. The neighbourhood around the castle is very pretty so it's worth to walk it.

Watch The Sunset Here!. Be prepared, if you are on the 'bottom' of Lisbon, for quite a hike. Lisbon reminds me of a very old, European San Francisco.I, unfortunately, did not get to the castle early enough for the guided tour. Instead, we decided to venture upward in the early evening. My wife and I perched ourselves alongside one of the outer walls and were blown away by the view. The entire city is visible from atop the castle and more. If you have a clear day, this will probably be one of the best places in the world to see the sun go down. So, if you're planning a trip, I would advise touring the castle first, and finishing your trip watching the sun set over Lisbon - it's incredible.Other than that, the castle is certainly worth exploring. Lisbon has some fantastic history (ancient history) available for you to discover and experience.If you love castles, like I do, you'll really enjoy Castelo de Sao Jorge.

Surprises - good and not so . . .. The view is a stunning surprise, which made it worth the effort.
Our Guide Book had suggested it was free entry, so the €7.50 each was not so good but glad we didn't turn away.
The Archaeological display was really disappointing, but overall the views made up for it.

Worth the trek!!. Wow, impressive and fun to walk around. Absolutely the best view of Lisbon. Lots of photo ops. The castle is clean and easy to walk around. The tricky part besides walking to the top of the hill to get to the front gates is maneuvering the steep steps so not wise for seniors. Price is 15 euros per person (adult) and you can spend 2-3 hrs walking around. We have seen a lot of castles in Europe and this one was great for the site seeing alone.

Impressive place, great views!. This is an absolute must do if in Lisbon! The castle itself is interesting and all very well maintained but the views across the city and river are fantastic! Well worth the nominal entrance fee and if you can - make the small effort to walk up to it from town.

Great view, nice castle. I think if offers one of the best, if not the best view in the city.It is in a very nice condition and well worth a walk around it.A slight pain to get there, but a tram (usually packed), or a cheap taxi ride will get you there. You can walk as well but its a long walk from the centre. Go there.
Beautiful castle. Very nice Castle worth to visit it. We decieded to walk up to the castle innstead taking the train to see everything else on the way up. Def wort it.

Definite must-see!. I don't know why this isn't a higher rated attraction. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes! It's at the top of a hill, and then you should definitely climb up the ramparts! The views are amazing! Some of the walkways are a little narrow and scary, but definitely worth it. There is a nice garden too where you can sit down and have a coffee. A wonderful place to spend an afternoon!
Another must-see!. A wonderful bit of history and breathtaking views of Lisboa. You cannot come to Lisbon and not see this!

Picturesque and Informative. One of my favorite stops along the way in Lisbon without a doubt. Take the 737 bus (less of a wait than the trolley) from Figueira Square and it is a fun little bus ride through some great windy streets - it only takes about 10 minutes and it takes you straight to the Castle - or walk which may be more fun! The castle has some incredible views of the city and is beautiful itself. My favorite thing is the camera obscura where they have tours every 30 minutes and they rotate between Portuguese, English, and Spanish. Make sure to get in line because only 20 people are allowed at a time! I recommend going to this spot first, seeing the city through the camera obscura, and then deciding where else in the city you really want to go because camera obscura guide will give you lots of info! Also, tickets for entrance are only 4 euros for students so bring your university card if possible!

Wonderful vista from the ramparts. This is a must see for EUR7.50.. you cannot miss it as it sits high on a hill top. You can climb up on to the ramparts (not for those with no head for heights) or stay at ground level under the shade trees and admire the views across the city and the Tejo from there. Perfect for photography. Take the Electrico 28 tram to get there and back as its quite a walk and the tram ride adds to the fun. Once you've been here if you go a short distance further up the hill look for the signs to the Miradouro de Graca which also has a great outlook and a kiosk for coffee or a cold beer
Good views.. Walking to the castle makes the visit a more rewarding experience. Once there walk the castle walls and view all the surrounding area.
Overrated ?. Or maybe it was because it wasn't a very clear day. Anyway, the castle didn't turn out as romantic as I'd been expecting. The best part was the tram ride up and down.

A CASTLE WITH A VIEW. Visit Castelo de Sao Jorge for the views, especially as the sun is setting over Lisbon. You cannot do better. We saw the planet Venus: it was so bright that you could hardly miss it. See the high level parts of the castle before the sun goes down: the Portuguese don’t seem to worry about the hazard of falling off the poorly protected edges of the battlements. The occasional warning sign doesn’t help: clearly not a place for small children or people with mobility issues. The lower level esplanade is fine for all of the family, so don’t be put off visiting especially if you’ve made the trip to the top of the hill! If you take a crowded tram to get up the hill, watch out for pickpockets! Alternatively, the 737 bus takes you much closer to the castle entrance but the road is rough and our driver turned the trip into a white-knuckle ride.

Knights Templar stronghold.. The Castle is obviously located on top of a large hill overlooking Lisbon and the view is wonderful. The fun way to get there from below is to use the tram. The tram can get very busy at peak times, so be patient, but once up there it is easy to reach the ticket area. As usual you must buy your ticket before you go to the entrance and there can be queues again in busy times. The turnstiles are London underground like and only work once, so don't wander back out (which is easy) or you will have to pay again.Once in through the turnstile though you can spend as long as you like there walking around the grounds, taking in the views, visiting the interior of the Castle and its walls and then have a drink and a pastry (avoid sitting under large branches of the trees, the peacocks are quite generous!) The history and explanations are a little thin on the ground so don't expect any in depth education and the rebuilt parts of the walls are of concrete, not limestone mortar so not good for erosion, watch your step! The camera obscura is a novelty and very good for seeing a little more. If you just want to chill out its a great place to be. Oh and you can even have your picture taken with your favourite bird of prey!

Camera Obscura!. The castle itself was cool, nice views, beautiful peacocks. But the camera obscura was awesome! I don't think it's widely publicized, but if you go to this castle, make sure to get into a session of the camera obscura (they have limited sessions due to weather and language restrictions). Most memorable part of the trip.

Worth for the view. It's a nice place to walk to... going up the narrow streets. Maybe at return take the tram (unless it's very crowded... it happens). A bit dangerous to go up all the walls, some guard rails would not hurt.Nice way to spend 1-2 hours, get a nice meal in a restaurant there or some natas in a nata shop nearby...

check out that view over Lissabon. The castle is located on top of a hill. You have a beautiful view over Lissabon. There are old canons and also peacocks running around. a nice garden to walk around. there was also some animation: a knight you could get on picture with.

Great views over LIsbon. Enjoyed this visit very much. Castle not the best I have visited but the views over the surrounding area/city of Lisbon made it worthwhile. Spent an enjoyable couple of hours there.

Guard rail needed on upper level...dangerous!. The view is breathtaking. The castel is only the 4 walls/towers and no roof. There should be railng around the upper level as the walls are very low and anyone, especially a child could fall over. The small garden area was nice with peacocks and their babies.

Magnificent views from St. George's Castle. We visited the iconic Lisbon landmark - Castelo de Sao Jorge castle during our maiden visit to Lisbon on 05-07 July 2013. We had the Lisboa card with which we got 30% discount for entry to the castle which proved quite useful considering the expensive entry fee to the castle costing around 9-10 Euro each ticket.The castle was once a fortress (taken by the Moors in 1147 AD) which explains it's strategic location on a hill top offering fantastic views over the city and the Tagus river. You can also get scenic vistas of the Alfama or the old part of the city and the 25th April Bridge from the castle precincts. The 10-15 minutes journey by the vintage yellow coloured Lisbon trams from Figuera Square to the castle also offers panoramic views of the city. Would definitely suggest as a must visit attraction in Lisbon for tourists.

wonderful city views. The moorish castle provides some lovely views of the city from about 5 different towers. The archealogical museum can be quickly viewed in about 15 minutes. There is a cafe and clean restrooms and a couple of people selling touristy wares.
Must visit. Very old, big and beautiful castle with magnificent view of the city of Lisbon. Not even expensive and offers student discount.

Perfect Spot for Sunset!. I happened to time my arrival just at sunset and it was spectacular! Amazing warm orange light over all of the old castle walls, sky turning pink, then watching the lights turn on in the city below :)

Worth the Hike to the Top. Walking directly from the Plaza below and zig-zagging our way to the top climbing streets and stairs we made it to the top while enjoying the route we took. The cemetery was worth a quick visit too. Look around you and take in the tile work on buildings. Once to the top the fee was minimal and the views and vistas were maximum. Too bad my disc got corrupt because I had taken hundreds of great shots up and down. When you reach the summit walk the grounds go into the inner workings and climb the walls. Then stroll down from the hill in a leisurely manner and enjoy different sites taking a different route down.

Good start to Lisbon. We started our Lisbon trip by getting the 737 bus up to the castle. You can get the 28 tram as well but I was told by a local to get the bus as I was with my Mum and there is a steep climb from the tram stop. The bus took us to the castle gate. The castle was a great place to view Lisbon from. We could see for miles right round the city. The views were fabulous and excellent for getting our barings. It was lovely walking around the castle, climbing the towers and seeing Lisbon for the first time.

What A View!. The climb up to St. George's Castle is tough going. The roads are steep, and the cobble stones can be hard to walk on, or you can take a taxi, or tram 28 to the top of the Alfama ares close to the castle entrance, and then enjoy the walk down through this enchanting area. Either way, once you enter the Castle you won't be disappointed. The fortress is mostly ruins., with a museum housing artefacts from its sat, but what you go for is a wonderful view of Lisbon. It allows one to get an over view of this lovely city. We went early in the morning before the crowds and were rewarded with a serene and quiet time. We walked on the walls and were lucky enough to get into the Camera Obscura tour which was excellent. This huge periscope and the guide talked us through the city in real time. If you can time your visit to get on one of the tours you should! We spent over an hour here, wandering around and enjoying our first morning in Lisbon.
Beautiful Views. Great views of the city. A bit touristy and pricey, but worth a visit. There is a restaurant within the castle too where you can have a nice dinner.

Go see it!. Great place for amazing views of Lisbon and the old castle is wonderful to explore. Only 7,50 euro in entrance and you can spend hours inside just enjoying the place. There's a restaurant too, but we didnt try it.

Excellent Attraction with Children. This is one of the highlights of Lisbon, particularly with children. Yes, the castle has been reconstructed (but rather well). There are excellent tour guides that give complimentary tours explaining the history of Lisbon as it relates to the castle. There are also fabulous views from the ramparts of the whole city. A small, but very well curated museum displays artifacts from the various periods beginning with the Phoenicians and early Iberians, through the Roman period, the Moorish period and beyond. There is also a camera obscura in one of the castle towers which provides a 360 degree live view of Lisbon, and is operated and narrated by a guide.

Great panoramic view of Lisboa. The castle offers the best panoramic view in town. If you go there, avoid Torre of Belem or other "miradouro", you will not get a better view.There is not much to see inside the castle, but it is a lovely place to hang out for an hour or so. You cand also have a coffee or something to eat at the restaurant inside.

Historic Lisbon!. The views from th castle were brilliant, looking over the city. It was great to be able to wander the grounds of the castle, walking the walls as well. Sensible shoes are a must as the doors are uneven and there is many stairs and walking to be done!

Great for the views of the city... ok as a castle. There are different types of castles: Those that you go to visit inside (as they have been well preserved), those that are magnificent on the outside (size, walls, colours, gardens) and those just located in a great spot - providing great views. St.George's castle is a mix of the last two as there is no "inside" to really visitWhat I liked: Totally open air, busy but not too crowded. A good mix of shaded and sunny area. Main pathways relatively well maintained making it ok for use with a stroller (but could be a bit better). Safe environment and great overall views of Lisbon and the sea. Some food light food options on site. Not too big so that it can be done in a relatively good amount of time. Lots of great picture opportunitiesWhat to watch for / could be improved: The castle itself is relatively simplistic

The suggestive heart of Lisbon. Wandering inside the castle and walking along the walls, meanwhile watching the view of the city from above. A really nice way to feel the history of that place and the history of the city. Reaching the castle is fun as well. Climbing the stairs and passing in the narrow streets is for me the real essence of this city.

Step back in time. We walked from our hotel up to the castle. Not a bad walk if you are in used to walking. Be aware Lisbon is ALL up hill and steps. Everywhere. As others have stated you can take a tram, but walking gives you a glimpse into the "real' city and the distances are not far. The setting on top of the hill offers magnificent views of Lisbon and the tree shaded grounds are cool and calming... a welcome relief from the hot summer sun. The birds and flowers help make interesting photos. There is a charge of several Euros, which as seniors (or as the sign said "persons with deficiencies") is much less, but you must have proof of age. Out side the castle are many beautiful tiled buildings, quaint shops and neighborhoods to explore. Depending on your interest, you could walk through in under an hour or spend an entire day exploring and relaxing. Oh, be sure to wear good shoes, those picturesque cobblestone streets and walks are murder on the feet!
Amazing history. The climb was well worth the views and very reasonable refreshments within you can catch the tram if you would rather but very packed with visitors

A good place to go on a hot Lisbon day.. We were advised by a local to get the No 12 tram, rather than the No 28, not sure if it is quicker, certainly had less people, or maybe to be safe as the 28 is notorious for pick pockets. Anyway we got to the castle quickly, a little walk uphill, & you are there. Can't remember the cost, views are amazing. There is photo ops with falcons, or just take a pic of them or the owls.Lyrebirds up trees or just strutting in front of you, with their chicks. Mostly nicely shaded areas to walk. Outside the castle walls you can have a cheap snack or drink.
Great Views. Amazing views from the top of the city! Definitely worth the trip up. You feel like you are actually in Temple Run! ;-)

A Must Stop for the Views. A fun short stop at the Castelo de Sao Jorge is highly recommended. There are not a lot of activities, but the views and wandering will keep even young children occupied for a few hours. Food and beverages are available within the castle walls. It is worth noting that some of the walls and stairs are a bit steep and if you are traveling with small children, please pay attention.Well worth the small fee.

Great Views. The castle can be seen from more or less everywhere in Lisbon and it is a great place to visit.Relatively inexpensive (although i can't remember exact price i think it was c25 Euros), family tickets are available - but it was worth every cent.Great to walk around the ramparts (although low side walls made it a little scary as a parent of a 7 & 10 year old) as well as look in the museum. The view is simply fantastic with uninterrupted views of the skyline, rivers, April 25th bridge and Christ statue. There is a large, shady paved area to enjoy an ice cream whilst admiring the views!Nothing to do with the castle but, CARE - we got the tram to/from the castle and there were three pickpockets (working together) who had as earmarked as a target whilst waiting at the stop. A local warned us they were thieves and after they argued for 5 mins they all left !! It should NOT put you off - but we aware and be prepared.

Views. The views from the castle were fantastic. It was quite good climbing the ramparts of the castle. But this was the most expensive attraction in Lisbon and I can't say it was worth the money. Best way to get there is by public transport. There is a bus - well it's more like a public mini bus that takes you right outside the entrance. It's free if you have bought a day tram, bus and metro ticket for 6.5eiros or 1.80 per person each way if you pay on the bus. Well worth the money to prevent the long climb in the hot sun

The best view over Lisbon. Take the tram nr. 28 and forget all those overpriced rides with the "sightseeing tram". The daily metro ticket also works by the way and it costs only 6€ for all the busses and subways in the city.When you are up there take your time to enjoy the view. It is full of history. The guide (a paper) that you can get in the front desk will give you a first insight of the rich history of the castle. Don't forget to go to the little museum in the castle. It is easily overseen but provides great information about the place itself.
Beautiful place and view !. A very nice place to visit and spend the day with an amazing view of Lisboa and the sea. Visiting the streets around the Castle is also a beautiful walk !
nice view of the city and very interesting. It was a very interesting historical site with a good view. There was also a nice place to get a snack and drink while peacocks strolled about.

Lisbon Many Centuries Ago. ST George's Castle Is one of Lisbon most visited and most beautiful sites of the old town in one of it nicest hills. Great views to the river and to oldest part of the town. Also nice walks between narrow streets to get there, climbing from Sé or from Graça mirador.

Stunning views and worth a brief hike. Well worth the 7.50 euros each (our 6 yr old son was free) The views are incredible,the museum was ok but we don't love museums - artefacts from different ages were interesting but its small.Theres a nice wee cafe.I would visit as early as possible to avoid the coach loads though.Will definitely visit again. :)
Great view. Nce to walk to and great views from the castle. The entrance free is aprox. 7 euro and worth the lst once youve made it up there.

A must!. Well worth a visit, even if steep roads up to castle on a blistering hot day took it out of us. The views are 360' awesome.
We had drinks at the café, surprisingly reasonably priced, and the free museum was a bonus.
Views!. Great views and well restored castle. Spend a relaxing day with a book after mooching about. Lots of steep climbs from centre of Lisbon so remember to get the tram

The museum though is not very interesting and can easily be skipped. It's quite a climb to get up - but the view is terrific and the peacocks are loverly to look at. There is also quite a few cats around which seems to be looked well after. The fee is low. You can walk around on top of the battlement.

Lisbon's Top View. Anyone travelling to Lisbon must find an hour or two to visit this place. First of all, it offers unrivaled views of the city's quarters - having been to the Castle (Castello in Portuguese) you'll have a clearer picture of the whole city. Secondly the castle itself is large, well kept, and offers a fine pass-time on its own.Last but not least: while refreshing at the castle cafe you may get a chance to feed numerous peacocks roaming the premises.
beautiful. the old streets, the castle, the view over the city, must visit it!the coffee shops are nice and the whole area it's just gorgeous.
Beautiful views of Lisbon and the Tagus River. Huge grounds to cover and lots of fun overlooks of the city of Lisbon. Take your time and sit and have a cervaja.
Nice,but expensive, view over town that's it. . Beatiful view over Lisbon but you can have nearly the same view from ohter places for free. In my eyes too expensive

A nice view from Lisbon. As the Castle is on the top of the Hill, one gets a wonderful view and can try and identify the places seen from the top.If you can take a binocular you will not regret.It is very easy to go back to town walking. You get easily to Praça da Figueira.Cons: the ticket is a bit expensive for what they offer, mainly if you consider other castles in Europe. (I can't remember if one can visit just the gardens for free).

Great views. A must to visit, you can try small bus No 737 from city center to avoid crowds in tram 28 and this takes you very close and saves you from climbing the steep streets. they have a kind of camera obscura which is interesting but has a limited space so once in the castle you should check the times and get tickets.

A great view with centuries of history. At the top of one of the Lisbon's seven hills this monument is located at the center of the city. With more than 800 years you can smell history all around. A great view over Lisbon and the Tejo river make part of Castelo de São Jorge. Close you canvisit another Hill, Graça and Monte, from where the view is completed with the castle. In your way back to the center you can walk through Alfama.

Excellent site. If you are coming to Lisbon, you surely have to visit the Castelo de São Jorge. One of the most emblematic places in the capital of Portugal. Completely renewed, it has a magnificent view over the city and over the Tejo river and its South Bank. You can also visit some ruins from the Moors and Roman eras.

Wonderful views. This is the castle above the Alfama area with incredible views of Lisbon. Light is best early morning or evening. It used to be free to get in but now you have a small fee. Good thing is that the place is that it less crowded and better kept.

Lovely walk. The walk up to the castle is very nice with old narrow streets. Great views from a viewpoint on the way up, as well as from the castle. I wouldn't say the castle is terribly exciting, but it's well worth a visit.

Beautifully Maintained Medieval Fortress. This is one of the best fortress's I have visited, it is beautifully maintained by the castle staff and is an amazing place to spend and afternoon in Lisbon. The outer grounds of the castle are lovely and shady, with the most amazing views over the old parts of Lisbon. The museum on site was very good, with a large collection of imported Roman and Greek kylix's and pottery. The castle itself, as mentioned before, doesn't have any interior decoration but the courtyards have the old foundations of many buildings which is interesting if you have any knowledge of this type of fortress castle. This castle also has the best bathroom facilities for an attraction of this type that I have ever used. This attraction is well worth the climb from lower Lisbon, if walking the locals are more than happy to give directions and the area around the castle is full of little cafe's and restaurants for rest stops.

It is worth the visit. If you want to experience watching the most wonderful view of Lisbon, be sure to visit Castelo de S. Jorge. This castle is dated from the Muslim occupation of Lisbon, and then conquered by Portugal's first king - D. Afonso Henriques. Do be sure to wear comfortable shoes, as the castle is very old and so are its walks and pavements.

Great views. Bit of a hike from downtown Lisbon but the views are worth it. Visit the museum first and pick up brochure. See excavation from Iron Age, and from time of the Moors. Note wall paintings from Moors. Enjoy the shops and street music.
Not to be missed!. Not to be missed and worth the effort to walk up the steep hill. Wonderful views across the city in all directions and wonderful cool areas to sit in the heat of the sun.

Walk carefully. Great views over the city and good value attraction. The walk along the battlements is great but be wary if taking children when up here due to the drop on the courtyard side. There is a small wall but no handrail .Small museum in the castle and lots of peacocks,but the star is the view. Worth the visit if only for the view of all the city. You have a 360 degree vista from the walls.
Do it for the views.. If you want the best overview of Lisbon then make the climb up to this castle, Wear good shoes as it is quite steep up the hill, but don't give up.

Great city views!. One of Lisbon's best tourist spots, the castle gives dead gorgeous views of the city and the april 25th bridge. If you are a student, show them your student ID and they will give you a nice student price.

Easy to get to and nice views but more a castle ruins. St. George is easy to get to by Tram 28 or walking, although it is very uphill. We went on a very hot day so luckily there were little shops walking up to buy water. It is more of a castle ruins with lots of steps to walk up and see wonderful views of the city. Don't expect an interior tour where royalty might have lived-this was definitely a military type fortress. There is a small museum on the premises with artifacts dug up on the property.
Beautiful view on Lisboa from the ancient remains of the castle.. There is nothing to dislike. The trip itself already was worthwhile: the old tram.The view on Lisboa is very exciting.

View from a Castle. In my visit to Lisbon I found one of the best views in the city was from the area in the Amalfa around the grounds of the Castle of St. George. However the castle itself is not as attractive. It is more craft vendors and less of an authentic castle with suits of armor and crests on the wall above heavy dark furniture. The better option is to walk around outside the castle and enjoy the view of the city from there.

Great Lisbon View. Went walking from the city centre by a bunch of side streets and stairs and we love it. You don't need to be the most fit person in the world to do it. Just some patience and pit stops. The view is outstanding an the atmosphere amazing. Everything is well preserved and maintained. It's a must of the city although the price for this type of attractions is not the cheapest for a city like Lisbon. Still would do it again.
Best views of Lisbon. The castle's walls offer up the best views of the city. Nice relaxing area of the city high above it. Very windy. You can climb around all the towers and walls

some years ago mankind was governed from the St.George Castle. On top of the wonderful Lisboa city there`s this remarkable castle. You should take the walk uphill for your visit. Each meter climbing up the narrow stairs or roads makes you more understanding of how the ancient decission makers felt when on top! And dont forget to visit the Vasco da Gama place!

Cool!. We took the famous old tram no. 28 to get to this must-see castle on the hill. Happy to know that children under 10 years old don't need to pay admission. It was an hot July afternoon, and so we were really pleased to enter this cool place and enjoyed a stunning view over the Lisbon old town area. It would be a wonderful place for picnic to while away a lazy summer day, too. The castle is huge and you can climb up the walls and walk about the ramparts. Good fun for kids, but not for under 5, as bits of it are steep and precarious. After the castle, we went on taking the same tram up to its last stop and found this beautiful church, which we spotted through the castle's window, offering good photo spot of the Castle. The 6 euro day ticket for each person bought from the metro vending machine allowed us to take all public transport in Lisbon in 24 hours, and so we got good value out of it. Highly recommended!

Castle of love. You will never be able to say, you know Lisbon as a city, if you miss St. George's Castle, it is a romantic and cultural place to visit and will give you one of the moust beautifull views you´ll ever saw.
Amazing place. Amazing view, unique, quite well preserved, long hours open. Hard to get there, very steep narrow street s, slippery , need good shoes, but very picturesque
Don't miss this!. Awesome views of Lisbon, along with some very interesting history. Take the #28 trolley for easy access, and walk back down afterwards.

Castle on the hill. The Castle is perched high on a hill, with breath taking views of the whole of Lisbon including the surrounding area's of Alfama. If you are fit its a lovely walk up the narrow streets passing the cathedral on route, those not so energetic there is a tram service.
Castle Review. a bit of a hike up to the castle but well worth it. Excellent views from the castle walls. Contains a number oplaces where one can eat and drink.

one of the best views in Lisbon. you can really see why they built the castle up there. I last went in November 2008 and very strong memories of the evening sunshine.Only regret is that I did not buy a CD from the guitar player under the tree in the courtyard then - I promised myself to buy one when we had finished walking round the walls but he had gone by then. Held a very faint hope that he would be back there this time. Just goes to show that one should take an opportunity when it presents itself as it may not happen again.

Good castle ruins. It costs 7.5 euros and is worth it. Note that to buy tickets you have to buy them around the corner from the castle. Once inside you're free to walk around and climb the castle walls. The views from the castle are amazing and there's no protection against falling to ruin the views (careful with kids). There were a lot of portugese day camps while I was there and it was fun to watch the kids singing their camp songs.

Wow!. If you want to get an idea of what the city looks like, be sure to go to the castle. We took the sightseeing bus (Red Line) to the top or almost the top of the hill and walked the rest of the way up. We are seniors and there is a discount for seniors so be sure to ask. If you have mobility or a fear of heights, you might have a few places where you can't/won't go, but most of the castle is on level ground. The view of the city is worth the price of admission. Not to be missed.
Amazing landscapes view. Great landscape view over Lisbon and Tagus River. It´s funny to see the colors of the Lisbon roofs, since it is a city of seven hills. Downtown is great also.

Go in the evening. This is a wonderful place to visit, go when the tourists are heading home after 6 p.m. (it is open until 9 pm in the summer). The views are probably the best in Lisboa, lots of shady places to sit and what looks to be a wonderful restaurant (we will try this the next time... check out if you have to pay the entrance to the castle if you dine there because that would make it expensive). Some peacocks roaming around.... Make the effort to walk the ramparts.... Lots of lovely little cafes around..... but shop around a some are VERY touristy and lack authenticity.

Great views. This Castle has a really fascinating history and is best visited with a guide. The walk up to the castle is a bit arduous but well worth the effort as the views all around are memorable. There are many stories to listen to about the various occupations and sieges - all fascinating.

A view but that's it. Figured we were in Lisbon and should go but were a bit disappointed about how little there was to explore. With so many national palaces around Portugal to explore that have lots of artifacts to see, this was just your typical ruin with a fantastic view.

Not enough information. Lovely area to walk around, but don't expect to learn much. Other than the artefacts in the museum, There is no information on site. The archeological site appears to make a feature of telling you nothing about what you are looking at!

City views - worth the trip. We decided to head up to the castle to get a view of the city...We took the tram to the bottom of the hill and followed pedestrian signs up to the castle which was easy enough. The walk up is quite steep cobbled streets but didn't take too long. The street up looks to have quite a few nice looking restaurants/bars too. The castle did cost about 7 Euros each which we worried might be a bit expensive, but given we had such a nice afternoon and only had time to do one 'touristy' thing I'm glad we did. The view is pretty great, I would try and go up on a clear day if possible, just to get the most out of it, but a great photo opporunity none the less. We also went on the periscope tour which is located in the Tower of Uylsses part of the castle. The talk inside seemed interesting, although given it was in Spanish we didn't get anything from it. It seemed like other talks may be in English but it wasn't clear at the beginning ours was not to be - tip check before hand. The periscope itself it quite impressive and looke d a good way to find out more abotu the history of the city. All in all, a good place to get above the city and have a good tourist experience.

A Walking Adventure & Breathtaking View. Half the fun of visiting this castle is getting there. On our way to the castle, we walk up and wandered around the lovely, winding cobbled streets looking at little groceries, restaurants and quaint apartment buildings. We had a drink at a cool bar/restaurant with a great terrace. And we had lunch at a wine bar with amazing food and excellent local wine and port to taste.As for the castle itself, we very much enjoyed this amazing piece of history. It was really fun to explore and walk atop some of the castle walls that remain. The view of the city from the park/grassy area right outside the castle is absolutely beautiful.Make sure you visit Castelo de Sao Jorge!
Beautiful views. Getting up the hill is a chore, but it is rewarding once you arrive. Enjoy the beauty and history of Lisbon.

Average castle, unbeatable views. We got tram 8 up to the castle and walked up the steep cobbled streets to the entrance. While the castle isn't as stunning as the likes of Ephesus and Warwick Castle as it looks quite renovated, but the views are worth the walk and small admission fee on their own. It offers amazing panoramic vistas over the city, so you can see the bridge, the buildings folding over the hills, Rossio Square and many more. Not easy to get to but the views are simply divine. There's a small white church nearby who's name escapes me, which is also worth a visit - it is spectacular.

If you have only a few hours in Lisbon then visit the castle. This castle tells the story of the city for the past 1000 years, as well as the castle remains be sure to visit the archaeological excavation too. The camera obscured gives a unique view of the city and whilst the commentary is in Portuguese it is still very easy to follow the explanations, both of the city sites and the technical explanation of the camera.
Breathtaking views!. It takes an effort to get up there, but once you are there you forget it all. Great breeze and breathtaking views of the city and shoreline.,

St. George’s Castle – Make the Hike Up the Hill. Lisbon is a beautiful city and the Castelo de Sao Jorge is one of the crown jewels. The views from the ramparts are breath taking and worth the effort. Be prepared for a long queue to buy tickets but the line moves quickly.I would challenge you to walk up the hill to the castle. If you do so, be prepared for the labyrinth of streets that date from the Middle Ages. The streets are not marked and a layout from the Middle Ages = a confusing maze which can lead to fun exploring. For those less adventurous, take bus #737 or tram #12 to the castle.

Amazing views of the harbor and city!. There aren't too many cities where castles are so plentiful! Within an hour's drive of Lisbon there are quite a few, but this one is in the heart of Lisbon and is well worth the time to visit! I went with my two sons, 12 and 10, and we had a great time. There are cats all over the place, along with peacocks. The castle is in great shape given the fact that its from the 6th century. The history is fascinating. The views are amazing!! We watched cruise ships, cargos ships and all manner of boats go in and out of the harbor. My only concern was the lack of safety rails around the high levels. There is easily a 60 foot drop in some spots of the castle. If you are afraid of heights or have small kids, take care. We had a driver take us there so access is fairly easy. Parking did appear to be a little bit of a concern. Lisbon is the oldest city in Europe, so the streets are very narrow. Our driver dropped us off and came back two hours later.
Go for the cats!. The castle itself is not that impressive but the grounds are lovely, the area of the alfama is great and the castle has cats! 19 of them to be exact and peacocks too!

Castle in the city center. It's up the hill with the most beautiful views of Lisbon. One of its top rooms holds a periscope. The periscope session lasts 20 minutes, shows you large parts of Lisbon and is presented in English, Spanish and Portuguese by the knowledgable staff who will tell you some of the city's history.

Well worth the climb. We missed the tram and walked up. Not for the unfit or weak knees and we got lost several times. But it was worth the climb and the views are as described, fantastic. Worth the entry fee for that alone
What amazing view. From the castle you have an incredible view of all the town , but don t forget to take the bus or the tram 28 to reach it, because it is on the top a hill

Beautiful Castle, short steep hike. A very nice Castle, but if you have difficulty walking up the steep roads there are some "jitney' type vehicles that you can pay ( sorry don't know how much) to drive you up the hill. The stairs up to the castle walls are also steep, and a little uneven, so be careful.
Beautiful. Worth to visit!!! Beautiful view, a lot things to see!!! Especially liked periscope. You can see lissabon in real time in periscope. Something very interesting and never seen before

Amazing place to go with children.... The building is not the real old one, but it looks like an old castle. Beyond that, it was built on the same place where we had a muslim fortress and, after that, a portuguese fortress and real castle. The place is very beautiful. Kids were astonished about the place. This is a must see...

Beautiful views, well worth the climb. Wear sensible shoes if you're planning to visit the castle - between the climb up to the castle and the steps to go up and down the walls, this is not a tour for stillettos. The grounds outside of the castle walls are beautifully shaded and breezy, and offer magnificent views of the city. The cafe is small but reasonably priced and has small tables outside where peacocks roam looking for handouts. We had a really nice morning and took over a hundred photos.

well worth the visit. We used the tram from Jeronimos Monastery to reach a square walking distance from the Castle. However, we chose taking another tram up the very steep hill to get us closer. The visit was well worth the time. We had spectacular views and there is quite a lot to see. It appears that they also have concerts at the castle and we hope to someday attend one.

Fantastic Views. We tried to follow a guided walk up through Alfama, and got lost, but that was part of the fun. It was well worth the climb as the views were fantastic and by paying the low entrance fee we were able to escape the crowds and relax on the ramparts. My partner loved the battlements which aren't for those who have a fear of heights; or those who don't yet realise they have a fear of heights! The castle is home to many cats who are fed by the restaurant after closing time, they are friendly and will enjoy a fuss.

Incredible views of the city, but beware the climb. If you are on a tour, buses cannot make it to the top, so you have to climb 20 minutes up a steep cobblestone street. One lady in our group was wearing heels and not having fun. Some of the older members of the group struggled also. But once we made it, the views of Lisbon and the Tagus River were absolutely amazing!
Another must. Walk up, it's not a big deal and it's relatively calm. Or take the bus. Great views, greenery, ruins, a café, old hollowed out olive trees, a nice breeze. Take your time

Very interesting history of the city. The grand castle one just wonders around and the views from the upper gangways are not for those with vertigo but very cool. The museum although not spectacular, gives a very interesting history from the Arabs down to more modern times.

Great little castle in the heart of Lisbon. We almost missed this place and decided to visit before dinner. The walk up to the castle wasn't the most fun I've ever had on a 95 degree summer day, but I am glad we did it. Great views of Lisbon and some great views inside the castle as well. We went with our two-year old and she had no trouble navigating the castle and we weren't worried about her injuring herself. It likely won't be the highlight of your trip, but it is worth a visit while in Lisbon...hopefully on a cooler day.

Disappointing. I love history so a visit here was expected to be a highlight of our visit to Lisbon. It's a very imposing building on a great site overlooking the city. My disappointment was with the lack of tour guides, reference information, historical background information, or anything else that makes a visit to a location like this more meaningful. Entrance is not cheap. If I knew what to expect, I don't think I'd have paid to go in. My recommendation... Take a photo with the castle in the background - you can do that for free...!

Just do it!. So you can walk, or catch the tram or bus up to the castle to get a taste of life in 1100ad. If you have an appreciation for walking the same paths, climbing the same steps of thousands of others over the years then you will enjoy this. Unbeatable views in every direction, beautiful shady spots to just sit and appreciate the building. Walk the castle walls, climb the towers....yum!

Exciting castle to explore with great views over Lisbon,. The title more or less says it all but also nice cafe, separate restaurant, interesting gift shop, spectacular peacocks plus interesting streets and restaurants outside the castle precincts

A haven of peace and quiet (before the tour groups arrive). Once you have recovered from the climb up the cobbled streets to the castle you find peace and space to move around. There is a special entrance price for Seniors but you have to ask for it. The views from the walls over Lisbon are wonderful. Although the layout of the castle is preserved there is not a lot to see other than climbing steep steps up the ramparts which would never pass UK Health and Safety regulations. (Where in Portugal does?) The refreshment facility is in a lovely shaded courtyard and reasonably priced. Toilet facilities are clean and conveniently located. An essential visit in any itinerary in Lisbon.

The views are great, to get there you build up your aerobic fitness levels. The ride up in one of the historic trams is interesting. Seating capacity 20, standing capacity 38 passengers - would be somewhat snug I think.Once you get to the final stop you still have a short way to go - up! But it's worth it. The panoramic views of the city, the surrounds and the Rio Teju are superb.You can enter the castle, go up steps to get better views.There are a couple of cafes and a restaurant on location. The cafe prices were good and there was a variety of foods - bread rolls, sandwiches and pasta dishes that could be washed down with beer, soft drink, various coffees or sangria.

From free to paid. The castle was before free and, from what it offers, it was only fair that it would have a 5 star note. But the price of 7,5€ to enter the castle, or better put, inside the walls, is still something that I never understood (it was totally free some years ago).The sights are truly amazing but better use others free points in Lisbon which also give breathtaking images and are free.

pricey but worth it. Paid 10 euros which I find pricey taking in consideration there's not that much to see, but still I think it's worth it. The view is absolutely incredible you can see a lot of Lisbon, the iconic bridge and the south margin of the river.
High Climb. Again lots to see if you like looking at ruins, surrounded by an old town with a village atmosphere. Lots of shady areas to sit, outside cafe with lots of peacocks and hens running round.
Castle. Well worth the climb to get here. We spent a whole morning just wandering around the battlements enjoying the superb views over the city from every angle.

Absolutely Worth the Trip!. We took a cab (cabs are relatively inexpensive in Lisbon). The views from the castle grounds, which sits at the top of a hill, are spectacular... the city, the harbor. And the castle itself, dating back a thousand years or more, is interesting even without the views! There is ample opportunity to climb the walls (hang on to your children!). There are refreshment stands and even a full service restaurant within the castle walls. This site is on every Top 10 list of Lisbon sites, and deservingly so!

Quaint little town in a Castle. Castles are on the high ground and St. George is no exception. Don't bother signing up for the tour. Go to the easily accessible ramparts by the entry gate and walk along the battlement for great views of Lisbon. Then have a coffee and custard at a cafe!
Magnificent View. I truly recommend a visit to the St. George's Castle. The view over the city is magnificent. It is situated in the Castelo bourough.
