Stunning Views. Take a walk up from the tram no. 28 stop. It is breathtaking. Good value for money stalls and cafe's are a stones throw away from the entrance to the castle. The usual tourist trap is to be expected in these places but this is different.Walk the ancient walls and see a spectacular view of Lisbon. Afterwards take a stroll down to the town and see all the places you saw from up there. Well worth it.

Great hilltop fortress and view of Lisbon. The Castle is well worth a visit for its architecture and the impressive views of the city and the harbor from the castle walls. It can be reached by trolley and a short uphill walk and by a longer uphill walk from downtown through the historic Alfama neighborhood. There is a nice outdoor cafe within the castle.

Great View, but Expensive. St. George's Castle is a really interesting part of Lisbon's history and has beautiful views of Lisbon. If you are willing to fork over the 7.50E entry fee, you get to enjoy the beautiful views and wander the castle ruins. The castle is amazing well preserved and is very simple...just the walls and staircases...no gimicky displays or tours. There is also a small museum, but we did not go through. I don't know their rules on food, but they don't check your bags when you enter, so I would maybe recommend taking a picnic or a snack up there to enjoy. There are plenty of seats and picnic benches...it would have been fantastic to enjoy the breeze and the view while eating lunch! The only downside is that it felt a little expensive to do!

Great views & beautiful castle. We visited the castle for a second time on our trip and still love the views which you can get from the platforms and castle walls. As previous reviewers have stated, there are other viewing points throughout the city which also offer just as good views and do not charge, but it depends if you are looking for the experience of the castle as well. The only thing to be wary of are the castle walls, although they are great to explore the barriers along the walls are very small and therefore if you have vertigo or any fear of heights / falling or indeed small children, be prepared!
A must see. is recomended in all tourist guides but is really worth seeing it. A great view of Lisbon and a great atmosphere created by a guitar player in one of the courtyard made it special for us!

Nice castle. This is a nice castle to visit. I was told it's difficult to walk up, but it's managable if you don't want to bother with trams/busses etc - takes around 30mins from Rossio square. You get student discount (€4 Euro) if you bring your student card, otherwise it's €7.50. The views over the city are amazing. You can climb the towers in the castle to get even better views. Apart from that, there's not too much else - it's missing some information boards to inform visitors about its history.
Very beautiful!. Nice place to go visit Lisbon, excellent street musicians next to it if your lucky, great sightseing in the castel as much for a couple or a family, great for pic nic and walks!
Good Views. It was cool inside, but I don't know if it was worth the money. There are some other good views in Lisbon and most of the castle is ruins. The history was interesting though.

Pretty cool view, castle walls are maintained well. This has a great view of the city! Make sure you take a trolley or taxi up to the castle, as even the most in shape people will think this is a hike! I would be super cautious about taking small children up as the castle guard rails are only 1 foot high when walking on the walls; even I was a little worried about tripping and falling over them!
Stunning views of Lisbon. Great views from the castle walls, a cool drink under shady trees, some gentle guitar and peacocks. This was a lovely place to spend the afternoon.

Provides great history and scenic views!. What magnificent views can be seen from inside the castle. It is very easy to get around in the castle, although some steps are steep - be prepared to hang onto the railings! It is very easy to get to and there are plenty of shops nearby! If you want some terrific historical and scenic pictures, you must go here!
Perfect landscape. A really good place to see the entire city, nice spot for pictures, and also a great castle to visit and stay few minutes relaxing with the great view.

Magnificient views on a picnic. Great place to visit on sunny day. Lot of places to enjoy views with a picnic. There is also a cafeteria/restaurant, but is is a tourist-routine-site. Several clean WC/toilets, free of charge. An elder man has got excellent sense of style, plays there charming medieval flute music, which can be heard almost all over the site. Happy to give some coins him for that.

Beautiful Views. Once I found the streets up to the castle, I had the best views of the city. I suggest going up to the castle on a clear day. You can do the castle, and the other major sites in two full days.

a must-see in Lisbon. This castle is on a high hill, but the view from the main square in the castle in definitly worth it! you can walk on the old castle walls. I think it's a definite must when you are in Lisbon. The entrance price is ok and you can walk around quite a while. It's all open air.

Fantastic views, great for kids. The castle is a series of well preserved ruins. It provided us with a few happy hours entertainment with our two small children: lots of battlements to climb and cannons to sit on. The views of Lisbon are fantastic.
magnificent views of the city. definately worth the walk from the town center! as soon as you reach the castle the city of lisbon lies underneath! the best place to take panoramic photos!!!

Fine views and interesting neighbours. Well worth going to the Castle - we took a tuk-tuk from the cathedral and then back to our hotel. Splendid views; great promenades and the whole area is clean and airy and pleasant. Seems to have escaped the graffiti blight that afflicts the rest of the older part of the city and renders it so unpleasant to the eye.Near the Castle - just a bit up the road from the cluster of souvenir shops in Rua de Santa Cruz do Castelo is Corvo Azul - a very good wine shop and delicatessen where you can eat a fine lunch based on the products for sale. Owner is friendly and knowledgeable and speaks good English.

For history buffs. If you are looking to learn a little bit more about Lisbon and Portugal as a whole visiting Castelo de Sao Jorge is a must! On a clear day the views over the city are spectacular. I love that you can mingle with locals and visitors alike. The admission price is also reasonable. The day I visited there were some little school children there being entertained with a little skit with actors dressed in period costume. There is a small museum, lovely gift shop, places to sit and relax and have a cup of coffee if you wish. It is tranquil and a great way to spend an afternoon. You can choose to climb the stairs and walk around the walls that protected the castle from siege in times past to get lovely views of the city. If you're lucky you may just see a peacock or two. Getting there is easy as well, just hop on a tram or bus. When you leave the castle walk around the neighbourhood surrounding it and enjoy the charming cafe's and restaurants in the vicinity and have some pasteis de nata.

Lovely grounds and great view. A restored castle, with cool shaded grounds and great towers and ramparts to climb up for fabulous views over Lisbon. Well worth a visit, but hard walking to get there, and not ideal for young children to run around in, as some of the parapets and ledges are not well fenced, if at all!
Must see for a visit to Lisbon. Lovely views over the city and also an interesting place in its own right. A must see for a visit to Lisbon

A Torontian (Canadian) in Lisbon. It was a nice walk to the location, but needs more signage but the locals help guide you there. Nice place to take pictures lots to see when there in terms of the city of central Lisbon since the location is very very high that allows you to overlook the town and surrounding areas. The entrance fees were 7.50 Euros which I felt was fair. Wear comfortable shoes for it is a climb up and down hills.

Unprecidented Views of Lisbon's Beauty. The hill climbing tram (or yellow bee) can whisk you there quickly, however for us half the adventure was meandering through the back streets of inner city/residential Lisbon. Hike up stairs and through the back alleys of startling varying width, we kept walking "up", eventually finding ourselves on the doorsteps of this tree shrouded ruin. The views from the ancient battlements and walls are awe inspiring. Though the admission may seem steep (at least for adults), it is worth the fare for a one-stop view of all of the old city.Though there is a nice cafe/bistro inside the castle, our preference for cost and beer selection was to stop again outside the castle walls at one of lisbon's countless sidewalk bistros

Great views. Stunning views of Lisbon from the walls of this castle. The structure is impressive though there is nothing left of the contents. Take the bus or tram up and walk down through the jumble of streets that make up the Alfama district.

Best view in town. This castle is not only is a great historical sit, but also a park, a great view of the city, and a small museum. It also has a firstclass restaurant and cafe. Take a taxi to the the location or walkthrough the old town (Mouraria) Driving or parking is impossible.
Climbing to the castle. Primarily you visit for the panoramic views. We walked through interesting neighborhoods. Was a little difficult to find but the Portuguese people are very helpful.
Don't miss it!. Wonderful place to view the city of Lisbon. Great place to just walk and get lost in. The placement of the trees in the courtyard is amazing and relaxing to sit under on a hot day.

Lisbon from a distance. I recommend getting there with a bus(I took 737 - Castelo) and coming back on foot and enjoying the way down stopping on the churches and Miradouros.The Castle itself is really great, and you have a chance to see Lisbon from up top. In sunny days, the Sun reflecting on the river is just beautiful...

Great Views from the top.. Was packed with people and expensive but if you have the time - the view is great. Easy (and inexpensive) to take a cab there and back into the town Square. Nearby cafe had terrific views.

Brilliant views. The tram takes you close to the castle, but there's an uphill walk, so not for the fainthearted. Lots to explore in the castle, but lots of stairs so not suitable for the disabled or for anyone with a pushchair. Well worth exploring the surrounding streets which are quaint and interesting. the views from the top of the castle are breathtaking

A must-see if visiting Lisbon. This particular location has had some type of fort on it since the Romans and it's easy to see why when you finally get to the top and can look out over the city below. It's built on top of the main hill in Lisbon so it affords fantastic views of the entire city, and the surrounding countryside. I highly recommend visiting the castle first thing in the morning when you are well rested and full of energy because it is quite a walk to get to and quite a walk/climb to explore once you do get there (it's also cooler in the morning). It's also a good idea to visit it early in your visit to Lisbon because it gives you such a great 360 view that you can easily plan your next adventure in the city. Finally. there is only one entrance into the castle so don't make the mistake we made of coming from the wrong direction and then having to walk all around the walls looking for a way in. Approach the castle from the southwest and you should be fine, ask tourists and locals for directions along the way because there is very little signage.Be wary that the castle and its ramparts have very low walls and no guardrails so if you are afraid of heights or have poor balance you probably want to stick to the safer areasFinally, make sure you get a LISBOA card first thing when you get to the city, it gives you free public transport and a discount (sometimes 100% off) on all attractions, it's well worth the cost and can be acquired at any tourist information center

At the top of Lisbon. It took a long while to find it, due to roadworks going on in area, it really needs to be sign posted better as we met several tourists who got lost trying to find it. It is definitely worth a visit I would suggest going very early in the day and you can easily spend a day strolling around

Great views, and no bums. Lisbon is not short of good viewpoints - many free - but IMHO by far the best views of the city and the river (the widest vista) can be found at the castle - truly spectacular. It was also pleasant to be able to enjoy the views without being hassled by bums and street traders - an unfortunate experience at some of the free viewpoints. (You'll have to run the gauntlet to get in, though.) The grounds also have some fascinatingly ancient olive trees, and beautiful wild poppies at the time of our visit.It's possible to get there on the 28 tram, but the 12 tram is far less crowded. The small 737 bus gets nearest of all to the entrance. All leave from praca Figueira. The castle itself is a fort, not a live-in building, and of no more than moderate interest. The barriers are quite low in places, so look out! I'd have liked to see the camera obscura, but they only let groups in every 30min, so I had to miss it.There is an archaeological site of some ancient ruins on site, though there isn't much to see yet - the oldest ruins are dated to 700BC, apparently.

St George castle. Good exercise to climb up and great views from there. The da Vinci periscope was fascinating ... A good demo. Liked the history timeline display. Worth seeing and a good way to orient yourself to the city layout .

Worth the Climb for the View. The castle dominates the skyline of the old part of the city. The castle can be approached on foot (follow the route 28 tram tracks) or take the tram, there is a bus or if you need a taxi. The castle is now only represented by the walls, there is an outer wall. As you pass through the gate purchase your ticket on your right, then proceed to the gate of the castle. While there is a museum of archeological finds and the sites of previous digs there are no other structures other than the walls of the outer and inner castle. The view is reason enough to make the visit.
Must see in Portugual. We spent most of a day here taking pictures, enjoying the history and great views of Lisbon. Would recommend to anyone visiting Lisbon.

A real castle. It was wonderful to walk around, and see the castle as a real place. There are not any rooms with gaudy chandeliers and velvet, but well presented history and chunky ramparts and lots of towers. A good walk to get there and good walking around. Great views of Lisbon as you walk around too. Definitely go there!

Overpriced. It costs 7.50euro per person to go into the castle It has great views but we had been to see Lisbon from lots of other heights already and it was a bit of an let down Even the gift shops were extremely pricey

A bit overpriced. We felt it was a bit overpriced - even the gift shop outside seemed to be far more expensive than the shops in the city. Very pretty spot though - even if you do not go into the castle grounds the area outside is sweet with lovely restaurants and shops etc
Good for the views. Take the walk up the hills to the castle, there some great views all around, it's well preserved, not extensive but not just a pile of ruins.

The best views of Lisbon. After seeing the views from some of Lisbon's noteworthy panoramas (Miradouros), I have to say that the view from the Castelo de Sao Jorge is the best of all. It makes sense, since this castle was built on the highest point for military reasons.After exploring several of the interesting areas around the grounds - my favorite was the archeological site showing foundations of buildings from the castle's different historical eras - we had lunch at the cafe (not bad) and then visited the museum (also not bad).

One of the best sights in Lisbon. If you only have limited time , this is one sight I would defintely recommend . Great views of Lisbon and ensure you visit the periscope - it gives a unique view .One for theh bucket list

Really neat, more up there than you think. A really neat little sanctuary atop a hill in Lisbon. Great views down onto the city. An expansive complex with small museums and exhibits in addition to the castle. There are even wild peacocks just meandering around the complex. Take you time to stroll through, several options to get a quick snack and enjoy the views.

Great views of Lisbon. First of all decide how you will get there - it's quite a steep climb or there is the funicular which is 3 or 4 Euros. This was a fort rather than a residence so there is not much to see other than the fabulous 360degree views of Lisbon. Walking the battlements is fun and offers the best views but the low walls may put some off.

Don't miss it!. It is absolutely not to be missed in Lisboa! Amazing view, beautiful old fortification. Even if you have only 1 day in Lisboa, invest 2 hours to get to this castle, you can see the whole city and decide, what you want to see next.
Tremendous views of Lisbon. Go and see Lisbon from the top. THe castle itself is very nice and there are beautiful peacocks all over the place.
Panoramic view. The castle is worth a visit both for the views of Lisbon from it and for the castle itself, but the ticket is quite expensive.

Nice castle.. If you want to see a castle like in the movies, you must visit the St George's Castle. It is worth to walk on top of the walls and climb to the towers. If you are with kids, watch out because there are not enough protection from the walls and towers. It was one of the best spots I visited in Lisbon.

it`s not a castle, it`s fortress. If you`ve ever been to any UK castle or you live in UK, i wouldn`t recommend you this place for not to be disappointed.Nothing interesting at all, except views.. In all other cases, you can try. Price is 8 EUR (overpriced for views only). There are a lot of nice places with fantastic views in old part of Lisbon and you can enjoy them for free.

WHAT A GREAT VIEW ON A CLEAR DAY I CAN SEE NEW YORK. To get there I would sugest taking a taxi, Going down is much better than climbing Mt. Everest. The views are just fantastic, Its 360 degrees of beautiful sites. If you dont have much time to see this city then this is the place to go. We went on a Monday when the lines were small, there are student prices and Sr. prices. I was too young for one and too old for the other.
St. George a must see.. Great view of Lisbon. Wonderful sea breeze to a shaded platform around the castle. I could have lounged there all day.

Don't Miss The Peacocks. On the highest hill overlooking all of Lisbon sits this wonderful part castle and part fort. Getting up there and back down is an adventure in itself, but well worth the effort. Yes there are peacocks all around, and yes they will pose for a photo if you are lucky. If you missed the "castle" on your last trip, do not miss it on your next.

What a hilltop location. There are a lot of interesting things to see when you work your way up to the top of the hill to visit St George's Castle overlooking Lisbon. We were unfortunate with our October day when it rained seriously. Somewhere to return to in better weather.
Lovely views. Don't take the tram up - walk the streets. The views over the city and worth the walk. Great photo op, especially near sunset.

nice panoramic view to Lisbon. It's worth it to see but the ticket is quite expensive about 7 euro.You can have a nice walk on the wall of the castle and enjoy the views to Lisbon.It was surprising to see from the short distance beautiful peacocks.
Perfect views. A bit too crowded by tourists. Well conserved and taken care of, clean. At some point it is a bit risky (climbing on high walls and very low veranda protections).

A leafy haven on a hot day. The castle was a surprising delight offering panoramic views from the walls of the castle. The delightful cool of the dappled shade of the piazza in front of the castle still allows the views more comfortably on a hot sunny day.

A tough climb but worth it.. The castle and its surrounds are very well worth seeing, and not just for the spectacular views. The buildings themselves are very well preserved and presented, A fascinating insight into Lisbon's past.The climb up the hill through the narrow old streets was amazing, but hard work. Take your time and take some water if the weather is warm! There are cafe and restaurant facilities within the castle, too.

Great old world experience .. Took a tour here , it was awesome . The castle is nice . You get to walk all over the castle and the views are spectacular . You can see all of lisbon from here. There a old canons sitting every where . You can imagine you lived then.

Neat old Castle. My boyfriend and I joke that once you've seen one castle you've seen them all. This is true to a certain degree, but the views are always breathtaking and I can't get enough of seeing the ancient architecture and how our ancestors lived. It was worth the hike up the hill, again :).:).
great views. its a quite a walk up the hills and small streets, but really worth going as teh views are amazing:)
Another Fine view of Lisbon and the harbor/river. The tram ride and walk up and down to the castle is wonderful, but the grounds are not especially informative relative to the other Lisbon sites.
Great way to spend an afternoon. This castelo is very interesting....we enjoyed climbing around the walls and also visiting the gift shop.

Expectacular view a must see. Do not miss the view from the top of the castle it is impressive of the whole city.
It leaves you in awe at the beauty of the city. The castle is really nothing different. Need to be fit to go up steep stairs but definitely worth the effort.

Nice place but with nothing too special. It is a beautiful place. The view over Lisbon is amazing but, besides that, it is only a castle with a interesting but small museum and a restaurant. Some cultural events take place in here, nevertheless.
The top of the visit is to get a 360º look over Lisbon through a periscope instaled in one of the castle towers.

Interesting. For those who are interested in history and to see the ruins of ancient life.Try to imagine what life must have been and be happy for what you have now. Entrance fee is 7,50 €/pers. There is a café if you like to sit down for a while. The view from the top both is breath taking! Only this is worth the climb..(well..we took a taxi...from Marques De Pombal Hotel to the top cost around 6-7 euros...sooo worth it!). There are some beautiful peacock wondering around in the area.

AMAZING VIEWS across lisbon. nice look into the history of lisbon and its culture , many artifacts an information , BUT it can get busy around sunset 6/8 ish and open till 9pm , AMAZING 360 VIEWS of lisbon and worth goin for this if you dont like history , ruins or culture , there is a cafe area and a picnic spot , so best advice go on tram 28 around 3/4pm with a packed snack have a good look round and stay for the sunset , then go out for dinner in downtown area , this is an old ruin so acess is a bit difficult , so beware if taking a pushchair or have needs
Steep Climb, But Worthwhile. This is actually the ruins of the Castle. It's a very steep climb to get there and then many stairs to see the site. The views are spectacular.
Nice. Nice place in Alfama - if you like castles, ruins - it is your place. If you don't - it is still a nice place to relax.
Nice Castle. The castle was very nice. The views were amazing from the castle, the grounds were fantastic but there was no castle to go inside.

Must be visit!. Visit the castle is a way to get into the primordial Portugal history, know a little bit of the construction of a nation into the medieval era. Its a part of what you can see in many of portuguese country side cities, a mediaeval fortification, a robust building, different of baroque churches and palaces in manueline style. By the way is the best city view/skyline.
good to see. This was the first attraction to see in Lisbon.It had beautiful views of the city! The view was especially nice on a sunny day! I am glad that we visited.

Amazing sunset and photographer's delight. This enormous castle seemed to provide endless opportunities and angles for any novice or professional photographer. Since they don't close until at 9pm, be sure to get there to watch the sunset.

Beautiful view of the city and nice walk. It is a nice walk uphill through the winding streets to get to the Castelo. There are little restaurants along the way with traditional food, and lots of small stores, many with just tourist souvenirs but some with nice antiques. The visit to the Castelo was wonderful, beautiful gardens and interesting construction.

Great views. The castle is quite extensive (even if it has been "tinkered" with) and you can spend a reasonable amount of time wandering around it to justify the entrance fee.
There are great views from it over Lisbon and the Tagus river.

Spectacular views of Lisbon. The castle is lovely. The museum is small but nice and modern. The views are the best I've experienced in Lisbon. Great cafe and reasonable priced gift shop. The ticket office is out side the castle. Make sure you have your ticket before joining the entrance queue. Leading up to and inside are precarious cobbles. Very difficult for anything with wheels or if unsteady on your feet. The hill to the castle is steep. However the taxis do drive up to the entrance if necessary.

If you don't have other plans. Re-built fortress. Panoramic view to the city but imho better from the observation point in Bairo Alto. DON'T go there by tram 29 - long waiting line and it's always packed. Take tram 12.In the fortress garden walking peacocks, near cafe they're coming close and pity looking at customers awaiting if they share a pastry with them. Looks touching, but those greedy people... well, you know them/ ;)

If in Lisbon, you have to visit the Castle.. The Castle is a contant in the Lisbon skyline, in fact we used it for directional purposes daily while exploring. After seeing it every day it was nice to climb up the hill, many steps and experience the Lisbon views from the Castle. Beautiful views.We did not tour inside or take a guided tour, but it was available.

Nice views. As with most tourist site entries in Portugal be prepared to wait 20 to 30 mins just to pay for the ticket, even if you have a Lisbon Card as the queues are long; and that is outside peak season.Once inside the castle you have great views over Lisbon and lots of rock stairs to climb, not much else to see apart from the old arabic ruins, which are just that.Not sure of the cost of entry as it was included in our Lisbon Card; the best value card in Portugal.

Beautiful landscape!. This castle is a must if you`re visiting Lisbon for the views you get from it. My partner and I went on a sunny day and it was just beautiful! We just missed seeing more of the castle itself, like some of the rooms or what it looked like inside but still, worth the visit for sure.
Fantastic!! Closed on the first of May.... The place seems to be great, but a lot of people were standing in front of the entrance that clearly was closed. Genius!
Without any doubt - worth visiting!. I was talking about Castelo de Sao Jorge on Alfama review so I'm not going to repeat myself. Give it a try. You wont regret it for sure.

Worth visiting. It was a bit hard to get here as there was so many other people doing the same. However, when we finally got here (tram 28 and walking) it was worth. Somehow also the croud disappeared in the big space of the area.We enjoyed several hours just by hanging around, resting and eating ice cream in the sun. Very nice. The view was great, could wonder around in different areas in the castle.Had a bad experience on the "Castelo de S. Jorge cafe" in the middle of the area. Very bad service, almost rude. Maybe the other places are better as there were several restaurants around.

Wonderful views and oodles of history. Having climbed a lot of steps to get to the castle, we arrived just in time to have the guided tour in English (free of charge). This was very good indeed, with Fatima doing a fabulous job of explaining all about the history of the castle and the people who lived and worked and fought there.If you don't want to climb all those hills and up those steps, get the number 12 tram!

Great Views. Visited Castelo de Sao Jorge on a bright spring morning. It will take some effort to walk up the hill to get to the entrance, but the views are worth it. Sweeping views over the harbor and city center. Probably the best views in all of Lisbon.The castle itself is reduced largely to the castle walls. There is a small archeological dig site on the edge of the castle grounds, but unless you are a history fanatic, it is probably worth skipping. We did not visit the museum on the grounds.

Wonderful Castle. The Castelo de Sao Jorge is historically interesting as well as offering superb views of Lisbon.. Reached by foot, taxi or tram the journey is worth it. The Romans, Moors and Christians all resided at this place and excavations are continuing.

Not to be missed. It may be 7 euros to get in but my wife and I arrived at 9 and didn't leave until gone 2 and we were not bored once.You could possibly walk to each point of interest in the castle in about an hour and a half but if you want to appreciate what you are seeing and the wonderful views the best part of the day is advised.In the heat there was a cool breeze and shady spots to relax; you can take your own picnic; coffee is a very reasonable price.Arrive by tram 12E to the start of Rua do Sao Tome (immediately after an uphill bend with such a camber that the side of the trram nearly hits the wall!!). This stop is at the bottom of a triangle - go up the left side and exit left and follow the road/track straight through.

Old and new. View from the castle is magnificent. Walk along walls is very nice. The place is crowded so try fairly early in the morning. And not forget about something to wear on - the wind is rather cold (late April)
More of a ruin..... More of a ruin than a castle but worth it for the views alone. It is quite good fun scaling the turrets also. The walk down is lovely and the alfama is worth a ramble through

Good views. Pleasant place for a beer with the view, and moderately interesting walking around the walls, however the archeological site and museum are distinctly underwhelming, and the view is nearly as good from the Zambezi terrace.

Forgetable Except fpr the Vies. The castle is a beautiful view from all over Lisbon and it is the view from the top that makes the trip there memorable. The actual Moorish ruins are not dissimilar to those one can see throughout coast Portugal and Spain. The museum did a very poor job of explaining the history of the castle and the way everyday life took place during it's various periods of occupancy
Great Views. I'd say its a place for history buffs; there are many places we've visited that are more special but the prominence of its location is special and the museum of artifacts is worthwhile.

Beautiful Views. One of the best things we did while in Lisboa. The views are outstanding and the Moorish castle remains are interesting. Make sure it's one of the best weather days you have so you don't miss anything, wear comfortable shoes are there are a lot of stairs.
Wonderful View of the City. Nice castle, brilliant location to see the whole of Lisbon. Must see! Wonderful time. To reach the castle there is some gradient, but well worth the visit.

Nice views of Lisbon from the castle. We took the number 12 tram to the top. It is the best way to get there from the city. There is still a small climb, but it is worth it. The view from the castle and the walk around inside was pleasant. Additionally we happened across a special exhibition of a telescope/periscope in one of the towers. It allows a person to get a real life view of Lisbon in some detail, as the operator moves the telescope around the areas of the city. The show is given in Portuguese, Spanish and English. on the half hour each. language. You can return from the Castle by tram 12 or a small local bus to the city. We bought a one day travel pass at 6.50 euro in a metro station. This allowed us to hop on and hop off buses trams or the metro.
Great views. Full of history and provides a great panoramic view of the city. It's a nice hike up to the Castle. Wear comfortable shoes.

Incredible Historical Site. The Castle is always in site while you are walking the streets of Lisboa, looking down upon you awaiting you visit to her beautiful grounds and architecture. Some advice: take a cab or better yet the Grey Line tour hop on hop off bus. Whatever you do....GO! The views of the city along are worth the effort. We spent several hours at the castle and so enjoyed our leisurely walk around the grounds, a coffee in the cafe and meeting some very nice people.
A wonderful viewpoint for seeing the city. The oldest part of the city, and a museum showcasing archeological finds. Quite a climb to get to the entrance, but Tram 12 makes the going easy!

The best views in Lisbon. If you have the strength to climb the hill (better to take a taxi) to this ancient restored castle, it's well worth a visit. The views of Lisbon are breathtaking and the castle ruins are interesting as well. Take good shoes, the cobblestones are tough on the feet.

Amazing Views and Lots of History. You can see all of Lisbon from the top when the weather is clear. Be prepared for some very steep steps and a very steep hill from the Tram 28 stop to the castle.You won't regret the effort.
April in Portugal. The castle is wonderful and is a don't miss for Lisbon. The views from the Castle walls are worth the entrance fee. Seniors get a great discount!!

How to get nice view?. Sao Jorge Castle is one of the "must seen" in Lisbon. Beautifully located over the city with astonishing view. There are possibilities to climb and walk over the walls. Street musicians who are there makes the ambient even more interesting. Traveler will appreciate shadows of the old trees. Around the fortress you can find nice shops which are not more expensive than in downtown.Only where I find problem is how to get there. If you choose old tram line 28 you will be in problem because you don't know where to step down. I missed the best station and goes until the last tram station. From there there are many narrow streets lacking any signs which will lead you to the castle. Entrance is not well signed. My suggestion is to take taxi which can bring you just in front of the ticket office. For the way back walk down and enjoy in the view, churches, nice shops and ambient.
Must see views of Lisbon. The most authentic and historic spot in town. This old castle is interesting and has amazing views of the city below.
Really interesting. This is an ancient place with lots to learn and amazing views to enjoy. Easy to get to although you may wish to conserve walking around energy and take the bus up there
A must. This castle is a must when visiting Lisbon, it offers great shady views of the entire city and the castle itself is very interesting and nice to walk around in.
Good. It is an interesting castle and it has a good little museum. It has amazing views of Lisbon.However, I thought it was a bit too expensive and with not enough going on to justify the price.

Best views in town. Well worth a visit. Incredible views over the city make some great photos. Get the tram up there to add to the experience - metro day ticket includes travel on the tram. Only downside was long queues to purchase entrance ticket.

Spectacular. Well worth the long hike up the hill! The castle grounds are extensive, so you feel you are getting your money's worth for sure. Aside from the few areas still undergoing exacavation, the castle feels relatively untouched for the past centuries, which make for a great tour. Walk over all the walls and see the city from every view. Every view is spectacular. If your camera still takes film, save it for this place.

views from the fortifications. The castle itself is empty, nothing much to see inside ! but what is nice about this castle is the walk that you can take on the walls of the castle with tremendous views over the city as well as beautiful gardens and pine trees around that create relaxing atmosphere.

A truly ancient place -- not over-restored. This is neither the grandest nor the best preserved castle I've visited, but its site -- high above Lisbon and the river creates a magical atmosphere. This was enhanced by the peacocks and partridges that roamed freely there. The houses that clustered around the castle walls fit in well too. I walked around the nieghborhood after seeing the castle and was distressed that so many of these old and charming homes are tumbling down. The economic crisis!
Excellent views. The castle is only the outer walls that you can climb all over on, but the views of the city are spectacular!

A must-see attraction. We found the long upward climb to the castle to be difficult at times, but, once there, it was worth the trip. You get the best views of Lisbon, great photo opportunities, and wonderful cobblestone paths all around the castle. Tame peacocks walk nearby and you can sit & have coffee outside. The whole scene takes one back to a bygone era and is amazing.

Beautiful View of the City. Although I visited the castle on a rainy day, it still provided a lovely view of the city. As with most attractions and things to do in Portugal, admission was not expensive. Until I visited the castle, I did not get a true understanding of the size and appearance of the city. Within the castle, there are various sets of stairs and elevated areas from which you can view the city. Because there are so many small, winding, and cobblestone streets in Lisbon, visiting the castle and marvelling at the city provides a much better feel for the Portuguese capital. There are also seated areas surrounded by trees (and peacocks!), making for a lovely break or snack during a hot summer's day. And just outside the castle, at the bottom of the hill, you can catch the 28 tram, the most well-known tram ride in Lisbon, which provides another great view of and feel for the city. Overall, the castle is a great attraction, whether you are traveling solo, with friends or with family.

Worth to visit. There is a great view over the city of Lisbon from Castelo de Sao Jorge. Entree will cost you around €7,50, but it's worth it as the castle (more ruin) gives you the feeling you're back in the 6th century.

worth it for the view alone. i think your experience of this site has a lot to do with the weather and how packed it is. I went on a Friday evening as the sun was going down and had the perfect hilltop view of Lisbon. however trying to actually find you way into the Castelo is a nightmare. there is NO signage and so you feel you way following tourists and the odd directional sign from a local. the tickets booth is inside the gate (ticket is 7.50) and really what you are paying for is the opportunity for the view. the battlements, gardens are all nice. the peacocks have run of the place and make enough noise to scare off any cats that are looking for an easy meal. there is a small museum, plenty of cafes. my advice is to double up this with a trip to Se Cathedral - when you come out of the gate veer left down the steep roads until you see the imposing cathedral building.

Fantastic Views of the City. The castle has been well preserved and for 7.50 Euros you can wander around the grounds for as long as you like. The Ulysses tower tour is part of your ticket and allows you to view the panoramic views of the city through a kaleidascope invented by Leonardo Da Vinci.
Lovely views.. It was also fun scrambling up and down the walls. Pleasant shady areas for a hot day. Certainly a "don't miss" attraction in Lisbon.

Nice Castle with Fantastic Views. The castle is nice to explore and the views of Lisbon are amazing. The museum has a lot of great artifacts from the 16th-17th centuries. You can climb to stair to the top of castle walls.

Majestic views. Stoney walls, very high paths between turrets to walk along (vertigo sufferers will feel queasy) , well kept gardens, views of the orange-roofed city, and peacocks performing courtship dances while you sip coffee. Best attraction in Lisbon.

Amazing View!. This is one of the most interesting castles I have been to. Its position on the hill overlooking the city provides for amazing views from any angle. I highly recommend spending a few hours walking the walls and taking in the sights and sounds of Lisbon.

interesting although slightly overrated. a pleasant afternoon - wonderful views of Lisbon. Atmospheric with musicians playing fado. Wonderful peacocks - they offer half hourly entertainment in themselves. Needs further development in terms of what they offer to tourists - little info around so you don't need more than 1-1.5 hours for this trip. Really interesting street-seller when we were there selling jewellery made from coins - fascinating!

Not much to see. We had been told that the Castle was a 'must' - perhaps we had expected too much. The views are probably great (on a clear day!) but there is little to see. The castle is in ruins and there is only a small museum which is indoors

Great views across the city!. We visited the castle on a day with weather that was a little tempremental to say the least! However when the rain stopped the views across the city were amazing and there were some wonderful viewpoints surrounded by the castle's history to take your time with. However, I found that the castle pretty much just stood alone, there wasn't many tourist parts to it, giving information about its history etc and the guide was very brief. Saying that, the entrance fee was reasonable, about 7E each and so was worth the fee. I didn't feel very safe climbing up the castle, the stairs were very exposed without railings and with it being wet I was worried of a slip! But worth a visit all the same if you are in the city.

Wish I'd brought my son here when knights were his passion. Great place to imagine pouring boiling oil on the invaders, and lots of slot windows to shoot arrows through. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit which my son would have enjoyed a few years back. Lots of high walls to see views, and turrets too. If you are a health and safety freak or little unsteady on your pins, this isn't the place for you - trip hazards galore!

A View to the City's Past. The Castle has a commanding view of the city and is a very pleasant place to explore. The view of the City is excellent and it includes a museum, an archeological dig and restaurant so it is easy to spend time there. It is about a half hour climb by foot from Baixa (there are lots of shops and restaurants along the way) or you can take the tiny street car (#28) which is a very interesting ride through steep, narrow streets which brings you near the Fort. We felt the visit was quite worthwhile but suggest visiting the site when the weather is good.
Excellent. Loved this castle. Wonderful views and historical value. Be sure to take a tram if you don't want to walk up a very steep incline.

Nice view, interesting spot.. Worth the admission fee to go in and walk around for an hour. If you're afraid of heights, however, you may not want to pay to go in as most of the best viewing areas are on small, high catwalks.
Wonderful. A must see, wonderful views of the city of Lisbon from many directions. Everything about this place was great

Best view of the city!. Easily the best views of the city are from the vantage point of the castle walls. The castle has lots to explore and ideal also for kids, but keep an eye on them, there are some very high walls you can access! There is a nice wee cafe in the centre (which we did visit), and also a nice restaurant (which we didn't, but heard good things about) a highlight for my nephew was the free roaming peacocks in the main courtyard area. Definitely advised to visit during the the morning as it can get very busy, with long queues to get in, and make sure you know how to get in, as the winding roads can be confusing.

Castle visit. A superb visit - if you are in any way elderly or disabled, less than agile, it's a very steep climb from the nearest public transport. We got a taxi from Marquis de Pombal square which took us rught up the hill and only cost 6euros 40 ( and there were 4 of us) The whole area around the castle is worth a visit and the views over Lisbon are superb. We had lunch at a restaurant up there and it was definitely not a rip-off.
Great view; nice castle. The most impressive view of the city (along with the Santa Justa elevator) in a nice historic place.

Great views and interesting site. This is a worthwhile attraction, mostly for the beautiful views of the city from the promenade surrounding the historical site. It makes for a pleasant around and within the castle structure and on top of its walls with views capturing the eye from every angle.Having said that, the castle itself if placed anywhere else would seem a bit empty and underdeveloped for the potential that is there and the price charged for entrance. There is much potential for development in terms of exhibition space, audio-visual presentations, and maybe even theatrical enactments, all seem to be missing from such a beautiful site.Overall, it is a must attraction, while in Lisbon, which has so much more potential than what's currently on offer.

Get there early.. My wife and I really enjoyed the Castle. It's a big castle and you can spend a couple of hours there. But get there early if the weather is nice as the ticket line can get pretty long.

Better than anticipated. I really enjoyed the views at this castle. It is bigger and better than the reviews I read. It is well preserved and clean. Also, located in the middle of everything. You can take a cab to the castle and then walk down to the center of town.

Great Castle with nice views. It was the first place where a ticket for 2 adults with 2 kids was CHEAPER than a ticket for two :)This is a great idea and would love to see such promotions in more places. The castle is well preserved, has really nice views over the older parts of Lisbon. When going up the hill you will pass by the famous Urinols. It tends to be crowded in the weekends, so be aware as you might be stuck waiting for tickets.

Lovely Gardens. We paid €7,5 for one adult and €4 for one student. The major attraction of the castle are the beautiful gardens, hidden corners and the views it offers from Lisbon. The museum was not exceptional, and the restaurant looked nice but expensive.

Expensive, not sure if worth it.. Large queues to buy a ticket, get there early. High prices for what it is - €12!Good views across the town, nice little museum, the rebuilt, open-to-the-air castle walls good for a quick walk around.

CASTELO BONITO. A National Treasure, well preserved castle in Lisbon. Great views. Big birds in the premises.Unless you are a top athlete do not attempt to walk up the hill. A bus or a Taxi can take youup there for a reasonable fee. If you enjoy views be aware of the weather conditions beforeyour trip.

Greg views over city. Suggest you get a taxi up to castle as it is very steep to walk and the taxi was very reasonable price .We spent a brief time here overlooking the city and walked the walls with a guitarist playing in the quad.

Lots of walking, but worth it. There is a lot of walking on uneven cobblestones to get to this castle, but once you're there it's worth it. The caste itself, the grounds, the views of the city, even the cafe. We had a great time, although by the time we got on a tram part-way down, we could hardly walk!

The view of Lisbon.... Castelo de Sao Jorge was built in 11th century during the Moorish period. It is located on the highest point of the city with the natural slopes from all sides. The castle was built mostly for defense and not as a residence. It has eleven towers, the most noted are: Tower of the KeepTower of Ulysses, Tower of St.Lawrence and Palace Tower. On the northern wall there is a small door called the Door of Treason, which allowed the messengers to enter and exit in secret. Later, the King Alfonso Henriques modified and enlarged the castle to accommodate his Court. By 13th century the castle was transformed intothe Royal Palace, but in 1755 during Lisbon earthquake, most of the castle was destroyed.

Preserve of peacocks. The massively solid Castelo San Giorgio, perched on one of the highest points adjacent to the Chiado and Praca do Comercio, dates from the 11th Cent. but has passed through many phases, including that of being a Royal Palace ( 13th Cent.), and a military barracks for the then ruling Spanish army ( 17th Cent.). Its walls are massive, wide, and very extensive. Of its eleven towers, four offer accessible viewing platforms. They are integrated into an exciting walk of over 300 meters along the walls that reveals every part of the city, and in its grounds and parks there are other belvederes that extend the viewing opportunities. It was badly affected b y the 1755 earthquake, and partial ruins of earlier constructions are to be seen in the gardens, Its visitors can choose from a large cafe and a fine Michelin-recommended restaurant (Casa Do Leao: operated by the Pousada organization and open from 12.30 to 11pm) where we enjoyed an excellent and affordable lunch. A Camera Obscura following a design by Leonardo da Vinci ( not working because of bad weather during our visit) and a modest Archaeological Museum are other attractions the Castelo offers. There is no finer Castle in all of Europe: its privileged position, and outstanding state of preservation and reconstruction, as well as its superb amenities, are cutely complemented by a large flock of variously-colored peacocks who arrogantly strut around as if they own he place, taking no nonsense from the tourists.

Great restaurant. I was there in January for an anniversary dinner and it was a wonderful experience. We didn't really see the castle, but only the outside going towards the restaurant. We had a beautiful warm evening, full moon, great views of Lisbon. The restaurant is great, the food was amazing, and so was the service. You may or may not be impressed by the castle, but i definitely recommend a dinner at this restaurant.

Lots of history with great views. Very interesting with history going back to the Iron Age. A nice museum etc. get there early to buy your entrance tickets and to avoid the huge queues! I paid €4•00 as a senior citizen. It was great value. The restaurants just by the castle walls are great value.

Lisbon on a plate. A wonderful view of old and new Lisbon and the River Tago.Nice walking or pic nic place too.The Alfama amd Mouraria neighbourhoods just below the castle are also worth a walking visit.

Great, and very atmospheric, after sun-down. The castle, though a little on the pricey side for admission (7 euro; which is a lot by Portuguese standards), is a great place to visit for exploration of its ramparts and various towers. It offers a commanding view over the city. It really comes into its own at night (open till 9pm), being one of very few castles that keeps its doors open to the wandering public after hours and where the operators are surprisingly laissez faire about visitors safe conduct in the dark, given the narrow walkways, very low railings and perilous drops. Also, the calling of the peacocks at sunset can be quit atmospheric.The castle doesn't offer much in the way of traditionally decorated rooms or artefacts, but it is a great place for being free to explore and to get an impression of what it must have been like to stand guard back in the day.

Very well preserved and interesting. Very impressed by the castle. Very well preserved and nice to be able to wander around and take in the wonderful views without any kind of guided tour. It was €6 entrance with the Lisbon Card. One word of warning - be very careful with toddlers, as there are lots of drops and low walls to plunge over!

great until our phone got pinched. we had a nice start to the day and headed to see the castle. Unfortunately it was raining heavily so we took shelter in a cafe til it eased. Some time afterwards as we approached the castle we discovered our iphone had been stolen which put a dampner on the morning and although we are normally careful travellers, we never worked out how this could have happened as no one bumped into us or seemed to come close enough to pickpocket us so beware

Awesome views. This is probably one of the best views you can see of Lisbon. High on the hill the castle is not much to look mostly exterior walls and grounds. Lots of peacock and cats. You can climb the battlements but be careful of the small staircase.

Great views, but the Castelo not among the great in Europe. The views from the Castle are great but you can get similar from a nearby lookout. It is a nice castle, but If you are short for time and, even more so, if you are counting your Euro, then I would save the fee for a more interesting Castelo.

What do you expect from a ruin?. OK, so everyone tells you to go to St. George's Castle. But it is just one more archeological ruin. Another set of old walls and broken-down structures. And pricey to get in. Enjoy the view from the outside and save some euros.

Beautiful views. Easy to get up here with the 28 tram. Once inside the visitor is treated to beautiful views of the city. Afterwards you can climb the castle walls for even more views. Nice open courtyards inside and a fun place to visit. Only downside is there is very little (if any) signage giving facts about the different areas. But that being said the views are incredible and make the visit worth it.

Great blend of old and new. Surprised to discover that only a portion of the castle is original. Outer walls are a recent re-construction for the mid 1900's but the interior to a large art is original. A pleasant location for lunch and the ramble the ramparts. Views of the city are wonderful and sunset, in particular, is magnificent.

Amazing views!. Must visit the Castle if for nothing else but the views! However, there's so much more to it than just the views. Take along Paolo from Lisbon Explorer and have him share the history of the place with you. He will even take you through the small but very interesting museum there. It's definitely worth the visit!

Interesting Castle. On the top of one of the hills in Lisbon, this historical Castle offers a great view of the lovely city. Many interesting spots to explore. One mixed thing was that there were many Peacocks which excreted around the WC. You may put your eye on them when passing down them.

Castle in th clouds. It was raining but the trip was worth the money.A must is to climb the castle tower and walk around the battlements.Breath taking views over Lisbon.If you only do one thing then this is it.

Good views. The castle was beautiful but also difficult to access. The walls are interesting and once you have climbed the steep steps you can walk around and look over the roof tops. We were asked about access as they are planning to make it more user friendly,dont know how they will do that without affecting the ancient fabric of the building.

A great view over the city. Spent a morning here and it really has spectacular views of the city and the river... Admission fee is E7.50 into the castle. Once inside there are plenty of steps- some of which are quiet step and uneven. Stair wells do not have rails so its not for those unsteady on feet. Worth a visit
A great view of Lisbon from the Castle. It's quite a climb up to the castle but well worth it. The views are fantastic and the castle well worth a visit.
Cat lovers. If you are a cat lover this is the place to go as there must be at least 20 of them wandering around or laying in the sun with the peacocks. Brillliant views from here over the city.

Interesting, but not extraordinary. The Castelo overlooks the city of Lisbon and is a 'must see' for any first-time visitor to the city. The entrance fee is low. The visitor can wander the castle walls and get a fine view of Lisbon from the battlements, but be warned that the stairs are original, which makes them slippery and of awkward heights (I watched one young fashionable lady try and negotiate the area in high heels - a major mistake on her part). However, after spending maybe an hour going from side to side of the castle and taking photos, there isn't much to do afterwards. The camera obscura is only available when the weather is decent (I was there on a blustery cold wet afternoon). Restaurants are available within the castle site, but there are also many right outside the walls. Parking is limited in the area, and the walk uphill can be rigorous.

Nice views over Lisbon. It was a rainy day, maybe that had some influence. The way to the castle, by tram 28, was nice. Views are also nice, but because of the rain is could be clearer.The castle and other things to see (small museum) where not much, in relation to what you pay: I liked the Morish Castle in Sintra a lot more.

Great workout!. Very steep streets leading up to castle though you can take a tram. Worth the effort. Great views over the city from the castle walls though that involves loads of steep stair climbing up and down but that just lessens the guilt when you sit down after your visit for your well deserved Portuguese pastries or wonderful wine.

Very cool place!. Outstanding view of the city from the hilltop!! Intriguing twists and turns within the walls of the castle and on the surrounding grounds. Local artisans and musicians! Cats! I was really moved by the poetry featured on the benches and grounds as well!
View to live for. U walk up the castle just to c the view . Do not count the roof tops .. Just imagine how it was build to look the way it does from this hill top ... Breath taking ...
Worth a look. You get a fantastic view of the whole city and the castle itself is very interesting. Its at the very top of a hill so wear good shoes and there are loads of steps to be climbed
Good for historical significance. The castle really only has the outside walls and courtyards, with no interior spaces that can be viewed. The view of Lisbon from the castle is great.
Nice ruin with lots of battlements. Nice and picturesque, but not a lot to absorb a person unless you like peacocks or taking photos of ruins
Worth seeing. If you are in Lisbon it is worth checking out, but it isn't anything spectacular. When I was there I saw a bunch of peacocks, which were cool.

Nice views and a relaxing wander.. Not a whole lot going on in the castle but its a old castle and i much prefer that. You can walk around enjoying the varied views of Lisbon is relative peace and for me this was the best part.There is a tiny museum in the centre of the castle that isn't great and does display some of the tiniest archaeological 'finds' i have ever seen. Its all a little bit tacked on but killed 10 minutes. The cafe in the Castle grounds is awful though. I'd give it a steer and go to one of the cafe's just outside the gate.
Beautiful views. Walking through the ruins of St George Castle you can enjoy the most beautiful views over Lisbon and on the way down walk through the atmospheric Alfama district.

Great place to visit. To get to the Castle there are many steps to climb but taxis do drive to the entrance or there is a bus / tram that stops close by.
Great views. Very picturesque. Clean cafe / wc's.
Helpful staff and very friendly.
Great for taking pics of the whole of Lisbon once at top of castle.
Would recommend a visit.

Came here for the panaromic Lisbon views. the castle St George, is well worth a paid visit for the stunning panaromic views of Lisbon.
The castle itself, i would called it a ruined ones unlike those in Edinburgh or in UK. however the views of Lisbon is stunning since this place is right on hill top.
We mix this visit with Alfama area wondering around

Great city views. Nice to amble around an ancient but renovated monument with great views all around. But be careful of the very uneven paths and steps. The periscope seemed to have disappeared though and the archeological site was not really worth the climb up and down steps especially as there was a 20 metre ground level path close by that was strangely gated off. Restaurant was also very expensive.

The view was amazing, but the site itself not so much.. Taking a walk along the walls of a majestic old castle overlooking a city is always great, and we fully enjoyed the astonishing view of the rooftops of Lisboa bathed in the sunlight of a warm day in spring. However, the site itself doesn't hold that much interesting stuff to make up for the entry price, so if you expect a full day's worth of exploration (the great Prague Castle comes to mind) you might leave just a tad disappointed.

The Lisbon View!. Is on the top of the city,. so, you can see everything from here.Really good preserve and clean. Walk in the walls is a good expierence.Don't forget your camera because you will use it!!!

Do not miss this. Fantastic place to see Lisbon from above. The tree covered terrace immediately after the entrance is a magical spot, tranquillity and elegance, following round the edge of the hill. Overall a very sympathetic and imaginative restoration job that just simply feels good. It delivers, in my view, a unique experience.The castle is a stunner - we live near to Warwick and Kenilworth castles so feel entitled to have a view. Museum has little to show but coffee shop OK.We jumped on the tram to get up the hill, and then walked around the narrow streets of upper Alfama just outside the castle walls, before strolling down back to the Baixa area. Wonderful.

fab views. I've been here on a number of occasions and never get tired of it. You can easily walk up to it through winding little streets with touristy shops or take a bus or cab. The views over Lisbon from the castle are spectacular to say the least. It's a well preserved castle, often with buskers playing to add to the atmosphere. Well worth a visit

a must see. The castle is a must see if you are visiting Lisbon. It is a beautiful building and the views from the castle are spectacular! It is at the top of a very steep hill so I would recommend getting a taxi which only costs €4 from Praco de Comercia. It cost €7.50 each for entry but you can easily spend a good few hours walking round the castle and grounds.

Beautiful view of the city.. Take the tram up the steep hills to visit the castle. The view of Lisboa from the castle is amazing. Visit the museum. I enjoyed that a lot. There were peacocks on the grounds which was nice to see.
meh. The view was great, but Lisbon is full of great views. The weather was nasty, so it didn't matter that the view was good. Not much to see inside.

I would suggest you don't miss it, any of it.. I think it’s a must see. Plan on spending a half day. Climb up up up to the top of the city, then up to the castle parapets for fantastic views of the city. Very nicely kept. Steep high staircases have railings. Take the 28E tram or 737 bus from the lower part of the city (on Rua Conceição, which runs perpendicular to Rua Augusta near the big arch.) You’ll still have to walk uphill a bit from the bus/tram stop, but if I could do it, so can you. The ticket office is before you get to the castle entrance. Look for the sign on the right and don’t get distracted by the stairs next to it. Not the castle stairs. The castle is a little further up the street. But do make sure you go across the drawbridge (no water) and into the castle, climbing to the very top walls, although the beautiful settings outside the “moat” are worth the time spent. High parapets are only accessible by stairs so strollers are prohibitive but still a great place below for kids. If you found my review helpful, please click on “yes.” Thanks.

Beautiful views, fascinating history.... The Castle of St. George looms large over Lisbon, and is definitely worth a visit. More of a fortress than a castle, stocked with cannons and other relics of a much earlier time, including a recreation of Da Vinci's Camera Obscura. Kids (ages 6 and above) will love walking on the castle walls and climbing the towers, and the views of the city and ocean are really breathtaking. And do not miss the ruins from the old Roman and Moorish precursor castles (ask security to let you through the ropes to take a look, they are more than happy to oblige). However, this is NOT a place for younger children. Stairs are steep, and railings are not ubiquitous. Further, there are dangerous gaps between stairs and railings that a younger child could slip and fall through if a parent looks away for even a second. Carrying strollers up those stairs could prove exhausting, and there aren't many places to leave your personal items. Finally, bring comfortable shoes- all of the cobblestone, tile and rock floors will seriously test your feet. If you're feeling up to it afterwards, I recommend walking down the streets of Alfama, the neighborhood is fascinating.
Amazing view!. Everyone visiting Lisbon must go to the Castle to enjoy the view and also have an idea of the whole city. Beautiful rock construction. The surroundings are very interesting too.

Views are worth the effort. We found that the views over lisbon were the highlight ofour visit to the Castelo de Sao Jorge. The ruins are interesting but be warned it requires a lot of care to navigate around the castle walls (especially when there are lots of of other fellow travellers around)

nice view of city. walk up to the castle on the hill, nice architecture, and when you get to the top, there's a nice view of the city, expect to pay double for a beer and crisps at the kittle cafes around the castle, but at 4EU it wasnt to bad, if you come from England
Not an awful lot to see.. There's not a lot up there apart from hazardous, but interesting battlements to climb up and walk along. Worth a visit though. Tremendous views of the city and river.

A nice museum. To be honest I did not know what to expect. The castle is accessible by bus. You can also walk to it. It has a great museum that explains the history of the site. You can walk on the castle wall, which offer a great 360 view of Lisbon.
great views. be careful its quite rocky ... great views over the entire city... interesting display of very old artifacts.

wonderful views. I walked up the hill to see the castle the first day after arrival. It was already later - short after18 pm, got around there and we were not allowed in any more!! The castle closes its gate at 18pm and we learned that the last entry is at 17.30. So we were bit dissapointed same as several people around, but the gate guards were strict. The next day we went earlier and found out that tram number 12 goes up there. We took the tram and it was very adventurous ride. We got off stop earlier and walked the rest.Entry to the castle is 7,50 eur but its definitely worth it!! The castle area is quite big and because its on a hill there are wonderful views. You can go up to the fortress and walk on the top of the castle walls. Here I suggest to take comfortable best soort shoes. Going up the castle walls is nothing for those who have highs fear. It can also be and at my visit there, it was very windy! Definitely go there for the great view of Lisabon!On the way back we went few streets down and then found free elevator that took us down to Baixa.

Enjoyable. I enjoyed my visit here, wandering around the ramparts, lunch at the cafe with the peacocks for company, good views of the city and along the way you can take in other sights like the Se Cathedral and wander around the neighbourhood. Walk up to the castle or catch tram number 28.

Worth a visit!. As a castle lover, I would say this castle is well preserved in such a nice place where you can see the Tejo River, located in Alfama neighborhood. So after visiting the castle, allow yourself to get lost in the narrow streets of this nostalgic place.
You have to visit. Its a huge castle , amazing location, uphill so you will have to walk uphill for a while but the way is lot of fun itself , beautiful building you have to visit.
Good on a nice day and for kids that need to run around. Took our time getting there via Tram 28. Nice destination and good place for kids who need to run around a bit.

Lovely walk up through the cobbled streets with the castle above. The walk was lovely up the narrow cobbled streets to the castle.
We did not go inside as the entrance fee was offputting.
Loved watching the peacock strutt his stuff on the castle walls and stopping off the small cafe/cake shop which was nearby.
The cappuccino was very good and the cakes especially the apple tartlett was tasty and fresh.

A real castle!. Wonderful castle. Wear flat shoes! The pavements of Lisbon are a challenge anyway - but the steps of the castle are steep as one would expect. Fabulous views from the top. It could do with a few more placards of what is what but the information provided is in English so easy to understand!

Of course!. A must!
Took Tram 28 to Graça, and walked down (can stop at Sé if you carry on down, towards Baixa and Praça do Commercio at the bottom, by the river
Great view of city and river
One way to retrace Lisboa/Portugal's history - from the Moors on

a nice view on the City. St. George's Castes is an old castle with hot that much interest:for sure is not a nice and well conserved building.But from there you can see an astonishing view of Lisbona and all the surroundings.This is the nice part of it that makes this visit necessary

Nice view, but not that much to do. You get a good view for sunset, but you can get that for free in Alfama. It wasn't the most interesting castle I have ever been to, but it was OK, it's good to work up an appetite so you don't feel so guilty on eating all the incredible food.
Well preserved and great views. Great views over the city and worth the walk around the walls. Small museum and nice terraced cafe. Take the tram to get here as worth the ride.

Beautiful, peaceful and a pleasant walk about. Wonderful views over the city and a pleasant walk about the castle can fill a sunny morning for both adults and children. The snoozing cats and the sound of live guitar music within the castle walls made a very siesta in the sun.
Beautiful place. Clean, beautiful, organized, with amazing views of Lisbon, a distinct romantic charm about it and many many cats and pheasants in the courtyard. Don't miss it!

Amazing site to visit. Really nice place to see, especially when weather is good. Nice views over whole Lisbon. It took us more that 3 hours to went through whole areal of the castle. I really reccomand periscore (in price of basic admission which is 7,50 EUR) - it took cca 30 mins and we sam every part od Lisbon. Castle is easy accesible via tram 28 or bus from Praca de Figueira.

Great View of Lisbon. Castelo de S. Jorge is one of those "must see touristic stops" in Lisbon. My reviews are always biased by the fact that I have small children and of course I'm influenced by their experience at the place as well as mine. I think if I was traveling just with my husband, I would've given this attraction a "very good" rating, but with my twin toddlers tagging along, I have to give it a "good" review. The reason why it's because it has a lot of dangerous spots for small children, so one has to be very attentive at all times, which ends up impacting your own experience. Neverthless, my girls had a good time, lots of space for them to run. There is also a museum and the views of Lisbon are beautiful.

Interesting Castle with Great Views. Very interesting castle with lovely city and sea views. Good English information. Bit of a hike up from the city so use the tram or bus. Find the nice port shop nearby for refreshments!

Castelo de Sao Jorge. Interesting castle. Lots to see and do. Nice period building. Lots of sightseers the day we were there and a line up to get in but it moved swiftly and we are on our way in no time. Better shopping the farther you get away from the castle. A lot of the same items but cheaper. Also found a great jewellery shop near our hotel.

Beautiful views. It was a nice walk up to the castle (beware lots of stairs, but very manageable if you're fit) through the old tiled houses and narrow lanes. The highlight of the castle was the awesome view of Lisbon and walking through the old castle walls.

Views of the city, nice place to visit. There is nothing that spectacular about the castle. It is nicely kept, the views are amazing and if you like old stones it is the place to go. The museum is small but give you an idea of what happened during the earthquake. All in all, good place to visit.

a good view but not much to the castle. it is at the top of lisbon and a good walk but you can take a tram to the front, if you can get on board really not but to see as it is mostly just a walk threw on the top of lisbon overlooking the city really not much left of the orginal castle but the senior fare of 4 euro makes it worth a visit

A view over Lisbon. Amazing view all over Lisbon. Situated in one of the hills surrounding Lisbon. From there you can see the old city and close to the horizont line you may find other castles from the defensive belt.

Lovely views, good museum. Some lovely views from the castle as expressed by other contributors.Must briefly mention the museum- it is small but executed with care and a really sensitive touch. Good exhibits and clear descriptions accompany the artefacts set in a carefully executed display. Impressed.

Beautiful castle with an amazing view of the city. I loved this castle... my only complaint is that I can't take my mother here since it's at the top of a big hill and includes lots of stairs (she doesn't walk well). I took a ton of photos here.

Awesome Views of Lisbon. This is a castle that dates back to Moorish times and has a rich history most notably during the Crusades. The caste ruins are completely 'open air' (eg no enclosure) so I wouldn't recommend this attraction on a rainy day. You can climb up the castle steps and walk the perimeter wall which I highly recommend - but be careful - there is little guarding or rails to support you. Great climbing for older kids, but I would be wary walking the perimeter with little ones. But once on the walls, the views are breathtaking. There is also some type of bird sanctuary & we saw beautiful peacocks strolling around the grounds - a nice surprise.

Nice castle. After wandering aroud the city we stopped off at this castle for a little break. There is plenty to exolore and look at. If it's a nice day bring a lunch as there are loads of places to sit and relax. There was a peacock just wandering around when we where there, it was a bit random!
Worth a visit. Great place to overview Lisboa. Best reached by Taxi, as signage from the Tram or Bus can be confusing.

I have seen better. Differently from many castles, this one is just a military post, i.e. no rooms to visit. While the view is nice, it is not the only place from where you could enjoy it, and here you have to pay a fee...All in all, for a week end visit, leave it out. If you stay longer, and got bored, it can be included.

Visit at dusk, and be amazed. After exploring the city center, we decided to take a chance and see if we could visit the Alfama district as well. We visited the castle at dusk, and it was amazing. The view is astonishing, and well worth the trip, but seeing this beautiful coastal city in the evening sun was simply unbelievably beautiful. Very impressive and romantic.

St. George's Castle, Lisbon. Fabulous Castle, full of historical interest and with spectacular views over the city. Full of nooks and crannies and the walk on the castle walls is fascinating.and quite amazing.
Great view over the city. Great view over the city, you can see from there on both sides. You can get there coming from the certer and then get back on a different route, through Alfama area.
The view!. It has a great view of Lisbon! You can also eat something here and walk around the castle. Don't forget your camera!

Worth the Effort without the Graffiti. By far the best vantage point to view Lisbon. The walk around the castle walls was also quite unique. Walk back through the windy narrow alleys and streets to the bottom. Buy the post cards outside the gate for 30 vice 50 inside. Not much in the way of guided tours or friendly guides - just stone faced security staffers who don't add to what was a great experience. Well worth the effort for a few hours of exploring without the graffiti ridden streets and walls of downtown.

go for the view!. it's hard to explore Lisbon and not see the famous moorish castle perched up on it's hill. I do hesitate to call it a "must see", especially if you have limited time in the city like we did but definitely go for the views. You can see clear over the Tagus river with Cristo Rei in the distance, Alfama, Rossio Square, and other sights as well. This is especially dramatic at sunset. If these views are of no particular interest, however, i should warn you that these are basically ruins more than anything. no suits of armor.... no torture chamber...... this isn't the Tower of London. You will see some cannons aimed toward the city however! There were some excavation efforts being done which was of no real interest to me but others might find neat. Be careful with the steps as some of them are "dusty" and slippery as a result. no handrails either. I almost lost my balance twice descending a flight of stairs which could have proved disasterous. There is a restaurant on site and bathrooms also. Admission was about € 7,50 eachTake tram #28.. it drops you off right in front

Awesome views. Place to go, especially during afternoon or sunset.Awesome views over the city, Tagus river, Bridge and Cristo Rei statue.There is a restaurant, inside the Castle, called Restaurante Casa do Leão (Pousada de São Jorge), which is fabulous, but expensive.

Stunning views in very scenic neighbourhood. The whole area around the castle is great to walk around, ending at the castle for some awe inspiring views. There are many typical restaurants, shops etc around and many things to see. Next door Alfama neighbourhood is also a must!

Best view of Tejo River. This is one of the postal cards of Lisboa. Although its historical interest, the main thing about going there is the view it offers. And from he castle, you can go downhill to Alfama, the oldest neighborhood of Lisboa.

is the view worth the entrance fee?. we didn't pay the entrance fee just to get the view, do a couple of miradores and you'll have something better, nicer and coller to sit. we did browse through the little streets but that's a quick stroll since it's tiny
