Take the 28 tram up to the top of the mountain in the center of Lisbon and walk around the castle. 360 views of the city. There are also some really good, fair priced cafes and wine bars to explore on your way down.

Definitely work your time.. We had a wonderful guide, Catia Luis. Our group of 8 really enjoyed the entire experience. It's a beautiful spot above Lisbon. We took a tram and bus. But, some people walked.

Best of Lisbon. Maybe its the best sight to visit in lisbon. Take a bus that leaves you outside the entrance, and have a walk inside the castle. You can sit in it's gardens for hours. Also, do not miss the guided tour With the periscope. Its short but it tells you everything you need to know about city.
Great view!. The castle was a nice way to spend the afternoon! The views over the city are unparalleled. Nice thing to see/do in Lisbon.

Fabulous views. An interesting place to visit with fabulous views over the city. For a a glimpse into the history I would recommend waiting to look through periscope - our guide was knowledgeable and the views were fascinating.

Stunning vista. Its a great day to spend and take in the city view of Lisbon walking around the different pathways. beyond that there really isn't much to see in terms of a " castle" its mostly the outer structure of a castle.
Brill. A lovely day out. Lots to see and explore. Remember not all steps have handrails!
Great views - nice site. Worth going to for just the views. No furnished areas - more if a fort really. But still some nice history and fun to explore.
A view to die for!. A brilliant castle to visit with stunning views of the whole city especially during sun set.

classic castle. Castle is another must see experience; well worth the climb or the tram trip. views from the top are amazing. Do visit the periscope in the Ulysees tower; amazing 360 degree views of lisbon really put the town into perspective; talks are structured in different languages in 30 min blocks. Cafe a bit non descript and expensive for what it offers and shop on site also very expensive.

It's a must. the 12 or 28 tram will get you up there. It's a schlep otherwise. Fantastic views, although not much really to see. A very nice walk around and a quiet space if you go mid to late afternoon, when the tourist buses have left.
Castelo. Well worth the entrance fee. Take a picnic.. nice cafe too and just relax..

Amazing. So well preserved and yet open to the public - not all roped off and guarded the way so many historic sites ordinarily are. One can literally wander around this ancient site completely alone - to take in at your own pace. When I was there, second week in June, there were no crowds at all. Most of my pictures are of the castle and scenery - no humans even in the background (pretty amazing!)

Beautiful place to escape the city for few hours. There is a beautiful view of Lisbon from this castle. Getting here is easy with a tram from the center of the city and entrance fee is somewhere between €5-10 for students. It's a grate place for an escape from the city for few hours with friends. Nature is beautiful, views are great, and you can simply walk through the parts of the castle and enjoy the day. Be careful to go here when the weather is good, do not go on a rainy day.

Take a bus or taxi. Like fellow reviewers have written in several reviews, the views are fabulous. Also the castle itself is nice, but quite small. Climbing up to the towers requires climbing some pretty narrow stairs, but the views from the towers are the best.We did climb up, although we happened to find an elevator (in a building in the south end of Largo da Alafona), which helped us halfway. After we got up there, being already tired from the climb, we saw the bus number 737 there. Looks like it runs every 10 minutes, starting from Praça da Figueira. I was so disappointed to see, that we could have avoided the whole climb by just taking the bus. Some people were also coming there by taxi.

Wonderful view of Lisbon. Visitors are rewarded for their steep and long climb to this castle by the breathtaking view of Lisbon and the surrounding area. The gardens are very lush and are home to some beautiful peacocks.

Great view and.... It´s worth seeing for the view it affords over the city. It took forever to get a ticket and it wasn´t such a busy day either. For the 7,50 euros (I think?), one could perhaps expect a little more?
The best part is the view!. Not much to actually see, the museum is quite small but the views are spectacular, try to get a ticket for the evening concerts they give during the summer.
Great Views. The views over the city cannot be bettered and the walk around the walls is a good one. Less sure about the camera obscura though.

History! Beautiful Castle. Amazing castle with outstanding views. Spent about 2 - 3 hours exploring and reading about the history of St. George's Castle. Take a look if you have some time, it is a great "to see". Also, I walked back down the hill from the Castle and enjoyed seeing some residential areas. It is a safe area in my opinion so take a chance and explore.
Great views. Also liked the narrow streets around it. How can these people park the way they do?

Go for the views if in the area. The lovely coloured stone walls of the castle catch your eye in most of Lisbon and the trek up there is worth it, repaying the effort with far reaching views over the city and beyond. It is rather over sold as the views are its main asset, the buildings and walls are basically archeology now. The garden areas were very quiet and relaxing when we were there, with several peacocks patrolling, watched by the Castle cats. Be aware that there are steep steps up to the ramparts and that the courtyard side on the ramparts is un-guarded. Worth including in a tour of the Alfama

It was a very nice castle to explore. It had a great overlook of the city, but I think we missed most of the fun. We were on a limited time frame so we didn't have much of a choice of when we could go. Wandering around the old castle and the archealogical site was quite nice.
Castle. Not a great deal to see but it has been well restored. Great views from the ramparts.

Not worth the walk. Just a ruin of a castle. If you want a view of the city and a lot of walking, then go. It wasn't that great and the only English tour of one section was not conveniently scheduled. The peacocks outside the restaurant were actually more interesting!

Magnificent. It was worth going to the castle if only for the tram ride up there!!!! It is a beautiful site to visit with so much history attached to it makes it a " must see " when in Lisbon and should not be missed, the cost was € 4 ( over 65 ) and we would have paid double that.
very old castle. the area around is good but found the restaurants pricey get the bus in the square that says castello and the tram back
One of the main attractions. Great location with lovely view and very interesting. Like all of Lisbons heritage attractions well maintained and cared for.

Not worth of it...... i would say it was more of a ruin, rather than a castle plus an expensive ticket for inside entry inside 8euros ..... yes the views were great, but the same can be had from other places.... if you have seen it from exteral you will find it pretty much he same on the internal side also....I would rather recommend walking from baixa chaido / praça figueira way up to the castle, seeing the narrow streets of downtown and the external of the castle. then continue walking down towards Sta. Apolonia....
Nice and cool on a hot day. Wonderful views. The area around the castle is a small town in itself

Amazing view of city. You have to buy tickets which were around $15.00 dollars a piece. The views of the city are amazing from here. There is a lot of walking to get here up and down stairs and lots of walking inside. You need to be in good health. The castle is mostly ruins. Outter walls. I would recomend this.

Perfect visit to see Lisbon from above. Beware of sunshine on a sunny day sun lotion a must..
Say hello to the peacocks

Boring castle with the expected views but little else. Really quite a waste of time and money. It is a castle, with ramparts and some very uneven paths. There is very little interpretive explanation and aside from the views, a few cannons and some gnarled old trees this is a major league disappointment. Probably the quickest way to blow 7.5 Euro's in Lisbon. We did laugh at home much fun Health and Safely would have if this castle was in Britain. It would be fairly easy to fall over the side of some very steep steps.
Excellent views. Worth the long climb up. Was very tranquil and the views were superb.

Great view but there are great views every where in Lisbon. We finished our walking tour near the Castle area so we decided to continue upward and see the castle area. One can walk up into the enclosing walls and visit all the vendors and houses without paying for the entrance fee. Once you do pay the fee, then you can go into the ruins and photo the view. But, if you are this far up in Lisbon you have probably already photographed that view a dozen or more times. And, unless you have never seen castle ruins I would re-think paying the fee. There are 100s of photo ops at every turn without going into the ruins. Pretty doorways. Singing canaries in their cages outside people's houses. Stairs to the top of the wall for a lookout and free photo op. And, of course, lots of vendors. We milled around for quite some time in the non-ruin section, when we heard activity and saw a couple of Police motorcycyles coming into the castle entrance. So, we decided to investigate. We walked back down to the gate and there were a dozen horses and horse soldiers unmounted milling about at the entrance. Wow. This is cool. We were surprised to see tourists, horses, and military persons all mixed up in one large swarming ball. My friend, who is Spanish, asked a policeman what was happening. He said there was going to be a parade of sorts. So we waited. The horse soldiers finally got their hats on and mounted their horses. Finally, more horses and mounted riders came out of the castle gate- meanwhile 100s of tourists were squished along the side of the street. The horses had on bright silver shoes. They frequently lost their footing and slipped several inches or a couple times they slipped a foot on the sloped cobblestones. At one point, we realized if one of these horses fell we would be mashed tourists! Pretty soon, a nearly lifesize figure of St George tied to a horse came out of the castle. St George was pretty shop worn. If I understood correctly, he came out of the church within the castle and was going to another church. The horses had to continue out the gate, join the waiting horses, then go around a steep bend on a sharp slope and travel down the street. About half the horses made it around that bend when one horse lost his footing and fell. The rider was thrown off. He lost his hat, his staff, and I would imagine he was hurt. But, several military stewards came and helped him back on the horse. He reset his hat and off they went, again. We decided that it was unsafe and we wandered off away from the crowds and the horses.

A castle with wonderful views. The Castelo de Sao Jorge wqas very interesting and had wonderful views over the city of Lisbon and is well worth a visit. The castle has many trees to shade you from the heat of the sun. There are many steps to climb so do wear some comfortable shoes!
Anyone for some exercise?. Great views of the city but take a taxi rather than walking up the hill!
great views. not much in castle keep but magnificent views of city and inquisitive peacocks make it a must see.
One of My Favorites. My husband walked to St. Georges one evening at sunset. It was just georgous! And we had the pleasant surprise of a drum group playing on the steps! Perfection!
Fabulous city views. Great tram ride trip up to the castle and superb views from the top. A nice walk down through Alfama can finish the afternoon.

Great views. Tough walk to get there but worth it, the castle is nice and the views of Lisbon from the top are amazing! I liked chilling out at the cafe terrace, enjoying the great views and the pleasant atmosphere.

Worth visiting for the best views of Lisbon. While the castle is worth visiting - be prepared for a LOT of steps - the best reason to go up to the castle is to take in the breathtaking views of Lisbon's neighborhoods, and all of the tile roofs. Simply gorgeous views of Lisbon. While you can take the bus or a taxi to get up to the castle, I highly recommend walking up the hills if you are physically fit enough to do so. The neighborhoods you must walk through to get to the castle are very interesting and give you a little glimpse into the lives of some of the residents of the city.
Chill out @ the Castle. Incredible views, fantastic atmosphere, lots of stairs but so worth going to just to get away from busy touristy Lisbon. Very relaxing.
A kid's dream. No matter how old you are, your imagination will take control and you're "Prince Valiant"! This site offers great views of Lisboa as well.
The best view over old Lisbon. The castle where the city began. It has a restaurante and the most wonderful view over the old city and the Tagus River.

Beautiful views. We found little English literature available to explain the history. The walk was tough but worth it to get up there, a lovely little hole in the wall cafe with wine tasting and small bites was a great find just up the road from the castle.
nice view and beautiful castle. the tram ride was very nice to go till the castle and the interior is amazing
Fabulous views of Lisboa!. This historic castle is high above the city (a grueling walk up a steep hill--or take a bus or taxi)--and well worth the magnificent views of this wonderful city.

OK if you like that stuff. Boring if you aren't into it.. It's an OK thing to do if you like that kind of stuff. But not really that big of a deal. Great views of the city and that's about it. If you do go, make sure you take in the panoramic tour from the tower. It is offered in several languages and is included in your admission price.

Lisbon, How are we. This summer there is a fantastic cinema and light show on in the evenings. The show is wonderful and is produced extremely cleverly. It gives you a great insight into how Lisbon was established. It's an open air screening in the fort of the castle of St. George. However, here's a big tip don't bother with the 'taste of Lisbon' "dinner" before hand. It was a box of 9 pastries which were cold and really not very filling. However, do enjoy the lightshow. Congrats to the team for putting together.

Walk up and enjoy the full experience. Walk up from the city and walk around to the entrance - then explore the many aspects of the castle. We liked everything about our experience here - including the wonderful food available just outside the walks of the castle

Bit of a climb but the view is lovely. I liked this castle but as we were travelling with my father in law perhaps walking up was not the best idea.The castle is a bit tricky for those with walking difficulties but the views are delicious. We got the tram down to Liberty Square? The one with Rossi Metro station, tram and bus stops. We should have got it up as well.
What a view!!!. Excellent view over Lisbon city and Tejo river... Very well preserved with beautiful gardens
great views but thats about it. as the title states - worth it for the veiws, but not much else really.

Worth the climb!. There is a bus service up to the Castelo but we decided to walk up from near the Sé (Cathedral) - it's a heck of a climb but well worth it! Tickets for the Castelo are €7 - expect to queue at the ticket office as there are only two tills. The entrance to the Castelo is another small climb up from there, and once you're in, the views are spectacular. Brits and Americans used to tourist attractions roping off 'dangerous' things like castle battlements in the name of health and safety will enjoy the opportunity to walk along the battlements, however those with wheelchairs and buggies will not find any special access provided for them. The cafe is good and not overpriced, and there is also a smart restaurant. The whole place is a suntrap, but there are lovely breezes due to the height, so a great place to send a boiling hot afternoon.

Visit to St-George's Castle. We took the train to get to the Castle and this in itself was fun as the streets are very narrow and twisting. The walk round the Castle walls (there is not much left of the castle unfortunately) was pleasant as were the gardens around it and the views of Lisbon were stunning.
Highest spot on the town. A very nicely renovated castle and the best sport for a high view on the city

Panaramic views of Lisbon and surrounds. Wonderful experience, worth the 7eu entry fee for the views alone regardless of the castles historical value. Walk around the perimetre and take in the views from all directions across the Lisbon city, broader region, water areas etc. Well worth it.

Great views, great walk, not much castle. If you're a castle buff, this one doesn't really have much, just the main walls and a ruined interior. A pleasant walk around, fabulous views across all of Lisbon, and for a real workout walk back down to center city. The tourist trap shops around the walls (that's pretty authentic, I guess) are a little short of English but the prices are fair enough.
Worth visiting. Even if the history of the Castle doesnt interest you, its worth it for the views alone..
Excellent views - too bad there is now an entry fee. Castelo Sao Jorge is the place to take pictures showing the entire city. Too bad that there is now an entry fee, even when having the Lisboa card.
Beautiful Views. If you're not staying up near here, the 737 bus from the main square goes right up here.
Great views. Bit of a climb but worth it. Make sure you walk the walls.

Evening at the Castle. I would certainly recommend a visit in the evening as the light is phenomenal and the panoramic views spectacular over the city. We found the archaeology museum very well curated (one of the best we have ever seen) but were sad to find the actual digging site closed for viewing. Walking on the ramparts is recommended and such a romantic way to spend an evening. The Peacocks are also a feature of the visit - very beautiful and cheekily demanding ones attention. I am not one for visiting each and every castle where I go, but this one is certainly different and well worth it.

Fantastic views of Lisbon. The castle itself is a little disappointing due to the toll that time has taken on it, it;s really little more than a skeleton of what once was, but the views from the walls more than make the long walk to reach it worthwhile, a photographers dream..
Great view of Lisbon. If you like the look of the entire city from above, this is the place. I advise to use the tram to get up close to the castle because it is a long walk.
Lovely views.... Great views from inside the castle...across all directions in Lisbon. Really nicely maintained and great way to spend a few hours. Definately worth a visit when in Lisbon.

Interesting. Reasonable entry price. Despite the growing number of tourists did not find access difficult to all parts. Suggest a visit layer in the day when the tour group busses depart. Good views of lisbon

Amazing. A great view of the city, don't miss the perescope show and try to go to all the turrets, the view from each one of them is amazing.Also, try going there by foot despite the incline, it's a beautiful neighbourhood.
STUNNING VIEWS. We thought it was worth the 7.50 euros upon our entrance seeing the gorgeous courtyard & stunning views over Lisbon. An absolute must.

Not for the mobility challenged. The views of the city, the overall construction was fascinating, but there are stairs and more stairs. The ground level offers a fair amount to those who do not do stairs, but many parts are out of reach.

good views, but be prepared for the climb!. we got lost a bit looking for the castle (following directions from guidebooks leading us the wrong way!) and the weather was pretty dreadful so it wasn't a great experience. there is a tram 28 that goes to the se (cathedral) but it is still a climb up from there. think we saw a minibus which stops outside the castle, but have forgotten the number now. when we finally got to the castle, it was pretty busy and i thnk as it was a bank holiday, entrance was free. from the terrace, it's a nice view of lisbon - again would have been better with more favourable weather - and you could have a short roam on the castle ramparts. i liked the village which was next to the castle as there were some pretty shops and cafes - nice to have a little wander about. the alfama district is probably one of the first stops when someone goes to lisbon, so no doubt the castle will be on the list of places to visit. the castle itself is not particularly breath-taking nor stunning by any stretch of the imagination, but offers some good views over lisbon.
Great Scenic Place. We wandered all over the walls of the Castle, and enjoyed the views. Great place for kids too.
Great. The castle is really beautiful and offers excellent views of the city...a must see if you're in Lisbon

Easily the Best Attraction in Lisbon. The castle is quite impressively well preserved and is deceptively large. My wife and I loved climbing up its many (steep!) sets of stairs to enjoy gorgeous panoramic views of Lisbon and the river below, and we spent almost 3 hours touring this beautiful landmark on a sunny May morning.We loved the friendly resident cats sunbathing in the grass, who were all too happy to let my wife pet them. And the beautiful flock of peacocks roaming the premises made for a fun and almost surreal environment.We liked the periscope in the Tower of Ulysses which incredibly showed live 360 degree views of the entire city. It was unbelievable to watch pedestrians walking and cars driving all over the city as projected into our dark room from the periscope above. This 20 minute presentation was a great overview of the various neighborhoods and sites of Lisbon, and was perfect since we spent our first few hours in Lisbon visiting the castle.I strongly recommend visiting this castle on your first day in Lisbon. Other than perhaps the wonderful attractions in Belem, there is nothing even remotely comparable in Lisbon from a sight seeing perspective.

Magnificent!. The castle has beautiful areas and great views although walking on the walls might be scary if you have a fear of heights. Sit down for a cup of freshly squeezed orange juice but watch out for the peacocks, they obviously have used to get treats from people at the cafe tables. The castle is open until late evening, so come here for the sunset and to see the castle lit for the night.
Castle. Very well preserved and fortified castle, well worth a visit
Don't miss. Great interest.Good value. Great views. Castle itself if worth the trip alone, but the local streets are also good.

Great Castle Ruins. Well, the day I visited, the subway was not working, so my friend and I walked about 2.5 miles (3.6 km) from our hotel to the castle. The view from the terrace was spectacular; you could see all of Lisbon laid out at your feet.I found fossils embedded in some of the stairs in the castle and learned quite a bit of the Portuguese history while touring. It was a great place to walk around, but even on a Sunday in November, it was very, very crowded. It is 10 Euros for the entrance fee, but overall, I think it was worth it.

A Must See Attraction. Easily accessible by Tram 28. Beautiful,well preserved and load with local history. Discounts if you are a senior!Plan on a couple of hours and then relax with a coffee outside and have panoramic views of the city
Beautiful views. great place to view the city - not a lot to see at the castle itself but the museum is worth a visit.

Good views of the city, but the "castle" is just walls. The Castle of St. George sits atop one of the 7 hills of Lisbon and can be seen from almost everywhere. The Castle has a 7,50 euro entrance fee per person. It had been used by the Romans, the Visigoths, and the Moors and served as a Moorish royal residence until captured by the first king of Portugal in 1147, with the help of Northern European Crusaders on their way to the Holy Land. Most of the castle was destroyed over the years, but the millennium old walls remain. Inside we climbed stairs and then walked along the ramparts where we had magnificent views of Lisbon. To our surprise, the food in the cafe inside was very good. You can eat outside if the weather is nice, or eat inside. We enjoyed a very nice lunch and photographed a strutting peacock who demonstrated what it means to be “proud as a peacock.” The peacocks alone might make the visit to the Castle worthwhile, but other than that there is little to see inside other than the walls and the view of Lisbon.
Lovely Day. Remember flat shoes and an umbrella in case of rain in March

St George's Castle. Its a beautiful place the peacock stole the show :-) The only thing is I didn't think there was enough information Plaques in other languages. We'd witness something amazing and have no clue what it was

Worth a trip. We were suprised to see how nice this place really is. You have a great view of the city on a clear sunny day. The ruins are interesting to walk around. It would be better if you manage to get up there early in the morning where there will be fewer people. Take Tram 28 and climb up the hill. Don´t try the restaurants around the castle.

Expensive and not all that interesting. The castle is an inevitable stop for almost any tourist to Lisbon. The first time I visited it, in 2004, i don't think I paid an entry fee or if I did it was not that 13,50 we had to pay this trip. It is WAY too expensive for what it is, but if you've never visited a fortress before, you'll enjoy it. The museum within the grounds is nicely conceived, but rather boring. There's a nice restaurant on the grounds as well, but I didn't eat there.

Good Views!. It's a great vantage point to see the rest of the city. The walk up and down wandering thru the little streets is charming. It's nice way to explore the city and see what else there is to see. There are some pamphlets with some history on them. There is also a small museum up there but I found the views to be the best part. To get to the top, there are a lot of steep stairs .

A slippery experience. You must go and visit the castle, I suggest to walk to reach it, so you will enjoy great view of the town while climbing the hill. Try to avoid rainy days, the castle stone are very slippery and it could be dangerous if you are on top of an old tower and have to go down. The ticket is 7 euro, the visit is interesting, don't miss the small museum.
I'm glad we did this.. We walked up to the castle through some side streets, guessing which way to go. It was much easier on the way down. We missed the museum...our fault.

A must for any traveller. We visited the castle fairly late in the evening having discovered it was open until 9pm, and avoided the crowds. It's beautifully preserved with lots to see and do with some of the best views of the city.
Great views. Not much to see at this restored castle but beautiful landscaping, beautiful views of the city, wandering peacocks and the periscope 9camera obscura)

Birds eye view of Lisbon. a fantastic view over the city from the ramparts.The keep is well restored, and there is a cafe within the walls( and loos!) but don't expect more than snacks and drinks at a price.Good fun to try and count the number of feral cats that have made their home in the castle..great scroungers..You can get up the hill by tram, but we found it easier to go by taxi. There are a few bars in the streets outside the castle, butstand your ground, don't be persuaded to try 'this and that' itwill cost!!!
A Must See. Lisbon's most visited attraction and rightly so. Great views of the city and interesting place to visit.
What a View. Just an amazing castle. Just remember, it's a castle not a palace so you will just see the grouds and the fortress, there is no palace where the actually lived.

Beautiful views. I think it may be an 8 euro charge to get in (but only 4 euros for students!). For 4 euros, it was definitely worth it - you got beautiful views of the golden gate look alike bridge and good perspective on the massive sprawling city. The castle itself isn't necessarily that impressive.

Fantastic view. Beautiful fortified citadel overlooking the city. We had a very nice long walk through this medieval gem. We found it interesting that one of the towers had a periscope that allowed a 360-degree view of the city.
Alfama Areas. Not much going on there. Just an empty castle. Practically visit for the view it offers on Lisbon and a very excellent restaurant but watch the price.
Great castle and views. A must see when you visit Lisbon. A really good mix of artefacts and trmendous walls and ramparts. You need a head for heights and be prepared for steep climbs.

Just a Beautiful view of the city. the access to this ruined castle cost more than a visit on Coliseum in Rome!but you can see the all the city from thereif you like coffe you can take one of the best in from of the entrance to the castle very good and with a oless cost respect to all the sites in Lisbon

Ex-Libris de Lisboa!. With hundreds of years of history, the castle of St. George is one of the places to visit in Lisbon. It's Mandatory. The price of entry is free for those who live in Lisbon and for tourists the price is too cheap. Upon entering, we see the wonderful Lisbon, the Tejo river and the downtown area of Lisbon. The castle is beautiful, with many entrances and the surroundings have many trees.
Great views of Lisbon. This was open on Easter Sunday when everything else was closed. We loved wandering around the grounds and enjoying the views. The walk down through Alfama is great, too.

Great moorish castle - worth the walk. Wonderful experience touring the castle, but beware that it has a lot of uneven steps and is at the top of the Alfama. A taxi is available, but most of the charm is the walking around the smaller streets.
Great view of the city. We went to the castle by tram 28 early on a Sunday morning. The view of the city was fantastic.

Gorgeous castle with a full range of history! Great time. We are sooo happy we took the time to go to this castle. It's really a special spot, with amazing views of all of Lisbon, three major periods well represented (from the 7th century BC!), and even the requisite peacocks squawking to add to the experience. We had the Yellow Bus tickets, which give a good discount, and went for the family rate (there were four of us) for about 33 euros for the 4 of us, but the public trams that go up are excellent as well and a good value with easy transport from the main square. We recommend it! Give yourself a half day, and maybe wander back down to the tourist distric (Baixa) for the other half for a really fun excursion.
A must see. Amazing view of the city. Plan to spend a couple of hours, and be sure to wear comfortable shoes. You'll be hiking.
Nice view. For the castle you do not have to go up there, it's only for the nice views of Lisbon
a nice castle. I climbed to this area of Lisbon and is worth it beautiful view but I would have liked more information of this castle it was a bit ruiness for me

a good panorama. one of the many "miradouros" that Lisbon has..a poorly conserved castle..nice coffe shop, some peacocks but I mostly enjoyed the ride until the castle and the surrounding Alfama neighboorhood.

A View over the city, Lisbon. What a way to have a city on your feet. The Castle is on the hilltop of one of Lisbon's hills and is where the city was conquered to the moorish 8 Century AC. The Restaurant Casa do Leão is a great way of finishing your day. The small Museum is quite interesting. Must go!
Nice view. The view from the castle is just stunning but that's about it. Nice place for a walk. However, the entrance is for cca 7EUR.
wonderfull view. Best view to Lisbon. It´s pure history here. It´s a good place to have a drink or fast meal. In the summer, they offer small jazz concerts. I missed, but shoud be amazing..

Good views of the city. We got the 28 tram beyond the Castle up to Graca to visit the veiwpont there, then walked down to the Castle. The literature is informative and the views over the city a very nice.
Worth the Visit. Great views of Lisbon, and an interesting site. The area around the castle is also great for walking, provided you don't mind hills.
just a good view!. Its a nice place to see the sunset and the view, but its not a museum or real castle- just ruins.

Visit to castle. This is very good value and I suggest is what you should do first. It gives great views accross the city, but note, the viewing platform is not next to the ticket office as I first thought, it is the castle battlements themselves. Watch out for the Peacocks, they are scrounging for food!

Landmark site to visit, fun just to get there!. Getting there is an adventure -- we chose to ride two different trams to get to the top of the hill, pausing to wander around the interesting and historic neighborhoods in a tight, hilly district with lots of stairs, slopes, and interesting buildings. Be forewarned, even if you take the tram to the nearest stop, there is still an uphill walk of a few blocks just to get to the ticket office, which is outside the gates to the castle. The entrance plaza after the castle gates has wonderful views of the city of Lisbon, from the waterfront, across the orderly streets of Baixa, and up to the hills and parks in the distance. This is the perfect spot for a family photo with Lisbon as the backdrop.The walkways along the cliff are rough cobblestones, so be careful of your steps. En route to the castle structure, you'll pass a restaurant, coffee shop, and toilets. There are also many peacocks wandering around.The castle itself is mostly outdoors, with many walls and battlements to climb. Again the views from all sides are excellent. Most of the steps have proper railings, but they require caution while climbing and children should be kept close.One thing not to miss -- there is a ~20 minute show using a camera obscura in one of the buildings up in the castle tower. This camera projects a large, 360 degree view of the city with live action onto a large circular table inside a room. A staff member highlights the key sites, which was very interesting for us to see and understand.We spent about 1.5 hours at the site, and could have spent more if we were not in a hurry to see other sites. Enjoy!
The best views in the city. Stunning and worth a visit, do it using the 28 Tram and kill two birds etc.

Good views and lots to see. Old castle overlooking Lisbon city. Good views of the city and a calm place to escape from a busy city centre. Lots of rooms and places to discover. We brought a pram with our baby, and that was all right, though we could not take the pram to the top of the walls. There was a finer restaurant and a smaller cafeteria, where food could be puchased, inside of the walls. Also toilets. Seven peacocks dwelling around the cafeteria also entertained quite a few tourists.
windy up top!. worth a visit for the views of the city; reasonably priced entrance fee and well kept

Lots to see, good with kids. Very good value, can spend ¾ of the day there, tours available but confirm which language they are in- we were told there was going to be one in English, but after we waited for it, it turned out that there was only Portuguese ones. No audio guide available. Gift shop closed a lot of the time. Take the tram there but make sure to ask the driver where to get off and confirm that it’s the closest to the entrance. Our tram driver directed us to get off at what he said was the entrance and we ended up having to wander uphill for another 30 minutes to get there.Big area to cover, lots to see, and the best part is that you can touch and climb everything. So it's excellent for kids.
WOW !. This is the best heritage in Lisbon one must visit when coming Portugal, never been such plece...

Amazing views. Go up here on a sunny day and you'll find stunning views over the city and lots of places to sit and watch the world go by. When we were there there was a fantastic acoustic guitarrist playing in the main castle courtyard. Good day out and worth the steep walk up the hill!
Number one in LIS. definitely the place you should start your Lisboa visit with! Great views and very lovely surroundings.
Great views. Well worth the climb to savour the spectacular views over the city.

Great place - overlooks the whole of Lisbon. Got here on tram 28E.Walked up 400metres to get to the castle.The entry was $7.50Euro.The place has some great history and opportunities to walk around and explore.The scenery and views from the highest point in Lisbon is amazing. I have attached some pictures!There is a cafe and restaurant at the Castle all at reasonable prices.Make sure you climb up the castle walls to the top and get some great pictures of the city and the Tagus river.

Great Views. Excellent views of Lisbon! Don't expect "real ruins" or a display showing historical facts. It is good for the views.If you want real ruins take a train to Sintra and visit the Moorish Castle. It is awesome!For Lisbon views and some "Castle's Photographs" St George is ok

If you use the tour buses, don't miss the stop for Sao Jorge Castle. Seeing the castle up close is worth getting off the tour bus, and the climb up the narrow lanes to the castle entrance surprises one with a pissoire handy for all the men in your party. Ladies will have to locate other facilities.

A great place to go. Lovely castle, great views of the city. You need to line up for your tickets at the booth just before the entrance. Once inside it is huge so don't be put off if there are lots of people wating for tickets. Take some time just to sit and look at the view

Castle walls with a view. Lovely spot above Lisbon with great views. Historic site though mainly only the castle walls remain with a small museum within the grounds. Worth a short trip (an hour or so should do it) we paid 7 euro each to enter at time of writing.
High up high. the best thing about this castle are the views, and the concerts they have sometimes! however the entrance is kinda expensive for what it offers..

Incredible Views. Was looking forward to visiting the Castelo de Sao Jorge. It looked so impressive from my hotel room and from down in the streets. Took tram 28 and made my way to Miradouro de Santa Luzia to take in the views before going to the castelo. Be warned that the path to the castelo can be a little hard to figure out as the signs to the narrow winding streets can be misleading. Upon arriving at the castelo it was confusing as to where you purchase the ticket. I noticed many people back tracking to the information/ticket booth. I have to admit I was a little surprised when I entered and realized the castelo is empty inside. There really isn't much more than the walls. You can walk on the walls and the 360 degree views of Lisbon from the top of the walls are incredible and make it all worthwhile.I would recommend a visit just for the views alone.

Fantastic Views. A must visit in Lisbon. Took the Tram # 28 and walked up the hill to the Castle. The best views of the city are from up the Castle. The Castle by itself is good. The views of the city and the Tram # 28 ride up is worth the price of admission and time in Lisbon. BTW, Beware of pickpockets on Tram # 28.I rate "Castelo de Sao Jorge" and the "Jeronimos Monastery" as the top-2 in Lisbon.
Beautiful views. A beautiful walk around the castle with great views of the city.
Beautiful views. The views are worth the price of admission! Panoramic views from high lookouts all around the castle.

Lisbon's crown. Not to be missed! Take the Tram 28 (if you can get on!) as far as you can and walk the remaining part to get beautiful views over the city. Much of the castle has been carefully renovated and it is definitely worth exploring the walls and fortifications.
If you like castles please visit the St. George Castle. Well maintained and very well organized. You can take great pictures of the city

Best views in Lisbon. Though a bit difficult to find (directions not signposted from tram stop) once there it is a fantastic place to spend a few hours. The views over Lisbon are fabulous and the castle fascinating. A must see while in Lisbon.
super view. it was relaxing place to visit. took tram 12 and 28.
What a view!. If you are too lazy to walk up here ( it IS steep!!) then the bus from Figueras Square takes all of 5 minutes. Try the Goan restaurant nearby.

Very very disapointing. The location in magnificent. The history of the place is intriguing. But the level of maintenance and the (almost absolute) lack of information surely disappoints those who have been in other (similar) places.

The greatest castle in Portugal. Overlooking the amazing city of Lisbon from one of the seven hills, the beatifull castle of São Jorge is a must visit during your stay in Lisbon. Very well mantained and with the best panoramic view of the city you will love it.Take the tram 28 and then walk up the hill to visit this fantastic castle. Don't miss it.

The best view to the Lisbon!. When you would like to relax and enjoy the day in silent, calm and full of trees and plants place, come to the St. George's Castle. You will not be disappointed. Do not miss this place!:)

Great view. When you want a great view on Lisboa, the bridge and the surroundings, please visit this castle. The climb itself to the castle is worthwhile, but the view is excellent. The castle itself is not a great treat (well preserved, but do not get to excited). But the view makes it all worth it.

Amazing view of Lisbon with a great sense of history. The castle is absolutely amazing! It is quite a bit of a walk to get to the castle (which in itself is quite lovely) but bear with it and you will not be disappointed.This is a Moorish castle, which was originally built back in the 8th century. Later on in the middle ages, a new section was added which is on top of the highest hill, with breathtaking views of the city. For over a thousand years the castle has been staring over the city, housing from solders to royals and kings and now tourists.Tip:- Check out the romantic gardens. There are peacocks walking around.- The restaurant is pricy but the food is ok. - If you have vertigo, be very careful when climbing to the top as it will feel as if you are on edge of the world. And the low railings don't help.
Unmissable views. Combine a visit here with a ride on Tram 28. The panoramic views of the city are superb!

Great views and loved the castle's cats. The walk up to the castle is a splendid labyrinth of cobbled roads. Spectacular views across the city make this a great viewing platform from which to see Lisbon. As well as the expanse of the history that is covered in a handy leaflet and the obvious features of walls and turrets, there are the peacocks and rogue cats that parade around – or bask in the sun. That said, the cats didn’t appear to have missed too many meals.

Great Views - Free for Locals. Amazing views of Lisbon. You can walk on the walls, but if you don't like hikes do not do it as the guard rail is a bit low shall we say. its cheap to get in, i think it was 5 euros. Get your required picture of sitting of a cannon or by one of the little lions. Nice restaurant there (with high prices, but still a nice restaurant)
Great view. Lovely walk up to the Castle to be rewarded with a gorgeous view!

Unrivalled views of Lisbon. The castle ruins as they stand today were actually restored in the 1930's after being destroyed in the Great Earthquake of 1755. Nevertheless the Castelo is great for children to explore and for adults to see spectacular views across Portugal's capital and its river. Tip: the cost of admission includes a visit to the camera obscura mounted in one of the highest towers but numbers are limited. If you wish to see this (and it is well worth visiting to see a truly panoramic view of Lisbon), go to book a time and collect your tickets as soon as you can, then enjoy the castle and make your way back for your time slot.

You have to go there!. In the castle you can turn back in time for a while, have a nice lunch and see some of the best sightseeing places in the city!And the adventure starts when you try to go there, because if you walk to it, you will find some of the most picturesc and traditional streets of Lisbon.
I loved it!. Beautiful, magnificent!! Views on the city were very very good!!
well maintained Castle. better mainatined that many old castles I have seen, entrance 7.50 Euro,great views over the city

Crowded and busy but worth the climb. A lot of history is crammed into a small space - archaeological digs are ongoing and the walk around the top of the alls give spectacular views of the city and one can see why the castle was built where it is and why it is still standing. Could do withy more guides and information but the long walk up through interesting side-streets are a great intro to the castle.
The Best View. Take a tram then a walk via a great coffee shop with outstanding views over the river. Walk up a rather steep, cobbled road into the castle. The views are magnifque!

A must see. First- take the short yellow bus; it'll take you all the way up the hill. The 28 tram only brings you about half way. Whoever owns the grounds has done very little to make it a real tourist attraction- which is absolutely great, feels more authentic and old. Once inside, you can just wander everywhere. There are no ceilings anywhere, so it's all dirt floors. Narrow stairs, walkways high up. There is also an archaelogical dig site on the grounds. Amazing views of the city as well. I think it was 9 euros pp for entry.

Highlight of visit.. This was my favourite spot in the whole city. Loved the views and the beauty of the castle. Spent half a day there just wandering around and then stopped for coffee and watched the peacocks strutt.
Best Views in the City. Great for a first day visit - to drink the views from every corner and to every corner of the city -North, South, East and West.
Beautiful to visit. Great spot to visit / walk around. Great views, pretty location.
Fantastic views. Worth a visit, really good for orientating yourself. Wonderful views from the keeps

Awesome city view; be prepared for climbing steps. We visited at the start of our trip and were not disappointed. Lots of climbing up, through and down the castle walls to enjoy the many parts of the castle. Though there are many interpretative postings in English and Portuguese, we would have benefited form a guide to answer some of our questions. The main courtyard was lovely and included a guitarist. Many peacocks on the site -- who would have thought! Located in a very picturesque part of town near the Alfama district; has a lovely (even romantic) garden where one can picnic; great views of the city and the water; nice cafe; great WC facilities (yup! it was worth mentioning.)

if you can find it... It has beautiful views.But if you plan to get lost in the little streets surrounding the castle before getting to the castle, I suggest be careful, because you might really get lost!The way to the castle's entrance is not as clearly put as one might want so you end up going up and down the hill until you catch the signs!
Fabulous Castle. what a fantastic place to visit, the views are fabulous and the peakcocks that were a few feet away were colourful, marvelous place...

Amazing old castle, great view over Lisbon. It was SO worth taking all the effort to climb up the steep hill all the way up to the Castelo de Sao Jorge / St. George’s Castle. You can easily take the tram No° 28/ and hop of close to the castle. Take your time for 1-2 hours to explore the different parts of the castle. Enjoy the panoramic view over the complete city, the harbour. It is amazing. The small cafè there is also nice. There are many wild peacocks running around close to the cafe.
Nice. Good fun, as part of the walking tour around the Alfama

Old walls and a wonderful view of the city. We could walk around and climb the walls and towers as we pleased. Beautiful and serene surroundings. Around the small cafeteria within the ground peacocks were walking between the tables, begging crumbs from the guests.

Great views and enjoyable hike up. We decided to walk to the Castle from the statue of the Marques of Pombal. A steep climb up but we cheated a little bit when we found a lift going up 7 floors. The views from the Castle are great anywhere you look. People still live around it which makes it a great neighbourhood to explore as well. The peacocks were a huge main attraction for everyone.

You can't beat the views of Lisbon. The Castle encompassed a much bigger area than we had thought - the grounds are quite large, and the view over Lisbon is terrific. The history of how the Moors captured the castle is really interesting, and there is a picture in the museum showing how the area would have looked at the time - all sand.
The Birth of Lisboa. From here you can get a fantastic view of the city and also appreciate the castle
Views are spectacular. Easy to get to on the tram, or a strenuous walk up the narrow winding streets. However you get there, it is a worthwhile trip
The best 360° panorama of Lisbon. A good way to discover Lisbon's geography. The olive and pine trees and the gardens give this fortress a human scale. The 360° panorama is outstanding. A must!
Nicely kept. Beautiful ruins, handsome view of lisbon, quite a walk to get there (yu can get a cab, but you'll miss the beauty of the old streets, cantinas, sangrias spreaded through the region).

The most beautiful Castel I ever been. Besides the fact that this monument has more than a thousand years, it has the most wonderful view over the city of Lisbon and it explains why Lisbon is so unique
a "must visit". Great views of the city; lots of fun exploring. Many great photos.
Great views. Take tram 28 and then enjoy the castle. There are beautiful views of Lisbon from here and a small museum with ancient artifacts. A nice place to ramble around for a few hours.

A lovely place to visit. Nice to have a wander around the castle walls and the views over the city are to die for!! There was a great musician playing within the castle, which added to the serenity of the place. There is a restaurant, which looked really nice, although was just closing when we got there. Fabulous outside tables with a stunning view. Enjoyed the experience.

Moorish stronghold in Lisbon. Castelo Sao Jorge is a castle located in the north west corner of the much larger citadel of Lisbon. The citadel also comprises a living quarter for city officials (now in ruins), a palace (now a restaurant), ancillary buildings and a large terraced square.The origin of the present castle is uncertain but the bulk probably dates from the Moorish occupation and already existed in 1147 when Lisbon was conquered by Alfonso Henriques. The structure was modified later on.The castle got its name in the fourteenth century. King Joao I married Philippa of Lancaster and signed the auld alliance with the English. In honor of his new allies the castle got the name of their patron saint.The south and east side of the castle are protected by a (nowadays dry) moat. The north and west side are sealed off by steep hills.The current main entrance is not original. The original entrance lies in the east and brings the visitor into a barbican. Attackers had to follow this long and narrow corridor with their right flank under constant fire from defenders.Finally they reached a second gate placed opposite a wall (through which the current main entrance is pierced) to prevent the use of a battering ram.Once past this gate they came into a small space with a third gate, entirely enclosed by walls and thus under fire from all sides.Eventually they ended up in the courtyard which is divided into two sections that could be defended separately.The castle has no keep and no living quarters. There are only walls and towers. This is because it served as a last refuge in time of war.Although altered in later centuries the current structure is very impressive in size and atmosphere. Visitors can climb the walls and towers and are rewarded with beautiful views of the area.A big setback however is the total lack of information about the history of the castle and its architecture. You only get a leaflet with a map and there are a few signs. No audioguides or guidebooks are available.Sometimes there are free guided tours. Our guide was very amiable but the tour had a duration of only twenty minutes and gave us very little insight into the castle.
Beautiful view. The castle itself isn't that interesting, but the view of Lisbon, priceless!!!

Magnificat!. The castle was all that a history buff could ask for. The reviewer who complained about the lack of artifacts in the museum...don't understand. A site gives up what it can. The view and sense of history were memorable.
beautiful area. It is worth the climbing up the hill. The view is fantastic.
Must visit.. A lot of trees, great view, fantastic city hill walk to arrive there.

Great views but that's it. Crqcking views over Lisbon but you can get them from a ton of viewpoints around the city. The castle doesn't offer much extra. Save your money by walking the perimeter. Unless you've never been inside a castle you don't need to pay 10 euros to go inside!
dont expect much. bare stony walls and some peackoks-these tings are all, that you will find inside. again, except for the view and the history of this place
A castle with a view. In a clear day, it's brilliant. You have a 360º panoramic view of the city.
Marvelous view from the castelo. The castle is a must as well. You have a great view over Lisbon center from there, lots of old castle walls to walk, a museum and even some archaeological diggings.

Great views from Castle. Take a taxi, very cheap and plenty. Drop you right at entrance. E7.50 for adults and E4 for kids. Well worth a visit. Wide ranging views, cafe, restaurant, shop, museums, ancient artifacts, very historic. Lovely relaxing walk. Well worth a visit.
Superb general view of Lisboa. An old castle with a wonderful 360° view over Lisboa if you have the courage to go along and up the walls of the fortress

explore, explore, explore. I will say nothing less than glowing about Lisbon and Portugal -- not from prejudice, but from the experiences of unknowing exploration, then familiarity, then complete affection. The Castle combines so many things - history, views, even inviting souvenir shops (how does Portugal do these so much better than other countries?). Great exercise, and a view of city you'll never forget.

Stunning views and the journey there, a trip in itself.. I could not go further than the viewpoint with a disability and my wife carried on and was impressed with the ruins. I waited for half an hour at the view and was very happy waiting. I could see all the way across the Tagus and coming back across the river, Belem and other areas could be seen below. Large clusters of red roofed traditional houses lay below. The journey there is through the wonderful district of Alfalma.
One of the highlights, but very expensive!. Not a castle like anywhere else in Europe (no roof, nothing in-situ), but a complex restored under the dictator. Only nice on a fine-weather day.
Very peaceful. This was a very tranquil place to visit. On the day we went there were few tourists, lots of sunshine and loads of quiet time
Dominant view. Overlooking the city to give a sense of the protective raison d'etre for such a structure.The camera obscura was really interesting to see.

Slightly disappointing. It's a beautiful castle with panoramic views of the coast and city but the captivating stories of maurauding hoards, damsels in distress and the Portugese royalty just aren't described or there. The artefacts shown in the museum are very humble indeed for a nation which conquered the seas and colonised the South Americas for such a long time. A shame that a wonderful culture wasn't represented better!

Worth it just for the views!. It is a little bit of a hike up the hill to the castle, but once you are there the views are stunning. The grounds are wll maintained. Definitely worth the trip and a must see in Lisbon.
Must visit the castle. Great views. Able to walk inside the remains. Must visit
Worth to visit. The castle ant the view from it is the number 1 thing to visit in Lisbon.
Views. Breathtaking views of the city and the river, especially at sunset
Outstanding Views. The views here are beautiful and I loved the winding cobblestone streets. This is a must-see in Lisbon!
Bird's view. The view is excellent and inside the walls you can start to understand something about Lisbon's history

Most romantic place in Europe. This castle is the most romantic place in Europe. You're in a medieval castle, looking at the river Tajo. Thinking of the Conquistadors leaving for Americas... You just have an incredible feeling!
Nice view. The castle itself isn't really special, but the view is really great.
Great view over the city. We went to the castelo on a glorious sunny day. The bastions has been restored but apart from the garden and the amazing views there is not much there to see .

Panoramic views of Lisbon. The signage to the castle could be better...we hardly found any. I used an app called OffMaps to help me find my way, but it showed 2 ways to the Castle. I almost went the wrong (seemingly easier) way but we were lucky to have bumped into an English speaking friendly and helpful local who said her family were "salad eaters from the days of kings". She walked us nearly to the front gate while providing a bit of side history! Love the locals! The castle offered the best view of the city. However, the castle is just an old castle that gave another 20 to 30 feet more elevation above the lower cannon platforms. On its grounds was a modest museum of artifacts found from its premises. Overall, the views of Lisbon justified the jaunt to the castle. My only regret? Although I intended to revisit after dark, each night we were too tired to do so....
A lot of History. The Lisbon Castle, you can't missed. With lovely city views.
best view. the best view in the city,its nice to walk inside a castle...its in a very good shape,i think it's worth to try it!
Excellent views of Lisbon. Take the tram up but get off near the cathedral for stunning views and then walk up to the castle.
Castle. Nice castle to visit you get great views of the city of Lisbon.
go for the views. Superb views over the city from the battlements ,coffee shop, restaurant and good gift shop
Beautiful city view!. Walk around the castle in Alfama narrow streets to get the local atmosphere. Clothes hanging from the windows... And always the beautiful view.

Very nice place, great views... Needs manteinance though. This place is a=in a very pictoresque area and there are very ncie views.Pros: Views, architecture...Cons: Would be much better with manteinance.
castelo. The St. George's castle is a good experience, there is a lot of space inside, steps up and steps down, plenty of tourists, and of course the castle itself. I liked my time there.
Nice Castle. one of the oldest monument's in the city, interesting and different from others European castles with great viewing place. The whole city is in front of you
Mouros adventure. amazing castle, with wonderfull view over Lisbon downtown
Pay for a walk on the grounds. We visited the castle more than once before, this time we wanted just to make a walk in the garden and admire the panorama, however one has to pay for it.
Historic. Historic and Magnificent, with amazing view over the city and the river.

Touching!!!. I have only great memories about this place! It´s kind of magic... It takes you back to some beautiful time you have inside somewhere! The view is unbelievable and they have always a few musicians all around it... The songs make it even more special! Beautiful!!!
View. Nice walk up and afterwards a fantastic view of the city

Great place to explore.... This a a wonderful place to explore the history of Lisbon and to see the city views. You can walk the walls for many different views of the 7 hills of Lisbon and explore the interior of this old castle. There are a couple of restaurants. One very nice place to eat and one cafeteria. Both have excellent food. Also the peacocks are beautiful on the grounds. Enjoy!

Beautiful Grounds with an Amazing View of Lisbon. Castelo de Sao Jorge is a moderate hike up from Baixa or Alfama, but it's not so bad you feel the need to take the tram instead of walking. It just LOOKS really high up! Tickets are 7.50 euros a person, and are worth it for the grounds alone. The former moat surrounding the castle is now a garden, and the whole place feels well-manicured. You can walk almost the entire perimeter of the castle along the upper walls, giving way to some fantastic views of the city below. There's a camera obscura that's absolutely worth a look, even if you have to join in another language. There's a demo every 30 minutes, but it cycles between English, Spanish and Portuguese, so if you hold out for your language you may have to wait up to 1.5 hours.

Best sightseeing place in Lisbon. Sun set at Lisbon's castle is amazing. Exploring this ancient site is one of Lisbon's best things to do. You have a panoramic view of Lisbon Rossio, Praça do Comércio, Bairro Alto, also the Tagus river views for amazing photos. Great place to bring a book and relax for a couple of hours enjoying Lisbon's great views.
Allow plenty of time. Don't rush this one -as I did . Allow at least 3 hours to take in the history, architecture and spectacular views of Lisbon.

Sterile and overly restored. The castle itself was oddly unwelcoming and not a lot of fun to visit. Very "cold" and the restoration was simply not done particularly well. In fairness the views are fantastic but we were pretty much disappointed.

go and plan time to relax..and just enjoy the view and think of what it was like. the view from here will make eyou appreciate Lisbon even so much more. soak in the history ...look at the olive tree with the poem...imagine you are there ..a long ...long time ago
Excelent view over Lisbon Center. Use the Tram and go upside. The castle himself has no much to see but the view over the city center is fantastic...
Stunning views. Really peaceful, the climb was worthwhile for the amazing views over Lisboa
The view. This is where you can see almost everything in Lisbon and beyond..
Very interesting. .Could get lost for hours walking the walls if you want. The steps can be very steep and railings are full of rust. Have something to wipe your hands with.
Best Lisbon view. A must see in Lisbon, nice castle, wonderfull view!
Nice to walk around but pretty boring. Was somewhat well maintained, but is your usual tourist trap. Was a good spot to get pictures of the city / river. The museum there took us less than 10 min.
nice spot. Castelo São Jorge is a nice place to visit, if you go to lissabon you have to visit it. I like the view, it is like a 300 degree view, beyond that only walls and history.

Great city view. The site is fabulous! you have an amazing view of Lisbon from up there! On the first day of the month they have free admission.
Take tram 28 up there and then walk back though the Alfama district.
A nice place to visit in the afternoon. You can watch sunset here and walking around the castle is a wonderful experience

Amazing Views. Besides visiting an historic site in Llsbon, one sees amazing views of Lisbon and the surrounding areas when at the castle. Also enjoyed seeing some beautiful peacocks that roam freely on the castle grounds.
It is need to be there!. I enjoyed every inch of the castle (which by the way I would see from my hotel - in distance of course). The view form every point of the castle is fantastic.
Amazing. High on a hill overlooking Lisbon, oozing history, conquest, intrigue, and beauty. It's good to be the king

What views!. During my first visit to Lisbon years ago I wasn't too impressed with this place, maybe because it was crawling with tourists and didn't seem to offer much more than views. This time, the gardens were impeccably kept, it was sunset, there were very few people in the cold, peacocks were running around and a single guitarists was playing beautifully in one of the courtyards. I loved the feel of the place which seemed utterly different than on a hot tourist-heavy day. It was solemn and quiet and beautiful. Go near sunset.
Amazing!!!. It's the most beautiful castle! You must see it! With amazing views over Lisbon
Fun Castle. Interesting castle with fabulous views. Take a picnic lunch to enjoy the views. Also take the tram to save a very steep climb.

Nice views of Lisbon. If your an American nearly every castle is cool. The views of Lisbon are quite nice and at dusk especially so. There is a small exhibit that tells the story of the castle and a gift shop of course.However, the bus/tram thing that takes you up to the castle stops fairly early. We walked back down the hill to the center of the city after hanging at the castle a little too long. I enjoyed the walk but I think my travel mates were a little uncomfortable. The area seems a little seedy at night.

Well worth a visit - great views of the city. I'm not a great one for historical buildings but this was a good one and apparently free on 31st December so great value ! We took the tram (E 12) up from Pr.Figueira and explored all around the castle and the grounds on a beautiful sunny morning. You can gain a great sense of the layout of the city and there are innumerable photo opportunities. Not having a good head for heights I must admit to feeling quite uncomfortable on a couple of occasions on the castle walls but there wasn't actually any real danger providing you exercised sensible caution. If you're visiting Lisbon you've got to do it really.

Castel from the mourish times. Very well kepted castel and sorroundings, worth the visit. You can see how lisbon city first becan, as a mourish city, with walls around it.The housing around and narrow streets are worth the visit, and make you fell a taste of arab in europe.

Worth a visit for the view. This is very much a "restored ruin" - not really very much to see in terms of a castle, but what an incredible view. Take the time, if you can, to take a long walk through the neighbourhood - the windy streets are great for exploring. There is an admission fee for the castle, but it's quite reasonable in comparison to anywhere else in Europe. I recommend taking a packed picnic and just sitting in the park at the top and admiring the view - it's really quite panoramic. If you can, make sure you catch dinner in the old inner city at one of the many restaurants nestled on the stairs - the view back up to the castle all lit up at night is breathtaking.

City view! City View!. If you're lucky to go on a sunny day as I was, you'll see how medievally beautiful Lisbon is! Don't worry about waiting a bit on the line, as it goes fast and the castle is a must see, definitely!
Great views. There are great views over Lisbon and the river from the walls of this castle, but not much anything else. Tickets cost a lot, around 7 euros.
Very nice view over Lisbon. Take tram 28 to where you can see the sign that points out the way. Walk up the hill - you can,t go wrong. Best to eat at the restaurants outside the castle.

Great views and a quiet oasis. Lots or steps and uneven paths, may not be suited to all.
Great views of the city from here. A pleasant oasis of calm and tranquility.
Great views of Lisbon. We went at sunset which is a lovely time to go for some excellent shots over the harbour
Stunning Views of the city. Enjoy the views and prepare your camera!! That's what I like the most of this attraction.

Interesting - Multi-Century Archeological Site. This was an interesting multi-century archeological site to visit. There were on-going digs on the site dated from the 3rd - 14th centuries b.c. Price was 7 euros for entry. The view of the city from the Castle's wall was wonderful

Nice views, not so much of a castle. First off, the views are amazing. You can see almost all of Lisbon in all of it's glory. I'd say go here if you have still one day to spend and have seen all the other places. It's nice to get aerial views to almost everywhere.
Castle itself is just walls and few points of more breathtaking views.
Outstanding views of Lisbon. Spent a relaxing 1/2 day touring the old castle. Breathtaking views of the city. Well worth the visit.
Well worth the walk up hill. Loved the castle and the walk up rather than using the tram meant we could wander off tyhe main route

Fun to explore the ancient castle overlooking the city. Castelo Sao Jorge is a huge reminder of a time gone by amongst the shops and restaurants in the area. Great for "kids" of ALL ages! Excellent views and lit up at night is absolutely magical! Don't miss the 'dry' moat and the house that served as the connection to the jails. Great to step back in time and let your imagination run wild...

Space, history and quirky corners. For a very small fee, you can happily spend several hours wandering the hilltop that is the site of St. George's Castle. I took a little bus (#37) up the steep hill and that was an adventure on its own. At times it seemed that it would be impossible for the driver to make a tight turn, at other times the ascent was so steep I thought we might be asked to push. But we got to a stop just outside the main entrance and wandered past a couple of brave artists who had their wares draped across the sidewalk on this drizzly day.Once inside the castle there are a number of look off spots offering great views of the city, the river and the statue of Christ on the south banks of the Tagus. You can poke around in old fountains, semi-submerged walkways and ancient courtyards. There is lots of statuary from various centuries, old gates, cannons and other artefacts to discover. And if you're lucky, the peacocks will be putting on a display.This is a place to head to if you have tired of the hustle & bustle of the city. There are lots of corners where you can claim a bench, haul out your book and settle back for some serious quiet. If you're traveling with kids, you can safely let them explore and discover.
What a wonderful view. Definatly worth the climb - A great place to see the city - one of our best days.
impresionat view. i like this castle i arrived very early in the morning and can aprreciate the so geourgeous view of this city this is a place you cant loose to go.
A highlight. Wonderful views, lovely grounds and a very interesting place to visit.
Great view over Lisboa. You`d better go the in the morning, since the sun at that tine is behind you when you are watching over the city from the lookout.
One of the best places in Lisbon. If you are not an inhabitante of Lisbon you have to get a ticket but it's a great place to visit. And it has a great view over the city

A must see in Lisbon. It is an ancient structure very close to the center of Lisbon. We could see it from our hotel balcony in the morning. We could see it lit up at night. It is easy to get there and the views our phenomenal. Why pass up the chance to see a structure that goes back more than a thousand years? You can really see the difference between that period of time and the ostentation of the buildings from the Renaissance era.
Great view from St George Castle. Great view of Lisbon can be seen from there. Especialy sunset is good time !!

Great experience. Very nice experience visiting the ruins of the castle. Lots of beggars around so be careful. But, nonetheless, it was enjoyable. Quite a walk from the Tram 28 stop, very hilly, so wear comfortable shoes. The views are amazing.

It's a great view just watch out for the pigeons roosting in the trees. The Castelo offered a scenic view overlooking Lisbon and an opportunity to walk the walls. There was an entrance fee to get in and I think it was 5 Euro per person. There were also two places to eat, a casual place for a snack as well as a more expensive restaurant. Be wary of the pigeons roosting in the trees by the casual snack restaurant. We were enjoying ice cream when we got hit by a pigeon. Had to toss the ice cream cone and go clean up. There were also a lot of peacocks walking around and in the trees too which were fun to watch plus cats, my favorite critters.
amazing view over Lisbon. If you're visiting Lisbon, you *MUST* visit the Castle and the surrounding neighborhood.
Great walk up and down an beautiful view on the city !. Go to the Castle ! It is worthwhile ! The view is great and have a coffee or even lunch in the restaurant inside.

Nice walk but not overly educational. I would have liked to have known a bit more about the Castelo for the ticket price while I was there but the views of the city at the Tagus were impressive, while the breezy ramparts were among Lisboa's few cooler spots on a super hot day!

Great View. We walked up to the castle, got lost, so ended up walking through narrow streets in neighborhoods. Great fun. The views are fantastic, we did not tire of them. The museum is OK, we got a sense of history, the age of Lisbon.imho: not to be missed.

Lots of stairs but be immersed in another era.. Need to walk uphill a bit from a Tram 28 stop although a local bus goes up almost to the castle entry. Enjoy the great views and photo opportunities. There is a restaurant inside but otherwise just lots of stairs to climb up the castle walls. There is a small archaeological museum and a section still under excavation. Not sure why a peacock and some young birds are kept inside a barred area along the castle wall. Be prepared to climb lots of stairs to the top of the walls and all the towers.
lovely. Great views beutifull castle we went very early in the morning no tourists around lovely and quite before the crowds arrived

Average grounds, great view. This 'castle' is really the remains of such on a hill, with some old cannons, arches from a former convent, and a cafe and whatnot. A nice area to walk around, but nothing really great to look at. The real draw is the view over the city.If you only get halfway up and look out over the water view on the way, and don't feel like continuing up to the castle, don't sweat it.

Wonderful. Fantastic view over the Tejo and Lisbon. Plenty of trees to over shade from the late autum sun (and 24C heat).A lovely space to wander, have a picnic, some glasses of very nice wine, and allow gravity to bring you back down the hill, slowly and happily.

great view of the city. Obligatory sightseeing in Lisbon. Great view of the city, river and bridges. Price - 7 Euro :-) You can get there by walking from a nearby tram stop or buy bus from Praca Figueira. Enjoy!

Great location and views. Go there, especially on a clear day. Walk the ramparts and imagine horses and knights. Think about Escher drawings. Recall the castle seige in "Monty Python and the Holy Grail."

Castle with great views. We spent hours wandering around and enjoying the views from the walls. There is plenty to see and lots of places to relax. There weren't always seats in places we wanted to sit so carry something if you don't want to sit on the ground.

Great views of the city. You get some amazing views of the city, and if you walk up, it's very interesting. Watch out for the pickpockets- you'd be surprised. Packs of pretty, fashionable young women converge on you out of nowhere carrying maps and looking perfectly innocent. Before you can blink, your wallet is empty or gone.

Feet, Calves & thighs be warned !. This was worth the effort but quite hard to find as signs aren't clear. The streets like a lot of Lisbon are steep but the views across Lisbon from the castle are amazing.Entry was quite cheap for 3 adults and after walking around the walls, there's an interesting geometrical contrast to the old and modern inside the castle, with a medieval ruin next to a rusty iron wall clad ruin next to a brilliant White washed building, well worth an abstract photo or two if your imaginative enough.The walk up to the castle is tough on the feet, calves and thighs, but worth it...

The Best Views of Lisbon. After 3 days here, we finally got to the castle. We'd intended doing it on day one, but in fact it turned out brilliantly - by saving it to the end, we got to see all the places we'd been, and how they all connect up - and also some places we hadn't known about that we'd like to go to next time we're here.

Totally worth paying 7 Euro for admission.. I thought I would be able to walk around the castle and get great pictures without paying for admission, but there is not much to see unless you go inside. It is totally worth the 7 Euro for entry. The castle is beautiful and the views of the city are priceless. I went about an hour before sunset and the lighting was gorgeous. Take extra money because there are locals vendors inside selling jewelry, ceramics, and CDs, and I would have bought a CD if I had the money (only 8 Euro).
Interesting. t may be an interesting ride if you like castles (but there are other best preserved castles in Portugal). Anyway offers a beautiful view of Lisbon.

Best view of the city from here!. You can take a lazy tram ride (which leave you till a point and then an uphill walk) or take a bus which leaves you right in front of the castle. Explore the place on your own. A visit to the room which has the periscope is an absolute must. You get to view the entire city ...real time.. from that one tiny room. After the tour you can grab a meal and drink right outside the castle premises. The a walk down to town is absolutely amazing.
Loved it!. Absolutely the best view of the city. It's amazing that so much of this castle is still standing. Great place to go and let your imagination run wild.

Good be good, but .... The castle itself is very imposing and could be interesting with a better explanation, but opening times on the web, the entry and the guide you're handed when you arrive are all different, so it's hard to tell how much time you have. Some internal areas close earlier, such as the periscope, and the archaeology museum inside looked closed for the season. The periscope was also very poorly signed (one reason why we missed it).
Best view in Lisbon. The grandeur and history of the castle is worth the ticket, but I must confess I spent a lot of time just enjoying the view and studying Lisbon geography.

Good views from the fort and in the old part of city.. Good for a walk in the ancient part of the town. A huge camera obscura (or something similar) that can focus on various parts of the city on a screen is an attraction, it is a new addition in the recent times to the fort though.
Lovely Views. Very nice view over the city and a great trip up on the 28 tram. Did not appreciate the busker in the courtyard of the castle!
