Well worth 7 euros. We walked here from our hotel, all uphill and in hindsight after seeing the no 28 trams at the top wished i`d seen them earlier. We spent easily 2 hours at the castle and there are many small cafes and viewpoints nearby.
Lovely views over the city. You go to enjoy the view, nothing more than the view.
Nice view at sunset. The sunset at Castelo de São Jorge is really a great experience. Beautiful view of Lisboa´s old centre from above.

Incredible Views. The views alone are worth the schlep up to the top, which is just as well because the castle is not that interesting. It is in ruins, so an imagination is necessary, but you can climb each remaining fort for...er...more views. Go to Sintra instead!

Transport up, wander down!. Large, well preserved castle. Great views over the city. Best to get there early on a warm week-end - large crowds queueing when I left just after lunch. Then wander through the local streets and find one of those delightful places with half a dozen outdoor tables, and enjoy a wonderfully relaxing slow lunch.

Best views of the city!. My husband and I walked from the lower city all the way up to the castle. It was quite a walk, but we stopped along the way, so all in all not too bad. The views from the castle are spectacular. It has been turned into a restaurant and we happened to be there late afternoon. So we grabbed a table outside and shared a bottle of wine and appetizers. Wow!
Going up in the world. This is an attraction well worth the steep walk with plenty of stpooing cafes along the way. The views are tremendous
Best view of Lisbon. Must go for a 360 degree view of Lisbon. The museum also has some rich artefacts.
Breathtaking.. Well worth the slog, avoid the trams as pickpockets abound. The views from the castle are just amazing, and walking around the streets in the area a delight. Do not miss this.
Excellent Views / Picture opportunity. Excellent views of Lisbon and worth the walk up. Entrance price is a little expensive for what you get (i.e. not much but to look at the views).
Impressive.. Full of History, an amazing view o Lisbon and a pictoresque neighborhood for a walk.
Lovely views. A good way to orientate oneself if new to the city. Also note the possible reductions available - don't pay the full entrance price!
Nice view!. The view from the Castelo is nice, it's a peaceful place, but not that much to see really. Rather pricey for what you get

Beautiful Views. One of the first places we visited in Lisbon. Enjoyed the views and wonderful photo ops. Strolling around the ruins and imaging another time .. nice. Refreshments were reasonable. Bought a watercolor painting from a talented artist just outside the gate (5 euros) .. wish I bought more; his were the best.

Great View of Lisbon. This was more a fort than castle, as there were no sleeping quarters here. You can see all of Lisbon from here, there is also a restaurant in the castle, although we took recommendations from other travelers and ate just outside the castle.

Worth the climb. For fabulous view it's worth the walk uphill (or tram if you cannot manage). Make sure you retain any tickects for the open top bus of Santa Justa elevator as they give you an discount on entry. Have a little change for the guy who plays the cello just outside - he's worth it!

Amazing views and amazing battlement walls. It is a lovely place to visit only 7 euros!!!!!!! The viewpoint is incredible , it really takes your breath away. The romantic gallery (its a garden) is lovely . There is a nice cafe , ok food but reasonable prices for the main tourist attraction. Beware of sleeping peacocks in the trees as my boyfriend had his drink poo'ed in ( was such a good shot as well ). Loved the towers and walls you can spend the whole day there and at night the city is so colourful.Although no trams go directly to the top so be prepared for a bit of walk or get the bus 37 which drops you off at the main entrance. Beware if yo are going with the elderly as it would be better taking a taxi 5 euro from downtown.

What a view. You get the most wonderful view of Lisbon from up here. I have a great photo taking in the Panorama of Lisbon from here that I use as my wallpaper on my computer and is a great reminder, when I am homesick for Lisbon

St. George Castle. Our InsideLisbon Walking tour ended in downtown Lisbon at the Commercial Praca. On the advice of our tour guide, we took a taxi up the hills to St. George Castle. The views were great, and it was a quiet way to relax while enjoying the overview of Historic Lisbon. We had the Rich Steves tourbook and by carefully following the maps, were able to walk back down the hills to the main shopping area -- no taxi fee. Happily, we found a large local department store on the way and were able to by some souveniors at a non-touristy, less pricy outlet.
the best view over Lisboa. You can walk from the hotel to the castle in nearly 45 minutes.Entrance has to be paid. Going back via the Alfama side.
take a look. you may start enjoying the Cafes in its outside, see the city by the wonderful view of the Castle and visit its remains.
Beautiful views of the city. Great views, interesting architecture. Part of it required an additional fee for a special event the day we went.
Amazing terraces. The castle of St George is one very interesting place - from the castle you can see the whole city, the river, the bridge 25 of April and to drink one caipirinha in the restaurant
wonderful sight. It was lovely to stroll around, looking at the peacocks, having a coffee, admire the old walls and the view of the city, listening to a guitarplayer!
Good for views over the city. Superb views and well situated near the arab quarter for the walk to lunch. Be very aware of pickpockets
Beautiful place for a Sunday morning. The views were terrific and the archaeological site fascinating

Beautiful view during sunset. We went to the castle during the late afternoon, and it was a very neat site to walk around and see. However, towards the end of our tour around the castle, we looked over to the side and watched the sunset. The evening view of the city from the castle was marvelous! We were able to see city lights, Rossio Square and the ocean. Very glad we went during the time that we did.
Very interesting with great views. See the periscope! It's tucked away and you have to wait for a time to go in but it is really cool.

Now This I Consider A Must See In Lisbon. We visited so many castles and cathedrals while visiting Portugal and Spain that I developed a bit of "castle fatigue" but I do remember enjoying our visit to St. George's more than just about any that we visited. First of all you can really explore the castle unlike many of the others that we visited. The views of Lisbon from the castle are fantastic as many have mentioned. So by all means make time to visit because you will not be disappointed.
Views to die for. Great views and worth the visit but you need to plan how to get up there. Bus or tram is best but you can walk if you are fit enough to negotiate some very steep streets.
Great views and worth the trip. Old and in great shape with outstanding views of the city
Probably not worth the money. You used to be able to get into the grounds for free, but now you have to pay. The view across the city's good, but there are better places which cost nothing

Okay but Underwhelming. My husband and I, along with another couple, visited the castle in March and although nothing was really negative, we didn't feel like it was much to write home about. The views, as other reviewers have noted, were fabulous. You could see for miles in about every direction! The castle itself though was only so-so. It seemed over-restored to the point where it lost some of its history. The market place inside the walls sold over-priced, kitschy wares and detracted from what charm might have been. The exploring was fun though and the photo opportunities were plenty. My husband, who hadn't ever been to a castle before, thought it was great. I've been to tons of castles though and was less impressed. However, a few days later he recanted his opinion about Sao Jorge after we visited the amazing castle in Sintra.Overall, I say go see the castle if you aren't going to be able to get to any other castles on your trip. But if you plan on seeing any others, this one could probably be skipped - there are other places around town that also offer amazing vistas free of charge. Another thing to note is that we were in Lisbon at a fairly low tourist time and this place was the only sight we saw that had crowds - I can't imagine it in the summer.

Great view, interesting yet unexplained architecture. Spent about 90 minutes here, easily walked up from Fig Square in 20 minutes (if you are at an average fitness level, you'll be fine!). I enjoyed exploring all the nooks and crannies, but I do wish there were more placards fixed around to tell me what I was looking at. Nevertheless, great views of the city, even at midday.
Take the tram. This is a very steep climb up to the castle. The views across Lisbon are magnificent. Visit the archaeological dig on site, it is very interesting.

Great Castle, Spectacular views of the City. This Castle sits atop a Hill and offers up a superb vista of Lisbon. It's only €7 for a day pass for an adult with an extra discount if you happen to be travelling on some of the Red or Yellow bus top tours around Lisbon and hold those tickets. There's loads of History here with guided tours re-enactments which are staged by Actors. Well worth a visit!

Great views of Lisbon. We went here twice. The first was on a walking tour; we didn't enter as our guide just wanted to show us where it was. We returned via taxi (€5 from Rossio) and that was worth it. The castle is preserved and well-maintained, but it does not have rooms filled with antiquities. You can walk the ramparts, climb up to the towers, stroll along the walls. The views of the city are great. They have quite a few peacocks on the grounds who are not afraid of humans! Worth the visit.

Beautiful Castle and amazing views of Lisbon. Loved Castelo Sao Jorge, it is beautiful and the area surrounding it is as well. Definitely a must do in a visit to Lisbon. We walked there from Baixa/Chiado neighborhood, it is a hike but a beautiful one. We're fit in our late 20's so it wasn't hard; however, you might not want to walk there if you are not in shape or not in good health.Lovely place, don't miss it!
Astonishing view of Lisbon. Astonishing view of Lisbon. A must see in Lisbon. Rember the discount cupom from the sightseen company

nice view , shame about the price. The castle is one of the main attractions of Lisbon BUT it doesn't justify the £17 entrance fee. We went on our sixth day in Lisbon in the afternoon. The sun was shining, the views are fantastic, but there was little to do except take photos and walk the battlements.Try a trip to Cascais instead... Its' wonderful. Costs £1.50 single on the train and its like Whitby with sun. A smart harbour, good shops, restaurants and great beaches. It costs a little more than in Lisbon but we loved it so much we went twice. Cascais triumphs over the castle any day.Peter

Nothing Special. We came here because it is regarded as one of the top things to do in Lisbon according to alot of travel books. There really isn't much to do here other enjoy the nice views of the city.It's also confusing to get in as you buy your tickets and enter in different places. We were probably in and out in 20 minutes and we saw enough.It's more impressive to see the to see the castle from the city than to actually go to it.

One of the best views in Lisbon. When you get inside the castle you can feel how old it is. But when you are at the top it is even better. You get to see a great view of lisbon. Not only Lisbon but thee ocean too. There are also some souvenir shops so you can buy something to always remember your experience. Oh and 2 other things:you have to walk up steep hils, and there are lots of cats there.

Enter the castle only if you enjoy exploring castle ruins. Instead of a arduous climb up to the Castle, take Tram 28 (heading East) from Rua da Conceicao and alight at the Santa Luzia stop. Alternatively, one could alight in front of the Cathedral (Se) and do a short walk up to the miradouro. In this manner, you can save your energy for the short climb to the castle gate. One can explore the Alfama neighborhood on the way downhill. Be warned that the path to the Castle can be hard to figure out as the signs to the narrow winding streets can be misleading. The castle ruins itself does not offer much to look at. Also, the site is not well sign-posted with information or maps. There are however good views over Lisbon from the castle ramparts, e.g. one could even see Praca do Commercio. Enter the castle only if you enjoy exploring castle ruins otherwise there are other free miradouros (e.g. Miradouro de Santa Luzia located a little downhill from the castle) which offer views of Lisbon that are almost as good.

Stunning views over Lisbon!. Take the famous Tram 28, get out at the Cathedral (Se) and walk the rest of the way up to the Castle. There are various look out points along the way. Be care full of speeding cars in the road as the pavements are very narrow in some parts and you often need to step of the curb. The Castle itself is defiantly worth seeing. Entrance 5 euros per adult. Amazing views all along from the castle walls over Lisbon. Enjoy and relax in the gardens with an ice cream as they provide shade from the heat in mid-summer and see if you can spot the pea cocks.I do not recommend climbing the steps up towards the tower if you are getting on in years. My thighs were quiet sore afterwards and all I could think of was that both our sets of parents would not have been able to climb the often uneven terrain. Wear good walking shoes, sun screen and a hat if you visit in summer. Wonder around the neighbourhood when you leave the site. It is charming to see the streets and buildings. Be very careful of the restaurants outside the Castle as they are waiting for tired and hot tourists to lure into their establishments. Avoid at all costs and rather walk down further from the attraction. Better food and value for money.Thoroughly enjoy the excursion to Castelo de Sao Jorge!

One of the best views I had of Lisbon!. If the Castelo by itself doesn't have much to offer (one tower here, another there...), the panoramic view you get when entering is just breathtaking. The general atmosphere in the little surrounding garden is also a haven of peace (or so I found). With the sun playing in the leaves of the big trees, the birds singing around and the peacocks showing off to their females, it was just brilliant!I arrived just a bit after opening time so didn't even have to queue at all.I felt so good up there that I had to force myself to leave (yes, there are other things to see in Lisbon). I only wish they would allow you to use the same ticket to go back later the same day as I would have loved to see the sunset from up there!

São Jorge never disappoints. I don't remember paying to go into the castle before, but with two adults and a child, we got a discounted family pass for 3.50 euros, which wasn't bad. They have made some improvements in the past 20 years and it's worth the trip and the money. The views of Lisbon are spectacular and on a nice sunny day everyone should try it out. The castle isn't great, but go there for the view and the experience.

Spectacular views of Lisbon!!. The Castelo really does provide some of the best views of Lisbon from the Esplanade, definitely beating the sight from the top of the Elevador de Santa Justa. Climbing the ramparts and towers are another highlight.I absolutely agree with the last reviewer on both points made - the site is not disabled access friendly, and I would not advise a visit to the Castelo for those with mobility issues, there are limited ramps, and only the Esplanade would be accessible to those with wheelchairs. The ramparts can only be reached via steep and narrow stairs, which can be especially precarious to climb when wet.Also, the site is not particularly well sign-posted with information about what you might be viewing, and a castle map is not offered either freely or for sale at the ticket office which was a disappointing surprise!! No audio guides here, either.Other thoughts... The on-site cafe-restaurant serves hot food as well as snacks, reasonably priced, but nothing special. There is also a well stocked and inexpensive souvenir shop offering higher quality, quirky, modern and well-designed items which you cannot find in other gift stores in the neighbourhood.I would recommend combining a trip to the Castelo with a wander around the adjacent area of Alfama - colourful and labyrinthine it provides a glimpse of 'local life' and also has some hidden gems for places to eat!

Great view shame about the lack of information. I was really looking forward to going to the Castelo and the views from the ramparts were not disappointing. However, the information about the Castelo and the surrounding area was minimal. I thought the access for disabled people or people with wheelchairs or buggies was poor. I asked at the ticket desk if there was a tour, which I was told there was and to register at the museum but there was no one at the museum to register with and at 10 minutes past the tour start time I finally tracked down a museum employee who told me that they only ran if there were 10 or more people. (In my head I am thinking, well if no one is there to register with and you are not advertising a tour then there are never going to be 10 people signed up to take the tour). We left after having a coffee, which was very reasonably priced given the tourist trap, but a little disappointed we couldn't get more out of our visit. It is a real shame the Lisbon tourist people can't get it together to organise even a self guided tour with those headset things as this could be one of the best tourist attractions if only a little more thought went in to what people might want to get out of a visit.

Feel the history - in Castelo de Sao Jorge. The Castelo de Sao Jorge is a castle in Alfama (Lisbon) which is integrated in the city. We visited the castle as a students group and we had about one hour to go around which is a little bit short because it is not a small castle.From the highest walls you have a brilliant view over nearly every part of Lisbon. Some places are without a balustrade and that might make you a little bit uneasy if you have to walk there.If you plan to visit the castle, take suncream, a camera (you wouldn't want to miss the view) and sturdy footwear! And take you're time!

Amazing views. We didn't pay any entrance fee on New Year's Day - Sat. Jan 1, 2011. We went there to explore the castle and watch the beautiful sunset. It was cold and windy but the views from up there are amazing and the hike that included steep hills and stairs was not bad, we're used to walking all over the cities we visit. There was a guy playing a guitar in the central square, I thought that was very nice. We spent about 2 hours here and this was one of my favorite stops during our holiday in Lisbon.

good view, absolutely not worth 7 euros. you pay 7 euros to get into the castle and the castle is just empty walls and shallow courtyards... nice the view but you can enyou it also form the nice miradouros ....

Fantastic Views. Started from the center of the city & tried to follow signs for St George Castle but halfway there the signs disappeared. We found our way on our own but it is definitely a major hike that included steep hills & stairs. Tram 28 is better suited for those who can't handle the exertion. Once you get inside the Castle walls though you can get great panoramic views of the city. The only downside is that as far as the castle is concerned though there isn't much to see except for some outer walls of a castle. You can climb the stairs in it to get even higher up for some views but that is all it is good for.

Glad I went but I'm not sure it was worth the entrance fee and hike. The castle sits on a hill overlooking Lisbon; I could see it from everywhere I went. But, when I tried to find it to visit it, I got hopelessly lost. Do not trust the signs that are posted around and just ask someone how to get there! When you enter the castle walls, there's a small community of homes and shops inside. I'm not sure how I would feel having tourists tromping through my backyard all day every day, so I left that area alone. The cost to enter is about $10 (or about 7 euro). The line was long but moved quickly and the folks selling tickets and souvenirs appear to speak every major European language as well as English. The castle isn't much to look at. You can walk along the walls (be careful -- an older woman came crashing down the stairs while I was there and was banged up pretty bad) and look out over the city, but that's about it. There was a man playing guitar in the central square area. If you wander away from the crowds, you'll find the archeological ruins dig area, where they are excavating some Moorish and Iron Age communities. I enjoyed the shaded castle grounds the most. It was a hot day and it was nice to enjoy a cold soda under a shade tree. Know that it's a good uphill climb to get to the castle entrance; if your feet can't take the cobblestones in Alfama, this climb won't feel too good and you may want to take a cab. There's a cafe there if you're hungry or need a drink. Not much for the kids to look at but it is a good view over the city.

Great view of the city. They offer a student discount (50% off regular admission price). It was fun to see and walk around but there's not too much to it. It gives you a nice view of the city and coastline for some pictures. It was hard to walk to, lots of steep hills and odd small streets, so those that aren't as adventurous may want to just take a taxi.

Great castle to explore, superb views. I read Trip Advisor reviews before going to Lisbon and only walked up to the castle as a matter of exploring in that direction. I was very surprised by how good it then was and was very happy that I did not miss it. I can see how people are expecting a castle to go into and see rooms, furniture, etc, but this is still far better then many ruins I have seen elsewhere.Although people recommend taking the Tram, it is an easy walk up several blocks from the city center. If you do this, do stop by the Se Cathedral. The castle was quite large with much to explore, we first walked around the outer terrace and easily made amazing pictures of the city - made great with a cannon or castle walls in the foreground. We then went into the inner castle courtyards and climbed the walls to get an amazing 360 degree walk around and views in every direction. My kids just loved exploring the castle and we only left after 1.5 hrs as it was closing early being December.On my list of things to do in Lisbon, this ended up being at the top of the must-see list.

Very Disappointing. I was realy disappointed at the castle in Lisbon. It is just a ruins of the remaining walls. Would definitely be too dangerous for children as there are alot of heights with no barriers. The views from the castle are good but once you see one view from there, the rest look the same. The walk up to the castle is pretty but steep - not wheelchair friendly. We went up to try and enter the castle to be turned around to go back and buy tickets at a little shop (you'd miss it only for the huge queues outside the door). I didn't see any attractions worth mentioing apart from the Panoramic camera viewing room which wasn't working although they were still allowing people in to sit in a dark room with the out of order piece of equipment. Also beware of a restaurant near the tram stop on the square under all the tress. We were overcharged on lunch for things like bread and olives which we didn't even get. I only discovered this when I got a portugese speaker to translate the bill afterwards.
Great views in Lisbon. Family ticket cost 5 Euro. Great views of Lisbon and great to stay and relax for a couple of hours. I suggest to walk down through Alfama. It's a good workout.

Go for the views. I read reviews and thought that there would be tons of cats and their caretaker...I also thought this was free. However they must have renovated it because it now costs 5 Euros a person, I only saw 3 stray cats and no cat caretaker at all. The views of the city are good, but other than that there isn't much else to see outside a half hour walking through the castle. However, if you take tram 28 up to the castle there are a lot of little shops and restaurants to check out.

Great views over Lisbon. Yes, most castles are just like another but you come here for the view over Lisbon! We took the Tram 28, got off at the cathedral stop in Alfama & walked up. The view from here gives you a good perspective of the city. On our walk down we spent more time in Alfama before returning on Tram 28 to downtown. Tram 28 is a great attraction just for it self! Since Alfama has many good Fado clubs, you can check some out & return in the evening like we did to enjoy one. You can take the blue metro line to St Apolonia and walk over to Alfama in the evening.

Incredible views and a fun workout.. The castle is not very close to a metro stop. The hike there would have been easy had it not been at some steep inclines. I was so happy we went in the later afternoon, so it was not so hot.The castle itself offers amazing views of the city and great pictures. There was a man playing guitar in the middle courtyard, making a wonderful ambiance around the towers' lookout points. Tired tourists were sleeping in the grass, old men were playing cards around stone tables, and there were cafés inside the castle grounds.I was dissapointed that there was not much to explain the history of the place- just a sign at the beginninng. Lots of stairs and the trek up to the castle insured that I was sore the next day, but it was a wonderful way to see the city and a fun walk. On the way to the castle, we passed a small place to eat that was real gem: creative munu, fresh ingrdients, freshly made papaya juice. It was across from an outdoor bar by a huge patio with couches overlooking the city.

Try the pastry.... It's true there isn't much to do, but the views are very beautiful and this is especially relaxing and a great place to meditate and chill out.Lisbon is known for their pasteis de nata (custard cups). I had some of my best at the castle. It's worth trying one!Just one tip: Parking is not easy to find. We parked in a nearby garage.

I loved it. I don't know why some people are complaining. It's a medieval castle, obviously there isn't going to be much to see of the castle itself in terms of decorations or furnishings!! It's a castle, not a palace... there's a difference. I loved the history and the spectacular view of Lisbon, it's breathtaking! Looking at those olive trees around the castle that are probably 1000's of years old is incredible. Also you can go up the steps to the castle to get an even better view... it's huge so there's lots to look at. Next time I go back to Lisbon I will definitely be returning to Castelo São Jorge. Definitely worth visiting at least once, even if it's just for the history alone that you don't get in North America.

Good castle, great views. There is little to actually see in the castle, but the views and possible photo opportunities of the city are unparalleled. You can walk all the walls and climb the towers, with nary a guardrail in sight - which makes it a lot of fun for castle-lovers. Non-castle buffs can stroll the lower levels but there isn't a lot to see of the castle itself.Don't miss the weird mirror-ball-video inside one part of the castle near the cafe! I've never seen anything like it!It was 5 euros well-spent, and took just over an hour to see every nook and cranny.

Nice boutique hotel if you don't get the small rooms without views. My partner and I stayed at Castelo de Sao Jorge for 3 nights in July 2007. We booked it through Tablet hotels and having used the website before to book many other great hotels was expecting this to be pretty good.The staff were lovely and freindly and went out of their way to suggest local acitivites and good nearby restaurants. The common facilities - i.e the outdood courtyard, the rec room and honesty bar are all fab. We were less than impressed by our bedroom which was tiny, without natural sunlight and located under a stairwell. We asked to be moved but seeing as the hotel was fully booked the only other hotel we were offered was directly above the one we had and was the same size and located on the stairwell.We managed to see into some of the other rooms which looked great but you should really make sure that you get a room facing onto the coutryard so that you have more light and a nicer view.

Rip-off. I wish I had read the reviews here in advance. This castle is a ripoff. Its only value is the view, and like others have said, you can get great views from other locations for free. Example, go to the top of the VIP Eden hotel!In addition, the day we visited there, the winds were outrageous and we were all sandblasted. I spend the rest of day with one irritated eyeball.

Waste of time and money.. It's difficult to understand why a structure such as a castle should be patched up using concrete blocks and cement render . . quite apalling. We found it ironically amusing though, the render is coming off in chunks, clearly ancient building methods remain superior!Whether we were just unlucky or whether the people running the castle really do have absolutely no taste I don't know. When we visited (13th May) there was an awful kind of flea market/fete thing going on, there were 'tents' everywhere selling all manner of tat. Music varying from reggae to shrill female vocalist was booming from various directions. It was a real cheek to charge an entry fee. We just took our pictures of the Lisbon views and left!There are equally good views of Lisbon to be had if you walk around the backstreets, it's cheaper and more authentic!

Go to Obidos instead. The Castelo's a big fraud. It's a relatively modern reconstruction of the medieval structure, and there's really not much to see aside from the views. There is an admission fee to see the castle, but what they don't tell you is that there isn't really much more than the walls. The castle is empty inside. The signs say there are several attractions, exhibits etc. but when we went all but one was closed for repairs, and the remaining one (a camera obscura that projects the city view on the walls inside one of the castle rooms) required visitors to sign up for entry, but it was unclear just where you do that. We were given no indication that the few attractions that existed were closed, and the office merrily charged us full price. The most interesting thing in the castle was a slightly cracked Brit dressed in a tunic playing folk songs on a recorder. Wandering through the area, you'll see an unusual number of feral cats prowling around - turns out there are about 30 of them, and they all belong to this guy. The music added a certain amount of ambience to the barren castle, as did the cats. Other than that it was kind of a waste of time.Earlier in our trip we had gone to Obidos, a real medieval town with no admission fee and much more to see. Like Castelo Sao Jorge, you can climb up to the walls and walk the perimeter, but the stunning views are of rolling countryside, and within the walls there's a living city. Granted, most of the restaurants and businesses thrive on tourist dollars, but overall it was a much nicer experience.

Disappointing!. I was really disappointed with the castle. I noticed on the way up that the guidebook refers to the castle as medieval, only "medieval" is in quotes. That's right, it's reconstructed "medieval." That's ok - except no where can you tell what was reconstructed and what is original. There are also no signs or anything that give you any history about the castle, where you are standing, what different areas had been used for. I don't mean I couldn't read the signs, I mean there weren't any. The pamphlet is nothing more than a map, and a skimpy one at that. The views of the city were great, however, but otherwise, there was not much to hold interest. After a little while you're just like "yep, there's another wall." It's sad - it doesn't seem like it would take much effort to make the place a lot more interesting.

Great views. If you want great views of the city, then visit the castle. You get to see most of the city from the castle, which is high above the city centre, but still close to it. If you want to walk up to it, it will take a strenuous 30 minute walk from the city centre. You can't see the castle for most of the walks so get a good map to do this. We didn't have a map so just kept on walking upwards, we got there in the end but went the wrong way a couple of times.If you don't want to walk up it get Tram 28, from the city centre.

Portugal has the best castles--Castelo Sao Jorge. I never would have thought it, and I've been to a lot of the most well-known castle countries, but Portugal has amazing castles! Castelo Sao Jorge in Lisbon is no exception.It's clean, well-maintained, full of history, offers breathtaking views of the city and the river, and it's pretty easy to get to. At first I was dismayed because there's not a subway stop nearby, but it really isn't a very long walk from the closest stop. It's right off the Alfama district, which is not conducive to tunneling. You'll want to walk around the Alfama anyway, so the Castelo is a great addition to your day.There was a small entry fee, which was well-worth it considering how well-maintained the place was. Be sure to check out the camera obscura (a small, dark room where a hole in the ceiling projects a live image of the city onto a big dish). I think they give the presentations in both Portuguese and English. I ended up in a Portuguese one, and even though I don't understand Portuguese very well, it was still worth it.Highly recommended!

Take the tram or a taxi.... Ok, first thing to be sure you know is that the tour guide you might have will tell you "we have to walk to the top because the bus can't go to the top" to get to the castle. Well, yes, it is true that a large tour bus cannot navigate the narrow streets to the top, but it is literally a 15 - 25 minute walk straight uphill on uneven cobbled street (many of which need to be repaired and make for treacherous footing)....but after we struggled to the top to see this castle, we saw a tram go by and lots of taxis. Do yourself a favor and take the tram or a cab to the top ...it will make your experience more enjoyable, especially if you are not in climbing shape, smoke, elderly, overweight...you get the picture. The view of Lisbon from this vantage point is spectacular, but not if you've been traumatized by the climb to get there!
